Obviously, Egon and Donatello have a lot in common, but it’s not like those two characters only talk with each other.The story itself is somewhat less interesting. Basically, a big bad ghost has been released and the Turtles and Ghostbusters have to stop him. It’s not particularly original and the villain is of the moustache-twirling variety. As an excuse to get the Ghostbusters and Turtles working together, it works. The team needs the skills of both the Turtles and the Ghostbusters to defeat the ghost, so it really does feel like a team effort. But the comic is ultimately more about the relationships between the Turtles and Ghostbusters than the story.The artwork is very effective. The art for humans in the Ghostbusters comics is more stylized than it is for the Turtles comics, but the two art styles blend together seamlessly here.Overall, this is a nice treat for fans of both the Ninja Turtles nor the Ghostbusters franchises.[I received a free advance copy of this book in exchange for an honest review]

I'd heard about The Last Starfighter for years, but always from people who claimed it merely copied Star Wars. During the 1980s, many studios tried to imitate the Star Wars phenomenon. Paramount pulled Star Trek out of mothballs so it could have its own sci-fi franchise. Universal's Battlestar Galactica was embroiled in lawsuits with 20th Century Fox over copyright infringement (not surprising given that Universal hired key members of the Star Wars production team). Dozens of other copycat space adventure films from that era have faded into obscurity.Indeed, the plot of The Last Starfighter does seem eerily similar to A New Hope:- Teenager with remarkable piloting skills can't go to college because of poverty and household chores;- Wizened mentor finds him and tries to recruit him to fight against an evil empire;- Teen initially refuses, but reconsiders when the empire threatens his family;- Mentor figure dies as teenage pilot flees with companions;- Teen pilot takes down evil empire's main ship with just his starfighter;- Movie ends with victory celebration.In addition, the production design is similar to the original Star Wars. The ships of the Rylan Star League have white interiors like the Rebel Alliance's capital ships. The Ko-Dan Armada has dark grey interiors like the Empire's Death Star. Rogan's starfighter has red lasers, like the X-Wings, and the Ko-Dan ships have green lasers, like the Tie Fighters.Despite the similarities, the film feels different from Star Wars. Or, at least it feels like it has a heart and soul of its own. I think it's partly the context. The Last Starfighter doesn't take place "A long time ago in a galaxy far, far away" but rather in a 1980s trailer park. Indeed, The Last Starfighter has a lot for fans of 1980s nostalgia. The film really captures what it was like to be a young sci-fi/video game fan during the 80s. Alex Rogen comes to the attention of the Rylan Star League because of his high score in an arcade game (I'm sure many of us wish our high scores had greater consequences). In A New Hope, Luke wanted an adventure; in The Last Starfighter, Rogan - like many kids - wanted to be Luke.The Last Starfighter is fun, but it lacks a rich ensemble of characters. The story is all about Rogan and his ability to shoot down enemy ships. The movie takes too long in showing Rogan's attempts to pilot the ship and fire the lasers (Star Wars smartly skipped over Luke's training). Rogan then proceeds to take down the entire Ko-Dan armada singlehandedly (the enemies make the Stormtroopers seem like crack shots). There's no sense that the victory was a team effort, or even that other pilots died on the mission with him (as during the Death Star trench run). The other characters seem to exist only to give Rogan moral and technical support rather than as a character in his own right.In 1984, The Last Starfighter was the first movie to use computer-generated effects to to depict realistic spaceships (TRON came out two years earlier, but it only used CGI to depict an abstract video game environment). The effects hold up surprisingly well, at least on my 17-inch computer screen. The film is pretty frugal with its effects and the camera doesn't linger too long on effects shots. The ships are definitely too shiny and clean, but they do look like spaceships.I recommend The Last Starfighter if you like space opera and want a 1980s nostalgia trip. The fact that it resembles A New Hope in so many ways yet feels different speaks to the diversity of stories that can be told within a single story archetype. The movie feels like an homage to the effect Star Wars had on a generation of kids, including yours truly.

I don’t usually read self-help books, but the title of “Should and Must” spoke to a personal dilemma I was having at the time it came out. To some extent, the book helped me clarify my thinking. It gave me encouragement for some of my decisions and forced me to reconsider others. To some extent, that’s probably the most important thing I can say in this review. Still, I had some other thoughts about the book after thinking about it for a while.For those who hadn’t read Elle’s essay, “The Crossroads of Should and Must” is about helping people overcome societal obligations and other barriers in order to achieve their passion. I don’t think the book breaks any new psychological ground, but what’s distinctive about it is the style. This isn’t a book filled with prose. Instead, it’s actually a piece of art. Every page has unique drawings, colorful script, markings, etc. It really drives home the optimistic message and definitely makes it more memorable.That said, the very design of the book tells you much about its intended audience – artists. Elle seems to be talking primarily to struggling artists. The examples she mentions are Picasso, Philip Glass, John Grisham, etc. Many of her ideas for finding your “must” involve paints, paper, etc. Computers are bad. If your “must” is to become a doctor, a president, etc., you’ll probably find that this book doesn’t speak to you as much. For me, I was looking at a writing career, so I probably fell within the target audience, but barely.I was also a bit surprised that, aside from the author’s own story, all of the examples in the book were of famous people. I know for me that one of the most intimidating aspects of “getting to must” is the recognition that I’ll probably never measure up the greats in my calling. Why try if you can only pale in comparison? I know as an aspiring artist I wouldn’t want Picasso as a standard. Instead, I’d like to learn more about how ordinary people found their “must.” What does it mean to have found your calling but to not become a celebrity in your field? That’s much more relatable and in many ways manageable.Quibbles aside, this book did help me. I’m going to take some of its advice to heart and hopefully start finding my calling. I don’t know if it’ll work, but I can recommend this as a short, easy read that might change your life.

Ever wonder why Gandalf chose Bilbo to join Thorin's quest in The Hobbit? Or what Aragorn was talking about when he mentioned the "Kings of Númenor"?The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings frequently mention events or characters from earlier periods of Middle-earth history. It turns out that those references actually referred to stories J.R.R. Tolkien had written but not published. In 1977, his son Christopher Tolkien published The Silmarillion, a collection of tales set during the First and Second Ages. However, Tolkien wrote many versions of these stories, some longer and more detailed than what appeared in The Silmarillion. To appreciate the full scope of Tolkien's subcreation, we need to look at his rough drafts as collected in Unfinished Tales of Númenor and Middle-earth.To call the Unfinished Tales a collection of rough drafts is misleading. Tolkien's rough drafts are more polished and engaging than the final works of most fantasy authors. Nevertheless, the stories in this volume were never completed, much less publishable. Christopher Tolkien provides helpful commentary situating these stories within Tolkien's legendarium. The stories provide some fascinating background material, but it's important for readers to realize that not all of these stories fit comfortably within the Middle-earth canon. Some details contradict Tolkien's published works. As such, the best way to appreciate the Unfinished Tales is to view it as an exploration of Tolkien's storytelling.The section on the First Age contains the stories of Tuor and Túrin. Tuor is a human tasked with delivering a message to the Elven King Turgon of Gondolin. The story in Unfinished Tales primarily covers Tuor's journey to Gondolin. Tolkien is a master at describing geography and conveying the arduous nature of travel in a premodern setting. He never completed this more detailed version, which is a shame because the fall of Gondolin is one of the most epic battles in Tolkien's works. Morgoth, the dark lord of the First Age, had multiple dragons and Balrogs in his army!The "The Children of Húrin" story is one of my favorites not just in this book, but in all of Tolkien's works. Morgoth curses Húrin's family, including his son Túrin. Túrin finds himself in a Shakespearean struggle against fate. Yet, in Tolkien's world, men have free will, so the story sets up a subtle tension between Túrin's doom and Túrin's choices. In addition, the story has dragons, incest, brigands, and even talking swords. Although the Unfinished Tales version of the story is not complete, it provides much more detail than the Silmarillion version. Fortunately, Christopher Tolkien adapted this version into a complete novel in 2007, so I would recommend readers read The Children of Húrin to get the best experience.The Second Age focuses on the Kingdom of Númenor. The Silmarillion contains more information about the fall of Númenor, a story that echoes the myth of Atlantis. Unfinished Tales focuses on the earlier kings. "Aldarion and Erendis" is an fascinating romance, especially compared to Tolkien's more famous Beren and Lúthien story. Aldarion, heir to the Númenórean throne, falls in love with Erendis. However, Aldarion also loves the sea and sailing. Naturally, this creates tension in their marriage. This is the only love story I can recall that does not follow the pattern of Beren and Lúthien, and indeed almost comes across as the polar opposite of their relationship. Aldarion serves as yet another example that not all of Tolkien's heros are idealized archetypes.There have never been - and likely will never be - any authorized film adaptations of these stories. However, artists have been depicting these stories for decades. In particular, I recommend Ted Nasmith's portfolio, which was featured in the companion book Tolkien's World and influenced my images of the characters and landscapes.The Slaying of Glaurung, by Ted NasmithThe Third Age will probably be of most interest to fans of The Lord of the Rings. It explains the fate of Isildur, last king of Gondor, and origins of Kingdom of Rohan. Perhaps the most fascinating part is "The Quest of Erebor," essentially an attempt to retcon The Hobbit with LOTR. As written, the former book is simply a light-hearted adventure story, whereas the latter is a serious epic. The two stories don't always fit seamlessly. Why, for example, did Gandalf waste his time with Thorin's quest for gold when he was also concerned with Sauron's return to power? In "The Quest of Erebor," Gandalf explains that he wanted to prevent Smaug from allying with Sauron and attacking Rivendell. Thus, he used the Dwarves to strike a covert blow against the enemy.Like many fans of The Hobbit, I have mixed feelings about "The Quest of Erebor." It has a tendency to minimize the joy and serendipity in Bilbo's journey as told in the original novel. I'm not quite convinced that Gandalf was really that foresighted, especially as in The Hobbit he doesn't appear to connect Thorin's quest with the larger struggle against Sauron. However, Peter Jackson apparently saw this story as a missing link between the two stories and used it to bridge his Hobbit and LOTR trilogies. The Hobbit films are heavily influenced by Gandalf's account and reflect the tone of this version more than anything found in the book. Indeed, one of the tracks on the Desolation of Smaug soundtrack is titled "The Quest for Erebor."The final section of Unfinished Tales contains a mix of background material on the wizards and palantír, among other things. The section on wizards is particularly interesting. Not only do we learn more about Radagast, we also learn more about Saruman's fall. Again, parts of it contradict Tolkien's published works, as well as his later letters (for example, Tolkien later concluded that perhaps Radagast hadn't quite failed in his mission).Unfinished Tales isn't for casual Tolkien fans. Nevertheless, it provides fascinating insight into the Middle-earth subcreation and shows why Tolkien was such a master at fantasy literature.Next week, I cover The Book of Lost Tales, Part I, which includes more of Tolkien's early writing.

Ursula K. Le Guin has said several times that she’s done with Earthsea, but she keeps returning to the archipelago. In Daughter of Odren, Weed, the titular daughter of Odren, wants to rescue her father from the spell of a corrupt wizard and her mother. In the hands of any other author, the plot itself would have been a simple revenge tale. Le Guin takes this simple concept in a darker and far more interesting direction.The Daughter of Odren is more about the telling than about the tale. Le Guin buries the story under multiple layers, as characters tell other characters what they know about Odren’s fate. At times, the accounts conflict subtly. It’s an interesting narrative technique as it gives the sense that the events we see had already become local legend. It’s also an effective way to convey the large amount of background material necessary to understand the plot.The Daughter of Odren is set in the world of Earthsea, but does not feature any of the major characters from Le Guin's other Earthsea novels. However, the story does assume some familiarity with the Earthsea system of magic, so it does not stand entirely on its own. I suggest reading at least A Wizard of Earthsea before attempting this novel.Daughter of Odren a worthy trip back to Earthsea. It doesn’t have a major impact on the Earthsea mythos, and it’s a short story (about 31 pages), but nevertheless enjoyable.

As I write this, there are several trending news items on Facebook about nude celebrities. That seems fitting given the sorts of questions Ursula K. Le Guin asks in The Left Hand of Darkness. What would human society look like without gender? How would love and politics differ if we were neither male or female? Gender is such a critical part of our identity that this thought exercise turns out to be incredibly difficult. Almost all human stories have some element of romance, or at least sexual tension.In The Left Hand of Darkness, Le Guin introduces us to a society world known as Gethen. ("Winter" in English) on which descendants of humans possess elements of both genders. The beings are asexual but during a mating season - known as kemmer - one gender dominates the other to allow for reproduction.The book starts when an envoy from an interplanetary consortium, the Ekumen, finds himself in trouble with political authorities in the kingdom of Karhide on Gethen. The envoy, Genly Ai, is definitely a male and the only male on the planet. Meanwhile, the prime minister of Karhide, Estraven, is exiled for his relationship to Genly Ai and his efforts to convince Karhide to join the Ekumen.Over the past two weeks, I reviewed two of Arthur C. Clarke's books, Childhood's End and Rendezvous with Rama. As an author, Le Guin is in many ways the polar opposite of Clarke. Where Clarke focuses on hard science fiction themes, such as aliens and technology, Le Guin uses science fiction as a setting for human analysis of the human condition.The Left Hand of Darkness excels in its depiction of characters. The book focuses on the convoluted relationship between Genly and Estraven. To describe it as a love-hate relationship would be too simple. The relationship transverses a range of human emotions, mostly platonic but at times even slightly sexual. Odd as it might be to say, there is a beauty to their suffering and the raw emotional intensity of the story.The book remains relevant over 45 years after it was first published because it touches upon such important questions about humanity. I don't believe Le Guin intended the book to be a direct metaphor for homosexuality, much less a call for homosexual, but given the political debates about gay marriage modern readers will probably make that connection. And they would be right to do so. Le Guin's complicated depiction of asexual romance might just help some readers to appreciate that love can transcend genders.Unfortunately, the book falters where Clarke so often succeeds. Le Guin does not provide much in the way of context for The Left Hand of Darkness. Although we learn a lot about the planet Gethen, its people, and culture, we learn almost nothing about the Ekumen or Genly's own culture. Technically, The Left Hand of Darkness is the fourth book in Le Guin's "Hainish" series, but in her introduction to the novel, Le Guin claims that The Left Hand of Darkness can be read alone. Perhaps not.Another - admittedly smaller - problem is that the point of view changes several times without warning. The book is told from a first-person perspective, but from both Genly Ai and Estraven's points of view. I only discovered this when in one of the earlier chapters the narrator refers to Genly as "he." I get the sense that some other readers have found this confusing. Once you realize the problem, it's not too difficult figure out who is narrating in each section, but Le Guin could have avoided much confusion by simply adding a note in the chapter headings.The Left Hand of Darkness definitely earns its place as a science-fiction classic. It definitely made me consider - or reconsider - my conceptions of gender and humanity. The book could have benefitted from some more context, as well as a longer denouement. But I always take it as a good sign when I want to learn more about an author's story.

Rendezvous with Rama is widely acclaimed as Arthur C. Clarke's best book, and it definitely deserves much of the praise it's gotten. That said, the book isn't perfect, particularly when it comes to the characters.Rendezvous with Rama starts when an large, cylindrical object is detected hurtling towards the sun. The object is named "Rama" after the Hindu god. The United Planets sends the solar survey vessel Endeavour under the command of Commander Bill Norton to investigate. The rest of the book focuses on the crew's exploration of the alien artifact.Rama is excellent at evoking a sense of wonder. Clarke manages to convey the artifact's grandeur and to create a uniquely bizarre alien world. The structures and other things encountered do not resemble the familiar sci-fi tropes. I especially liked how Clarke takes advantage of Rama's artificial gravity (generated by the object's spin) to present the astronauts with a new challenge. Even more than the alien structures, I'll always remember the description of Commander Norton climbing "down" the ladder towards Rama's "ground."That said, Clarke demonstrates an admirable amount of discipline in not revealing everything about Rama. Some mysteries remain unanswered, and are thus all the more intriguing. I can only imagine that, when the book was first published in 1973, the effect was even greater and there were fewer books about alien worlds. I haven't read the sequels, but fear they would undermine the majesty of this book.Clarke has always focused more on alien life and technology than on characters in his stories. That said, the characters in Rama are surprisingly serviceable, if not great. Commander Norton gets enough backstory to make him relatable. Norton's interest in and admiration for James Cook, captain of an earlier Endeavour, gave him some depth. For those who know their history, it also infused the story with some foreshadowing over Norton's fate.Most of the crew members at least get a few personality quirks that help distinguish them, although few are actually memorable. The lack of characterization generally works - until it doesn't. At a few points, the book places some of these characters in danger and the reader is expected to care, but I found it hard to do so. For example, two-thirds into the book, a character whom we'd never seen before, Jimmy, suddenly appears, and then the next 15% of the book focuses on him and his trials. At the least the character would have benefitted from some sort of introduction.I've criticized Clarke's problems ending some of his stories in a satisfactory manner, especially his tendency to rely upon incongruous twists or cheats to resolve plot threads (see, for example, my review of Clarke's Childhood's End). Fortunately, Rama avoids this problem. The story ends in a manner that suits the mystery and grandeur of Rama. There is a twist at the end, but it manages to be both subtle and thought-provoking at the same time. I could see how readers demanded a sequel, but the book was designed to - and mostly manages to - stand on its own. Rendezvous for Rama isn't for anybody. This book is about exploration writ large, about drive to explore rather than the discoveries. If you want a fully realized alien civilization, this isn't the book for you. However, if you want a somewhat realistic account of how man's first contact with alien technology might occur, Rama is still a classic.

This book is frustrating. The story has several great twists, even brilliant, but it's sloppily executed and the ending veers into paranormal mysticism rather than science fiction. Too often, the story drops the really interesting ideas it raises in favor of some of the sillier concepts. I can't really discuss the problems with this book without SPOILERS, so be warned that there are spoilers throughout!The story begins rather quickly as a mysterious alien race comes to Earth and... helps mankind create a utopia! Even today, most stories about aliens are either about alien invasions or first contact. But "Childhood's End" presents a race of benevolent aliens actually helping mankind. Initially, the struggle becomes getting mankind to accept and trust their new "overlords." A group of humans resists the aliens and promises mass resistance. Great twist, right?Unfortunately, Clarke drops the part about human resistance to the aliens less than a quarter of the way through the book. Some of the great characters in the human resistance movement are suddenly abandoned as Clarke jumps 50 years into the future and abandons that plot thread. At this point in the story, all humans have magically accepted the aliens and everything is unrealistically utopian.Clarke tends to "tell" rather than "show" these developments. Clarke gives the reader large chunks of narrative text describing the utopia, but the actual characters and their own stories seem to have little to do with that utopia. I almost got the sense that Clark was writing a short essay about his vision of utopia rather than telling a story.The book still had potential because the aliens promised to reveal themselves after 50 years. This promised new opportunities for conflict and tension. The reveal itself is well handled as we learn - SPOILER - the overlords resemble devils. Imagine aliens coming to Earth and finding out that they all look like Satan!Again, great twist, but another lost opportunity. Apparently, humans had evolved sufficiently by this point to not care that the aliens looked like devils. So the whole mystery of what these aliens look like, a huge part of the first third of the book, really does nothing for the story. The characters only seem mildly perturbed. Why the buildup if no payoff?Finally, the ending of the book was horrible. It turns out that the reason the overlords came to Earth and helped mankind was... because humans have some sort of weird paranormal telepathic power that needed to be cultivated. A new generation of humans become godlike creatures. These new creatures have no personality and just seem to do randomly destructive things. We only get a brief glimpse of how regular humans react, but Clarke again tends to tell rather than show these developments.At this point, I had to wonder why Clarke brought the story to this resolution. What sort of scientific or human themes did this ending explore? Science fiction aficionados often praise Clarke for writing "hard sci-fi," but this ending seemed more like magic than science. At least with something like the Force in "Star Wars" the mystical aspects help illuminate facets of the human condition and religion.I understand this is one of Clarke's earlier works and so I'm inclined to forgive him and not swear off any of his other books. Still, it seems like a missed opportunity. I'd love to see another author pick up on some of these ideas and do them justice.

I have a lot of friends who absolutely adored this book. I finally tried it and, well, I like it a lot, even if I'm not about to adopt a pet rabbit.As the product summary states, this is a story about a group of rabbits trying to reach the safety Watership Down and fighting off the enemy Efrafan rabbit clans. Richard Adams does an amazing job bringing this admittedly odd concept to life. For the most parts, the rabbits do feel and act like real rabbits. I could almost believe that the rabbits in my backyard could be undergoing their own such dramas.The characterizations in the book were all excellent. I loved how the characters had such deep and complex emotions, yet emotions believable in the animal world. The villains were driven by insecurity in a world filled with predators and other threats. This theme is played out in the rabbit religion, which promises that although rabbits are weak they will have a fair shot at survival. The protagonist rabbits develop over the course of the book, but the development is subtle as they find the best way to utilize their unique skills to overcome insecurity.Adams' use of parallelism is the best I've seen since Tolkien's "Lord of the Rings." Adams creates several rabbit societies and establishes clear points of comparison. The book doesn't just present the rabbit clans as good or evil. Rather, each clan has developed unique responses to the problem of insecurity. The Watership Down, the primary protagonists, clan cultivates individualism and encourages each individual rabbit to contribute his or her own skills to the greater good. In the Warren of Snares, another smaller rabbit clan, the rabbits passively accept the risk of being trapped by snares. The Efrafans, the primary antagonists, created a militaristic society to fight off predators.At times, the rabbits did seem a bit too intelligent, which took me out of the story. For example, the rabbits seem familiar with the concept of machines and tool use, particularly cars, which seems a bit too far. After all, if they were aware of the possibility of tools, why not try to build their own? Lacking opposable thumbs doesn't seem sufficient as an explanation. It's a small nitpick, but it broke the otherwise excellent illusion that these were real and realistic rabbits.Definitely recommended for fans of good literature - and rabbits.

As a big fan of James Luceno’s “Darth Plagueis,” I was excited to hear that Grand Moff Wilhuff Tarkin would be getting the Luceno treatment. Unfortunately, “Tarkin” isn’t quite the equal of “Darth Plagueis” in that it doesn’t provide a sweeping backstory for Tarkin. It’s more a story in which Tarkin is the central protagonist. However, we do get some great background information about Tarkin, especially about his upbringing on Eriadu. And there are some wonderful treats for fans of the old EU.*** MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD***The novel takes place about 5 years after “Revenge of the Sith.” Wilhuff Tarkin is in command of a base overseeing the construction of the Death Star. The Empire is busy hunting down former Separatists and others who oppose Palpatine’s New Order. The story starts with an unexpected attack on Tarkin’s base by a group of dissidents using advanced Holonet technology. The Emperor sends Tarkin and Darth Vader on a mission to track them down, but they in turn fall into a trap. The dissidents end up stealing Tarkin’s ship and attacking Imperial targets.This is a novel in which the context is more interesting than the text. The actual story isn’t particularly interesting or epic. Vader and Tarkin track down a bunch of dissidents who steal Tarkin’s corvette and go on a joyride. It almost seems like a task below these two iconic villains, if not for Tarkin’s personal connection to the ship and the dissidents. Nor does Tarkin rise to the occasion to display any particularly formidable investigative or tactical skills during his mission. I had been hoping to see Tarkin emerge as a larger than life character akin to Grand Admiral Thrawn in Timothy Zahn’s novels. Instead, he seems mostly along for the ride.A big part of the problem is that Tarkin’s adversaries don’t provide much of a foil. The dissidents aren’t particularly interesting characters. Even though the book spends quite a bit of time with them, I felt like I never really got to know them and had trouble telling them apart. Their motives were pretty basic. I think Star Wars characters work best when they’re based on bold archetypes (i.e., “the smuggler,” “the princess,” etc.), but the dissidents were mostly low-key individuals who had similar motives. A great hero needs a great villain – or, in this case, a great villain needs a great hero – but Tarkin just didn’t have a worthy adversary in this novel.That said, there is still much to enjoy in this book. Luceno takes the opportunity to delve into Tarkin’s upbringing on the planet Eriadu. Luceno portrays the Tarkin family as akin to early Australians or Afrikaners, whites who colonize a new land and develop a healthy respect for it, but also take great pride in taming nature. Eriadu itself has a sort of outback feel. Many of the scenes on Eriadu show Tarkin struggling against nature, but not outright destroying it. Instead, he learns how to tame nature through fear and manipulation. Thematically, it’s a nice echo of the “man versus nature” themes in “A New Hope.” I probably would have enjoyed the novel even more had it spent more time in this period of Tarkin’s life.“Tarkin” also answers a few questions fans have long had about the character. For example, we finally learn if and to what extent Tarkin knows Darth Vader’s true identity. We also learn – much to my shock – Palpatine’s first name. For fans of politics, we get to see the Imperial Ruling Council in action during this era for the first time. However, as with much of the Prequel-era of Star Wars, sometimes the fan service goes too far. We see familiar characters like Admiral Motti, Colonel Yularen, etc., but they hold the same exact rank that they do in “A New Hope.” It is simply not plausible that they would hold the same rank for over 15 years, especially for Motti, whose character in “A New Hope” was relatively young (the actor was only 30 at the time of filming).For Star Wars fans disappointed by Disney’s relaunch of the EU, Luceno goes out of his way to bring some of the stories from his previous novels into continuity. I won’t give any spoilers, but let’s just say that we see a few old EU characters reemerge in this novel. They’re not the focus of the story, but it’s a nice signal to fans that some of those stories and characters live on in the new continuity.As I said above, “Tarkin” is not nearly the equal of “Darth Plagueis.” There story isn’t particularly epic. That said, I did enjoy it, both as an adventure tale and for what we learn about Tarkin himself. I would definitely recommend the novel to Star Wars fans, but temper your expectations.Overall: 3 stars.[I received an advance version of this book from the publisher in exchange for an honest review.]

I admit I haven't had a chance to use this in the wild yet. Hopefully soon. However, I did try it on to post the review. It fits very well over my face, which has always been a struggle in the past with snorkels and masks. I love the cover over the air tube. It opens and closes to allow air and cover the air hole to prevent water from going down. It's a simple yet effective design. Finally, including a net bag to hold and carry the snorkel is a small touch, but one I really like.

I'd actually been looking for a new dicer. This one does work a bit better than my older one, and is more compact and convenient, and has different speeds. But it's still not a fine dicer. With this device, I find less is more. Trying to chop fruits and veggies too finely will result in a slushy sludge. I'd recommend this if you want something that can give you moderately small chunks, but for very small pieces I'd recommend a manual dicer, something with a metal grill that you can use to chop fruits and veggies.

I've been a big fan of Foreman grills for years. This is definitely an improvement over the last one I had. One of the bigger challenges I've had is getting the right size. I used to have a 4-serving grill but it was just too large and heavy to store and take out frequently. My 2-serving grill was a bit too small if cooking for more than two people. This one though is a good balance. It's not too heavy nor too large. It has a good amount of surface area. I also love the removable racks. Finally, the black color allows it to fit in with most kitchen decors (unlike my older red grill, which really stuck out). Definitely recommended.

The thing that most surprised me about this toaster oven is how large it is. I probably should have realized it from the product descriptions, but I guess it didn't really strike me until I pulled it out of the box. You obviously need a lot of counter space, but it's definitely worth it. I've tested it on a range of items, from toast to pizza to meats, and it cooks them all well. Given the size, you can fit quite a bit into this. Definitely a great option for reheating things if you don't want to use your oven.

Upon finishing “Utrom Empire,” my first thought was: “Wow, I just read a comic book about a bunch of mutant brains.” My second thought was: “Wow, those brains had a more compelling character arc than many human characters in adult novels.”Yes, “Utrom Empire” is primarily about how Krang rises through the ranks and ultimately ends up on Earth. The story intercuts to the current IDW series (taking place around issue #29). We see Professor Honeycutt plot his escape from Burnow Island. The relationship between him, Baxter Stockman, and Krang becomes infinitely more complicated. It’s a great side story.But again I was struck at how well IDW has managed to develop Krang’s character. Watching the original cartoons in 1987, I’d never imagined that Krang would be anything more than a one-dimensional, brain tentacle-twirling villain. As it has with other characters, IDW decided to give him some more depth. In “Utrom Empire,” we see a Krang who also has realistic motivations, to save his people. He also finds himself at odds with his father, the ruler of the Utrom Empire. Talk about daddy issues! Through it all, one never gets the sense thatFor fans of IDW’s ongoing Ninja Turtles, “Utrom Empire” adds wonderful depth. However, I’d go so far as to say that this volume should appeal more generally to comic readers who appreciate a character story about villains. Highly recommended.[I received an advance version of this comic from the publisher in exchange for an honest review.]

This story starts off slow. It actually took me a while to figure out where Tim Siedell was going. But once the comic really reaches the heart of the story, it's definitely a tale worth reading.Despite its title, “Darth Vader and the Cry of Shadows” is actually told from the point of view of a Clone Trooper, Hock. The first issue or so seem to just recapitulate Hock’s background. It’s obvious some of these plot elements and characters will come back later in the comic, but it’s not yet clear why they’re so important. In short, this first third or so just seems like a major digression from a yet-to-be-revealed story.Then we get to the Battle of Ostor. This is where the real character development happens, for both Hock and Vader. And it happens beautifully. I won’t reveal much more for fear of revealing spoilers, but Hock really becomes a fully realized character. I loved the types of challenges he’s forced to confront. There are some great battle scenes, but I really enjoyed seeing him wrestle with tough moral decisions.Siedell also handles Vader beautifully. Darth Vader in this comic has a real presence. One of my problems with depictions of Vader in recent comics is that he just becomes an all-powerful, mindless killing machine able to take down Jedi (such as in the Purge comics). Not so here. Vader is menacing, but the comic does a great job building up that menace through dialogue, artwork, and mise en scene rather than by simply having Vader kill a bunch of people. More importantly, Siedell does a great job building up Vader through the reactions of his subordinates. I found this Vader far more terrifying than anything we saw in the films!Siedell and the artists also create some innovative scenes for the comic. In one scene, after Hock crashes, the page is simply white with snippets of dialogue indicating that he’d gone unconscious. There are some other wonderful fullpage spreads. I read a digital version a single page at a time, so when those pages came up they really had a large impact.Overall, despite the slow start, this is definitely one of the better Star Wars comics I’ve read in a long time. Definitely recommended.[I received an advance version of this comic from the publisher in exchange for an honest review.]

I admit, when I was younger I was a Nintendo fanboy. I remember hearing about Sega from my friends but not really getting the appeal. Some 20 years later, Blake Harris helps put a new spin on this chapter of my life as he shows what happened behind the scenes of the console wars that dominate my youth.What makes Harris' account unique is that it's not just a dry third-person narrative, but rather reconstructs dialogue between key players in the industry. At times, it almost feels like a novel. And this is one exciting story filled with confidence men, devious schemes, and sudden but inevitable betrayals. In addition to being entertained, I learned a lot about the marketing world.Ultimately, I think Harris nails the core of the Sega vs. Nintendo debate. Sega, led by marketing guru Tom Kalinske, focused on market and giving the Genesis a "cool" appeal, whereas Nintendo focused on quality and reaffirming its core market. I had intuitively understood this even as a kid.My one issue with the book is that it seems almost too centered on Tom Kalinske. It's almost as if he were the main protagonist of the "novel." I could tell that Kalinske was a or even the primary source of information for Harris. As president of Sega of America, Kalinske was certainly at the center of major developments. But I would have appreciated more insights into other players in the story. Also, Kalinske comes across sometimes as a bit too much of a "mary sue" (not Kalinske's fault for sure, just a consequence of Harris' way of telling the story). In fact, the most fascinating parts of the book were those focused on Nintendo.Overall, easily one of the best and most important books about this era of video gaming. Game on!

Like many other Deep Space Nine fans, I loved Andrew J. Robinson's portrayal of Garak. Robinson knows his character and it comes out in this book. "A Stitch in Time" is written like a set of letters from Garak to Dr. Bashir. We get to see Garak's rise through the Obsidian Order and fall from grace. Robinson also plays with Garak's psyche and is much willing to dig deep into a character than other Trek authors.The one issue I have with the book is that the ending is a bit open-ended. I won't spoil it here, but it seems like Garak is posed to assume a new role in Cardassian society, and it seems like there should have been additional chapters to explain that role, but the ending seems almost abrupt. In some ways, I thought the more open-ended ending on the TV show worked better because it represented the end of one part of Garak's life. This book goes a bit beyond the beginning of the next phase of his life, but we don't learn enough to know where everybody's favorite tailor is headed.Overall, a must-read for fans of DS9.

Finally had a chance to see this last week. This movie is a celebration of LEGO, but more importantly it's a celebration of fun. The comedy is extremely witty and even quirky. This isn't low-brow humor. As an adult, I probably appreciated the humor more than the kids with me because I got all the references.However, what makes this film a keeper is that it's actually a good story. It's not just a string of gags. The story has a lot of heart, about the ability of ordinary individuals to become something special. It reminds me of the best of the 80s movies with that theme. The ending... well, I won't spoil it, but it blew my mind. It was an awesome twist.I haven't laughed so much at a movie in ages. I haven't cried so much at a movie in ages. The LEGO Movie hit both emotional cues brilliantly.Highly recommended for kids of all ages.

Like others here, I had hoped this tape could be used for sealing packages. It sticks well enough, but I found I needed to use more tape to seal a package properly. The tape also has an odd smell from the adhesive used. Still, this is advertised as a security tape and I guess it works for that purpose. It's just that the purpose is much more limited than what would be appropriate for most customers.

I'm not much of a water snob, but I do notice a real difference in the quality of water from different sources. Of course, bottled water does taste better than my local tap water. No surprise there. What surprised me about Glaceau smartwater is just how good it tastes. There's a real clearness and cleanness to the water that is really refreshing. My only regret is that I only had one bottle before my wife and her friends drank the rest. Glaceau smartwater is a bit more expensive, but if I ever need bottled water again this will be at the top of my list.

Sorry, but somebody has to say it. It's absolutely outrageous that Paramount is double-dipping like this by holding back the Star Trek Into Darkness special features for this release. Many of us who bought the STID blu-ray last fall complained that the special features had been split up between different retailers (Best Buy, Target, Amazon, etc got different exclusives) and NO deleted scenes. As a reward for our loyalty in purchasing the blu-ray early we now get the opportunity to purchase the complete version almost a year later.To be clear, I do not mind studios releasing deluxe versions of a movie. It's great for fans of movies to have deluxe options. But I don't like the studio telling us that certain features are exclusive and then going back on that promise. Nor do I appreciate the studio not telling us that a version with the deleted scenes would be coming. For comparison, Peter Jackson has been very up front in telling fans that extended versions of the Lord of the Rings/Hobbit movies would be released and WHEN they would be released.I think it's important that movie consumers take a stand and tell Paramount that consumers will not stand for such practices. The best way to do that is to refuse to buy this set. If studios want us to buy blu-rays and not just stream movies, then treat us as premium customers rather than gullible suckers.UPDATE: There is a bit of good news. Apparently Paramount will offer a rebate for customers who had previously bought an earlier blu-ray version of STID. This is some consolation and makes the double-dip less problematic. Nevertheless, I think it is still important for consumers to send the right message.

This iPhone case snaps on pretty easily and looks pretty good on the phone. The light blue aesthetic is neither too masculine nor too feminine. It doesn't look as glossy as it appears in the photo. However, I personally prefer a soft, rubbery cover for my iPhone because I'm prone to drop it quite often. The rubber absorbs the impact a bit better (and the phone even bounces, which is always fun to watch). Unfortunately, with this type of hard case, the case is more likely to crack or get chipped. The front also isn't as protected. The edges of the case don't extend far beyond the front of the phone, so if you drop the phone face-down there's not much protecting it. I'm a bit too clumsy for this, but I gave it to one of my more careful family members for his 5c and he's enjoyed it.

As with Book 1, Book 2 of "The Left Hand of Destiny" is more like a Klingon space fantasy than your typical Star Trek book. Much of what I wrote in my review of Book 1 applies to Book 2. J.G. Hertzler and Jeffrey Lang do a great job telling the story. The writing is much better than your typical Star Trek novel. The characters feel real and given the time to really develop and breath.There are a few additional points I wanted to add about Book 2. First, the plotting is a bit less smooth. The first 20% or so essentially fills the reader in on essential background. It's not an exciting beginning, but as the middle of the two-book series it's OK and probably necessary. Then, the rest of the book focuses on various parts of the Battle of Boreth. At this point, there are elements in the story that seem a bit too "fantasy", including mystical warriors and a magical sword. It works in the overall story, but again feels more like Klingon opera than Trek.As the conclusion to the series, some characters die. I was shocked to see which die. The book treated each of these deaths respectfully. I found each major death moving, much more emotional than anything I'd read in other media tie-in novels. It's wonderful that the books set up these characters with such depth that I ended up caring about them, and even more so that the authors weren't afraid of killing them off without some Star Trek-style "reset button" that resurrected them (at one point, the authors even seem to poke fun at reset buttons).I think this novel concludes Martok's epic story in a very satisfactory manner. It's not perfect, but definitely recommended. Overall, 4.5 stars.

2:03 Mins This is just a quick video of my girlfriend using the brushes to paint my finger nails to demonstrate how these brushes can be used. This is good backing for the price. It filled up my small reel nicely and went on without a hitch. I bought it for my trout fishing reel and will be ordering some more for my steelhead setup soon. It seems to have good knot strength and I feel confident it will be able to handle the brutal runs that steelhead dish out. It also comes on a nice spool that I filled up with some 0x tippet for streamer fishing after I used the backing. Overall this is good stuff that serves it's purpose well.

This is a really cute little book about the Iron Golems from Minecraft. I've played Minecraft quite a bit myself and I know a lot about it. There's definitely an eye for detail in this book and it really grabs the attention of my cousin. He's 9 years old and he loves playing Minecraft himself so when he's not playing, he likes to read this book on his off time. It's really nice because he's pretty much learning while he's having fun which is really great!

I had already bought the ebook about the villager sheppard and my cousin had loved it but was left wanting more. I found this soon thereafter so I obviously had to get this for him. As I've said yet again, this will be a great book for any of the younger audience that love to play Minecraft. My cousin is absolutely addicted to it and he even loves reading these ebooks as well. It's an easy read and I've played/read this book myself and you can tell there are details from the game and the writer really knows how to grab your attention!

To be completely honest, I thought this would be a stupid little kid's book but I was wrong. I actually liked it quite a bit. I read it for my cousin, since he absolutely loves Minecraft in the first place, and he loved it. He was interested in the story the whole time even through some of the child drama that was in there! It has many of the components that Minecraft the game itself had and that helped a lot to keep him interested. I would recommend this book to whoever's child loves to play Minecraft even a little bit.

This coat is absolutely beautiful and it's really like the cut. I looked for a new jacket or trench coat to wear and found this trench coat. As you can see, design is unique and good for this weather. And thinking about buying this one for my brother too. I would definitely recommend this coat!

This lightbulb is fantastic! It will pretty much last forever and it's at a perfect dimness. It's not too bright it's not dark at all so it's so comfortable to use and it's perfect! It doesn't have the yellowish look that almost every other lightbulb has and just the fact that this will last so long baffles me!!! ANNNDDDD it uses less energy it's like the perfect combination.

Great HDMI cable, I see nothing wrong with it and it works perfectly fine. I also got 2 so I can give one to a friend and I could've even sold it off to someone else! It's very long so you won't have to worry about distance at all and it works great. Everything looks great, the graphics, my xbox one, and especially the look of my games!

Bought this as a gift for my sister who just is having twins and she liked it so much that she ended up buying the remaining two books in the series as well. In her own words - I wish I had bought these books sooner. The usp of this book is how the writers talks to the reader in a friendly voice and imparts advice just like a friendly doctor would. The last thing you want in such books is usage of big words and long drawn out text. The book carefully avoids those and sticks to being a highly informational source. My sister loves it certainly feels more confident about dealing with twins now that she is armed with all this knowledge. 5 stars from her for this book.

I purchased this CE Ferulic serum because of the great price and became pleasantly surprised with its results. It works just as well as the Skinceuticals serum plus it applies easier and smells better. I apply it at night and my face is velvety smooth in the morning. It evens my skin tone and softens my wrinkles. I'm extremely satisfied with this product and recommend it to all looking for a reliable C product.

At first, before I purchased this e-book, I was extremely skeptical because I mean... $25k a month? That's just absolutely insane but as I kept reading I could understand more and more about Binary options and it really caught my eye. This e-book is very simple and it gets to the point clearly so you won't have much trouble understanding it at all. I've bought books such as these before and none of them have gone so in depth about their method as much as Roy did in this book it's absolutely incredible because he also keeps it very simple. I've also contacted Roy for a little bit of help because I was slightly confused at a small part of the book and he responded so quickly that I barely had to wait. Binary options are definitely a complicated system to figure out but with the help of this e-book you'll have just about no issues understanding every part of it and how to make some real cash through it. Roy's great, his software is great, and his responsiveness is just absolutely amazing. I would definitely recommend this product to you if you're in the middle deciding whether or not you should buy it. It will be a steal especially for this price.

This book has 50 different recipes that taste absolutely amazing so far. I've tried a few of the recipes and they have all tasted great so far! The foods are easy to make so you won't have to worry about that and it tastes good too!

This bread was absolutely delicious and I couldn't believe it would be useful for the Paleo diet and such. It was amazing and I would definitely buy it again because it was just so amazing. One of the best tasting breads I've ever had and it was baked perfectly.

I had a few viruses on my computer that made it slower than it should've been. It was driving me crazy how slow my computer was because I had only bought this about 3 months ago. I ran this and it actually fixed all the problems I had with my laptop! It was absolutely incredible now I can play my favorite games again without lagging at all!

This battery is a life saver. I had over charged my previous battery for the longest time and it would only last for like an hour max and this was absolutely annoying me. So I had to find a new battery and this was a great replacement. It lasts SOOOO much longer it's crazy and it looks just like the original one!

This eye mask is super super soft and delicate on your face. it does and excellent job of blocking out the light It is filled with a super thick foam.Plus it has earphones built into it with an audio 3.5mm jack adapter that descends from under the right eye and came with a braided nylon rope style audio cable to use with my devices. The audio cable has a volume control switch to lower or up the volume of my music. I love how cool this feels to my skin when i put it on my face. It helps me mellow out and relax. The volume is pretty decent as well and the bass is nice. i love listening to my calming sounds such as the ocean or nature while i'm falling asleep. i keep the mp3 player tucked under my pillow and i just lay there and realx and eventually just fall asleep. If i just want to use it as a sleep mask i can unzip the bottom and tuck the cable back in and put it on. The band is elastic and has velcro that fits nicely around my head it does not get caught up in my hair or pull. and it does not come undone.

I actually showed this to my pastor and his wife to see if they found it offensive, Some people will and some won't. they did not find it offensive the said irony of it is that this is the answer you will get from some people and i think that is sad. It just shows they forget the true meaning of the holidays. I let the pastor keep it and he has it tucked away in his bible i'm sure he will use it in a sermon or something along those lines. But is great for the church goer's in your life that have some sort of sense of humor. I received this product  free of charge in exchange of my honest and unbiased review.
Great game my son loves it keeps him busy easy for him to figure out and the graphics are impressive

This eye mask is super super soft and delicate on your face. it does and excellent job of blocking out the light It is filled with a super thick foam.Plus it has earphones built into it with an audio 3.5mm jack adapter that descends from under the right eye and came with a braided nylon rope style audio cable to use with my devices. The audio cable has a volume control switch to lower or up the volume of my music. I love how cool this feels to my skin when i put it on my face. It helps me mellow out and relax. The volume is pretty decent as well and the bass is nice. i love listening to my calming sounds such as the ocean or nature while i'm falling asleep. i keep the mp3 player tucked under my pillow and i just lay there and realx and eventually just fall asleep. If i just want to use it as a sleep mask i can unzip the bottom and tuck the cable back in and put it on. The band is elastic and has velcro that fits nicely around my head it does not get caught up in my hair or pull. and it does not come undone.

It just shows they forget the true meaning of the holidays. I let the pastor keep it and he has it tucked away in his bible i'm sure he will use it in a sermon or something along those lines. But is great for the church goer's in your life that have some sort of sense of humor. I received this product  free of charge in exchange of my honest and unbiased review.
Great game my son loves it keeps him busy easy for him to figure out and the graphics are impressive
Me and my daughter love  this! Very good for bedtime.
Me and my daughter LOVE this book and other Amye Rosenburg books!! So cute! This book is very sweet and our copy came with stickers.

Good movie but one I could never watch twice. My daughter and I were both sobbing our eyes out in the end. We were uncontrollably crying. It's an emotional rollercoaster! It's very good but if you are tender hearted get your tissues ready!!
Bought these to make scent sachets for my drawers and closets. Most of then we're fine but unfortunately some were torn and had huge holes in them. Probably not ideal if you need these for a wedding.
My daughter loves this short cartoon and thinks it's so funny. Much more lighthearted and humorous than the feature film. A great followup to the movie.
Fits my stove perfectly. Exactly what I needed!

So, for about the same amount if paint you can get chalky paint from home depot (in the sample size) for less than $9. But I didn't know that when I ordered this.Ordered 2 colors and had 2 different results. One can was really runny and the other can was thick and gloppy. Both covered well though. Make sure to use a good sealer and primer. i tested what would happen without a primer or sealer if I tried to clean a spot and all the paint came right off. So if you are going to paint a table or something  be sure to waterproof it. It also will stain if you do something like spill coffee or tea.Cans come sealed very well. I was extremely worried about opening my box and finding it full of paint. But the lids had been sealed tight and had things on top that you need to pry off. Then they wrapped in bubble wrap and plastic as well.  I was so glad to see how well they been packed!!Finish is very nice and I love the look. The colors are perfect and exactly what I was looking for. Very accurately represented on the picture.
Bought this as a gender neutral gift for dirty santa. It was a huge hit! Unfortunately does not include Legos but would be a fun gift to include with a box of the mini legos!!

Very sweet but best for religious families as these stories mention God and church etc. If ypu are not religious you may not enjoy these.Lovely illustrations of children and animals. Gently worded so even babies can understand but I think older children would enjoy these stories as well.

I bought these for my daughter to use with her tea pot to play with and she has been quite rough on them. There have been no chips or breakages! Best of all they are real dishes do she can use them for real tea!
perfect fit for my daughter. we got a lot of wear out of this outfit this year and it still looks new even after being washed a lot.

I had this book as a child and I have many happy memories of sitting with my great aunt to read this with her. I am so glad my daughter can read this too!Illustrations are PACKED with detail and whimsy, text is poetic but still informative. Tells all about how things are grown on a farm and the hard work involved. Shows plants growing and goes through the seasons. There's a sweet song in the end too.Boys and girls will love this. Absolutely adorable and fun too while still educational.
I love this peanut butter! I never thought plain peanut butter would be this good! After trying the other flavors I decided to try the plain and I love it! Never ever ever going back to jif!

Pretty good short story about Sophie, a mischievous little toddler mouse. She throws food and knocks over folded laundry and is sent to time out. (Without fussing) then she steals grandma's glasses, and granny puts herself in time out until Sophie brings back the glasses. Then Sophie is better behaved.I pointed out to my 3 year old how Sophie waits patiently in time out and  doesn't throw a fit and that has helped us a little. She seems to enjoy the book and I think she likes seeing Sophie acting out some of the behaviors she knows she isn't supposed to do.

This was one of my favorite books as a kid. I remember it being to read to me and  being so excited when I could finally read it myself. Perfect for any kid, young or old, who loves Sesame Street.While teaching about being being patient to wait on something we want, this also subtly teaches color recognition and subtraction. Also teaches the value of giving.

I loved White Girl Problems and I couldn't wait for Psychos to come out. I've read it twice and enjoyed it both times. The Babe in Psychos is very different from WGP, she's more mature and slightly less self-absorbed and rude. But she's definitely still Babe. This book had more of a plot and steady pace than the last book, which was a little bit all over the place and was really an introduction to Babe Walker.I loved reading about Babe's various adventures and laughed a lot. This is a great pool-side, beach, or bathtub read.

Perfect for toddlers and pre-k, the board book version was perfect for my 3 year old daughter to help her remember not to yell. We are still working on this but I have noticed definite improvement since we read this together. The paperback version is a longer version for older kids and I think I will be ordering that soon, since this book is very simplified.I honestly think parents and caregivers sometimes need reminding too, and this is a great book for the family to remember to lower the volume.Now if I tell my daughter, "voices are not for yelling" or "i can't hear you when you yell" she instantly knows what I mean and usually stops and tries to calm down and tell me in a calm voice.

I have a little Medusa with long, blonde, curly hair who hates having her hair brushed. This book has definitely helped reduce the daily battle we go through each day. But I also set her up with a little vanity table too and that has also helped. My daughter LOVES the story at the end of the book about Perseus battling Medusa. I didn't expect her to enjoy it but she really does.

Such a cute book about a little boy who isn't playing nicely/gently and upsets his little sister. After seeing her crying, he decides to fix it by playing with her. Very sweet for siblings or even for kids who might not always be so gentle when playing with others. At the end of the book is a short version of Hercules' tale.My daughter loves these Mini Myths books! Short and simple with bright and bold illustrations!

A great little board book for kids (great for toddlers but could still work for preschool aged kiddos) to teach what could happen if you are impatient. Also is a great way to introduce kids to Greek Myths, which it seems a lot of kids love.Pandora is a little girl who wants to open a box, but her mother says to wait. Instead she opens it and cupcakes go flying everywhere. But in the box one cupcake is left, and Pandora asks her mother if she still loves her. And of course she does. In the back of the book is a short version of Pandora's tale.My own little girl can be a bit too curious at times and this is a great book for her. She likes how each Mini Myths book ends on a positive note.

This is a large book which makes it a little hard to sit and read at leisure but it helps show the texture of the paint. I absolutely LOVE Mary Cassat and have used this book to help me introduce my daughter to Impressionist art. She loves the pictures and we talk about them together. She also loves Cassat's work (a lot of paintings of children, which she loves) and she can flick through this book for many minutes at a time.Includes a lot of information about Cassat's life and work. Very useful for reports. I used this in college for a research paper and ended up keeping it. I can see this being useful to my daughter in school later in life.

Really adorable and stylish. Even cuter in person. Comfy for my daughter to play in, I love that these shorts are not too short. My daughter has REALLY long legs so regular shorts look too small on her. Bermuda shorts are better for her to play in on the playground to keep sand and gravel for going up the legs of her shorts.
SO comfy for my daughter! Almost like pj's. These are super cute and perfect for playing outside in!
Comfy for my daughter to play in and matches many of her blouses and tees. Easy for her to dress herself with these.

Perfect for elementary school aged kids but also good for pre-school aged. My daughter really enjoyed this book and she's only 3. I loved Steven Kellog's illustrations as a child and still do as an adult. Very detailed and humorous. My daughter and I really liked this book, very positive compromise in the end!

Not bad but a lot of the episodes can be found on Prime, I didn't realize that at first. All episodes are Love/Valentine themed. Very cute and sweet  but not inappropriate for preschool aged children. The Yo Gabba Gabba episode and the Blue's Clues one are the best in my opinion.

Might be in the top 5 most annoying shows my daughter watches but nothing inappropriate. Just super cheesy and very LOUD. Not good for if parents are suffering from a migraine but for a little silly time this is not too bad. Songs are upbeat and positive, bright colors and goofy stunts/jokes keep kids engaged.

These work so much faster than regular pink Benedryl caps!! I like to take a Benedryl to help me sleep on a flight because I get nervous, I take 1 or 2 of these and in 20-40 minutes I'm feeling sleepy. I hate the 'hangover' feeling I get with Benedryl (they dry you out) but it's worth it for me.I also get seasonal allergies which make it hard for me to sleep at night and these help. They do make me VERY drowsy so I can only take them at night. But I have found the body does build up a tolerance to Benedryl, you need more and more each time. It's also a little addictive/habit-forming and I have withdrawals when I stop taking it for my seasonal allergies.

**Insert heart eyes emoji here**I LOVE LARABARs and I'm so glad Prime Pantry carries these. The price is about the same amount as my grocery store.Some of the flavors are vegan (this one is) which I need. Blueberry Muffin is delish. Good and soft, I can't stand super tough chewy bars, they hurt my teeth. These are perfect for when you are traveling or during an outing and don't want to get fast food.
Awesome book to help my daughter settle down for bedtime or a nap. Also great for helping her remember to slow down and try to notice the little things and her surroundings.
Cuts well, really tiny holes. I actually needed this for a costume and it was perfect.

Really short sheets, good for doing crafts. I ordered this pack because I needed a few of the colors, but buying the individual colors was more expensive than buying this small pack. I needed the foam for a costume I am making but saving the rest for doing little art projects with my daughter.There's so many great things you can do with foam sheets. My daughter likes to let the plain sheet be a rug or flooring in her dollhouse. Also good to cut up and make shapes with and just let kids be creative. There are tons of uses for these.

Really short sheets, good for doing crafts. I ordered this pack because I needed a few of the colors, but buying the individual colors was more expensive than buying this small pack. I needed the foam for a costume I am making but saving the rest for doing little art projects with my daughter.We've already used these to make a daily schedule for her and some play credit/debit cards. These are good to glue a magnet to or make shapes and stuff for 'busy bags'. I cut one into itty bitty pieces and combined with other materials to make a sensory tub for my daughter. There's a ton of uses for these!

I really doubted that these would actually stick to my lip but they did. When I get a cold sore I often have trouble eating and drinking and this protects my mouth. I've seen where people use these and apply makeup over them to cover the cold sore but I have not tried that. 1 pack was enough for the duration of healing but I will have to order another pack for next time, as I only have a few left over. Kind of expensive but totally worth it. It definitely helped with the pain since nothing could get to the area to irritate it.

Great paint! I've been using Folk Art brand for years. I needed to paint a piece of foam to look like metal and I used this and it looks really good. Shiny but not TOO shiny. I used dry brushing with a bit of brown to make it look 'distressed' and my project looks perfect. Dries quickly and evenly. I had no streaking at all, only needed 1 coat in most spots but some small areas needed 2 coats.

Definitely does dye clothing (I used a plain old 100% cotton tee) but does not dye the thread garments are sewn with. Same with other RIT colors I've used.Follow the directions PERFECTLY. I didn't follow them exactly as written and my tee was not evenly dyed but not very noticeably uneven.

I honestly do not believe this helps speed recovery/healing, but I do think it somewhat helps the cold sore look less scabby. I've tried Abreva several times and my healing time is always the same no matter what I use.

These are perfect for my daughter who is potty trained but still sometimes wakes up wet at naptime and bedtime. She's in the 90th percentile for her age group (not overweight, just tall for her age) and regular night time diapers do not fit her. These are a better option since they are more like the training pants she has. These allow her to sleep 12+ hours comfortably.
Fits great, very comfy. Ordered XL. I'm 5'3 and wear a dress size 8-10.

This was one of my favorite books as a kid. If I remember correctly, I first saw this on Reading Rainbow and then checked it out from the library after that. I loved the illustrations and the message, which is to do something that makes the world a better place.This is a wonderful storybook and my daughter loves it too. Even though she's only 3 I can tell that she is trying to understand the concepts, but mostly she's enjoying the pictures. Probably better for elementary aged children (my teacher read this to us in 2nd or 3rd grade and we did a little unit on it) but could definitely be good for young ones too, since it's a sweet story.

Definitely works as an herbal/natural thermogenic. I take 2 capsules with every meal 4 times a day. I had hit a plateau in my weight loss (trying to lose that last bit of baby weight) and no matter what I tried I couldn't get past it. I tried cinnamon and cayenne capsules and these really do help. I have been steadily losing weight again.I noticed that my body has built up a tolerance to the cinnamon though, so I like to wait a few weeks and not take any, then start taking them again with meals. This is way better than taking diet pills or something.

I was one of those weird people who didn't like this movie as a kid and I still don't really like it. But my husband LOVED this movie when he was little so I bought this for our daughter so he can share that memory with her. They are so sweet cuddled on the couch together watching this. My daughter isn't really that into it (she makes my husband skip past the 'mean parts') but I think as she gets older (she's only 3) she will enjoy it more. Right now a lot of the references go over her head.

One of my all time favorite movies from childhood. I have no idea why my parents let me watch this actually since it's pretty trippy and violent. I know it's nothing like the books but I have a special love for this movie since I have great childhood memories of it.Digital purchase worked great. Looks good on tv and on computer.

This was one of the first movies I ever saw in a theatre as a child, I've been hooked ever since! Humor is a little cheesy by today's standards but still fun. Definitely one of my favorite Halloween movies that I HAVE to watch each year, right next to Nightmare Before Christmas and It's The Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown.Probably not considered age appropriate for under middle school aged but I was 6 when this movie came out and I was fine. All the less than innocent things went right over my head.Digital purchased worked fine and played great on my television.

Purchased as a gift for my husband. He says, "It's not a Jawbone but the sound is good, quality is good." Haha!My husband mostly uses this but sometimes I use this to provide white noise for my daughter's bedroom. This is really easy to use (I'm not great with electronics and this only took me a minute or two to figure out) and I have not experienced any problems.

I ordered the board book version thru Kindle which was great to introduce my daughter to the concepts in the book. But it turned out that the longer version for older kids was better for her as it has helped her be more empathetic towards our pets.

Ordered 1 episode - 'If You Give a Mouse a Cookie' because it's one of my daughter's favorite books and she LOVES Reading Rainbow. This is a great episode and really fun for little kids if you are trying to introduce them to RR.

A little more bulky in my bag than the PRIMO folding one because of the cushion, but way more comfy for my daughter. Makes using a public toilet slightly less intimidating for her. I allowed her to stick stickers on it to make it more fun for her. Takes up WAY less room than a regular adapter seat. Comes with a carrying bag which keeps toilet germs off the rest of our stuff. I don't know what I would do without this thing!

My daughter loves Thomas so I actually bought these for her since they fit exactly the same as the girls. I prefer cloth training pants (seem to motivate my child more) but for naptime or going out somewhere I prefer disposables since if there is an accident, there's no ruined clothing or sheets. These are great for those times.

Really sad actually and kind of dark for a children's movie but my daughter loves this movie for some reason. She doesn't really care for the sad parts but she does like the songs and when all the animals dress up as a Tigger. There's a happy ending, of course.

Easy to pull up and take off, don't get torn or messed up when taken off and on several times to go potty. Not too bulky under clothes but does hold accidents. My daughter used to bad diaper rash with Huggies brand if she fell asleep and peed in the trainers, but not with these. Odd, because Pampers diapers always gave her a rash. These were also slightly less expensive than Huggies which was nice and the reason why I decided to give them a try. Having Dora on the front has definitely helped encourage my daughter to try and stay clean and dry too.
Cute short episodes, nothing I find to be inappropriate for my child. Fun songs and lots of silliness.

I LOVED this book, my daughter was a little less thrilled. She's 3 and I guess she's not quite ready, I could tell some of it was going over her head. She asked me to read her something else haha.  But I think around age 4-5 when I try again she will love it. Quite long for a picture book, with soothing text. This is the type of book that helps kiddos fall asleep. The illustrations are interesting and inspiring but not bright and crazy, perfect for looking at before drifting off to dreamland. Definitely a winner if you enjoy poetry.
Hilarious fun for family. Durable mat. Classic game sure to go over well at gatherings.

Great lotion but unfortunately does not dry on my face as well as the liquid. I tried both at the same time and I just liked the liquid better for my needs. But this was a great lotion, didn't clog my pores at all!

It works and does what it's supposed to do but my daughter hasn't responded to it. There's nothing wrong with the product, but my daughter just wants to play with it and hold it rather than wearing it so she either ends up losing it or sticking it somewhere it does no good. Also it seems my daughter resents being reminded to go to the bathroom, which results in a power struggle since she decides to hold her bladder rather than admit she actually has to go.

Works great for us. We have my daughter wear this when we take her to the zoo or theme parks. Even though we hold her hand she sometimes lets go and tries to run off so it gives me an extra little sense of security. I used it a couple of times to test it. It's LOUD! I was worried it would be too quiet to hear in a small space.Only problem is that my daughter wants to hold it like a toy rather than actually wearing it.

Interesting light reading if you aren't the blushing type and have a sense of humor. If you are at all familiar with erotic literature nothing in this book will shock you. This book was turned into a popular tv series and lots of other books have been published but almost all the source material was (and perhaps still is) available on her blog, where Belle posted lots of tips and anecdotes. Where the blog was more random, the book tells more of a story.Good to pick up and read if you like autobiographies or are fascinated by working girls. I really enjoy reading stories about call girls and such, it's a very different lifestyle from my own and I find it interesting like I'm sure a lot of people do. The psychology/mindset of working girls is interesting to me and this book offers a glimpse of that.Very mildly sexy. This is not going to get you going like traditional erotic literature. Belle is candid about her feelings toward her clients (they're not always so sweet) and leaves out many details that would have turned this into a literotica novel.I enjoy light reading like this when I take a break after completing a long series or dark or depressing novel so this is perfect for those times when you aren't sure what to read next and want to take a mental break.

We LOVE Hello Baby! Mem Fox never goes wrong in our house! This was such a wonderful book when my daughter was just learning to speak. She's 3 now and recently passed it on to my sister in law and her new baby, but my daughter and I still repeat the last lines. They go "What are you baby? Wait let me guess. Are you my treasure? The answer is.." and then my daughter says "YES!". It's become our little thing.Very short little story, perfect for infants and toddlers up to preschool age. Awesome of your child likes animals. The rhyming text is good for helping soothe little wiggleworms for bedtime and get them to settle down. Short and sweet so it's perfect for short attention spans.

Really cute and funny with rhyming text and silly illustrations. Perfect as a board book for infants all the way up to preschool and even use as an early reader!! The repetition and predicable rhyming make this great to keep on hand when your child starts to read. It's short and has simple words so it will give them the encouragement and confidence they need to take the next step to longer books.
Loose abd breezy and super soft! I love it! Fits great and is flattering. Perfect for the beach or bright sunny day.

I really wish this book showed positive or alternative behaviors to contrast with the negative. It shows a lot of disobedient behavior but no good ones.This book sounds preachy or like a lecture, but my daughter has still responded to the book.
