To compare this new WS-853, I used a new setting called "Simple Mode" which means the more specialized settings are suppressed to give just basic recording functions, and also the font on the display is larger and easier to read. I suspect that Olympus included this "Simple Mode" because of complaints from customers like me that their recorders had become too tricky.Neither recorder is instantly on; if they have been off for awhile, it's necessary to press (any) button to wake them up before they can record. This is annoying, but the startup time of the 853 is noticeably quicker than the 311. It also has distinctly better sound, and stereo, although this is more significant for recording meetings than in the front seat of my truck.The big new wrinkle of the 853 is computer-friendliness. Whereas the 311 can only be played back by actually listening and scribbling notes, the 853 has a USB connector on the top and when plugged into my Mac, comes up as a folder full of sound files without the need to do anything special. It is only necessary to click on these and the computer plays back the memos, very handy and easily saved as sound files with no need to transcribe. (It seems it may also possible to use voice recognition software to actually transcribe the memos, but I haven't figured out how to do that yet.) Also the batteries are rechargeable and charge while it's plugged in.Although the 311 has a larger display and is easier to read and use at night, the 853 is more sophisticated and higher in sound quality. It is better suited for recording of meetings, and definitely convenient if you work with a computer all day. Not expensive either. Recommended. Five stars.

Burberry Weekend is a classic women's scent on the market since 1997. It was formulated for Burberry by Nathalie Lorson, a well known perfumer who has created more than 70 formulations for various brands. Burberry is an old line British firm and on the conservative side, and this is a traditional fragrance, not too exotic or otherworldly. "Weekend" is not for teenagers either; it's a scent for a grown woman, perhaps a professional woman. It is a fresh scent and can be worn every day, with a bit of tangerine on top, wild rose in the middle and a layer of musk and sandalwood on the bottom. It's sexy in a digified way.I gave this to a woman friend and she loves it. Not cheap but a classic and a safe bet as a gift.

Dewalt is the standard in angle grinders and you will find them all over the industrial world and in metal working schools. This is one heck of a useful tool, powerful and durable. The kinks have been ironed out of this classic design - it just works. The low price is a real bargain - would be higher if these were not sold in such large numbers.However, don't let the reasonable price draw you into buying this 11 amp unit if you don't really need the full power - because it is large and weighs over 6 lbs. Dewalt, Makita and Bosch all make smaller, lighter 7 amp products which cost about the same but are easier to handle in tight spaces.
I love this tea and somehow it is produced so consistently. The Amazon price was about the same as my local Whole Foods.

These are convenient and effective for mild cases of hemorrhoids.However, there is a problem. Along with other wet wipes, they are advertised as breaking down after being flushed. Unfortunately, tests show they do not. Urban sewage systems are getting clogged with wipes and a rural septic system like mine can be destroyed. So I stopped using them. They need to be discarded with solid trash, not flushed. Which is yucky. So conventional Prep H is a better solution.

These are Old Man Shoes - it's OK, I'm an old man - and some of us are just too crotchedy to tie our laces ten times a day. This was my problem when I was four, and now it's my problem again.These are not running shoes. The main feature is the velcro closers, which make it quick to go out for a walk to the mailbox or down to the Village for the Early Bird Special. They are not expertly engineered such as my Brooks Beast sneakers, which are much more sophisticated and supportive for all day use or running. Rather these are just very easy to get on and off, plastic uppers, rather simplistic design. I did appreciate they are available in wide 2E sizes, which gained me a better fit. So that's the story - have to go now, Early Bird time, meatloaf tonight!.

These are very inexpensive steak knives but I actually don't use them that way: I keep eight in a box for everyday use in food prep, then throw them in the dishwasher. They are OK for what they are; ergonomically designed, sharp, well shaped, machine washable and CHEAP.However, the blades are marked "China" and "Stainless Steel." But these are as much Stainless Steel as I am Arnold Schwarzenegger. The blades spot with rust immediately coming from the dishwasher. Blatantly false advertising.Second, they can't be sharpened, certainly not at home. The edge shape is a complex curve formed by some machine or laser manufacturing process. The Miracle Blades outfit says they "never need sharpening" which really means - there is no way to do so.These are to be used a while and when dull, discarded. Two stars.

Trashbags are humble things and there are only three things to know about them; the thickness of the poly, whether the tie at the top is easy to close, and whether the seal at the bottom is reliable so you can toss in some liquids. These 30 gal Hefty's are pretty good on all counts and sell for about 40c per in quantity. The plastic is 1.1 mil. Other competing bags which have recycled content are only 0.9 mil; I don't recommend those. There are some Clear bags on Amazon which are 1.2 mil and sell around 25c per; those look good but I haven't tried. The place I work uses the clear ones. In the meantime, these Hefty's are about as good as any supermarket trash bag.

Hand tools available these days tend to fall in two categories; professional, high quality, US or European made and expensive, or consumer grade (that is, junk) Made in the People's Republic of China. There are exceptions such as the German designed Wiha line, manufactured in Vietnam to European quality standards.So I was quite surprised to receive this set of three Tekton groove joint pliers, which are cast and precision ground to high standards - excellent quality - and marked Made in USA! I'm not sure how the company manages this, but if you care about supporting American industry over China (I do), this is the way to go.

This worked much better than I had expected. The wireless in my house is only useful a few feet into the yard. There is another building, a workshop, 150' from the house, without any internet or telephone access. So I set this up, first in the house to be sure it worked, then moved to the workshop. Amazingly, it worked! This appears to be the maximum extreme range however, as the light on the unit was mostly pink and not green. But it did connect. (I actually have two wireless routers in the house, one 5 GHz band the other 2.4 GHz band. It worked better with the former network.)At the fringes of the range, it does slow the connection down. My normal download speed in the house is 8 Mbps. Using the Linksys by plugging an ethernet cable into the box and into my MacBook, it slowed to 3.4 Mbps. If I used the secondary wireless instead of the ethernet cable, slowed further to 2 Mbps. But certainly better than nothing!I'm impressed! Recommended.Note added later: I see that this was voted 'unhelpful' by the only two commenters. I'm not sure what exactly would have been more helpful on a review like this?

CK ONE is now more than 20 years old. At the time the idea of a unisex scent was daring and provocative. Not so much anymore, in the current social atmosphere of softened gender boundaries and sexual fluidity.ONE is a light, citrusy and benign EdT which yes, has notes typical of women's scents along with other notes typical of men's scents. However I do think it works better for a woman, giving her a mysterious air ..

CK introduced Euphoria about ten years ago. It has been popular and gone through some evolution, including a version for men. This is a bright lively yet soft fragrance - and yes, very sexy. Every woman I asked to try it liked it but most thought it more suitable for younger rather than mature.My friends and I had a laugh about the bottle, which is somewhat phallic, and we are not the only ones who noticed this. Of course CK is known for very sexy advertising, so probably no accident.

I love Turkey, Turkish food, and I'm a tea drinker so I thought I would try this Turkish grown tea. It's OK, pleasant, not too tannic, but undistinguished. Not the equal of a fine Chinese Keemun etc. But good for iced tea and as a base for spiced Middle Eastern tea with the addition of cardamom, cinnamon, ginger, clove, anise and sugar.I wish it would come in a smaller package because I just wanted to try it - now I have a full pound sitting on the shelf.

Wow.  From packaging, to fit, to sound, these are really really good headphones for their price.  First, the construction: they can be folded up into a fairly compact shape, the brushed metal looks fierce, and they also pivot side to side so they fit perfectly over the ear.  The cushioning is wonderful, and have a nice noise isolation effect.  Sound quality is really quite good, with crisp highs, some serious lows.  I would note that they certainly feel very hefty, which can both be a pro or a con, depending on what you prefer.For a set of 50 buck headphones, these are excellent headphones which would be a score as a gift, and which I received for a straightforward review.

I am always on the lookout for a crafting project which allows for a variety of different projects, since the ones that only do one thing end up with kids losing interest and me being left with a bunch of leftover project material which gets donated.  This kit works for three different projects, which is nice.  Also, it comes with many little trinkets and accessories which are great for kids who like to bling out the stuff they are crafting (see pictures).A great rainy day project kit, which I received for a straightforward review.

Hilarious for any Walking Dead fan, and pretty darn freaky too.  Let's just say this might not be the best book to leave around the house if you have younger kids.  That said, my older kids thought it was a belated Halloween book and think its hilarious.

From right where you left off in book two, The Game of Lives pulls you right back into Dashner's meticulously crafted virtual universe.  As before, the world is crafted with such amazing detail and is written so well that the reader finds themselves drawn into it.  On thing missing from this book is the usual VirtNet experience that readers are accustomed to.A little bit of a slower start than the first is due to differing dynamics between certain characters but the latter 2/3 of the book speed right up again, heading straight into a page turner.In all, it is a good third novel to the first two, which is often difficult to pull off.  There are many many unexpected twists and turns, shining an entirely new light on certain characters and tying together loose ends.  And I wont even mention the end: mind...blown.

Down the line of an all-in-one survival knife, the Chaos Ready has some good things going for it.  I like the weight and balance of the knife, which is pretty good given that the handle has a few extras tucked into it.  It sits well in the hand, and the blade is a solid lock blade which is easy (but not too easy) to disengage.  The blade was delivered fairly sharp (but I always sharpen my knives after delivery), and the design is good: it has some serrations at the thickest part of the blade and the backside has a bottle/can opener.  The handle has a metal prong at the end (glass breaker) and a seat belt cutter too.The included flashlight is very, very small.  When I removed the cardboard, the light that it emitted was not exactly bright either.  But, after taking the batteries out of the sleeve and re stacking an inserting them, the flashlight worked and it was quite bright for such a small light.  As for the fire starter I had difficulty getting it to work, but my guess is that I had to scrape down a bit to get it to spark.I like the knife, and though I would not use it as a backpacking/camping knife, it will be a great tool to add to my office emergency bag since, given the extras in it seem to be a bit more useful in an urban environment.In all, an interesting knife, which I received for a straightforward review.

Though this is billed as a dog training pouch, I am guessing it may have been intended as something else when it was first designed.  On one side, it even has a little pass through which looks like it would have been used for headphones?  Just as a great little carry all, it is actually quite nice, with little zip pockets to hold extras and the blue lining is really a nice touch.  The material is very tough so durability will be good.  As for a dog treat bag, it certainly can hold little treats nicely inside.  It has an interior drawstring to close up the interior.  What it does not have is a removable interior lining, which given there will be food in it for an extended period of time, may make cleaning a bit more complicated.On the whole though, a very tough, usable little pouch, either for dog treats or otherwise, which I received for a straightforward review.--------------update---------------So, per the comment below, it looks like the pass through was intended to hold clean up bags, which is actually a pretty great idea.  So, the bag just got even more useful.

For its price, this projector is quite something.  First, the led bulb is nice since it does not run as hot and should have a better lifespan.  The connectivity is incredible: it can connect by usb, hdmi, component (with included cable), pretty much any possible way (except for bluetooth, which I would never expect at a price so low).  Also, it can be used with a plugin power source AND can be plugged into a battery pack, making it awesomely portable.The picture quality is pretty good, if you have your expectations realistic given this is not a $300 projector.  We shone it up on the ceiling, and it made a pretty good picture at a size of about 6 feet (see pictures).  At that size, the colors were good, and there was a little bit of pixelation, but honestly, if you are watching on a cheap projector it is more for the novelty of it rather than regularly using it as your TV.  The speaker is a little on the weaker side, but adequate.In all, a really good projector at its price point, which I was fortunate to receive for a straightforward review.

This colander is perfect: it is built sturdy, stainless, and the hole size is great for most things.  It has a base which keeps it up off of the bottom of the sink (a must) and it cleans up easily in the dishwasher.A very good kitchen tool, which I received for a straightforward review.

Indeed this is a decent cheap waterproof endoscope which can be used for whatever on earth you want to view through a tiny camera.  Oddly enough, the kids ended up having more fun with it than me: they used it to scope out lego buildings they made, look inside holes in the ground, look up drainpipes, etc.  Construction quality appears good with the cable being fairly solid but yet flexible enough to get around corners.The software comes on a mini cd but fortunately it worked plug and play for me.  The instructions are indeed bad and poorly translated, but since this basically functions plug and play and has a manual switch for the brightness level, I did not need them anyway.An interesting gadget, which I received for a straightforward review.

As noted by numerou speople, the beige curtains are in no way blackout curtains, and they should not be marketed as such.  At best, they are no different than a heavy cotton curtain in dimming outside light.  The material is not lined, and not particularly thick, so their insulation ability is no where near a lined curtain.  That said, as a cheap pair of beige curtains with nice enough grommet tops, these work fine, but, given that they did not work as blackout curtains, I would have simply then preferred 100% cotton thick curtains instead.

This was a huge hit for my little pokemon fan.  The material is on the lighter side and great for the warm evenings.  The shorts do not have any graphics, which is too bad, but the long pants and shirt graphics are great.  My kid just lit up when he saw these, and has been wearing them ever since.

This is a great sleepwear set, particularly for those warmer nights.  The material is more on the lighter side and seems roomy and comfortable for my seven year old.  The graphics are ok, but given the material and three piece set, it is a great buy.
Nice big size and heavy duty construction, this sign is a perfect deterrent and addition to the house.

The U.S. Joint Special Operations Command (JSOC), the U.S. military's most elite fighting force, combining the Army's Delta Force, the Navy's SEAL Team 6, and various Army and Air Force special mission helicopter and aircraft squadrons is unearthed in this fascinating book.  Many of their operations have been documented over time, but the their missions in Iraq, Afghanistan, Somalia, Syria and other places are still secret.This book unearths the history in all of its good, bad, and ugly glory.  Apparently, there is a bit of controversy as to whether the material contained within is or should be classified, but Naylor gets around the highly classified nature of many of these missions by using  available primary and official sources with interviews from soldiers who have written their own books.The book is very readable and feels like it is part fiction and part military history which keeps the reader engaged, but does not hold back on being sure to analyze the some of the darker moments of this elite force.  There is simply too much ground to cover in this review, but the story is exhaustive on detailing the whole evolution of this organization including its controversial missions in the 1980s and 1990s in Central and South America, the invasions of Grenada and Panama.The timeliness of the book is good particularly given the increasing role of special ops during this time.  On the whole, this is one of the must-read military history books of the year.

This is not going to be an entry level book: it requires some pokemon knowledge and a bit of research for the kids to answer all the questions.  However that is what has made it fun!  Otherwise my son just cruises through the book and is done without any effort.  It certainly is rich with trivia, but also has some easier games.  It has quite a variety of different games and puzzles, and has managed to keep interest for more than a week now, which is pretty impressive for one of these books.A great book for kids into pokemon from age 6 up.

We were in need of great ankle-length socks for a sporty girl who is constantly on the move.  Many of girls socks are either way too thin to protect the foot from abrasion from all that running, or way too thick so that the foot ends up super sweaty.  These ones are just right: the material is medium weight, tightly woven, but breathable.  It has already withstood numerous washes and the socks are still soft on the inside but hold well to the foot.  The neon colors are a hit too.In all, perfect ankle socks for the sporty girl.

Having reviewed a couple of these mp3 players, I am pleased to say this one was the best quality in build (no rattle) in terms of the device itself.  The earphones are still pretty weak, to the point I would not be using them.  The menu and sound quality is not bad, but the controls certainly take a bit of getting used to since the buttons and what they do are not exactly intuitive.  Is it an ipod?  No.  Is it a good imitation of one?  Not exactly.  Is is a good bargain mp3 player for its price?  Yes!

The design is cute and friendly and the interior is a gel which I think is way more fun to squish.  One down and up side is that, if you throw it on a ceiling or wall, it will stick a bit; the downside is that it leaves a yellow mark where it hit our white ceiling.  Kids seem to like it, but the staining means it is definitely not staying inside the house.

Though I am not usually a sling bag guy, I was interested in this bag as it is holds a pretty good volume, has a hole for a water bladder or earphones, and has a water bottle holder too. It works well for the office since the sling is a little easier on the nice clothes than a backpack, and is sized well for lunch, a water bottle and whatever random items (ipod, phone) you may want to throw in it. I think it would work pretty well as a commuter bag, but note that it would not work well for hauling files like a briefcase. The construction and materials are very good, particularly at the present price.I ended up using it for a simple office emergency bag which holds a few essentials; it was big enough to hold a pair of shoes, snacks, my water bottle, and a few emergency related items. It does not take up much room, and in black, is fairly inconspicuous.On the whole, a great bag, which I received for reviewing purposes.

Barely changed color and then stopped doing it all together and just stayed the same dull color.  Got this to add to the splash science lab (which is also a poor purchase).  I would stay away from these sets since they are a total waste: stick to tracks that let the kids race or do loops instead.

The Raqpak Reflective Cord, as others have mentioned, is on par with a 550 Paracord about 4mm thick.  Works great for just about any paracord use, from guylines, tents, lashing things to backpacks, and laundry lines.  I especially like it for laundry lines, since as anyone who has walked around a campsite at night may know, running into a line at night can be treacherous.  With the little reflective flecks in the casing, the line reflects just enough in a headlamp to make it noticeable that you do not end up running into it.  This makes it also a great application for fly tie downs (tripping over those is a specialty of mine).  Would note that I'm not sure why I would get the green rope again, since it can be hard to see in the day compared to a bright color which would be more visible in the daytime.On the whole, a good rope which will be put to good use, which I received as a free sample for a direct and unbiased review.

For those who remember Ali from In Living Color, we already know her as a brilliant comedienne.  As a writer, I have to say that her wit was new to me.  This book was simply absurdly funny.  This book weaves throughout the absurdities of her fairly extraordinary life, and her touch in recalling even the simple things makes for a good laugh.  This books is focused on her anxieties and misgivings that seize her as she faces as she approaches her 50th birthday.  Her method of trying to reinvent herself and the sometimes unfortunate remedies she resorts to in trying to overcome them lead from one funny story to the next.  The stories touch on a wide range, from fishing to Percocet (you just have to read it), to driving craziness, to failed attempts at anti aging regimen.Its a fun easy reading book, with short chapters suitable for a quick read.  Does it translate to everyone?  Maybe not, but life and ageing is somewhat universal, and the stories really are funny as heck.A good, light, read.

Have you ever tried to brush your kids teeth?  It's excruciating.  Given the limited window of opportunity to get in a few brushes, having a power brush is a godsend.  In limited time, these brushes manage to do a pretty good job of powering off all the gunk.  I would note that the heads on these brushes are the standard oral-b heads which mean they might be a tiny bit large for the 6 and under crowd, particularly in the gum line.  Kids loved the graphics and love having their own power brushes that actually work (unlike the battery powered versions which seem woefully underpowered).A savior of teeth brushing time

I notice these cans at out local elementary school and, seeing the abuse these things take there, I got one for home.  We have destroyed so many cans, particularly given the new mechanical arms from the garbage trucks which invariably destroy lesser garbage cans.  The Brute has stood up these maniacal mechanical arms, has been dragged, sat on, jumped in, and thrown about, without so much as a scratch.  More expensive?  Yes, but worth every penny given they simply do not break.A must for homeowners.

A great basic bait knife with a sheath that holds on very well.  Arrived sharp and the saw blade on the back is helpful to hack through frozen bait when needed.  Love that the sheath clips on to the knife so that the knife does not fall out when it is rumbling around in the tackle box or bucket.A great buy at a great price

My kids absolutely loved having a set of UNO cards with pokemon characters.  The deck looks like it came straight from Japan, even with Japanese lettering on the graphics.  A great gift for the little kids who like pokemon but are not ready to play an advanced pokemon game.

Though I may have missed it in the description, these loot bags are not paper, and do not stand up when filled.  They appear to be printed plastic or vinyl, and, given their material, are pretty underwhelming for the price.  Yes, they do have pokemon graphics, but if you are looking for bags that will get little kids excited and are actually useful bags, these are probably not it.

Another great quality speedo suit.  So many other one pieces end up stretching too much too quickly at the straps and in the crotch.  This suit is holding up well: no stretching, no fraying of the fabric, and it is quick to dry.  We have already put it through the ringer with the swim team, and it has survived the season well.  A great suit for the under 10 crowd.
Big bag of medium sized swivels which all look just right for some mid pound test line.  The construction seems sturdy, and for the price, a good deal.

There are quite a few solar chargers out there, and as a simple entry unit at a great price, this is it.  This is a single USB charger 10watt tri fold panel which seems constructed as sturdy as the other panels I have purchased in the past.  In fact, it feels even heavier duty than some more expensive ones.  It has many attachment points so that it can be put on a pack.  I have already used it to charge a few USB charged toys, charged a few smaller battery packs, all with no problem.For the price, a great entry panel.Received this for a brutally honest review.  Enjoy.

Kids are always fascinated about treasures.  This book is a great companion book to have for any California road trip as it covers 313 different legends of lost treasures, hidden mines, and even sunken treasure ships.  Each site is described in a fairly succinct paragraph which is sufficient detail to maybe get the kids dreaming about a treasure site, but the book does not provide much detail such that someone could begin any treasure hunt in earnest.  That said, the book even notes that this is not the point of the book, rather, it is meant as an overview of some of the bigger treasure legends in California.  The book also comes with a fold out map which maps out the various locations of these legends, and has a very short section on hazards of exploring in the back.  Received for reviewing purposes.On the whole, a good book to stoke the imagination of kids while on the road, but likely not going to be of much use to serious treasure hunters.

Harlan Coben is one of the best mystery and suspense writers in the business so there are always high expectations which come with his books.  For the most part, Coben does not disappoint with his latest book,The Stranger, an addictive mystery novel driven by great characters.The Stranger is a mystery set around a seemingly happy and mundane family Adam and wife, Corinne, and their two sons Ryan and Thomas who live in a nice suburban neighborhood in New Jersey. But, upon meeting a stranger at an American Legion Hall, Adam's life starts to unwind with a slow burning paranoia. The Stranger is a normal looking guy who knows things about Adam's wife and family. He knows things about his wife that a stranger should not.  With each piece of information, Adam is thrown deeper and deeper into doubt and disbelief about his own reality.In classic Coben style we have elements of mystery, strong characters, and relevant and current themes as here where the book relates to the prevalence of information in the internet age.  The stories herein have a strong edge to them as they feel like situations which could actually be occurring and are realistically drawn as they begin in the normal and mundane world and then take a hard left into intrigue.  However, The Stranger is a bit different than Coben's other books, and though it has classic twists, turns, suspense, and wit, the book tends to slow down in the middle as its flips between characters and the confusion that has ensued because of mysterious stranger.  The book also has parts which are not particularly believable and downright strange.  That said, the whole the story heads to a classic Coben stunning conclusion, which makes up for the pacing issues.On the whole, though not at his best, Coben fans will probably like the book.  Any general mystery reader will enjoy it too.

As many folks know, buying a house is a ridiculously stressful, arcane, and drawn out process.  Stress is a given.  Her personality coming through the book, Sherrod brings the stress level down by providing a "No-Stress" guide to buying a home and hits on many of the critical issues involved in assessing home buying, dealing with your agent, how to deal with bidding wars and making sure to do a home inspection.For any real estate newbie heading into buying their first home, this book is a helpful tool to give potential homeowners a bit of ammunition heading into the process and advice to avoid some classic home-buying mistakes.  In all, a fun read and helpful book for the first-time home buyers.

There are so many issues with this book, it is difficult to even know where to start.  As with all "do this and you will make tons of money" books, the first thing to look at are the assumptions and assumed projections, which are usually how authors manage to get to their "amazing" returns.  Lichtenfeld suggests that investors need to focus on just three things: initial yield, dividend growth rate, and payout ratio. There is nothing about assessing the quality of the underlying business and the book does not touch on valuation of the businesses.  For starters, there are no guarantees that a company paying a big dividend will continue to do so, particularly in down markets.Tellingly, the author presents some historical data showing how well dividend stocks have done in the past and guesses where they will go in the future, but then provides no proof that his system can produce the results he claims in actual practice. Even in his "Perpetual Income Portfolio" he does not report its long-term returns nor the stocks in it.There certainly is a spot in a portfolio for high dividend stock, but as anyone knows by now, there is no "surefire" way to have double digit returns.  Blue chips, high dividend, emerging markets, small cap stocks, they all sound great until they are not. Also, note there are much better books far better books on dividend growth investing out there like The Dividend Toolkit by Matt Alden and The Single Best Investment by Lowell Miller.So, dividend stocks may be a good part of a portfolio, but this book misses on a lot of critical issues.

Though I cannot attest to having vast experience with card cases, I must say that this one has proven perfect for the extraordinary pokemon card collection that my kids have amassed.  The interior is nicely padded so it does not damage the edges of cards, has movable velcro dividers so you can separate cards into sections but at whatever size you need.  The shell is also very strong, so it saves any cards from being crushed.Frankly, this case would be perfect for storing any smaller items which need crush and scratch protection, and serves as a high quality case to store cards in. Highly recommended.The case was provided to me for evaluation purposes so I could provide my honest feedback in this review.

In Dead Wake, as in past books, Larson touches on the surreal and unlikely intersections that often arise in some of the biggest turning points in history. Larson's narrative story centers on the RMS Lusitania, a British ocean liner whose sinking by a German submarine provided Britain with a propaganda opportunity and shifted public opinion in the United States against Germany, which played a part in influencing America's eventual declaration of war.Larson's book narrates the story from divergent perspectives, including those of U-boot-20 and its captain Walther Schwieger, the crew and passengers aboard the luxury transatlantic liner the Lusitania, and the political buildup to World War I. A work of narrative nonfiction, it draws from historical records, letters, and journal entries to tell the story all during a time when Germany, France, and England were are already locked in combat while America remained neutral.  The continuing tension between the naivete of the passengers of the luxury liner, the pacifism of the Americans who underestimated the German threat, the failures of British intelligence, and the patient stalking of the U-boat build throughout Larson's book, make for a compelling story.That said, this book does not quite live up to the greatness of In the Garden of Beasts and Devil in the White City, which both felt more like the author unearthed a story that had not yet been explored.  The Lusitania story is one that has been much discussed in the past, and thus the book misses the fresh feel of those other ones.Anyone with a casual interest in history will likely enjoy this book, but those who hold Larson to the high standards of his prior works may not be quite as impressed.

Dream With Me Now of a Dinosaur Dash is a cute nighttime book for any young dinosaur loving kid.  It meets all the requirements of a good bedtime book for very young kids: a simple and compelling story, cute (though inconsistent) graphics, and a nice calm tone to set the kids up to go to bed.  On the whole, a very nice bedtime story for the little ones.I received a free copy for review.
These are perfect replacement lids, however for a bit more you could get an entirely new container set.  Fit just as snug as the originals, yet my first graders still manage to open the container.

For the price, you get a decent case with quite a selection of thread, a thin measuring tape, a nice container for needles, and a pair of basic scissors, among other items.  Put together, this is a decent kit, though I agree with other reviewers which mention that the kit is a bit big for a simple travel kit.  It is, however, a good kit to send off with your kids to college so that they have the basics which they can use to repair things.On the whole, a decent basic sewing kit, which I received for free for an straightforward review.

These earbuds make a great first impression: the braided line looks very refined comared to the normal slick nylon lines, the wood on the bud look sophisticated, and the general design of the wood, chrome, and black looks good together.  The packaging is also fun with great graphics and nice presentation.  In all, first impressions are that they look more expensive than their price, and would make a nice looking gift.I tested the out in comparison to a pair of older apple earbuds, and listened to everything from havey base old school rap, jazz, classical and pop tunes.  The mid and highs on the buds are good, but I found the base and fullness of sound to be fine but not as good as the apple buds.  They sit comfortably in the ear, and, unlike apple earbuds, are certainly highly noise isolating.  I did notice that because of the tight isolation, any abrasion to the braided chord would sound transmitted to my ears, which would mildly interfere with the sound.On the whole, awesome first impression, and ok performance.  For the price, they look nicer than they cost, and their performance is probably on par with price point.I received these for an unbiased review.
giving it 4 stars because I only received one battery not two like it said in add. the one battery does work great on my 168 LED high power video camera light.
I love this bag so much. It looks cute n matches everything I have for my daughter. I love zebra print. So I was very happy when I received it in the mail. well worth the money
good working keyboard perfect for the price.

This is a fun, inexpensive bath toy that is supposed to serve a double purpose of testing the bath water temp. The problem is, the duck thinks almost all water is too hot, even if it is Luke warm. So, if you're looking for a true gauge of safety, I wouldn't rely on this. I use a good quality instant read thermometer to test water temp. However, I do love that it doesn't have any air holes and therefore doesn't fill up with water (that is hard to get our and gets stinky over long term). It is cute, fun to play with, and easy to clean!

bought this for my granddaughter she hated baths and hates being cold. This bath tub really soothed her to where she didn't fuss at all she actually enjoyed the bath! It looks so comfy for her too she loved it. Thank you FP for a great tub.
Best coffee and price. If you like grind your own beans to get that fresh taste then eight o'clock is the way go.
Works great for cleaning down in some tight place in firearms.

I use several different sizes of Avery labels, and recommend the entire line. These labels let me print out full-page shipping labels which go onto boxes and envelopes. Professional appearance, and I don't have to search for the Scotch tape!
These rolls are super strong and a great value. I give these a thumbs up and will be ordering more!

Just the right size for left overs for one person microwave safe dishwasher safe and can be used in the freezer. Good for preparing food in advance can store in refrigerator or froze for a later date, just take out the night before, quick and easy when you get home from work just pop in microwave and enjoy.
I love these brushes for cleaning. I have used toothbrushes for ages. These are perfect, more sturdy and well built. Great for cleaning grout!

No more fear of using a slicer, grater or knives! I just received these to begin drying apples. The apples needed slicing on a mandolin slicer as well as to be peeled. With my new gloves on, I deliberately slid my finger across the grader - not even a pick in the glove. I was impressed. Also, no issues whatsoever with using the slicer. I am thankful for having these, only wish I would have had them years ago, would have saved me lots of pain! easy to clean I just leave them on and put dish soap on them and wash them like your washing your hands rinse and hang them to dry. DON'T put in dryer. well worth the money will buy these again if and when the time comes.

I am glad we spent a little more for this model. It is very sturdy being all metal and does a fantastic job slicing. I'm looking forward to trying out the other blade for slicing really thin. Cleaning is somewhat of a chore but is disassembles rather easily. look closely at purchasing a food grade lubricant or you will need to use Vaseline to lubricate it. I also would invest in a pair of High Performance Level 5 Food Grade Cut Resistant Gloves for Protection when handling the blade there cheaper then a trip to the ER.
This seasoning is fantastic. First time we have tried it and we really liked it. Lots of great comments from friends.Try it - you will not be disappointed.

I bought this Chef's Choice 615 slicer to replace my old Nesco slicer and it works fantastic. I use it mainly for slicing beef/venison for jerky. this blade also works great for slicing paper thin deli-style meat. I would recommend getting a pair of Food Grade Kitchen Level 5 Cut Resistant Gloves to wear when washing the blade. they're cheaper then a trip to the ER. I think this blade was worth the money and would buy again.
works ok not the best though
I downloaded it since it keep bugging me to upgrade it and now the videos I try to watch take FOREVER to load and it lags.
this stuff works great on my food slicer, jerky gun, and sausage stuffer among other things will buy again.

Absolutely phenomenal mouse. I had previously bought a mouse from Amazon but it was extremely huge and heavy. This one is lightweight and easy to use. The middle mouse button is a little hard to push down, but it scrolls amazingly. The DPI changer works as well! Remember to buy (2) AAA batteries since the mouse doesn't come with them.

Great keyboard. Case fits perfectally. Connects with no problems. Wish that tablet screen turned off when case closes, and sometimes if keyboard is left on, then keys will depress when closed, but very minor inconvenience IMO compared to the $100 dollars more it would have cost to purchase Samsung or Logitech brand. Very happy with purchase.

I absolutely love this tablet!! I was in the market for buying the note 10.1 2014 edition but when I found out about the note pro 12.2, I knew that the additional screen size would come in more handy for note taking for school, internet browsing, media consumption, etc. The added multitasking features such as having four apps opened at the same time come in very handy when doing research, jotting down notes, and writing a word document all at the same time! A lot of people are saying that it is too big, but I have not had an issue with that at all and you come to get used to it quite fast. The Hancom office suite that comes with the tablet is the closest to microsoft office that I have ever seen on any mobile platform and simply better than any app out there that I have seen so far, for those interested on having a similar experience as the microsoft office apps. The Spen features come in very handy for note taking, drawing, cutting and pasting pictures or objects onto some other documebts or apps. Knowing that it uses wacom software technology, this allows the spen to have pressure sensitivity on the tablet which straight out beats and puts to shame any ordinary stylus out there. Ever since getting this tablet mainly for use at college, I have never once pulled out a paper and pencil since I now do it all on the note pro, thus possibly saving me money on buying paper and pencils/pens while also giving me a better experience than I can get out of paper and pencil. The note pro 12.2 is simply a beast of a device as I have not had any issues at all with the software because it has 3gb of ram so it allows multiple apps to run at once without slowing down the device nor causing any hiccups or freezing. No other device can stand up to this note pro 12.2, the kindles and ipads have nothing on this device. Im not here to rip on any of those two devices, im simply just stating what is true because none of those two allow you to do as much as the note pro 12.2 allows you to do. I know this device is not cheap, but it is worth every dollar if you are looking for a very capable device for work/school with lots of power and multitasking features.
My favorite part of this app is how I can choose topics that interest me without having to watch a whole broadcast. The full shows are good too, I just appreciate the option
perfect for my stall shower which has no window. it keeps shower area well lit while giving the privacy. when i need to replace it, i will buy the same from this brand. thanks.

they do the job ... they look like they are tough enough that they are not going to break ... combine with a nice blue and white shower-curtain, like I got from Amazon ... just be sure you get them all on facing the same direction so it doesn't look like you live in a man-cave.

these bags work great and buying them in bulk saves lots of money!! I would definitely buy them again! I love having the different sizes without having to cut off a roll!

I have always known the movie 'Deliverance' because of the dueling banjos tune and that is why I finally wanted to see this movie. Turns out that this is one of the best movies I have seen in a long long time.It is the story of four Atlanta businessmen on a rafting trip. While on the river they encounter some 'crackers'. One of the four gets raped and the other almost before one of the businessmen (someone who does not believe in law) kills the attacker with an arrow. Because the whole valley will be flooded soon they decide to leave the body there and tell no one. The one with a heavy heart falls overboard however.What is right? What is wrong? are questions asked in this movie and no one is sure. The movie is very disturbing, a strange look into the human mind and human society and also that part of the world where civilization as we know it does not exist.The duelling banjos are fun, but the movie is really good.

I’ve been using this vacuum flask bottle to take cold juice with me to work every day for the last three weeks. Though the bottle needs to sit in my truck for about five hours before I get my lunch break, my juice always tastes fresh-from-the-fridge cold and ready to drink. The flask’s screw-on top has an ergonomic design that makes removal easy, even with dirty or sweat-streaked hands. Cold water, hot coffee, or juice: ready for a desperately thirsty worker to drink.And it comes with a handy small insert that I couldn’t figure out at first. It sits inside the mouth of the bottle, holds about two teaspoons of something, and is perforated on the bottom. It took me a while to realize this is a tea infuser. Put hot or warm water into your bottle, slip the infuser with some loose leaf tea into the top so water comes through the perforations, and by lunchtime, your tea is ready to drink. How handy is that?I received this product from the manufacturer, at their own expense, in return for an honest opinion. As always, all opinions expressed are strictly my own.

Since I started working construction earlier this year, I've learned one absolute rule: keep your tools on your person. Not only do you not know what you need until you need it, but tools set aside have an annoying propensity to walk away. But jeans only have so many pockets. The easiest way to deal with that is to get yourself some added pockets that you can carry around with you. Like, say, this.This tool pouch is made of heavyweight leather, chain-stitched on the edges with what appears to by nylon thread. Many points through the center are reinforced with rivets, like classic Levi's. It has different sized pockets to hold a range of tools, everything from small narrow slip pockets for your pen or your tire gauge, to metal loops to catch your claw hammer, to long narrow pockets sized appropriately for standard pry bars, utility knives, and speed squares. I like having everything right there. And I like that, because this isn't a complete belt, I can place it wherever I want it, and know where to grab my tools.So far, I've had no complaints about this system. It has withstood use and abuse, and simplifies the requirements of my job. It's constructed solidly enough that I feel confident doing multiple job-related tasks under a range of conditions. I've read some other reviewers say this system *might* come apart under repeated use, but it's done me quite well so far. If you have to carry a range of tools, and grab them at a moment's notice, this system may take a great deal of pressure off an already complicated job situation.

I knew I was probably facing a difficult slog with this novel in Chapter One, one character took three pages to descend a staircase. Not because she was slow-moving, or descending from the highest tower, but because author Staub kept intruding long expository recollections between steps. That set the tone for this entire novel: it’s difficult to make even incremental progress, because even minor actions trigger rambling recollections.In today’s networked age, local actions have potentially global circumstances. Meredith Heywood is the unofficial mother hen of a blogger’s circle, comprised entirely of breast cancer patients and survivors. These women have built a transnational friendship, without bothering to meet, or in some cases to learn one another’s real names. So Meredith’s death prompts their first-ever meeting, at her funeral. Too bad Meredith was actually murdered.Staub crafts a massive ensemble for a modernized, tech-friendly rendition of a classic Agatha Christie locked-room mystery. At its heart, the women bloggers have deep connections which they’ve shared only online. They believe they know one another intensely, but with passing scenes, it transpires that each keeps deep secrets they don’t divulge digitally. One of these friends has mysterious motives. And now they’re all in danger.But upon this intriguing premise, Staub has layered countless, disjointed internal monologues. Every character has a backstory, expounded interminably, whether they advance the story or not. The cast of thousands each get their own moments, to the detriment of pacing. Single conversations challenge readers’ patience, because between successive exchanges, Staub inserts Proustian recollections, sometimes pages long. The promised mystery never quite begins, because these recollections never quite cease.I wanted to enjoy this book, but Staub wouldn’t let me. In today’s media-saturated age, authors realistically get about thirty pages to engage readers’ attention in books this long; but well past page 100, Staub still indulges in chugging expository scene-setting. The narrow thematic focus prevents this being a Jane Austen-ish character novel, but Staub’s interminable narration doesn’t let it be a mystery. I tried, but I just got bored.

Because I work construction, which often involves close detail work in confined spaces where built-in lights haven’t been installed, having a flashlight is frequently very important—all the more so as winter rolls in and we board up windows that haven’t been glassed in. This pocket-sized flashlight provides illumination for diverse tasks in less-than-ideal circumstances. I’ve only had it about a week, and I’ve already gotten enough use from it to justify the (admittedly modest) price.It has multiple brightness settings, making it ideal for a range of tasks: sometimes you need only a dim glow, just enough light to line up screws and drive them in securely. Other times you need light bright enough to read instructions and perform kludge repairs on power tools. And sometimes—probably more in the car than at work—you need a flashing strobe that will get people’s attention and let passers-by know you require immediate assistance. This one does all of that.It’s not perfect. Though it advertises that a simple tug turns it into a camp lantern, even at full brightness the lantern function isn’t very bright. The single LED light source, which shines pretty well when it’s focused into a narrow cone, becomes diffuse enough when spread out to be functionally useless. Though someone might use the lantern function to avoid being trapped in pitch blackness during a power outage, it’s not bright enough to do camp functions like cook or build a fire.Therefore I must conclude that this light, though useful for most circumstances where you’ll need a flashlight, is imperfect. Most people probably won’t notice the imperfections in most practical circumstances. When you need a flashlight, you usually need a tight beam, which this energy-efficient beauty provides. So if you’re seeking a cheap, long-lived beam flashlight, consider this one. Just don’t expect the lantern to do you much good in camp conditions.The manufacturer offered me a sample of this product, at their own expense, in return for an honest review. As always, opinions expressed are strictly my own.

Francis Bacon has grown bored and lovelorn in London. No, not that Francis Bacon, the other one: the Anglo-Irish figurative painter whose tortured, distorted human forms revolutionized postwar British art. So he follows his paramour and sometime torturer David to colonial Morocco, a paradise of anonymous sex and late imperial exoticism. Once in Tangier, however, he finds a warren of crime, including a mysterious murder tied to local art forgery.Though this is American novelist Janice Law’s third, and reputedly final, “Francis Bacon Mystery,” the book itself is functionally freestanding. It doesn’t require any particular familiarity with prior novels, or Francis Bacon, or art generally, to grasp Law’s narrative of cruel romance, venal empire, and postwar chicanery. Though marketed as a mystery, Law essentially crafts a tale of character and circumstance, which just coincidentally involves fraud and murder.Bacon simply wants to drink copiously and romance as many Moroccan “beach boys” as limited time and money allow. When one prominently flamboyant party host’s newly purchased Picasso proves forged, however, the local constable blackmails Francis into joining the investigation. Seems they have a blank warrant for David’s arrest, which they’ll sign if he doesn’t comply. Thus Francis becomes an unwilling, but entirely too proficient, art counterfeiter.When it appears everybody lies about this deeply conflicted case, nobody appears particularly surprised, except perhaps Francis himself. The police have political motivations that don’t involve aestheticism or intellectual property. The party host proves remarkably duplicitous when the spotlight shines elsewhere. When Francis finds himself stalked by a suspiciously James Bond-like agent of the British Legation, he realizes he’s stumbled into a case with truly international implications.Tangier, in Law’s telling, has a familiar yet discordant ring. As a colonial capital, it catches every expatriate the European homeland doesn’t want to see. But unlike Bogart’s Casablanca, this African melting pot doesn’t catch diverse wartime refugees fleeing Naziism and generalized homeland oppression; Tangier caters specifically to sexual outcasts, the bon vivants and sybarites forced into exile from Continental homes where homosexuality remains wholly illegal.David, the man who induced Bacon’s newfound expat status, is the consummate charming abuser. A masterful musician and storyteller when sober, a raconteur of wartime extravagance, his fondness for gin transforms him into a knife-wielding psychopath. Francis admits his fondness for “rough trade,” but also opens his narrative by fleeing into a hog barn overnight to avoid David’s homicidal wrath. The romance apparently flees rough trade pretty quickly.Yet Francis remains steadfastly willing to defend David, whose distant but amorous attentions combine mentor, lover, and big brother in equal, and equally terrifying, measures. The fact that neither Francis nor David remains particularly faithful reflects, not homosexuals’ innate moral corruption, but how pliable ethics become under circumstances of official oppression. As first-person narrator Francis explains, police often serve traumatic beat-downs to “beach boys” for sport.Readers selecting this book for gripping mystery may find this book awkwardly slow-moving compared to contemporary thrillers. Law doesn’t expend energy on creating complex mental puzzles, and though she does well in concealing her culprit, she doesn’t particularly care about red herrings and other familiar tropes. For Law’s money, historic Tangier and its milieu of Crumbled Empire decadence holds more interest. This is mainly a historical novel and costume drama.And what a historical novel. More literate critics than I have extolled Law’s scrupulous attention to detail. Where less meticulous authors have recently frustrated me for their willingness to compromise accuracy to create a better-selling paperback, Law creates a narrative for audiences who desire the more difficult journey. Like visiting a foreign land, one gets the feeling nothing here is sanitized for modern Anglo-American sentiments. Bacon’s Tangier is very dangerous.This painstaking accuracy sometimes results in moments that make modern readers distinctly uncomfortable. Watching the revolutionary independence movement evolve from their rooftop divans, Bacon and David are sometimes prone to observations we’d call racist. And although I balk at modern complaints about “cultural appropriation,” Bacon’s tendency to regard Moroccan culture as a profligate shopping trip uncomfortably reduces African culture to a shopping mall. As imperial conquerors often do.But these very uncomfortable moments contribute to the immediacy of Law’s narrative. As Bacon navigates Tangier’s difficult political byroads, we sympathize with him, while still realizing he’s a colonial monster. We want him to win, but not too much. Where suit-clad Bogart represented a pre-war antihero model, Bacon epitomizes postwar moral collapse. His narrative is immersive, and perilous. And we emerge wondering: how much am I like these colonial taskmasters?

If you’ve ever felt adrift in today’s technological world, helpless amid infinite options, unable to make meaningful decisions in buying or reading or even just watching five hundred TV channels, you’re not alone. UCLA behavioral economist Shlomo Benartzi has reliable scientific evidence demonstrating what perceptive people already know, that today’s online environment creates a panicked, lost-in-the-woods feeling in most people. Fortunately, wise engineering can reverse this paralyzing trend.From its earliest origins, pro-Web enthusiasm has gushed over the Internet’s capacity to provide users more information, more choices, and more autonomy. It’s been the classic capitalist assertion, that simply having more options available flushes bad choices away and consolidates good choices. But anyone who’s shopped for consumer electronics online recently knows that simply having more choices isn’t good enough. Without guidance, increased options generate snap judgments, haste, and paralysis.Benartzi himself has participated in new research demonstrating how screen users handle information overload. His conclusion, based on his own research and the published discoveries of his peers: human attention isn’t adapted for broad, undifferentiated knowledge dumps. (Anyone who’s read government reports recently knows this.) Wise information merchants going forward will need to make the digital screen conform to what Benartzi calls “the mental screen”—our attention capacity.“It's not that screens are making us more superficial,” Benartzi writes. “Rather, the world of screens merely makes it easier for us to act on those superficial first impressions.” We gravitate toward first options, self-indulgence, and whatever’s placed in the center of the screen. When people order food digitally, Benartzi says (with generous scholarly evidence), we’re more likely to pick unhealthy options. When we get doused with a firehose of buying options, we pick familiar images, not good choices.Too often, Benartzi and his sources claim, humans rely upon facile heuristics to comprehend digital resources. (Anyone who’s read Daniel Kahneman already knows this, but Benartzi proves how this applies specifically to screens.) We think better when we enjoy instant feedback… until we become overwhelmed. We think in purely present-tense terms, unless prompted. Simple design tweaks can transform not only our experiences, but our thinking about those experiences.Similar tweaks have the potential for abuse. Benartzi describes circumstances where unscrupulous operators have manipulated screen options to maximize unfair trades, and places where even worse abuse is possible. Some online vendors, for instance, have gotten caught spotlighting more expensive options on mobile devices than on computers, because apparently the smaller the screen, the smaller our attention to detail. Crooked vendors manipulate our impatience and forgetfulness for venal ends.This tendency has remarkable ramifications. As America enters an election season, unprecedented numbers of voters will garner political opinions from articles read online. This seems innocent, except we don’t read well off screens. Benartzi writes: “screens allow us to read more than ever before, but they also encourage us to read poorly, and to remember less of what we read.” Screens encourage casual, unengaged, incomplete reading… and thinking.Every fault Benartzi describes, though, has easy fixes. Some involve top-end design improvements. Counterintuitive as it seems, evidence demonstrates that we read better when confronted with clunky, inelegant typefaces. When confronted by endless buying choices (Amazon sells over 100,000 breakfast cereal varieties), categories help us prevent getting overwhelmed and numb. The disastrous Healthcare.gov rollout could’ve been salvaged with March Madness-style brackets.Benartzi also suggests end-user improvements, though these are less numerous. In giving feedback, for instance, actually sign your name; this prevents the Disinhibition Effect. Seek carefully for resources which encourage without criticizing and which have meaningful action plans. Allocate attention carefully: it’s impossible to actually read those bottomless “terms and conditions” we all click on, but when somebody asks you a real question, read the whole thing before answering.The answers aren’t always easy, and seldom one-size-fits-all. The problem with digital reading, for instance, has different solutions for different audiences. Younger readers will probably finish reading this review better on Amazon’s brightly colored, graphics-heavy layout, while my blog’s muted colors and text-driven format will attract older readers. Other problems have similarly nuanced solutions. My final takeaway from Benartzi’s explanation: effective design is more art than science.Late in this book, Benartzi states what could arguably be his thesis: “We don't want endless possibility. What we really crave is effective curation.” The Internet has become a vast repository of information, much of it exciting, some terrifying; and new information gets created or repackaged daily. Top-level providers who follow Benartzi’s guidelines will more likely earn users’ attention, today’s real economic prize.

If you need an inexpensive polo shirt to wear to the company picnic or a casual night out, this one might be a good place to start. It fits like a t-shirt, has a collar that stands up nicely, and pairs well with your choice of sport coat, jacket, flannel shirt, or other garment. (It’s thin enough that, if you wear it by itself, you’ll want an undershirt.) It lacks a breast pocket, so if you’re accustomed to carrying stuff right there, you may want to make sure you’re wearing trousers with a pen pocket, or something. But if you need something casual without looking slovenly, something between business wear and sweats, this perfectly pleasant and reasonably priced middle-weight shirt deserves a second look of your time.

Let’s not kid ourselves: in our society, we pass snap judgments on women for their bustlines, and men for their hairlines. It’s unfair, but that doesn’t make it any less real. I’ve been dismissed by women, mocked by men, and insulted by anonymous persons online for my vastly receding hairline. If I had a firm, butch halo like Ed Harris, that wouldn’t be any problem, but the patchy ghost of hair I have doesn’t reflect the smart, assertive guy I actually am.So when the manufacturer offered me a chance to sample and review this product at no obligation, I jumped at the chance. After taking the full thirty-day supply, I can say I’m glad I did. Though my widow’s peak and bald spot have not yet filled back in, I have baby-fine new hair growing into those spaces, while my existing halo is growing in thicker and darker—my few grays are actually getting color back in them. I’m not back to my hirsute twenties yet, but my hair does look better.This product works by blocking dihydrotestosterone, a more potent androgen than the common testosterone in male bodies. As with the high dose of female hormones used in hormonal birth control pills, DHT is an example of too much of a good thing: rather than doing what androgens ought to do, like putting hair on your chest and muscles on your arms, DHT actually overpowers and blocks these functions. And it causes certain forms of male pattern baldness.As the accompanying sequence of photos shows, after taking the full thirty-day regimen, I don’t have the full head I enjoyed as an undergraduate. This isn’t a miracle drug; like new hair growing on a baby’s head, it will take some time to fully revitalize all your follicles. However, the photos clearly show that, in just one month, my hair has already begun reversing the decline that I’ve suffered over the last decade. I’ve decided, having used up my sample supply, to buy more and make this part of my regular routine.The manufacturer offered me a sample supply of this supplement, at their own expense, in return for an honest review. As always, all opinions expressed are strictly my own.

Unless you’ve lived or worked in China since 2010, you’ve probably never encountered Earth’s third-largest mobile phone company, Xiaomi. The company, whose name translates as “Little Rice” in Chinese, currently dominates China’s mid-range smartphone market. Despite having no market presence in North America or Europe, Xiaomi’s global aspirations have flourished, and in five years, it has progressed from geek-oriented software startup to punching above its weight class.Clay Shirky, NYU professor and new media cheerleader, sees Xiaomi as emblematic, not of the mobile phone industry, but of China’s changing place in global technology leadership. China has a lengthy reputation as America’s favorite offshore dumping ground; Apple famously labels its products “Designed In California; Assembled In China.” But as Chinese manufacturers become increasingly comfortable with American designs, many have assumed the design role and created native products domestically.If you’ve experienced the existential dread of realizing you’ve forgotten your phone, you understand how important networked mobile technology has become. This goes double for poor countries. As rising technology puts mobile phones within mass customer reach, villagers in Africa and Asia who cannot afford laptops, cars, or books, nevertheless have global access with affordable phones. Networked mobile access puts poor, distant villagers on (theoretically) equal footing with everyone else.Shirky quotes technology maven Jan Chipchase that mobile phones have joined money and keys as the three things without which we cannot leave the house. This presents China unprecedented opportunity and unique obstacles. Mainland China remains among Earth’s last nominally Communist nations, though “Communist” now means more party control than economic principle. Mobile phones offer instant global access to information, but also permit instantaneous coordination, anathema to one-party states.Xiaomi straddles this complicated line. The corporation got its start pitching an open-source Android variant operating system, crowdsourcing critical design elements. This democratic hybrid business model remains central to Xiaomi’s success, even as they’ve transitioned into hardware development. But the corporation must tapdance between the Party’s twin mandates of unprecedented personal liberty, and absolute political autocracy. Xiaomi’s technology must permit everyone to do everything… except challenge the state.Chinese President Xi Jinping has recently pushed something he calls the Chinese Dream. Unlike Maoist slogans of expunging both ancient and Western influences, Xi’s vision has a distinctive monetary value. Like the American Dream, the Chinese Dream involves home ownership, wealth management, and upward mobility. However, it infuses distinct collectivist tenets into its language. Xi wants Chinese to become wealthy in ways that redound positively upon the state.China actively restricts domestic access to global Internet sources. Chinese citizens can access Amazon, Gmail, and other international sites through demi-legal network loopholes, and enforcement runs two-tiered for elites versus plebeians. Whatever advances business and globalization, the Party deems good, or anyway tacitly permits; whatever permits citizens to organize, coordinate, or pitch any alternative to the state, the Party squashes. (State speech codes forbid puns, to excise double meanings.)This creates market narrowing for Chinese firms outside China. Shirky describes how, when Xiaomi first marketed phones in South Asia, Indian media generated panic that Xiaomi was shipping user data into China. Well, all mobile service providers store metadata on native server farms; Apple and Samsung do it. Their servers merely dwell in non-totalitarian states. Xiaomi, by contrast, must simultaneously appease state officials and free-market buyers, a difficult global sell.For Shirky, Xiaomi isn’t another corporation, despite its massive size (its market is huge enough to dwarf international firms while remaining primarily locked inside China’s borders). Rather, Xiaomi represents China’s strange relationship with modernity. China has become economically free but politically restricted; socially diverse but ethnically homogenous; global yet totalitarian. If it survives ten more years, the People’s Republic will become history’s longest-lived one-party state.Thus China is already making history, even if that history feels muddled to technocratic Western observers. It’s yoked competing influences together, with apparent success, and seems to be winning the global three-legged race. But China’s aggregate wealth hasn’t translated into individual well-being; the typical Chinese citizen remains poor by world standards. How information firms like Xiaomi fare in coming years will define how China faces today’s global situation.Shirky’s writing combines journalism with technical expertise to describe powerful conflicting influences which will define global market considerations within our lifetimes. Xiaomi’s rapid advance, from zygote to market dominance inside five years, and its odd, counterintuitive business model, are symbolic, for Shirky, of China’s changing role in global economics. To understand China through analogy, Shirty says, let’s understand Xiaomi. That isn’t easy, but it’s decidedly unnerving.

I confess, when the manufacturer offered me these cloths for review, I had my doubts. When I heard they were woven from bamboo fibers, I feared they’d feel like jute, hemp, and other non-cotton natural fibers: lump, itchy, and prone to disintegrate after a few washings. It makes me very happy in this case that I find myself proven wrong.Popping these washcloths from the package (they come in a six-pack), I noticed they were baby-soft and very thin. Don’t let the lack of thickness fool you. These are as sturdy as any terry washcloths you already own, and you can lather them up with soap, shaving foam, baby wash, or whatever you’d like. They’ll spread your lather widely and efficiently, without the coarse texture that irritates a baby’s skin… or your own freshly shaved skin.And despite their light weight, they hold up to multiple washings. I got a huge splotch of blood on one of these when I cut myself shaving, and failed to blot it out right away. This cloth shed the stain after only one washing, which would take several washings with my cotton washcloth. Washing my face with this soft cloth simply feels good after a warm shave.These cloths are designed for babies’ tender skin. But lemme tell you, once you use one on your own face and body, you’ll keep your own cloths in reserve for washing yourself. I’d simply resigned myself to the idea that lathering with a washcloth meant cotton terry. But this stuff makes cotton feel downright unpleasant. This will quickly become your favored washcloth.The manufacturer offered me these cloths at their own expense in exchange for an honest review. As always, all opinions expressed are strictly my own.

I find it refreshing that historian Gil Troy doesn’t conceal personal positions behind mealy-mouthed bipartisanship attempts. Around this book’s one-quarter mark, he writes: “Clinton’s alluring idealism, passion for people, and atomic smarts mixed unstably with a hard-edged will to power, a puppy-dog neediness, and a super-human buoyancy--during a time of cultural, technological, and economic upheaval.” This perfectly encapsulates Troy’s attempt to do everything at once, with predictably chaotic results.Gil Troy, whose published bibliography includes multiple collaborations with the progressive historian Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr., proposes with this book to create an overview of the entire 1990s, with Bill Clinton as emblem of the era. Like Reagan in the 1980s or FDR in the 1930s, Clinton’s name is so linked with his American decade that we cannot explain one without another. Troy proposes to examine person and time together.His success seems, at best, mixed. In early chapters, before Clinton’s campaign and presidency, his emphasis lies on a synoptic overview of the spotlighted years. Once Bill entered national affairs, however, Troy’s focus shifts to personality. On occasion, he resembles the “gotcha” journalists he mocks and deplores within his text. Though Troy putatively approaches his subject with historians’ dispassion, I find myself wondering what subtextual purpose he’s really pursuing.Troy lards his exposition, at seemingly random intervals, with weasel words and personal imprecations: Bill had not dodged, but “slithered past the draft.” Troy characterizes Clinton’s administration as “campaign kids” versus “professional grown-ups.” Or he repeats talk radio ad hominem attacks, often without endnote citations: Hillary’s leadership in Health Care Reform and other issues struck Americans as “Byzantine and Stalinist.” Troy comes across as a moralizing jerk.But weirdly, Troy also exempts Clinton from his most cutting contemporary criticism. From the very prologue, Troy emphasizes Clinton's success injecting centrist morality into conventional Democratic politics; yet he wholly writes out Clinton's critics from the moral Left, like Reverend Jim Wallis or Rabbi Michael Lerner. The latter contributed heavily to Hillary's “Politics of Meaning” speech, which Troy acknowledges as her biggest early misstep, and found himself exiled for it.In fairness, Rabbi Lerner himself kept mum about such issues for over a decade. If Troy wants to examine a particular decade, citing sources not written until 2006 might arguably seem reasonable. But Reverend Wallis had no such compunctions. He openly criticized President Clinton as early as 1995. He certainly had audience enough to receive and repeat his criticisms. Why then doesn’t he merit precious column inches?This complex “what to leave in, what to leave out” issue persistently confounds Troy’s narrative. Early on, Troy declares his intent to focus on preponderantly domestic issues. Foreign policy, while perhaps interesting, lies too far afield for our purposes. But then Troy offers only hat-tip acknowledgments of the Defense of Marriage Act and the Glass-Steagall Act repeal, the two pieces of domestic policy that debatably most defined Clinton’s lingering legacy.Policy little interests Troy; he’d rather talk personalities. George Stephanopolous; Zoe Baird; Ken Starr; Vince Foster. That’s saying nothing of more rabble-rousing personalities, like Rush Limbaugh, whose popularity peaked during Clinton’s first term. Troy busily name-checks every personnel misstep and media gadfly, while spending little time on actual Clinton accomplishments, that I felt less like I’d read a comprehensive history, more like I’d dived into a morass of tabloid journalism redux.Meanwhile, the decade itself gets some sporadic treatment. Remember, the 1990s saw tech-stock CEOs getting rock-star treatment, appearing on Rolling Stone covers, speaking to applauding stadium crowds, making millions on stock offerings that actually produced nothing. With the Cold War over, American attention spans wavered on countless brightly colored do-funnies and financial mousetraps. Troy mentions some, but lingers on not one long enough for true comprehension.Full disclosure: I’m no Clinton loyalist. During the 1990s, I voted Republican, but converted to liberalism after 9/11. Since then, I’ve drifted toward Distributism, a Third Way political-economic theory based on moral precepts. Bill Clinton’s willingness to appease his opponents (cf. Ian Haney López or Barry Glassner) strike me, then as now, as craven. And anyone expecting anything different from Mrs. Clinton seems incredibly nave.That said, Troy’s low-tension, milquetoast synopsis will satisfy neither inveterate Clinton haters nor died-in-the-wool True Believers. He surveys the decade with great breadth but little depth, often stumbling into the very traps he contends doomed Clinton’s contemporaries. I simply learned more reading Conason and Lyons’ The Hunting of the President. Too flimsy for readers my age, too superficial for younger readers, this book just drifts.The author's publicist provided me a copy of this book, at their own expense, in exchange for an honest review. As always, opinions stated are my own.
