This feels like our reward for remembering the old days. It’s every inch Morse’s successor without being its knock-off. I love it. If you watched Morse, you probably will too.

I'm of two minds about energy drinks. Too often they taste medicinal, and besides being loaded with caffeine and sugar, many have dangerously high levels of vitamin B complex. But since I started working construction, I've needed those very qualities to finish a workday. What's a blue collar boy to do?Unlike many other energy drinks, this one doesn't taste like cough syrup. It has a rich, distinctive fruit flavor, like a cherry soda, but not. This makes it easy to drink when time is scarce. It also has a muscular kick that gets me through a long, slow weekday when my brain wants to wander off early. Between them, these are just what I need.Nobody should drink energy drinks every day. Like fast food or painkillers, they're meant for occasional consumption. However, on those days I really need a jumpstart, this one is quite handy for that, being both effective and tasty. It's just a convenient tool to keep on hand, and I like it.

Back around the middle 1990s, the Centre Pompidou, one of France’s nerve centers of public intellectualism, commissioned Marxist philosopher Jacques Rancière to write mid-length essays coinciding with exhibitions of film and art, respectively. These essays provided snapshots into Rancière’s thought, without needing to grasp his exceedingly dense prose stylings. But the essays languished unreprinted, and untranslated into English, for nearly twenty years. Until now.These essays, one on historical film and one on art-on-canvas, focus a socially engaged conviction onto Twentieth Century art expression. Such artworks, Rancière contends, represent a distinct relationship with power. This may reflect the power exhibited by traditional control centers— he commences by describing a powerful general instructing peasants how to kneel before the czar— or the power artists exercise in determining what does, or doesn’t, merit immortalization in art.Rancière, whom humanist thinkers would consider a patron saint of the 1968 uprisings if sainthood didn’t require transcendence, maintains a sideline in modernist aesthetics. Yet for him, as for George Orwell, art and politics are inextricable: all art carries a message, and that message resonates with institutions of power. Art may lack political party, but it exists within a social continuum of power and subordination. Rancière purposes to pick this continuum apart.Reading these essays involves a trade-off. Anyone familiar with Twentieth Century French philosophy knows authors pride themselves on hermetic inscrutability; finding a thesis or through-line is often prohibitively difficult. So it remains here; but in exchange, these two essays together total under 100 pages, and are essentially self-contained. This permits more casual reading, since you needn’t have savvied Rancière’s preceding corpus, though it never becomes easy.For Rancière, “history” isn’t some objective facts which students can memorize. We constantly make and remake history, he contends, with the stories we tell about the past. Rancière, in the second, and probably more digestible, essay, identifies “four senses of history” and “three forms of history [art].” Therefore, many debates active today about how to utilize history in the present exist because people don’t realize they’re using different sense and different forms.In Rancière’s first essay, he focuses on historical representations in cinema, both documentary and artistic. The camera, he says, is essentially an instrument of power: it shows what directors, writers, and in state-controlled media, what politicians want it to show. Yet being inanimate, its power is offset by remarkable passivity. This tension comes across in storytelling techniques that combine staunch realism with novelistic narrative. The combination, he implies, sits uneasy.His second essay deals with painting, though its implications could apply to all static art. He particularly focuses on modernist aesthetic, which distorts and upends conventional historical narratives. This sometimes involves ventures into the pre-modernist milieu that nurtured modernism; he particularly appreciates the twin threads of rebelliousness and commercialism implied in Francisco Goya’s works. This reflects how art simultaneously challenges and appeases power.Rancière’s choice of source material may stymie non-Francophone readers. His film essay name-checks multiple art films, mostly French and German, mostly from the 1980s and 1990s, which you’ve probably never seen. Throughout his art essay, I recognized only two named artists, Goya and Warhol. The book provides no reference illustrations, a severe limitation; I found myself searching images on my smartphone every few minutes. Digital image-checkers will aid in reading.Nevertheless, Rancière provides an engaging survey of how visual arts read history. His revisionist Marxist perspective shines throughout his telling; for him, aesthetics inevitably reflect power structures, an interpretation that certainly won’t sit with the “I just want to be entertained” crowd. However, as he carefully dismantles the unspoken assumptions permeating art’s sweeping gestalt, it’s hard to deny his viewpoint may have some legitimate foundation.This book strikes a difficult balance. It isn’t easy fun-time reading, certainly. But compared to most philosophy by living thinkers, Rancière included, it’s remarkably accessible, with an eye toward audiences who haven’t already exhaustively read Rancière’s back catalog. This makes an interesting introduction to contemporary Marxist aesthetic, or an alternate viewpoint for art and film buffs. But however you elect to read it, rest assured, it asks questions you’ll struggle to answer.

I have two other Bluetooth speakers from this manufacturer, so I opened the package with high expectations. And this product didn't disappoint. It's slightly longer than my palm, and the width is such that I can wrap my fist around it. Too big to make it disappear like a coin onstage, but small enough to fit in a coat pocket or the outside pocket of your attache case. It's also plenty big enough to carry your music, your audio book, or to double as a speakerphone attachment for voice calls.As I said, I found this speaker every bit equal to others I've owned from this same manufacturer, in terms of its sound ability. But just to be sure, I tried an experiment: I took this puppy to work with me. I work construction, and between the sounds of various motorized equipment, power tools, people shouting, and general outdoor noise from the adjoining street, my workplace has no concept of the word "quiet." What better place to test a speaker's quality than a place where the ambient noise level is always high?The sound quality proved more than sufficient to compete with ordinary sound. When I had to run an electric hammer drill, or when one of the forklifts drove twenty feet away, my music continued loud and clear. It couldn't compete with exceptional sound, like when I had to fire up my diesel-powered scissor lift and run the engine up to the second story. But nothing can compete with that; people standing right next to me have to shout to make themselves heard. So this speaker works for ordinary sounds you'll likely encounter.It also has an unusually rich bass line. Though the picture above shows it sitting up, looking unidirectional, and one side does have rubberized feet, suggesting there's a correct way to set this up for regular use, I've found that, if you lay it on its back, the sound radiates outward, capturing the acoustics of the entire room, while accentuating the bass for optimum resonance. This is a very good speaker for music and other audio uses, and will do you proud. (I haven't had a chance to try the speakerphone feature.)So if, like me, you got your smartphone so you could download streaming audio players, or if you want to connect a quality speaker to you mp3 player and make a homemade boom box, this one will do the trick. Just remember, it's a regular speaker, not a loudspeaker, and it'll satisfy your every reasonable demand.Acknowledgements to the manufacturer, who provided a sample for review. As always, my opinions are entirely my own.

I purchased the Daisy Prints in size medium. I love the look, it is so adorable. This is for my 45lb beagle lab because she needs a harness for her runs.The blueberry pet step in harness is easy to put on, a step in harness. It is padded and lined inside so it feels really nice. The stitching is really well done and the quality is excellent. It's easy to adjust and looks great on my dog. She doesn't mind wearing it at all and it feels very secure which is important for me since she is a strong puller and likes to go on runs and sprints.If anyone is wondering if it will fit larger size dogs, I do believe it would fit my 65lb border collie but I haven't put it on her yet because she doesn't need a harness, but if someone wants to know i will try it on her.i received this product for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

My dog is blowing her coat and for the most part it is easy to deal with. But the hair gets on my comforters and it does not come off in the wash no matter what I do. I tried a lint roller and it ended up using an entire lint roller of 56 sheets to get the comforter clean of hair.With this I can get the hair up much faster, and it only takes 1 sheet. Pulls up hair that I wasn't able to get off with multiple other methods.I definitely recommend this if you are having trouble getting pet hair to come off your laundry.

This blueberry pet collar is really well made and nice quality. I have a 45lb beagle lab and a 65lb border collie and the size Medium fits both of them.The collar is padded and lined which makes it feel really nice. I had my dogs wearing kong collars which i have used for years and loved them but I actually love these even more, they are excellent quality.I received this item for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review

My dog is blowing her coat and for the most part it is easy to deal with. But the hair gets on my comforters and it does not come off in the wash no matter what I do. I tried a lint roller and it ended up using an entire lint roller of 56 sheets to get the comforter clean of hair.With this I can get the hair up much faster, and it only takes 1 sheet. Pulls up hair that I wasn't able to get off with multiple other methods.I definitely recommend this if you are having trouble getting pet hair to come off your laundry.

This is very nice quality. It is padded, I have included a picture where you can see the padding on the inside. The colors are very nice as well as the look of it. The collar is extremely well made. My dogs currently have kong collars which I was in love with but I am actually going to switch them over to these because they are nicer.I got the medium which fits my 45lb beagle/lab but it also would fit my 65lb border collie.Disclaimer: I received a complimentary item in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

I got this shirt for my 45lb beagle lab. I got size 16. It fits her but I could probably do the 20 next time. It was easy to put on and most importantly she loves it. The seams seem very well done, high quality. Several people had recommended I try bentonite clay and I am glad a friend gave me a chance to try this product. As a first warning do not mix this clay onto something metal, it will decrease the effectiveness of the clay.I have used this clay for a few things now. Initially I bought it to heal a burn that left a red mark, a pretty large red mark. It's been working on that. I've also started using it on my chin which has helped with the discoloration and blackheads that i thought were permanant dark marks of pores that constantly got blackheads. My chin is clear.I used this as a foot detox as well.The best though, I used this on a boil, and it drew out the gross stuff right away. This will be my go to for boils, as well as bug bites. This works way better than calamine lotion on bug bites.Some info about bentonite incase you don't know:According to Mountain Rose Herbs:“Bentonite, also referred to as Montmorillonite, is one of the most effective and powerful healing clays. Bentonite can be used externally as a clay poultice, mud pack or in the bath and, in skin care recipes. A good quality Bentonite should be a grey/cream color and anything bordering “pure white” is suspect. It has a very fine, velveteen feel and is odorless and non-staining. The type of bentonite offered by Mountain Rose herbs is a Sodium Bentonite.”Bentonite Clay is composed of aged volcanic ash. The name comes from the largest known deposit of Bentonite Clay located in Fort Benton, Wyoming.“Bentonite is a swelling clay. When it becomes mixed with water it rapidly swells open like a highly porous sponge. From here the toxins are drawn into the sponge through electrical attraction and once there, they are bound.”Bentonite clay carries a strong negative charge which bonds to the positive charge in many toxins. When it comes in contact with a toxin, chemical, or heavy metal, the clay will absorb the toxin and release it’s minerals for the body to use. Bentonite also helps get oxygen to cells as it pulls excess hydrogen and allows the cells to replace it with oxygen instead."

Lip balm2 teaspoons pure, filtered, unbleached cosmetic grade beeswax pastilles1 teaspoon organic raw shea butter3 teaspoons organic unrefined coconut oil6 drops of essential oil of choice6 3/16 oz. (5.5 ml) lip balm tubesCombine all of the ingredients in a small sauce pot and put it on the oven on low-medium heat. Stir the mixture until all of the beeswax and shea butter has melted. Turn the burner off and remove the pot from the heat. Fill the lip balm tubes using a funnel. Let the tubes sit undisturbed for 20 minutes to cool and set (leave any spill-over temporarily undisturbed – it is not worth trying to wipe it off right now).After your balm has cooled and set, it is ready to goEasy Homemade Whipped Body Butter RecipeBody Butter:1/2 cup Shea Butter1/2 cup Cocoa Butter or Mango Butter1/2 cup Coconut Oil1/2 cup light oil (like almond, jajoba or olive)Optional: 10-30 drops of essential oils of choiceHow to Make Body ButterIn a double boiler or glass bowl, combine all ingredients except essential oils.Bring to medium heat and stir constantly until all ingredients are melted.Remove from heat and let cool slightly.Move to fridge and let cool another 1 hour or until starting to harden but still somewhat soft.Use a hand mixer to whip for 10 minutes until fluffy.Return to fridge for 10-15 minutes to set.Store in a glass jar with a lid and use as you would regular lotion or body butter. If your home stays above 75 degrees, it may soften and need to be kept at the fridge, but it will stay whipped at a temperature lower than that.Enjoy! (source: wellnessmama)Shea Butter Lotion Bar Sticks Shea Butter Lotion Bar StickShea Butter Lotion Bar Stick Ingredients (great for feet):2 tablespoons raw organic shea butter1 tablespoon unrefined coconut oil- solid at room temp (can use extra shea butter if allergic to coconut)2 teaspoons olive oil OR castor oil2 teaspoons beeswax20+ drops of essential oil of choice (optional) I used chamomile, geranium and orangeSlowly melt all ingredients, except essential oils, down in a double boiler or sturdy glass bowl over a small pan of boiling water. (TIP: I found an old double boiler at a thrift store that I use for skin products only).Remove from heat and add essential oils.Pour in to lotion bar tube.Let cool for several hours or overnight. I put mine in the fridge to speed the cooling process.Note: This recipe makes enough for one 4-ounce lotion bar tube. For a firmer lotion bar stick, use more beeswax. For a smoother lotion bar stick, use less beeswax and more coconut oil or olive oil.

This model is a dc65. Some dc65s look different because they have the asthma and allergy one, and the animal one, and those have a different color bin, but the only difference in them is the attachments that are included with the vacuum.42.4" x 13.4" x 15.4" (H x W x D)Bin Capacity - .55 GallonsWeight - 17.35 lbs.Suction Power - 245 AWCord Length - 35 ft.Maximum Reach - 51.7 ft.Radial Root Cyclone Technology - No loss of suctionI've included this information because it wasn't easily visible. If you buy a dyson please research before you pick one. The suction power on them is very different between the models. This actually has a great suction power, and the price is excellent for it.The 5 year warranty is included and dyson is pretty easy to deal with when your vacuum is under warranty. I have needed replacement pieces in the past and a phone call was all it took to have one overnighted, including the entire canister part.

This wand is great, it's powerful and it has 7 speeds.It's rechargable and much more affordable than the lelos that I have owned. Charges via usb to your computer or a wall charger and the cord is included to charge it. It holds a charge very nicely and I can use it for several hours before it needs to be recharged. It charges quickly.The vibration is strong and the pulse settings are great.I highly recommend this.I received this product at a discount in exchange for an honest review. I'm very glad i did because i do plan on buying more from this company.

Much cheaper than the brand name stuff, and the purple is the best flavor of these, it also tastes much better cold. Not that it tastes good but if you need to use it, that makes it less painful to drink. Not just good for kids but anyone who is dehydrated and sick. When I'm not going to use a whole bottle I freeze the rest in icecube trays and then use them popped into water to help keep hydrated in the summer.

This has everything and is very organized.The antibiotic oinment is NeomycinThe non asprin is tylenolThe anti bacterial wipes are Benzalkonium ChlorideThis zips up easily and keeps everything organized in its sections. It has everything you could need. I highly recommend this kit to have on hand and one for traveling.* Alcohol Prep Pads* Antiseptic Towlettes* Instant Cold Compress* Tweezers* Safety Pins* Antibiotic Ointment* Burn Cream Ointment* Non-aspirin Tablets*Aspirin Tablets* Sting Relief Pads* Cotton Tip Applicators* Finger Splints* FIRST AID INSTRUCTIONS* Adhesive Bandages (1in x 3in)* Adhesive Bandages (3/8 in x 1.5 in)* Adhesive Bandages (3/4 in x 3 in)* Butterfly Closures* Paper Tape Roll (1.5 in x 2.5 yds)* Sterile Gauze Pads (2 in x 2 in)* Sterile Gauze Pads (4 in x 4 in)* Sterile Trauma Pads (5 in x 9 in)* Examination GlovesI received this product at a discount in exchange for feedback and an honest review

I love these sheets. They fit my mattress perfect and I do have a thick mattress (14 +3inch memory foam)They look great on the bed and they wash well. They are very soft and do not trap in heat to create a sauna effect.Upon getting any sheets I always wash them 3 times and run them through the dryer to break them in and give them softness.To avoid getting beads on your sheets don't wash your sheets with towels, and preferably wash sheets only with other sheets. That is how you avoid balls of fabric on any sheets.They material is not thin, it is thicker than many other microfiber sheets I have tried on amazon.Very nice looking and very happy.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review and feedback.Feel free to comment if you have any questions for me

Very easy to put on my dog and she doesn't mind it at all, this has stopped her pulling to the point that it is manageable.I did not measure her prior to buying this, she is a 45lb mixed breed however she is muscular and chesty and this just barely fit her. It would be lovely if they come out with more sizes as this would not fit my larger dog, who doesn't really need one, but it would be helpful for other owners.It's very nice looking and well made and the leash is comfortable to hold. I prefer a slightly thicker leash however I can switch leashes as needed depending on what I am doing with the dogs. Great deal considering I've paid more than $15 for a harness alone without a leash for my dogs in the past, and this is much better quality than many of the ones I have bought in the past.Very easy to adjust the size. The ease of use of this harness makes it well worth it for the benefits of a no pull harness.This is not a front clip harness, or a tightening front clip harness which are generally what someone would want in a no pull harness. This is a step in harness.I recieved this item at a discount with a coupon code in exchange for my honest review

Extremely relaxing light, I purchased this for the kids but have since purchased one for myself as well.-The cord is short however you can buy a longer USB for cheap to easily plug this in through usb-Auto shut off after 1 hr, which makes it great for using to fall asleep to-it can be a solid green, blue,red, or multi color - you can set this-Can be used in a partial light setting or complete darkness-Play music through aux in to your phone or ipod-its able to project up to my cathedral ceilings which are over 20 feet however looks best in our bedrooms with 9ft ceilingsThis is a great video review with instructions here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9SlWC733F7Q&app=desktopI received this item at a discount in exchange for an honest review

If you liked the first you should like the sequel. If you didn't like the first I don't know why would watch the sequel.Our ages, Female 34 Male 29Is it as funny as the first? No, and you can't expect it to. The original had different humor than seen in other movies, once it's done once you can't expect to laugh the same in a sequel. It was still funny though. I wish they had more from the quiet asian. It still made both of us laugh.Was there new humor or was it the same style as the first? There was new humor. The magician had some great lines and Fat Amy and Bumper have some great moments together.We both enjoyed the film, not as much as the first but it was still great. Would I buy the movie? I don't know, I likely will buy it because I would still watch it again. The soundtrack was not as good as the first.I would not recommend watching this movie if you haven't seen the first. It will still make sense, but not nearly as much sense, and the first is hilarious.I would not recommend this for children because the humor is more suitable for adults and teens.

I love this massager and I use it with my body brush and alongside my essential oils 3 times a week. I have noticed a definite difference in the firmness in my skin and the dimply looking areas no longer look dimply.This fits in the hand easy and is very comfortable to hold and use and is great quality.I received this product at a discount to test and provide an honest review

Ingredients: 100% pure, therapeutic grade essential oils of Juniper Berry, Lavender, Geranium, Bergamot, Chamomile, Rosemary, Grapefruit & Fennel mixed in a base of fractionated coconut oil.Cellulite looks much worse if you are suffering from fluid retention, and massage activates the lymph vessels and nodes which help to transport toxins out of the body. I've bought these a few time and have not had any problem with them being inactive or already used. I believe amazon fixed this issue since I have purchased them at least 5 times without any issues at all. My review is from late 2014-2015 orders.

I like Danielle Panabaker,and I thought she did great in this movie. If you also like her work or enjoy lifetime movies you would enjoy this. It was one of the better lifetime movies, and she did an excellent job.

One of the better sci fi's in a while, and definitely one of the best AI movies.I am not going to give any spoilers in my review and no summary. It's a good movie if you like sci fi and artificial intelligence. It's very interesting if you actually think about what is done in the movie and how it relates to life now and what is capable. I think most people interested  tech, coding, and human behavior and social experiments would enjoy this movie.

Most dog toys I give good reviews even if they get destroyed as long as my dog likes it. This one she got the crinkle piece out right away and she didn't really seem to like it that much. It's still well made and I do like most toys from this company. The crinkle sound does sound a lot like your dog got "into something", so every time I heard it I thought she had gotten into something she wasn't supposed to be in.For the price it's worth it, it's a nice stuffing free toy

Just to clarify, these are two 48 packs of the same thing. The listing should be updated instead of saying 96 exclusive colors, because it is 48x2.I use these for coloring my adult coloring books and they are great for that. It's hard to find something to color with that has a fine tip to fit the tiny areas of the coloring book and also not bleed through the pages. These work perfect and I have so many colors to choose from.I own so many gel pens it's not funny. I have had an assortment of problems with others, with drying up ink, colors barely showing up, glittery ones not being glittery, metallic ones not being metallic. These all come out nice and I have had no issues with any of them. They write and/or color very smooth and glide and don't smudge.I received these pens at a discount to test in exchange for an unbiased review and testing.

The vials are listed as 1/4 Dram, and then in the description they say 1 dram (1.5ml). The volume of the ones I recieved is 1.5ml, which is not 1/4 dram or 1 dram, but just 1.5ml.  1/4 dram is .92ml.  I use them for making essential oil blends when I want to make a small amount. They hold approximately 30 drops. So if you are using them for this purpose and you also have 1.5 ml bottles, 30 drops is what I use for my master blends.I do not use the reducers on these, I use an eye dropper or a pippette to get the oil out when I want to use them.The glass is weak like another reviewer stated, however I have not found any in this bottle style that are stronger. If you want a stronger 1-2ml bottle you should purchase the taller style bottles,w hich have rather thick glass. OR use the clear glass vials that look like perfume testers, and you can stick many of them inside one amber or colbalt jar for storage. This eliminates the headspace and still keeps the oils in a dark jar.

This is awesome for holding cell phones, i have several phones and it holds each of them with it's expandable grip. Great for using as a tripod or even using it for regular use. I use it when I skype and I use it to hold my phone at night when I'm in bed because I have a tendency to knock my phone off the nightstand trying to find it.

This is a perfect fit for my fire phone. It's not bulky at all, and it's protective. The button cut outs are perfect. The only thing protecting the actual face of the phone is the screen protector, which I didn't like the one that came with this case, but it wasn't a big deal. It did bubble a lot, and I have applied screen protectors to many of my devices and not had issues so it isn't a matter of just not knowing. I wanted to write this review since the others are from 2014, and I wanted to have a more current review up there, I just purchased this April 2015.

Great sound from these, I was very surprised since I own other small speakers that didn't get sound close to this.This has a 2000mAh battery that you recharge through USB. This works with any of those external battery packs to give you longer battery life if you are camping.I got the blue and it was accurate to the photo, I love the colors of these. It's a little heavy for me to consider attaching it with a carbiner to carry around would be a good idea. But for drunk camping or outdoor parties, the carbiner attachment is always good just to add that extra level of protection to ensure the speaker doesn't go flying. It does seem durable enough to take a big fall though. I got a chance to try this product out at a discount as part of a review panel to provide feedback, and I am very glad because it's an awesome bluetooth speaker and better than the others I have, and perfect for outdoors.Charge time really was 3 hours. Playback time is 10 hours.

Clove, Cinnamon Bark, Rosemary, Lemon and Eucalyptus make up this blend, this is an undiluted 100% pure therapeutic blend of essential oils.Scent: I like the scent, it is a strong scent though, but christmasy, which most people like, I can't imagine someone finding this scent to be offensive.I apply this at a 2% dilution on me, to my feet at the pressure points in my feet and my spine, and then I follow the pressure points associated with what illness I am trying to ward off. I have no doubt that this oil is effective because my husband is military and around new Marines non stop as he is an instructor, and with that amount of people he brought home pretty much every cold and flu I could think of. I haven't gotten sick since using this blend, which is about 6 months now.I highly recommend dilution starting with a low dilution because of the hot oils in it. I have sensitive skin so I started with 1% to see how I handled it, and I stayed at 2% and find this works just fine. Wash your hands after because it is not pleasant to get this in your eye by accident, or your lips. I have seen others recommend this oil applied to the lips, but I can not recommend that because the clove and cinnamon bark may irritate as they are powerful oils.If you don't know the story behind the Four Thieves I recommend you read it just so you know where this came from. It's about 4 thieves who were robbing graves and using these ingredients to ward off the plague. It's interesting to just know the story behind it.There are a ton of uses for this oil and you will find many just by using google. This is an oil I recommend you have regardless if you like the scent or not.Mix Four Thieves and purified water into spray bottle to kill bacteria and harmful germs. By spraying in front of the A/C unit, the mixture travels through the filter onto bed covers, sheets, pillowcases and bathroom counters.Feel free to check out my other reviews as I am getting around to reviewing all my essential oils (which is a lot). You also will likely find the reviews for other products I use with my essential oils such as rollerballs, carrier oils, inhalers, carrying cases, diffiusers, etc. I didn't buy all through amazon, some were purchased from the sellers website, so I may not show up as a verified reviewer on some, but I am only reviewing products I own and have tried.

Ill be honest, I bought this because it was the only one like it that I could find. I had previously used storage tubs, and the type, but i am very glad I purchased this. It is deep, the handle is strong and easy to carry without spilling and very high quality, I doubt the handle will break.I soak for 30 minunites and it stays hot the entire time. I put 1 cup epsom salt in.If you are soaking with epsom salt, you need to soak for at least 12 minutes for any transdermal absorbption of the mangesium sulfate to take place. In case you don't know, magnesium chloride (the magnesium flakes, which are much more expensive), once mixed into water both the magnesium chloride and the magnesium sulfate break from their bond, so you end up with Mag either way, so if you are trying to soak, there really is no reason at all to soak in the more expensive magnesium chloride vs the magnesium sulfate.If you want to add essential oils to your food soak, oils do not mix with water so they will not be diluted, which can be harsh on the skin, they will also sit on top of the water. The best way to avoid this is to drop essential oil drops in the salt, or the baking soda first, which will help disperse the oils throughout the water, they will still not mix as oil is still not soluble in water, but they will be more dispersed.I went through so many of the more expensive massage type foot baths and they all ended up being crap, I am so glad I purchased this.

What is it about cinematic psychos, in particular the two best villains in recent memory, Anton Chigurh from No Country For Old Men and Lorne Malvo from Fargo, and terrible hair? In the case of those two, both of them deadly beyond normal reckoning, but apparently possessed by the spirits of trickster gods, following their strange and arbitrary whims regardless of the mostly fatal consequences, it's like a taunt. A page-boy and a bowl-cut. Two of the stupidest-looking styles ever devised by barbers, both unskilled and evil, on two of the most dangerous and compelling characters in fiction. I can only surmise they were selected as the looks most likely to provoke laughter and/or ridicule from strangers, providing all the reason they'd need to indulge their murderous predilections.Malvo may have actually been another incarnation of Chigurh; it may have been Fargo writer Noah Hawley's way of combining the two best Coen Bros films into one brilliant series... but Thornton did some great work with the character, a far more playful, but just as charismatic and malevolent version of the enigma that Javier Bardem made all his own.This second season takes us back a couple decades. It's awesome, even without Malvo... or Chigurh. But there's some newly minted killers playing deadly serious games of their own, and a lot of really bad hair. It bodes well for the gods of blood and chaos... and every last bit of it's still as true as the film was.

I don't know why I'd expect anything better, but Supernatural fans are drinking the cult Kool-Aid if they think this series still deserves three stars or higher. It's now reached the tipping point -- after 5 very entertaining seasons and 5 mostly terrible seasons, these are the episodes that will decide matters, the metaphorical weighing of the soul. Clearly, none of the writers or producers care at this point. 'The Darkness'? Kripke and the original writing staff got away with a lot of very stupid ideas, sometimes thanks to a clever sense of humor, but mostly by dropping hangers on the worst ideas, the not-so subtle winks and nods that let you know they were in on the joke; 'yeah, it's ridiculous, but this is a show about werewolves and demons, we don't take ourselves all that seriously.' Fair enough. But for the last three years in particular, there's been nothing clever, nothing new. The actors are on cruise control. This all feels a bit like life after death, as if the fans are keeping a brain-dead corpse on life-support because they don't want to let go. Ackles and Padalecki have gotten a taste of their post-Supernatural prospects, and they're both willing to ride this beast into hell... or 'The Darkness'... or whatever crap they come up with next to insult viewer intelligence. For any of us still watching at this point -- myself included -- that seems like an oxymoron. Continuing to watch just encourages them to make more of this drek. It's not as bad as 'Under the Dome', but it's knocking on the big glass fish-bowl.

If Season 1 didn't really beat the fact into your skull, Season 2 will: Nic Pizzolato loves James Ellroy. Deciding to do a modern-day adaptation of Ellroy's L.A. Confidential was a gutsy decision, especially since he changed up the names and put the super-dense plot of the novel into a blender with a small amount of Chinatown and The Wire. No, we didn't really need another L.A. Confidential of any species after the brilliant, Oscar-winning mid-nineties adaptation... but I don't give a damn. This season came close to its celebrated predecessor in terms of smart, satisfying entertainment, but even if it were the best thing ever committed to film, you'd still hear someone whining about it.To make it clear, my references to a contemporary adaptation of L.A. Confidential were made in jest, but carried a gentle but valid criticism; maybe Pizzolato was unaware of it while writing, but he comes dangerously close to owing Ellroy royalties and a story credit. There's more than enough fresh inspiration and brilliance to forgive his literary love affairs, however, and enjoy the mystery as it unfolds.As cinematic art it falls short of the first block of episodes, but not all that far. Vince Vaughn, Colin Farrell, Rachel McAdams and Taylor Kitsch all deliver great performances, but none of them have the skull-rattling intensity Matt brought to Rust Cohle. In some ways, the writing and pacing are better in Season 2, but most will likely disagree with me there. Believe it or not, True Detective's first storyline was not particularly revolutionary... it was about cops with personal demons chasing down a serial killer. It 'just' did everything very, very well. This season doesn't have the originality of the first, and there's some questionable, predictable and illogical moments as the writer sends his messed-up cops careening towards their shot at redemption and a bad end -- perhaps in more ways then one.Still, if these episodes had been sent through a wormhole, dropped on the door-step of HBO circa 2003... this would be unanimously hailed as brilliant.

Well, that 400$ price-tag is moronic. This is the first volume of a three-volume set from the brilliant Japanese art-book publisher Editions Treville. Stock is running low, but it's said that for several months now. I picked up the complete 3-VOLUME SET from the publisher for 170$ USD, shipping included, and it arrived via EMS in 5 DAYS. Go to this website (copy/paste, outside links aren't allowed) and pick up all three:[ http://treville.ocnk.net/product/48 ]... if you like Beksinski's paintings, you'll love these books. If you're like me, you'll still want more of his work... Zdzislaw Beksinski 1929-2005 (Polska wersja jezykowa) is something you'll want. Beksinski is one of those rare artists who became even better the older he got. The oils that he painted between his son's suicide in 1999 and his own murder in 2004 are some of the greatest I've seen.

I thought I had already seen Beksinski's best work; after being introduced via Juxtapoz a few years back, I picked up the Morpheus book, and then the first of the Editions Treville volumes. The Morpheus volume is pretty slight and terribly designed, with one of the ugliest art-book layouts I've ever seen. The Editions Treville book is beautiful, and features many of the same oil paintings, but is a bit longer, up to 120 pages from the 80 or so in the Morpheus collection.This volume from Bosz is a far more satisfying overview of the artist's career, and also serves as an excellent biography, in both Polish AND English. It features a good number of the paintings that made his name in North America, large oil canvases that were a dark fusion of Surrealism and Fantastic Realism. He is often compared to Swiss Surrealist H.R. Giger, and both men are visionary talents who created worlds that are mysterious, disturbing and almost nihilistic; but Beksinski is by far the better artist of the two, in my opinion. He could also be compared to Ernst Fuchs and Fabrizio Clerici, especially the connection to Symbolist painters of the late 1800's, like Arnold Boecklin and Jean Delville. Beksinski's Symbolism is more instinctive, however; he did not consciously emulate the art of the past.The history of modern painting that critics like Clement Greenberg proposed, a linear succession with closely parallel movements and trends, is now obviously myopic. Anything that didn't fit in with his philosophy of painting's destiny, one that ejects all trompe l'oeil illusionism and embraces it's 2-Dimensional essence, was deliberately ignored. This was a knee-jerk reaction to photography's ascension to high art, prompting an existential crisis... suddenly, oils were not the most faithful method of capturing the world as it is. The answer -- abandon realism! But another line of historical development -- from the romantics, to the symbolists, to the cubists, futurists, new objectivists, pittura metafisica, surrealists, and fantastic realists -- culminates in the growing number of representational painters who have made their peace with photography. One of the early 20th Century artists to influence Beksinski is Otto dix... both artists have a misanthropic streak that refuses to lie and make humanity look prettier than she really is.What is most surprising about the art collected here is the number of 'new works' -- the canvases painted between the mid-90's and his death in 2005. They're absolutely stunning. As much as I like his 'Fantastic Realism', the even more surreal, sometimes abstract work he produced in the decade before his murder is the best of his career. Neither of the volumes mentioned above include substantial selections from this period, so it might be a revelation for other Beksinski fans familiar mostly with the oils from the 70's and 80's.The common criticism that followed Beksinski throughout his career is that his work is relentlessly bleak and disturbing, a pointless excursion into the ugliest corners of existence. To me, anyone who holds that opinion has simply missed the point... but it's very easy to find. Beksinski's entire career was an existential campaign to find beauty and mystery in those regions of psychic geography most fear to tread. Desolation and despair are claimed, then shaped into archetypal imagery. The horrors of the past, from mass crucifixions and impalements to the death camp holocausts of Soblibor and Treblinka, and the Atomic holocausts of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, become monstrously desolate dreamscapes where the organic and inorganic, the living and the dead, have fused. There is life in death, and death in life. Monoliths constructed from wasted corpses, skyscrapers and cathedrals wrapped in tattered, ancient leather, the actual bones and ligaments of its architectural skeleton exposed and open to the caustic, thinning atmosphere.Everything has been altered by some alchemical perversion, faces and identities obliterated. The wasteland over which Beksinski presides is also populated by living and similarly faceless creatures, usually desiccated, with too many limbs and fingers, and always blind. Everyone in Beksinski's other-earth is blind, but there is music -- the dozens of fingers are employed on horns and trumpets and flutes, making music humanity is not yet ready to hear. Our always loyal friends -- dogs and horses -- have followed humanity into the wasteland, and have been doomed to similar fates. This desolate place has music, it has faith, and it has incomprehensible rituals we can only make some sense of in our nightmares. It is beautiful. It is inspiring. Even in the wasteland there is something wonderful, if you can find the ears to hear it, the fingers to feel it. But no one had the eyes to see it, before Beksinski. He has found a way to appreciate both the threat and the promise of total nuclear annihilation, WWIII, the viral apocalypse, the great and terrible dying of all things.If you find no beauty or mystery in this book and the art, it's because you're unwilling to peer through this artists' eyes. To be clear: it's not for everyone... but it's rare that visionary art ever is. Zdzislaw Beksinski went deeper into these dark places than almost every artist before or since... his predecessors and peers: Hieronymus Bosch, Pieter Bruegel, Salvator Rosa, John Martin, Fransisco de Goya, Arnold Boecklin, Gustave Moreau, Giovanni Segantini, Jean Delville, Otto Dix, George Grosz, Ernst Fuchs, Fabrizio Clerici, Werner Tubke, Michael Triegel, Ken Currie, Glenn Brown, Ruprecht Von Kaufmann, et al.Beksinski's son, Tomasz, committed suicide in 1999. It was after this loss that Beksinski completed the most powerful and perfect works of his entire oeuvre... they are beautiful and tragic, even when divorced from their context. The artist always wanted his works to exist on their own, and insisted that any meaning should be created by the viewer. Every single painting in his (as yet uncollected) catalogue raisonne is untitled. The son dead by his own hand, the wife gone as well, the father, husband and artist left alone, finally murdered, an act of senseless violence. Beksinski knew the taste and textures of despair... and is one of the few to succeed in the alchemical transmutation of elements, turning filth into gold.P.S.: As good as this volume is, it includes works donated by Beksinski, his friends, and his patrons to the museum in his home city of Sanok. Many or most of his best work from the 70's, 80's, and 90's is held in private collections, making it difficult for any monograph to obtain their own high resolution photography... especially when it's hanging in the homes of the rich and famous. The three-volume series collecting Beksinski's work by Editions Treville, a Japanese artbook publisher, is probably the most complete. Books 1 and 2 are devoted to his paintings and photography, while Book 3 is dedicated to his drawings. Volume 1 is going for ridiculous prices, and they're all steadily increasing. The Editions Treville site still has a few copies of Book 1 left, as well as Books 2 and 3. If you buy all three together from ET, it'll cost a total of 165$ USD, shipping by EMS airmail included (it's something like 20 000 yen). I've seen volume 1 alone going for 180$, so that's a pretty good price. Here's a link to their site: http://treville.ocnk.net/product-group/14There is also a fourth 'Editions Treville' Beksinski collection, released a few years before the three volume set. I own all four ET books, the Bosz book, and the Morpheus book. The only one that doesn't contain largely unique material is the latter. Again, it sucks. The others, and this one -- brilliant. Buy this one here, buy the ET books from ET.
Fight Club + We Are Legion + American Psycho + Breaking Bad + Trainspotting = Genius [WATCH] Mr.Robot [/WATCH]

It is a rare thing, finding an artistic visionary who can find the trace elements of beauty in utter desolation. Beksinski went deeper and darker than anyone before or since, exploring the vast abyssal cave-systems where existential dread is born, facing a universal emptiness in which life is a just an insignificant spark that flared and died without meaning or consequence. Anyone trying to overcome this dread must learn to accept life and death for everything they are -- the very worst along with the best, and find beauty in squalor, injustice, absurdity, disease, suffering, cruelty, cowardice, hatred.In Beksinski's paintings, the living and the dead are one; organic and inorganic are often fused, and individual identity nullified. Facelessness is the way of things, as victims of some inconceivable torture akin to crucifixion and impalement are seamlessly joined by the face to their death-stakes -- this mysterious obliteration has erased them as living beings, and they are locked together, fossilized midway through a circuit of dehumanization.I thought I had already seen Beksinski's best work; after being introduced via Juxtapoz a few years back, I picked up the Morpheus book, and then the first of the Editions Treville volumes. The Morpheus volume is pretty slight and terribly designed, with one of the ugliest art-book layouts I've ever seen. The Editions Treville book is beautiful, and features many of the same oil paintings, but is a bit longer, up to 120 pages from the 80 or so in the Morpheus collection.This volume from Bosz is a far more satisfying overview of the artist's career, and also serves as an excellent biography, in both Polish AND English. It features a good number of the paintings that made his name in North America, large oil canvases that were a dark fusion of Surrealism and Fantastic Realism. He is often compared to Swiss Surrealist H.R. Giger, and both men are visionary talents who created worlds that are mysterious, disturbing and almost nihilistic; but Beksinski is by far the better artist of the two, in my opinion. He could also be compared to Ernst Fuchs and Fabrizio Clerici, especially the connection to Symbolist painters of the late 1800's, like Arnold Boecklin and Jean Delville. They're absolutely stunning. As much as I like his 'Fantastic Realism', the even more surreal, sometimes abstract work he produced in the decade before his murder is the best of his career. Neither of the volumes mentioned above include substantial selections from this period, so it might be a revelation for other Beksinski fans familiar mostly with the oils from the 70's and 80's.The common criticism that followed Beksinski throughout his career is that his work is relentlessly bleak and disturbing, a pointless excursion into the ugliest corners of existence. Desolation and despair are claimed, then shaped into archetypal imagery. Buy this one here, buy the ET books from ET.One last point -- I have the hardcover edition, which is a very nice oversized smyth-sewn volume with a thick, glossy archival stock. It has the same cover as pictured for the soft-cover, no dust-jacket, instead of the red cover that is shown for the hard-cover. I'm not sure what to make of that.

A deadly virus has killed off 99% of the world's population. What should patriotic military types and conscientious folk from all walks of life do next? Finish the job, obviously! Load your automatic rifles and take care of that pesky 1%. Mindlessly gung-ho think-it-through-with-bullets fun. Because not even the near-extinction of the human race will convince Americans to stop killing people. The speed and ruthlessness with which the characters suddenly decide to shoot other surviving citizens in the face is disconcerting... but probably accurate.

Exactly how much drama -- measured in Drams, Hitchcocks, or SSU's (Swiss Suspense Units) -- can an author wring from a 'man vs. nature' theme, especially when the 'nature' in question is the dead red sand of Mars? Quite a bit, actually. That kind of speculation drives much of the action in Andy Weir's incredibly popular novel, 'The Martian'. If a first-person novel that involves copious amounts of ultra-detailed descriptions of the technology that any near-future Mars mission would likely use doesn't interest you, then just put the Kindle down and slowly back away...After their Mars expedition is cut short due to a sandstorm, the mission's botanist and engineer, Mark Watney, is separated from the rest of the crew during the evacuation. His suit sends physical telemetry telling them he's dead, and they are forced to leave without him. Determined to survive, he uses every scrap of knowledge and imagination he possesses to stretch his supplies out long enough for a rescue mission to reach him. Using whatever technology lies buried from Mars missions past and present, he becomes an accidental colonist, and the first true 'Martian'.If you can't calculate the SSUs (or Hitchcocks) in Watney's account of using an iridium catalyst and an open-freakin'-flame to break hydrazine down to its elemental parts (in a risky attempt to make enough water for a makeshift hydroponic garden), you should probably pass on it. It's one of those novels, however, that defies the best publishing prognosticator's guesstimates about who the hell might like this book, and how many copies it might sell. Weir does an excellent job of keeping the story buoyant, never letting it get sunk by dry, scientific exposition. It is precisely this attention to detail, however, that makes it so utterly convincing. Is it 100% accurate, based on current trends in space exploration technology? F***, I have no idea. It sounds good though. If it were 100% accurate, I guess, the book would have never been written, because the future of manned space missions looks kind of grim at the moment. This is a scientifically-literate and realistic SF love-letter to the spirit of exploration... and it's a great read; Weir's passion for the material is really the rocket-fuel that puts 'The Martian' into orbit, and never lets it decay -- work like this is the best hope for resuscitating public interest in space travel.In case you're wondering, the protagonist's first-person journal entries aren't the whole story; Weir alternates between 'Letters from Mars', a third-person account of the desperate rescue mission being organized on Earth, and his despondent crewmates, still making the long trip home onboard the shuttlecraft. The break in perspective provides added suspense, as Mark Watney's plight becomes big news around the world, and differing ideas about the best course of action lead to heated struggles and painful defeats.This novel deserves all the praise and attention it's received, and I recommend it highly for anyone who loves 'realistic science fiction' -- 'The Martian' is proof-positive that the label is not an oxy-moron. The fact that Ridley Scott will be adapting it for the screen, with Matt Damon playing Watney, is a very good sign that the film version will do the source material justice. I'm not surprised that a director like Scott snapped up the movie rights; with over 340 SSUs (or 0.8 Hitchcocks), he would have been crazy to let a lesser director have it.

The Slysz Bowie just arrived in my mailbox, and I haven't been this impressed with a Spyderco since... well, ever. I'm a fan of the Taiwanese models, but the Southard, despite being a beautifully made knife with one of the best steels available and excellent fit and finish, just didn't work for me in terms of ergonomics. I prefer larger knives, so when the K2 and the Slysz Bowie came out, and a marketplace seller on Amazon.ca was selling the K2 for the ridiculously low price of 210$ Canadian (about 175$ USD), I didn't hesitate. The K2 is an awesome knife, with a huge CPM 10V blade that is razor sharp; it spyder-flicks open with a smooth, easy action, and has very nice stonewashed titanium and a unique faux-spherical polished standoff. But it's an eccentric design, to say the least, over 10-inches long but thinner than a Sebenza, only vaguely ergonomic, and with an eternally sticky lockbar that requires injecting steroids into your thumb to close (I'm kidding, obviously, it's not all that bad now that it's broken in after a few weeks; but it still sticks, and all the graphite in the world won't stop it... on the positive, it is an incredibly secure lock-up -- about 80%, due to the thinness of the profile and the tension on the lockbar). While I do really love the K2, in all its massive, oddball glory, the Slysz Bowie hasn't required the same kind of parent-like unconditional acceptance. It's a virtually perfect knife. An excellent video by Solo's Knife Reviews pointed out the two minor questions related to the design -- a flat surface on the tang connecting with a round stop-pin, and thicker-than-usual bronze washers. Given how silky smooth the action was on mine out of the box (Sebenza smooth, without the grease!), I've already decided the washers are a positive, and the tolerances are pretty tight anyway. As for the former, while a rounded notch might have been better, or a flat-faced, D-shaped stop-pin, I don't think the pin is likely to flatten (creating theoretical up and down blade-play in the lock-up) any time soon. Even if it did, I don't see why I couldn't simply spin the stop-pin 90-180 degrees so it could hypothetically start flattening the other side. After those two minor-to-non-existent concerns, there's nothing to criticize. I would have preferred CTS-204P, I guess, but CTS-XHP is purportedly an excellent steel as well, a lower vanadium alternative to CPM S30V, S35VN, or Elmax. Like CPM Cruwear, PSF 27, Sleipner, and many other steels, XHP has been compared to D2 (or CPM D2, since XHP uses Carpenter's version of particle metallurgical technology), with better corrosion resistance. I've also heard it tastes like chicken. The fit and finish on the Slysz is truly impressive. The Spyderco full-flat grind and long, distal taper are combined with a beautiful stone-washed finish; it has what looks like a transparent protective layer of something like cerakote (virtually identical to the Southard's stone-washed finish), giving it a glassy smooth texture that no doubt contributes to the smooth action as well. The blade spine has fairly 'passive' jimping (as opposed to aggressive jimping), but it does provide some traction when heavy pressure is applied. The jimping on the stylish G-10 backspacer, on the other hand, is very functional with minimal pressure, helping to offset the untextured ti surface. About an inch-and-a-quarter past the handle, the gentle angle of the Bowie profile leading to the point has been flawlessly radiused, a touch I particularly like. The stone-washed blade has been matched with stone-washed titanium handle scales, and the Taichung factory has once again nailed the details. While it looked similar to the K2 when I first saw them, the Slysz is a completely different species, expertly refined to justify the higher price. The contoured titanium, in contrast to the flat scales of the Farid Mehr design, is an expensive feature that only knife aficionados are likely to appreciate, and the same can be said for much of this knife's finer points. One thing everyone can appreciate is out-of-the-box cutting ability. It came with a very sharp edge -- something Spyderco is known for -- but even relative to Spyderco standards, it might be the sharpest of the dozen or so models I've owned. Yes, it's important to be comfortable sharpening your own knives, but I still hate getting brand new blades that are too dull to cleanly slice paper or deal with arm hair. It immediately darkens my view of a maker when I'm shipped an expensive cutting tool that can't f***ing cut. I know some people immediately put their new knives on a Sharpmaker or Wicked Edge for that beautiful mirror-polished look, but I shouldn't HAVE to sharpen a new blade. Thankfully, the Slysz Bowie comes with a neater, sharper cutting edge than I'm ever able to get with my Lansky stones. The lock-up is perfect, and unlike the K2, there isn't the faintest trace of stickiness. One minor concern related to opening is that -- again, unlike the K2 -- it's extremely difficult to 'spyder-flick' right-handed, but it 'thumb-flicks' open using the hole with ease. This is because of the cut-out providing access on the presentation side, which doesn't help lefties who prefer using their thumb for opening, since the lock-bar obscures 50% of the hole; the spyder-flick, however, is very doable for a primary left-handed opening method. So: thumb-flick for right-handed users, spyder-flick for left-handed users. The much-loved, occasionally disparaged wire-clip allows tip-up left-handed carry, so even though it's not as truly ambidextrous as spine-lock and ball-bearing-lock alternatives, it's not quite as righty-centric as it seems. I keep comparing it to the K2, but if comparisons are going to be made, the Slysz Bowie is clearly emulating the Sebenza, and doing a damn fine job. It might not be quite as good as Chris Reeve's crowning achievement, but at 55-60% the price, it is most assuredly 55-60% as good... maybe even 70%. That's high praise, I know, but I think it's justified.

'Late Harvest' accompanies an exhibition at the Nevada Museum of Art, and was part of a larger conference addressing ecological concerns. This attractive, well-constructed 'turtleback' -- which has rigid covers with rough-cut edges and a thick, glued spine, held together like a softcover -- gives the reader a contrast between the way wildlife was portrayed in late 19th and early 20th century paintings, and how contemporary artists express a far more complex relationship between man and animal, artist and subject, using a variety of media. Taxidermy, in particular, has been used extensively, in works by the Icelandic duo 'Idiots!', Damien Hirst, and British pARTners Tim Noble and Sue Webster. The pseudo silhouette sculptures of the latter, for example, use a tangled mess of rats and frogs and birds to create two perfectly formed shadows on the white screen behind it, giving us the severed heads of the artists in profile, mounted on stakes. This obvious interpretation would be a commentary on our exploitation of the natural world for the sake of vanity and selfish greed. The artists retain their usual self-deprecating humor, and include themselves in this almost playful condemnation; the severed heads on pikes might symbolize a punishment, meant to serve as a warning -- but they cheated the executioner, leaving the 'vermin' they sacrificed as disgusting duplicates. Leelee Fernandez uses staged photographs, costumes and sculptures in her multi-media projects. A photographic diptych portrays the artist herself half-transformed: naked from the waist up, with the legs of a black bear, then naked from the crotch down, with the torso and head of a bear. Many of the artists selected, like Fernandez, are dedicated wildlife and ecology conservationists. The idea that there is no excuse for mistreating animals, that we need to see them as beautiful creatures who have emotions and thoughts that are different from ours, perhaps simpler, but no less valid, is something most of the contemporary artists featured share.The romantic themes and fashionable, mildly impressionistic styles of the American wildlife painters, provide no evidence of the idealistic philosophies and passionate concern that drives their 21st century successors. There doesn't even seem to be a hint of the bittersweet sadness that many felt as the frontiers of America were finally 'tamed'. It was all too vast for man to inflict any real damage. What they chose to paint were scenes of a beautiful wilderness, the grandeur of the forests and mountains, continuing the romantic tradition of Bierstadt and Church.While I found the eclectic, almost haphazard assortment of artists interesting, and admire the curatorial focus on taxidermy in contemporary art, the exhibition's glaring omissions were just as noteworthy as the submissions. Elizabeth McGrath should be a part of any important look at taxidermy in post-modern art, but she's curiously absent. And how could any exhibition on the relationship between man and animal, on humanity's changing perception of the natural world, without including work by Walton Ford, who has built an ingenious oeuvre spanning over twenty years on exactly those subjects. Utilizing the style of eighteenth and nineteenth century Natural Historians/artists like Audubon and Haeckel, he uses written accounts drawn from scientific journals, religious texts, and obscure historical ephemera, and creates vibrant, breathing allegories that hint at influences as distant as Bosch and Dali. Instead, we have Andrew Zuckerman, who takes photos of animals that are slick and attractive, and make for nice, oversized books your Aunt will like; but his work says nothing but 'Behold! An Elephant!'

[Some Minor Spoilers, but the Biggest Twists and Surprises are Still in their Original Packaging]There's been a great deal of negativity directed toward this film, something I find somewhat baffling after watching it. It might be the wheat-fields, barns and farm-houses, as well as the Steinbeck-meets-Heinlein vision of a dust-bowl future where agriculture has become the most vital concern (I get that; sometimes wheat-fields make me so angry I go blind and piss myself). Earth is no longer viable for much of the remaining population, as grim ecological forecasts come to pass. McConaughey plays a pilot-turned-farmer and father whose hopes for his children are dying with the crops. A seemingly supernatural encounter leads to the discovery of a top-secret space program (it's not quite as ridiculous as it sounds), run by a former professor of his, played by Michael Caine. He is recruited for a desperate space-mission unlike anything NASA has ever attempted, an intergalactic journey through a mysteriously convenient worm-hole, leading to a solar system that has planets that are very Earth-like, one or more of which might be capable of supporting human life.The odds of these phenomena converging by chance are too slim to merit serious consideration; someone, somewhere, has thrown a metaphorical lifesaver to a drowning man. They've opened a door in space-time for a doomed planet, giving humanity another shot at survival. The hero must leave behind his young children in order to save humanity, and the sacrifices he will be forced to make become increasingly painful. McConaughey gives another dead-on portrayal, settling into middle-age well as one of the finest actors in Hollywood, while Anne Hathaway and Matt Damon are both excellent in supporting roles.Interstellar gives the viewer a look at space travel that is far more realistic than most of the science fiction tales that have made it to the screen. Man is his own greatest enemy in 'Interstellar'; the conflict between the selfish motives of the individual and the selfless concerns of the greater good is always raging, as the crew members struggle not just with one another, but with themselves. Man isn't the only enemy, however. Relativity is perhaps the most frightening threat the expedition will face in 'Interstellar', as the characters confront the harsh extremes of time-dilation. Hours, days, months, and years become very real concerns, with time no longer the inexorable, predictable force it appears to be. The river still flows in one direction (mostly), but the current is slower near the banks and faster near the center, pulling one far downriver in the blink of an eye, as intense gravitational fields stretch space-time 'thin'; Einstein's ground-breaking discovery is no longer just an intimidating or baffling abstraction, a monkey-wrench jamming up the elegant precision of Newton's clockwork-universe; it becomes something almost as tangible and terrifying as the barrel of a cocked .45-magnum, 'making your day' into decades. Black holes and relativistic speeds will kill your family and everything you ever loved or knew; one might fall asleep aboard a space-ship that is moving at a certain velocity, or straying too close to an accretion disk, and wake up several hours later, without realizing that decades have passed on Earth, and everyone you've been trying to save is gone. Father Time -- according to the proverb -- may indeed be the greatest of teachers; but he kills every last one of his students.I liked 'Interstellar' immensely, but it's not for everyone. The conclusion is not as strong as it could have been, and there are plot holes -- or at least questionable narrative decisions -- scattered occasionally throughout. That, however, is something I can say about every SF film ever made. Perfection, or near-perfection, is rare in every genre, but in science fiction it's impossible; 'Interstellar' comes about as close as any film since '2001'. I think that audiences expecting an 'Avatar'-like experience will be disappointed. I hated 'Avatar'; this is the kind of science fiction I wish there was more of, and yet another brilliant film by Christopher Nolan. If you liked '2001', 'Moon', or 'Gravity', I highly recommend this film. If you enjoyed 'Jupiter Ascending'... I'm surprised you can read.

Apologies to fans of the Spyderco 'Tatanka' -- which is essentially just an 'Endura' on steroids -- but the biggest, most impressive blade in the Spyderco catalog is the Farid Mehr 'K2'... which is, essentially, a Sebenza on steroids. I love titanium, and I love frame-locks, both of which Spyderco is making more of from their high-end 'designer-knife' facility in Taiwan. This is one of the biggest Sebenza-style knives I've seen, with an OAL of 10-inches, and a 4.54-inch blade with the full-flat grind and distal taper that is so effective for deep slicing. The 'K2' may be a brute, but the simplicity of the design is almost elegant; it has small, tasteful accents like a unique, serpentine cut between handle and lockbar, and a faux-spherical backspacer/stand-off.Spyderco has always used the best cutlery steels available for each design, releasing limited sprint runs and mules to get knife user feedback on newer or more exotic varieties. The CPM 10V blade on this knife was a huge part of its appeal. This knife can cut through ridiculous amounts of rope and cardboard without dulling or damage, a blade with the best retention of any production folder. For an excellent review with rigorous testing go here:http://www.bladeforums.com/forums/showthread.php/1222344-Spyderco-FArid-K2-Full-Review-and-testingIt might sound similar to CPM S30V or S35VN, but it's not. A heavy duty tool steel manufactured using Crucible's 'particle metallurgical' process, it has a very high 2.5% carbon content and just as high 10% vanadium, helping give it the best edge retention possible, better than ZDP-189, Stellite 6K, CPM Rex M4, Vanax 75, Maxamet, or Cowry X; the only possible exceptions are CPM 15V, CPM Rex 121, and the equally rare and difficult to work CPM S110V & CPM S125V (three of these share the record for highest carbon level - 3.40%). CPM 10V's ability to take a razor edge and hold it means -- according to the fairly exhaustive tests found here:http://www.bladeforums.com/forums/showthread.php/793481-Ranking-of-Steels-in-Categories-based-on-Edge-Retention-cutting-5-8-quot-rope-- that where a knife with VG-10 made 160 cuts before dulling, and one with CTS-XHP made 240, CPM S30V made 300, M390/CTS-204P and ZDP-189 made 420, the Spyderco Farid Mehr with CPM 10V made an unbelievable 1100 cuts. This test has been added to, edited and updated regularly since 2010, with the last one done on Jan. 15 2015. The Spyderco Manix 2 using CPM S110V did just as well (after a regrind of the cutting edge, that is), with 1100 cuts before dulling; rope was used as the test material in this case, but the reviewer also uses cardboard and carpet, all of which make for consistent test subjects.But the best performer of all was another knife using CPM 10V, by custom maker Phil Wilson. An acknowledged master of high performance fixed blades, Wilson uses most of the high-vanadium steels that terrify other makers (I'm joking, obviously, but the amount of work that 10V, S110V, S125V, Rex 121, Maxamet, Stellite 6K, Talonite and Vanax demand make them dauntingly expensive, time-consuming, and frustrating choices); instead of being hardened to 63 Rockwell, like the 'K2', the 10V was hardened to 64.5, and managed a seemingly incredible 2400 cuts. Increasing the hardness by just 1.5 Rockwell more than doubled its already unbelievable edge retention. Whether or not that causes 10V to become too brittle for hard use, or impossible to re-sharpen, with results like that, it might be worth it. 1100 cuts is still far more than most people will make with material as abrasive as rope, however, let alone 2400.The only criticism I can make is that the lock-bar face is sticky, making it difficult to disengage. Spyderco should use the stainless steel lock-bar inserts that Zero Tolerance have made standard issue for their frame-locks, at least on the K2. The Slysz Bowie works as well as any frame-lock I've tried without the insert, and the Southard usually has a problem-free lock-up. The other caveat is that the Farid Mehr K2 is BIG. I know, that point has been made repeatedly in reviews and descriptions, but past experience suggests that someone will eventually post a review complaining that the K2 is way bigger than they thought it would be. To be clear: it has a 4.54" blade, a full inch longer than the blade of a Spyderco Paramilitary 2 or Southard, and is 10" overall. The photo will make it fairly obvious, if the repetition hasn't.P.S.: After a couple weeks of use I've been cutting things up like a psycho, with no discernible dulling whatsoever. Not that I expected any. It speaks to Spyderco's care with blades that the K2 came shaving sharp, and sliced a magazine in half with relative ease. If you try it, though, make sure there's no staples in whatever mag you're cutting, it can still chip.On the down side, the lock is still sticky and very stiff; this is not a knife for women -- unless you happen to be a woman with freakishly large and powerful man-thumbs -- and it's not a knife for guys with small or delicate hands.I've also noticed that because the placement of the pocket clip, I tend to place my fingers above it for solid purchase, and end up putting them on top of the wide lock-bar, pressing in with my fingers while pressing out with my thumb, and making things difficult. It's another argument against tip-down placement when there's no choice of a different configuration. It means you have to be conscious of your grip when dis-engaging the lock, but I got used to it quick enough.

This knife is a thing of beauty. I was one of the people who showed up a minute too late to get the limited edition ZT 0454, which is as close as I could get to a custom Dmitry Sinkevich like the 'Cardinator' it's based on. A day after the release, it was being sold on eBay for 1500$, 2000$, and even higher, for a knife with a 500$ price-tag. Unfortunately, that happens a lot with Zero Tolerance limited editions, particularly the 0777 or 0888.The 0452CF retains the scale, profile and essence of the 0454, but for a much more affordable price. The CPM D2 and Sandvik composite has been replaced by a sleek and deadly looking two-tone blade of CPM S35VN; the 3D-contoured carbon fiber is now chamfered on the presentation-side; and the sub-frame-lock titanium-and-CF is now solid, stone-washed titanium. Of course, it has all the Zero Tolerance details, like a lock-bar stabilizer, replaceable stainless steel insert, oversized decorative pivot, KVT caged ball-bearings, and a tip-up clip fit for right or left-hand carry (the carbon fiber has been pre-drilled, and threaded steel sleeves keep the screws from stripping out the carbon fiber).This is a big knife, with a 4.15-inch blade and 9.3-inch OAL, which makes the 4.6 ounce weight truly impressive. ZT took full advantage of the carbon fiber, using it not just as a scale laminated to a steel or titanium liner, but as a full, thick handle; carbon fiber has the structural strength of steel at a far lighter weight. The look of the CF is stunning, and it has a different pattern from the type used on the 0562CF Hinderer 'Slicer' -- another example of Zero Tolerance's dominance in the world of high-end production knives -- which has a 3.5-inch blade and an 8.25-inch OAL, with a weight of 5.6 ounces. Even though the 0452CF is over an inch longer than the 0562CF, it's a full ounce lighter; it's also one of the most streamlined knives you'll ever find for carry, similar to a Spyderco Southard in terms of thickness and width.With the KVT caged ball-bearing pivot system, Zero Tolerance flippers are known for firing better and having smoother action than many custom or midtech alternatives. The 0452CF may be their best flipper yet; it has a stiff detent, and the standard 'light-switch' method fires the blade out with an authority that makes a failed deployment virtually impossible -- the bare minimum of stored kinetic energy required to break the detent is more than enough to launch the blade into the locked position. Even not quite closed, in a position just before the detent ball pulls the blade shut, I'm able to hit the flipper and fully engage the blade without wrist movement.The pocket-clip is a bit odd. For a knife as large as the 0452CF Sinkevich, you might expect it to have an XL clip. But it doesn't; it doesn't even have a standard size clip, opting for a miniature clip I've never seen on a ZT. The reason for this, I think, is because the regular size ZT clip would end over the milled-out pocket. The small clip works great however, so it doesn't really qualify as a negative.The move to CPM S35VN will please some, no doubt; Crucible is an American steel manufacturer who pioneered the first cutting-edge 'particulate/powder metallurgical' formula specifically for cutlery, gathering input and advice from a who's who of custom knife-makers to develop CPM S30V. It quickly became the gold standard for high-end blades, used extensively on customs, midtechs, and high end production companies like Spyderco. Chris Reeve was largely responsible for the development of CPM S35VN, a variation of CPM S30V that added Niobium to the matrix to make it easier to sharpen. Both are excellent choices, and many consider them the best all around stainless steels for knives available.Zero Tolerance has used CPM S35VN (and CPM S30V) before on the 0550, but has preferred Austrian manufacturer Bohler-Uddeholm's own specially-made cutlery steels using 'powder metallurgical' technology, Elmax and M390. I've found Elmax to be slightly better than CPM S30V/S35VN, overall, but others have disparaged it for various reasons. M390 is, along with Carpenter's CTS-204P, the best knife steel for folders yet developed, in my opinion -- an assessment many people agree with (despite the fact that it's pretty close to Elmax, with higher levels of Carbon, Chromium and Vanadium, and the addition of 0.7% Tungsten). The popularity of M390, especially on the ZT 0562CF and 0620CF, has led to a shortage. ZT's decision to use the widely available CPM S35VN for all four of the models introduced in 2015 was a good one, in the end. It's not as cool as M390, but it has decent corrosion resistance, is easy to sharpen, and has good edge retention. The 0452CF came wickedly-sharp, even for ZT, who usually make certain their knives ship with a truly sharp edge. This is another brilliant release from Zero Tolerance.

Everything seems to be converging to form a career rebirth for Alejandro Jodorowsky. Not that he ever really went through a decline, in any way; he's remained one of the most prolific writers of bande dessinee since the early 80's, and has written books on various subjects, such as the Tarot and ritual magic. But with the critical acclaim garnered by the fascinating documentary 'Jodorowsky's Dune', and the long-anticipated conclusion and collected edition of 'Final Incal', he seems more vital now than he has since creating the cult film 'El Topo' over forty years ago. 'Final Incal' completes the central trilogy in the massively complex series of graphic novels that share a continuity dubbed 'The Jodoverse'. Moebius, who illustrated the original Incal, creating one of his most important and visionary works around Jodo's brilliantly eccentric story, also completed one chapter of 'Apres L'Incal' before abandoning the project. Retitled as 'Final Incal', Ladronn started over, and spent nearly a decade crafting some of the most gorgeous artwork in comic history.With so much attention devoted to 'Final Incal', another corner of the Jodoverse, based on an enigmatic character from the original Incal -- The Metabaron -- has almost been overlooked. 'The Metabarons', lavishly illustrated by Spaniard Juan Gimenez, was the dark companion to 'The Incal', a brutal, incredibly violent, multi-generational epic relating the bloody history of the Metabaron caste. Like a futuristic, technologically advanced version of the medieval Samurai, adhering to a warrior-code -- Bushitaka -- very similar to the Samurai's battlefield philosophy of Bushido, the Metabarons were the most feared men in the Jodoverse.Following Juan Gimenez, Travis Charest matched Ladronn's sublime artistic perfection in the all-too-brief, 64-page follow-up to the 550+ page original in 'Weapons of the Metabarons'.
