Although he is excruciatingly self-critical, and this demand for perfection makes for slow work, it provides a showcase for what the Canadian artist is capable.While 'Final Incal' takes us to the end, Jorowsky's 'Metabarons Genesis: Castaka', takes us to the beginning. While Charest is an incredible talent, producing this 112-page volume would have taken far too long. In his place. Das Pastoras was the choice to illustrate this prequel to 'The Metabarons' -- which was itself a prequel -- taking the story back to Castaka, the home world,before the Metabaron caste had been established. If The Metabarons represent the Tokugawa Shogunate of Edo-period Japan, then this gorgeously rendered story takes us back to the Sengoku period, the era of the warring states, which culminated in the battle of Sekigara, and after a short time of struggle between the generals of the victorious army, a stable, unified Japan ruled by the Shogunate. The correlations are obvious, after reading it.'Castaka' is another masterpiece for Jodo, and an ending. It has been taking us backwards -- the 'first' Metabaron is introduced simply as 'The Last Metabaron', and the MB saga begins with the first. This final installment is a prequel that tells us how their horrific traditions began, stemming from a long conflict between the two tribes that originally populated Castaka, both fighting for control of the marble-planets meager life-sustaining resources. Das Pastoras establishes himself as an artist of the highest order. His fully-painted art is every bit as awe-inspiring as Ladronn's, and is worth it for the art alone.These two artists have helped Jodorwsky realize his vision perfectly, and it will be interesting to see what he does next, both in the Jodoverse and out. 'Castaka' is a stunning book, both for it's art and its' design. It's a deluxe limited edition, numbered somewhere between 0001 and 1500 (mine was 0351), and is an over-sized !0" x 13" hardcover, complete with slipcase. Don't ignore this book for Final Incal, go ahead and buy both, because prices will skyrocket soon on both (I pre-ordered a copy of the original deluxe, slip-cased, edition of 'The Incal: Classic Collection' in 2010, just as Humanoids was stepping up its English translations for the US market again. It had the same over-sized dimensions as 'Castaka', and announced on the slipcase-cover that it was limited to 750 copies. If you didn't pre-order it through a comic-shop, you were out of luck -- the 100$ USD book never made it to the shelves, selling-out fast enough that even the later pre-orders never got their copy. I have yet to see one for sale).

I liked the premise, and this is the kind of story that Warren Ellis used to excel at. 'Trees', however, is an example of his occasional tendency to burn out after a strong start, slowing the momentum to a crawl as if unable to decide on a direction -- usually a sign the idea is not premium Ellis. To be clear: 'Trees' is definitely NOT premium Ellis. This is one of those scripts he writes with his left hand while his right hand takes care of the 'important' work (any innuendos that come to mind are completely unintentional). I'm not sure what's most important to Ellis now, what stokes his creative fires -- his novels would be my guess -- but there is none of the anarchistic zeal that defines his best material in 'Trees'. It's a paycheck, and a movie-pitch... call it 'left-handed story-telling' (my apologies to lefties -- in your case, reverse the analogy).The massive, world-encompassing alien phenomenon is intriguing, but the mystery of the trees gets lost in a patchwork soap opera involving unconvincing characters from around the world. The personal melodrama -- for example, a Chinese artist's sexual confusion after joining an unlikely community of freethinkers that has congregated around the base of an extra-terrestrial tree -- seems trite and irrelevant in the shadow of a looming extinction-level event. Even the researchers actively involved in uncovering the secrets of these bizarre organisms (you can probably guess their purpose, but I won't offer any explanations for those determined to read this tepid tale) seem mostly uninterested in them, and Ellis gives us more snarky arguments and shallow conflict. The plot moves forward at a crawl, as Ellis drags the minimal suspense out for as many pages as he can, stretching a thin story to the snapping point.While Ellis is clearly treading water with 'Trees', he's not the only problem. The art matches the story perfectly with its mediocrity. That's harsh, I know. I don't like disparaging an artist's work, but with the ever-growing number of truly talented people vying for jobs, there's no reason for putting up with lazy, uninspired art. Jason Howard has a style that catches the eye, but it quickly becomes apparent that it's a hack approach; it's quick and sketchy, an attempt to camouflage a very limited grasp of the basics of representational art. Awkward, unnecessary cross-hatching runs rampant throughout 'Trees'... and I'll leave it at that.Or maybe I won't. To be fair, art isn't quantitative; maybe you're into over-scribbled, under-considered styles. The same applies to story-telling: I think this is one of those Warren Ellis books I wish he'd never written -- like Black Gas, Tokyo Storm Warning, and Red (yes, Red kind of sucked, IMO) -- but you might enjoy a tale that comes roaring out of the gate at 150mph with a pretty good idea, then inexplicably drops back into first and does slow figure-eights. I'm far from an Ellis hater; I've got somewhere between thirty and forty of his collections in my actual, molecular library -- from Transmetropolitan to Stormwatch, the Authority and Planetary; from Global Frequency to Gravel, Freakangels and the rest of his Avatar titles. Ellis may not be in the same league as Alan Moore, or Grant Morrison, but he's still a far better writer than 'Trees' might indicate.

That's quite the handle. This company needs to find a more decisive writer for their listings, but I can't find fault with the product itself. If you've ever guest starred on COPS, Dog the Bounty Hunter, Caught on Video Vol.1-23, or America's Most Wanted (is that still on?), this is the... 'Micro Fleece Polar Neck Warmer/Face Mask/Hat Snood/Scarf Military Fleece Neck Warm Face Warmer Black Thermal Ski Snowboard Cycling Sports Genuine'... for you.Ninjas, Bank Robbers, and aspiring Superheroes from the frozen wastes of Canada and North(ern) America can now stay warm as they hide their identity and skulk about in nefarious or righteous ways. Oh yeah -- it's also very comfortable; I recommend the polar fleece over the unaccountably popular wool-and-asbestos version. It can also come in handy as a defense against viral outbreak, a filter for those afflicted with 'Class 9' halitosis, and a fashion accessory for those everyday plastic surgery disasters.The only real problem with this... face... thing... is that it's so comfortable, you won't be able to burn it after the bank robbery.(I'm joking, of course; you should ALWAYS burn your clothes after a bank-robbery.)

If you want a summary of the premise for 'The Following', try this:An FBI agent hunting a vicious serial killer seeks the aid of a brilliant university professor for his insight into the murderer's motivations. As it happens, the prof IS the serial killer. When the truth is revealed, a brutal life or death struggle ensues, except... neither man dies. The killer is fast, striking first and striking hard, but the agent hangs on to consciousness long enough to stop him from finishing the job. The psychopathic professor is badly wounded, but is patched up and sent to prison. The hero is more seriously injured, and bears emotional as well as physical scars. Years later, the now-retired agent is called upon to help with another series of killings that his maniacal nemesis is the key to stopping.That's actually a summary of the premise for 'Red Dragon', but it also sums up the back-story for 'The Following' perfectly well, and comes pretty close to quite a few other serial killer movies and TV shows, of varying quality and limited originality, that have appeared since 'Silence of the Lambs'. The show's writer and creator, Kevin Williamson, knows all about clichés, making a name for himself with 'Scream'; it was a clever satire that played with the comically repetitive tropes of the horror genre, and a fairly suspenseful horror film in its own right. He also created 'Dawson's Creek', and some truly mediocre movies like 'I Know What You Did Last Summer'. There's no real excuse, then, for the criminally derivative aspects of 'The Following', especially coming from a writer as attuned to pop culture precedent as Williamson; actually, there's never any excuse for the recycled garbage that ends up as 'cop show 5267B', but...'The Following' manages to rise above the mire from which it sprang, to some extent. The idea of a serial killer who becomes the leader of a cult devoted enough to carry out his nefarious, convoluted schemes, isn't THAT hard to accept, after the Manson family, and the Patty Hearst case, and Jonestown, etc. Memories of the Heaven's Gate cult, the corpses neatly arrayed in bunk-beds, with their identical track-suits and running shoes, provide a vivid example of the power a disturbed but magnetic guru can exert over followers; murder seems like it's just a couple stops past drinking the poisoned kool-aid on the weirdo-cult crazy train. The Manson family's brief rampage, however, has remained an isolated event in the annals of American crime. What's more, the power a cult leader exerts over his followers is based almost entirely on a freakishly powerful charisma, and once removed from that strange gravity, critical thought processes begin to function in whatever diminished capacity passes for normal amongst cult members, and loyalty wanes. Nevertheless, if the guru was charismatic enough, he might be able to pair his will with a pseudo-religion or philosophy compelling enough to start his own holy war.The idea of using Edgar Allan Poe as a sacred text, however, is pretty uninspired. It's not as whacky as using the lyrics to a Beatles song as a divine manuscript, like Manson did, but 'truth is stranger than fiction', and fiction writers -- unfortunately -- have to try harder than Manson did for something believable; oftentimes motives are a mystery in the real world, but never in fiction. Williamson's use of Poe is pretty lazy. Once again, he stole the idea from 'Red Dragon', in which a serial killer has formulated his own hermetic philosophy based on the art and poetry of William Blake. Blake is a far more interesting inspiration than Poe, who is seemingly the writer of choice for every crappy horror movie and TV show. For all aspiring writers: you might think Poe, Dickens, and Twain are fascinating, and you might believe you have a profound connection to their literature, but dig a little deeper. Williamson, I think, just pulled the name closest to hand and easiest.Everyone else involved tries harder than Williamson did, which isn't that unusual, in network television. James Purefoy is one of my favorite actors. I had a fairly well-defined image of Mark Antony in my mind before watching the HBO series 'Rome', but by the time the series was done, his performance as one of history's most fascinating characters had made Purefoy indistinguishable from the real figure. He was one of the many reasons that series stands out as one of the best ever made -- top 5, unquestionably. In fact, if you haven't seen it yet, forget 'The Following' for now, and watch both seasons of 'Rome'. The same goes for 'The Wire'. If you haven't seen 'The Wire', WTF are you doing here? If, however, you've already gone through the 'best of' list, and have now worked your way down to 'The Following' (waaay down), its got enough story and suspense to hold your interest, and the cast is excellent. The writers have their moments as well, suffering occasional fits of creativity that save the story from drowning in a swamp of deja view.Compared to the inexcusable crap that passes for crime drama on network TV -- like CSI: Miami, Law & Order: SVU, NCIS and Criminal Minds (profilers are only marginally more useful than psychics to any serious investigation -- 'We need an APB on a middle-aged Caucasian male, who may or may not be a bed-wetter, and who probably molested woodchucks as a boy... judging by the pattern of the stab wounds and the butterfly-like shape of the blood-splatters, it is believed this unsub might be dangerous...'), 'The Following' represents a sharp improvement. Compared to the one series whose creators, producers and writers paid for the privilege of ransacking Dr. Lecter's storage locker, however, 'The Following' is far inferior. 'Hannibal' reinterprets the mythos created by author Thomas Harris in ways that are very clever and unexpected. Ironically, it's also the rare show about serial killers and FBI agents that actively avoids falling into the deep ruts previous incarnations of the Hannibal saga have cut into the trail. If it's a question of finding the best take on ingenious psychopathic killers, it's 'Hannibal'. If you can't get enough of this sort of thing, 'The Following' is a distant-but-decent second-place finisher (or third place, if you put 'Bates Motel' in the same category).The inexplicable stupidity really does run rampant: Bacon's character is just a 'consulting agent' (Ugh. How many times...), but every episode finds him rushing to the scene ahead of everyone with just one agent for back-up. Every time this happens, instead of waiting for back-up, he decides to 'go in', but not before sending his partner off to 'cover' the back of the warehouse/farm house/crack house, and face off against multiple armed and dangerous suspects alone. No agent would allow another one to enter a situation like that alone -- and especially not when they're the ones giving the orders. Nevertheless, when the agent in charge of the case allows him to run into the abandoned factory without her in episode 08, she proves completely useless -- the three or four surviving 'followers' come rushing out the door she's been left to cover (they're all armed, but flee when Bacon surprises them and kills the extras without speaking parts, despite the fact that he's alone with a close-to-spent clip), pile into the vehicle she should have rendered inoperable by pulling a spark-plug, or cutting the tires, and escape before the backup that should of accompanied them from the start. Bacon gets held at gunpoint by Joe and his followers over and over again, at which point the gunman always looks smug, says he can't die yet, then makes vague, grandiose threats. He usually manages to get the upper hand before long, and chase his captors before they ultimately escape, capture one of them, or kill them. Hollywood gives the average FBI agent way too much credit for intelligence, imagination, and common sense, and 'The Following' is no different. But the stupidity they display in every crucial situation almost seems like Williamson's anti-authoritarian, passive-aggressive way of giving the feds a narrative b***h-slap.So... the Feds in this series are brain-dead, and they're also way better at killing people than the actual serial killers, and... less bothered by it. The bad guys let them live, then get murdered by Kevin Bacon. Maybe the worst thing, however, the cliché that has it's roots in Greek mythology and drama, is the nemesis. The killer is always the dark reflection of the hero cop. In 'Hannibal', they get back to the myth, in which your nemesis is a doppelganger wearing the antlers of a stag. Will Graham is haunted by stag imagery throughout the series, often in surprising and creepy ways, symbolic of his powerful connection to Hannibal Lecter. So far, Hannibal has avoided uttering some pathetic variation of the line that makes me ill - 'We're not so different, you and I'. It has popped up in hundreds, and possibly thousands, of films and TV episodes since Belloche popularized it in 'Raiders of the Lost Ark', freeing it from its pulp fiction and comic-book origins. Purefoy is a great Nemesis, but the idea is just exhausted. Played out. Done. End it.

[NOTE: To R. Rodriguez -- I nor anyone I know has any relationship to Avatar or anyone even remotely involved with the making of Caliban, and received no free 'review copy' or payment of any sort. Feel better? Of course not. Now STFU with the dumb insinuations. Some people like things you don't like, and I probably hate a couple of the books you think are just freakin' wonderful. It happens. This is the realm of opinion, not fact (for example, I thought 'El Mariachi' and 'Desperadoes' kind of sucked, but your first adaptation of 'Sin City' was excellent)Caliban is not Ennis' best book -- I'd call it a 3.5 out of 5 --  but it's entertaining; if anyone thinks this is his worst, I'm going to make the same kind of BS implications you're apparently into, and say you haven't read much of his work at all. 303 and True Faith - terrible. Streets of Glory, his work on The Darkness -- which was not salvageable, true -- pretty bad. Hitman sucked as well, IMO, and so did his work on the Punisher... or what I read before giving up on it. He tends to work with artists he's also friends with, which is unfortunate, because as much as I loved Preacher back in the day, Steve Dillon proves that being a good person won't make up for being a crappy artist. John McCrea, Carlos Ezquerra, and Mike Wolfer in particular -- all terrible hacks, IMO. Fercundo Percio, on the other hand, is getting quite good, and Jacen Burrows has his moments.]Garth Ennis always gets the first class treatment when he pens a series for Avatar, and rightfully so. Ennis joined Warren Ellis after 'Strange Kiss' and it's sequels (collected in Gravel: Never A Dull Day) introduced William Gravel. After some infuriating editorial meddling and straight-up censorship prompted Ellis to give DC, Vertigo and 'Hellblazer' a cheery 'f**k you'*(See Below), he decided to find an indie label that was big enough to promote and distribute his work effectively, but were willing to let him do whatever the hell he wanted. Avatar, who specialized in publishing some of the most laughably 'written', exploitative tits-and-gore comic trash around, were ecstatic at the notion of becoming the scrap-idea receptacle for one of the hottest writers around. Garth Ennis, who has a genius for writing stories about characters in extreme situations**, was the next writer to find success at Avatar. Alan Moore, Jamie Delano, Jonathan Hickman, David Lapham and Keiron Gillen are among the many acclaimed writers who have followed the Ellis-Ennis lead, and Avatar has made the unlikely transition from a purveyor of SUB-sub-mediocre, ultra-violent softcore porn-comics, to a source of stories too shocking for Vertigo and Image, from some of the mainstream medium's very best writers. While Ellis is still one of the biggest names, and titles like 'Freakangels' (art by Paul Duffield) and 'Crecy' (art by Raulo Caceres) are among the best of his prolific career, it is 'Crossed' by Ennis that is the definitive Avatar book, perhaps the most horrifying and shocking horror-comic of all time.The first-class treatment, in this context, means that any Ennis story gets one of their 'A-List' artists. There's only so many truly talented artists out there, and while Avatar have obviously paid generously to keep Jacen Burrows, Paul Duffield, Gianluca Pagliarani, etc. from being poached by publishers with deeper pockets, others like Oscar Jimenez have moved on to better (paying) things. For 'Caliban', his brilliant take on the space-horror genre, Ennis was matched with Fercundo Percio, one of Avatar's star scribblers, who is absolutely perfect for the futuristic, hardware-heavy backgrounds that the story requires. Wally Wood-type banks of rectangular grids representing buttons or indicators show up here and there, as well as the loops of insulated wire that artists love to add, but overall Percio does an excellent job. Anyone who's tried to draw realistic machinery from a near-future space-ship knows how hard it is to make them look convincing. There's a reason why other artists are so in awe of the 50's/60's SF-work of Wally Wood in particular, and why Geof Darrow's artwork is so revered. Somewhere between Bryan Hitch and John Cassaday, or perhaps Kevin Nowlan, Percio has a nice understanding of contrast, balancing bold outlines with a subtle but exact method of texturing that is fairly unique. Since the first time I discovered his art on the Ellis-scripted Avatar title 'Anna Mercury - Volume 1: The Cutter', his work has greatly improved... and it was pretty damn good to begin with.Starting with an 'Event Horizon', 'Sunshine' or 'Prometheus'-like setting, 'Caliban' begins on a futuristic spaceship with a crew that is obviously jaded to the wonders of warp-travel, but discussion alerts the reader that intelligent life is still an exclusively Earth-bound phenomenon. A mysterious 'collision' that occurs in the no-man's-land of warp-space, however, promises to change everything. Surveying the damage as the 'Caliban' drifts through something analogous to 'the Bleed' (an Ellis 'Planetary' concept), the shaken survivors of the incident discover that their vessel has fused with another ship. They did not collide, but instead occupied the same area of 'subspace' simultaneously. Metal and flesh alike were instantly incorporated, fusing with the alien alloys of the intruding structure. As strange and dire as their situation is, the crew is completely unprepared for the things now inside the crippled, half-alien Siamese-twin that was 'The Caliban'. It might have been a floating cosmic zoo, or an alien scientific expedition returning with specimens, but not everything from the 'xeno-vessel' is dead. As the crew scrambles to seal hatches and protect their remaining atmosphere, and work to make contact with the other ship's operating system via their own computer, one member of their crew is seemingly possessed by something inhuman. When the killing starts, it's as horrifying and brutal as Ennis fans expect. He has a genius for writing violence that is always shocking and unforgettable. Shouldn't violence, even fictional violence, always be shocking? The only gratuitous violence, in my opinion, is the kind that allows readers to pass over it without a second thought. Death should always make an impact, even on the other side of our galaxy. 84/100[INCIDENTAL NOTE: I just watched the mediocre science fiction thriller 'Supernova' on Netflix, a 15-year-old film starring James Spader and Angela Bassett. It concerns a deep-space rescue vessel that takes on board a passenger and a mysterious alien artifact. It alters him physically, and he begins hunting and killing the crew. It's really similar to Caliban, but nowhere near as good. I wonder if Ennis watched this movie when it was released, then promptly forgot all about it, just like everyone else. If it was lodged in his subconscious when he created 'Caliban', at least something positive came from a crappy film... and there's plenty of significant differences.]* (A POST-SCRIPT ABOUT HELLBLAZER, WARREN ELLIS, & AVATAR THAT IS ONLY INDIRECTLY RELATED TO 'CALIBAN' [But it's not like I'll run out of page-space -- no trees were murdered because of this tangent -- I wonder if you could write a book-length review? A 100-page review for a 200-page graphic novel?]) In a match-up that John Constantine fans had been demanding, Vertigo finally hired Warren Ellis to write for the long-running horror comic 'Hellblazer'. It was a 'spin-off', based on the foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, English sorcerer created by Alan Moore in the pages of 'Swamp Thing', and was one of Vertigo's only house brands, since the 'mature reader'-label's primary attraction was that it allowed creator's to retain the rights to their work... for the most part. Ellis's Vertigo cult-hit 'Transmetropolitan' {Transmetropolitan, Vol. 1: Back on the Street} had demonstrated his gift for pitch-black humor, acidic political criticism, and big, crazy idea's. The central character, an infamous journalist nearly driven mad by the hypocrisy, greed and injustice that plagued his 'transmetropolitan' super-city of the near-ish future, shared a lot in common with John Constantine. Ellis was better suited to write 'Hellblazer' than perhaps any writer before or since, including the Irish writer who did more to make Constantine such a fascinating, indelible anti-hero -- Garth Ennis (his run is one of the longest and the best, although Brian Azzarello's version of the character is also unforgettable).The first couple issues of the Warren Ellis run were excellent, particularly those featuring art by the criminally overlooked genius of Marcelo Frusin, and hinted at what was to come (Frusin has a wicked chiaroscuro/ligne-claire style, similar to that of Eduardo Risso, and he was obviously a favorite partner-in-crime for Azzarello. Of all the esteemed artists charged with interpreting the iconic character -- Simon Bisley, Mark Buckingham, Richard Corben, Steve Dillon, Jock, David Lloyd, Leonardo Manco, and Sean Phillips, to name a few -- Frusin's near-perfect art captured the darkness at Constantine's core the most vividly, reminding everyone that he was a dangerous man).Then everything went to hell for Hellblazer. An Ellis script involving guns and angry school-kids was scrapped by DC, due to a then-recent real-life school-shooting. Ellis was furious at having an entire storyline rejected, and drama ensued. A few months later, a British S.A.S.'Combat Magician' started having all manner of wild and disturbing adventures, beginning with the 3-issue mini-series 'Strange Kiss', as Ellis adapted his ideas for John Constantine to fit the equally intriguing William Gravel. I think Ellis was so high on righteous indignation he could have cared less who published the 'Gravel' stories. He wanted an editor-free environment, but it was almost as much about giving DC the middle finger (or two fingers in a 'V', as Brits prefer) as it was about comics. DC has inspired this kind of hatred before (most notably after infuriating Alan Moore with a passive-aggressive campaign of intimidation, insults and harassment. They nearly drove him insane with their vindictive persecution and petty, sleazy punishments, all intended to induce cooperation regarding their awful film adaptations of his brilliant work. Why they would be so childish and aggressively hostile to the writer gave them the greatest superhero stories ever written, and some of their biggest money-makers, is baffling).The modern Avatar is built on spite, but they definitely profited from the deal, becoming a home for angry British ex-pats who write comics that grab the reader by the throat and shake like a Rottweiler. They publish crap as well; Hickman's 'God is Dead' had promise, but went very wrong right from the start, with Hickman providing rough storylines that his partner proceeded to butcher, and a D-list artist who is among the worst hacks I've come across. P.S.: Warren Ellis and DC made peace, or at least agreed to a truce, eventually... and the rejected Ellis storyline was published a few years later. 'Hellblazer' passed away, recently. After reaching the ripe old age of 300 (issues, that is), DC 'cancelled' the Vertigo title and moved 'Constantine' back into the DC Universe, where he can play with Wonder Woman and Green Lantern. The new 'Constantine' TV series hasn't quite managed to catch the magic of the Vertigo series; if it were a bit nastier, and uglier, it could be quite good, I think. The actor they found to play the title role is perfect, with exactly the look and punk rock attitude necessary, and a huge improvement on Keanu freakin' Reeves.**Garth Ennis, A Recommended Reading List For People With Strong Stomachs: ('Hellblazer: Tainted Love', 'Fear and Loathing' and 'Damnation's Flame'; Preacher: Book 1 - 6; War Stories: Volume 1 and 2; Garth Ennis' Complete Battlefields: Volume 1 - 3; Crossed, Volume 1 and 4; Rover Red Charlie: Volume 1)
Great film, but you should definitely avoid the sequel, 'Old People F***ing'. Unless... you know... you're into that.

Dig this premise, 'cause it's going to blow the top of your head off (if you have absolutely no knowledge of the Judaeo-Christian and Islamic mythologies that people still enjoy killing each other about): Jews and Christians have used every crumbling scroll and codex to get their sneak peek of Armageddon, and secretive, fundamentalist factions devoted to each of their respective visions of the near-future are actively conspiring to bother God until he pushes the big red button... or whatever mechanism he keeps handy just in case a rescheduling of the planned Heat Death of the Universe is in order. Reacting to the birth of a red Norwegian cow (! and ?), Hasidic Jews somehow crash an amazingly unprotected archaeological dig-site under Temple Mount (which is perhaps the most contentious chunk of religious real estate in the Western world, sacred to Jews, Christians and Muslims); they then entreat Adonai in the divine language he seems to prefer -- candles, chanting, and goat's blood (apparently the only frequency God hears is still the 'dead animal channel', so you can either stop praying, or buy your chicken so fresh it can both cluck and die). Christians in Nevada, meanwhile, have their own crazy-ass ideas about the apocalypse, involving what might be a 'Boys From Brazil'-type scenario, based on Gnostic variations of the New Testament long ago expunged with the other apocryphal scriptures (maybe...).Is your head blown off? No? You don't find the religious prophecy that's been bleated loudly in all directions for thousands of years fresh and exciting? Hell, I don't know, maybe you do. Why not go to church and get the story? I'm kidding, obviously, nobody's going to do something that ridiculous. Myself, I wasn't too interested in yet another take on the Judaeo-Christian End-of-days, which I consider to be about as likely as Ragnarok or a zombie plague. I was less interested still in seeing it done by Tim Kring, who created 'Heroes'. I don't think I need to explain why. But the commercials looked pretty good, so I gave it a try.After all of that poking at deeply-held-convictions with a sharp stick, you might be confused by the four-star constellation shining down on this review. 'Dig' may start with a very old and tattered idea, and Tim Kring is responsible for a terrible atrocity that can never be forgiven, but the pilot was pretty entertaining. Mining details from 'Raiders of the Lost Ark' and 'The Boys From Brazil', Kring stole from the best and made it all his own, but specifics will give too much away. Jason Isaacs is an excellent actor, and a great choice for the male lead. He plays FBI agent Peter Connelly, who is stationed in Israel... for some reason; he becomes personally entangled in a case that puts him in the midst of all the religious conspiring. Anne Heche is also very good as his superior, with whom he is once again 'personally entangled', as the kids like to say. It feels like Heche fell off the edge of the world a decade or so back, but she has returned from her cryo-tube unchanged, for the most part. Burkas aren't a good idea in Israel, but she should think about making a dangerous fashion statement and wearing one, because her skin is way too pale for the Middle East. With that brilliant observation, I'll stop reviewing and describing. It's too early to say with any certainty how successful this show will be, but the pilot was both surprising and entertaining; not revolutionary, but unique in a way I wasn't expecting, and the international locations add to its intriguing take on a tired subject. There was some silliness here and there, but the writing was very solid. I'll give this a 4.5 out of 5, and hope for the best.P.S.: 5 episodes in, it looks like my early guesses about 'Boys From Brazil'-type clones of Jesus were right. But... since Jesus was/is the Son of God, or one of His three aspects, it's doubtful that cloning his physical 'vessel' would force Almighty God to reprise his critically acclaimed role as Mankind's savior, since he likes to take credit for creating the universe. If the clones were not made as pre-teen prisons for Jesus/God, the other option is obvious -- he's the Anti-Christ, a necessary component for the machinations of Armageddon. While some people have been pretty hard on this series, I've been pleasantly surprised.

OR: The Alien Rapture; The Figurative Becomes Its Symbolic Essence, Ascending as Pure Abstraction... Something Like That.For anyone who appreciates the art of Ali Banisadr: buy this book now, and do so quickly. For those unfamiliar with the name -- why are you reading this? ;) . Ali Banisadr is the most important artist of his generation, and that little secret has reached very few ears. This beautiful, clothbound hardcover, '125 Paintings', is a catalogue raisonne of his artistic output to date. Since previous monographs have only collected about half the work included, this is one of those rare times that the book I've been wishing someone would make actually got made... and surpassed my hopes and expectations. I own hundreds of art-books, and this one has immediately moved into my top five.*Trying to explain what you see in the work of an artist is always difficult, but that's never stopped me from trying to do with words what a Google Image search will do instantly and perfectly... If you combine -- 1.) the complicated and delicate beauty of the Persian miniatures (relics of his Iranian heritage and childhood; his family fled the chaos of the 1979 revolution, emigrating to the US); 2.) the bird's eye view and intricate, sprawling triptychs of Bosch; 3.) the equally complex works of Bruegel and Altdorfer; 4.) the graphic language of motion invented by the Futurist painters Boccioni, Balla and Depero; 5.) the mix of modern subjects and medieval allegory introduced by Werner Tubke and Ernst Fuchs; 6.) the early abstraction of Kupka and Kandinsky; 7.) the abstract Surrealism of Matta-Echaurren; 8.) the fusion of form and movement that define the disturbing vision of Francis Bacon; and 9.) the methods of paint removal found in the abstract oeuvre of Gerhard Richter; as well as 10.) the meticulous layering, archaeological-feel, and pentimento-like effects of uncovering those buried layers, in works like De Kooning's 'Excavation' -- you might get a basic idea of the genius that is evident in the paintings of Ali Banisadr.No artist has so successfully blended the figurative and the abstract, with stunningly rich colors and delicately rendered forms that vaguely resemble costumed revelers or scenes of monstrous carnage. His 'characters' are like lavishly, garishly adorned supernatural entities, moving too quickly for the eye to accurately see, captured on camera mid-motion, out-of-focus and under-exposed... the viewer might be looking down on another circle of existence, a demonic mandala of nameless demi-gods oblivious to humanity, gathering on what might be a battlefield, or a marketplace, or a graveyard. There appear sometimes revelers in brightly-hued silken finery and grotesque masks, costumed for a Venetian carnival that itself masks a Satanic ritual at its heart. We might be looking through the golden retinas of an angel in flight, seeing the souls shining through the skin of ordinary mortals... or an alien perspective in 11 dimensions, translated back into 2D oil on linen and canvas after the artist received this intergalactic-telepathic-transmission he interpreted as a dream. Or maybe it's just... stuff, informed by a deep connection to the great artists of the past. I don't care. His work is endlessly fascinating and beautiful.This 250-page, 9 x 12-inch volume features an interesting and well-written introductory essay and a great interview with the artist. Following his artistic progression between 2007 and 2015, this monograph is unbelievably dense and rich. Charting his evolution with perfect clarity, the early paintings of 2007 and 2008 could almost be called figurative. With his transitional masterwork 'The Hashashins', however, he moved in the direction that would soon crystallize into his own unique, immediately recognizable style -- the canvases exhibited by Galerie Thaddeus Ropac and collected in the accompanying 2010 catalog.That catalog (now selling for ridiculous prices) was my introduction to Banisadr's work, a complete revelation I stumbled onto while checking out the work of Raqib Shaw (another inspired artist exhibited by GTR). Those often massive, groundbreaking canvases and diptychs -- like 'The Gatekeepers', 'The Merchants', 'What They Cannot See', 'Nothing That is So is So', 'The Charlatans', and 'The Magians' --  illustrate just how quickly and confidently Banisadr embraced this new approach; those mysterious visions of a secret world, with their evocative, alchemical titles and themes, encapsulated everything that I love about art.'One Hundred and Twenty Five Paintings' collects his early efforts from group and solo shows, all of the works from the GTR catalogues, as well as the just released HC catalog from his latest exhibition, 'Motherboard'. Best of all, it features his newest, as yet uncollected works from 2014/15, including a double gatefold spread of the monumental 5' x 24'-triptych, 'At Once', the central piece from his first solo UK show. This stunningly ambitious painting might be his masterpiece, incorporating all the themes, textures, and brilliant, carefully considered colors that have defined his vision for the last six years -- reflection and dichotomy; fixation, and forms caught in the midst of furious, preternatural motion; chimerical fusions and mutations; a division between heaven and earth, spirit and matter, ancient and modern; subtle monochromatic miniatures and massively-scaled explosions of vibrant, violent color.Using glossy, acid-free archival stock of the highest quality, this monograph features several gatefold reproductions and many full-page details; needless to say, the plates are all photographed with the resolution and clarity you'd expect from such a publication, even though I've come across some other-wise well-made art-books with terribly reproduced plates. '125 Paintings' does what it's meant to do -- serve as a massive retrospective exhibition, the best source available for art-lovers. Banisadr's paintings are too expensive for most of us, but even the rich will have only a couple works. Exhibitions shows eventually close, and much of his work is scattered all over the planet, hidden away in private collections, or galleries, or in specialized art storage house. This book is the best and most complete source on the art of Ali Banisadr. Highest Recommendations.P.S.: If there are no copies for sale on Amazon, you can try here, directly from the publisher (it's where I went; shipping was pricey, but it arrived in 6 business days):http://www.blainsouthern.com/bookshop/50P.S.2: *[Footnote for the end of Paragraph 1] The last monograph I was this enthused about, transcending some already high expectations, was Walton Ford's 'Pancha Tantra'; with over 300 pages collecting his most important work, a brilliant watercolor fusion of natural history, allegory, and under-stated Surrealism/Symbolism, the power of the art was translated very faithfully into the bibliographic medium. Beautifully produced and over 11 x 15 inches, it still has a couple minor 'flaws' -- it's a trilingual international edition, and doesn't match the level of quality materials and construction found in '125 Paintings'. The only other contemporary art favorites that share a similar proximity to monographic perfection would be: The Gagosian Gallery and Rizzoli's 'Glenn Brown: Three Exhibitions'; their slipcased retrospective on the career of Lucian Freud; the Hatje Cantz publication 'Neo Rauch: Paintings -- Leipzig-Munich'; the D.A.P. and Marlborough Gallery collaboration on 'Vincent Desiderio: Paintings - 1975-2005'; 'Akira Yamaguchi: The Big Picture', by Seigensha; 'Michael Borremans: As Sweet as it Gets', by Hatje Cantz; 'Flogging a Dead Horse: The Life and Work of Jake & Dinos Chapman', by Rizzoli; 'Darren Waterston: Representing the Invisible', by Charta; and the Hatje Cantz edition of my favorite book of Photograhy, 'Taryn Simon: An American Index of the Hidden and Unfamiliar'. Those are just a few examples of what I consider the best Contemporary Art-Books; if you consider books on various artists from throughout Art History, the list gets even more difficult to limit to a few volumes.[In anticipation of the increasingly rare comments whining about word-counts: I apologize if that review seemed overly long, without actually feeling apologetic. Too long? Stop reading. This isn't a newspaper -- journalists aren't clawing each others eyes out over page-space; no trees will die due to a rambling editorial that requires an extra 4-page fold. In fact, I'd say I was remarkably concise; if a picture's worth a thousand words, I still owe Mr. Banisadr One Hundred and Twenty Four Grand, but I'm sure he'll let the debt slide.]

Yet Another British cop drama, and Yet Another show set in a small, idyllic community, this time on the Dorset Coast, in Southwest England. It's Yet Another gritty blend of mystery and police procedural, following the investigation into the death of a 11-year old boy. Once Again we meet the many bland and eccentric personalities that make up a small town, delving into the lies both harmless and explosive that expose the ugliness just below that quaint surface. Of Course, you have wrong turns and red herrings, before the final, shocking revelation.Just another cop drama... except it isn't. Not remotely. I don't think there's ever been a BBC or ITV drama as emotionally engaging and intellectually satisfying as 'Broadchurch'. Any synopsis is going to completely fail in its attempt to convey the power of this short, nearly perfect series. I had heard comments about 'Broadchurch', but a brief look at the premise suggested 'just another well-done, mostly forgettable BBC-ITV series'. It took a while, due to my lack of enthusiasm, but I finally got around to watching it. Needless to say, I'm glad I did. Forget the plot, forget the actors -- although the two leads are brilliant, particularly David Tennant -- all you need to know is that, along with the French series 'The Returned', this is the best European television drama of the last few years.

In the abandoned warehouses that post-apocalyptic survivors always enjoy visiting, scientific shenanigans are underway. They send Cole back a few decades, to 2015. He does the typical time-tourist bulls**t, flirting with dead girls, shooting people and then making speeches that underline the importance of his world-saving mission, one that nullifies all ethical dilemmas. That's fine. A viral armageddon is imminent, so kill whoever you want. Suddenly, he begins to flicker like a hologram run through an old-timey silent-film era projector, then disappears. He re-appears in the Lazy-Boy recliner/time-machine. 'What happened?' he asks. 'We had to bring you back early', is the reply. Huh. That makes no sense. The idea of sending someone decades into the past means that you can set the return time -- be it one minute or one week or one year -- and bring them back ASAP. The notion of the people behind the time machine switches WAITING on Cole, praying he manages to learn what he needs to learn in 2 hours -- even though that two hour period already happened twenty years ago -- and being forced by attacking Road Warrior-extras to bring him home after just 1 hour and 34 minutes, because they can't WAIT any longer... that's just too stupid to justify. I've seen other time-travel stories that use the same inexplicably moronic premise, and it's a clear indicator of lazy writing. You don't have to wait one hour to give a time traveller one hour in the past. You send him back, set his return for sixty minutes later, and immediately bring him home -- to him sixty minutes passed, to the time-machine operators from the future, thirty seconds have passed. But... 'racing against time' is the soul of suspense, so in 'Twelve Monkeys' we get this inexplicable fixed-time correlation, something they ignore when it's inconvenient.The concept of time-travel is almost always terribly executed in film -- reverse time travel is ridiculous (even if it is theoretically possible), but forward time-travel is not just possible, it's something that's always 'happening' throughout the universe, thanks to relativity; fictional space-ships that approach the speed of light experience time-dilation, with travellers on board experiencing just a fraction of the years that passed back on earth. Gravity stretches space-time: even the atomic clocks on satellites in high-orbit record time as 'faster', relative to those of us feeling the full gravitational pull of Earth's modest mass. The atomic clocks from downed satellites, compared with those on the ground they were originally synchronized with, always differ by exactly the nanoseconds predicted.Then there's multiversal possibilities, and M-theory -- seeing 'time-travel' as multiversal navigation amongst infinite narrative tracks. Hollywood is still stuck with a time machine created by H.G. Wells, a distinctly Newtonian SF vision that predated relativity and quantum mechanics.Still... the original '12 Monkeys', directed by Terry Gilliam and written by David Peoples, was one of the best SF films of the nineties. This series is basically a remake, and while it ejects much of the brilliance Gilliam brought to the endeavor, the show's creators find enough inspiration of their own to make for an entertaining story... as long as you don't think about it much. The actors do a fine job, particularly Kirk Acevedo in a supporting role; he's making a career out of stories featuring monkeys, the apocalypse, time-travel and parallel realities: from '12 Monkeys' to 'Dawn of the Planet of the Apes', 'Fringe' and 'The Walking Dead'. Aaron Stanford, who plays Cole, seemed to drop off the Hollywood grid after a big start in the indie film 'Tadpole' and 'X-Men' 2 and 3. The time-travel notwithstanding, each episode has improved on the one before it, and the writing maintains a level of suspense that allows you to enjoy the ride without giving that critical voice a chance to get too yappy. [4 out of 5]

Yeah... I'd feel like a hypocrite praising 'Under the Skin' and completely dismissing 'Beyond the Black Rainbow'. It's a rich audio-visual experience. The film-maker has been digesting much of the cult-cinema from the seventies and eighties, cheap SF television, the culture of paranoia that trailed behind the cold war and the constant threat of nuclear annihilation. After metabolizing this toxic goo for a couple decades, 'Beyond the Black Rainbow' is either the strange energy he managed to harvest, or the crap he left behind. Or both. Let's say 'both'. I loved the regressive trip back into my earliest childhood memories; the eighties have almost become something I thought they'd never, ever, be -- nostalgic. The imagery is lifted from films like 'The Hunger' and 'Alien', very heavy on the Scott-school of movie-making. As for the story... who the f*** cares. If you're looking for an engaging story, flee now, and start screaming 'No' if anyone you care about suggests giving it a try, rocking back and forth in the fetal position and whimpering until they've forgotten all about it. If you suffer from insomnia, I heartily recommend it; insomniacs are going to be almost the only people able to watch the whole thing without passing out, and there's a good chance it'll cure them. Seriously. If you're high, I'm going to offer some counter-intuitive advice, and say stay the hell away... especially if it happens to be an hallucinogenic or psychotropic substance. Visually rich does not equal entertaining... In fact, other than insomniacs and speed-freaks trying to come down, I can't recommend this film to anyone.

Kramer's Ergot established itself as the most important comics anthology of the millennium, particularly Volumes 5, 6 and 7. Volume 7 is the legendary over-sized 16 x 21-inch hardcover, borrowing the format introduced by Sunday Press for their equally ground-breaking centenary reprints of the original 'Little Nemo in Slumberland' pages. Reproducing the exact dimensions of the fin-de-siècle broadsheets, these archival facsimiles were a revelation for McCay fans new and old; Kramers Ergot creator-editor-contributor Sammy Harkham had the idea to allow some of the world's most brilliant and cutting edge cartoonists a chance to create work in the same massive tabloid scale, a challenge that yielded brilliant results. Volumes 5 and 6 were both produced as 10 x 11.5-inch flexi-bound books with vinyl covers, and were both around 350-pages long. They share the same high-quality materials and design as Volume 7, and feature a rich and diverse assortment of avant garde artists working at their peak.Volume 8 faced a couple of serious problems. Firstly, it was released by Picturebox instead of Buenaventura Press; Picturebox is an excellent indie publisher, but previous instalments benefitted from the creative input of co-editor and publisher Alvin Buenaventura. In his absence, the eighth outing experienced a quality decline on every level. Secondly, Kramer's Ergot faced a clear navigational crisis. Having made its name as a consistently surprising and ambitious anthology, the question of where to go after releasing a book as stunning as Volume 7 became a serious one. No matter what they did, it would seem like a regression... so they didn't bother to try. It's not as bad as other reviewers have made it out to be -- at least IMO, for what it's worth -- but it doesn't stand up to past volumes. It's a smaller, clothbound edition, but it's nicely constructed, with several changes in paper stock to best suit the material. It's also shorter than 5 or 6, with stories from the usual suspects that range from brilliant to uninspired. New contributors fail to leave any positive impressions, particularly the selections of artwork chosen to illustrate the book's loose thematic direction.

Considering there have been about 28 people killed in the sleepy little town of White Pines since the Bates showed up, the residents are remarkably unfazed. If they have a population of 2800, 1% of the town's residents have been murdered in a period of several months. If that death-rate continues, Norman, Dylan, and Sheriff Romero will wipe out the entire community in just under six years, AND all three of them have full-time jobs or school to deal with. Excellent work.I had fairly low hopes for this show. Gus Van Sant's remake of 'Psycho' was a perfect example of 'Why are we doing this again?'-film-making; a shot-for-shot redux of Hitchcock's classic. But 'Bates Motel' is a very different breed of stuffed owl; it sets the iconic house and motel in a modern-day environment, and takes on the ambitious task of charting the transformation of Norman Bates -- from the polite, helpful. sensitive boy who is intensely close to his mother, to the completely insane 'Psycho' who stuffs her dead body and becomes 'possessed' by her murderously punitive pseudo-personality. There's more soap than subtlety here, but the writers keep the drama simmering 1-degree below boiling-point whenever a situation isn't in straight-up melt-down mode. The town of White Pines is like Twin Peaks, if the residents traded in their LSD and Shrooms for good old-fashioned coke and a few metric tonnes of sour diesel. Nestor Carbonell is brilliant as Sheriff Romero, bringing a gravity and enigmatic charisma with him from 'Lost' (where several of the writers and producers, like Carlton Cuse and Javier Grillo Marxuach, were scribbling and pointing and yelling before they moved into the Bates Motel). Max Theriot -- who joins Nestor in the 'Guys who look like they're wearing eye-liner, even though they aren't'-club -- plays Norman's brother, Dylan Masset, the true wild card thrown into the game. As the older half-brother who has long been treated like an outsider, forced to endure his the obvious favoritism she displays toward Norman. As Dylan becomes an integral part of the drug-production that props up the local economy, with plenty of his own troubles, he is forced to do terrible things to protect his family, saving their lives again and again. Dylan is the voice of reason, and along with Emma, the conscience of the series. The fact that he's a drug-trafficker and a killer makes it all the more sweetly ironic. After the shock he received in season 2 about his father, and the position of power he has stumbled into, season 3 promises to be interesting. Norma and Norman are the crux of the matter, however; Vera Farmiga has been creeping up on genius in her performance, handling the one character more complicated than Norman with a deftness and subtlety that is lacking in the story. And then there's Norman himself -- facing the crucible that might trigger the inevitable break in his psyche, like an egg cell dividing to produce twins.The series is a bit uneven at times, with over-the-top scenarios that no one seems to be reacting to in a realistic way -- (SPOILERS) the storyline involving Keith Summers' sex-slave ring ends with the girl they rescued being chased into the woods by the Deputy; after he's dead, they're all sitting around devising a story, instead of trying to find her -- he claimed to have killed her, but he might have been lying, or he might have been wrong; she could have been badly injured, but alive. No one's going to see how the poor sex slave is doing? Really? Then there's the question that gets repeated about 20 times per episode, in many creative combinations: 'Are you alright?' 'I'm fine.' 'Are you okay?' 'Yep!' 'Is there something wrong?' 'No, why would there be anything wrong?' 'You know you can tell me what's troubling you Norman, you know that, right?' 'I do know that. And thank you. But everything's fine.' Everyone's constantly asking each other if they're 'fine' or 'okay'. It happens quite frequently, and once I noticed, it became pretty annoying. But it's not that big a deal. I suggest you forget I mentioned it in the first place. You'll be okay, right?This is yet another addictive, beautifully crafted series that threatens to overtake the traditional film in terms of artistic importance. There have been very few films that are as powerful as The Wire, Game of Thrones, Rome, Breaking Bad, The Pacific and Band of Brothers, Deadwood, The Walking Dead, The Sopranos, Boardwalk Empire, Fargo, Broadchurch, The Returned, The Shield, Vikings, The Borgias, Banshee, Penny Dreadful, Black Sails, Orphan Black, Bates Motel... and those are just some of the best dramas.

Considering there have been about 28 people killed in the sleepy little town of White Pines since the Bates showed up, the residents are remarkably unfazed. If they have a population of 2800, 1% of the town's residents have been murdered in a period of several months (it's probably bigger, seeing as how they apparently have a community college; but even at 28 000, it's still 1 person dead in a thousand). If that death-rate continues, Norman, Dylan, and Sheriff Romero will wipe out the entire community before long, AND all three of them have full-time jobs or school to deal with. Excellent work.I had fairly low hopes for this show. Gus Van Sant's remake of 'Psycho' was a perfect example of 'Why are we doing this again?'-film-making; a shot-for-shot redux of Hitchcock's classic. But 'Bates Motel' is a very different breed of stuffed owl; it sets the iconic house and motel in a modern-day environment, and takes on the ambitious task of charting the transformation of Norman Bates -- from the polite, helpful. sensitive boy who is intensely close to his mother, to the completely insane 'Psycho' who stuffs her dead body and becomes 'possessed' by her murderously punitive pseudo-personality. There's more soap than subtlety here, but the writers keep the drama simmering 1-degree below boiling-point whenever a situation isn't in straight-up melt-down mode. The town of White Pines is like Twin Peaks, if the residents traded in their LSD and Shrooms for good old-fashioned coke and a few metric tonnes of 'sour diesel' -- they're high-strung and weird. but not David Lynch-weird.Nestor Carbonell is brilliant as Sheriff Romero, bringing a gravity and enigmatic charisma with him from 'Lost' (where several of the writers and producers, like Carlton Cuse and Javier Grillo Marxuach, were scribbling and pointing and yelling before they moved into the Bates Motel). Max Theriot -- who joins Nestor in the 'Guys who look like they're wearing eye-liner, even though they aren't'-club -- plays Norman's brother, Dylan Masset, the true wild card thrown into the game; he's the older half-brother who has long been treated like an outsider, forced to endure the obvious favoritism his mother displays toward Norman. As Dylan becomes an integral part of the drug-production that props up the local economy, with plenty of his own troubles, he is forced to do terrible things to protect his family, saving their lives again and again. Dylan is the voice of reason, and along with Emma, the conscience of the series. The fact that he's a drug-trafficker and a killer makes it all the more sweetly ironic. After the shock he received in season 2 about his father, and the position of power he has stumbled into, season 3 promises to be interesting. Norma and Norman are the crux of the matter, however; Vera Farmiga has been creeping up on genius in her performance, handling the one character more complicated than Norman with a deftness and subtlety that is lacking in the story. And then there's Norman himself -- facing the crucible that might trigger the inevitable break in his psyche, like an egg cell dividing to produce twins.The series is a bit uneven at times, with over-the-top scenarios that no one seems to be reacting to in a realistic way -- (SPOILERS) the storyline involving Keith Summers' sex-slave ring ends with the girl they rescued being chased into the woods by the Deputy; after he's dead, they're all sitting around devising a story, instead of trying to find her -- he claimed to have killed her, but he might have been lying, or he might have been wrong; she could have been badly injured, but alive. No one's going to see how the poor sex slave is doing? Really? Then there's the question that gets repeated about 20 times per episode, in many creative combinations: 'Are you alright?' 'I'm fine.' 'Are you okay?' 'Yep!' 'Is there something wrong?' 'No, why would there be anything wrong?' 'You know you can tell me what's troubling you Norman, you know that, right?' 'I do know that. And thank you. But everything's fine.' Everyone's constantly asking each other if they're 'fine' or 'okay'. It happens quite frequently, and once I noticed, it became pretty annoying. But it's not that big a deal. I suggest you forget I mentioned it in the first place. You'll be okay, right?This is yet another addictive, beautifully crafted series that threatens to overtake the traditional film in terms of artistic importance. Or maybe not; it's always engaging and smartly written, but it's probably not one of the upper echelon shows... close, but no. There have been very few films that are as powerful as The Wire, Game of Thrones, Rome, Breaking Bad, The Pacific and Band of Brothers, Deadwood, The Walking Dead, The Sopranos, Boardwalk Empire, Fargo, Broadchurch, The Returned, The Shield, Vikings, The Borgias, Banshee, Penny Dreadful, Black Sails, Orphan Black, Bates Motel... and those are just some of the best dramas. The last few may not belong in the same class as the first few, but they're pretty darn entertaining, and still going strong. When the final episode has aired, we'll have a better chance at deciding where Bates Motel ranks.UPDATE: Season 3 was far from a disappointment, in my opinion, but it represented a significant change in the scope of the narrative. Bates Motel during seasons 1 and 2 was much more of a high-end soap opera in the Twin Peaks tradition, and the townspeople played larger roles, making for a large, ensemble cast. Season 3 has tightened its focus on the Bates family and their closest friends and enemies. The psychological degeneration of Norman has accelerated, and Norma has served as the clear axis-point. Her relationships define the course of events throughout this ten-episode run -- with the son she'll do anything to protect, but is starting to fear; with the prodigal son, Dylan, who she has become close to again, and has come to rely upon more than anyone else; with Sheriff Romero, who now seems to feel as strongly about her as she might feel about him; and with new friends and enemies, like the helpful psychiatrist she becomes romantically involved with, and the murderous proprietor of a very exclusive, sociopathic social club, who she tries to blackmail. I won't reveal anything more, because there are many surprises throughout. There are some predictable moments as well, but all in all, Bates Motel is still one of the most compelling shows on television.

Just a brief review and a piece of advice, to be taken or left behind, for Clerici fans. Heellooo! Are there any people interested in one of the 20th century's greatest, and by far, most under-rated artists? I honestly have no idea; as someone whose interests have always diverged from those of friends and family, I'm used to making earnest, impassioned speeches about things that make the other person's eyes go dead and fishlike, as they silently implore some ancient demon to kill me -- or at least f*** up my voice-box.Since Skira published this beautiful retrospective monograph on the centenary of his birth, there's definitely a couple of us scattered across the 'New World', but most of the artistic appreciation still derives from his homeland of Italy. I am drawn to surrealism, but the group that orbited Andre Masson in Paris were not the beginning-point of surrealism in it's broader sense, and they certainly weren't the end. Bosch, Bruegel, Durer, Arcimboldo, Rosa, Goya, Bocklin, Moreau, Redon, Segantini, Hodler, Delville, Khnopff, Ensor, Klinger, Von Stuck, Klimt, Picasso, Dix, Grosz, Radziwill, Boccioni, Balla, Carra, De Chirico -- throughout art history, the fantastic has found its way to the canvas; artists have mined the dreaming-worlds for unnatural resources long before Ernst and Dali.Clerici is my pick for the greatest surrealist painter of the last century; both Clerici and DeChirico were powerfully influenced by another criminally under-appreciated artist, this time from the 19th century -- Arnold Bocklin. Again and again, Clerici takes imagery from the great Symbolist's oeuvre, particularly one of the most famous of his many masterpieces, 'The Isle of the Dead'. But Clerici's paintings are far different from any artist who came before him; comparing his work to other 20th century Surrealists, you find the subtle yet powerful compositional mysteries of DeChirico, with a mastery of fantastic realism that exceeded even the prodigious technical abilities of Dali. This is the book on Clerici that I've been waiting for, and thankfully, it includes an English translation next to the Italian..

If someone crammed Hernan Bas, Peter Doig, and Adrian Ghenie into a super-collider, you would end up with three dead, liquefied artists, their flesh, bone and viscera reduced to a spreadable paste.If you forget about the super-collider and the dead-artist condiments, Marius Bercea could be seen as an aesthetic and thematic synthesis of the aforementioned trio. He possesses the Gauguin-influenced oil-on-linen eeriness of Doig; some of the playful, surreal, faux-primitivism of Bas; and aspects of Adrian Ghenie and Victor Man's high-concept fusion of dark symbolism, abstraction, and the Richter-inspired photo-realism that informed their early development.Like Ghenie and Man, Bercea is part of the 'Cluj School', a group of talented figurative painters who have helped to revitalize the Romanian art-world. While they are linked by age (roughly), geography and shared history, and are all painters who prefer figurative styles, there is more difference between the work of Bercea and fellow Cluj-schooler Serban Savu than there is between Bercea and Canadian/British painter Peter Doig. Nevertheless, the Romanian painters are giving the art-world good reason to pay attention, doing their part to resuscitate an artistic heritage that was almost obliterated after decades of political and cultural oppression by pseudo-Communist dictator Nicolae Ceaucescu.

This is formula horror at its worst. Dumb in every possible direction, as far as the eye can see. I think the most disturbing thing about Ouija is that investors threw money at an obviously terrible screenplay, apparently written by a committee of business school undergrads. It's offensive and insulting to horror connoisseurs that Hollywood schlock-specialists would have the audacity to dump this slop in the movie-going feed trough, and expect us to like it. To them, I simply say: F*U*C*K*Y*O*U*. You probably won't need advice from the ol' Ouija board to figure out I hated this film, and I didn't need some bored ghost to tell me that this movie sucks.

Beksinski belongs to an elite class of fantastic realists who transcend the 'Spectrum'-crowd. It's not easy to explain the distinction between the work that ends up on paperback covers -- from sword-and-sorcery heavyweights of old like Frank Frazetta, to modern day favorites like Brom -- from the art of painters like Zdzislaw Beksinski, Ernst Fuchs, and Takato Yamamoto. The difference between fine art and illustration often seems completely arbitrary; it's a matter of subjective judgements, often influenced by the professional status of the artist: if the artist paints book covers for a living, and the work in question was commissioned for, and based upon, a fantasy or science fiction novel, it's illustration. That doesn't mean that illustration can't stand on its own merits, and be appreciated as fine art, of course.But in the realm of figurative/representational artwork based on dreams, imagination, and symbolism, you find the most confusing array of often over-lapping categories in modern and post-modern art:Surrealism (the original European group including Dali, Ernst and Magritte), Neo-Surrealism (modern-day contemporary artists like Neo Rauch, Jonas Burgert, Ruprecht Von Kaufmann, and Glenn Brown);Pop Surrealism (an 'alternative' art trend that includes Robert Williams, Mark Ryden, Todd Schorr, Tiffany Bozic, and James Jean);Fantastic Realism (Ernst Fuchs, Werner Tubke, H.R. Giger, Zdzislaw Beksinski, and younger artists like Michael Triegel);andMagic Realism (which is also the category many of the most popular and talented fantasy/science fiction illustrators best fit into, such as Brom, Kinuko J. Craft, Gil Bruvel, Michael Hiep, and Rodney Wood).There's others that share similar themes and subject matter, of course. Romanticism, particularly the strain dubbed 'Dark Romanticism' in a brilliant exhibition and monograph of the same name, is where the modern incarnations of the fantastic can trace their lineage. Even more important, Dark Romanticism evolved into the loosely defined movement known as Symbolism; from the Romantics like Goya, John Martin and Caspar David Friedrich, the most influential and original Symbolists -- Gustave Moreau, Henri Fusseli, Arnold Bocklin, Ferdinand Hodler, Giovanni Segantini, Edward Burne-Jones, George Frederick Watts, John William Waterhouse, Fernand Khnopff, Jean Delville, Leon Frederic, Odilon Redon, Carlos Schwabe, Sascha Schneider, Max Klinger -- embraced the sublime and the fantastic in a way that hadn't been done since the days of Bosch, Bruegel and Durer.Before Surrealism had really taken root, New Objectivist artists Otto Dix, George Grosz and Max Beckmann explored the darkest, most nightmarish elements of the subconscious and the ugly truths they had to tell about humanity's violent and selfish nature. In the late 20's and 30's, Dix in particular painted very dark dreamlike allegories that were very different from the experimental, instinctive methods that the Surrealist philosophy developed by Andre Masson advocated. Dix wasn't afraid to walk through all the doors of the mind we usually lock up tight, and scrawl ominous latin warnings over the lintel in pig's blood.Beksinski was closest, aesthetically, to Fantastic Realists like Fuchs, Tubke and Giger. But he also shared the unedited working philosophy of Surrealism, Dali especially. His grim, thoroughly nihilistic visions put him close to Dix as well. His art defines the nightmares of the cold war, with deathscapes of a barren, irradiated world, populated by wraiths, monsters and corpses. He might've been the great visionary artist of the 20th century.This book, published by Morpheus, is just as ugly as every other monograph they release. It's not a bad volume -- it's about 10" wide x 12.25" tall, with well-reproduced plates that make good use of the page-space, and about 96 pages in length -- but it's not great. The Beksinski collections from Editions Treville and their Pan-Exotica line are brilliant; there is a 130 page hardcover collecting some of his most powerful paintings that I recommend very highly. But for anyone looking for a more comprehensive look at the artist will want the 3-volume catalogue raisonne, each book of which contains another aspect of his artistic output, including his drawings, sculpture and photographs. All four books are of the highest quality, and perfectly designed.In comparison, the Morpheus album looks like a self-published venture. The layout and fonts are pretty tasteless. Given the price it's selling for, find the Editions Treville single volume instead.

A frozen waterfall is seen many times in 'The Captive'; it is visible through the windows of a hotel room, where Cassandra's mother is working as a maid. Years after Cassandra was kidnapped, objects with very specific emotional links to the missing girl keep turning up in that room, and she's beginning to question her sanity. Director Atom Egoyan carefully keeps that wall of ice in frame throughout these scenes. It's a powerful image. For the parents of a missing child, it's like life freezes over, and time has stopped; all that water, all that pressure, just frozen in time and space, waiting for the thaw... in this case, as the years go on, it becomes less and less likely that 'the spring' -- the resolution, a break in the investigation -- will bring good news. But in order for the waters to flow and fall, there has to be an answer: a girl who is suddenly a teenager, or a collection of bones in a shallow grave. Until then, they live life on hold. frozen in place, all that weight crushing down without relent... Or something along those lines. Cassandra's father, Matthew --  Ryan Reynolds, in a moving performance -- is tortured by guilt, ashamed that when he went into a store to buy a pie, someone stole his daughter from the back seat of his truck. In the film's standout performance, Mireille Enos (from the TV series 'The Killing') portrays Tina, a mother whose pain is so acute it threatens to destroy her; she is unable and/or unwilling to help assuage her husband's suffering, and uses that moment Cas was taken as a weapon to hurt him further, as if the more pain she can inflict on him, the less she'll feel herself. Matthew bears his wife's bitterness, and the baseless accusations, much better than most people would, I think.Atom Egoyan's latest film returns to the same cold, starkly beautiful emotional and geographical terrain he examined in 'The Sweet Hereafter'. This film seems like a mix of the low-key art-film and a standard-issue police procedural, with odd narrative choices that leave the viewer confused. It leaves the grand tragedy of 'The Sweet Hereafter', its schoolbus full of children disappearing over an icy slope, for a more private, personal tragedy. The narrative jumps back and forth through the eight-year period of Cassandra's disappearance. In 2005, a detective named Jeffrey -- Scott Speedman -- joins an RCMP unit tracking missing children and crimes against children. His new commanding officer is Nicole -- Rosario Dawson -- whom he will later become romantically involved with. Cassandra, meanwhile, is very much alive. Having endured years of terrible abuse at the hands of her abductor, she is now old enough that he has lost interest in her sexually, thankfully. Mika is a monstrous anomaly, but incredibly, he belongs to a group of like-minded freaks in an online pedophilia ring. They have a bizarre fixation with the mundane stories of their victims, and Cassandra is kept alive to not just tell these stories to an audience of perverts, but to someday ensnare another young girl. Kevin Durand is excellent, as usual, interpreting yet another psychotic monster in an unusual way. He deserves credit for taking on such a thoroughly repugnant character in the first place. Mika is aided by a mysterious woman... the question hangs unanswered of whether or not she began as a victim herself, before turning into his accomplice. The pedophiles enjoy witnessing the agony of Cassandra's parents; Mika has installed camera's in the rooms where Tina works, and he begins leaving significant objects for her to find, and witness her pain and confusion. Matthew feels compelled to traverse the snow-covered highways, hoping for a miracle, that the next girl he sees hitch-hiking will be his daughter.The problem with 'The Captive' is that it involves too many characters and subplots... and leaves almost all of them unaddressed. It's not that the story is over-sized or convoluted; other films have juggled far larger casts and far more complicated stories with ease. But there were obviously scenes cut from the film, in an attempt to keep down the running-time. Whatever choices were made in the cutting room, they were issues that should have been addressed in the screenplay, because you can't solve every problem with editing. Jumping forward and back in time is a device that can be intriguing, dropping clues to quickly grab attention, i.e. the early scene in which Jeffrey is interrogating Mika's boss (Bruce Greenwood, portraying one of the several characters who serve no function whatsoever, except perhaps as red herrings in a previous draft that didn't give away the mystery immediately) and the audience learns that Nicole has gone missing in 2013... but since her character doesn't appear until afterward, it's easy to miss this detail, especially if you haven't been paying attention to the dates that pop up briefly every scene. When it does rewind to 2005, it doesn't help much to propel the plot. Nicole heads up the team of RCMP detectives working on cases involving children; Jeffrey is the hotshot with the 'excellent clearance rate' who has transferred from homicide for mysterious reasons; that doesn't stop her from 'testing' him with some awful piece of child porn, then acting smug when he expresses disgust and outrage, as if he didn't realize that this would be a part of his mandate in a squad investigating child abuse. Then both Jeffrey and the viewer meet the eclectic group of cops on the team, in the contrived manner of NCIS or CSI: Miami -- the tech guy, the science guy, the pattern recognition guy... wait, the what? So they dump out a large puzzle on the table in a jumbled mess, and he soon describes in detail the finished picture on the box. 'That's impressive', says the new guy. Sure is. Too bad this 'pattern recognition' character does absolutely nothing through the rest of the film. There are other examples that I won't get into, for spoilage reasons. Needless to say, I was surprised by the seriously flawed story-telling; the chronological confusion is exacerbated by the number of 'jumps' - 2005, 2006, 2011, 2012, 2013... it's an amateurish mistake. Maybe I expect too much from Atom Egoyan. Usually, I associate Egoyan with prestigious, artistic film-making, but I don't think that reputation exists south of the border. In Canada, he deserves as much credit as David Cronenberg and Denis Villeneuve for establishing a Canadian cinematic identity, for 'Exotica' and 'The Sweet Hereafter' alone. But that was a long time ago. If I didn't know that Egoyan directed this film, I probably wouldn't have been so patient with the disjointed, off-putting mess that is made of the story. There are inconsistencies in the tale that no brilliant performance, no poignant visual metaphors can balance out.Nevertheless, it's beautifully shot, it has deep emotional resonancy, and it's suspenseful, even if it's not prime Egoyan; if you're willing to be patient with an often frustrating narrative, it's worth watching.

[SPOILERS!]'Kill the Messenger' is the negative image of 'American Sniper', a counterpunch in some strange contest of propaganda cinema. Like 'American Sniper', it's also a very entertaining film; it isn't groundbreaking, as it follows a deep narrative track carved out by movies like 'All the Presidents Men' and 'JFK'. There's an inevitability to the plot that doesn't trace back to the title, or even the viewer's familiarity with the book or the original articles; it feels inevitable because it's predictable, and it's predictable because its been done. The only reason a legit true story has for fitting itself to the well-worn grooves and cogs of Hollywood formula is because it's targeting a wider audience. But as was the case in 'American Sniper', smoothing those rough edges for the sake of mass appeal makes it harder to hang on to, less memorable and less true. The compromises that converted these true-life biopics into Hollywood product are also the variables that kept them from greatness.The 'Sniper/Messenger' parallel is purely conjectural, but the similarities aren't hard to spot. Both films are based on best-selling books about public figures who did something remarkable, but were also heavily criticised for their accomplishments. Chris Kyle was a Navy SEAL who killed over 150 people as a sniper in the occupation of Iraq, more than any other sniper in US military history. Gary Webb was a San Jose Mercury News Reporter who exposed the link between the CIA's funding of Nicaraguan rebels and the widespread trafficking of crack cocaine in cities across the US. Both men become symbols for a political POV, and both men died by gunshot wounds to the head -- Kyle by another veteran allegedly suffering from PTSD, while Webb's death was ruled a suicide. Conspiracy theories accusing the government for responsibility in both deaths are fairly popular; Webb suffered two fatal gunshot wounds to the head, which always raises red flags in a death that was ruled as a suicide.Although Webb was initially celebrated in the journalistic community, organizations like the LA Times and Washington Post criticized his series of articles -- 'Dark Alliance' -- as ethically reckless, and discredited both Webb and his work. He was never able to support himself as a journalist after his editor backed away from the stories.
