Claims that Webb was the victim of a smear campaign form the basic premise of 'Kill the Messenger'.Even though I was well aware of Webb's articles -- which were later vindicated to a large extent by a CIA document admitting to their involvement with known drug traffickers -- it was still fascinating to watch as Webb began pulling at the threads of the mask, the cover-up, which were hanging there for anyone to pull, but no one did. It was a sloppy operation, which kind of makes sense when you realize that the CIA are better at acting like spies than being spies. Like any huge, government bureaucracy, there were too many people to keep the secret forever. But they're well aware that forever isn't necessary. They just have to keep it long enough to protect the company men and important assets who were directly involved. So the truth always comes out, twenty or thirty years later, and its all new faces by then, who insist that the CIA is done with drugs and president killing. Or maybe not.Jeremy Renner is a great actor, and he does an excellent job as Webb. If it's a warrior to warrior battle between Jeremy Renner and 'The Hurt Locker' versus Bradley Cooper and 'American Sniper', there's no question -- 'The Hurt Locker' is a masterpiece, and Renner killed it; 'American Sniper' is a good movie, but not on that same level of greatness. 'Kill the Messenger' isn't on that level either... it's enjoyable, and powerful at times, but it's also clear that Webb's tale -- like Kyle's -- has been repackaged and adjusted to make it more palatable for the American public, which compromises the original story, in my opinion. Hollywood doesn't need more propaganda. And since I have my own problems with the 'War on Drugs' in the first place, a prohibition that oversteps governmental authority, I think that 'Kill the Messenger' ends up losing its grasp on the sheer hypocrisy behind the audacity; I think Gary Webb broke an important story, but the film might end up replacing the facts.Still, it's a film worth watching. When you set the political context aside, it moves very well, with some standout supporting roles by a lot of respected actors. Oliver Platt and Mary Elizabeth Winstead are great as Webb's worried, then supportive, then actively unhelpful editors. The ending bogs down, as the story becomes progressively darker, and concludes on the aforementioned inevitable and depressing note. While it's not intended to be a feel-good film, the speech Webb delivers to a now hostile room full of reporters is excruciating to watch.

This is basically an oversized special-issue of Blade Magazine... which is what I was looking for. It has some interesting articles, including a fine piece by Michael Janich about his personal history with 'tactical folders'; if it were anyone else, that might seem lame, but fortunately, Janich played an integral role in the modern history of tactical knives, so his perspective is pretty damn interesting. Much of the page-space is devoted to blade porn, of course. You get hundreds of pages of beautifully photographed custom knives, most of them by American Bladesmith Society members. This means lots of traditional Bowies and Fighters, lots of Mammoth-tusk and brass bolsters and mosaic Damascus. The majority are knives too pretty for using, really, but there's also a selection of more 'cutting edge' designs, i.e. tactical flippers dressed up in Mokume and Moku-ti, 'Timascus', 'lightning strike' carbon fiber, 'Super-Collider' and 'Super-Conductor' and Zirconium... which are also too pretty and pricey for using. There's also a huge reference section, essentially a phonebook for the knife community, which takes up more space than it should, given the book's cover price. This is information you can easily find online. Needless to say, it's a book for hardcore knife-aficionados only.

These are beautifully-produced, high-quality playing cards. I'm not trying to be David Blaine, and I'm not trying to win the World Series of Poker. I was attracted to this deck as an art object, and as deadly weapons, and they're very impressive in both respects. It would have been interesting to see artist Tom Lane's style applied to a visionary redesign of the 'face' cards, but the classic Bicycle Kings and Queens work too.As far as the construction, these are a very thick, sturdy stock, with a slick, plasticized surface for quick shuffling and dealing; but they also have a finely-grained texture that prevents them from being too slippery. And most importantly, if it becomes necessary to employ the 'Archangels' as deadly weapons, you can unleash divine wrath and retribution without worrying about blood stains.The price was pretty reasonable, and the variety of aesthetically pleasing card decks available makes this the kind of collectible you can get into without going broke. Also, I can use my Bicycle deck to master the martial arts of 'card-jitsu' and 'deck fu', throwing them with enough force to slice up fruit. I know, kitchen knives and blenders work better for food processing, or so the Nazi-Zionist-Scientologist-Anarcho-Buddhist media would have you believe. But if I can accomplish all my fruit-slicing needs with a 3$ deck of playing cards, I can use the savings to retire early in the proverbial lap of luxury... AND be feared by all.

"'I killed Richie Wheeler...' 'Sure you did.' BLAM."Brace yourself for this shocking revelation: the acting in this tightly coiled, ingeniously crafted crime drama, starring Tom Hardy, James Gandolfini, and Noomi Rapace, is quite good. It made me believe they were people with completely different names and everything. Yes, that sentence is so stupid, you'd probably be disappointed with your cat for saying it. There is, however, a 5-carat 100-Rockwell diamond of hard, shiny truth in it, since I'm sick of watching actors who can't even be convincing when they're essentially playing themselves.Tom Hardy is the best actor of his generation -- as much as I like Jake Gyllenhaal, Ed Norton and Joaquin Phoenix, Hardy is better. I have a tendency to step outside the narrative, vivisecting films as they play, examining the story, the editing, the direction -- the guts of the work. Nothing triggers this more frequently than an apparent 'flaw', and flawed acting is the most common variety. The better a film is -- usually -- the less often this happens. I don't remember anything pulling me from the story in 'The Drop'. Tom Hardy is as impressive here as he was in 'Locke'. That's a big, important statement that I don't take lightly, believe me. And while it was sad to watch James Gandolfini's final role, this is the final performance and the final film that every actor prays for. Hardy and Gandolfini are absolutely incredible, and Noomi Rapace is game for the challenge of matching them, never flagging, never faltering.Novelist Dennis Lehane and director Michael R. Roskam deserve much of the credit, obviously. I've been keeping up with Lehane's novels for over a decade, and as one of the crime writers David Simon and Ed Burns hand-picked for 'The Wire' -- one of the 3 best TV series of all time -- his name is cast in platinum, as far as I'm concerned. He's also had his novels adapted into consistently brilliant films: 'Mystic River', directed by Clint Eastwood; 'Shutter Island', directed by Martin Scorcese; and 'Gone Baby Gone', directed by Ben Affleck. Considering the filmography that the first two directors have behind them, it seems crazy that the best of these three excellent films was Ben Affleck's directorial debut, but it's true.Mastering yet another tiny regional accent (the region is tiny, not the accent), Hardy plays Bob Sagowski in 'The Drop'. He's a simple, earnest bartender in Brooklyn, albeit one with a criminal history, and a loose connection to Chechnyan mobsters. The bar was once owned by 'Cousin Marv', portrayed by Gandolfini, whose aspirations as a neighborhood bookie and gangster were crushed when Chechnya invaded his particular corner of Brooklyn. Still managing and tending the bar with Bob, Marv's bitterness leads him down a dangerous road. The illicit cash proceeds of various criminal endeavors throughout the Borough are collected in a floating 'drop': one of the many bars under the mobster's aegis, decided on with very little notice. So Marv is waiting for the word, and making very bad plans.Bob is slow, good-natured, and unambitious. His career as a gangster ended the same day Cousin Marv's did, and now he's just another American errand boy for the new mobster management. But what Lehane is getting at with Bob's habit of attending mass without taking communion, what the director hints at, and Hardy himself communicates with the subtlest changes of expression, is eventually made very clear: don't f*** with Bob. He's not just the sweet, dumb guy he seems to be, he's dangerous; and he might even have a couple skeletons in his closet (or basement, or wherever the proper place for skeletons might be... I'm not an HGTV fan). When he finds an abused and abandoned pitbull puppy in a garbage can, he meets Nadia -- Noomi Rapace. She's got a dark past herself of course, involving a psychopath who made his reputation by allegedly killing a local who vanished years earlier. As Bob and Nadia build a relationship around the foundling puppy, a small-time robbery puts Bob and Marv squarely responsible for the lost money, and raises the suspicion of both the mob and the cops. Tension mounts when Bob is confronted by the thug who left his pup in Nadia's garbage can -- her ex-boyfriend. When he threatens to take his dog back, s*** gets real.Unless you're one of those super-religious types who get all twitchy when people use words like s*** and f***, you need to go watch 'The Drop' (a.k.a. 'Leave the Puppy Alone, Part 1') right now. Forget about volunteer work, prayer, or bathing your smelly cat, and watch this movie. It will make you a better person. It will make you cool. It will regenerate that missing kidney you've been whining about. Do it now (or whenever you've got the time, its not important).P.S.: *Leave the Puppy Alone, Part 1: The Drop, is far better than its less realistic sequel -- Leave the Puppy Alone, Part 2: John Wick. In fact, it almost seems like a completely unrelated story. If it weren't for the puppy, and the title -- which, admittedly, I made up -- you wouldn't guess there was any connection at all.

Pitch Black was premium-grade science-fiction/horror. It gathered up all the creative detritus left behind by the Twilight Zone, The Outer Limits, Star Trek, and E.C. Comics like Weird Science, retro-fitted them for use in a CGI-equipped modern-day monster movie, and hit the ignition. It didn't explode. Or it did, but in a good way.A space-ship full of cosmic pilgrims crash-lands on a thoroughly alien world. They find themselves in a scorched wasteland, a desert graveyard holding the bones of hill-sized behemoths. It seems bad, and the presence of a convict named Riddick makes things seem even worse. When they learn that subterranean tunnels house myriads upon myriads of nocturnal exo-monstrosities, like terrifying hybrids of the Hammerhead shark, Komodo dragon, Bengal tiger, and the alien from `Alien', they're relieved that these terrifying things can't handle sunlight... starlight... whatever. When they learn that the hourglass is about to be flipped, and the planet's eccentric orbit and axial rotation will result in something too `lastingly dark' to call `night', well... it's a bit scary. Riddick ends up being the pitch-black anti-hero his badge-wearing escort isn't, and Radha Mitchell finds classic 1961-style redemption for her selfish past.Director David Twohy earned his stellar reputation among SF and horror fans with `Pitch Black', and deservedly so. Then he destroyed his stellar reputation among SF and horror fans with `Chronicles of Riddick', and deservedly so.

[Some Spoilers]This kind of film should probably be on the endangered species list. The 'Multiversal Dinner Party' sub-genre isn't going to be trading punches with Captain America at the box office, but that's alright. If the creators of this crafty little pic had trans-festival ticket-sale aspirations, they're living in a fantasy world where money doesn't matter and philosophers are sex symbols.'Coherence' gets a bit incoherent at times -- one would assume by design -- using a cinema verite approach with semi-improvised dialogue, conversations melding into white noise as the actors talk over each other, sentences dropping off mid-way through, or drifting into... But this naturalism makes the strangeness to come all the more convincing.This could have easily been an off-Broadway play. It has no CGI or FX make-up, and takes place almost entirely in the dining-room of a suburban L.A. bungalow. It begins with a small dinner-party attended by several affluent 30 and 40-somethings. The viewer learns that a comet is in the solar neighborhood, and when cell-phone touch-screens spontaneously shatter, it is assumed to be somehow responsible. They move on to other topics, however, introducing a 'Birdman'-like parallel when Mike mentions being a long-time regular on the TV-series 'Roswell'; another guest claims to be a fan of the series, but doesn't remember him. The actor who portrays Mike, Nicholas Brendon, played 'Xander' on 'Buffy the Vampire Slayer', which was on the same network as 'Roswell', at roughly the same time; they also shared a large and devoted fan-base, appealing to identical demographics. This comical exchange has a slight factual dissonance -- or a symmetrical confusion -- that might be explained by unknowingly stepping through a doorway, inexplicably opened in the wake of the comet, that leads into the next universe over... like a needle skipping onto the closest of a seemingly infinite number of alternate narrative tracks*; it serves as foreshadowing for events to come.When the lights go out, it triggers a kind of instinctive Cro-Magnon panic, especially since they fear it might also relate to the comet. The candles come out, and high anxiety settles into a slightly paranoid disquiet. When they notice a house nearby with lights on, two of the men venture out to see if they know more. That's when things get weird. They return looking shaken, if not terrified, to report that when they looked through the window of the other house... they saw themselves. The entire group. Sitting around the table. This baffling tale is followed by a knock and a mysterious note on the door.Doppelgangers, glow-sticks, code words, and games with photos and numbers; as the group overthinks, then underthinks, always over-reacting, they only succeed in generally freaking one another out. By the end, the story really is incoherent. But it never made much sense in the first place; the strength of the film is the actors, and the characters, and watching thousands of years of intellectual and social progression completely unravel.Highly recommended.P.S.: FOOTNOTE *(Each universe might differ by as little as the super-positional possibilities of a subatomic particle -- defined by the probability wave function that famously collapses when someone gets curious enough to crack the lid and check up on the cat... who was alive AND dead, thanks to the poison gas triggered/not-triggered by the decay of a cesium isotope. 'As above, so below' -- in this case, a thought experiment by Erwin Schrodinger, the cat is either alive or dead; but it elucidated the alchemical maxim by demonstrating how the counter-intuitive weirdness of quantum mechanics and the subatomic level in general, can also affect the world at the macro-level. Calculating all the possible positions of every particle, for every nano-second in the last 13 billion years, multiplied exponentially by the super-positional nano-seconds of every other particle in the universe, produces a number of theoretical multiversal variations so vast it approaches the infinite. One could step through the next trillion universes without seeing any discernable changes.)

[Spoiler-Free and long, with a rambling intro; skip down to the paragraph preceded by two stars (**) if you’re only interested in ‘Gone Girl’.]David Fincher has built a body of work that is stylistically distinctive, increasingly complex, and thoroughly engaging. Movies like ‘Alien3’, ‘Panic Room’, and ‘The Game’ all had moments of brilliance and visual power reminiscent of Ridley Scott. ‘Se7en’ was his first real success, a slick, stylish thriller that was the most horrifying serial killer film of the nineties, with the exception of ‘Silence of the Lambs’. But criticism that Fincher was approaching movie-making with the techniques and aesthetics that made him famous as a director of music videos -- flashy and exciting, but essentially hollow -- certainly had some merit. ‘Fight Club’, however, Fincher's cult hit based on Chuck Palahniuk's novel, was a flawed masterpiece of undeniable originality, power, and messy, sticky substance.‘Zodiac’ was a far more mature take on serial killers. A brilliant adaptation of a difficult true-crime memoir, it is one of the best films of the millennium. It was the product of an incredibly talented and confident film-maker who had harnessed a high-voltage vision and propulsive narrative style. It’s hard to imagine ‘Zodiac’ in another director’s hands; the story is incredibly complicated, relying on minute details and cryptic clues, with multiple suspects, and a frustrating variety of red herrings and dead-ends. Fincher juggles what could have been a tedious and confusing tale with utter genius.Even movies I had no interest in before learning that he directed them – ‘The Social Network’ and ‘The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo’ – ended up blowing me away. The latter, based on the first book of the best-selling Liz Salander trilogy, is probably what led to Fincher’s latest project, another adaptation of a mega-selling novel.**‘Gone Girl’ deserves all the superlatives and hyperbole being flung at it. I was thoroughly uninterested in (unaware of?) the novel; but the intentional correlations to the Scott and Lacie Peterson murder case sparked my curiosity, as did interesting twists such as the title character’s role in a series of Nancy Drew-type children’s books – created by her parents -- called ‘Amazing Amy’. Once again, in another director’s hands, this could have been a mediocre, made-for-TV mystery. To be fair, the writer deserves credit; this is a clever subversion of viewer expectations, which in turn becomes a sly commentary on media manipulation.Ben Affleck is the perfect choice for the lead as Nick Dunne, and his physical resemblance to Scott Peterson deepens the meta-contextual associations (I never thought I’d utter those words, and yet Birdman and Gone Girl both rely on specific but never specified mass-cultural awareness), and viewer assumptions about his character – even though the intentional similarities to the case soon diverge from reality. His portrayal of Nick Dunne -- a charming and selfish ‘alpha male’ who’s used to getting his way – isn’t too much of a stretch. The way in which he walks the line of viewer judgement and perception, moving from one side of the margin to the other, from concerned husband, to unfairly accused victim, to probable killer and terrible person, et cetera… is impressive.Not as impressive as Rosamund Pike, however. She’s one of those rare-beautiful actresses whose appearance stands out, as opposed to the eternal queue of bakery-fresh generic beauties lined up at the gates of celluloid stardom. As viewers and police alike struggle to uncover the truth behind the disappearance of ‘Amazing Amy’, Pike creates an utterly fascinating mystery in the character of Amy Dunne herself.Fincher takes us through the pages of ‘Amazing Amy’s Diary’, beginning with a storybook romance, but a venomous serpent is sleeping, nestled in one of these lover’s hearts. The ‘diary flashbacks’ soon begin to diverge from the ‘reality’ that Nick Dunne is giving police. As the investigation of Amy’s disappearance begins to look harder into the husband’s story, the evidence seeks him out like a lodestone.As thoroughly engaging as ‘Gone Girl’ is as a mystery and a thriller, it is just as noteworthy for its satirical critique of ‘news entertainment’, and the savage manner that the media tears people apart over a smile at the wrong moment, and uses the tragedy of others as obscene amusement. At the risk of sounding like a smug, self-righteous jerk, I’ve always tried to question the assertions force-fed to us by the media; but I’m well aware that I often fail in that regard. Humans are programmed to make assumptions; to gather information from a trusted source and accept it as truth. Questioning the information we’ve already accepted as ‘fact’ is not natural, and in most cases, without real reward or advantage. ‘Gone Girl’ -- like Dan Gilroy’s ‘Nightcrawler’ -- is a brilliant thriller, but it also happens to be a clever satirical examination of truth, justice, and the media. Wow. That sounded excessively heavy and dry. Suffice it to say that David Fincher has created another 5-star film, one that is beautifully shot, cut, and performed. It’s gripping and very, very surprising. [91/100][ I went into ‘Gone Girl’ without the spoilers, so I’m refraining from spoilers in this review. I suggest anyone who hasn’t read the book, or seen the film, cautiously avoid spoilers before hitting play. There’s not that many films for which I feel such warnings are necessary, but this is one.]

Cormac McCarthy, James Carlos Blake, Ron Hansen, Larry McMurtry, and Charles Frazier are the reigning lords of the hard-eyed American historical novel. 'Blood Meridian' can't be called a 'western', any more than 'Wildwood Boys' or 'Desperadoes'. Larry McMurtry comes closest to embracing the tropes of the 'western' genre, but subverts reader expectations at every turn. The frontier was not settled by singing cowboys. Native Americans weren't simple savages, but they weren't the noble nature-loving quasi-Buddhists that became the Hollywood cliché in the late-sixties and seventies. The 'New World' was a brutal, vicious battleground, where every random encounter between strangers would very likely end violently.Patrick DeWitt has joined this august company with `The Sisters Brothers', a novel that combines the flawlessly crafted prose of Charles Frazier or fellow Canadian Michael Ondaatje, with a darkly comical tale that suggests Charles Portis -- 'True Grit' as realized by the Coen Brothers - and James Carlos Blake - particularly his brutal masterpiece `In the Rogue Blood'. Like the latter, DeWitt's book is a story about brothers who are born killers made for a bloody world; like the former, it has a darkly comedic intelligence. As a Canadian myself, I felt bad about NOT feeling bad about the lack of native literary fiber in my pulp-heavy diet. Ondaatje, yes. Atwood, sure. But beyond `Oryx and Crake', I can't remember the last time I read another Canadian novel. Tony Burgess and `Pontypool Changes Everything', I guess, preceded by the loosely connected stories in `The Hellmouths of Bewdley'... 10, 15 years ago. Which means that I'm confessing to being a bad Canadian. Even before Jian Gomeshi was unmasked as Jack the Ripper, I still fled in terror when `Canada Reads' infected the CBC airwaves, with a suitably terrifying frontman. I knew that anyone who could create music as undeniably evil as the sonic terrorism of Moxy Fruvous had to house rows of retractable shark teeth behind that smile...I feel like Dewitt has finally crafted Canlit that doesn't feel like a homework assignment. `The Sisters Brothers' is a cocaine counterpoint to the literary laxatives of `Two Solitudes' and `The Stone Angel'. If the point of using Hugh f*****g McLennan and Margaret f*****g Lawrence was to scare kids away from Canlit forever - brilliant. They could also have value as practical demonstrations of Relativity: narrative black holes clearly distorting space-time, each paragraph requires a dogged determination; when you manage to break free of it's oppressive gravitational pull, hours have passed... and you're still on the same page.It's probably true that those wacky kids would hate any book they're forced to read. But the chances of creating an entire generation of anti-Canlit jihadists will be significantly reduced if we take a sledge-hammer to `The Stone Angel' and go with `The Sisters Brothers' instead. Unless teenagers completely suck. I'm willing to consider that possibility.What's it about, you ask? Due to my severe case of CBPTSD (Canlit-based Post Traumatic Stress Dissorder), any attempts at literary synopsis or criticism may result in projectile vomit, pointy eyeballs, and an elegant, convulsive style of dance that is like an unholy union of Krumpin', Riverdance, and the Macarena... but it's actually a Grand Mal seizure. Still, I'm doing this for my country, dammit!Eli and Charlie Sisters are cold-blooded killers employed by a man known as `The Commodore'. Eli is the narrator of the tale, and he often defers to his brother. Eli has a soft streak that Charlie doesn't seem to possess, showing a sympathy and occasional empathy that is totally inappropriate for a hired gun. Charlie is very different person - lean and quick and calculating, with a violent temper that often affects his trigger finger... his primary source of income.The story opens in Oregon City, as the Sisters brothers set out on orders to murder a prospector named Hermann Kermit Warm, whom the Commodore has denounced simply as a thief. Their journey to San Francisco is an eventful one, and Charlie begins to express anger with The Commodore, and dissatisfaction with their arrangement. Upon arriving in the city, they track down a friend of Warm's, who reveals some very interesting details concerning the German prospector's partnership and subsequent falling-out with The Commodore. It involves a method of finding and extracting gold from riverbeds, based on a chemical of Warm's devising. He absconded with his work and secrets when he realized that his partner would certainly kill him once the formula was done. Eli and Charlie now must decide between loyalty to their employer, and a chance to get rich by betraying him.In between, `The Sisters Brothers' is rich to overflowing with fascinating characters and stories. The dynamic between Eli and Charlie provides the most memorable relationships and characters I've come across in ages. This is one of my new favorites, and it feels super patriotic to say that Patrick DeWitt is one of my favorite authors. He's saved fiction in Canada. If someone says that Canadian Literature doesn't need saving - smite them with a righteous vengeance!... Or start a conversation. Either way is good. But READ this book... Do it for Canada (Or if you're American, read it because it f*****g rocks).

I liked the idea of the series, and I thought I liked the laid-back manner the producers used, so the artist could explain their process, inspirations, personal history, and so on. I thought that was what I wanted. But after watching the entire 6 season run, I found two memorable segments on artists who were personal favorites -- particularly Walton Ford -- and one memorable segment on an artist I was unfamiliar with, and who has since become a new favorite, Shahzia Sikander.It didn't take long to remember why I usually avoid reading interviews with my favorite artists. It's f***ing torture. Sometimes, it's the fault of the interviewer, but it's never enlightening (I'll amend that to 'rarely'; I have read interesting artist comments, but it's 1 time in 20. Critics always do a better job than the artist. Call it the "Yeah, Ditto" phenomenon). Even Gerhard Richter, one of the artists I respect more than any other, isn't able to say anything meaningful about his massive catalogue raisonne. They're not writers. And the 'good talker/bad artist's who end up famous are usually con-men (con-people?); they're an insult to the real artists killing themselves with Cheetos at the moment, because they haven't learned schmoozing and the jargon-laden language of bulls*** common to crappy artists, tech salesmen and politicians. 'How to Say Nothing in Eighty Words or Higher'... until people assume the fault lies with them, and drift away with a glazed look in their eye... Hint: if the listener doesn't understand what the speaker is saying, the fault probably lies with the speaker, not the listener -- art is not quantum mechanics. Art is another form of communication. If an artist has failed to communicate their meaning to an audience, the fault probably lies with the artist.Too many of the artists featured had achieved success through trendy whims that breeze through the galleries of New York and Paris, making ugly, meaningless works that spark no feelings and no intellectual curiosity, sold by agents and gallery owners who market personalities, regardless of their talent or utter lack thereof. The goal is to convince people that the artist and their acolytes understand something, see something that others do not, even though this failure to effectively communicate means an artist has failed. But rich Americans believe in the 'fake it til you make it' principle, and will buy any moronic piece of crap that the 'in crowd' believe to be cutting edge brilliance.After listening to dozens of famous pretend artists stumble through their used car salesman routine for the three hundredth time, obviously possessing no talent and no way of articulating a clever explanation for superficial trash, it gets really dull. A bit of variety would have been nice; more artists with craft and skill -- it's okay to be talented again... you don't have to deliberately make crap that looks like it was slapped together by a retarded kid (sorry, that's unfair to mentally handicapped kids).This would make a great sleep aid. I'm getting drowsy just thinking about it... and I LOVE art.P.S.: Reading this again, it sounds pretty hostile. Wow. I must have been in a bad mood. Check the PBS website for a list of the artists involved, if you like even a quarter of the people featured, you'll likely get way more out of this than I did. If you're into some of the styles that the show-runners favor, that's all that matters anyway. And the price was really reasonable for the amount of material collected. If you don't recognize any names... you should probably skip it and check out some info first.

This stunning book, published by Somogy, was released to coincide with the accompanying exhibition in 2001. Arnold Bocklin, one of the most brilliant and still under-rated artists of the 19th Century, produced a work that has deeply affected generations of admirers, 'The Isle of the Dead'. This French-language monograph includes dozens of works by a diverse array of talents, all created for the exhibition and inspired by Bocklin's most famous piece. It also includes scholarly articles on the paintings' unique and lasting appeal, inspiring some of the 20th Century's greatest artists. Ernst Fuchs, H.R. Giger and Fabrizio Clerici are just three of the contributors that make this book as fascinating as it is. It has also been selling for ridiculous prices, unfortunately, owing to the quality of the work and the resurgent interest in Arnold Bocklin. Every now and then a more reasonably priced copy pops up; if it does, this is one you'll want to grab up fast.

This is an absolutely beautiful book. Schwabe was a Swiss Symbolist who was not as well known as most of his contemporaries, but who produced a remarkable body of work as both a painter and illustrator. The only artist I can really compare him with is Max Klinger, in terms of 2-D subject matter and media. But Klinger is best known as an Art Nouveau sculptor, something for which Scwabe never made his name known.The reproductions in this volume are excellent, especially given the book's age -- it was published in the mid-nineties. It contains his most famous and important paintings, as well as lesser-known works and preliminary studies. His illustrations are just as fascinating, providing work for Baudelaire and some of the other most notorious writers of the time. His drawings are not as explicitly sexual or satanic as the oeuvre of Felicien Rops, and he wasn't the proto-surrealist visionary that Klinger was, but his pictures are still far ahead of their time, and brilliantly executed. The downside -- the text is in French. If you can't read French, here's a great book to learn with. Or screw it... Jus' lookit the pichers...

Whenever a monograph is released in conjunction with a gallery or museum exhibition, it usually shares the faults and successes of the show that inspired it. The biggest problem here is that it has a very limited selection of Hunt's paintings, reflecting the real-world logistical difficulties of convincing private owners and public galleries to part with such rare, expensive and delicate treasures. The reproductions in the book are limited, therefore, and on more than one occasion include slightly different variations of the same painting, as well as thoroughly irrelevant photographs of Hunt's homemade shirts and skirts and whatnot. As a consumer, I would appreciate a selection of the works they couldn't acquire for the exhibition; there is no reason for not including them, and it would improve the anemic limitations of the catalogue. One more gripe: many of the reproductions are of a poor quality, which there is no excuse for. Hunt enthusiasts should wait for a Phaidon monograph, a publisher who has done brilliant work with Millais, Waterhouse, and Alma-Tadema.

The third and final volume of Charles Burns' latest sequential art masterpiece is here. This is not his magnum opus. That honor goes to 'Black Hole' (which, on an unrelated note, featured prominently in 'Dawn of the Planet of the Apes', as the graphic novel that a human character offers to the wise, semi-literate Orangutan; later, he reads from it to his new friend, before things go wrong at the hydro dam). This trilogy -- which is made up of X'ed Out (Bk.1), The Hive (Bk.2), and Sugar Skull (Bk.3) -- is something exciting for a long time Burns fan like myself.The color art allows the strong European influences to show, and the 'ligne claire' technique he employs for the deepest dream levels of the story tie in to the narrative as well. Doug, the protagonist, is a performance artist and poet who goes by the stage-name 'Nitnit' -- 'Tintin' in reverse. His 'act' is an unfortunate variation of the Burroughs/Gysin 'cut-up' method -- imagine collage poetry and automatic writing puking on one another. The Moroccan motifs of the 'Interzone' world with its Mugwumps and lizard-men, are executed in the style of Herge and Jacobs, as are the endpapers and the design of the albums themselves -- all based on the adventures of a globe-trotting (and moon-hopping) teenage journalist from Belgium. Even Doug's silent Virgil, a dead black cat named 'Inky', is a direct contrast to Tintin's little white dog, 'Snowy'... who could speak (though I don't think anyone understood him).The Burroughs influence is just as strong -- the Moroccan Interzone-world where Doug has layered his memories in 'Naked Lunch'-nightmares -- and it signals Doug's state of mind as a morphine addict, as well as the horrors of withdrawal. We also learn that there is nothing in Doug's life so horrible that it justifies his fear. He's a coward, which is no doubt a terrifying revelation itself. He really is Nitnit, the reverse of Tintin. If Tintin represents bravery, curiosity, and a love of life, Doug has become the anti-Tintin.As to the specifics of the story, I'll keep this spoiler-free. This is essentially a dark psychological drama, with a very sad outcome. But this trilogy is one of the most beautifully executed examples of comic art ever. Period. I can't say that it's better, artistically, than the infinite pools of Feldstein spot-blacks that make up the 360-pages of Black Hole, but it's close.

[No, I'm not serious. But the violence is far more realistic than the last anime incarnation of 'Berserk'.]If you've ever wanted to see a realistic film depiction of Medieval siege-warfare, well... go elsewhere. `Berserk' is a strange, hyper-violent vision of European sword and sorcery, from a Japanese POV. It looks like the dark ages, but there's no historical connection whatsoever; instead, it serves as a brutal playground for Kentaro Miura's twisted imagination.This film trilogy is actually a reboot; it takes the viewer back to the first meeting of Guts the Black Swordsman and The Band of the Hawk, rather than acting as a sequel to the first series. It's different from the manga as well, but retains the essence of the tale.While I liked the original anime, I wasn't terribly impressed with the animation. This film, as well as the two that follow, are spectacular in comparison. The blend of animation and CGI isn't flawless, but it's pretty damn good, providing much more detailed art and realistic movements. The battle scenes, in particular, are very dynamic, giving the violence the kind of impact it needs.

If you're a Walking Dead viewer wondering if the comic is as good as the series -- the short answer is yes. In some ways, the show has transcended the source material, and as someone who followed the comics before the series, I don't say that lightly. But in other ways, the comic is incredibly powerful, and remains the soul and center. One thing Kirkman, Adlard, and the writers of the show deserve praise for is the way both storylines have diverged. 'The Walking Dead' is essentially two parallel worlds, and both have really bad luck. If you know the comic, you will still have no idea what's going to happen in the show, and vice versa. There are moments where both stories seem to coalesce, but then break apart to follow separate roads once again.This is the format to buy, without question. The deluxe hardcover is larger, the 8" x 11" oversized edition instead of the standard 7" x 10". Each hardcover book contains two of the softcover volumes; so Book 1 collects Volumes 1 and 2. Every storyline is about the same length -- 6 comicbook issues. So the Volumes are around 150 pages, and the Books are a bit longer, 320 or so pages; they come with extras -- like the original single-issue covers, and miscellaneous artwork from Charlie Adlard and Tony Moore -- that the softcover Volumes do not. While Adlard has been the series artist for a very long time, and does a brilliant, remarkably quick, and consistent job, Tony Moore's art in Book 1 played a big part in the success of 'The Walking Dead'. He's one of the many artists I consider a 'favorite', but he couldn't keep up with the unforgiving monthly pace. Pricewise, each oversized, extra-long hardcover Book is about the same price as the two softcover volumes it collects. Highly recommended.P.S.: The Compendiums are the most affordable way to pick up the comic -- collecting 48 single issues/8 Volumes/4 Books/2 Omnibus(es) (Omnibae?). They're a bit awkward though. The Omnibus is the super-deluxe format, similar to the Absolute Editions from DC. Image does as excellent job producing each.

`He just viciously murdered like... eighty people!?'`Yeah. It was a really cute dog.'`He seemed angrier about the car.'`It was a nice car.''John Wick' is another rousing entry in the ever-expanding action sub-genre known as `Now... you know you done ****** up, now, don't ya?'** To get more specific, there's actually a few basic templates; there's the `Taken' scenario, where the protagonist is a former special ops bad*ss turned bodyguard to the stars, and someone kidnaps his daughter, or kills his girl. Then there's the `Red' variation, where the hero is a former secret agent badass, who has been living quietly in retirement, until someone in the agency learns of his existence, labels him an unacceptable liability who knows way too much, and gives the order to terminate with mild prejudice. The scenario that `John Wick' shares with quite a few films, including `The Professional', by Luc Besson, and David Cronenberg's `A History of Violence', is a classic. It always involves a notoriously gifted hitman who has retired, gone into hiding, or been betrayed by his employer. He might be an emotionally stunted killer who finally makes a human connection - as in `The Professional' - or a one-time gangster who disappeared and made a new life for himself, forced to return to his violent ways to protect his family - as in `A History of Violence'.In `John Wick', Keanu Reeves plays a killer of prodigious ability who retired when he met the love of his life. When she succumbs to a sudden illness, Wick is grief-stricken. After the funeral, a posthumous delivery from his wife arrives. It's an adorable beagle puppy, and the accompanying card from the woman he just buried says she doesn't want him to forget how to love. Sniff. A ridiculously unfortunate gas-station encounter -- with the son of the Russian gangster he used to work for -- leads to a home invasion. Neither party recognizes the other, they just want his 1970 Mustang. None of this makes any sense. As the viewer later learns, his father is very rich. And yet, they orchestrate a violent armed robbery to steal a car. They take Wick for a `nobody', who would certainly report the crime, so they'll have to sell the car, which they try to do. They wear Bellaclavas to hide their faces, but the mobster's son lifts his mask to reveal himself. Then... the stupid ****s kill his love-puppy.That sad detail is not graphic, thankfully. It probably says something terrible that I've never enjoyed watching dozens of well-dressed thugs get super-slaughtered more than I did in `John Wick'. I don't know if there's any cosmic system of weights and measures that could balance the life of one sweet little beagle with a hundred dead a*******. And I'm quite sure no judicial system would accept a dead dog and a stolen car for a triple-digit massacre. But in Hollywood, you never, EVER, mess with another man's family, his car, OR his puppy.Keanu is back in Matrix mode, staying away from the things he does poorly - emoting, for one - and playing the kind of character he does well - blank-faced, mostly silent killing machines with an enigmatic charm that can almost be confused for intelligence. Reeves isn't smart. I've seen enough footage of him screwing up references to everything from Greek Myth to physics, with hilarious results, to accept him as a genius. He has matured, though, and he can become an inscrutable-but-likable killer as convincingly as anyone... except Ryan Gosling, in `Drive', and Terence Stamp, in `The Limey', and Mel Gibson in `Payback', and Chow Yun Fat in `The Killer', and Denzel Washington in `Man on Fire', and Clint Eastwood in `Unforgiven' (my personal favorite) AND `Gran Torino' (another example of how stealing the wrong man's car can be hazardous to your health) AND... well, Eastwood is undeniably the master when it comes to inscrutable killers out for vengeance.`John Wick' isn't doing anything that hasn't been done countless times before, but it does it well; it gets the hook set early, and it never lets the line go slack. And of course, the `Gun Fu' choreography is fast and slick, without glossing over the violent impact of bullets striking bone. If anyone in Hollywood qualifies as a 'Gun Fu' black belt, it's Keanu Reeves; regardless what your opinion of 'The Matrix' is, few films have revolutionized the mechanics of the action genre so profoundly. The supporting cast is solid as well; Willem Dafoe is a welcome addition as one of Wick's peers, looking to collect on the open 2 million dollar contract. For action fans, this is highly recommended; if you're not, stay away, because this is all about the chrome-plated carnage.P.S.: *For 'Leave the Puppy Alone, Part 1', check it out by it's Muslim name, 'The Drop', which it acquired after a prison-yard conversion. Happens all the time in Hollywood.P.S.2: **In case you were wondering, it's a line from the interrogation scene in 'Menace II Society'.P.S.3: ***Thanks Amazon! Thanks for deleting reviews without warning or notice. It's nice to know the time and modest effort reviewers expend is appreciated less than 1 whiny person's irrational complaints about already censored 'profanity'. The 11 of 11 (last time I looked) positive/helpful votes were deleted with it, and worse than that, the comments were destroyed for all eternity. Yeah, many people wouldn't care that Amazon deleted their comments without cause, but some people put thought into them. Ammy asked me to review, I did. It passed the automatic protocols without incident and was up for weeks before getting pulled. Ammy asked people to vote, and eleven people did. Ammy asked people to comment, and a couple fine people did. 15 people contributed when Ammy asked, because they assumed their input would be valued. I do; I value it greatly. But Amazon gave all of us the big 'Yuck Fou' when one complainer did their thing. Well Ammy, Tuck You Foo. Now that MY whining is done, I'll whole-heartedly agree that expecting anyone to care about this crap is silly. Luckily, I don't expect anyone to care... after Amazon didn't respond, however, I had to spill it.

This double-volume hardcover set, collecting 'The Complete Etchings' of the 18th century artist Giovanni Battista Piranesi, is another beautiful, remarkably affordable release from Taschen. Piranesi is one of the most renowned artists to make engraving/etching his chosen medium, and this comprehensive slip-cased set shows off both the genius of Piranesi and the stunning possibilities of a now dying, if not dead, art-form. Speaking personally, between the late Baroque and painters like Salvator Rosa (to whom Piranesi was compared to), and the Neo-classicism and Romanticism of the early 19th century, not much worth mentioning was being created in Europe. Except for some masterful vedute by Venetian artists like Canalletto and Tiepolo, the Rococo period was dominated by the decadent, soulless style for which it's named. The Renaissance and Baroque masters were gone, and Italy would never again be the center of European Art.He is likely most famous for his 'Carceri d'invenzione', a sixteen print group depicting imaginary, sometimes slightly fantastic prisons. Justice and Law were still firmly anchored to Catholic dogma in the 1700's, and the penitentiaries were not concerned with rehabilitating criminals; instead they smaller versions of purgatory and hell. The pain one suffered on the rack was nothing compared to Satan's infernal machinations; but for a man still capable of redemption, torture was a warning, a taste of the eternal pain to come. In that spirit, Piranesi's 'Imaginary Prisons' can be seen as dreamlike, proto-surrealist imagery that captures the black essence of the 18th century prisons and dungeons.Rome was his inspiration. It is his series of engravings on Roman architectural art, perfectly scaled and minutely detailed, that was perhaps his most important work, as well as his Roman vedute, or views. His drawings of temple ruins, sagging arches and broken edifices captured the sad, beautiful evidence of Rome's former glory to perfection in 'Le Antichità Romane de' tempo della prima Repubblica e dei primi imperatori' ("Roman Antiquities of the Time of the First Republic and the First Emperors") -- which is reprinted in its entirety. Piranesi spent years documenting Rome as it was in his lifetime; crumbling, collapsed, half-shattered and grown-over. Thousand-year-old ghosts still seem to inhabit this dead and broken Rome.Beyond these unique projects, his gifts as an architectural designer are demonstrated in the hundreds of plates he executed of chimneypieces and vases, etc. If that doesn't sound too interesting, I have to concur. But when Piranesi was set loose on anything, it became a grand and daring experiment. Editor Luigi Ficacci provides an illuminating biography with historical context, and because this is Taschen, it's provided three times over... in different languages. I wish Taschen would just publish separate English, German, and French editions separately, but it's something they do to cut down on costs, and for the price, it's a decent compromise. Each volume is about 10.25"w x 12.25"h, and together are a total of 800 pages. Instead of the thick, glossy art-book pages everyone loves, the paper-stock is a medium matte-finish, light-weight but acid-free. It works quite well for this release, however, since it's reproducing monochromatic and black and white artwork. Highly recommended.

It's no doubt been said by many a dewy-eyed fanboy (or fangirl) -- the sort who gets future-nostalgic for an apocalypse less likely than The Rapture or Ragnarok -- but I'll join the zombie-chorus anyway -- man, I love this show. I remember when I first picked up the trade paperback of volume 1; I was amazed at how good it was, but still skeptical. It was Image comics, after all, and those who only know Image since Robert Kirkman became supreme overlord probably have no idea that Image used to suck with an absolute purity that makes diamonds look like horse-s***. It won me over after I mowed through the available material -- I think volume 5 was out at the time. One of the critical remarks that stood out then said something to the effect of "'The Walking Dead' would make an incredible HBO series"; it may seem obvious now, but not long ago, that was a very unlikely prospect. Since one of my top 5 favorite shows had wrapped up around that time -- HBO's `Rome' -- I thought that sounded like the best idea I'd ever heard. As it turned out, HBO didn't agree. When I heard AMC had greenlit a six-episode run, I was excited, then uncertain, and then pessimistic. `No swearing, no sex, the violence will be toned down, the fact they only committed to 6 episodes means they're not really behind it'. All of those things were true -- except the violence -- but in the end, none of it mattered. Like Breaking Bad, they managed realistic dialogue without using 'f**k' or 's**t', which was quite impressive. Like the comics, there was virtually no sex... and was much better because of it. I don't want to see sex and dead, rotting corpses in the same scene. Everything in 'The Walking Dead' looks like its been covered in liquefied cadaver; you can almost smell the putrefaction. Regardless how hot the actresses may be, I actually prefer that they skip the no-nudity AMC PG-13 sex scenes. Just carry on with the horrifying horror, thanks.Well into season 3, I still felt nervous about the series... in a weird, geeky, proprietary way. Watching that first, two-hour pilot, I was anxious, and ready to denounce the show loudly and obnoxiously if it offended my smug sensibilities as one of the glorious few who had been a Walking Dead fan from the beginning (even though I actually hadn't... I think issue 34 was the first 'new' single issue I bought after the trades, but close enough). One of my favorite comics - although I have way too many favorites for that expression to mean much - was (and is) `The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen', by Alan Moore and Kevin O'Neill. If you're familiar with both the original story and the celluloid atrocity that bears the same title, you know just how flawlessly Hollywood can f*** things up. They can take one of the smartest, most exciting stories ever written, illustrated with exacting detail far superior to storyboards, and then proceed to do every wrong thing imaginable. If I made it my life's mission to create the worst film adaptation of LOEG possible, I could not have done a better job of sucking. Hence my unease. I started feeling sick as I listened to the terrible, silly exchange between Rick and Shane, just before the pivotal shootout. 'This is gonna suck', I thought. As Rick woke from his coma, left to rot in a hospital full of zombies, I was pissed off by his beard, which was definitely NOT the wild three or four days growth he should have had; instead, it was neatly trimmed to follow his jawline, his throat freshly shaved. Zombie barber? Was it nibbled away? Do zombies nibble? By the end, however, I was almost moved to tears as Rick followed the ravaged, near-skeletal remains of 'Bicycle Girl', as she dragged her legless half-body away from the road. 'I'm sorry this happened to you,' he said, in a choked, emotionally-weighted whisper, placing the barrel against her skull.Season 1 was far more popular than anyone dreamed it might be. While it wasn't perfect, I was one of the comicbook fans who gave it the imperial thumbs up and pretended the rest of the world should give a f***. Then HBO partially redeemed themselves for passing on The Walking Dead with Game of Thrones, which stole some of TWD's thunder. It also gave me a chance to handle the crappy end of the stick as a GRRM noob; I remedied that embarrassing fact by blasting through ASOIAF and everything else he wrote, buying a T-shirt, getting a cool GoT tattoo, and pretending I'd been down since '95. Meanwhile, news was ominous on the season 2 of TWD front. The power struggle between Frank Darabont and Robert Kirkman sucked on every level. Darabont was a great director, and his involvement as executive producer was a big deal; he certainly played a major role in the show's success. 'The Mist' is one of the best horror movies of the past decade, and watching it, you'll recognize a lot of actors who would go on to be cast in TWD, no doubt on Darabont's recommendations. But TWD is Kirkman's creation, and if Darabont was trying to wrest control from the creator's hands, I've got little sympathy. That kind of thing has happened too many times in the comic industry to count. Siegel and Shuster may have created 'Superman', but 15 years later DC wouldn't even let them do an issue for chump change. So the two parted ways, Kirkman firmly in control.Season 2 suffered because of it. After an excellent premiere, the series seemed to be moving underwater at times. Some of the behind the scenes footage for production on season 2 captures the cast treating Kirkman like a f***ing leper... it's clear that some were backing Darabont, and the rest weren't backing anyone, just letting things play out. While the series has always deviated at important junctures from the comic, it's interesting that all the characters portrayed by actors from Darabont's film 'The Mist' were conveniently killed off or exiled by the mid-point of Season 4. Herschel replaced Dale -- whose death was bumped way up in the rotation; Andrea was killed -- a huge shock for the comic fans; and Carol was exiled. All the Darabont faithful have been weeded out. Maybe Lori was on the wrong side. I was very happy to see her killed off, but it was a strange, anti-climactic death that seemed influenced by behind the scenes variables more than compelling narrative choices. But man, I was happy to see her go. I didn't just hate her, I hated anyone she shared the screen with. Every time she opened her mouth, I prayed for zombies. I don't care if she's hiding her pregnancy from Rick... just STFU and die, already...Season 3 saw the show turn a corner, in terms of quality, popularity, and creative direction. The prison, the war with Woodbury, the appearance of Tyreese (Hey, it's Cutty from the Wire! Awesome casting), and of course, Michonne -- everything was moving with Swiss tolerances, cogs pushing cogs, and the mechanism of story-telling smoothly working without obvious strains or conflicts. About three episodes from the finale, I realized that I cared more about the show than I did the comic. That was a hard thing to admit, but it was clear that the series hit me harder than the comics had since issue 48 or so... although issue 100 is a hard one to forget, especially as a Glenn fan.Monsters have always been stand-ins for deeply-rooted anxieties afflicting various social demographics. The thinly-veiled sexual aspects of blood-drinking vampires, could also be interpreted as a metaphor for class inequality -- Dracula as the rich, decadent aristocrat, feeding on the 'vitality' of the English working class; the aristocracy did feed on the lower classes, living on the time, energy and skills of the plebs while they enjoyed luxury and idle pursuits. Labor = time/energy = life = blood. The immortality of the vampire may have spoke to the rigid permanence of class. The aristocracy was always on top, generation after generation. The plebs had no hope that a better life might await their children. Immortality stems from procreation, and for the blue-bloods, aristocratic privilege was eternal.Werewolves, in their Victorian incarnation, spoke clearly to the fears of the English Bourgeoisie. In a society where all traces of base animal instinct were denied or alleged to not exist, and any hint of crude desire could become a minor scandal, or even threaten to destroy a person's life. The idea of being the werewolf, completely losing control of one's animal instincts, was more frightening than the creature itself. Zombies can represent the fears of the young, born into a self-destructive civilization, where the choices of previous generations threaten to destroy the not-so distant future. The way that humanity sacrifices its young in times of war could be compared to cannibalism. They can also represent a consumer culture in which buying - or feeding - is more important than producing. Whatever.The most important thing about The Walking Dead is the story-telling, and how f***ing good the show has become. Season 4 was like an entire season of 4-and-5 star horror films. Every episode felt like an event, and the tension kept building. After the mid-season apocalypse-within-an-apocalypse, the comics and the show had converged in the same sublime manner they had in the beginning; things were changed, things stayed the same. Comic fans could smile as both small episodes and notorious moments suddenly emerged in unexpected ways, and they could be just as horrified when the Governor held the samurai sword. Even though I had guessed that Tyreese would escape the chopping block, and who would take his place, it still played out with a familiar, tragic intensity. When you compare season 1 or 2 to season 4, they don't even come close. The writers, directors and cast are getting better with every episode, becoming more confident, unafraid to push it into new territory. I still felt anxious watching season 4, but it had nothing to do with fears that the series wouldn't live up to the comic (if anything, it's now the other way around). I felt the same anxiety I did watching Breaking Bad, The Wire, Rome, and Game of Thrones, a nervousness that comes from the very best storytelling, when you're so emotionally invested in the characters and the plot, the danger feels almost real. The Walking Dead is no longer one of the best shows airing on basic cable, or one of the best horror series on television; it's one of the best TV shows ever, period.

I own a Benchmade 52 'Morpho' Balisong and a Benchmade 'Contego' Axis-lock, and coincidentally, they both needed Loctite 'Threadlocker' 242 to keep the pivot screw from loosening. The Balisong needed threadlocker on every screw, which I only realized when one of the tiny zen-pin screws went flying amidst the flipping. If you own knives, this is the stuff you want. If you have no idea what the f*** I'm babbling about, this still might be the stuff you're looking for. It locks screws up solid, but not so solid you can't break the grip with a driver. It won't mess things up irrevocably if you apply it then realize you forgot a washer, for example. But as far as hard use, preventing screws from loosening due to vibration and shock, it's excellent.

[REC] was one of the most important films in establishing the 'Found Footage' premise as a popular sub-genre in horror. The raw, unpolished camera work included long, continuous shots that convincingly emulated news and documentary video. The mind recognizes it as 'real' on a subconscious level, giving it a profound emotional impact, and CGI effects never look more stunning than they do in 'FF'. Despite the temptation to use the premise whenever a film-maker is working on a low budget, higher price found footage projects like 'Cloverfield' -- another classic -- have proven just how instinctively terrifying the combination of shaky, hand-held camera-work and realistic CGI can be. The finale of [REC] -- as the female journalist stumbles through the darkness, the cameraman using night-vision to direct her through the top-floor apartment, as a grotesquely distorted creature is hidden somewhere in the cramped space with them -- is amongst the most terrifying ever scenes ever made.The decision to abandon the confines of 'Found Footage' for the latest instalment -- [REC]4 -- is just as baffling as the decision to do a standard, formulaic sequel to 'The Blair Witch Project'. TBWP, Cloverfield, Paranormal Activity, and [REC], represent the four corners of the FF foundation; abandoning the format it pioneered might be a reaction to the current market over-saturation, but it was an ill-advised maneuver.Just as vampires and werewolves were dark reflections of the culture that produced them, and have been altered and updated repeatedly to better suit the times, the zombie has seen similar changes. The British zombie is the most scientifically viable species; it is the product of a viral epidemic -- like almost every post-Romero zombie; the virus can be government produced, extra-terrestrial, or supernatural -- turning the 'vector' into a rabid, ravenous monster. but a living, breathing monster. '28 Days Later' and the Garth Ennis' graphic novel 'Crossed' are excellent examples. The Spanish zombies in [REC] are the result of a 'demonic virus', combining 'The Exorcist' and 'The Walking Dead' for an unlikely, but undeniably creepy result. This time around, the intrepid journalist from the original film is back, rescued from the quarantined apartment building, and transferred to a naval vessel. Like 'The Last Ship', research is being conducted on board, as scientists race to develop a vaccine or treatment that will keep the 'disease' from spreading. Obviously, things go awry.[REC]4 has exciting moments, but without the documentary feel that made the first two films so compelling, it's unable to establish itself in any significant way. 'Found Footage' has lost much of its power to suspend the viewer's disbelief, thanks to repetition. But recent films like 'As Above, So Below' have proven that it still has possibilities. While I wouldn't want to suggest that a franchise should keep repeating itself, I think the writer and director should be careful to define the essence of a given film's appeal, and work within those parameters. 'Paranormal Activity 3' stayed true to the aspects of the original that made it so popular, ejecting all the things that the second film did wrong, and expanding on the 'PA' floor-plan to make a better, far more frightening film. It's easier to point at another film, of course, and say 'they should have done that', than to actually apply those seemingly obvious variables. I don't know if there will be another [REC], but if 'Paranormal Activity' could peak with its third film, there's no reason [REC] couldn't peak with its fifth.

This mega-fable by Haruki Murakami, while occasionally oblique, is a long, clear-voiced, and languidly paced story about conformity, and the ramifications of breaking free of the familial and social expectations that are placed upon us. There are legal, ethical and social expectations we are all subject to 'a priori' -- as both humans and citizens -- and there are the expectations custom-tailored for us by parents, siblings, friends and lovers -- as individuals. It imagines the 'multiverse' as something like an endless apartment complex made up of locked, sound-proofed and windowless suites. Every one of these earth-sized/universe-sized apartments have hidden passages linking them to an adjoining, otherwise hermetically-sealed unit, and rare individuals, prompted by extraordinary circumstances, can see and use these passages, stepping into a unit built just for them... perhaps by them.The story follows two main characters, with connections to one another that are only apparent well into the narrative. But they are each the center of their own personal solar system; the moons and planets and satellites in each respective orbit are often eccentric, and as celestial bodies orbiting different stars collide, the tale moves into the strange gravitational stability of a binary star... a cruel galactic romance that sloughs off all orbital relationships and responsibilities. Similarly, they both encounter a second moon that no one seems to notice.Both Aomame and Tengo were raised in difficult environments, albeit of very different kinds. Both characters make a choice that opens, for them alone, a door. Each of their respective doors will take them into an alternate universe, one with very slight narrative differences. Aomame labels this world '1Q84', as opposed to '1984', the world she came from -- the Orwellian connotations give further evidence of the 'individual vs, society' theme Murakami explores. At several points Orwell's novel is mentioned; instead of 'Big Brother', rewriting history and confusing the present, there are the 'little people'... instead of Big, little; instead of singular, plural; instead of a huge totalitarian machine that destroys and rewrites the past, tiny, mysterious people who remove certain individuals from their reality, to remake them in another.After getting caught in a traffic jam, a simfonietta by Janacek heralds Aomame's fateful decision, with a mysterious taxi-driver as harbinger. Rather than missing her very important 'appointment', she uses an emergency stair pointed out by the cabbie, which takes her off the elevated expressway, and down to a city street below. Not long after, she gets her first clue that things aren't quite right, when she notices a police officer carrying a semi-automatic pistol instead of a revolver. Later, she learns that this change happened years previous, following a gun-battle between police and a group of political and religious radicals, an event she has no memory of.For Tengo, a 'cram-school' math teacher and writer, his life suddenly leaves its well-established course when his associate and mentor Komatsu suggests a strange and risky idea. A teenaged girl named Fuka-Eri has submitted a story titled 'Air Chrysalis' for a high-profile new writer's competition. Tengo is impressed with the story, but both men agree that it can't win as it is, due to its rough, amateurish prose. Tengo finds his door, so to speak, when Komatsu suggests he rewrite Fuka-Eri's manuscript. Their plan is to combine Tengo's technical gifts as a writer with Fuka-Eri's imagination and raw talent as a story-teller, keeping his involvement a secret. Tengo is concerned about Komatsu's scheme, but feel's compelled to work on the manuscript. Fuka-Eri is one of the most important and enigmatic characters in Murakami's novel. When Tengo meets her he is struck by her beauty as well as her unusual personality. She speaks with a complete lack of emotion, and answers questions only when it suits her. He also learns that she is dyslexic, and it was actually her little 'sister' -- the daughter of Fuka-Eri's guardian Professor Ebisuno -- who recorded the tale as Fuka-Eri dictated. After meeting the Professor, and learning more of the mysterious girl's life -- Tengo steps through the door, and commits to revising 'Air Chrysalis', which turns out to be less fictional than anyone could believe such a fantastical tale to be. Secondary characters, like the Dowager, who conspires with Aomame to dispense vigilante justice, are just as intriguing, and new characters emerge as the story progresses, including a surprising figure from Fuka-Eri's past, and a repulsive private investigator.The many characters and storylines of 1Q84 converge, coalesce, and sometimes diverge again. The complexity of the tale is never confusing, and Murakami's writing style has been translated with impressive clarity. The prose has an earnest concision that can say many things at once, or one thing with absolute precision. It's quite a feat, really; I have no idea to what extent the translators deserve credit for 1Q84's brilliance as an English-language novel -- echoing Tengo's dilemma as he rewrote 'Air Chrysalis' -- but I do not doubt that Murakami has created a powerful, profound work of fiction. I haven't read any of Murakami's previous works, but there was something about this story that reminded me of Roberto Bolano's '2666' -- both the meandering, almost haphazard feel of the plot from the outset, slowly tightening midway through, and the language; again, I will always find translations frustrating, on some level, especially with novels like 1Q84 and 2666. They're both purposely ambiguous; I worry that the translator might be twisting and confusing the original intent for the sake of style, or misrepresenting stylistic power in their concern for retaining presumed intellectual intent. If you could quantify it, would 1Q84 be 99% Murakami? 85%? 50%? In the end, you have to take the story as you find it, and trust the translator -- a thankless job, really; translators are seen as technicians instead of artists, despite the aesthetic sensibilities required -- rather than second-guessing a strange word choice, or trying to dig much deeper. But I liked it. As I said, I think the translation is excellent, stylistically. Translating Japanese to English is a far more difficult task than translating Spanish to English. The way 1Q84 was released, in separate parts, echoes way 2666 was released, and the two books have many thematic and stylistic similarities... I'm curious whether Murakami intended it, or if I'm imagining things.

Skip the Prozac, Vodka and Heroin, or quadruple-up on artificial joy! God it feels good to use exclamation marks! Yeah! Bring the kids, 'cause it's a guaranteed explosion of fun and happiness for the whole family! Yeah!!An introverted young woman named Esther, suffering from the purest case possible of Munchausen-by-Proxy, fires off a chain-reaction of suffering, vengeance and violence as shocking as it is completely ridiculous. After being artificially inseminated, she convinces her angry and unstable lesbian girlfriend Anika to 'surprise' her in an alley outside the obstetrician's office, knocking her unconscious and using a brick to brutally terminate the fetus after several months of pregnancy.Her extreme ploy for sympathy and human contact leads her to a support group for those who have lost loved ones. A kind and outgoing woman named Melanie reaches out, and Frau Munchausen quickly becomes obsessed with her. A drunk driver killed her husband and son, or so she says... When Esther sees Melanie in the park with her supposedly dead child, very much alive and well, she assumes that her lies at the support group meetings are expressions of an unfulfilled wish, and that Melanie is exactly like her. She finds her way to the family's home, and drowns the toddler in the bathtub. Esther is surprised when Melanie is emotionally devastated by the discovery of her dead son, and tries to explain instead of moving on to kill the husband. He returns with a shotgun (inexplicably), and kills Esther.The focus then shifts to Melanie, by necessity, and to the husband, Patrick, who takes a surprising left turn to insanity and overwhelming creepiness. He suspects that there was some kind of connection between Esther and Melanie, but she admits nothing. Anika, meanwhile, is determined to avenge her lover's death, and another violent collision is inevitable.Written and directed by Zach Parker, this film is unrelentingly grim and fairly brutal. The plot becomes less and less believable, but crazier stories than this end up as headlines on a regular basis. I don't know what to say about 'Proxy'; watching the misery unfold doesn't make me feel better about anything, which makes me wonder what it is that support group fakers like Melanie get from wallowing in the unfiltered suffering of others. I will admit, however, that most of my favorite works of art, literature and film are reliably dark and brutal; 'Blood Meridian' and 'The Road' are damn near nihilistic, and yet they're at the top of the list. There's just something lacking in 'Proxy'. Nothing redeems it. It reminds me, in some ineffable way, of a far less imaginative 'Irreversible', by Gaspar Noe; that film gave the viewer an entirely uncompromising tour of hell, but by tracking the horrific events backwards in time, they took on a strangely poignant significance. There is no alchemical process at work in 'Proxy', turning lead into gold. Base materials remain base. If you decide to watch it, have fun and hide the razor-blades.Damn it! Spoilers, SPOILERS! I forgot to add a spoiler alert. Well, there's nothing I can do about it now, it's carved in stone.

Arnold Bocklin is one of the most exciting painters out there, a name I constantly punch into crappy used book-seller search engines and hope for a miracle... but he's dead. So there's very little he can do to promote himself, and restart his century-and-a-half old career. As one of the key figures in the loosely defined movement known as 'Symbolism', his work deserves to be exhibited, collected and published, yet he remains largely overlooked. Far less important, far less talented painters are being 're-discovered' on a fairly regular basis, but some of the real giants of 'symbolism', like Gustave Moreau, Fernand Khnopff, and Arnold Bocklin have no significant monographs available.Prestel released a huge retrospective/catalogue raisonne on Bocklin in the seventies, but it sells for a few hundred dollars. The exhibition catalog that accompanied a 2001 show in France based on works inspired by Bocklin's famous work 'The Isle of the Dead' now goes for over 1000$. The book itself is a beautifully produced volume, published by Somogy, and is a testament to the profound inspiration Bocklin has had on artists like Max Klinger, Giorgio De Chirico, Fabricio Clerici, Ernst Fuchs and H.R. Giger. They all counted Bocklin as a primary influence, and each produced a homage to 'The Isle of the Dead', evidence enough that his art merits a new retrospective.This particular volume was released by Rizzoli, who are among my favorite art-book publishers. It dates back to the seventies, however, and is peculiar compared to their current output. Just 8" square and under 100 pages, many of the paintings reproduced are black and white, and most do not depict the entire composition, opting instead for details. The text is limited to quotes by the artist, printed without any particular context save for the art itself. The quality of the color photographs aren't bad, but they're definitely not up to digital standards, and the entire book feels abbreviated in every sense; it's a frustrating and usually over-priced little book, for what you're getting. Even enthusiastic aficionados of Arnold Bocklin, like myself, will probably be disappointed.As another option, the English version of 'Myths and Mysteries: Swiss Artists and Symbolism', published by Somogy, prominently features Bocklin's art, as well as dozens of others. It's an excellent book, large format and comprehensive, with a rich selection of critical essays.

The dialogue is terrible, the ideas are all recycled Kirkman and Romero storylines, and the actors all seem embarrassed by the lame attempts at humor. The bad comedy and predictability are 'Z Nation's only distinguishing characteristics, but I still kind of liked this show. There were entire scenes I skipped, but still... if you're of that same rarefied breed who can watch 'Outpost', 'Dead Snow', and 'War of the Dead' -- without making judgements about originality (or even basic crappiness) -- enjoy.P.S.: Criticisms about SyFy's obvious attempts to cash in on The Walking Dead, and/or the 'zombie apocalypse', are a little confusing. Isn't this the network responsible for 'Sharknado'? If they can't cash in on crass pop-culture trends, who the f*** can? I'm sure they were spammed with several million pitches for a zombie series thirty minutes after The Walking Dead pilot aired. 'Z Nation' was the idea that triumphed over thousands of others, the end result of fierce creative competition that quickly separated the best and the brightest from the pretenders and opportunists. That is unquestionably the scariest thing about this show.

I can't recall ever being so utterly baffled about where exactly a horror film was going. I'm sure there's a few people who will claim they knew what was up. I'm usually one of those people. But every once in a while I find a new blindspot. 'The Cabin in the Woods' surprised me at every turn, even though I was given plenty of clues -- as well as straight-up exposition from the 'office staff' -- before the chaotic finale, when the last piece of the puzzle was fit into place. 'Honeymoon' doesn't give you any warnings before the sudden jerk on the steering wheel that sends the story careening off the road. There are plenty of signs that things are very wrong, and the tension builds quite steadily until the final scene... but I was imagining something far less 'exotic'. The director deserves credit for her restraint, teasing out the suspense until it's almost unbearable.Toward the climax, I was cautiously sympathetic for the increasingly unhinged husband, backing him up as he was begging his wife to make sense of the increasingly surreal data:  "You have to explain this to me, Bea; You have to tell me, what's going on? What's going on, Bea, TELL ME WHAT'S GOING ON?!" I was almost as mystified, but I got a bit embarrassed about my support for Paul after he tied her up in a very un-fun way; but my imagination was over-clocking about scenarios including murderers, rapists, multiple personalities, amnesia, and a Norman Bates-like substitution to replace the original Bea. This is a spoiler-free review, so I'll clarify: one of the theories above may be right, or partly right, or completely off-world.After a sickeningly sweet beginning, the happy honeymoon goes really, really wrong; this particular cabin in the woods has no cellar full of evil objects, but when husband Paul awakens in the night to discover Bea is gone, and finds her in the forest, naked and disoriented, it's clear things won't end well. She has trouble remembering even the most basic things, from how to make French toast to the details of their first date. Then there's the not-so-strange bruising on her inner thighs, which is just the most obvious of several indications pointing to rape. His suspicions immediately fall on Bea's childhood boyfriend, which seems fair, considering he's the only other male and one of just four actors in this film. But Bea is maddeningly reluctant to explain anything... and I won't say any more, either, except that it's not that simple.The acting is excellent, and both leads are convincingly non-British... although, on a continent full of truly non-British people, why import Brits to pretend they're not Brits? Are British actors that much more awesome than American and Canadian actors? That's rhetorical, of course, since we all know they are. Rose Leslie has been in two of the most critically acclaimed series of all time -- Game of Thrones and Downton Abbey.
