I have previously purchased other balance pads to both help with rehab after a bad ankle injury last year, and for use with my standing desk. In reviewing this pad I will compare it to the Airex Balance Pad Blue and Yes4All Balance Pad.First, there are two price points, with the Yes4All pad being about half the price of the Airex and SPRI pads. Is there a difference between them? Yes - the Yes4All feels different. It provides less instability, compresses a bit more and seems to be standing up less well to wear and tear, though by no means is it bad. It is simply designed as a more budget conscious alternative and will work well for most people.Comparing the SPRI to the Airex there are a couple of differences. First, the SPRI is a little but smaller (15.75" L x 13" W x 2.5" Thick) than the Airex (19.5" L x 16" W x 2.5" Thick). For physical therapy purposes this is not an issue. I do notice however that the larger size of the Airex makes it a bit better when I am using it with my standing desk. The Yes4All is closer in size to the Airex, coming in at 19" x 15" x 2.5".These is also a slight difference in compression, with the Airex compressing slightly more. This wouldn't be noticeable unless you are comparing them side by side. One doesn't seem meaningfully different than the other.Where the SPRI seems to excel is in the printed instructions that ship with it, as well as with some of the online information they provide. The Yes4All provides practically no info, and the Airex has limited info in the box.Overall I would probably recommend the Airex because it is a little larger and performs essentially at the same level as the SPRI. That is not to say though that the SPRI is an inferior product. In fact, if you are purchasing a pad to help with physical therapy and haven't had sessions with a physical therapist where you learned how to use it, I would probably recommend the SPRI.

My wife is a big fan of these earrings. A couple of things to keep in mind:1 - These are not tiny earrings. They have some size and heft to them, though they are not so heavy that she notices wearing them.2 - The design is more angular than "soft". These will go best with clothes that have their own straight lines and edges.Overall they are much nicer than many of the standard Turquoise jewelry that you will find at low end jewelry shops.
I only watched this episode due to the Hawaii Five-0 crossover. If this episode is indicative of other NCIS episodes, I am glad that I have never wasted time on it before.

Great preparation for my pilgrimage next year. It is the English translation of the famous travel guide written by Miyazaki Tateki. It is divided into two sections. The first deals with the practicalities of the trip:Chapter 1: TimeChapter 2: Number Of Days RequiredChapter 3: Preparing For The TripChapter 4: How much will this cost?Chapter 5: How To PlanChapter 6: Pilgrimage Goods and Things To Pay Attention ToChapter 7: Recommended equipmentChapter 8: The Weight Of The Gear (light is good, waterproof is good)Chapter 9: Pre-Departure Preparations (lose weight, practice walking and get yourself ready to go)Chapter 10: Money (finding ATM's isn't always as easy in rural Japan as you might think)Chapter 11: Making ReservationsChapter 12: Manners/Customs At The Sacred SitesChapter 13: Do's and Don'ts Of A PilgrimChapter 14: How To Walk The Pilgrim PathChapter 15: Sleeping Outside (I don't plan on doing it)Chapter 16: About TakuhatsuChapter 17: Waterfall Training (fun read)Chapter 18: Going Home — The End Of The TrainingAppendix 1: Chart Of Time/Distance Between TemplesAppendix 2: Weight Of Gear - note that this is an estimate only and your options will vary. Light is expensive...The second section contains information about the 238 sacred sites along the way. You are not going to get tons of detail on each site but you will get enough to tell you what you are looking at, basic history and the deities who the temples are dedicated to.My plan is to carry this book on the trip in Kindle form on my Iphone so that I have easy reference to the charts and temple info.

This is a workhorse of a corkscrew at a price that is so low that I had to look twice to make sure I didn't misread it. This is the sort of corkscrew that you will be using 20 years from now and you will be annoyed when you lose it while tailgating. The wine stopper is better looking than many other more expensive options out there on the market.Stop comparison shopping and just buy it. At this price you cannot go wrong.

I have been drinking Nespresso for more than 10 years and I am a hard core user. I have tried all sorts of Nespresso machines and capsules and have indoctrinated others into the clan. While I don't dislike the taste of these capsules from Puroast I have three problems with them:1 - At $1.29 per capsule they cost much more than capsules purchased through Nespresso or for other brands sold through Amazon. Examples include Aldecoa Nespresso Coffee Capsules, Intense, 10 Count (Pack of 4) which I found to be VERY tasty at half the price of these capsules.2 - Unlike standard Nespresso capsules these pods must be kept in an airtight pouch in order to stay fresh. If you drink espresso on a daily basis this will probably not be a big deal. Just keep in mind that there is a shelf life once you open the foil bag.3 - If you are going to pay double the price of other brands of pods, you would expect a significantly better taste or other benefit. The taste is no better than competitors, and a bit on the weak side for me. To be fair Puroast does indicate that they have less acid than "other leading coffees" but I don't notice any difference between it and pods from Nespresso or Aldecoa. Perhaps they are comparing it to Maxwell House or other commercial brand - they don't specify which brands they are comparing themselves to and I don't feel obliged to make their argument for them.The bottom line is that these pods make perfectly acceptable, though weak, espresso in your Nespresso machines but they charge twice the price of other, equally good or better pods from Nespresso and other companies.

I know what you're thinking - it's a french press with most of the plunger's shaft removed. That's not an incorrect description BUT this small change makes for a pitcher that is very good for infusing water, iced tea and other drinks. A couple of characteristics that merit your attention:1 - This pitcher looks VERY nice on a table. The ratio of height to width makes is aesthetically pleasing and the pitcher shows off your creations.2 - The plunger does a very good job of filtering out most solids that you are using to infuse in to the water. We tried herbs, thinly sliced fruit and vegetables as well as toasted rice and none of those solids made it through and into the cups.It's a single-purpose item and I usually am not a fan of that sort of thing. The elegant design though makes it worth keeping around.

I have been using this product for a few months and it has earned a permanent home in my travel bag. It is light, usable around the world and powers all USB devices I have used it with including an iPhone 6+, an iPad air, a bike headlight, external batteries, headphones, etc. Why worry about adapters when traveling - get this and you know that you can power your USB devices no matter where life takes you.

Note to self: just kill the bad guy once he has been eviscerated...A quick and enjoyable read. Perhaps more authors can release occasional short stories in between their big releases- it makes the wait bearable.

I know that Halle Berry can act because I have seen her in great roles in the past. You wouldn't know from Extant that she can express anger, fear, deep sorrow and passion. Most of the characters express anger-lite of something more akin to mild exasperation in situations that should have had them raging in fury.The scifi aspects gave me a reason to watch the season. Overall though I probably will not be watching a second season if it is released.
Slightly dark and subversive, this video was enjoyed by two 40-something non parents this past weekend.

I have been using this cleanser for a couple of weeks and am blown away by the difference. Granted I was using plain bar soap and a wash cloth before switching to this but the results over just a few days of using Biore was amazing. My skin is much smoother, not at oily and the dry red patches are all gone.After a few days of use I decided to up the exfoliation by using this with a buf puf. Yep those are still for sale and amazon had a good deal. I use the buf puf every other day or so with the Biore cleanser, and the other times I wash my face I just use the Biore. I am a convert.

The photos of the Lenox Winter Greetings Plaid 5 Piece Place Setting do not do the set justice.  In order to appreciate the subtle beauty of this product one must be able to touch and admire each piece.  The glint of gold trim picks up the light and is certainly not reflected in the photographs on the item page.  The trim seems larger on the photo when in reality it is sophisticated and more intense, the tones darker rather than the orang-y red that is depicted here and of course, references the holiday season.  This set is so lovely that it can be used throughout the winter season as the name suggests and not only as a Christmas novelty.  Even more importantly, for those of an Outlander persuasion, these dishes have a distinctly Scottish plaid design which just might be the thing to serve your personal Jamie Fraser! Check out the photo with Blackjack Randall served up for dessert!The set consists of a cup and saucer, a butter plate, a salad plate and a dinner plate.  All are of the legendary Lenox quality that brides and anyone setting up a new house always coveted and touted as "the good china."  One look at this set will tell you why Lenox has been the standard for so many generations.Bottom line?  Recommended.  Its lovely, delicate, sophisticated and can be used at other times--not just during the holiday season.  Outlander fans, check these out for a Scottish themed dinner party!Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

Fodor's Paris 2016 Full-Color Travel Guide doesn't recommend activities that aren't worth doing; everything in this 400+ page book is geared towards the Parisian enthusiast.  It accommodates both first time visitors to the City of Lights and the frequent traveler.Like many travel guides, the Fodor's breaks its book down by devoting chapters to individual locales in the city.  But this guide includes several pages on the places themselves as well as the area's top attractions.  For example: In "The Islands" segment, we are treated to a detailed map and the top reasons to go to the area at-a-glance--in this case, Notre Dame, Sainte-Chappelle and the ability to stroll along the oldest portion of the city.  The best cafes are noted: La Charlotte de l'isle and Le Saint Regis.  A discourse on ice cream versus gelato is offered as famous shoppes, Amorino (gelato) and Berthillon (Ice Cream) are both located on the Ile Saint Louis.  The rest of the sections pages are devoted to fleshing out the at-a-glance features, stipulating family oriented activities and pointing out less obscure curiosities. Notre-Dame has its own section, complete with photos and times where the spectacular windows are shown in their best light.Each attraction is afforded the same thoughtful treatment which will allow travelers to create an itinerary that brings the Paris to them from the best perspective--almost like a personal guide. The rest of the book has indexed portions that detail places to eat, places to stay, places to shop, places to enjoy the nightlife, places to enjoy performing arts and includes side trips from Paris to Versailles, Chartres and Disneyland.  There are a few pages dedicated to the language and traveling smart which are quite good as they include local taboos and cultural no-nos.  Best of all is a fabulous fold out map that details main tourist attractions.  Well thought out!Bottom Line?  The Fodor's Paris 2016 Travel Guide provides an updated summary of attractions and suggested itineraries for anyone interested in journeying to Paris.  Detailed and thoughtful, it is almost as good as having a personal guide.  Recommended as it travels well, isn't overly bulky and contains many colored illustrations.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

"Bitter Greens" by Kate Forsyth details the story of Charlotte-Rose de Caumont de la Force, the French storyteller who is best known for her story Perinette--or Little Parsley which became widespread under the more familiar title, Rapunzel.  Forsyth does a fine job of crafting a woman of great emotions and passions who must tread softly as a Huguenot in the Roman Catholic court of the Sun King, Louis XIV.  Her story begins rather depressingly as the heroine is remanded to a convent by order of the king and must sacrifice her lovely clothes, her freedom and all her other privileges due to her scandalous behavior.  Forsyth's depiction of the convent, its cruelties and hypocritical women is balanced only by Charlotte-Rose's narrative of her former life and her dreams for her future.Some readers may become lost as Charlotte-Rose flips from one part of her life to another in an order not always chronological.  Nevertheless Forsyth's magnificent handling of her character proves her mettle as a writer who can not only depict the times and circumstances of 17th century France but can build a character of great nuance and power.As with all good stories, there is a lesson to be learned.  While in the convent, Charlotte-Rose learns a bit about humility when she comes in contact with an older sister who entertains her with a version of the Rapunzel story that reveals a great truth.  This fairy tale is encrusted with pain, vanity and passion like the original version of Rapunzel that was included in the original collection of the Brothers Grimm and criticized for its inappropriateness for children. The nun's tale is woven within Charlotte-Rose's own story which makes for an entertaining and suspenseful break from the dreary life at the convent.Forsyth's language and narrative is extremely well-done.  I listened to the unabridged audio version of this novel and was pleased by the performance by Kate Reading.  If you are a fan of Forsyth's you might recognize some of her descriptions and scenarios from other novels, but even if this can become repetitious, it does not detract from the overall enjoyment of the tale.Bottom line?  Kate Forsyth's "Bitter Greens" is recommended to all those who enjoy a detailed adult version of a popular fairy tale--in this case the beloved story of "Rapunzel."  For those who are gentle readers, Forsyth does not pull any punches--her tortures, punishments and sorrows are very much on point.  Recommended.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

As a big fan of the original Millennium trilogy starring Lisbeth Salander, I was thrilled to discover that David Lagercrantz had picked up the torch and renewed the spirit of this great character originally created by Stieg Larsson in a new fourth novel entitled "The Girl in the Spider's Web."  Now Lagercrantz did have big shoes to fill and it is a tribute to his self-confidence that he even picked up this endeavor in view of what fans around the world would inevitably have to say.  Let's face it, no one is going to be absolutely thrilled with another author's perception of this character.  Only Larsson with his ins and outs, side stories and secondary characters knew where he wanted all these players to end up.  I, for one, am pleased to hear Lisbeth's thoughts again; I was doubly pleased to have her interact with such sensitivity to an autistic boy who has been misread and misdiagnosed in the pages of Lagercrantz's first offering.  I was equally thrilled that her relationship with Blomkvist continues from a problem-solving vantage point but also from a personal perspective where she not only gets to show her technical savvy but a sensitivity that hasn't been dulled by life's harsh treatment of her.  Lagercrantz writes in the same circuitous style as Larsson--perhaps the translation from Swedish to English helps truncate thoughts without much literary styling--but somehow that works to create the quirky dark world of these characters and to underscore the terrors that lie in wait in Larsson/Lagercrantz's depiction of progressive Sweden.Bottom line?  I liked it!  I look forward to another episode where Blomkvist and Salander continue their relationship and uncover more secrets.  Hopefully this series will continue to explore Lisbeth's psyche as she tries to put her rugged past behind her.  Recommended for all Salander fans.

As I recently hurt my knee, the Fitoby Knee Support Sleeve came in very handy.  I must admit that it helped me to ease back onto the road to recovery.  Having never used any type of support during my training, I was extremely surprised at how efficiently this extremely easy to wear sleeve worked to help soothe my hurt muscles.  While wearing this compression sleeve, I was able to work out hurt muscles that otherwise cramped and hurt me to the point of sleepless nights.  After wearing this sleeve one afternoon in conjunction with some magnesium lotion, I was happy to sleep the night and felt good enough the next day to press onward towards recovery with more exercises that stretched out my tight muscles.  Knee pain is awful; avoiding using muscles that are conditioned to be used only tightens the pain into a coil of hurt.  I alternated this heavier sleeve with a less expensive and thinner Copper Fit Sleeve.  (http://www.amazon.com/Copper-Fit-Original-Recovery-Sleeve/dp/B00PNY3DS4/ref=sr_1_4?ie=UTF8&qid=1445132654&sr=8-4&keywords=copper+sleeve+for+knee.)  I live in Louisiana where the Fitoby gets a little sticky to wear all the time.  Both sleeves acted as miracle cures for me, turning the tide from pain to wellbeing.  Recommended but watch your fit on this--where the Copper Fit is more elastic you may be able to gamble between small and medium.  The Fitoby is much thicker and needs more consideration as to which on will actually fit smoothly.

The Yellow Plated Sterling Silver Multi Gem Necklace looks pretty much like the photo except for one extremely important difference:  the gem studded portion of the necklace only extends to about 1.5 inches on either side of the dropped portion.  The drop is about the same length as the two sides.  The rest of the necklace consists of a fairly thin chain that could very well break easily if care is not given--no yanking or rough handling as this piece will definitely end up in the trash as unwearable.  Instead of the thin link chain, this necklace would have been better serviced with an anchor, Byzantine or wheat chain that would have added some heft to the part of the necklace that is most apt to snap!  The clasp and links are so fragile, I hesitate to wear it!  The stones are as specified: Amethyst, Citrine, Garnet, Peridot, Topaz.  The gold setting offsets the color of the gemstones, dulling them against the gold plating.  Perhaps these would have looked more vibrant in a strictly silver setting.  The original pricing on this is absolutely ridiculous--in fact even at the current price, this necklace is a bit pricey mostly because of the weak chain and fastening.  Nevertheless, it is pretty and looks especially nice when showcased within  additional graduated chains without pendants.  Recommended at a less expensive cost.

The Carhartt Women's 1889 Slim Fit Denim Dungaree fit as one would expect from a slim type jean.  Luckily, I am not exactly tall, so after I cut the length the tighter portion of the leg did allow me to fit these over boots--however, I would think that for those who do not need length alteration, these may be a little snug around the ankles and may not accommodate the added bulk of higher shoes or work boots.  The material is stretchy--hooray--the cut higher on the waist--double hooray--I am so tired of zippers that are only three inches long on below the waistline hip-hugging jeans!  The color is superb--there is a slight whiskering on the crotch area which I prefer.  The pockets are not exactly functional--the two top ones are shallow and the long fronts are not pockets at all but a decorative double fabric that I suppose would work to one's advantage if actually using these jeans as functional workhorses.  As to whether or not these will work as farm jeans, I cannot say; I liked the style, will not be mucking about in them and because of this, I do expect them to last a while without a show of wear.  Recommended.

For those who are a bit fragrance-phobic, this "Poo-Pourri Before-You-Go Toilet Spray" may not work for you.  Unfortunately, it does not work for me.  The "Royal Flush" fragrance is a combination of Eucalyptus and Spearmint that should be fresh and aromatic, however it includes a fake perfume-y note that ruins the effect and in my case, could trigger a migraine:(As far as its usage as a toilet spray, it works to camouflage foul odors. Spray it onto the water before toilet usage and, ahem, you are good to go!Recommended for those who do not have a problem with perfume-y fragrances, love candles and don't mind paying $15 for home fragrances..

SoTru Fermented Medicinal Mushrooms is a powdered product that combines the properties of six types of medicinally used mushrooms with a citrus taste to produce a reasonably palatable drink that takes second to make.Eight ounces of water plus a level scoop of the product (the scoop is provided) into my Nutribullet and seconds later, the drink is emulsified and ready to drink.  Don't be dissuaded by the color of the product--its a pale brown so the mixture looks a bit silty.  If you are expecting an earthy mushroom-y flavor, you will be in for a surprise.  The main taste note one detects is a citrus lemon. although the supplement does include acerola cherry, green tea leaf and ginger root.I took this supplement after exercise and was pleased that it refreshed me and did not cause bloating or any other adverse effect. I have not experienced any digestive disturbance with it, but I have noticed a bit of an energy increase and hunger decrease.  I am not a coffee drinker and limit my green tea intake to morning hours only, so this brings with it a nice boost of energy in the early afternoon.The container contains about a month's worth of daily servings.  Considering how much specialty mushrooms cost, the price is understandable at just below $40.  I cannot attribute to its immunity-building power as of yet; but it seems a good idea to counteract the effects of back-to-school germs and transitioning weather.  Because of this uncertainty, I lowered my rating one star.Bottom line?  A good tasting product that contains powdered mushrooms. Recommended.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

0:12 Mins The Iron Stop KWS100 Butterfly Kinetic Wind Spinner is a little pricey--but it is absolutely delightful.  It is a snap to set up: simply screw in the middle tube to the Spinner portion and then open the screw all the way on the portion designed to anchor into the ground, slide the tube in and secure by replacing the screw,  I used my foot and weight to step the bar into the ground and my hands to tilt it in a pleasing direction.The butterflies can be angled to catch the wind and create a more three-dimensional piece.  However for those who like the cylindrical look that comes straight out of the box. this works, too and is just as pretty.  In fact, my original idea was to put this in my front yard, but it is so strikingly pretty, I think it will tempt many to transgression!  In the back yard it went, making a very appealing focal point.Bottom line? This Wind Spinner will definitely appeal to all ages; the painted butterflies shimmer with dimension, giving it a one-of-a-kind appearance rather than a mass produced item.  Colorful and appealing!  Check out the video to see it in action--and this without bending the butterfly wings to better catch the wind!Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

Paula Brackston's "Lamp Black, Wolf Grey" starts out with promise and then dissolves into the mists of the Welsh countryside that stands as a backdrop to this tale of Merlin and the lasting power of storytelling. Brackston, an author popular for her novels revolving around magic and witches, tries to underscore the importance of keeping legends alive while writing an under-whelming plot that fails to be memorable.Laura, a modern day artist, moves from London with her husband Dan to the rural Welsh countryside where she intends to indulge in her artwork while fulfilling the couple's dream to conceive a child. Instead she meets up with the reclusive Rhys--a passionate soul who immediately mesmerizes her into infidelity.In a parallel story, Megan from the time of King Arthur, meets Merlin the Magician--Brackston's Merlin is of the Pierce Brosnan variety--dark haired and blue-eyed--no long white beards or sorcerer's apprentice robes for him--and falls in love awhile acting as a nanny of the lord of the manor's two children.  Politics abound and sadly, roadblocks are put in the way of Megan and Merlin's love.Brackston pulls the reader into the story initially but fails to develop any of her characters--all are stereotypical at best.  Where she succeeds is creating the Welsh landscape--a place of dreamy unreality where magical things can happen.  Brackston wields her magic, but this, too, is ineffective; the story flails.plunging into trope as both Megan and Laura's hearts move in directions that lead then to their eventual and very predictable fates.Appearing in both story lines is Merlin--Brackston's portrait seems off as one would think the clever magician would employ more wily devices to charm and control his hosts and enemies. Instead, Brackston depicts the wizard as a man with a not-so-clever tongue, defying the local nobility in alliances that do not make much sense and are never fully explained.Laura in particular seems a babe in the woods--her ability to step into dangerously foolish situations is part of her characterization, but Brackston's unraveling of the mysteries in her plot line render her unsatisfying at the very least.  On the other hand, Megan is a fairy tale heroine who gives her all with maidenly virtue even in the darkest moments.  This too is not fulfilling in terms of the story.The story ends with an lengthy epilogue that summarizes the characters outcomes.  There is little emotion or reaction, just relief when the last page is finally reached.Bottom line?  I recommend Lamp Black, Wolf Grey only for its atmosphere.  The story line while initially compelling fades into stereotypes and contrivances that quickly become boring and disappointing especially for those who want to see Merlin in a more faceted light.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"B

I agreed to review the South Shore Callesto 4-drawer Chest because of a conversation I had with my cousin who is in the process of setting up her new condo after living in a five-bedroom house for most of her life.  My cousin has a knack for fastidiousness; there is nary a paper or pen floating around her abode without a proper place.  With this in mind, I viewed the haphazard stack of mail that usurps nearly a quarter of my kitchen countertop and decided that this white chest of drawers would be just the thing to hide the mess while providing extra storage.The chest is IKEA quality, although, I must admit, that when the product was delivered to my door, I was not expecting such a heavy item and would have insisted that the carrier at least pop it through my door.  It took me several minutes to figure out a way to get that box into my house--so those who live alone: take heed--this item is extremely heavy.  It took me several hours to assemble this--the weight alone daunting to negotiate and the instructions . . . .well after carrying the box into the house, I suggest several minutes of recuperation time to at least regain some semblance of patience to be at a point where interpreting them was doable.  My main problem with the assembly was alignment: the holes did not always match--definitely presenting a strain on my desire to just get the job done.  Most definitely two people are required for assembly--especially for those like myself who do not attempt such endeavors more than once a year.The result is a satisfying chest of drawers that fits nicely in its designated niche.  It is constructed of particle board--so I would not expect this to function in anyway other than storage.  I would not place heavy items on its surface as there will definitely be a limit to its holding capacity.  It would work nicely as clothes storage and for my purpose of paper filing, it does an adequate job of hiding a daily mess.

The Zwilling J. A Henckels Nose and Ear Hair Trimmer makes a bit of an odd impression at first glance.  Packaged within a small plastic box, the device resembles something that an Inquisitor may have used to force confessions from penitents.  However, the mechanism works, requiring the user to merely press the head of the device into the nostril and press the levers to create a rotating scissoring effect.  An accompanying brush helps to clean lodged hairs.I had no problem using the trimmer and was pleased with the results.  Some reviewers claim that the trim isn't close enough; I do not adhere to this opinion.  The Zwilling trimmer is compact and travels well; it provides a quick, painless groom.  For those a bit more fastidious in nature or those who have become reliant upon battery-operated trimmers, I recommend the Zwilling nose and ear hair scissors: Zwilling J.A. Henckels Nose and Ear Hair Scissors as a good pairing product that also does not require batteries.

Valerio Massimo Manfredi's "Odysseus: The Oath" means well.  Trying to emulate the work of Mary Renault, it starts out with a bang, depicting the life of the young Odysseus in a compelling first person voice that allows the reader into his mindset as he combats obstacles of his heritage and his obligation.  Unfortunately, once Odysseus ships off with the other Achaeans on their mission to claim runaway Helen of Troy. Manfredi's narrative becomes almost boring despite his retelling of the Trojan war from the perspective of the wily hero who designed the first Trojan Horse.Manfredi's novel ends as Troy is razed to the ground.  Part Two covers Odysseus's long journey home.  I doubt I will read this second installment as the recount of the Illiad was not all that exciting.  Manfredi would have been better off concentrating on his character's ties to Ithaca--his grandfather, the wolf man, his mother's cryptic role as well as his relationship with his father Laertes and his wondrous alliance with the goddess Athena.  The retelling of the Trojan war, sadly does him in; it fails to include the depth of characterization at which the earlier part of the novel hints.Bottom line?  "Odysseus: The Oath" is a retelling of the Greek hero's earlier life up until the point in time when the city of Troy tumbles at the hands of the Achaeans.  Manfredi gives the impression of wily older Odysseus but does not succeed in convincing the reader in a way that engages him/her in the day to day trial of sustaining a war involving a thousand ships and a beautiful trophy wife.  Recommended only for the first half of the novel.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

I asked the men in my life to try out this Shave Oil.  One of them suffers from razor burn and although can use regular shaving cream, cannot shave every day.  With the Thrive Shave Oil, he was able to shave every day.  He used about a quarter sized drop of the oil and ran it over his face--the shave was smooth and he equated it to a barbershop experience.  He's a believer.  The other tester compared the oil to another  product Cremo--he said the shave he got from Thrive was comparable--smooth and easy to use, but he liked the Chrismas-y scent of Thrive better.  Neither men experienced any breakouts and will use the product again.  Mister Razor-burn will definitely repurchase.Recommended, then for those who have sensitive skin and don't miss lathering.

The Sterling Silver Oxidized Celtic Knot Pendant is an interesting piece of jewelry that looks attractive on the neck and generates complimentary conversation.  The Oxidized look gives the piece a darker appearance which emphasizes the intricate design of the Celtic knot.  The disk itself is about the size of a U.S. penny, the chain is delicate but holds up well and hits the throat a little low--I wear it on a shorter chain but my neck is small and I like pendants to hit a the base of the throat.The necklace is packaged in a substantial black box lined on one side with velvet.  The lid is lined in a royal blue paper which makes for a nice presentation if you are thinking of purchasing this as a gift.  The price is about right for the weight.  Recommended.

Melanie Benjamin's "The Swans of Fifth Avenue" depicts an era in New York City history when Truman Capote was the darling of the social set and chose the women that hung around him for their beauty and status.  Benjamin bases her story on truth, but elaborates certain instances for the purpose of further dramatization; her portrait of the quirky self-indulgent flawed Truman Capote seems to be spot on--his tragedy perfectly spins out to its rather desultory ending.  Whether or not Benjamin is crafting a moral fable as to the repercussions of egoism or warning future writers to honor the confidentiality of their friends' stories or simply recreating an era that obviously fascinated a Mid-Western girl in love with the idea of New York and all things "Breakfast at Tiffany's" must be taken into account during this fascinating read.The author spotlights each of Capote's 'swans' with stories most likely garnered from Capote's stories or items collected from the gossip columns; she underlines the 'trophy wife' concept so prevalent in the mindset of these women and almost plagues the reader with the sadness of such beauties getting old and falling out of popularity.  She focuses on Capote's relationship with Babe Paley--depicting this society grand dame as a sad woman desperate for love.  Benjamin's  Capote is the Capote of the film staring Phillip Seymour Hoffman--a man obsessed with telling a story to gain celebrity and falling into the trap of becoming the ultimate user--where the story means more than the people--and the negative reactions mean more publicity.  As in the film, underneath it all is the failure to be accepted; the desire to be loved and admired.  Ultimately, the single-minded excuses result in self-destruction, especially after Capote reaches his pinnacle after the publishing of "In Cold Blood."While all that is entertaining, the overall tone of the novel is bleak and may not appeal to readers who may want something more uplifting.  Its written well, and Benjamin does a fine job with her portrayals but ultimately when she urges the reader to find out more about this era in celebrity history, I must ask, 'What for?"  The entire novel is populated with superficial people who care more about facade than life itself.  Ugh.Bottom line?  "The Swans of Fifth Avenue" is well-written and well-researched.  Sadly, its a downer tale.  Recommended for those who want to explore the mindset of author Truman Capote.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

It takes a while for the reader to get passed the fact that none of the narrators in Paula Hawkins, "The Girl on the Train" are likeable reliable narrators.  All three of them have problems, their commonality a residential street of houses that backs the train going in and out of London each day.  As all three narrators get their turn to tell their story, the reader pieces together that they are connected in even more intricate ways.  Hawkins does a superb job of keeping the suspense up without revealing much of her hand until the very end of her tale.A young wife goes missing; one of the first person narrators, Rachel, knows the missing girl--she's observed her in passing from the window of her commuter train.  She wants to help the police; she wants to help herself.  She needs a new starting point in life because her husband has left her for another woman . . . and now they have an infant daughter.Hawkins writes of disturbed people whose faces are raw with shame and self-pity.  Her mystery revolves around need.  I listened to the unabridged audio presentation of this book; the performance gets high marks for theatricality and poignancy.  The narrators all have their flaws--there are no super human stereotypes here; together their voices pull together to find a light at the end of a dark tunnel at their own expense.Bottom line?  Some might find the characters too disagreeable to give them time to work their simple magic.  Make the time; this thriller is quietly exciting and chilling in its every day reality. Recommended.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"
Fast delivery; packaged well to prevent breakage, this frame makes a great gift and presentation of a celebratory moment commemorated with both certificate and a portrait.  Nice.

I only read the first book in the Fifty Shades Trilogy; perhaps, because of this fact, I can afford to be a little less critical about "Grey," E.L. James fourth Fifty Shades offering--which as a retelling of the first of the Fifty Shades books from the perspective of Christian Grey, can be redundant for readers who have overindulged in the series or the film.  I have not seen the film, but I found the compelling image of Jamie Dornan as the lead feeding into my thoughts as I read "Grey."  Getting into the mindset of James' character has its perks and if the reader can get over the character's muttering to himself, describing Miss Steele's anatomy as if she is the first woman he ever saw, and some details to his business life that have little relevance to the story other than the fact that it fuels his large bank account, it could work from an amusement standpoint.  That's not to say that there is some poignancy to James' work, but let's face it, the fact that her books have garnered millions for her, gives her more than one capitalistic option to wallow amongst the greenbacks she continues to accrue within this franchise.  (She should come out with a Fifty Shades Braided flogger . . . )  If people will buy another trilogy from Grey's perspective, why not?  Why wouldn't she write it? And there is something fascinating about already knowing where such a character is going even before he does.  Listening to his voice and hearing his expectations and first hand reactions regarding scenes and events of which the reader is already aware adds anticipation to the story and more nuance to the Grey character.  Perhaps, James started her series off on the wrong foot; Anastasia Steele, all innocence and burgeoning kink, is not all that exciting; however, Grey is a memorable character--he's flawed and readers want to know what he thinks and what he's going to come up with next.  I don't know if he is ever "tamed," if that's the case, James makes a mistake in throwing cold water over a hot blanket.Bottom line: If you liked Christian Grey as a character, you might find "Grey" a fun read.  Be prepared for a redundant story as this a retelling of "Fifty Shades of Grey."  Be ready for E.L James' signature mutterings and repetitive thought patterns.  Recommended for Christian Grey fans.Diana Faillace Von Behren

The V-Light LED Energy Efficient Pyramid Style Lamp is the perfect size for my small secretary.  The long adjustable arm where the light sits is easy to swing over my computer screen, so that when a lamp is necessary, one poke on the pyramid shape provides me with just the lighting that I need.  The light is bright and clean and will last for years, but I doubt that when it burns out, it can be replaced. Nonetheless, the three settings will provide adequate light for even the most intricate hobbies; I find for reading the lower settings are adequate.  I had a little difficulty keeping the arm steady, but a quick turn on the standard screw holding the swivel rectified that in seconds.  The USB plug at the end of the base adds a great feature to the lamp; I always liked the efficiency of hotel room desks with built in phone chargers and now I have one of my own.  Recommended.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

Ben McPherson's "A Line of Blood" is a thriller that those who enjoyed the Australian television series "Secrets and Lies" will find of interest.  The theme of secrets within the bonds of family motivates protective overlooking as each member of the Mercer family--Alex, his wife, Millicent and his son, Max try to come to terms with the gruesome death of the neighbor next door.  Concerned at first by the trauma young Max (eleven-years-old) has sustained at the sight of the neighbor dead in his bath tub during a routine search for the Mercer family cat, Alex must deal with the police investigations as well as some hard-to-face feelings of alienation regarding his wife and feelings that he has a difficult time suppressing that go back to a dark youth with a suspect father.  McPherson works hard to sustain a twist and turn narrative; he succeeds at times, but then fails in instances where Alex's narrative becomes murky or segues into new information too quickly to be absorbed smoothly by the reader.  All in all, the novel entertains in a painful cynical manner that eventually reveals the truth before the author's reveal.Alex's first person voice is tentative and emotionally stifled by his negative view of the world.  He is a man at odds with himself and what he looks at as convention.  Does he believe in love? Does he believe in family? Or is he just someone with selfish motives?  Someone who has never grown up?  This sense of angst prevails through Alex's story--throughout his puzzling out of events that will forever change his life.  He's a confused protagonist that signifies the edgy mistrusting persona of our modern world.  From a reader's perspective,  he comes across as befuddled and off-center.  Unlikeable but capable of eliciting compassion.Bottom line?  "A Line of Blood" redefines the role of the family in a convoluted thriller that will entertain but ultimately will instill the reader with a sad reticence. Recommended.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

Tess Gerritsen's novel, "Playing with Fire," starts out like a typical thriller.  Second violinist and first person narrator, Julia, discovers a piece of music in an old book in an antiquarian shop in Rome; intrigued she purchases the book and returns to her Boston home.  She can hear the music in her head, but when she actually attempts to play the piece on her instrument, its frantic crescendo has a violent effect on her three-year-old daughter.  Julia is convinced that the music is diabolical in some way and she catapults into a frenzied investigation to find out why and how.  As in all such stories, Gerritsen relies upon another voice explaining the history of the artifact from the perspective of an earlier time; she journeys the reader to the Venice of the 1930s where a young violinist dreams of winning a competition with his partner, a beautiful young cellist.  Lorenzo's POV is presented as a third person voice; his love of music, his family and of his home evident in his fervor.  Inevitably, the two stories coincide to offer the reader an entertaining, albeit mournful story of love, music and loss.Gerriitsen, of Rizzoli and Isles fame writes in voices that are easily followed and leave little speculation.  Her storyline is straightforward and quickly gets to the point, leading the reader into the horrors of the second World War.  While her ending seems a bit abrupt--there are so many things going on that are rectified in a few short chapters, the overall impact of the story becomes less about the paranormal aspect of the music as originally intended and more about the infinite horrors perpetrated on humanity.  Gerritsen quickly weaves a tale of hope that is smashed by the thriving of power.  Some readers expecting more supernatural effects will most likely be disappointed no matter how poignant Gerritsen's outcome.  In particular her segment about secondary character Laura seems contrived and ill-developed. In fact, instead of focusing on Lorenzo, the historical voice should have been Laura's--the impact of her discovery would have been far more illuminating, adding to rather than truncating the drama.Bottom line?  Tess Gerritsen's "Playing with Fire" will provide a good day's read; her prose flows as does the story.  However, for those intrigued by the cover blurb promising paranormal effects and long ago mysteries, be prepared--all will be resolved but not to your liking. Recommended for historical content.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

The historical story of Cleopatra and her vying for power has graced the pages of literature for centuries.  The life of this last of the Pharaohs is wrought with so much drama--and this without the inclusion of Julius Caesar or Mark Antony.  Cleopatra's play for power and the skirmish between all the Ptolemy siblings is hinted in Emily Holleman's novel, "Cleopatra's Shadows"--a prequel to Ptolemaic struggles to come as Rome intercedes.  Unfortunately, the two first person voices of lesser sisters Berenice (77-55 BC) and Arsinoe (65 or 58-41 BC) in this pre-history lack a vivaciousness that flattens the reader's interest rather than entices it.  At times  the Wikipedia articles about the sisters and other relevant reports regarding Arsinoe's bones are far more exciting.Machinations abound once sister Cleopatra leaves Alexandria; eight-year-old Arsinoe finds herself a virtual prisoner of her older sister Berenice who has crowned herself the new Pharaoh queen. Defying her angry and vengeful mother Trypgaena (the sister of Ptolemy her father), Berenice allows Arsinoe to live; Holleman's depiction of Berenice has her thirsting for autonomy in a world of distrust but doesn't provide enough examples of her fear to allow the reader to commiserate emotionally.Likewise, sister Arsinoe lives with the threat of death over her head yet her technique for survival is less obvious; she uses her mind to craft a subtle and brutal game of chess which serves her well.  Ultimately, one of the sisters will conquer the other and then?  A force from Rome will appear to reclaim power--but that is for a later novel."Cleopatra's Shadows" takes the reader up to the point in this last Egyptian dynasty's history where one of the sisters is executed which leads this reviewer to speculate as to whether or not Holleman will craft another novel or perhaps complete a trilogy that will finally end in Ephesus.As compelling as the history of Cleopatra and her siblings is, Holleman's novel lacks a personal touch that most great historical novels must include.  As I read Arsinoe and Berenice's thoughts, I sadly did not connect with either of them, rendering their machinations a drudgery and their  futures insignificant to me.  While Holleman succeeds in crafting a feel for a reader's ancient Egypt, her inability to capture the souls of the two girls catalogs this novel as ineffective; sadly her usage of modern expletives doesn't quite fit with the time or locale.Bottom line?  "Cleopatra's Shadows" by Emily Holleman tries to be a good first historical novel--perhaps the first in a trilogy of Ptolemaic intrigues.  Unfortunately, the author fails to create characters that are vital enough for the reader to follow faithfully into the her next offerings.  Key features of likeability and empathy are sadly missing.  Not recommended.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

Having read Beatriz Williams' novel "The Secret Life of Violet Grant" and liking only the historical portion of the story, I was prepared to have a similar reaction to "Along the Infinite Sea"--another novel in Williams' Schuyler sisters trilogy.  I did; Williams' insistence to frame her historical story from the perspective of one of her aristocratic 1960s sisters detracts rather than enhances the beauty of her main plot.Pepper Schuyler, like her sibling, Vivian, is vain, spoiled and promiscuous.  After an affair with an unknown Washington senator from a prominent Democratic family--any guesses as to the identity of this political tribe are deliberately left unconfirmed by the author--Pepper finds herself pregnant and forlorn.  In a whirlwind of serendipity she finds herself practically kidnapped by a woman of her mother's era, a famous cellist, Annabelle Dommerich.  It is Annabelle's story, told in the first person, in alternate chapters, that holds the reader's attention--it sparks with love, romance, intrigue, duty, and adventure.  Pepper serves as a foil to a newer age, where women are not quite as cataloged in their roles as adjuncts to their men.Annabelle, with her innocent optimism, details her story with precision, rattling off the names of luxurious places and providing views of lifestyles most readers would deem aristocratic to lend a fairy tale quality to the tale. The reader likes her instantly--wanting her to get her happy ending, rooting for her as the story moves from Monte Carlo to Paris to Berlin and finally to America during the days before the second World War.  Caught between two men, Annabelle must make difficult decisions; she does so with great bravery and always with a gracious panache worthy of a Grace Kelly or Audrey Hepburn.  At times the scenario depicted lacks credibility--but as the plot winds and turns and as Williams' story is a fiction, must be accepted with a few grains of salt that would make a wonderfully exciting film.The ending of Annabelle's story immensely satisfies enough to rate five stars; Pepper's not so much--detracting the overall review by one star.Bottom line?  "Along the Infinite Sea" with the subtraction of the Pepper Schuyler frame is a wonderful story of love and bravery during the years just prior to WW2.  Anyone who enjoys reading a historical novel driven by the love of two--no, three people will surely find this entertaining.  Recommended.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

At first, Helen Phillips' novel, "The Beautiful Bureaucrat" has the feel of the 2002 Steven Shainberg film "Secretary" starring James Spader and Maggie Gyllenhaal where the sterile backdrop of the office space creates the perfect foil for the two lead film characters', ahem, antics.  Relax. "Bureaucrat" is not that kind of story; it borders on another type of universe--a dystopia where paperwork is paramount and drone-like workers juice their bloodshot eyes in order to insure that their rate of processing meets the office standard.  A la Margaret Atwood, Phillips successfully creates a world of drudgery where life is black and white rather than fleshed out in full color. Yet she hints that as in reality, the drones carry out their work, but do not really understand their purpose--they are paid and understanding, "isn't [their] job."In prose that emulates the different people we become during the day depending on the circumstance, alternating from stark to colloquial, befitting our roles,  Phillips thrusts her character Josephine into the Office World where her shuffling of paper couldn't be more boring, her interviewer doesn't even have a face and her boss definitely has bad breath. Yikes--the familiar industrialism of what Phillips creates washes over the reader like a coat of that sour pea soup green paint used in every school cafeteria at one time in every lower school in the country. Other characters, in particular, an odd fortune telling waitress and another bubble gum pink clad office drone with a uber-contrived name--Trishiffany--LOL--populate the rest of the novel's pages giving the reader a sense of god-awful reality that as in real life borders on the ludicrous crafting a sad contradiction.  Yet, horror of horrors!  It's real.Slyly, Phillips couches the reader in little word games and manipulates language--snidely suggesting how thoroughly serious we all take ourselves to be the more we become immersed within a contrived arena--devoting our precious lives to becoming building blocks of what? Terror? Our ultimate demise?  More housing? Soylent Green? She comments about the modern world--her ultimate coup de grace reveals sinister machinations of governments and corporations, that who knows?  may not be too far off the mark.Bottom line?  This slim novel by Helen Phillips reads in only a few hours; Phillips conversational tone helps humanize her character and keeps the pages flying.  Short chapters help with this, too--keeping the feel of the novel short and truncated as mechanical as data entry.  She plays with words in the same way that large powerful entities twist and turn humanitarian themes into profits--all is not what it seems--behind the mundane lies the awful truth . . . "The Beautiful Bureaucrat" would make a chilling dystopian film along the lines of "The Handmaiden's Tale."  Recommended as a clever  urban cautionary tale.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

After reading author Lauren Willig's "That Summer," and enjoying the pace of alternating past and present story lines, I quickly pre-ordered "The Other Daughter" for another good reading experience.  I was not disappointed.  Although Willig's newest offering isn't as scintillating as "Summer," "Daughter" proves to be an adequate summer read.  Utilizing a familiar formula, she includes impersonation, romance and an aristocratic Downton Abbey type family to engender a post-WW1 era tale of a young woman discovering that her middle class family background is nothing but a sham.Lead character and narrator, Rachel represents the typical Willig heroine.  Taking a page out of Victoria Holt's vast body of work, Willig crafts her main girl as a bit prissy, with high expectations and moral guidelines that at times are as tight as a too small girdle. She creates a rift--the wild modern lack of care versus the goody-two-shoes. Like Imogen in "Summer" and Addie in "The Ashford Affair," Rachel, a well-brought up woman with armchair spunk, cannot imagine doing anything vaguely outrageous; her spine is too straight.  And yet, like the others, she unbends; finding herself in a situation where she must improvise in order to get what she wants, Rachel conjures up the imaginary personage of Vera Merton with her co-conspirator Simon, cuts her old-fashioned waist-length hair--shades of "Sabrina" and barges into the high society with a borrowed wardrobe and a dangling cigarette holder.  Her goal? To meet her father, the Earl of Ardmore, whom she thought dead.Like all novels that are fun, the premise immediately engages the reader.  Who can resist a masquerade?  Will she pull it off?  Will her efforts afford her her heart's desire?  Or will that desire change along with the game?Don't get me wrong--"The Other Daughter" most definitely is formulaic.  Nonetheless, it entertains even if from the get-go the reader understands the exact structure along with the function and role of each player.  As in such novels, the ending is predictable and because of this fizzles into anonymity.For those expecting a great mystery--the hidden diary read by two present day sleuths a la "Possession" by A. S. Byatt, look further.  This is a straight storyline told in the flapper era.  The tension is provided through revelation of self-identity rather than from some quirk of history.  Where "That Summer" provided information regarding the Pre-Raphaelite artists which played heavily in the plot outcome, "Daughter" relies only on the "hang-it-all" mentality of the post WW1 generation, tired of war and the death of so many young men--both from a physical and mental standpoint.Like many writers of this genre, the lead characters have no real differences from one book to the next.  The heroines are all feisty and independent even if they are not independent financially.  The love interests are damaged--in need of saving--and the women are willing to give it a try whether or not they succeed. The only difference is the time period--the players play according to the rules of the time but, in essence--they dance to the same tune and all end up with a perfunctory bow and curtsey under the arch of a rainbow.  Those readers in the mood for this, will find Willig an entertaining albeit trite read.Bottom line?  If you are in the mood for romance from a historical perspective, give Lauren Willig's "The Other Daughter" a chance.  The pages will turn even if the ending and the premise is familiar and predictable. Recommended.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

In her first novel, "The Book of Speculation," Erika Swyla pushes the reader into the deep water off the north coast of Long Island and asks how long he/she can hold his/her breath.  While in that state, time stands still and the utter loneliness of waiting underwater takes effect.  Soundless and weightless and yes, somewhat helpless: this exemplifies the mindset of most of Swyla's major characters as they try to make sense of the life fate has dealt them. Like a tidal wave, Swyla presses the reader into a cold world where the undertow dominates with the determination to conquer.  Swyla's strong theme of family underscores the need for love, understanding and connectivity in order to float through it all.Tragedy lingers in the north shore air on eastern Long Island and is embodied by the 18th century house that erosion and disrepair will eventually decimate.  The remaining Watson family--as represented by first person voice Simon--still reverberates with too much loss; he is powerless in terms of money, influence or even willpower to stop the inevitable in its tracks.  But does he really want to be a savior--or is it all too overwhelming for someone as bitter and entrenched in melancholy as he is?When an antiquarian bookseller sends him a tome dating back to the 1700s--a traveling circus journal kept by a man named Peabody--Simon finds hope and inspiration in the information he gleans from within its pages.  He also discovers something sinister about his family--a odd and dire phenomenon that curses its women to die young--drowned in the sea despite their extraordinary ability to stay underwater for ten minutes. His thoughts turn to his sister, a tarot card reader in another traveling circus--and he knows that he must save her from this fate.  In an alternate storyline, the reader becomes privy to Simon's information source as he learns the history of his family and realizes along with him just what he must do to protect his future.Elements of the paranormal abound and for those readers who enjoy divination with tarot cards, the dueling plot lines will definitely intrigue.  However, this reviewer speculates as to whether or not lead character Simon merely needed a jolt to press him into action.  While I do believe that intentions can become reality, I prefer to look at Simon's findings and solution as figurative--real or unreal, they motivate him to change and get out of his funk.  As the title suggests, they are merely speculations that initiate change.Because of this, I found the ending of this novel convenient and not all that fulfilling. Simon manages to subvert disaster while neutralizing malignancy with a fizzle in spite of the climactic natural events.Swyla writes a good first person narrative from the POV of an upset male character.  Her use of language works well; her passages written in the past have a modern feel yet convey another era.Bottom line?  "The Book of Speculation" will entertain on a literary level even if some of the chapters written from the perspective of the past in the third person come across as too convoluted and too divorced from the actual present day story line.  Author Swyla's paranormal elements and quirky sideshow carnival details layer the plot with details that the reader will find amusing to piece together.  After the crescendo of revelation and natural disasters, the ending seems trivial and uninspired even though it most likely is the only logical solution. Keep in mind the title and read with a large grain of salt from the sea.  Recommended for the Long Island ambiance and the whisper of malignancy gathering relevance and force.Diana Faillace Von Behren

"We Never Asked for Wings," the new offering by Vanessa Diffenbaugh of "The Language of Flowers" successfully and enjoyably depicts a coming-of-age story for troubled Letty Espinosa, a 33-year-old single mother living in California with her two children, 15-year-old Alex and his  younger sister Luna.  Letty's mother and father have always acted as surrogate parents for her two children, allowing her the luxury of more mistakes, but when they decide to return to their Mexican homeland, Letty is left with the hazardous responsibility of Alex and Luna.  Barely capable of taking care of herself, she juggles a job as a bartender at the airport with  an errant motherhood that often results in catastrophe.  Along the way, she discovers a new maturity that fits in with her new identity while her son Alex finds love for the first time and breaks some rules and hearts as he desperately tries to hold onto it.As in "Language of Flowers," Diffenbaugh's prose is interesting; she plays with words with a poetic minimalism that works to move the story along while getting her point across. Her dual theme of a mother and son both facing coming of age simultaneously is an interesting take on single, early and unplanned motherhood.  Her depiction of illegal immigrants reaches out to the heart of the matter: men and women trying their darnedest to inject their families with new life and sustenance. Particularly compelling along this line is her portrayal of Carmen, Yesenia's mother--whose love transcends her tiredness on an extremely sympathetic level.Perhaps the last portion of "Wings" glides by like a shanghaied rocket--ricocheting out of control within the realm of the third person narration.  As soon as this reviewer became involved in the everyday lives of these characters, the story catapulted into its crescendo--a little too fast for my liking.  The fact that Letty is caught between two men who have obtained a certain status of identity also does not ring true.  Her character, flawed and selfish, seems an unlikely magnet.Bottom line?  "We Never Asked for Wings" by Vanessa Diffenbaugh is a good second novel for those who enjoyed this author's style in "The Language of Flowers."  Her plot and narrative immerse the reader into the unfamiliar world of the illegal immigrant; I, for one, would have liked more of a segue into the rushed ending. RecommendedDiana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

In this second Maisie Dobbs mystery, author Jacqueline Winspear sends her protagonist, the intrepid Maisie Dobbs, investigator and psychologist, into a world where she has little personal experience--that of a coterie of rich finishing school students.  The daughter of a grocery store magnate has gone missing and Maisie is set on the girl's trail, investigating her family background and affiliations to determine the girl's mindset and to discover her probably whereabouts.  What she discovers creates a nuanced backdrop of London after WW1 where the population still mourns an entire generation of men lost on the battlefields of France.The episodic story enables Winspear to expand her character's development and to facilitate healing from the perspective of understanding her own loss during the war and the impact that it has on her current life. Secondary characters Billy Beal, Frankie Dobbs, Inspector Stratton, Maurice Blanchard, Lady Rohan and a new character, Andrew Deen impress the reader with their quirky personalities and the balance they add to the mix.  Maisie's meditative technique helps her to fit into the shoes of her clients; her persistence and earnestness earns her likeability.  As Maisie moves out of the fog of WW1, she gains insight into herself that the reader understands will eventually  help her love anew and find added purpose with each new adventure.Winspear has a wonderful way of allowing the reader a glimpse into a different time period; she details dress with fine precision and spends much time describing the cars, accents and entertainments that filled 1920s life, rendering a three-dimensional portrait of the era.Bottom line?  This second installment in the Maisie Dobbs series is just the thing for any one-time reader of Nancy Drew, Trixie Belden or any of the serial detectives so popular with aspiring detectives during youth.  The character of Maisie Dobbs is all of these intrepid girl sleuths grown into maturity with the added benefit of immersing the reader into the lend of the Roaring 20s. Recommended.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

"Thirteen Chairs" by Dave Shelton, written for the 12 and up age bracket, might have some trouble keeping its intended audience properly spooked. With the influx of film and, in particular, television shows, the impact of "Thirteen Chairs" in terms of an actual quantifiable  horror or fright fright factor will most likely wane in the light of these other more visual mediums.Shelton's premise is reminiscent of an old 60's horror film, where thirteen people sit around in the shadows of an old haunted house and spout out their stories--one more gruesomely horrible than the next--a sort of Addams Family camp out indoors, definitely without the marshmallows and the fire.  The vantage point is Jack's--described as a curious boy--he is the last of the party to be seated.  The pale Mr. Osterley acts as the leader of the group, selecting participants in an order all his own to relate their particular ghost story.  Jack listens to each of the tales and awaits his own turn, which, of course, occurs last, as the thirteenth.Each participant has their own voice--there are adults and children who weave their stories and after each are finished with the telling, they seemingly disappear into the shadows.Each story stands on its own as a representation of the horror genre; they all are framed by the interchange of Mr. Osterley and the other guests, along with Jack's overall impressions.  As the time draw near for Jack to recant his tale, the reader begins to realize that some sort of reveal will occur. Unfortunately, the impact of this reveal is dulled by the reader's immunity to an overplayed genre.None of the stories are particularly memorable--in fact, this reviewer can't really remember one of them that stands out or is worthy of retelling.  Sadly, Shelton doesn't (excuse the pun) flesh out his characters enough to make them tantalizing--Mr Osterley is no Vincent Price and Jack is no Cole Sear  (The Sixth Sense (Collector's Edition Series)). The creepy factor that crawls the skin is missing.Technically, the tales are all well-written with the younger audience in mind, but they lack the allure and fascination of horror icon Edgar Allen Poe--young readers can't do better than that as an introduction into the genre--the incessant pounding emotion of The Black Cat cannot be replicated.Bottom line?  "Thirteen Chairs" by Dave Shelton isn't that scary; young readers wanting to chill their blood best read old Edgar The Terrifying Tales by Edgar Allan Poe: Tell Tale Heart; The Cask of the Amontillado; The Masque of the Red Death; The Fall of the House of Usher; The ... Purloined Letter; The Pit and the Pendulum to get a taste of the horror genre at its best.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

The mere fact that "Just Go Girl Athletic Leak Pads' exist make me feel better.  I guess that's a bit silly, but at times I feel as if I am the only human being on the planet experiencing this extremely uncomfortable phenomenon when I exercise.Be aware as one reviewer has pointed out that these pads are made in China and this may be of concern to some potential users.  As far as I am concerned, I feel that removing the pad once your exercise is done is the ticket to good hygiene.  Sweaty plus leakage is not a good thing to have near your body whether its contained on a pad or not.  After two hours of exercise, this pad (any pad) has to go.Just Go Girl Athletic Leak (cool name) pads have a thong-like shape that keeps the bulk factor down.  If you are wearing leotards, running shorts or bicycle shorts, no one wants to see your personal business and with this pad, they will not.  Once the pad is in place, the user feels comfortable without getting that diaper feeling.  (Ugh!)For a ten-count package, however, at approximately $9, these are a little steep, price-wise.Thankfully, these pads are unscented.  I do not think I would even try them if they included one of those floral or clean laundry scents--that would make me fear an allergic reaction.Bottom line?  Tapered design, not bulky, unscented.  They do the job. RecommendedDiana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

In the wake of the hundred year anniversary of the Great War, author Jennifer Robson delivers a novel whose tone and style depicts the era and the sensibilities.Main character Lily is the daughter of an earl; her love interest is her brother's best friend from university, the Scots surgeon Robbie Frasier.  She remembers him from her childhood as being kind; his memory depicts her in pigtails.  When they meet up again, Lily is twenty, a sparkling pretty woman that strives to have more of a purpose in a world about to become unhinged by war.  Impressed, Robbie encourages her.Opposition comes from parents anchored by tradition and the time's prejudices.  Nonetheless, Lily plugs on, intent on being useful in the war she knows will come.Robson's voice befits a young woman of aristocratic breeding; her dealings with the WAC places her in situations with others not of her class, yet she does so with great patience and a dogged perseverance.  As the romance between Robbie and Lily develops, the author does resort to a describing their encounter in all its quivering awakening.  If there is one complaint this reviewer has it would be the almost too gentle and too complacent character of Lily--her desire to help puts her in the ranks of a Mother Theresa from the very start.  Yes, Robson does describe her sickening at some of the things she sees, but the fact that she remains so levelheaded and sweetly cheerful after such a drastic change of life seems a bit A Little Princess to me--some complaining and gnashing of teeth would have made this character a bit more realistic.Nonetheless the story is sweet and has a pleasant if not overly done ending.  I listened to the audiobook performance of this novel from iTunes(at $5.99 unabridged, I could not resist)--the reader has a cultured voice that befits the character--her Scots burr gives Robbie some needed nuance.Bottom line? "Somewhere in France" is a tribute to the men and women who worked frustratingly against horrendous circumstances during WWI.  The story of Lily and her Robbie a bit pedestrian other than in its ability to reflect the feel of the time.  I doubt I will be exploring this author's sequel After the War Is Over: A Novel that concentrates on this novel's secondary characters.  Recommended for those who like a straightforward story of love during war and duty.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

Judith Fertig's "The Cake Therapist" presents a feisty heroine with a penchant for baking and the paranormal talent to sense just what flavors her clients need to round out their lives (a la The Mistress of Spices: A Novel). Fertig uses her real time experience in the culinary world to enhance her enticing descriptions of flavor combinations and baking tricks of the trade while allowing the reader a glimpse into the mindset of a woman who employs flavor  as paints on her personal palette to describe, color and interpret her day.Although the story moves along quite nicely, this reviewer would have liked a bit more play with the main character and her ability with the flavors rather than the in depth history behind a mystery involving some of the Rainbow Bakery's neighbors.  The premise of a flavor detective wielding her talent to ferret out otherwise deeply hidden secrets like a psychic helping the police find missing children hints that perhaps Fertig is crafting a series where her baker heroine will solve other neighborhood cases while piecing together her own future in a larger story that will span the length of the series--the usual episodic puzzles interspersed with the main character's slow growth over a larger arc of time.Unfortunately, in this offering, Fertig interrupts the intimacy of her main characters first person voice to shift in time (and a third person voice) where she jumps from 1908 to 1932 etc to depict a bit of Queen City history that took place in the area where the Rainbow Bakery currently stands. This back story hits the reader with a question mark until he/she becomes accustomed to the fact that it will continue at the end of each chapter, even though it is not nearly as interesting as the larger present day story of the bakery, its owner and employees--even if there is a tie-in to an engagement ring that one of the client brides is wearing.Instead of immediately backtracking into old stories and hidden mysteries, Fertig would have been better off allowing her main character to introduce herself more thoroughly.  As a runaway from a marriage gone awry, Neeley O'Neil returns home to Queen City, Ohio to sort out her life amidst the chaos of butter, sugar, flour and the beat of power mixers to open up her dream bakery, specializing in special event cakes to compliment the town's bridal district.Fertig begins with luscious chapter headings like January "Dark Chocolate. Rich Coffee"and then explains that it suggests the idea of "starting over" with a "take-charge" air.  She instills an instant pique of interest.  When February comes along, the flavor changes and somewhere in the chapter we understand why this flavor and its connotation (Fertig employs the Chinese medicine ideas of sweet, bitter, salty, pungent and sour to express emotions) are relevant to the storyline.  In March the flavor changes again, but somehow the mystery has taken center stage while Neeley and her problems have become less stressed--almost resolved and just begging for the simple closure of the spoken word or a letter. The flavors fade into an overly sweet Hallmark Channel-type mystery show. Disappointing.Along that line, Fertig abandons characters that she introduces early on:  what happens to Gavin? Will he reappear in the next Cake Therapist novel? The mystery revolving around the past starring Shemeul, Olive and Edie becomes overpowering, pushing aside the quirky fun of the bakery with its fun mix of personalities.  Instead the reader is forced to focus on Mrs. Amici and her nutty daughter--both of whom are almost schtick-y, straight out of an episode of "Murder, She Wrote." Fertig is presumptuous in her assumption that she will be popular enough to write an arc large enough to fit in all the characters she has introduced and give them all a main story line in a separate novel--shades of Cedar Cove.Bottom line?  "The Cake Therapist" will appeal to all those readers who love to read culinary fix-it novels like The Mistress of Spices: A Novel or How to Eat a Cupcake: A Novel.  However, be prepared for author Fertig's inclusion of a mystery that makes this novel seem episodic, as if there will be more to come featuring other neighborhood mysteries that need solving all centering around her fictive "Rainbow Bakery" and her detective's interesting talent.  The main character seems to solve her own problems too quickly in this introductory offering.  I would have rather delved into the Cake Therapist herself, rather than have her introduce her first solved mystery.  Not sure if I will read another one if my hunch is correct and a series is launched.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"She titles the chapters and then foregoes

Don't get me wrong, "Letters from Skye" by Jessica Brockmole is a charming novel of love and loss during the two World Wars. However, as I've been planning--at least in my mind--a visit to the Highlands, I expected "Skye" as in the Isle of Skye to be more present in this offering.  Some rudimentary descriptions tell us of fog and fishermen, but I anticipated feeling the lengthy walks over hilly terrain in all of my muscles; I wanted to feel the chill, smell the peat, see spectacular lights in the sky as well as languish over sunrises and sunsets.  I wanted to meet the characters who live around the main character, Elspeth; I wanted to revel in their lifestyles and their eccentricities. Perhaps the blame lies in Brockmole's choice to write her story in an epistolary format. I imagine it to be more difficult for a writer to attach a strong sense of place without adding a lot of redundant descriptions--comments about the sea and sky that to the letter writer and reader who have already shared a referenced event would come across as false or overblown--within the medium of only letters. In this regard, Brockmole should have either named her novel something else--something more generic--like "Letters from the Great War" or "Letters from a Poet in Love"--or told a straightforward story in a third or first person voice.  In The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society, Barrows has little trouble crafting her Guernsey residents through the medium of letters and she writes a love story that manages to break through the reserve of a reader, reading another person's private correspondence.  "Skye" gives me no sense of place or time--her characters could live anywhere at any time; there is little difference between the American, David and Elspeth's mother--a woman of an older generation who has lived on Skye for her entire life--where is her burr, her Scots expressions?  Perhaps, I have been overindulging on Outlander: Season One - Volume One, but I expect to feel transported to another place when the name of a beautiful location is in the title.That's the trouble with expectations--disappointment is sure to follow. Brockmole's premise is sure and sweet:  two people meet through letters.  David writes to Elspeth initially through her publisher; he is a fan of her poetry which has been published.  Elspeth, a young married woman, writes back and their letters span the Great War.  In alternate chapters, Elspeth's daughter Margaret writes to her love interest, Paul, from the perspective of their romance and separation during the second World War.  Between the two voices, the reader understands that that war is a dank grey umbrella that severs and destroys dreams with its uncertainty.  Immediately, the reader knows that Elspeth and David did not have their happy ending and now Margaret is on the trail to find out why.Yet even more is missing--the letters span the period between 1912 to 1917.  Where is the sense and language of that time?  If Elspeth speaks Gaelic, then by all means, allow her voice to come through. Brockmore's sensibilities are too contemporary and they are telltale in her letters.  (There is a glaring out-of-time error in the novel and darn, if I can't remember it!)Sounds like the premise itself would make a lovely Hallmark movie--the mists rolling off hills as Elspeth walks to the post would delight and provide atmospheric tension.
