Fast-forward to London during WW2 with the Blitzkrieg on at full blast . . . dark scenes in trenches with ambulance drivers rushing along France . . . lyrical music playing an emotional theme song.  Now that wouldn't that work better?The last two pages drew a tear--Brockmole did not write that part as a letter and immediately, the reader is drawn in--in a far better more intimate manner that such a dramatic story of loss and love deserves.Bottom line?  "Letters from Skye" is a generic story that would work better as either a screenplay or a third-person or first-person POV, rather than an epistolary novel.  Author Jessica Brockmole's idea is lovely, but it needs the oomph of characterization, scenery, and tone to drive its drama to the point of melodrama.  Brockmole's letters do not nearly convey the emotion and depth of such events.  And Skye?  Its sadly missing. For an emotional read, try Letters to the Lost--there are letters there that will reach across the boundary of time.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

Wllen Marie Wiseman's "What She Left Behind" features a parallel story of two young women facing loss.  For Clara in the late 1920s, loss is bound to betrayal--the betrayal of her parents who incarcerate her in a mental asylum merely because she falls in love with an Italian immigrant and refuses to marry the man her mother and father chose for her.  For Izzy, in 1990-something, loss means being put in the foster system after her mother kills her father in cold blood with a revolver, cutting herself to anesthetize the emotional pain and dealing with being the new kid in her senior high school.  Wiseman succeeds in creating a story of alternate chapters that eventually bring these two characters together in a cathartic moment of healing that is life-changing for them both.This reviewer enjoyed Izzy's portion of the novel much more so than Clara's.  The sorrow of Clara's life as a prisoner, thought to be insane and treated as such is palpable; Wiseman's descriptions of patients, treatments, doctors and nurses chill the blood with the lack of compassion and misunderstanding prevalent for that time period in dealing with the mentally ill.  Although emotionally most of this is redeemed in the novel's last few chapters with a happy ending, I found myself skipping over many of the gruesome details.  Wiseman's victim Clara is too sad to be enjoyable.As a seventeen year old, Izzy technically is a young adult and while some reviewers may find her story more acceptable as a YA offering, I enjoyed Wiseman's perspective, even if the intensity in some of the scenarios could be defined as unrealistic.  The bullying she describes puts the reader into Izzy's shoes and allows him/her to feel her insecurity.  Her teenaged characters are much better shaped then the character of foster parent Peg and her husband--although I might attribute my inability to engage with these two due to the voice given to them by the performer of the audio book version of the novel.  Realistic or not, the scenes starring Izzy are fraught with emotion and drama that eventually brings her to a good place, allowing the reader a long exhalation of breath after so much angst.The audio book's reader does an good job of performing both Clara and Izzy's roles.Bottom line?  "What She Left Behind" will not appeal to all readers.  Half the book is set inside an insane asylum during the 30s and 40s.  The other half relates to the strength a young teenager builds within herself as she researches the sad life of the asylum inmate and struggles to understand the tragedy of her own family.  A pleasant ending makes all the suffering worthwhile for the most part.  Some contrived circumstances may have some readers rolling their eyes. This book was recommended to me after having read three novels with a ghost theme--this book is definitely not in that genre, so keep that in mind if a similar recommendation is made . . .Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

"The Idea of Love" by Patti Callahan Henry delivers exactly what one would imagine from such a title: a love story that plays with what love means to different people.  Henry explores her "idea of love" with a simple, sincere story line set in a quintessential town in the lowlands of South Carolina.  You know the place:  lace curtains stirring in breezes from off the coast, wooden rocking chairs still in motion on the porch of a clapboard house painted in a Charleston pastel and cicadas chirping in a never-ending background symphony.  While Henry does rely on the backdrop to allow her characters to dream away with much romantic license, the story works--it draws you into the scene, allows you to anticipate what you know will happen and enjoy the moments that get you there.Nonetheless, "Idea" does have some faults.  Henry does a better job of fleshing out main character Blake Hunter as a man on a mission to save his reputation and remain in an industry that he loves with full marks. However, even with Blake, Henry waxes a bit too lyrical about him and his uncontrollable feelings, reminding us that, indeed, this is a novel constructed of fictional people--even though I wanted to fully immerse myself and believe, at least for a while, that they were real.While she does manage to recreate the confusion obviously surging within Ella Flynn's soul, she fails to fully craft a character that is all that likeable. She elicits only sympathy.  Poor Ella; she doesn't deserve that--but then after getting into Ella's mindset, the reader begins to understand why she is in the pickle she is in.  As she gathers strength, pity turns to semi-interest, but somehow this isn't quite enough.  Ella does transform as any good character should, but this reviewer only got a hazy view of her.That being said, "Idea" hits the bull's eye when it comes to the category, "Novels that Should be Turned into RomComs."  Blake Hunter, as a screenwriter sees Reese Witherspoon as the lead of his fictive account of his days in South Carolina.  Hands down, a good choice!  Witherspoon has just the spunk needed to inject Ella with a more winsome exterior--not all that reliant on soft looks.  And maybe a Hugh Jackman-type as Blake and Bradley Cooper as Sims . . . what fun!  I leave the choice of the secondary characters to other readers who see this book as potentially a box-office hit as a screenplay!  Maybe Sandrine Holt from the A&E remake of "The Returned" as Betsy . . . sorry. couldn't help myself! . . . Margaret Colin as Margo?There are moments in the novel that are just too ridiculously convenient--the Margo and the dress scenario?  The Vogue challenge? Trite. Not enough of a lead-in--Margo should be struggling with that from Day One.  Reese, oops, I mean, Ella should be scratching away on her sketches because of the challenge . . .Rent-A-Runway?  I don't think so . . . Ella should have her own style that she sews up and embellishes herself.Some deeply psychological issues are handled in moments where suddenly the characters take a deep breath and ahhhh!  All is better.  Perhaps there is something in this simplicity--the journey starts with a single footstep and all that. Such poster messages are appealing in such a book.  Nevertheless, Henry has a predilection to overdo this.For those who do not like name-dropping, there is a bit of this in "Idea."  ET is given a plug as well as the Kardashians and few other current headliners.  Unfortunately, this appeals to those who need such associations; for those who don't the novel becomes sillier rather than more realistic--I prefer a more classic take where there is a modern setting without all the references that pinpoint the year. With that said, I could have done without the last chapter.Bottom line? "The Idea of Love" is a fun novel that draws you into the sad situation of main character Ella Flynn--a woman with dreams but no anchor.  Enter the anchor: failing screenwriter, Blake Hunter.  Lies abound in a typical but enjoyable romantic comedy romp with great secondary characters.  Recommended for a fast 2-day read.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

Lincoln Child's enigmalogist, Jeremy Logan, stars in this chilling compact offering "The Forgotten Room" by returning to a think tank called "Lux" off the coast of Newport, Rhode Island where he attempted once to promote his paranormal brand of science.  Requested by the director of the prestigious organization, Logan must manage difficult personalities of some of America's premier scientists while discovering the reasons behind a mild-mannered colleague committed a horrendously brutal act of suicide.Child's style is quick-paced; his chapters barely contain five or six pages each.  He employs a straight-forward third person voice that at times varies to allow the reader a glimpse at some of the secondary players.  Nonetheless, the focus is Logan and his find of a "forgotten room" in the old multi-winged building that houses the organization and just may be the cause of some of its members unexplained psychotic episodes.  In his usual manner, Child marries the paranormal to science in an exciting page-turner that will entertain the reader for about 24 hours.Logan is an interesting character that deserves more of a back story as well as a new adventures. Most of Child's readers who follow the author's Pendergast series written with co-author Preston will just expect some retrospective in the future.  The plot of "The Forgotten Room"is a lot more entertaining than the rather dismal The Third Gate, featuring the same character in a forgettable adventure that tries too hard to be Stargate.TFR is made smaller and more intense by the limited venue--the action barely leaves the Lux headquarters.  The ploy of a hurricane at the end of the novel is used to up the dramatic effect of the climax with the usual lack of electricity and wailing winds.  The science behind the adventure makes up for some of this.Bottom line?  "The Forgotten Room" is a quick read with more appeal than Child's other Jeremy Logan novel, "The Third Gate."  Expect a fast-paced adventure that can be read in a few hours and most likely you will be somewhat entertained.  Recommended as a fast entertainment.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

Sorrow and disappointment pulse through all of M. J. Rose's heroines; in "The Witch of Painted Sorrows," the first installment in Rose's  "Daughters of La Lune" series, first person narrator Sandrine Verlaine is no exception.  Grieving for the death of her father and receiving no sympathy from her brute of a husband, Sandrine flees from her home in New York to the Paris of the Belle Epoque.  Her grandmother, the fiery red-headed courtesan of the demimonde, embraces her with open arms, providing a sanctuary where Sandrine can recover and pull the pieces of her life back together.  With almost no experience in the art of love, Sandrine finds little to relate her life of strangled pleasures to that of her grandmother's lusty experiences--that is until she becomes fascinated with the Maison de la Lune, a house wreathed in the history of her family and recently closed for some unknown reason by her taciturn grandmother.Rose explores Sandrine's hungry desire for identity in the same way that she depicts the angst of her character Jac L'Etoile in The Book of Lost Fragrances: A Novel of Suspense, Seduction: A Novel of Suspense and The Collector of Dying Breaths: A Novel of Suspense who is plagued by dreams and images of reincarnation until she finds her ultimate happiness.  Perhaps, Rose's theory consists of a simple premise:  humans are tortured by thoughts of the unknowable until they find an all-consuming purpose.  With such purpose, the need to squelch melancholy and thoughts of death and sadness are forgotten--an immunity is created.  The darkness, the sadness as represented and evoked by La Lune cannot take hold.  Like Jac L'Etoile, Sandrine becomes prey to the sad strength of La Lune, an ancestor of the Verlaine family who suffered greatly.With that in mind, the tone of "Witch" replicates the tone of Rose's other novels--the sadness permeates the reader with its sense of loss and its desperate need for vanquishing in a way that may not be appealing to many readers.  Those expecting a joyful, triumphant resolution, realize beforehand that as the first in a new series, this novel acts as an introduction to installments of cautionary tales. After the novel's conclusion, Rose provides an excerpt to "The Jeweler of Stolen Dreams" which, although not labeled as the second book in the series, most likely is, as it begins in Paris in 1918.Rose's first person voice is fraught with the same mixture of innocence and pressing motivation as her characters from her other novels.  She relies upon the intimacy of this voice to compensate for a lack of excessive detail that would bring the Belle Epoque to life from the perspective of a historical novel.  Instead she envelopes the reader in the events of the narrator's life as they occur, describing events and places as Sandrine experiences them rather than constantly remind the reader that the novel takes place in another era where sensibilities, styles and protocols were much different.  It works.Nevertheless, there is a deadness to the character that fails to make her likeable; as I tumbled towards the last page of "Witch," I wasn't necessarily rooting for Sandrine.  Perhaps, I had already realized that she was the introductory vessel for an entity that would make its appearance known in the other La Lune novels.  Even Sandrine's engagement in lustful acts with the lover of her dreams does not succeed on the level that one would expect; something is missing but, these only detract a little juice to the story which is, otherwise, an entertaining albeit melancholy read.Bottom line?  In "The Witch of Painted Sorrows," M. J. Rose returns to what she is best known for--a novel of human longing, disappointment and a turning to the occult to find answers to staunch the pain.  Good read.  Recommended.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

Hermoine Eyre's "Viper Wine" engenders two diametrically opposed reactions from me.  On one level, it depicts its heroine, the 17th century beauty Venetia Stanley from the perspective of the aging beauty whose worst fear has been realized--her diminishing looks have resulted in a disintegrating power that causes her to be the butt of sarcastic jokes; it disallows  her the ability to garner attention with the same  cuteness quota that worked so well when she was much younger than her 30-something years.  In this regard Eyre succeeds, illustrating the lengths one woman is willing to take in order to "restore" her youthful beauty; she cleverly parallels Venetia's slights, doubts and resolutions to modern day models, actresses and celebrities that will and do resort to treatments that allow them to still participate in all the activities that keep them in the spotlight and while claiming the title "beauty." Eyre proves that despite an egalitarian revolution of the genders, good looks still count--so nothing has changed very much no matter how far things seem to have progressed.However, where Eyre more than emphasizes her point about beauty and its superficiality, she struggles somewhat with her other main character's perspective--Kenelm Digby, Venetia's husband, wants nothing more than for his wife to realize that at any age, she is beautiful in his eyes.  As an apothecary and dabbler in the hermetic arts, Kenelm could, if he so wishes, concoct a bit of "viper wine" that would ease away his wife's wrinkles with the 17th century effectiveness of Botox, but he stands firm in his opinion that aging is inevitable even for the era's great beauties.  Besides, his mind is filled with his inventiveness--he freely floats through time whenever the notion takes him to explore such modern concepts as quantum particles and nanobiotechnology--when he isn't encumbered by the fact that his father was tried and hung as a traitor to the Crown.  For the reader, it is this paranormal ability of Kenelm's that muddles the plot--creating a labyrinth of ideas and thinking that stall the story instead of endowing it with the intended added dimension.As Eyre's story progresses and Venetia resorts to the most dire beauty aids, her ability to think rationally deteriorates as her reliance on the witch doctor who assembles her potions becomes more addictive.  Eyre's comments on the pursuit of beauty at all costs transcends the 17th century in the same way that her character Kenelm avoids the limitations of the science of his time.  Nonetheless, as interesting as her thoughts are on the subject of beauty, vanity and other absolutes, the overall presentation detracts from the strength of the premise; the reader gets lost within the labyrinth of too much cleverness, opting to get more rapidly and straightforwardly to the point.Bottom line?  Hermoine Eyre's "Viper Wine" points out that beauty treatments in the form of Botox or surgery may result in a younger version of a generic human being, but don't necessarily ever replicate the youth an individual once had; it may erase the etched lines and expressions of experience time and age have rendered, leaving that face devoid of character and life. The result is always disappointing--a pathetic substitution for health and well-being--and in the case of Venetia Stanley hastens her demise after destroying her mental state.  Eyre gathers her 17th century characters to deliver this message with great success, but muddles the effect with too much paranormal activity and time leaping to keep the reader within a range of reason that doesn't compete with the story's main thrust.  Not Recommended.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

With all the speculation and frightening happenstances at fictional Lyle College, the reader of "The Sixes" by Kate White cannot help but eventually ask why the protagonist, Phoebe Hall, continues on with her snooping when her background includes a harrowing experience with bullies and her life is jeopardized by similar oppressors of a newer fiercer generation privy to tools more technically competent in ruining lives.The premise, that a non-fiction writer specializing in celebrity dirt who has been accused of plagiarism is hiding away in a north-east college as a substitute writing instructor until she rethinks her career, starts the ball rolling immediately for the reader to trust in the author's ability to suspend disbelief.  Of course, she is "connected;" her best friend from boarding school--the scene of her personal bullying experience--as dean of students gets her the job and acts as not only her confidante throughout the tale, but the person who assigns her the muck-racking task of looking into the disappearance of a young co-ed who might be on the roster of a secret girls' society bent on ensuring that their members take their female empowerment seriously.As a character, Phoebe is dogged and relentless, not at all cowed by a miserable experience from school that threatened her life and sourced all sorts of unimaginable nightmares.  That in itself seems incredible.  Of course, as readers, we are not privy to the specifics of her experience until much later on in the telling of the story.  By that time, the amount of frightening adventures that revolve off of her investigation of the sixes churn her stomach, cause waves of terror to climb up her spine, punch her in the gut, make her nauseous and all manner of other cliche phrases to get across the idea that she is indeed in dire jeopardy.  The adrenaline rush this woman gets on a daily basis is enough to leave her muscles wobbly--and yet she persists . . .The story itself is interesting and as I listened to this in an unabridged audio format for a number of hours, it did entertain with its conspiracy theory ideas and  sinister people lurking in the dark at every turn in Phoebe's investigation. The insult to the reader, if one can call it that, is the expectation that the reader will buy into several premises that in a more realistic world would never make sense.  But, then again, this is fiction that reads like a beach thriller, so what can one expect?Bottom line?  "The Sixes" by Kate White is a suspense thriller that will engage the reader who does not expect too much realism.  The action takes place on a small college campus; the focus on over-amped feminism and the collateral damage of bullying and peer pressure.  Implausible at times, it drags on to reveal the brains behind the operation that the reader guessed from the start.  Recommended as a good audio book that entertains during exercise.  Overlook the trite emotional explosions of the main character.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

Scott Mariani's Ben Hope series has been likened to "Dan Brown on steroids."  I, for one, am not sure about that comparison.  The connection between letters and secrets from history's past and running around Europe trying to discover answers to modern terrorist activity--killings, kidnappings etc. may remind the reader of the Dan Brown school of fast-reading travelogue literature, but that is where the parallel ends.  Not that Professor Robert Langdon (The Da Vinci Code, Inferno (Robert Langdon) and Angels & Demons: A Novel (Robert Langdon)) is a more finely drawn character than "The Mozart Conspiracy's" main character, Major Ben Hope--he's not--but the storyline and its conspiracies and establishments are better rectified.  Mariani writes of a troubled hero with a past who fights as a professional avenging angel to protect innocents who get caught in the crossfire of powerful men who crave influence.  The so-called conspiracy of the title of this offering, the second in the Ben Hope series, revolves around Mozart's death, a letter written by the composer before he dies and the lengths present day fanatics go to maintain the status quo of their clandestine organizations.I listened to the audio presentation of this book--performed adequately by Steven Crossley. I believe that listening to this type of story makes the narrative more believable as I don't have the option of skipping over chase or fight scenes that become predictable.  Listening forces me to hear the entire novel.  Upon purchasing this audio book, I did not realize that "The Mozart Conspiracy" was part of a series.  However, when the plot line went into overdrive after the climatic scene where a helicopter explodes and Hope saves the day within an inch of his life, I found it difficult to understand why I still had another hour of the book left before it concluded.  "Mozart" would have been a more likeable story if that last hour of the presentation was eliminated--its overdone, unnecessary and would have made a better beginning for the next novel than the superfluous conclusion of this one. I say let the poor hero have at least a hiatus between books where he and his beloved can enjoy one another without the inquisitive eye of the reader trained upon them. As I listened, I realized that this extra ending was an annoying set up where an episodic series starring the woebegone main character and his primary motivation for his vendetta lifestyle was being baptized and launched into the arena of conspiracy theory criminals. Come, come, Mr. Mariani even that does not make that extra hour palatable. Give your hero his due.I imagine that the author intends to develop Ben Hope over time--feed him different tidbits of women--maybe Eve will continually crop up like 007's favorite Bond girl-- and keep the adventures somewhat historical in nature to appeal to that Dan Brown audience that he is targeting.  Seems to have worked for him so far as there are already nine Ben Hope thrillers on the market! I don't think I will be reading another, unless it is offered as this one was on iTunes for $5.99 in an unabridged format:)Bottom line? Undeveloped characters and a choppy conspiracy theory backbones this thriller that really should end about an hour before its conclusion.  Recommended only for those who have read every other formula thriller out there.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

When I opened the box of the Instyler Tulip Auto Curler, I must admit that I was skeptical--especially after I saw the cardboard Tulip device that is meant to act as a guide for the maximum hair thickness to be curled at one time.  My hair is thick and its layered--so I figured that coaxing my wavy hair into curls with this device was going to take a longgggg while.I was wrong. Make sure you take out some time to learn how to operate the machine.  My learning time was kicked off with Bunny's review on YouTube--she tests out the Curler in front of her mirror and her comments will help guide you when you try out the Curler for the first time. Its a little awkward at first, the biggest challenge for me was dividing my very layered hair into individual strands of one length that would fit into the machine.  I made sure, after reading some of the disaster tangles on this site, that I used the cardboard thickness measure.  The next challenge was getting the device in the correct position to insure that my hair went in it in the proper way.  Doing this in front of a mirror, is not easy.  I find that once I oriented the machine to face me in the mirror, if I separate the hair and pull it down, sliding it into the slot in the device is easier to accomplish.  A press of the button winds the hair into the heating section and a series of slow beeps tells you that the hair is being curled.  A faster succession of beeps indicates that its time to slide the curler down--and out the comes the curl.Because my hair is layered, I do not think I will try this on the top part of my head--its just too short--but, I will use this to touch up the bottom and sides of my hair--the results were a far neater hair style, which I liked.  Using the curler was successful; I experienced no tangles and no burning--just uniform curls.  Nice.Bottom line:  The Instyle Tulip Auto Curler worked well on my layered hair.  I can only think that it would work very well on hair of one length.  If you take some time to figure the machine out, watch a few Youtube videos, you will quickly catch on to the operation of it while looking in a mirror to style.  Great for a finishing touch for me--like all curling devices using heat, I would not use everyday as it will probably dry out the hair.  Recommended.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye Reviews"

Starting a novel series from the last book in the sequence may seem like an odd beginning.  Nonetheless, Jacqueline Windspear's "A Dangerous Place," the eleventh in the Maisie Dobbs series stands on its own as a woman-in-crisis novel--where the crisis is one of the heart--a very dangerous place, indeed.Main character Maisie's whole world is upended.  Personal tragedy has struck her deeply--so deeply she needs a hiatus to make sense of the world again.  Instead of returning to the UK as her loving family wishes, Maisie detours to Gibraltar where almost instantly she finds herself embroiled in a mystery surrounding the death of a photographer.Windspear tells her tail of pre-WW2 Europe with a subtle style.  Employing a third person perspective, she manages to allow the reader to see inside Maisie's soul as she slowly heals without tiresome hysterics.  Maisie, as a character, possesses great strength and Windspear tells her true, allowing a hairline crack in her public facade to widen slowly to reveal the underlying emotions with sympathetic understanding.As Maisie undertakes the solving of the photographer's death, her calculus of thought provides a gradual solution to her own funk and by the end of the novel, the reader and Maisie both have subtly changed through the experience.  Windspear deserves praise for her intricate weaving of the actual mystery adventure with the mystery of Maisie's heart.She also does a fine job of creating 1930s Gibraltar where planes of many nations fly overhead and boats travel under the cover of night to the troubled landscape of Spain.  The reader feels the threat with the same impact as the characters.Bottom line?  This eleventh novel in the Maisie Dobbs series allows the reader to stand vigil with the main character as she emerges from personal tragedy.  Having never read the other novels in the series, I was impressed with the author's ability to create a stalwart woman who handles herself very well in the face of danger.  Recommended for its sincerity, depiction of Europe before WW2, its engaging language and plot.Diana Faillace Von BehrenBuzzard's Eye View

Pick up Jane Heller's "An Ex to Grind" when you are in the mood for a fun, predictable story along the lines of a made-for-TV movie on Lifetime. As soon as the first person voice of main character Melanie Banks begins her diatribe about women in the workplace and their effect on the aims of men, I could actually hear this as a voice-over opening scene--where investor Melanie struts through her office in a chic business suit wearing a livid expression on her face because she has just witnessed yet another of her ex-husband's extravagant purchases using her hard-earned alimony allowance.Melanie's character is frank, bordering on a little too much self-deprecation that doesn't seem to jive with her chosen career.  In fact, for a woman so driven that her husband accuses her of work-a-holism, her mind can't seem to get off the track of having to fork over half of her salary.  For me, that made the premise a little unrealistic.However, that is exactly the reason I purchased the audio recording of this novel--Melanie's voice is reminiscent of a friend unloading her deepest secrets and her less than stellar moments infused with probably more humor than actuality as in any good retelling of a story beginning with "You'll never guess what happened to me. . . "The first half of the novel entertains a lot more than its second half.  Unfortunately, this is when the author must tie up all the loose ends and actually keep the story real without being too predictable.  Does it work?  That depends.  Melanie is a madcap heroine--cut from the clothe of Katherine Hepburn in Bringing Up Baby--or Rosalind Russell in "His Girl Friday."  Those characters do some crazy things to get what they want with the old adage, "All's Fair in Love and War" at the top of their list of Words-to-Live-By.  In this same respect, Melanie, does some despicable things--but that doesn't take away from the fun of the book.  So what if she doesn't have the moral compass of a Girl Scout or missionary? Once you dedicate yourself to such a book, or the viewing of that Lifetime movie, you already know the outcome as soon as you see the titles--you are expecting to be outraged.  What fun would it be if the main character never did anything unsavory?  The predictability of the story should factor into the the comedy as in the classic films mentioned above.  In "An Ex to Grind," Melanie works towards what she wants, gets what she wants, realizes she doesn't really want what she thought and must go through the fire of disappointment to become a newly baptized Melanie--one that views things in a different way because of her experience.  This does happen in this novel, however, the outcome is not all that satisfying--its too saccharine-y sweet.  I may expect that from a classic film, but not from a novel published in 2006.Reader Caroline Schaffer does a great job of acting out each characters voice while still keeping the timing of a comedienne, making the audio presentation of this novel a worthwhile listen.Bottom line? Having not read any of Jane Heller's other novels, I found "An Ex to Grind" predictable fun with a madcap heroine.  Recommended for those who want a typically crazy comedic read that probably would work best as a Lifetime movie.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

The Solo Executive Backpack in Khaki features a multitude of padded stash space--there are two large zippered compartments that open the case fully and will accommodate a Macbook Pro safely and bundle the associated wires and charges accordingly in separate slots designed for that function.The color is more brown than khaki as is depicted in the images.  The front sports a snap closure that opens to split pockets--the snap device on this feature is a little difficult to open--perhaps some lubricant will help to ensure faster access and closure.The zippered pocket beneath the decorative vinyl opens to a slotted organization area for pens, cell phone etc.This backpack is meant to be worn on the back--it does not have a luggage sleeve that would ease it onto the telescopic handle of rolling luggage. Compare it to the  Zuca Business Backpack that is almost double the cost--the Solo is specifically built for laptop and office carry whereas the Zuca could double as an overnight bag.  Like a standard school carry, the Solo has no wiggle room or ability to expand like a piece of luggage.The padding is substantial enough for everyday--although I would not check this if using for airplane travel.Bottom line? Nice professional looking storage for those who like a backpack at a good price. Recommended.Diana Faillace Von BehrenBuzzard's Eye View

Environment is crucial to tea drinking.  A beautiful place, a wondrous brew calms and nurtures the spirit.When I lived in Tucson Arizona, I had the good luck to be able to drink wonderful tea in a Chinese Tea Shop called Seven Cups on 6th Avenue.  During my short time in the city, I was happy to experience Cloud-fog tea--an everyday Chinese tea that was so popular in its native country it rarely made it out of China.The area where it is grown is the Lushan Mountain area in the Jiangxi Province where a perpetual cloud hangs over the landscape--this misty climate slow-grows and hydrates the tea bushes resulting in leaves that are filled with abundant plant chlorophyll and sweet/unusual flavor development.The Cloud-fog tea has a buttery flavor that may be reminiscent of asparagus sprouts--however, do not over kill this tea with too hot water--it will become bitter.  Rich with tannins and Vitamin C, it requires delicate handling--water temp around 140 degrees--abbreviated seep time. Sip and savor.Happily, this interesting tea is now available through Amazon!  Recommended.

While Amy Schiebe's newest novel "A Fireproof Home for the Bride" is set in 1950s Minnesota, the plight of her heroine Emmy Nelson remains relevant almost seventy years later despite the novel's ability to gather its reader in a tornado of descriptions and mindsets that seem only fitting for that earlier age.  Disguised as a coming-of-age novel, Fireproof's theme of tolerance presses through as the main character struggles to craft a universe where what she feels in her heart becomes at least an esoteric if not actual reality.Main character Emmy whose voice is expressed within a third person limited perspective possesses strength of body and will due to the hard life provided for her by her farming/factory-working family.  Strict Lutherans, Christian and Karin Nelson abide strictly by the tenets of the Bible where mother Karin especially lives within a stingy emotional climate where bare-knuckle duty and faith sadly drain the joy out companionable living and shame and fear guide all behaviors.From the novel's beginning, the reader is made aware that Emmy will marry Ambrose Brann, the college grad son of a wealthier neighbor and embark upon a life similar to that of her mother's.  Although Emmy, at times, sparks with a coming-of-age need for exploration--she cannot help be attracted to the glittering adult sexual portal that a relationship with Ambrose opens to her--she cringes at the thought of subjecting herself to the lack of freedom that she knows a life with the Brann clan will bring her.Her natural curiosity spurs her forward past her mother's vision of her as the wife of an influential Brann and when the opportunity arises, she breaks free of this control and attempts to discover a more fulfilling life on her own.Unfortunately, Emmy's small world is defined by other darker threats where the perhaps comfortable idea of community where everyone knows everybody else leads to a lack of privacy that work to thwart her attempts.  The reader is led through the labyrinth of cousins and other distant relations that either help or hinder Emmy's progress and suggest just how claustrophobic Emmy's universe actually is.Although the tone of the novel marvelously reflects the dour backdrop of Emmy's upbringing and what she views as the limited options and sour histories of her environment's inhabitants, at times the reader feels as if he/she is wading through heavy water--so dense are Schiebe's reflective descriptions that instead of drowning in her interesting metaphors and preponderances of emotion (or lack thereof) the tendency is to want to move along and get past the tedium to a place of action.  While this fog of emotional quandary and growth is necessary to the definition of Schiebe's main character, it still evokes a dreariness and muffled uncertainty that might have been easier to navigate without all the superfluous characters--relations and what not. Although Emmy is marked with the determination to persevere, the tone remains controlled, retrained and devoid of the excitement of forging a new world.Schiebe's depiction of the Doyle family--the large stereotypical Irish American Catholic family works up until she flounders with secondary player Bobby's (Emmy's love interest) indecision regarding himself.  This reviewer finds that her dismissal of him and the hint of his potential proclivities weakens the story line rendering it with a triteness that while convenient for the main character is unnecessary.  On the other hand, Emmy's feelings for Bobby and her view of his family and the life they can make together helps make her ultimate decision more authentic.  (Note:  Schiebe's research on the procedure of the Catholic Mass needs editing. Keep in mind that my version of "Fireproof" was an ARC. Although the addition of "The Kiss of Peace" was reincorporated into the service after Vatican II, it certainly did not occur until way after the Latin Mass was substituted for the vernacular celebration.  This did not become a part of the Mass in the 1950s--it most likely became an addition to the New Mass in the 1970s!)From the start of the novel, the reader is aware that there is more to Emmy's family than just straight-laced religion.  The overtones of hatred and bigotry voiced by the Branns' and the snaky character of Curtus Davidson and Emmy's innate dislike of their ability to cow her parents and their adjuncts fuels the latter portion of the novel where Emmy's true calling is nurtured by her interest in finding out not only the truth of her background, but the universal truth of real fellowship.  It is in this portion of the story that Schiebe abandons her denser prose and the reader, aware of this push forward rushes along with her gratefully.  Unlike other reviewers of this novel, this reviewer enjoyed the darker mysteries that Schiebe outlines as intrinsic to her main characters growth spurt.  Rather than get lost within a miasma of too much contemplation and woebegone recriminations as reflections of the past, Emmy's involvement with something larger, lightens her as a character, making her more understandable and likeable. Otherwise, "A Fireproof Home for the Bride" just follows another struggle-to-undo-the-chains-that-bind scenario.Bottom line?  "A Fireproof Home for the Bride" disguises itself as a gentle read of a young woman's coming-of-age.  While part of the story does indeed address an escape from the convention of 1950s' expectations for women, "Fireproof" describes a a darker maze of incensed power taken by supposedly upstanding people who do not understand the true meaning of the American melting pot. As author Schiebe's main character constructs her own truth, her new understanding of her past and the horror of the present help her to grow in a way she never thought possible.  Recommended despite some dense descriptions that stall the novel's beginning and may make this novel more enjoyable in an audio format.Diana Faillace Von BehrenBuzzard's Eye View

The title of Kate Alcott's novel "A Touch of Stardust" will appeal to a certain type of reader: one looking for a bit of fun about the glamour days of 1930s Hollywood during one of the town's most significant events in cinema history--the filming of Gone with the Wind.Even though Alcott interjects her story of an ambitious Smith graduate from Fort Wayne Indiana looking to make it as a screenwriter with political inferences from the time--Julie eventually must learn to stifle the power of an ingrained anti-Semitic background, view skeptically the less-than-hopeful statistics of success for women screenwriters and voice outrage against the racism and censorship of the Hollywood machine as it struggles to depict Margaret Mitchell's novel as a true adaptation--she makes such issues seem almost anecdotal, thrown in to create a genuine atmosphere rather than concentrate on what really shines within her pages.  The relationship Alcott depicts between actress Carole Lombard and the film's Rhett Butler, Clark Gable redeems the novel from a triteness that would otherwise render the novel quickly forgettable.  When viewed as a romp, despite the attempted pull of weightier subjects, "A Touch of Stardust" becomes a quick, fun read.Its not that Julie's story isn't memorable--something tells me that Alcott might further explore the girl, her assured success and her romance with the zealous Andy Weinstein in a sequel--she's predictable, roughly drawn and as the author puts it in her Afterward an "Everywoman" that strives for some individual success. Unfortunately, in this case, "Everywoman" equals been-there-done-it-before.I, for one, enjoyed the "Ma" and "Pa" relationship between Lombard and Gable and would have liked more of that repartee in addition to more insights into the making of the great film. Alcott weaves in many bits of Hollywood gossip and other incidental tidbits that reflect her research, but these manage to come off as cutesy expositions rather than necessary character depictions.  Nonetheless, viewing the book as a "feisty Midwestern girl makes good on man-eating unknown turf despite the odds" kind of novel will ensure a pleasurable read.Bottom line? Kate Alcott's novel "A Touch of Stardust" depicts the Hollywood before WW2 where profit-making is king and the huge endeavor of filming "Gone with the Wind" is a huge gamble.  While main character Julie Crawford drives the story with her confused ambition--straddling her desire for career rather than the safety of marriage and eventual motherhood--the more colorful fleshed out personality of Carole Lombard keeps the reader entertained and somewhat forgiving of Julie's bumpy ride. Recommended as a fast read to while away the winter hours.  After reading, indulge in a movie night starring Rhett Butler and Scarlett O'Hara and marvel at its staying power.  For those enamored by Mitchell's Gone with the Wind, 75th Anniversary Edition try the sequel by Alexandra Ripley Scarlett: The Sequel to Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind" or indulge in a viewing of the mini-series Scarlett. Antebellum fun.Diana Faillace Von Behren"Buzzard's Eye View"

I ordered 180s Women's Tahoe Ear Warmers in White--I had been using Chatties Ladies Printed Patterned Headphone Earmuffs with built in Speakers and unfortunately the connection became loose and the muffs became useless. When I purchased these, my intention was to use these with ear buds for exercise purposes--the levee near my home is extremely cold and windy in the winter time. The ear bud portion of this idea works, however the adjustable feature of these muffs simply does not work.  Pulling the muffs supposedly adjusts the size, but the adjustment does not stay fixed--once the muffs are placed around the neck, they slip off the ears, rendering them useless. I am a small person with a small head, so I can't figure out why they don't fit.  The only reason could be poor construction or they are made for a child.Bottom line?  Although constructed with plush fabric, these earmuffs do not stay on my ears.  Not recommended.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

A surprisingly high-capacity "card" wallet.  There's 3 card sleeves on each side, and the surprise is the almost-hidden center compartment that can hold a few folded bills (or other pieces of paper).The slots face outwards (with nothing covering them), so there's no extra bulk. Each slot is a bit wider than the average card, providing some wiggle room for pulling out a particular card. Cards neither stick in place, nor fall out easily.Pictured: The wallet containing a single standard-sized US credit card.  [ A free sample was provided to me for review. ]I use this wallet for travel, during which it holds my backup credit cards and cash for the departure tax. But those of you with streamlined finances could use it as normal wallet. It looks nice and works well. Recommended.

A nice Slayer design, but no back design, and a weirdly oversized fit.There's no matching back-design, which makes for too much blank cloth. The front design is reasonably large but could do a better job of filing the front of the "XL" I tried. The XL is weirdly baggy, with untapered sleeves. That means unless you're enormous, the top of the sleeve puffs out awkwardly. "Fitted" tee-shirts have been a thing for so long, I can't imagine why anybody is selling 1980s cut (think "Hanes") shirts.If you were hoping for a cool fan-appropriate shirt, this one is the best of several I looked at here on Amazon (I tried 3), but you might do better going to your local vintage or novelty mall store instead (think Hot Topic or Spencer's). Not recommended.

A so-so Slayer shirt.The design is okay, but there's no matching back-design, and there's too much blank space on the sides (more than you see in the product photo), and on the bottom.The L is oddly cut, too tight across my shoulders (despite this tee-shirt manufacturer's XL being massive), but with untapered sleeves. That means unless you're totally built, the top of the sleeve puffs out awkwardly. "Fitted" tee-shirts have been a thing for so long, I can't imagine why anybody is selling 1980s style (think "Hanes") shirts.If you were hoping for a cool fan-appropriate shirt, this one is okayish, but you'd do better going to your local vintage or novelty mall store instead (think Hot Topic or Spencer's). Not recommended.

A disappointing Slayer shirt.Mine did not have the (pictured) logo on the back, without which that's a large expanse of plain cloth. The front design isn't scaled up to the XL, so it covers a lot less of the shirt than pictured (double the empty space on the sides of the design).And the XL itself is weirdly cut (much larger than this company's "L"), too long, with non-tapered sleeves. That means unless you're enormous, the top of the sleeve puffs out awkwardly. The non-scaled design would make sense if this was a boyscout troop ironing decals onto fund-raising shirts, but is inexcusable for commercially produced designs. It's not even a very decent shirt apart from the design. If you were hoping for a cool, well-fitted, fan-appropriate (or even novelty appropriate) Slayer tee-shirt... This isn't it. Not recommended.

Despite an interesting design, these sunglasses are unusable uncomfortable. The wire "arms" curl around my ears in a hugely uncomfortable way (I'm L/XL-size in men's hats). They also sit further out from one's face than you might expect, which feels awkward and unstable.Also note they have leather "sides" (threaded with a thin neck strap). that are hard to see in the current listing photo, presumably to make up for how far the glasses sit in front of your face. The leather sides look like they're removable, but you might have to break their mounting piece in the process.Without modification, the design ends up too dark for costume usage (eg. steampunk-styled events), too awkward for active outdoor usage, not covered enough for dusty outdoor usage (eg, Burning Man), and the earpieces are uncomfortable for all those situations. Not Recommended.

A narrow wrap bracelet. It's thinner than it appears in the pictures, has different stud patterns on each half, and unlike the current product name, doesn't actually have any spikes.It works as an unusual bracelet / wristband, but doesn't lay flat (since it has to cross over itself to be snapped shut). I also found it worked as a slender gender-neutral choker, which I wore as part of a rockstar costume-- as long as your neck isn't too thick (it was borderline tight on me, I wear a 16" dress-shirt collar).I also tried the "punk rock wide" bracelet which is currently part of the same Amazon listing as the wrap bracelet (mentioning it here, since I can't review 2 items from this listing separately). It works fairly well also, though seems a little too shiny for the its punk design, and I found it unsnapped if the bracelet edge caught on something. The "wide" version is less interesting than the "wrap" version.That versatility and solid construction make this bracelet Recommended.

An inexpensive, well-sized semi-rigid HDD case. It easily fits modern portable 2.5" drives, with room for a cable or two in the mesh accessory pouch. While this product is aimed at hard drives, it would work for a GPS, smart phone, or other small items.The case is most crush resistant along the outsides, and has some give in the middle, but the combination of rigidity and padding should provide decent protection against bumps or short falls. An elastic strap holds your drive in place, and the zipper has a pull-tab.Pictured with a Seagate STBX500100 2.5 external drive. [ A free sample was provided to me for review. ]All of that makes for a decent feature set for a basic protective case. Recommended.

Received the wrong item, with a crucifix-style pendant instead of the goth/punk design on the listing.Unlike the current first product photo (but matching the other 2 current photos), the rope is a brown rawhide-looking leather, rather than black. The rawhide is better suited to a ren-fest style outfit, rather than completing the rocker outfit I was designing for Halloween. The strand has an adjustable portion that lets you lengthen or shorten the strand, but it's not the most intuitive to adjust.Two stars since the crufix design is okay.

Received a design not shown in the product listing, with a much paler (white) nylon background, making the sleeve unusable for my purposes.And oddly enough, this is a one-pack. Unless your skin matches the nylon exactly, you'll need a pair of these. And the price for 2 sleeves is much higher than comparable listings. Not recommended.

I wore this pair of tattoo "sleeves" as part of a Halloween rocker costume. The quality is good, but the nylon construction is inherently fragile.The design looks good even stretched to the sleeves' max fit. It's one of the better designs of similar listings I looked at. Those other designs are garish or look particularly fake (comparatively, people seemed to find these sleeves looked real at a dimly-lit glance). The "skin color" (of the base nylon material) is on the light side, so if you're particularly dark (or absolutely pale) they might not work. They worked okay on my tanned / light brown skin.These are much like old-school women's "nylons", complete with the same fragility (runs, tears possible) and needing to smooth or hitch the sleeves into place. But I found they generally stayed in place on my arms, needing only periodic smoothing.The fit is on the tight side, the upper part is almost too tight on my medium male build. Larger folks should look elsewhere. There's a seam down the underside (it doesn't show too much), there's a fabric-care tag you'll want to remove, and there's a seam where the sleeves end that you'll want to cover with a wristband or gloves.I found the wrist-seam tore a little getting after getting pulled over my hand several times, and that made it curl up, but I was still able to cover it up with a broad wristband.5 stars since they are superior in quality (to other sleeves I've tried), the design is one of the best ones I've seen, and the price is good for the pair of sleeves. Recommended.

A solid, metal spiked ring for increasing the impact of your strike. The one-size ring is a comfortably-almost-loose fit on my average-size male hands (slender fingers). It comes on a chain (for hanging or wearing), in a gift-suitable pouch.This ring is less visible than brass knuckles (and presumably less likely to count as a concealed weapon), but you'd have to be in close and striking effectively for it to make a difference. The best goal would be to inflict sudden, unexpected pain, allowing you to run away from the attacker. That said, things are pretty bad by the time you're struggling with somebody at arm's length. Best to pair this with pepper spray or a baton for being able to fight at arm's length.I don't believe it's pointed enough to break newer shatterproof car windows, but I wasn't so sure of that as to try it out myself. According to the manufacturer, it can be used for that purpose, which is useful for rescue of a child or animal trapped in a hot car, or for escaping a sinking vehicle. [ A free sample was provided to me for review. ]While it's not the most practical self-defense weapon, it might lend an edge during a struggle, and it doesn't hurt to keep such a device in your car in case of needing to break a window.

Small speakers serve up big Bose sound, but this package comes with an exorbitantly high price tag, and some surprising limitations.Summary: This package produces substantial sound from compact gear, while drawing only miserly amounts of power. Easy setup, and everything in one box, including cabling. But the featureset is lacking basics like an on-screen display, the lovely compact speakers have long proprietary cables, and Soundtouch seems like an unnecessary complication for simple audio streaming usage. Several aspects feel "dated". For the price-tag, I expected better. Details follow:* Sound: Classic Bose sound. Crisp, clear, distinct. The "ADAPTiQ" headset is used to let the system figure out the acoustic properties of the room (and adjust its sound accordingly). Presumably the headset is more accurate than the small mic other receivers use for this purpose.* Receiver: A/V receiver functions are split into 2 pieces, the "console" and the "SoundTouch wireless adapter" (which end up cabled together), making for a clunky layout. All the more so since the remote works with the console, but the app works with the Soundtouch adapter. This layout feels like the recycle of an old hardware design that should be rebuilt as one unit. Combined with the lack of an On-Screen Display, that means both pieces have to be "out". On power-cycle, the console doesn't seem to remember what HDMI input was set last.* Display/controls: Unlike modern AV receivers, the console doesn't output control overlays to the current video output. That means you'll be squinting to see the tiny display on the console, or using the soundtouch app (yes that means a remote AND a mobile device), or they simply didn't provide the receiver feature you were looking for anyway.* Wireless speakers: The Sub unit ("Acoustimass") is wireless (since it plugs into power anyway). The other speakers are all cabled. Unfortunately, the cables provided are very long (and proprietary). So to get the nice clean (no cables) setup in the promo pic? You're going to need to do both drywall work and cable management.* Power: Electrical draw (measured at the wall) is impressively low. For modest volume, the Acoustimass and console together drew well under 50W.* Cabling: One of my biggest hits on Bose is the completely unnecessary proprietariness of what should be commodity parts. That includes the speaker wires. Long cables are provided, which will be much too long for the fronts (to get the setup pictured in Bose promo shot), and possibly too short for the rears. And they're black. (how many of you have black walls?)  The power cables also lack "normal" ends.* Remote: Nice to have a universal remote, but the layout is amateurish. What do you use most on an A/V remote? Power, perhaps? It's not in the top row (it's in the top middle). What else, volume? A smallish rocker crowded by other buttons. Mute? (which I use most) That's a tiny button below the volume rocker. They should have repackaged one of Logitech's brilliant universal remotes, instead of this cluttered 1990s throwback.* Connectivity: I only experimented a little. Despite the dedicated add-on hardware for this purpose, Soundtouch seems primitive. The app is required. It's far more steps than it should be to do something simple like "stream from my device" (no simple pair-and-go).  It seems like you lose the ability to switch to somebody else's accounts or devices, since things are pre-configured through your Soundtouch account. The happy couple is going to have to decide who runs the AV system. There's nothing like the Logitech Squeezebox where you can play music from an arbitrary source such as your PC.* Unpack: One big box with multiple smaller boxes inside it. All cabling (including one HDMI) and batteries for the remote are included.* Other: Front and rear speakers seem to be identical. There's no subwoofer threshold to select what frequencies are sent to the Acoustimass.I wanted to rate this 3.5 stars, but considering the price and the fact the speakers can't be used with other receivers, I rounded down.The solid Bose-tuned audio will appeal to anybody who likes the way Bose sounds, the easy setup will appeal to those who don't want unnecessary features and configuration, the compact size works well for smaller spaces (or larger minimalist spaces), and the Soundtouch adapter ties in modern audio sources. But the clunky proprietary-ness of the design and cabling, the afterthought of a remote, the lack of an on-screen display, and the limited tunability are galling at this price.If you're invested in the Bose ecosystem, or are particularly fond of the Bose sound, this system is a good choice. If you simply want a compact, easy-setup AV system, you can likely find a cheaper, more modern system that does more.

Textured synthetic motorcycle gloves. They're sturdily made with reinforced knuckles (that have breathing holes), spot reinforcements, and a velcro closure.They're much more solid than my cycling gloves, but seem to be cut small. The "L" is on the tight side for my average-sized male hands (slender fingers), even though I wear an "L" in most types of gloves. If you're on the border between sizes (eg, L/XL), go up a size.  [ A free sample was provided to me for review. ]Protecting your joints and knuckles is important for many activities including motorcycle riding. If you're not set on leather, these gloves are a decent choice.

A motion-detection nightlight with a twist; instead of having to place it on top of the nearest convenient outlet, you can place this rechargeable light anywhere using the included sticky pad. The light itself is removable from the base, and USB charged via a standard microUSB cable (one is included).Mine is the "warm" yellow color, which resembles incandescent light. The light distribution is even, from the sides of the light. This is meant to light up the wall it's attached to. The resulting illumination is pretty bright compared to most small LED nightlights. In the picture, the light is just sitting on a bathroom counter, but is bright enough to cast shadows-- plenty bright when it's dark.Quibbles: The sensitivity of the motion sensor seems to vary. Sometimes the light stays on the 20 seconds the manual describes. Other times it stays lit for longer, as much as 2-3 minutes, even when I move the light to a bright room. The light also comes in low-light (not just dark), so it's not calibrated to work only in the dark. I only dock one star, since it still serves the purpose (comes on with motion when it's dark)-- the opposite would be less forgivable. [ A free sample was provided to me for review. ]A nice twist on the usual nightlight, and the combination of LED and rechargeable are big improvements if you've been using old-style nightlights. Recommended.

A 2-pack of solar-powered, rechargeable, automatic lights.They are plastic, with a faceted front-plate. Inside is a rechargeable battery (replaceable), an on-off switch, and the LED circuitry. Once switched on, the lights charge from ambient sunlight, turn on when it's suitably dark, and run until it's light again (or the charge runs down). Mounting hardware is included (screws and anchors). For their light weight, you could also mount them with Command strips or velcro.They are designed to be placed with the solar panel up, which creates a pleasingly focused light pattern along the wall. It's possible to mount them sideways (sunlight allowing), but the LED glare is harsh at that angle.Concerns: I'd worry about the cover becoming brittle with outdoor exposure, or moisture condensing inside the cover in humid climates. You probably need to wipe off the solar panel every so often.[ A free sample was provided to me for review. ]Decent pricing for small, outdoor safety or accent lights. The pair are ideal to place along outdoor steps. Recommended.

Basic industrial-grade disposable gloves. Light-blue colored, the "small" size is true-to-size (buy the same as you would in winter gloves). These feel pretty lightweight, so you may want to look for heavier gloves if working with harsher chemicals.The gloves are "non-medical" (which designation is based on the glove failure rate). I tend to prefer nitrile for my gloves, since it reduces the likelihood of allergic reaction versus latex (and no dust). The manufacturer also states nitrile provides better elasticity than vinyl and better puncture resistance than latex or vinyl.It's good to always have disposable gloves on-hand. I usually buy heavier-duty gloves (for working with chemicals), but for lightweight food-handling or cleaning usage, these gloves will work well.

Basic medical-grade disposable gloves. A nice purple color, and the "small" are true-to-size (buy the same size as you would in winter gloves). These are pretty lightweight, and likely would not be suitable for working with cleaning chemicals or other harsher usesThe gloves are "non-sterile", but presumably you aren't going to be doing surgery with your Amazon purchase. I tend to prefer nitrile, since it reduces the likelihood of allergic reaction versus latex (and no dust). The manufacturer also states nitrile  provides better elasticity than vinyl and better puncture resistance than latex or vinyl.It's always good to have disposable gloves around. I usually buy heavier-duty "industrial" gloves (for working with chemicals), but for lightweight sanitary or health usage, these gloves will work well.

Pur's newest pitcher. A little bigger (by 1 cup) than the Brita competition, but also a little less functional. The expensive Pur filters are superior to Brita's, but work much more slowly. You likely want the Pur if you're more skeptical about your water, and the Brita if you're just moderately skeptical, or on a tighter budget, or drink a lot of water.The details:* Size: This slim design is higher-capacity (11 cup) than either Brita's slim pitcher (5 cup) or their larger pitchers (10 cup). Pur wins if you keep the pitcher in the fridge, otherwise 1 cup isn't decisive.* Filtering: The Pur filters are much bigger than the Brita's, and are rated more specifically for more contaminants. Some big differences: the Pur is rated for removing cysts, has been rated for removing pesticide traces, and for removing various metals that the Brita does not mention. The Pur also has a rating for reducing pharmaceutical traces (for which there's no established threshold, but I'd like as little of them in my water as possible). Pur wins hands down on producing cleaner, safer water.* Filters: Unlike the new Brita design, the Purs still need to be pre-soaked before rinsing and installation (similar to the old Brita design). The Pur filter doesn't have an easy-grasp top like the Brita, I've sometimes had to use tools to get a decent grip on the old filter I'm removing.* Design: This Pur has a small fill opening designed to minimize the chance of contamination, similar to the nicer Britas. But unlike the Britas, the lid isn't fitted, so a casual upward motion will cause the lid to bounce up or even pop off. The handle is less comfortable than the Brita Monterey (see my pics), but better than the Brita Everyday. Brita wins slightly on better lid and handle design.* Speed of filtering: The Pur is distinctly slower than the Brita for the same water / same age of filter. Brita wins on speed.* Pouring: The Pur's spout is shaped for faster pouring, and no glugging. There's a small flap that keeps the opening covered normally. The Brita 10-cups don't have that flap, and pour more slowly. Pur wins on pouring.* Pouring while filtering: Pouring from the Pur while the top chamber is full causes the unfiltered water to mix with filtered in the pitcher, as well as to pour from the spout. This is a bad design (especially considering the slow filtering). The Brita Monterey has the same issue, but less so-- if its top chamber is less than 1/3 full, you can pour normally, and there's much less of the accidental intermingling in the pitcher even when more full. The Brita Everyday barely has the issue (only if the top chamber is full). Brita wins on pouring while the top filtering chamber is filled.* Plastic: Like all such water pitchers these days, the plastic is labeled as BPA-free. Both pitchers feel sturdy and I've never had a Pur or Brita crack from normal usage. Only once when a cat knocked a filled pitcher off a counter.* Filters: Only one filter is included with the Pur. The Pur filters are historically more expensive than Brita's, including here on Amazon.Pictured: This Pur pitcher alongside the the similarly-sized Brita Monterey 10 Cup. I use both of these at home.Pur filters work well, the water tastes great even if you had decent tap water already, so I won't reiterate the "yay for filtered water!" that many reviews already express. Especially for drinking plain (or for making coffee), it's always well worth using filtered water. And it's much cheaper than bottled water!This is a nice-looking pitcher, and Pur filters are particularly effective (if a bit slow). Recommended if you have problem water or don't use so much water as to be bothered by the slower filtering.

A versatile smartphone holder for the car. The suction base and swivel mount allow placement anywhere on the car's glass, and the combination of locking sides, and a bottom support, make for a secure mount even at sharp angles.Construction is sturdy, and the suction cup doesn't seem like it'll accidentally give way (if anything, it's a little bit of a struggle to release the suction). The sides ratchet in and out, with a flip-down support, that together hold my phone steady. Once I've tighten the nut on the swivel mount, my phone isn't going anywhere.My testing was all done with my LG Nexus5 (5" screen), which is pictured. In the pics, I  was trying an alternate location at the top left of the windshield (easy viewing for the driver). I ended up deciding to place it under the rear view mirror (which is still in the driver's reach, in my car), which is less distracting to me visually, since I already expect to see something in the middle of the windshield there. This Aukey mount made it easy to angle things "perfectly" from that location. The user should be careful to not obscure their view, observe local traffic regulations regarding their device, etc, of course.[ A free sample was provided to me for review. ]For using a mobile device for navigation, or really for any other hands-free usage while driving,  you really need a mount like this one. Not having to balance your device somewhere, and not having to keep glancing down at your lap is a major upgrade. A minor bonus-- the onboard speaker on the phone is much easier to hear when the device is mounted at head-level. This is the finest of several smartphone mounts I've tried, and it is Recommended.

A party light with low-power LEDs that create alternating, spinning colored patterns.It's intended to be sound activated, but in practice I found the pattern varied regardless of ambient noise (ie, it changed on its own in a quiet room). It also responded to the unit being tapped (but not spoken to), so I think the description is a bit misleading (neither voice-activated, nor responsive to music). At most it may match up to the bass beat of some cranked-up music.Although there are shallow indentations on the back that would allow the light to hang from a pair of screws, it's probably most easily placed with a stick-on adhesive strip like 3M, or velcro tabs like Command. A power meter showed the light drawing just 4W, notably less than the 10W described in the listing.The light has an odd level of brightness where it's too bright to have shining in your face, if you have it on a bar or tabletop (especially in a dimly lit room). But it's not bright enough to mount on a ceiling or high wall.  I think it would be best placed near the music, near bottles where it'll make interesting reflections, or with 2+ units mounted on different walls to create a club-lighting effect.[ A free sample was provided to me for review. ]Quibbles: the power cord is much too short, and the conduit meant to hold the cord while wall-mounted doesn't have clips or hooks to hold the cable flat. It would be nice if there was a way to chose which patterns or types of patterns the unit will produce.Despite my quibbles, I only dock one star, because this is a fun, bright party light at a reasonable price. There's many a get-together that would benefit from some ambiance and color, and a few of these lights would do the trick!

A perfect-fit rubberized skin for your Mac laptop's keyboard. It fits equally well on both my Macbook Pro 2013 and Macbook Air 2015. The fit is close enough to the actual keyboard that I have to look twice to see the "skin" is in place (in dim lighting, I can only see it around the cursor keys).While the fit is perfect, it does slow down my most brisk typing rate. I think that's because the thin silicone layer sort of evens out the subtle curve that each Mac key normally has. But considering its protective purposes (especially for those who don't type heavily), it's barely an impediment.[ A free sample was provided to me for review. ]This XSKN is a great idea for working in cafes, or for those of you who like to eat at your desk like I do. The skin installs and removes very easily-- so if you get it dirty: just rinse, wipe dry, and put it back into place. I also suspect this will keep my kitty companions' fur from working its way under the keys, which invariably happens to my unprotected keyboards.Recommended.

This DRAC5 "dedicated NIC" add-on card was a good fit in one of the legacy Poweredge 2950s at work (the PE1950 and PE2950 take the same parts in many cases). It came in a static bag, looked new, and works fine. And way cheaper than Dell charges for this part. (or used to charge)Make sure to snap in all 3 contact points before connecting the two ribbon cables. Don't be fooled by the PCI style connector, it's actually unused. And check for firmware updates, labeled as "Dell Remote Access Controller" in the case of the PE2950 firmware.Remote management (aka IPMI interfaces) makes life a lot easier, and this card is Recommended if you have this generation of Poweredges without DRACs.

A metal stand sized for larger cell phones and tablets.The sturdy aluminum construction has Apple's aesthetic and will look at home in a modern workspace. Having the phone standing up lets you check for updates without picking up the phone (especially with wave-to-wake devices like the Moto X), or maintain the correct angle for photo/video (eg, Facetime). For visually-cued people like me, it also provides a convenient "everything in its place" spot for my phone.[ A free sample was provided to me for review. ]The stand's display angle is adjustable, and it locks firmly in place (except when the hinge button is pressed). There are rubber bumpers on the angled part of stand and on the bottom to keep things in place. The stand doesn't display and branding.It's a good fit for my LG Nexus5, where I prefer the phone in the horizontal orientation. For phones under 5", I'd worry the metal of the stand would interfere with the wireless signals (ie, when the stand overlaps the edge of the phone to any major extent). For those of you with larger phones or tablets, this stand is Recommended.

This rubber coupling was the exact fit to replace a leaky, deteriorated one connecting my sump valve to the drain pipe.It feels solid, and the fit on the clamps is good. Oddly, my local Big Box store didn't carry this size, and turns out the couplings are cheaper here anyway.As the listing notes, the actual dimensions are 1.94 inch x 1.63 inch x 3.45 inch.I'm not sure why American hardware is always mis-measured (eg, a 2"x4" piece of lumber always measures smaller than 2"x4" in at least one dimension). While I'd like to have a long, frank heart-to-heart with whatever genius came up with that scheme, that's certainly not this manufacturer's fault. Still, it's worth noting the real dimensions are not anything near 1.25" or 1.5" (inside or outside, on either end), so don't go by that.

A basic 4-port USB wall charger, of the sort you want once you realize how unwieldy having a charger-per-device is.This GRDE model provides full power (2.4A) and the same settings on any of its 4 ports, so you don't have to keep track of which port is optimized for which kind of device. I found my LG Nexus 5 charged as rapidly from this GRDE as it does from its native 1.2A charger.The drawback of the simple "wall wart" design is you need easy outlet access for plug-unplug (under the desk is bad), unless you are leaving the cables attached and accessible. While I'd prefer to have per-port LEDs to show the device is powered and/or which ports are being used, in reality mine is likely placed out of sight against the wall or under a desk.[ A free sample was provided to me for review. ]This is a high-capacity, small-sized charger without any extra frills, and is Recommended.

Pads to keep wooden floors from being scratched or dented by the legs of your furniture. They are a good thickness and hold in place readily on the floor. They are neither so sticky that they're a pain to move, nor do they slip and slide on their own.The pads are larger than I expected, which can be a drawback when visible against lighter-colored wood, but the greater size accommodates a variety of furniture. These pads can also be cut to fit (or if you're thrifty, to effectively get more than 8 pads out of this set).[ A free sample was provided to me for review. ]A far cry from the old, slippery felt furniture pads (which would fall apart over time) that I used to place for my mom. These new-style ones are on the expensive side, but they work very well. Recommended.

A sturdy metal flashlight with broad coverage, using a high-capacity 18650 rechargeable battery. It's easy to operate one-handed and uses a CREE LED.Like most LED flashlights that don't have a curved lens, the beam has a bright center and a broad, dimmer circle around it. Still, the beam is wide enough to mostly illuminate a 12-foot bedroom wall, if dimly (from 10 feet away). I prefer the design of Securitylng's zoomable flashlight model, which provides more even light, but this model's high-capacity battery promises better longevity.Lightly pressing the power button switches between bright, dim, very dim, strobe, and SOS modes. I usually only bother with "bright".The barrel is a good size to hold and the metal build feels very sturdy.[ A free sample was provided to me in exchange for an honest review. ]Some folks might find the unusual battery size off-putting, but its greater power output and capacity make for a brighter flashlight with staying power. You'll have to buy the battery (and a charger)  separately, but if that doesn't pose a problem, this flashlight is Recommended.

This medium-sized version of the GRDE flashlight has a metal barrel with a camouflage pattern, and takes an 18650 battery (rather than an AA like the smaller version of the flashlight uses).The camo pattern I could do without, but the cool part of this flashlight is the zoomable head. That allows the beam to go from "wide" where it can evenly illuminate a large area (eg: most of 12 foot bedroom wall from about 10 feet away), all the way down to a focused, bright-white square at the "narrow" end.The even illumination is a pleasant surprise, most likely the outcome of the curved glass lens. It's unlike most LED flashlights, which have uneven light distribution with a bright center, and a dimly lit outer circle surrounding the bright spot. The "square" beam at the zoomed end of this flashlight's range looks a little unusual, but doesn't pose any problem (it so happens the LED itself is squarish). That zoomed beam has a decent range.Lightly pressing the power button switches between bright, dim, strobe, and SOS modes. I usually only bother with "bright".The medium-small barrel is a good size to hold, but the clip gets in the way (and doesn't seem very useful). I removed the clip by loosening the hex screws with a pair of pliers.The small version of the flashlight is very similar and uses a single common AA cell, but has a lot less light output, and is more awkward to hold. For the minor price difference, I like the medium-size a lot better.[ A free sample was provided to me in exchange for an honest review. ]Some people might find the unusual battery size off-putting, but its greater power output and capacity make for a brighter flashlight with staying power. You'll have to buy the battery (and a charger) separately, but if that doesn't pose a problem, this flashlight is Recommended.

Despite what you might expect from my title, and from its very thick manual, this rice cooker is exceedingly easy to use. That manual turns out to be mostly translations.To get the sort of fluffy, lightweight, unseasoned steamed rice that accompanies most East Asian cuisines (and some SE Asian as well), this is literally all you have to do:* Remove bowl from rice cooker* Use (included) measuring cup to measure rice* Add water and swish / drain a couple of times* Add water to the marking on the bowl.* Put bowl back, select "plain" (the original/default setting) and hit start.And done. It runs, and changes over to "keep warm" mode once the cycle is finished (30 minutes for plain white rice).Unlike the rice I've always made on the stovetop, the rice cooker method doesn't require any fat at all, making for an exceptionally light, fluffy rice that can then pick up the sauce and seasonings of whatever dish or condiment you prefer. You can also add seasonings, herbs, etc, to the bowl before cooking.There's a steaming tray (which can be used while making rice, or separately). It works reasonably well, but the capacity is low for an American appetite. For veggies, it holds enough for a side-dish for one, or rice addition for two, and definitely not enough for a main course.Cleanup is easy although hand-wash only (there's 3 parts that come out, and a steam outlet that may need cleaning periodically).
