He earns credits as he wins or completes races, which he can use to upgrade the various components of the car, or to purchase a more powerful car.Many types of races are offered: Online Mode in which players race each other, Arcade Mode in which the player races AI drivers or his buddy in the same room, and the single player Career Mode in which the player progresses from Novice through the Nationals and the Internationals to the Red Bull X Challenge, as he earns his racing licenses through a series of driving tests.  As the player becomes more experienced, special racing events are offered.To do the game justice, the player needs a decent racing wheel.  The standard PS3 controller simply doesn't cut it.  There is the Logitech G27.  It is an excellent wheel for the PS3.  Unfortunately, it is NOT compatible with the PS4, which offers exciting new racing games like DriveClub and Project CARS.  For wheels compatible with both PS3 and PS4, there are the entry-level Thrustmaster T80RS and the high-end T300RS (See Note).  Many players are disappointed with the T80RS because it doesn't have force feed-back, but the price is reasonable.One additional thing I like to mention is the background music of the game - I hate it.  But fortunately, the game offers the player option to replace it, which I did with the soundtrack of the 1966 film Grand Prix.  What is more fitting for an auto-racing game like Gran Turismo 6 than that?Note:  According to what I read, the T500RS, released for PS3 over three years ago, is supported in DriveClub and will be in Project CARS.

This Philips Sonicare Toothbrush is an entry-level electric brush. It is relatively short, measuring 8-5/8 inches long from end of the handle to tip of the brush. It is powered by two disposable AA batteries (included), instead of a built-in rechargeable battery in many upscale models. The brush head is fixed; it is not replaceable. So when it wears out, the owner has to buy a new brush. However, at fifteen dollars a pop, it is affordable. It is very quiet, compared to the Oral B electric brush I am using. For users who prefer a quiet electric brush, the Sonicare brand is the choice.When all things being equal, an electric brush does a better job of cleaning teeth than a manual one.  This Philips Sonicare Toothbrush is a good choice for those who want to graduate from a manual brush to an inexpensive electric one (See Note below)............................................Note:  Electric toothbrush 101There are two types of electric toothbrushes on the market today: the rotation-oscillation type and the vibration type.  The rotation-oscillation type toothbrushes rotate clockwise and counterclockwise alternately, whereas the vibration type vibrates back and forth linearly.  The vibration type is further sub-divided into the sonic and ultrasonic type.  The sonic toothbrushes vibrate at a frequency of 200-400 Hz (cycles per second).  It is in the audible range and hence sonic.  The ultrasonic toothbrushes vibrate at a frequency of 20,000 Hz or higher.  It is above the hearing range and hence ultrasonic.The difference is as follows: The rotation-oscillation type covers a larger area.  The user places the brush head on each tooth and progresses down the line.  The sonic vibration type moves in relatively shorter strokes and hence the user gets to move the brush head around a bit to cover the entire tooth.  The ultrasonic vibration type uses ultrasonic wave to break up plaque and bacteria instead of the sweeping action the sonic vibration type.This Philips Sonicare electric toothbrush under review is an example of the sonic vibration type.An example of a rotation-oscillation type is the Braun Oral-B Triumph with SmartGuide.  Check it out here:  Braun Triumph Professional Care 9000 series (9900 - 9930 - 9950) Power Toothbrush with Smart GuideFor an ultrasonic vibration toothbrush, check it out here: Emmi-dent 6 100% Ultrasonic Toothbrush

These Westinghouse Lighting Corp connectors do not look much but they are little lifesavers.  They are good for repairing bead chains commonly used in ceiling fans and window blinds.  The homeowner hooks the last beads of the two segments of a broken chain onto each end and crimps down lightly with a pair of pliers.  And viola, the chain is whole again.  Highly recommended.

This Case Login Griffith Park Plus Backpack is designed to carry electronic gears like laptops, tablets, mp3 players, smart phones, and such securely in its numerous padded zippered pockets of various sizes. In addition, there is room in the central compartment for a book or two and a binder. Unzip the front panel and the user will find a small portable office with numerous pockets for pens, note pads, veggie snacks, a joint perhaps in Colorado, and small whatnots, conveniently within reach from the front.  The two side pockets are good for water bottles to keep the user hydrated under the hot summer sun. There is a zippered compartment at the bottom for a small rolled-up vinyl poncho, easily accessible from the outside in foul weather, or whatever the user wants to keep away from the delicate electronics. It is a thoughtful design. The back and the shoulder straps are deeply padded and covered with ventilating mesh fabric for user comfort.This Griffith Park backpack looks and feels sturdy. It is also attractive with the 2-tone black and green color scheme. It is perfect for college students going about their business on campus. Highly recommended.

Alaska always holds special fascinations among many viewers, myself included. It symbolizes natural beauty as well as rugged life in the wild. This series Railroad Alaska, aired in 2013 on Destination America, depicts the men who work on the Alaska Railroad and the "off-gridders" who live along the route.The Alaska Railroad starts at Seward with a deep-water all-season seaport. From there, it runs through Whittier, Anchorage, Palmer, Takeetna, Hurricane Gulch, and finally ends in Fairbanks and a little beyond, spanning over 470 miles. The viewers get to watch as the locomotive engineers drive the trains through treacherous terrain and the maintenance crew replaces cracked rails and removes waist-deep snow and ice to keep the railroad passable. The show tells the stories of the off-gridders who live in isolated cabins along the railroad which they depend on for food and vital supplies. Many segments are obviously re-enactments but they do tell credible stories. Don't miss out on this excellent reality TV series.P.S. Railroad Alaska Season 2 with ten new episodes will premiere on Destination America in Fall, 2014.

This InterDesign Metalo Hose Shower Caddy is made of steel with a bronze-color satin finish. It measures 13-3/4 inches wide, 24 inches high, and 4 inches deep. It hooks on the shower pipe. A suction cup secures the bottom to the wall. The shelves measure 5-1/4 inches wide, 3-3/8 inches high, and 4 inches deep. They are 3-sided without backs. The wall is apparently the back. I found that odd when I first saw the caddy. Small items might fall off from the back if the suction cup detaches from the wall, intentionally or otherwise. This did happen the first time I used the caddy, when I tried to dry the tile behind it by lifting it slight away from the wall.  Now I take everything out of the shelves before I dry the tiles.  I also noticed that the caddy tends to twist from side to side. There is a clearance of 9-1/2 inches between the bottom of the top shelves and that of the lower shelves. Items taller than that will have to go on the top shelves. There are two sets of double hooks at the bottom for whatnots. I hang my roped sponge on one of those hooks. I can also hang my hats on them to dry after I hand-wash them. They surely are handy.In conclusion, I found this caddy very useful in my small shower. It also looks good.  It provides much needed space for soap and shampoo but the backless shelves could be problematic.

Jackie's new album Awakening is a mix of classical and contemporary pieces with several original compositions, as well as covers of musical & movie sound tracks. The Walmart exclusive 2-disc album also contains six Christmas classics. There's a lot for everyone on this album, just like Jackie said.For the classical fans, there are "Ave Maria" by Russian composer Vladimir Vavilov and the traditional art song "Dormi Jesu" (The Virgin's Cradle Hymn). They are beautiful and timeless. There is "Vocalise" by Sergei Rachmaninoff, which is a wordless song carried only by a soprano voice with light orchestra accompaniment. These classical pieces showcase Jackie's gifted voice, which has evolved through the years from the operatic in Dream With Me to the bright crystal-clear vocal today.For the pop fans, there are Jackie's covers of "With or Without You" from the album The Joshua Tree by U2, "Memories" from the album The Silent Force by Within Temptation, and "Je t'aime" from the album Pure by Lara Fabian.  More notable are Jackie's covers of "The Rains of Castamere" from the popular HBO TV series Game of Thrones and "Your Love" with lyric by Dulce Pontes and music by the legendary Ennio Morricone from the 1968 film Once Upon A Time in the West.For musical lovers, Jackie sings "Think of Me" from Andrew Lloyd Webber's Phantom of the Opera. This musical is her favorite.  There are new songs in this album.  "Take Me There" by Johan Oberholzer, "Open Fields of Grace" by Paul Sumares and Lisa Venkatrathnam, and "Made to Dream" by Jean-Pierre Steyn are original compositions for Jackie, written specifically to fit her range and tempo. "Take Me There" is notable for its faster beat than Jackie's usual singing style.On August this year, Jackie's third PBS Great Performance was filmed at Longwood Gardens in Pennsylvania. It is based on the songs of this album. The show will air in December on PBS stations. It will be a treat for Jackie fans.The music tracks were recorded in Budapest, Hungary with the Budapest Concert Orchestra and the Budapest City Choir, conducted by Nicholas Dodd and Richard Cottle. The Budapest Concert Orchestra has performed in a number of classical music recordings, including Symphony No. 1 & Hungarian Dances Nos. 5 & 6 by Brahms, and Mozart's Requiem - Coronation Mass.This album was produced by record producer Nick Patrick who has worked with many classical crossover artists, including Katherine Jenkins and Russell Watson. "We all wanted to find a balance that would present Jackie in all that she is as an artist," says the famed record producer regarding the new album. I think he has succeeded. The mix of different genres in this album signifies new directions in Jackie's music while maintaining her classical root. Fans like myself are waiting with bated breath for new things to come.

This George Foreman GR136B Classic Plate Grill is advertised as "Service for 2", but that is a stretch, because it is so small it is only good for one.  The cooking surface measures 6-1/4 x 7-1/2 inches.  It is so small that I could barely fit three strips of Moriningstar Farm "bacon" on it.  The small size is actually okay, considering the fact that there are 102 million unmarried people 18 and older in America in 2011.  A lot of them are living alone and cooking for one.  There is a niche on the market for small one-person cookware.  In my opinion, George Foreman should sell this little grill as "Service for One".This grill appears to be made of heat resistant plastic.  It is electric, running on 110VAC.  The cooking surface is non-stick.  It is tilted downward so that grease and oil will run down to a detached plastic drip tray (included).  A green indicator on the cover lights up when the heater of the grill turns on.  There is no temperature control.  It will be nice if there is one.  Cleaning the cooking surface can be problematic because it is not detachable and since the grill is electric, it cannot be immersed in water.  I tried to wipe off the cooking surface with a soapy sponge, followed by a wet paper towel.In conclusion, this little grill is good only for one.  As such, it is a good addition to the microwave oven in a single person household.  The price at twenty dollars a pop is reasonable.  I recommend it to single Amazon shoppers.

This is my favorite EDC AAA light. It's comparable to the Maratac AAA light in stainless and copper, but the titanium Thrunite is a bit lighter than the copper, as much as I love my copper Maratac. If you want something lighter than Ti that's comparable the Olight i3s EOS AAA in aluminum is also a good choice and much cheaper in aluminum than the titanium. There's also the Streamlight Microstream AAA.If you prefer the AA format the Thrunite T10T is also very nice but I prefer the AAA for EDC because of the smaller size. If you want the AA format, and also in the pricier titanium category, the Klarus M1A Ti is also excellent, as well as the Eagletac D25A Ti AA light.But getting back to the AAA format there's also the Thrunite neutral white AAA version in stainless, as well as the rainbow flamed Ti version from Vinh over on the CPF, which is beautiful, but again not cheap. There are both cool white and neutral white versions, so you can pick the one you like. All of these are quality AAA lights but I prefer the Thrunite AAA Ti. Titanium is, after all, "The metal of the gods." :-)The UI and mode spacing are fine for me although I'd prefer the UI to remember the last mode which mine doesn't seem to want to do. But at about 130 lumens it's very bright. Threads are pretty smooth for titanium which can feel gritty. Some people don't like Ti because of that. The light has good throw for such a small light, which I like as I'm more of a throw than spill or flood type of guy. The knurling is not too aggressive. Overall a great little light.

Silly and poorly written script, poorly employed science, stupid characters with inexplicable or unexplained motives (maybe they were just "space happy?"), multiple plot holes the size of an asteroid, and a truly absurd climactic library scene (hard to explain, you just have to see it), this movie has it all, and I don't mean that in a good way. Even the gravitational field of a black hole couldn't hold this disjointed and illogical film together. Apparently cobbled together from the worst and most shopworn sci-fi ideas they could find, Intersteller is one Big Bang of a galactic sized mess. Two stars for the realistic spaceship and space station interiors and astronomical backdrops and scenes, but that's about the only redeeming thing in this otherwise one star movie. The talents of the otherwise competent actors in this movie like McConaughey and Hathaway are wasted here. The sound track is actually decent; too bad it was wasted on this movie.

We bought this after reading the positive reviews here.This is definitely the best call blocker around. The features I like especially are the capability to block whole area codes and automatic blocking of private, anonymous, out of area, name not provided, and unavailable numbers. It's easy to call up and block numbers. On our Panasonic cordless you had to manually punch in the number plus the capacity was only 30 numbers. With this unit you can potentially block thousands, especially the ability to block whole area codes where robocallers change one digit to bypass your device. For example, a lot of robocallers have a Detroit area code since the city has been losing population for years so there are lots of numbers available for robocallers. By comparison New York City has very few. And online services like Nomorobo are only available to those who have VoIP service for their landline which not everyone has. Also you can chain multiple units together. This is the best call blocker I've seen so far.

I have half a dozen different stainless and titanium holders which I use for everything from holding AA or AAA NiMH batteries, 10180 or 10280 lithium ion batteries, to pills, depending on their size, but the GUS model was my first. Great for pills, vitamins, or any small items. Well made and sturdy, it's nearly indestructible. The rubber O-ring makes it pretty waterproof. Occasionally you will need to lubricate the O-ring. I use DuPont Krytox which is popular but there are other good lubricants out there; I just haven't tried them personally. Be aware that you can't use petroleum based lubricants on neoprene O-rings as it will corrode the rubber. I don't know whether this one is neoprene or not but I avoid petroleum based ones just in case. Overall a quality product although not cheap because of the cost of machining stainless steel.

I note the previous negative review but actually these are great to store and protect AA sized NiMH or alkaline batteries, or 14500 sized lithium ion batteries, especially while traveling. Since a typical AA battery is 49.0 to 50.5 mm in length and 13.5 to 14.5 mm in width this capsule fits an AA battery just about perfectly. I have several AA battery holders in titanium and they're great for that. Granted, it's a lot of money to pay for one holder but serious flashlight users and hobbyists are used to paying a lot more than this for their lights, especially semi custom or custom lights which can cost an arm or a leg.

I have several titanium holders in different sizes and they're great for EDC'ing extra batteries, pills, vitamins, or whatever. Titanium is as strong or stronger than steel (depending on the grade of titanium, most everyday items aren't made from the highest grade titanium but then it's not really necessary) but unlike steel or cobalt is non-magnetic. These are perfect for CR123A size cells. I also have the Titaner ones in AA size and the BangGood and Steve Ku 10180 size holders, so if you need those sizes you might want to check those out. Unfortunately you can't seem to find AAA size holders anywhere.

I note the previous negative review but the ones I bought have been fine. I bought one each of the polished, the matte finish, and the gold, and the ones I received are good quality. I was looking for a replacement for the original German made "Rost frei" stamped ones I had from between the wars that I inherited from my father. I've tried clones from Hoffritz, Zamberg, and others, and these are good; the problem is that they seem a bit pricey now that Amazon has the Victorinix ones for so much less. I would just buy the Victorinox model which is almost if not as good quality and a fraction of the price. It looks like Victorinix noticed how expensive the market was in these little clippers and figured they could do just as well for cheaper. I recently bought two of those to try and I was impressed at the quality for the much lower price.

I was looking for a replacement for the original German made "Rost frei" stamped ones I had from between the wars that I inherited from my father. I've tried clones from Hoffritz, Zamberg, and others, and these are good, but in my opinion a bit pricey. I bought one of these as well as the regular finish. The gold is quite attractive and doesn't cost anymore than than the polished steel finish. but I would just buy the Victorinox ones which Amazon carries now, which are almost if not as good quality and a fraction of the price. I recently bought two of those to try and I was impressed at the quality for the much lower price.

I was looking for a replacement for the original German made "Rost frei" stamped ones I had from between the wars that I inherited from my father. I've tried clones from Hoffritz, Zamberg, and others, and these are good, but in my opinion a bit pricey. I would just buy the Victorinox ones which Amazon carries now, which are almost if not as good quality and a fraction of the price. I recently bought two of those to try and I was impressed at the quality for the much lower price.

I've had some of the original German "Rost frei" ones from between the wars that I inherited from my father, the similar clones from Hoffritz Cutlery from 30 years ago, the Inox ones from Zamberg, the Malteser models, and even a French made clone, so I thought I'd try these Victorinox made ones since I'm a big fan of their knives. They're surprisingly good quality for  the price.  Cutters are sharp, nail file is fine, if they're not as good as the originals they're pretty close and I've bought much more expensive clones over the years, including the regular and gold plated Profinox Solingen ones from Malteser, which, although nice, were several times the price of these. Overall a good quality clipper and good value for the price.

This is the ultimate multi-tool. At 7 pounds and $1000, there's nothing else quite like it. No job is too big for it. I used it to tear down my friend's Porsche engine and overhaul the engine. Saved him thousands of dollars. Next my friend and I used it to add a playroom over his garage for his toddler. Finally, we did the logical thing and decided to open our own machine shop. No other machine tools were needed. The machine shops down the street with their expensive and specialized CNC machines just can't compete with the versatility of the Wenger. Like I said, no job is too big for it. Get one for yourself and you'll see. It'll change your life.

I prefer this version of the pocket knife with the pen to the one with the tweezers which I don't find that useful. But the pen I often need because I'm always forgetting my pen. I also have the tweezer version with the sterling silver in the checkered design, which I prefer to this design, but you can't have everything. (I also have this in mother of pearl, but it's too pretty to EDC). One of the most useful things I own.

At over 2800 reviews I'm not sure I can add anything to what's already been said, so I'll be brief. Like millions of other satisfied owners I've had one of these on my keyring for years and have been quite happy with it. My only criticism is that for me I wish the opening direction for the scissors and knife were reversed. The scissors opens opposite the keyring rather than the knife, and since I use the knife more than the scissors I find this arrangement a bit awkward as it's easier to open and use the knife that way. Other than that an almost perfect pocket knife. I also have it in the Sterling silver and the rare golden mother of pearl, which are great for more formal dress occasions.

These are similar to the regular pack it cubes except they have a zipper compression feature, which works very well. It's amazing how much stuff you can fit into them and how much space it saves. Overall construction seems similar to the regular cubes. Eagle Creek gave them somewhat different colors from the original pack it cubes which is how I tell them apart from a distance. A useful travel aid if you need to save space.

These are similar to the regular pack it cubes, but I find them less easy to use. They're the same size, but they don't have the see-thru mesh, and the zippers don't go all the way around. Other than that they're pretty much the same, but I still prefer the others. They have the zipper on the top rather than the side, which I don't mind. But I find I like the see thru mesh, which is very convenient, as well as the longer zippers on the originals. These are okay, but the originals are better for my needs.

I have several of these sets and with them I can organize everything I need when traveling. The quarter cube I use mainly for electronic and computer related stuff and accessories, and the half and full cube for clothing. I have them in different colors which I use to color code things. The see-thru mesh is useful and the zippers, stitching, and handles are all strong enough so that I've never had a problem with any of them. For me these are just the right size slthough I know some people would like them somewhat larger. For me though the sizes are perfect. Overall another useful travel aid from Eagke Creek.

I have probably a dozen of the quarter cubes, which I use for smaller items, mostly computer related and Apple product items such as cords, chargers, power supplies, connectors, batteries and battery holders, as well as miscellaneous personnel items. These larger cubes I use mostly for organizing smaller clothing items. I have several of them in different colors which I use to color code the contents. The nylon see-thru mesh is convenient and sturdy enough to hold up to frequent use. Zippers work great and have never had one break. Same for the stitched handles. Another great Eagle Creek travel and organizer aid. I just wish they did an expandable version like with the quarter cube.

This my fave Eagle Creek size for travel. I probably have 12 of them in different colors and use them to mainly organize computer and Apple product items such cords, chargers, power supplies, connectors, batteries and battery holders, as well as personnel items. The expandable versions are great as well. I probably buy several new ones a year because I also find them to be useful around the house. The nylon see-thru mesh is convenient and sturdy enough to hold up to frequent use. Zippers work great and have never had one break. Same for the stitched handles. Another great Eagle Creek travel and organizer aid.

This is a good, brief intro to Silat, covering a number of different styles and techniques, including both empty hands and weapons. Draeger's famous bigger book was groundbreaking and this book although shorter continues that tradition. Of course nowadays there are dozens if not hundreds of videos on Silat but at the time these books were all there was. I have an original copy from 1970. Like the previous reviewer I never expected to see it again anywhere. A true piece of martial arts publishing history.

Really nice selection of styles that I wasn't as familiar with. Am more familiar with Serah (Serak), Cimande, Suci Hati, Perisai Diri, Syahbandar, Harimau, Mande Muda, etc. Lots of techniques are shown with both slow and fast demonstrations make it easy to see and learn from. I'd seen videos from a couple of these gurus before so I was expecting some good stuff. Overall a good intro to silat with lots of interesting material.

When the SOG Bowie first came out over 30 years ago it was a landmark knife for the industry and for the consumer. It combined first rate design and aesthetics with toughness and practicality and just outstanding quality overall. The blade is somewhat thicker than the well known and venerable Kabar WWII knife with which it was no doubt intended to compete, which it did. This makes it very stout and sturdy. Add to that the AUS-8 steel which has excellent edge holding ability and the Bowie was and still is an outstanding knife. Not cheap but then you get what you pay for.

Another quirky, funny, oddball, downbeat comedy with Bill Murray doing what he has done best in his mature career ears, which is playing down on their luck, somewhat irascible, but still lovable characters. Much of the humor comes from his cynical and snarky but nevertheless dead on observations about life, people, and relationships. There's no one who does this sort of thing better than Murray ever since Nicholson did As Good As It Gets many years back. But Nicholson's character had more of a belligerent in your face edge whereas Murray's persona has a sort of resigned and exasperated bellicoseness about it. It's sort of funny that Hollywood is able to keep coming up with different versions of this role for Murray to play. It's always fun to watch despite the somewhat downer tone of these movies. Probably a must see for Murray fans.

If you want IMRs, I've found these are comparable to the AW brand ones (no relation to Andy Wan's company despite the similar name). I use these in several high end flashlights that don't require the high pulse or drain currents like the custom sub ohm hot wire mech mods do, so I can't comment on whether they really can handle a 35A draw, but 10 or 15A should be no problem. IMRs are preferred by many vapers because of their high drain capability, plus the lithium manganese chemistry is regarded as more stable and therefore safer as they are considered less likely to go into thermal runaway, which is why IMRs are typically offered as unprotected types. Overall a good battery especially if you need high drain or high current types.

If you want IMRs, I've found these are comparable to the AW brand ones (no relation to Andy Wan's company despite the similar name). I use these in several high end flashlights that don't require the high pulse or drain currents like the custom sub ohm hot wire mech mods do, so I can't comment on whether they really can handle a 35A draw, but 10 or 15A should be no problem. Overall a good battery especially if you need high drain or high current types.

This, along with the 4Sevens Quark Mini MLR2, is my favorite production CR2 EDC light. I really like CR2 form factor lights because they combine compactness with brightness. The Sens Mini is pretty much the same as the 4Sevens light, except for the accelerometer based interface which is somewhat controversial over on the candlepowerforum website which flashlight pros, tech types, and power users frequent and talk about lights. But I like it. Takes a little getting used to but it's actually a pretty cool idea. But you should research it before buying to make sure it's for you. Besides that, the overall build quality of the light is excellent, and I have no complaints there. The throw for such a small light is impressive, and I'm more a throw than flood guy when it comes to beam profiles. The 170 lumens is more than adequate from such a small package. Overall a nice little EDC light. BTW, I and other CPF'ers have found you can use 15270 3.7V batteries as well as the 3.0V CR2 batteries. Although not officially rated for them by the manufacturer, they seem to be able to handle the higher voltage without ill effect, and you get increased brightness.

I have an old SOG Trident from the 80s bought at the now long defunct Cutlery World when it was owned briefly by the great Jim Parker, who revolutionized the knife world at the time when he was the first to produce quality, hammer-welded 512-layer Damascus at a price the working man could afford. Suddenly this fabled steel was now within reach of many ordinary knife buyers. This was one of the few non-Damascus knives I bought back then and have been happy with it ever since. Even with all the developments since it's hard to beat this knife. The newer versions with the seat belt cutter, the black titanium nitride finish, and probably an improved spring mechanism are no doubt worthwhile improvements, but they wouldn't be here if it weren't for the original. Sturdy, well made, practical, and an eye pleasing design are all hallmarks of a SOG knife. The Trident stands as an enduring classic.

There are all kinds of uses for these little magnets but if you're a battery hobbyist or high end flashlight user you might find these useful as I have. Be advised this review is aimed at these two groups, otherwise it might not make much sense to regular consumers.There are all kinds of uses for these little magnets but if you're a battery hobbyist or high end flashlight user you might find these useful. I have both these and the .118 size. I use them as charging spacers for my smaller batteries such as my 14250 and CR2/15270 batteries so that I can charge them in my CR123A/16340 chargers. I have not investigated whether there's a significant conductivity difference compared to my brass and steel spacers but they seem to work okay. They're especially useful for my Xtar MC1, MP2, and MP2s USB chargers which I like to use while on the go and in the car. Just make sure you're not exceeding the current capability for these smaller batteries. They're also great for adapting 18500 batteries to use in 18650 size lights.The 18500 format lights aren't very common compared to the very popular 18650 size ones, but I have several, such as a Tain Zenith, Mr. Bulk, and Convoy M2 "shorty" (cut down from 18650), and these magnets allow me to use my AW red, AWT yellow, and Efest red and purple IMRs in my larger 18650 lights, which is sorta cool. They also allow me to use my 14250 batteries in my CR2 and CR123A lights, and even my 10180 batteries in my 10280 lights. Just make sure if it's a CR2 light at 3.0V it can handle the higher voltage at 3.7V. Although not officially rated for 3.7V batteries, in the case of my 4Sevens Quark Mini MLR2 and Nitecore Sens Mini, which are 3.0V CR2 lights, I and other users on the CandlePowerForum have found they can operate at 3.7V without burning out the emitter.Also be careful if your light has a QTC (quantum tunneling composite) as these are direct drive with no PCB circuit to monitor the cut-off voltage which is a critical safety function for a lithium ion battery. These lights are only suitable for professionals or knowledgeable flashlight users and should not be given to children. Also be careful about overheating on high or turbo mode. Finally I can even use them in a pinch to adapt AAA size Eneloop and Eneloop Pro NiMH batteries for use in my mini Nebulizer 2xAA unit.

These are 14500 rated at 600 lumens. Unlike the Ultrafire, Trustfire, and the other "fire" named batteries which will claim higher ratings but will only deliver half or one third of that, with AWs you get what you pay for. AW's are top of the line batteries. I have many of them in different sizes and colors, from the tiny 10180 and 10280 ones to 28650 size. The components are made by Panasonic in Japan, famous for their Orbtronic brand, and assembled in China, which helps to lower cost. People complain sometimes about the cost on the CPF battery forum but again you get what you pay for.Be aware that AWs are often faked. If you Google it you will find good websites that show how to spot fakes. I've read that all the AWs on Alibaba and many on Amazon are fakes, so caveat emptor,You should know that the colors designate different types. Blue is ICR or lithium cobalt unprotected cells. Black and silver is protected. Red is IMR or lithium manganese unprotected cells. The best protected cells have vent holes plus a built in circuit to detect overcharge, overdischarge, a short circuit, or too high a temperature. The lithium manganese chemistry isn't as susceptible to thermal runaway hence they are typically offered as unprotected types. They are considered a relatively safe chemistry among lithium ion batteries but be aware there are no truly 100% safe lithium ion batteries. Green I believe is unprotected non-rechargeable but as it's been a while since I've seen them I'm not sure.The color coding can be confusing between different makers as there's no consistency. For example, Panasonic uses green for one type of rechargeable cell, but Ultrafire uses red for protected cells whereas red AW is unprotected lithium manganese. So be careful and check this and don't make assumptions about color coding between different manufacturers. If you're not familiar with hazards and safety issues in using and charging lithium ion batteries you should do a search on lithium ion battery dangers and read up on it. The BatteryUniversity and Candlepower websites, as well as several vaping websites have some great info on that. Overall AW is a top quality brand like Panasonic Orbtronic and is a trusted brand by high end battery users such as custom vapers and flashlight users.

These are 14500 rated at 600 lumens. Oddly enough they're about the same capacity as CR123A/16340 ICR chemistry batteries. I'd just like to make a few comments on this light and on the competition which potential buyers might find useful. I like the JetBeam titanium limited editions, which are considered better than average quality. But I also have a couple of their regular aluminum lights like this one, which, although production lights, are still considered decent quality. The PC10 compares favorably to the other regular production CR123A lights from major Chinese makers like the Sunwayman V10R, V11R, M10R, Nitecore SRT-3, Olight T15, and Fenix PD25 lights.You could also add the Surefire E1E and other Executive series lights here but of course Surefire is American made and much more expensive, but at one time was considered the ultimate in build quality. The expert consensus now though is that their quality has slipped significantly in recent years, which is attributed to the departure of Paul Kim and Dr. John Matthews, the chief engineer and founder, respectively, and the two main driving forces behind the company's success for many years.But getting back to the JetBeam, build quality is good and the feature set is fine. On the Candlepowerforum.com where high end flashlight users, engineers, and pros hang out, JetBeam quality overall is considered good but not quite as good as with Fenix, but better than Nitecore. I personally love Nitecore designs and ideas but they have gotten a reputation on the CPF for rushing new designs to market that aren't adequately debugged and tested and so they get more lights needing to be serviced, which they are happy to do. Next to Nitecore though JetBeam is my favorite light company for great looking designs and fun ideas, even if their lights have the occasional problem. Just my two cents and others mileage may vary.

This is a good tester, and should be as it is U.S. made and costs about a hundred bucks. Because it uses a load testing method rather than simple voltage it gives you a much more accurate reading on the state of the battery. It tests 95% of the batteries I have and the remaining ones I rarely use. The number of devices around the house that use small batteries continues to grow, including smoke and carbon monoxide detectors, many remote controls, a postage scale, bathroom scales, a label maker, an iPhone power bank, and a number of high tech flashlights. These devices can use anywhere from 1 to 8 batteries. Then I realized we had over a hundred batteries after I rounded them all up and didn't know the state of health of most of them, so I decided to bite the bullet and get a real tester.The pros for this meter are:1. Easy to use, self-calibrating2. Uses four AA batteries rather than 9V which I prefer3. Tests dozens of different types and the most important chemistries (lithium, lithium ion, alkaline, and NiMH)4. It's fast, returns reading in just a few seconds5. Uses pulse load method which is more accurate but doesn't drain battery much6. Easy to follow manual and instructions7. Construction and build quality seems sturdy and solid8. The optional soft cover case is a plusThe cons, which really aren't serious, are:1. Would have preferred a continuous scale; this meter indicates 10%, 20%, 40%, etc. up to 100%. But then battery capacity measurement isn't super accurate anyway.2. You have to line up the small positive terminal of the battery with the metal stud on the meter. It would be easier to line up the bigger negative end of the battery.3. It's not a small meter if you're looking for something small and portable. It's not a big deal for me but be aware it's about the size of a regular hardback book and about as heavy.Also I note the comment from another reviewer here who was complimentary about the company's phone support. He also said they advised using alkaline rather than NiMH batteries because the slightly lower voltage of NiMH could give inaccurate readings. But I'm going to try it with both Sanyo Eneloop NiMH and alkalines and see what I get.So far I'm very happy with this tester and can recommend it for anyone who like me who has lots of batteries around the house and didn't really know which ones were good or not.

Up until this light I had only owned small lights from Thrunite, but I was very happy with them. These were mainly their AAA or 10440 lights like their TISvn 10440 which I have in the beautiful flamed titanium version, modified by Vinh54 over in the Candlepowerforum.com to put out a whopping 750 lumens on high, which is ridiculous for such a small light, and it heats up quickly as you might expect. I also have the TiS NW XP-G2 and the Ti CW XM-L2 versions.This light however is a 18650/18350/16340, making it pretty versatile as far as batteries goes. With a couple of magnetic spacers, I can even use my AW, AWT, and Efest 18500 IMR batteries. At 1040 lumens it's very bright. The black anodized finish is flawless, the threads are smooth, the modes are spaced well, it comes with a decent holster, the extension tube makes it very versatile, the neutral white tint is nice, and I like the user interface. I also don't mind side switches instead of twist or rear clicky's. In fact there isn't anything I don't like except as with the other reviewers here the one thing it's missing is a pocket clip. Other than that I'd say an almost perfectly executed light especially given the price.

Knowledgeable flashlight users make fun of these on the candlepowerforum.com website but for the money they're really not a bad deal. The lumens rating is way overstated of course as it's more like 150 lumens, but the plastic focusable lens actually works pretty well and the machining and anodizing are actually pretty good. A focusable AA light from Coast like the H5 will cost you more like $30, and if you want a real AA light that puts out several hundred lumens (actually 500) you'll need to buy the recently released Zebra Light SC5 model, but that's a lot more money than this light. Some have complained theirs stopped working after a few months but mine (I have several in different colors) have been fine. There are several factories in China I've heard that are turning out these little lights. The design appears to be a ripoff of the small Voidhawk light (just do a Google search on Voidhawk) except these use non-lithium ion batteries. I wouldn't trust the low voltage protection circuit or the reverse polarity detection on these lights though as they probably don't have these features, but I just use them as beaters and don't care if I drop or lose them.

This is one of several makes of 18650 IMR batteries I've tried, the others include the well known AW reds and the AWT yellows (no relation to Andrew Wan's AW company). They've all worked well. These are the button top as opposed to flat top versions. This is potentially important for users of lights that have a battery carrier inside the tube holding three or four 18650 batteries. If you get button top batteries, especially those that also have a protection circuit board in the tail, they can be long enough so that they won't fit in the carrier and you'd be better off with flat tops or even without protection. This means that before buying batteries you should find out what the maximum length of a battery can be for your light, which the manufacturer should specify. However, since IMRs are typically offered without the protection curcuit, either button top or flat top batteries should work fine unless you have a really tight battery carrier.As far as the important points to know about IMRs goes, these include:1. They are lithium manganese dioxide chemistry rather than lithium cobalt oxide which is more common.2. They have higher drain but less energy capacity than ICR.3. They're considered safer since this chemistry is less likely to go into thermal runaway.4. Because of 3, they're typically offered without a protective circuit board.5. Although they lack 4, they do have vent holes and I'm pretty sure a fusible link although I'm not certain.6. They have a wider temperature operating range compared to ICR types.7. Considered better han ICR for high drain applications, such as high-end e-cigs and vaping devices.These cells have worked well in my high drain lights with 4x18650 battery carriers such as my Niteye Eye40 light. I have the Eye40vn version modded by Vinh54 (a well known modder over on the CandlePowerForum.com site) which now puts out 10,000 lumens on turbo mode and requires high drain cells. I also use these in my Soshine 2x18650 power bank, although I really didn't need the 35A version just for that. But in the Eye40 they're necessary.

This is one of several makes of 18500 IMR batteries I've tried, the others include the well known AW reds and the AWT yellows (no relation to Andrew Wan's AW outfit). They've all worked well. I only have three lights that take this size, which isn't as common as the 18650 and the 16340 (CR123A) size. The latter designation is because it is 2/3 A cell length, the full length A battery size no longer being made.Efest is not an OEM but packages and markets cells they buy from the main manufacturers. I don't know which ones they buy, but there aren't that many quality makers that are respected by knowledgeable battery users and hobbyists. *** These include Panasonic, Sanyo, Samsung, LG, and AW. But since AW buys Japanese made components and then assembles them in China I doubt they use AW's which are also excellent batteries.The important things to know about IMRs are:1. They are lithium manganese dioxide chemistry rather than lithium cobalt oxide which is more common.2. They have higher drain but less energy capacity than ICR.3. They're considered safer since this chemistry is less likely to go into thermal runaway.4. Because of 3, they're typically offered without a protective circuit board.5. Although they lack 4, they do have vent holes and I'm pretty sure a fusible link although I'm not certain.6. They have a wider temperature operating range compared to ICR types.7. Often preferred for high current situations such as such as high-end e-cigs and vaping devices, and powerful flashlights.I use these in my Tain Zenith titanium, Mr. Bulk, and Convoy M2 lights, where they've provided good service, and I've also used them in my Soshine and Xtar power bank/charger.***Note: These include the RC (remote control) hobbyists, custom vapers, and high-end flashlight users, as well as professional technicians and engineers who work in the field.

As you can see from the other reviews here people just love this clever little Spyderco. If there's a cute knife this is it. I bought mine 20 years ago and it's still in use. It's a testament to the ingenuity of the design that it's remained in the Spyderco catalog that long.It's small size makes it very convenient while being sturdy enough to tackle more serious jobs. Spyderco's trademark large thumb hole for one-handed opening doesn't seem out of place on such a compact knife which was my first impression. The Cricket's stout construction for its size is impressive, reminding me of my original S.O.G. Mini Tanto style model although that's a very different design of knife but similarly sturdily built for its size.The clip is very strong just like on all Spyderco's. It's attached by three tapped and threaded screw holes and small Phillips machine screws, and is removable if you prefer. It would be even better if Spyderco used hex or Torx screws but the Phillips are fine. I've never had a Spyderco clip strip out. I'm just not a fan of small Phillips screws, compared to the larger ones which I don't mind. You could even use it as a money clip.I like the all metal design but if there was a lighter version with a Kraton handle like my Mini S.O.G. or synthetic handle I'd buy that one too just for the lightness. But if you want super light you'll just have to buy the Spyderco skeletonized model with both a skeletonized blade and handle. It's another very clever idea on Spyderco's part and that knife always gets comments from friends and acquaintances who've never seen a knife like that before.I like the serrated version but there's a regular bladed version as well. I could see buying both as the non-serrated blades are easier to sharpen, the small teeth requiring a good set of ceramic triangle sticks to sharpen or similarly capable sharpener. It's also small enough so that it shouldn't cause any concern for law enforcement.Finally, a note on the metallurgy is in order. The VG-10 steel with 0.4% tungsten is excellent and a bit different from the more common sub-zero quench 440C stainless steel originated in the U.S., which I have on many of my other knives such as my Case XX models. (Case actually invented the sub-zero quench method after WWII if I recall right, which is notable for the very strong, needle like Martensite crystals which gives this steel it's high tensile strength). VF-10 is a cutlery grade steel originally created by Takefu Special Steel Co. Ltd. in Takefu, Fukui Prefecture, Japan. Blade making in this area goes all the way back to Shogun days when it was a sword-making center in the town of Echizen.Overall a great little knife that offers a lot in such a small package.

These are the Ultimate Lithiums in the AAA size. Although these days I prefer rechargeables, these batteries have their uses. Lithium primaries are a lithium iron disulfide chemistry and in the U.S. Energizer has the patent on it, so no one else can make them, at least here. Compared to other secondaries like NiMH and most other lithium ion batteries, they have great shelf life (up to 20 years)***, excellent temperature tolerance (-40 to -140 degrees F), and output voltage (1.5V vs. 1.2V for NiMH). They perform well in high drain applications that ordinary alkalines aren't really adequate for, such as photographic equipment, infrared night vision equipment, etc. The difference between the L91's and the L92's is the L91's are rated for 3.0A discharge current and are AA and the L92's are only 1.5A and are AAA.As far as using them in devices around the house goes, such as remotes and flashlights, which is what I'm concerned with, lithiums will outperform alkaline batteries, as well as most NiMH batteries. Battery Guy over on the CPF (CandlePowerForum.com) points out that flashlights that have 2W draw or less per cell will do better with Li-Ion primaries. Above 2W, he says you will get longer runtime using NiMH types.Overall a good product if you need it and don't want to mess with the additional device of a charger. Unfortunately they're no longer made in the U.S. as production was moved to Singapore in the last couple of years.By the way, safely charging lithium ion batteries requires some extra knowledge and skill. You should read the CPF battery forum and go to BatteryUniversity.com for more information if you plan to do it. That's what I did and I'm now almost 100% in rechargeables for both NiMH and Li-Ion. Rechargeableis can save you a lot of money over the long term. Finally, the PDF data sheet from Energizer is here: http://data.energizer.com/PDFs/l91.pdf***Note: There are some exceptions. Lithium thionyl chloride batteries also last very long, said to be as long as 25 years, but these are special use cells and not generally used by the average consumer. They are often used for memory backup, and are common in applications which require long life, where extreme temperature tolerance is needed, and where maintenance will be infrequent, such as remote arctic weather station equipment and sensors, remote animal tracking devices, remote alarm systems, etc.Note that they are not actually a lithium ion type and are not rechargeable. Tadiran, SAFT, and Varta are among the few companies that makes them and sell them in the U.S. The Varta sales and technical handbook has some good info and is here: http://www.varta-microbattery.com/applications/mb_data/documents/sales_literature_varta/handbook_primary_lithium_cylindrical_series_er_en.pdf

An intense music school drama (set at a thinly veiled Juliard) that just keeps getting more dramatic and more intense until the final scene. Although there's a good supporting cast, the real show is the toxic, high decibel, over the top, and abusive relationship between the young drummer and the psycho band leader played by veteran TV actor J.K. Simmons in an Oscar worthy performance. I wasn't familiar with the young actor who played the drummer but he was also outstanding in the role.I'm no expert on drums but I found I enjoyed all the drum virtuoso parts. The talk about great past jazz musicians inspired me to look up names like Buddy Rich and Charlie Parker on Wiki and read their bios there.A brief comment on the psychology, however, is in order. The band leader uses as justification for his abusive methods the example of Charlie Parker who gave a historic performance after being persecuted by his band leader. Simmons comments "There are no more harmful two words in the English language than "good job." This is just pop psychology nonsense of the worst sort. Decades of research and hundreds of studies by psychologists have shown that people overwhelmingly respond best to positive, not negative reinforcement. You can catch more flies with sugar instead of vinegar as the saying goes.This also applies to leadership styles. Of the various leadership styles, the leader who leads by example and by providing a positive image and exhibiting positive qualities and ideals has been found in studies to be the most productive and effective.Of course, then we wouldn't have had a movie. :-)

Black pearl and abalone are my two fave handle materials for knives so I had a soft spot for this particular Al Mar. Beautiful overall design combined with great aesthetics, but practical too as it will handle most jobs quite well. The Osprey is one of his best ideas and dates from 1979 and it's been a catalog offering ever since. The front lock design was relatively new at the time, which I prefer. Al is no longer with us unfortunately but his legacy lives on. I was a big fan of everything he did in the old days when he was still with us.

I love the special snifters put out by breweries and distilleries and have a modest collection of them.A few words are in order about this popular premium bourbon. At a price point above the classic Jim Beam Black Label 8 yr. and Wild Turkey 101 which are the standard competitors here you expect something a little special. I find Woodford a clean tasting light to medium bodied bourbon similar to the more expensive Basil Haydens with smooth attack and finish, subtle top notes which I can't quite identify, and a lot of up front vanilla. It's a lighter, more delicate bourbon than either the Beam or Wild Turkey, or the Knob Creek at about the same price.Other light style whiskies but in the less expensive category are Early Times or Rebel Yell. Despite being cheaper I don't find them very harsh and spirity, my only quip is that the lighter bourbons lack enough true bourbon flavor and character in my humble opinion. My view is that since what distinguishes bourbon compared to other distilled spirits like cognac, scotch, rum, etc., is its emphasis on the darker fruits: i.e., prunes, plums, raisins, peaches, stewed fruit, etc., those flavors should be at least as noticeable in a bourbon as the vanilla imparted by the charred oak or the cereal grain maltiness which is pretty much universal among distilled grain spirits.This is also why, although many people love the Woodford and Basil Haydens, I prefer a heavier bourbon like Wild Turkey, Knob Creek, Bookers, Jefferson's Reserve, Bibb & Tucker, etc. I just think If you're paying a premium price you should get more intense flavors.This is also why I like the Blanton's, still a lighter bourbon (although getting very close to a medium one if not actually) but it has more bourbon flavor and character. At the same price point as the Woodford there's Knob Creek which is also more fully flavored and is excellent.  I just prefer a more intense, medium to heavy style. Just my two cents. Others mileage may vary.

This is a great little AAA light at a reasonable price. I have many more pricier small pocket lights but this is the one I EDC because for this price I don't care if I drop it or if it gets dinged up. it's very bright on high mode, has two more useful low and medium modes, has nice smooth threads, and I love the colors. Even the clip is well designed and not wimpy like the clips on some small lights. I like to wait for these to go on sale for $15 and then buy several to give as gifts. People luv 'em. It's also worth mentioning that Olight, although one of many Chinese flashlight companies, has made a commitment to maintaining its U.S. jobs (there are many sales, service, and tech support jobs located in the U.S.) and has honored that commitment so far.

I have the original Delica with the serrated edge from 25 years ago and it's still going strong. I think the VG-10 steel used today might be different from the original. I'm not sure if VG-10 was used back then.Anyway, it's an excellent steel and has small amounts of molybdenum, vanadium, and manganese which create extremely hard carbide crystals which explain this steel's edge holding ability but also can make it hard to sharpen for the amateur. If you've had experience with the old sub-zero quench 440C, a process which produces martensite crystals, which can have tensile strengths of 240,000 pounds per square inch, you know what I mean. Since Spyderco edges are only ground from one side I use a very low angle grind from the other side to sharpen, using a small triangle stick to get at the scalloped serrations.As far as EDC goes I really like the somewhat smaller size of the Delica compared to the Police model. The handles are light but sturdy and the locking mechanism is precise and strong. Overall another quality blade from Spyderco.

Show your love of one of the iconic Islays with this lapel pin! A few words are in order about this unique malt. Caol Ila isn't considered a beginner's malt by experts. That's because even for an Islay Caol Ila is considered a rather eccentric malt because of it's dual nature. It is in fact considered the most schizoid of all malts, with the phenolic and "burnt plastic" aspect of a Laphroaig (which many people find unpleasant) but the fruitiness and sweetness of a Longmorn, Little Mill, Dallas Dhu, Glenfarclas 108, or the famous Scapa 1965 (obviously more pleasant). This is why it is considered an unusual and even somewhat forbidding malt and not appropriate for beginners.Some versions by the varitous independent bottlers may be more approachable to the neophyte than the standard distillery issue. There was a very atypical one, it might have been a Whyte & Whyte bottling, that was relatively tame for a Caol Ila. But that was almost 30 years ago and I haven't seen anything quite like it since.

This video introduces the famous Harimau style from Sumatra. Included are basic standing and ground positions and postures (or kudas in Indonesian), basic combinations of the kudas, applications and self defense, and even a little bit of multiple attacker material with guru de Bordes showing the use of the blade. One of my instructors had the opportunity to attend one of guru de Bordes's seminars and said it was a lot of work. I would like to have seen the jurus but you can't fit everything on a basic video. The videos by Herman Suwara have the jurus if you're interested. Overall an excellent intro video on Harimau.

I like the glasses put out by breweries and single malt distilleries with their logos and have a modest collection of them. This one commemorates the famous malt from the Isle of Skye, north of Islay where most of the island malts reside.A few words are in order about this malt. The Talisker 10 is famous for having an oiliness similar to Irish whiskey and a peppery quality and flavor which some people find off-putting, but there are people who will drink none other. There is an 18-year old which is definitely smoother, but is toned down considerably from the boisterous 10-year, as extra aging on the Islays tends to do.The Islays tend to get more restrained and darker, but also more integrated and more refined with age, but then I don't go to the more intense Islays for the Scotch equivalent of a French Burgundy or Bordeaux. This is why I don't think paying the extra money for the higher ages in the Islays is worth it. I drink them for their intensity and often idiosyncratic character and because I want a good kick in the seat of the pants. The Laphroaig 15 year for example just doesn't seem like real Laphroaig. Too tame. But there are exceptions. The Bowmore 18 yr., 21 yr., and others are good examples. Just my two cents. Others mileage may vary.

I used this book extensively for our many road trips around Calif. back in the 80s and 90s. I learned a lot of geology that I wouldn't have otherwise. For example, it was especially fun driving down Hwy 1 south of San Francisco where there are lots of exposed rock layers such as the graywacke near the famous Devil's Slide area, as well as many other areas. Driving down I-5 south of Hwy 152 we learned that the low mountains to the west comprised the Central Valley Sequence, and marked the location of the subduction zone for the Pacific and continental plates. The geology of Calif. is very complex which means it is a challenge for an expert to make it intelligible to the layman, but I thought the authors did a great job. If you're an avid naturalist and want to get to know your state better the roadside geology books are great way to do that. When approaching a new area we would break out the book and see what it had to say, and often there was a section on it. This was a fun and interesting way to learn more natural history and geology.

Show your love of the classic lowland malt with this lapel pin!A few words are in order about this great single. Auchentoshan is considered the archetypal Lowland, along with Rosebank. It was always the first lowland I introduced new whisky buffs to at tastings because of it's very balanced and integrated character. Lowland whiskies are typically triple distilled comoared to the highlands but there are exceptions as the highland single Glenmorangie is also.My other two fave lowlands were Littlemill, which was notable for it's cocoanut and vanilla flavors and overall very sweet and fruity character. I've seen bottles of Littlemill that you could literally pour over ice cream (I've done it, fun stuff :-)) like you could one of the sweeter bourbons. Littlemill could have quite an expressive range, though; check out the tasting notes on various bottlings by this reviewer who seems to have a pretty perceptive palate:http://www.maltmadness.com/whisky/littlemill.htmlThen there was Bladnoch, which has a very lemony, lemon-grass, citrus-like taste. As I considered those more "specialist" type lowland malts I would often follow the Auchentoshan with those. The point was to demonstrate that the lowlands could be almost as individualistic and eccentric as the weirder Islays such as Caol Ila since the lowlands usually don't get as much attention as the other regions.Note I said "almost" because in general the lowlands are traditionally considered softer and more approachable than the other regions. But they're an important part of a good tasting. You progress from the lowlands to the highlands and other regions and finally to the Islays. The lowlands are more well behaved; you start there and then end up with the Islays where you're in psycho-freakshow territory. :-) Usually the Caol Ila or one of the "liquid peat" Ardbegs was the last malt on the list. For a while I used a Cadenhead barrel strength Ardbeg at around 120 proof that was ridiculous; it tasted like heavily peated shoe or nail polish, until it ran out. I've seen died in the wool Islay drinkers almost spit it out and not be able to finish a shot. A tasting can be a lot of fun if set up right. :-)Now of course there are always the exceptions and limitations to the geographic approach. The classic examples of that are Bruichladdich and Bunnahabhain which are not typical Islays and are more like southern highland or even lowland malts. Most of the Islay lovers I've given those to who had never tried them before were disappointed. On the other hand, they liked the Springbank and Highland Park which although Campbelltown and Orkney malts respectively are basically second cousin to the Islays. They even liked a Clynelish which I mixed 50-50 with a Longmorn better (the favorite concoction of the late, great Victorian connoisseur, Professor Saintsbury--who am I to disagree with the professor?) LOL

I'm a bit obsessive when it comes to good battery cases and I've tried dozens over the years. The Storacell holders are in a class by themselves. They offer a number of advantages:1. Sturdy, thick plastic offers very strong construction2. Precise fit, batteries don't rattle3. Positive retention feature4. Recessed fit protects positive & negative ends5. No plastic hinge or clasp to malfunction or break6. The see-through frame allows you to see the battery label & info7. Last but not least, the colors are useful too, and there are even translucent glow-in-the-dark versionsI use the colors to color code the different makes and brands I have, which in the case of the many AAA and AA batteries I have include several generations of Sanyo Eneloops, Powerex, Duracell Iron Core, Tenergy LSD, etc. I also have the CR123A and 18650 versions which are for lithium ion batteries. The colors are useful there too since I have Nitecore, AW, Orbtronic, Panasonic, Voidhawk, etc.One important feature here which may not be immediately apparent is the lack of a plastic hinge or clasp. It's not uncommon for battery holders with those to break from "plastic fatigue" because the manufacturer didn't use the right plastic to make the holder. It might work for a while, but then over many cycles it eventually wears out and breaks. Also, sometimes the tolerances aren't very precise and the clasp doesn't really work right. The Storacell holder has neither hinge nor clasp to fail.This version offers storage for the 9V types. For some reason there aren't as many makers of 9V holders as of the cylindrical batteries, so if you need that, here it is. Overall a great line of battery holders. They're more expensive than the others but you get what you pay for.

I'm a bit of a nut when it comes to good battery cases and I've tried just about everything out there at one time or another. The Storacell holders are by far the best. Sturdy, precise fit, positive retention, the see-through frame allows you to see which battery brand you have, and the colors are nice too. I use them to color code the different makes and brands I have, which in the case of the many AAA and AA batteries I have include several generations of Sanyo Eneloops, Powerex, Duracell Iron Core, Tenergy LSD, etc. I also have the CR123A and 18650 versions which are for lithium ion batteries. This caddy version offers storage for all the main types of NiMH and is for someone who really needs to organize or transport lots of different kinds of batteries. Overall a great line of battery holders. They're more expensive than the others but you get what you pay for. There's one other possibility. If you just need an individual holder for one battery you can't beat the machined, military spec Delrin holders available at Countycomm. Again, not cheap but very high quality.

I knew Segal more as a scholar of the Greek and Roman classics rather than as a popular writer until he wrote this book, which became an instant blockbuster best seller and later movie. It propelled Segal from an obscure academic into worldwide popular fame. I remember a TV appearance for example where he talked about how he came to write the story. Suddenly he was a celebrity in a way most academics never will be. It's especially ironic since most Ivy League colleges had de-emphasized their Greek and Latin requirements and  curriculums since the late 19th century, and Love Story enabled Segal to become famous to an extent his scholarly specialty would never have allowed. It became one of the greatest one-hit wonders in the history of the U.S. publishing industry as the book sold millions of copies and was translated into dozens of languages.But onto the novel, which isn't nearly as interesting as a work of fiction as what it actually did for Segal's career, who went on to write a number of other screenplays and novels and even film scores. But Love Story wasn't Segal's first foray into popular culture; he had written the screenplay for the Beatles movie, Yellow Submarine several years earlier. As a novel and a romance it is very minimalistic and is simplicity itself (which is no doubt where its charm and popularity came from) so if you're looking for something deeper and more profound (Goethe's The Sorrows of Young Werther come to mind :-)), look elsewhere. Due to the brevity of the novel, for example, some things just aren't explained, such as the strained relationship between the father and son. But although not the greatest romance novel I'm sure it made Segal very wealthy. Since academics don't make much I have no problem with that and I say all the power to him.***Footnote: Segal was also an avid runner, who ran the Boston marathon 19 times until Parkinson's forced him to retire. Segal recounted that a spectator once shouted at him, "Hey Segal, you run better than you write!"

Unfortunately I have to agree with the other one star reviews here that the remastered CGI special effects really destroy the historical accuracy not to mention the charm of the originals. It's especially unfortunate in the case of this episode which is one of the most admired and loved for several reasons, including the portrayal of the superior alien technology, the introduction of the Romulans, the rivetting battle of wits between Captain Kirk and the Romulan commander, and the first appearance of Mark Lenard in a truly memorable role as the commander. Of course Star Trek fans are aware that Lenard went to a distinguished career as Sarek, Spock's father in a number of later episodes and movies. I have to mention I had the honor to hear Lenard speak in the 80s at Calif. State San Francisco's school of TV & Broadcasting to a packed auditorium. But getting back to the present episode, just remember if you're a newbie that you're not getting the original. Caveat emptor!

Batteries tend to rattle around and get nicked and so on especially when traveling so I've found good battery holders are essential equipment. I have these in five different colors which I use as color coding for different types of batteries. The glow in the dark feature is cool, as is the interlocking feature which works well, and I've only seen one other battery holder with this.Some reviewers have reported that the hinge wears out and breaks but I haven't experienced this. One commenter said this is because the plastic chosen is too hard to handle constant flexing and that's why it breaks, but again all I can say is that I haven't experienced this myself. I do try, however, not to bend the lids back all the way or flex them too much since I have seen this "plastic fatigue" myself in other products.I use these translucent/whitish ones for my third generation Orbtronics AAA and AA NiMH LSD's (low self-discharge) in the white color. I really like these holders although I don't use them for CR123A's because they're too snug as others have commented here. Since I mainly use them for the slightly smaller CR2 3.0 volt and 14250 3.6 volt batteries, and also a lot of AA and AAA ones, these work fine for me.They are also excellent for protecting very small mini-flashlights like the Steve Ku 38, 40, and 44 models in various metals, the Veleno Designs Quantum D2 and Helix Zi zirconium, the Lummi Orb Wee, the Modamag Draco and Drake models, the DQG Spy and Fairy, and others. All these lights use sub-CR2 size batteries such as the 10180, 10220, and 10280 sizes, which is why they're so small and fit into these cases. I really like them for that too as it protects the lights, especially when I'm traveling. Overall it's a decent holder. It would be 5 stars if it weren't for the CR123A problem which as I said doesn't really affect me much.

Good battery holders are essential if you have lots of batteries. I have these in five different colors which I use as color coding for different types of batteries. The ability to connect them is useful as well. I use the blue ones for th AW 14250 3.6V ICR lithium cobalt batteries which are blue themselves, which makes it easy to remember.  I really like these holders although I don't use them for CR123A's because they're too snug as others have commented here. Since I mainly use them for the slightly smaller CR2 3.0 volt and 14250 3.6 volt batteries, and also a lot of AA and AAA ones, these work fine for me.For those who want lots of colors, I have seen these offered in the following ones, although not all are available here and you might have to look elsewhere to find them all:OrangeGreenBlueRedClear or translucent (glows in dark)Light red or pinkLight greenLight yellowSmokey color (double-sided one)They are also excellent for protecting very small mini-flashlights like the Steve Ku 38, 40, and 44 models in various metals, the Veleno Designs Quantum D2 and Helix Zi zirconium, the Lummi Orb Wee in various metals and alloys, the Modamag Draco and Drake models, the DQG Spy and Fairy, and others. All these lights use sub-CR2 size batteries such as the 10180, 10220, and 10280 sizes, which is why they're so small and fit into these cases. I really like them for that too as it protects the lights, especially when I'm traveling. Overall it's a decent holder. It would be 5 stars if it weren't for the CR123A problem which as I said doesn't really affect me much.

I'm always looking for the ultimate battery holder and probably have around 8 different types. These universal ones are among my favorites. I have this style in five different colors which I use as color coding for different types of batteries. The interlocking grooves work well too. I use these for the AW IMR 14250 lithium manganese batteries which are red, unlike the ICR lithium cobalt batteries which are blue. I really like these holders although I don't use them for CR123A's because they're too snug as others have commented here. Since I mainly use them for the slightly smaller CR2 3.0 volt and 14250 3.6 volt batteries, and also a lot of AA and AAA ones, these work fine for me. They are also excellent for protecting very small mini-flashlights like the Steve Ku 38, 40, and 44 models in various metals, the Veleno Designs Quantum D2 and Helix Zi zirconium, the Lummi Orb Wee, the Modamag Draco and Drake models, the DQG Spy and Fairy, and others. All these lights use sub-CR2 size batteries such as the 10180, 10220, and 10280 sizes, which is why they're so small and fit into these cases. I really like them for that too as it protects the lights, especially when I'm traveling.Some reviewers have reported that the hinge wears out and breaks but I haven't experienced this. One commenter said this is because the plastic chosen is too hard to handle constant flexing and that's why it breaks, but again all I can say is that I haven't experienced this myself. I do try, however, not to bend the lids back all the way or flex them too much since I have seen this "plastic fatigue" myself in other products. Overall though it's a decent holder, and at nine bucks for ten holders that comes down to less than a dollar per holder. It would be 5 stars if it weren't for the CR123A problem which as I said doesn't really affect me much.

I have a bit of an obsession with battery holders and have tried out many different types and these are one of my favorites. I have these in five different colors which I use as color coding for different types of batteries. The interlocking capability is useful too when transporting several or more. I use the green ones for the Orbtronics 3.0V RCR2 which have a green plastic case so are green themselves. Simple. I really like these holders although I don't use them for CR123A's because they're too snug as others have commented here. Since I mainly use them for the slightly smaller CR2 3.0 volt and 14250 3.6 volt batteries, and also a lot of AA and AAA ones, these work fine for me. They are also excellent for protecting very small mini-flashlights like the Steve Ku 38, 40, and 44 models in various metals, the Veleno Designs Quantum D2 and Helix Zi zirconium, the Lummi Orb Wee, the Modamag Draco and Drake models, the DQG Spy and Fairy, and others. All these lights use sub-CR2 size batteries such as the 10180, 10220, and 10280 sizes, which is why they're so small and fit into these cases. I really like them for that too as it protects the lights, especially when I'm traveling. Overall it's a decent holder. It would be 5 stars if it weren't for the CR123A problem which as I said doesn't really affect me much.

Great old time war movie with incredible and very realistic action scenes and with a fabulous all star cast. The movie makes clear some of the problems that contributed to the disaster, such as the correct deployment and use of the radar, the order to group the planes which made them more vulnerable, and the fact that admiral Kimmel had no direct phone line from his home to the base and a courier had to be used. I just watched the movie again recently after a span of many years and it held up very well. Overall a fine old war flick that has stood the test of time and is worth your time and money.

Although I enjoyed the series the problem with this program is that there are so many historical inaccuracies as to render it practically useless as history, which is why the four stars, but it probably should be 3.0 or 3.5. These have been discussed in the many one star reviews by people far more knowledgeable than I so I'm not going to comment on that here except to point you to those if you're interested. But there are a lot of American history buffs out there, many of whom have spent their whole lives reading about it and they basically hated this program.From a dramatic and character portrayal standpoint though I think the series does better as it shows Adams as the fair-minded, intelligent, articulate, stubborn, and sometimes vain and socially awkward individual that he was, and as a man totally dedicated to his country, whatever his personal flaws might be. Giamatti did well in that regard as did the actress that played his wife, Laura Linney, whose intelligence and character were of great value to Adams and that comes thru here. Veteran actor Tom Wilkinson as Ben Franklin is also a plus, as was David Morse as Washington, although Wasington's part is quite low key until later in the series, which is okay as this is supposed to be about Adams. The actor who played Jefferson was also good and at least the series accurately portrays the tension between the northern bankers and the southern planters and between the Federalist and Republican views on government.I also agree with many other commenters who pointed out the series spends too much time highlighting the low points in Adams's career and the negatives in his character which were minor compared to his many great strengths. There are also those who hated Giamatti's portrayal of Adams and to see a real hatchet job on that see Stanley White's comment under Brandon Price's Highlight review for an informed take on that. I guess you could say it's priceless. :-)To mention one other positive thing, the script and dialog are snappy and taught; too bad they couldn't stick better to the facts as the series would truly merit five stars then. So overall a mixed bag but possibly worth your while as a dramatic story if you keep in mind the series's fast and loose take on the facts.

I think that Simple Green Smoothies, from the ladies who run the well-known website with the same name, is much more than just a smoothie cookbook. The drinks are all “Green Smoothies,” which they define as: leafy greens, plus fruit, plus liquids.
