It’s not a crash diet book, but there are testimonials of losing weight by replacing a daily meal with a green smoothie (There are several lists of optional “booster” ingredients, including a list of more substantial boosters when using smoothies as a meal replacement, like grains, seeds, and more). And while there are mentions of cleanses, this is clearly something I can drink everyday. I also found the book to be quite fun with lots of goofing-off photos and puns galore. My family’s favorite smoothie (so far) is probably the Simple Melon smoothie, which includes spinach, coconut water, honeydew, and pineapple. It’s refreshing and delicious, and takes just a minute to make. My kids also love their layered ice pops, and I’ve been known to sneak one or two myself. I would like to work my way through every single recipe. I always feel great after drinking one, and I’m thrilled at how much nutrition can get packed into one smoothie!

This cute story describes the different sides that people (and yetis) have — loving winter AND summer — and why that’s a good thing. It has some really good messages, like learning to be flexible and the limits of labeling yourself. My kids (and I) love to look through the cute illustrations, which have a fun, flat illustrative style, which reminds me of retro animation, with an updated look. Each illustration has clever details and my kids giggle about all of the fun activities Yetis enjoy. I also appreciate that the children are multicultural and there is even one child participating in the fun from a wheelchair, which is great. The book itself is well-made and well-bound, with thick, high-quality paper and printing, and a fancy book jacket. This is a delightful book that my family and I enjoy re-reading again and again.

I enjoyed studying art history in college, especially the lavishly painted still-life’s of flowers — everything from Breughel to O’Keefe, I love them all. Veranda's The Romance of Flowers raises photography to the level of the great masters. Each full-page painterly photo and double-spread panorama show the absolute heights of artful, still-life photography, and the wide variety of flower arranging as well. It’s a brilliant coffee table book, in the very best sense. It’s all so incredibly beautiful, I’ve never seen anything quite like it before, just one jaw-dropping photo after another.There is a limited amount of text, portrayed in large and lovely typefaces — some quotations related to flowers, some inspirational keywords, some discussions of floral arranging, and so forth — which is engaging and well-written on its own, but primarily acts as a complement to the lavish photography. The book itself is very well-bound, with about 300 thick and large, semi-gloss pages (10.5″ x 12.5″). It is a masterwork in its own right, and a beautiful addition to my library and, yes, the new, gorgeous focus of my coffee table.

I grew up near the ocean, and actually lived for a while in the South Pacific, so I really like this coloring book. It has lovely designs, all in a circular style, and is good for relaxing. But mostly I enjoy the various nautical designs and themes throughout. My favorites are those with mermaids, sailing ships, and surfboards. I suppose my favorite though is one with waves and small fish, in a yin-yang spiral. The book is softcover, and not too big to carry or bring with you. The designs are consistently drawn, lovely throughout and really enjoyable. I use my sharpest colored pencils for these since most have fine details, so I enjoy that, too. I found this to be a truly delightful all-ages coloring book, and I hope that illustrator Wendy Piersall publishes more soon!

Making sushi for dinner is something I regularly do. And what I mean by that is, basically I make various versions of California Rolls, and that’s about it.  As far as I can tell, this is basically a sushi chef textbook — as it seems to teach just about everything a professional sushi chef would need to know. Yet, authors Elliot and Cook make these skills accessible to anyone in their beautiful and lavishly photographed book. Every style of sushi is laid out, step-by-step, showing how to make all the big sellers, in every conceivable style. Sashimi? Check. Sushi-in-a-bowl (Chirashi)? Check. Those little sushi-cup-things (Gunkanmaki)? Check. Pressed and stuffed sushi (Oshizushi and Inarizushi)? Check. California Roll? Spicy Tuna Roll? Tempura Shrimp Roll? Spider Roll? Dragon Roll? Rainbow Roll? All of our favorites are here and accounted for, along with many more, each shown step-by-step with a photo and explanatory text. There is also extensive info on all the various sauces, accompaniments, knives, and different fishes, along with how to prepare them in detail. Everything is presented so clearly and in such a straightforward manner that anyone could learn how (even me), alongside numerous helpful sidebars and explanations. And it’s all actually really simple, once I saw it laid out like this. My whole family is thrilled with my broadening sushi skills, including me.

Since I have been a huge fan of the author for what seems like forever, I was thrilled to have this opportunity to have a peek into her life! I loved the format, with text, photos and her lovely watercolor illustrations all together in one book and I found it hard to put down until I had read it cover to cover. This volume covers her moving away from California — and the fallout of her heartbreaking divorce — at the end of her twenties. Everything else is told as extended flashbacks, of her young adulthood, and then childhood. Her story intertwines with numerous quotes, song lyrics, photos, illustrations, and more. I really enjoyed reading about Susan’s growing interest in cooking, home decor, gardening, and domestic life. One of my favorite parts in the book is the story of Susan sharing her personal, watercolor recipe cards with a friend. The wise and insightful friend encouraged her to collect and publish them — an excellent foreshadowing of her future career. I found The Fairy Tale Girl to be told in an engaging and visually delightful way, and I very much look forward to reading and enjoying the upcoming second volume!

I’m a firm believer that Lucky Peach is the real deal. And their new book, Lucky Peach Presents 101 Easy Asian Recipes, proves it. These are genuinely simple-to-prepare meals — no frying (at least deep frying) and no sub-recipes (except a few epic sauces and condiments, if you like). It’s comprehensive in a way few cookbooks attempt, yet easy and fun to read, and just as easy and fun to cook. The cover promises recipes which are “100% INAUTHENTIC” and while they’re not remotely junk food, they aren’t expensively or meticulously high-end either. Their Summer Rolls seem pretty authentic to me, but I don’t remember finding fresh mint and basil leaves in them before, which is so good. My kids asked if our scrambled eggs can always be Dashimaki Tamago from now on (YES). I just buy frozen dumplings now ($2 a bag!) but their Dumpling Dipping Sauce is perfect for elevating them to flavorful heights.Their Miso and Doenjang Jigae Soups have become frequent favorites for our whole family, too. We have made Slow Cooker Pho twice, including once with meatballs and store-bought stock, and it was great both times (the short ribs version was greater, though). The recipes range across Asia, often in unexpected ways, including what for me was their two most unexpected recipes of all: Corn Cheese (which is a Korean bar snack that my kids are love), and their first and foremost dessert recipe: Oranges (“Cut them up or don’t.”).Each recipe has a sense of being urgently written, just as they’re designed to be prepared, which is also like the book itself, which all has a slightly random yet perfect awesomeness unlike any other cookbook I’ve read. The text explaining unfamiliar Asian ingredients is spot-on, yet sold-on-the-sidewalk accessible. It’s all like this quote about buying the best sushi rice: “Our blunt but hopefully helpful Goldilocks advice on that: Don’t scrape the bottom of the barrel, but don’t reach for the clouds either. The middle is just right.” Which sums up the book very well. Just right.

I’ve never had the chance to go to The Hot Bread Kitchen, where women who have immigrated from all over the world offer their favorite breads from home, and they get an education in the American culinary world at the same time. Yet, I’ve been able to learn so much from this cookbook about lots of delicious breads from all over the world. The book starts off with a fantastic grilled flat bread, m’smen, from Morrocco. Mine didn’t look quite like those from the bakery when I tried the recipe, but my family loves them! Great for eating with hummus (recipe included) and curries (like the beef and potato curry recipe, also included here, which is simple yet so flavorful), or folded with cheeses and other ingredients inside, like a quesadilla from heaven. We’re looking forward to trying the naan next.We also enjoyed the olive oil focaccia, although I was in a hurry, so I didn’t let it rise much, and while not as fluffy and light as shown in the book’s photo, it still turned out crusty, flavorful, and fantastic — we love it with pasta dishes instead of regular garlic bread. I like how the book shows how to use one type of dough, like pate fermentee or traditional challah, and uses it for other baked goods, like bialys or rolls. I also appreciated the section which explains how to use leftover breads too, like their epic tres leches bread pudding, which is my favorite recipe so far. I also found their frequent anecdotes about women succeeding, in their work and in life, to be very inspiring.

In this classic book, everyone is happy to see Jimmy Jinks, The Fixit Man, wherever he goes. I am glad to see G+D Vintage sharing these classic books with children today. This version, in 8″ by 11″ hardcover, features the original illustrations as first published in 1952. The Fixit Man finds that people would be happy to get some help wherever they are, in town or country, in the mountains or at the seaside. Of course, in serving other, the happiest one is Jimmy Jinks, himself, which I think is a wonderful moral to this simple tale.

The Christmas Puppy is the original 1953 children’s picture book, republished for a new generation. I read this book with my grandmother when I was child, and as a new 9″ x 12″ hardcover presented with its original text and illustrations, it’s just as adorable as I remembered it. In the story,  Polly’s letter to Santa Claus for a toy puppy arrives on Christmas Eve, and Mrs. Santa says there is no time to make her a new one… but then Santa sees his own dog, Jingle — who just had puppies — and has “a wonderful idea.” Now, I'm so glad that I can share this sweet story with my own new grandkids!

My daughter loves the Disney princesses and is a big fan of characters from the Littlest Pet Shop and My Little Pony characters. I thought that this book kind of pulls those together into one adorable animal. It also does a good job of teaching the basic techniques of illustration starting with basic shapes, then adding secondary shapes, then filling in details. Each Disney princess has a little pony to draw, and a cute pet — kittens, puppies, etc. It’s helpful how the basic shapes are shown in different colors, and my daughters really love the cute style.

This set includes two parts, a book showing suggestions of how to fill out basic shapes into 26 different animals. The second part of the set, is found in the glossy folding cover, and has a drawing pad with the original basic shape included. This is helping my kids learn that, by starting off with general shapes, they can add details to create anything they want to draw — including all kinds of animals! There is extra space on the drawing pad, and my kids love to create their own animals by re-drawing the original shapes, and adding details from there.

We have some little artists in our home, and I want to encourage that, but worry that they won’t be able to transition from their doodles to serious artwork in the future. When I was young and trying to draw, I didn’t understand that most artists draw out the basic shapes and then fill in the details. This book and kit comes with an art set, and magnetic closing case. I especially like how the book shows how to draw simple cartoon-ish shapes, and then fill them out into a cute character. I think it’s a good skill for kids to learn while young, plus they are having a lot of fun making their own characters.

I’m really liking these sponges. Normally, I replace sponges — every couple weeks or so — before they get yucky; it’s kind of expensive, inconvenient, and one more thing to remember at the store. As far as I can tell, the Pura Natural sponges don’t smell at all. So that’s great. But more than that, these are much sturdier sponges than what we normally use, no matter how expensive.They are thicker as well, so they soak up more spilled liquids than regular sponges. They also seem to be very long lasting. The scrubber materials are tough but don’t scratch. The embedded bits of soap work well and is gentle on my hands. And when I rinse them out, all the water runs out — in one squeeze. These are simply better sponges than anything else I’ve ever used.

I’ve been concerned about my health and working to increase my well-being by eating more carefully, and getting more exercise, including yoga. The Essential Ayurvedic Cookbook, has been a big help to me in finding healthy and balanced ways of cooking in a realistic way for today’s modern world. Of the 350 pages, about 100 are devoted to offering guidelines for balanced Ayurvedic foods.From among the 200 recipes offered here, the ones I’ve tried are delicious and very healthy, including the Yogurt Parfait, which includes pumpkin seeds, sunflower seeds, and slivered almonds with goji berries and is now one of my favorite breakfasts. My family all loves the Broiled Lime Ginger Shrimp, which offers sweet, sour, and savory elements! Most of the recipes are predictably Indian, but they range across the globe. This book would be a must for anyone exploring a healthier diet, especially based on Ayurvedic principles.

This is the first time I've tried Niacinamide in a skin care product and I feel like it's working really well for me. I know the B vitamins play a large role in keeping skin healthy, so i thought it was interesting that they use Vitamin B3 as part of their formula.  I'm glad it is made without including alcohol, as I find products that have alcohol to be quite drying to my skin. It soaked into my skin very quickly and my skin seems tighter and firmer after applying it. My skin also has a healthy glow after applying, too.  It seems to  be helping with some light acne scarring I have, as well as the fine lines around my eyes, I hope it will continue to do so.

I love cooking shows, especially those that include travel and a sense of adventure. So, I’m very happy about this book, which goes along with a new TV series (available on PBS) to America from New Zealand, where author/chef Annabel Langbein is a popular chef. It’s a beautiful book, with tons of lovely photos of the dishes and of Annabel exploring “Middle Earth.”There are many deliciously rustic recipes included, most of which are simple to make, and elevate simple ingredients easily and deliciously. The recipes are grouped around regional menus that span the globe, like the Turkish Bride Soup, which is one of my new favorites. It’s a hearty lentil soup with lemon and mint that brighten the flavor. It’s traditionally served to brides on the evening before the wedding to sustain them throughout the busy day ahead. My favorite menu so far is the Asian Summer Meal, which includes refreshing Pork and Cilantro Spring Rolls, with a sweet and spicy Apricot Chili Glaze.The recipes are healthy, yet often quite hearty, like my husband’s favorite Cowboy Hash, which he makes himself on weekend mornings. My children’s favorite recipe has to be the Orange Lightning Cake (because you can make it so quickly), although I use a fine grater for the orange zest, then blend the orange segments, rather than blending the entire orange. Gorgeous photos, too!

Max and Marla is so darling! Max and his non-speaking friend, Marla the owl, have decided to become Winter Olympians. I love how Max cares for Marla, for example, carrying the little owl to bed when she falls asleep while waxing their sled’s runners. I like how the story shows the importance of working to make things go well, rather than merely hoping they will, and how caring for others can make any effort a victory in its own right. The book also has some of the cutest illustrations I have ever seen. I also loved all the blues throughout the book. This is a lovely and charming book for children of all ages.

I found Robo-Sauce to be a simple, heart-warming story — with a big surprise at the end! It starts out with a boy, dressed as a robot, who is bothering his family. When they leave without seeing how much fun it is to play robot, the narrator offers the boy the top-secret formula for robo-sauce, which will change him into a real robot. But, things go awry and everyone, even the book itself, transforms into a robot!Spoiler alert: When I reached the page that reads, “ACTIVATE ROBO-STORY,” I found a hidden, silver-foil printed book cover, folded up inside. So I covered the book, and inverted it, then read the rest of the book (backwards). It’s a simple device that is nonetheless very creative and fun. I’ve actually never seen anything like it. I think Robo-Sauce is a very clever book and my kids loved the surprise at the end, too!

So many gorgeous ideas! I think that they would also work well for just about any outdoor rustic themed party. The arrangements are pretty simple to create and they show suggestions for decorations or centerpieces. Each floral creation has a large photo that shows the details of the project and I really liked how many of the ideas used recycled items. For instance, I love the hanging bottles, which are actually empty soda bottles, filled with some water and fresh flowers (they used beautiful yellow roses) and hung on a tree with jute twine. Lots of simple, yet lovely ideas!

Love these pretty favors! There’s lots of ideas using kraft paper, doilies, burlap and more. There’s a full page photo for each project and a shopping list of what is needed to make it. The instructions are brief and easy to follow. My favorite ideas are the cute succulent plants in tiny terra cotta pots and I also think the birdseed hearts would make a nice decoration in addition to gifts!

I’d actually love to see a movie version of The Last Kids on Earth, which tells a comic story about a team of friends facing off against zombies and monsters at the end(?) of the world. I enjoyed the first person narration as it describes the clever weapons and tactics they use to mostly avoid — and occasionally fend off — the monstrous people of this small town. The story moves along quickly, with lots of fun humor. My concerns that the book might turn grotesque or violent were unfounded, and I found that the characters, which include the hero/narrator, a strong female (who is definitely not in distress), a brainy friend, and a now-reformed bully, do a good job of showing how great teams can succeed together. I also really liked the illustrations that were part of the story, too. I really appreciated the fun and wholesome messages about friendship, teamwork, and trying to be happy and enjoy life — even during difficult circumstances.

This book is small and easy to carry or take with you and I also love the lovely floral hardcover. I like how simple it is to add a quick thought for the day, but after five years of doing so, it will amount to a lot of memories. It also gives me the opportunity to compare from year to year to see how my  feelings and life has changed over the five years it covers.The writing suggestions include thoughtful ideas like: Describe a beautiful moment with your child or What is getting easier in your life? In addition to it being a nice way for evaluate my progress, I also think it would make a lovely heirloom to pass on to my children or grandchildren one day. I would love to have something like that from my own grandmother.

I'm really liking this product, it feels very healing and soothing to my skin. It is a clear gel that soaks into my skin very quickly and with no residue or greasiness left after it is applied.  I also like the easy to use pump. With my skin aging, I've noticed some rough spot and dry patches. This completely evens them out  and also gives my face a very smooth base for applying makeup afterwards. On the bottle it says it thickens the skin and I'm not exactly sure what that means, but my skin definitely does feel stronger and younger after applying. I also noticed that the smooth feeling lasts for days after I use it.

I was excited to see that Eric Carle has a new book out, and my kids and I are really enjoying this funny book that is a little different from his others, since this one has silly, word play instead. I like how Carle continues to grow and expand his artistic style, and I think his use of colors is fantastic.

In my work as a party printable designer, I have become familiar with Gemma Touchstone and her incredible party styling. I’m thrilled to be able to  see her brand new book. This smaller-sized paperback is completely jam-packed with creative ideas and fun party planning suggestions. It’s very easy to grab and flip through and the layout makes it easy to skim and get some quick inspiration!I enjoyed taking the quiz to find out what type of party person I am and I love the delicious recipes, too. She has lots of really fantastic edibles, like gorgeous rainbow-hued rock candy quenchers. There are many finger food ideas, ranging from a bacon burger on a stick to many different individual jar snacks. All of them are ideal for serving at just about any type of celebration or gathering.There is so much helpful information throughout, I loved the section on exactly what types of decorations you could use for a party. There is also a large amount of game ideas and many specific party themes shown in stunning photo collages. I found this book to be a comprehensive party planning book with literally everything I could want to help prepare for a party and lots more!

I really like how this book contains a story with a story within another story. The first is about a little girl and her grandfather getting ready on Christmas Eve — making little snowmen, and frosting sugar cookies. The second is a war story about how the Grandfather’s grandfather got a copy of the Book of Mormon for Christmas one year, and how later, he was comforted by reading The Book of Mormon when he was lost during a war.And the third is the story of Nephi having to fight his brothers, but loving them anyway. There is lots to learn and talk about with this warm and charming book. The illustrations are well-done, and I like their vintage look they had, too. I think this is sure to be a Christmas classic in many family’s homes.

I think that this book is a fun way to apologize when it may be kind of hard to do so. Couldn’t just about anyone use a little help with that? I know I could! I especially liked the “apuglogy in advance” and my son’s favorite was one that just says, “Ooooopppssss”. All twenty of the coupon style tear out pages have a cute pug and funny apology and then the back has lines for you to write out your sincere apuglogy. It's a perfect size for a stocking stuffer, too.

I definitely know some book nerds, including my husband and oldest daughter, who both majored in English and love the classics. This book would work well as a gift to a book-loving friend. Or, if you know someone who enjoys a particular book, it would also work well for removing the lovely book-themed illustrations and framing them individually. I found many favorites of my own in there, too, including the precious children in Grimm’s Fairy Tales and the striking image of Homer’s Odyssey.

I think this card pack is a fantastic idea! I have several of the grown up coloring books and have often thought how nice it would be to give them as a card, but they really just weren’t a good size for it. I also love the beautiful illustrations and all of the sayings, some of which are funny or just sweet. Very thick pages and they work great with my standard colored pencils and gel pens! Really nice gift for yourself or others.

There are lots of great recipes in the Mug Shots Desserts! I’ve tried various mug brownies and (literal) cupcake recipes online, but thought that was all there was. But there are many clever ideas here, that I would have never thought of on my own. For example, Rice Krispie treats, monkey bread, pineapple upside-down cakes, cheesecake(!), and even creme brulee. Some require you to use the various power settings on your microwave, which I hadn’t really used before, I’ve found that the recipes were really spot-on, and made great treats in just a minute or two.I had some leftover pumpkin in an opened can in the frig, so I tried out the pumpkin pie recipe. I was concerned about how the custardy dessert would cook in the microwave, but it turned out fantastic! There were no hard parts or uncooked parts and I cooked it in a fairly tall and thin mug. I love to eat pumpkin all year round, I’m thrilled to have a super fast and easy pumpkin recipe to make!

When I see a crochet pattern, it can be hard for me to envision if the style would fit well on me or not. I like how this book has already tailored the sweaters to specific body types, so I have much better idea if the garment is one that would work for me or not. It explains the different body types and then has a sweater to create that will flatter that particular type. The instructions are very clear and helpful, with many color photos throughout and there is much helpful info on catering patterns to body types, too.Since I am a novice crocheter, I especially appreciated the tips about fixing things that didn’t turn out quite the way that I had hoped they would. Uneven edges is a problem I have always had and they had some good suggestions on how to prevent and fix that issue. One extra that I enjoyed, was the pretty edgings that I can add to my sweaters to personalize them a bit. My favorite was the Neapolitan Lace that has a lovely scalloped look.
The best product I've found for removing the extremely hard water stains we have where I live.
Got the pink one for my teenage daughter, she has used it constantly and it has held up well.
I bought this for my daughter, who uses it non-stop. I appreciated the option to do the payment plan. Has worked great for us!
Arrived quickly and in excellent condition. Bought as a gift and they loved the color choices and quality.

I love Food 52’s previous book, Genius Recipes, so I knew I’d love this one, too. It’s well-bound, with gorgeous full-page photos of each recipe, and recipes which are all pretty easily made, but turn out tasting like something that took you half the day to make. Of the recipes I’ve made so far, I like “Bestest Banana Bread” the best(est), and my husband’s favorite is the Six Ingredient PB&J Sandwich Cookies. My kids really liked the No-Knead Thin-Crust Pizzas, because everyone gets to make their own delicious work of pizza art and they are ready to eat very quickly (important with kids!).The Brown Sugar Shortbread (with three ingredients) turned out wonderfully, too. The brown sugar added a nice browned-butter flavor. I’ll definitely be sharing these around the holidays, which was suggested by the book’s listing of all the recipes divided up by occasion (“For Bringing to a Dinner Party”, etc.). Next week is my daughter’s birthday, and I can’t wait to make the Coconut Tres Leches Cake for her, which I know my whole family will love. I’m really glad I got Food52 Baking, it’s one of my very favorite baking books ever.

I appreciate how this book shows how to make enjoyable and authentic Italian food — without pasta, bread, or other gluten sources. It is also a beautifully designed and photographed book. The soft-bound, full-color book begins with several “starters,” including info about Italy, the Paleo lifestyle, how to set up your kitchen, and numerous cooking tips.The recipes include basics, sauces, condiments, appetizers, salads, brunch, Tuscan favorites, soups, stews, meat & poultry, seafood, sides, and (my favorite!) desserts. There is also a section of pasta dishes which use vegetables to replace pasta, such as Spaghetti Squash Puttanesca, I love this recipe for using one of my favorite veggies.My favorite recipe overall is probably the sole piccata, which is fantastic, yet is easily made and works well for a variety of different fish. I also made the Tuscan vegetable and herb-baked omelette for a my family and I’ve also tried the Osso Bucco, but with a less expensive cut of meat. Both were delicious! Such a beautiful book, with many authentic recipes from Italy that anyone (paleo or not) would enjoy.

I’ve shared different stories of flights I’ve gone on with my kids, so when we see planes flying by, they’ll sometimes ask how this or that works. How to Build a Plane makes it easy for me to teach them about just how planes work. The story line of friends building a plane together is fun and engaging, and the diagrams are fantastic — with a clarity and warmth you rarely see together. There is also a section about how planes actually fly, and what the instrument gauges are for. I think this book would be engaging for children of all ages, especially if they have an interest in flight.

I’m really impressed with this book. I have a son who is destined to be an engineer of some kind, as he is always trying to figure out how everything works, especially vehicles, and he loves this book. It’s from the junior division of art-book publisher Walter Foster, so the illustrations are excellent, both in terms of their detailed, retro appeal, and also in how accurate and informative they are.Diagrams of the various components, such as the engine or suspension, are fun for kids, yet fully accurate, with little flags noting which part is which. The “technical tale” features a fairly in-depth story line of some anthropomorphic critters who decide they need to build a car. And although at first glance it seems like it is “just a kids book,” it encompasses everything I remember from a year of Auto 101, and then some.

This is a really cute book that offers solid information about dog breeds and how to care for your puppy. My kids love reading through it, it is fun and has many adorable illustrations throughout. We’re talking through the book together as we plan our family’s next addition to our home. It’s a fun, easy-to-read yet reliable guide to all things puppies.

We recently adopted a new kitten, so my kids and I are really enjoying this book. It has cute illustrations on every page, and it breaks up accurate and reliable information into kid-sized bits that are fun to read, and helpful. We’ve especially learned a lot from the grooming and training sections.

My daughter-in-law is having a baby, and it’ll be our first grandchild. I got her this book, which was produced by three doctors from The Hospital for Sick Children in Toronto, one of the world’s leading pediatric care hospitals since 1875. The book provides exactly what the title claims, covering the basics in a friendly and concise book which still manages to be extensive and authoritative. It’s easy to read, with each chapter divided up into lots of very small sections, including sidebars, notes, pull quotes, FAQs, and “Works Best for…” bullet points, with clear headings, so you can find what you’re looking for quickly (even in the middle of a 3 a.m. feeding).I’ve had several children of my own and have had some training as a midwife, so I was glad to see the practical, accurate, relaxed and down-to-earth information new parents need, with a minimum of panic-inducing “see your doctor” commands. For example “Sleep when your baby sleeps,” is just the sort of advice every new mother needs, as well as a chapter introduction that advises new moms to just focus on them and the baby their first month together. There are many practical tips, like how to hold and swaddle your infant. There is some great info on breast-feeding, including different positions, how to get a good latch, and treating common problems.The book continues on through the first year, covering sleep, eating, teeth, and sickness, with some helpful charts on development stages. I especially liked the listing of how to interpret your baby’s cries — which generally increases toward 6 weeks, and diminishes thereafter, the book notes. The soft-cover book is well-bound, with nice paper, and includes lots of photos for reference as well.

In many ways, this book is a major work, with a fascinating interpretation of what a taco (and it’s many cousins) can be. The many variations of sauces, salsas, fillings, and toppings of all kinds are well-considered and delicious, respecting tradition while innovating in equal measure. For instance, the simple green cilantro sauce, which takes no more than two minutes to make, is really a revelation to me and I make it regularly now.Similarly, the various molcajete sauces included here (with alternate instructions for making them in a blender) are each fantastic, and for me, refreshingly new. Her numerous fresh pico salsas are fresh and delicious, and we end up eating them alone with chips or added to every Mexican meal we have.  My family also loves the orange and lemon juices and zests in her Cuban-style pork recipe, which is a new family favorite.Another one of our favorites is her recipe for crab salad, which I keep ready in the fridge, it’s a great meal or snack for the whole family, including in fresh wraps or burritos. There’s so much that I’m enjoying about this sophisticated, yet family-friendly, cook book, the recipes and photography are just fantastic!

I think this set will appeal to many people, including fans of chess, cats, dogs, and fans of origami. This set includes 100+ sheets of origami paper, printed with various designs (including photos of fur), along with a surprisingly substantial book with visual instructions that make it really easy. I loved how the dogs and cats are sitting in cute little positions, and each sits on its own chesspiece marked stand. The nice 2-sided chessboard is included. I’ve just gotten started with making my favorite cats and dogs first, and I’m really enjoying this set!

This is a large set which recreates Noah and his ark — in folded-paper oriami figures. The set includes a large case with plentiful papers for creating the 13 figures of Noah and his wife, and 11 different animals to go along with them on the ark. The book provides basic instructions for origami generally and then walks through the steps needed to create each figure. Plus, there is the ark itself, which my daughter put together herself easily. I liked how the book includes a 26-page discussion of the story and research of Noah’s ark. We’ve already made Noah and a couple of the animals and are hoping to make them all.

For me, this book + art supplies seems like a crafting set with a purpose. Rather than simply crafting for its own sake, it shows that crafting is most fun when making something for someone you love and appreciate. The set includes colored pencils, a sharpener, two stencils, blank greeting cards, and matching envelopes to create unique and fun thank-you cards that my children have enjoyed making. The booklet included is short and sweet, with several great ideas for making spectacular home-made greeting cards. My children especially liked making the fingerprint doodles, along with the pop-up cards.

I liked how, since the recipes begin in her San Francisco home, I could get a sense of the author's favorite tastes and culinary perspective — vegetarian with a pan-Asian bent — for her later unique interpretations. I also enjoyed the listing of pantry items she would stock for each type of cuisine, which I found really helpful and informative. The book is well-designed and written, with helpful descriptions and tips, alongside beautiful modern photos of foods and scenes in each area she visits.I haven’t tried all the recipes, but some stand-outs for me so far were the shredded tofu stir-fry from San Francisco, although I substituted stir-fried greens for the pea shoots. I took her tip and rolled it up in spring roll wrappers, and my whole family enjoyed them. I’ve also tried the spring rolls, with brown sugar tofu and mushrooms, and I loved how the brown sugar carmelized the tofu and mushrooms, creating a sweet-and-savory combination.From Morocco,  the Harira soup was delicious, with chickpeas and seasonings like a mild masala, and a little bit of fresh lemon at the finish. The ricotta crespelle pancakes from Italy are a favorite of my husband, and I prefer them with the whipped egg whites, per Heidi’s suggestion. Her listing of kitchen basic recipes is very helpful, including her orange thyme za’atar seasoning. She suggests adding this mix to ripe avocado with a drizzle of olive oil, which I’ve been enjoying as part of a quick lunch. This is a substantial and well-written cookbook, that I’d recommend to anyone who enjoys expanding their palate.

I’ve often wondered how Iron Chefs cook at home. I think I  might have found the answer in this book. Based on the popular segment on The Chew, his food-oriented talk show, this sequel to his previous, best-selling book lays out very original recipes, based on simplified versions of high-end restaurant fare.  TBH, I haven’t actually eaten many dishes like those Symon offers within, but they all look fresh, healthy and inviting.A major theme seems to be salad-as-meal. Many take an unusual/trendy green or vegetable of some kind — raw, shaved Brussel sprouts and chopped endive are favorites — served with a quickly prepared protein, and served with a light sauce, frequently a vinaigrette. There are not a lot of starches, although a few pasta dishes do show up, like the Spaghetti Puttanesca, which was delicious even though I substituted a less-expensive kind of canned tomato.So far, I found the Spicy Salami, Cantaloupe & Mint Salad to be surprising and fun, which is served with a light vinaigrette and a spoonful of Greek yogurt. My family really likes several of the shrimp dishes, including the Thai-Style Shrimp Salad, served on finely sliced napa cabbage, and Shrimp in Coconut Broth, which is like a Thai soup but with tomatoes. Everything is very light and fresh, and I’m looking forward to trying more recipes.

I’ve always wanted to visit London, so I’m really enjoying coloring and learning from this book. It features a 9-inch tall, single panorama of London, featuring tiny people among all the sights to see. Since it is folded, accordian-style, I can color a little bit at a time. The back shows a detailed plan for a stroll to see the most famous landmarks of London, with interesting facts about each. It’s really fun to color and I think it would make a great decoration or a fun gift for someone planning a trip to London.

I hope the BabyLit book series might lead to a love for the classics for my children, plus, they are a lot of fun to read! Emma teaches infants, toddlers, and their literary-minded parents how to recognize different emotions, in this case, as shown by the characters of Jane Austen’s literary classic, “Emma”. The left side of each two-page spread will say someone is feeling a certain emotion, and on the right, the vintage style illustrations features character feeling it — “MIss Taylor is happy,” or “Emma is excited.” As for me, I am delighted with this charming book series, and am pleased to read them (over and over) to my children.

This board book teaches shapes by including them in illustrations based around people and things in Robert Louis Stevenson’s classic, Treasure Island. So, the left side of each two-page spread features a basic geometric shape, and there are vintage-style, lithograph-like, Treasure-Island-y illustrations on the right, so the triangle is shown in the Hispaniola’s sails, and an oval can be found in Long John SIlver’s eye patch. Great way to introduce my children to the classics!

Charlie and the Chocolate Factory was such a huge part of my childhood. I read the book over and over many times, and also looked forward with great anticipation the whole year to when the movie would be on TV. The book was not only incredibly entertaining and engaging, but it also taught valuable lessons in terms of children’s behavior, and I pondered on the character’s examples time and time again. My kids and I had fun making our own version of the lickable wallpaper from the book. One of my favorite snacks as a kid was graham crackers spread with vanilla frosting, so I thought that by adding some colorful fruit shaped Runts candies, it could evoke that delicious wallpaper from the classic book. Although Mr. Wonka did run a chocolate factory, I loved all of his imaginative candy creations!

I found this book to be an incredibly charming coloring book and amazing visual journey, it would make a wonderful gift, for any child or adult coloring fan. There is a brief text story at the start and end, while the detailed illustrations lead us through a dreamlike journey. The story is about a young girl who, late one night, decides to investigate her family’s new cuckoo clock. She somehow climbs inside and pulls a lever which reveals the clockworks underlying reality… and more. It’s a beautiful story, which works well as a stand-alone children’s book, and as an adult-level coloring book, too. It’s a simply lovely book and one of the finest and most sophisticated coloring books that I’ve seen.

This small yet thick book would make an excellent gift for anyone involved in designing things for a living or as an avocation, visually or otherwise, both as an introduction or refresher. These principles often concern issues of communication and persuasion, so I believe it could be very beneficial for anyone involved in marketing or advertising as well. It names a principle, gives illuminating visual examples, and clearly describes it in brief text. Each principle is described in a few paragraphs on each little two-page spread.I think that by reading (or revisiting) these well-described concepts, one would develop Depth of Processing (“Thinking hard about a thing improves the likelihood that it can be recalled.”) and avoid the Dunning-Kruger Effect (“A tendency for unskilled people to overestimate their competence and performance.”). Even though I’ve been designing professionally for many years, I find myself turning to this exceptionally helpful book, over and over again.

Anyone who draws or paints will need to draw plant life at some point. For me, it seemed to take forever to draw trees, bushes, or flowers, and my results can seem overworked besides. I have wondered how illustrators managed to suggest a properly proportioned tree with just a few lines, and just the right amount of detail? I discovered that author/artist Matt Pagett has many answers to my nature questions, and showed me how to sketch plants with a light-yet-expressive touch, as detailed and/or evocative as I needed.Pagett reviews the basic media (pencil, pen, charcoal, paper etc,) and elements of art (line, tone, color, composition, etc.) in a brisk yet helpful fashion. A variety of truly beneficial exercises follow, and a series of approaching different styles as well. In addition, there is a second exercise sketch book included — both held within an additional hardbound cover — which is also exceptionally useful. I’d highly recommend this for anyone ready to expand their nature (and other) drawing skills.

According to Van Gogh, “Drawing is the root of everything, and the time spent on that is actually all profit.” For those who wish to spend their time more profitably, while being inspired by a true master, I think that this beautiful and inspiring sketchbook would make a wonderful gift. Each page features an original Van Gogh sketch, licensed from the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam, and many include quotes from (what I assume were taken from) letters to his art-dealer brother, Theo.Most of Van Gogh’s quotes seem to be comments about the artistic process, while others recognize the amount of work that it takes to create successful art, all of which I found to be encouraging. “I can’t help but make progress precisely through learning by doing; every drawing one makes, every study one paints is a step…” “for the great doesn’t happen through impulse alone, and is a succession of little things that are brought together.”I was able to find ample space for drawing in the large and beautiful hardbound book. There is lots of space to emulate the master, or strike out on one’s own. And even if some of my drawings are less than a success, well, as Van Gogh says, “…one must spoil as many canvases as one succeeds with", so I'm trying to be patient with myself while learning.

This cute tale shows that hanging out with your sister is not a bad thing. It (very) loosely follows the storyline of Edgar Allan Poe’s “The Fall of the House of Usher,” as Edgar the raven tries to play in his friend’s treehouse — no girls allowed. I think the illustrations are clever and fun, with gothic touches throughout, and offers a warm ending that I enjoyed. The restrained palette reminds me of classic books like “Harry the Dirty Dog.” I think this would work well for parents with very young children, who hope to share books like “A Series of Unfortunate Events” with them someday — Edgar and the Tree House of Usher would be a great place to start!

I love cardmaaking, it takes me back to arts and crafts class at school (my favorite class by far!). This book is filled with gorgeous cards and has given me lots of inspiration, especially for the holidays, which is the main time I end up making cards. It’s really fun for me to look at all the great styles, I’ve gotten a lot of ideas for designs. I love adding pins, buttons and other embellishments on my cards to make them three dimensional, too. I usually focus on making cards, but I found some gift tags and I need to try those out, too. I think they’d look really cute on a mason jar filled with cookie mix for the holidays.

I got this crochet kit for my daughter, as she is enjoying practicing her crocheting skills. She taught herself to crochet with the help of books from our local library and also YouTube videos and is getting pretty good at it. This kit has all the materials to make Mickey and Donald, and it also comes with a little book that has instructions for making those two, plus Minnie Daisy, Goofy, Pluto, and several other classic characters. There’s a lot of photo instructions, so it’s easy to follow along. She’s working on Mickey right now, but I hope she does Jiminy Cricket later, he’s adorable!

Having been a fan of Ottorbox and LifeProof cases, I have tested many iterations.  These are the cases I love and the cases I buy and recommend to others.  I have tried impostors but have not found other cases that hold up to the rigor that most LifeProof cases do.  This has been my experience.I was given the opportunity to test the LifeProof FREPower iPhone 6 Waterproof case and did so happily.  I have had this FRE case LifeProof iPhone 6(4.7" Version) Case - Fre Series - Soaring Blue (Light Cobalt/ Dark Cobalt) on my iPhone since Januray 2015 and was happy to take a step up to the FREPower.  I find that one of the biggest issues I have with my iPhone is running through the battery with a busy day.  I take precautions to save battery power - these are some of the more specific things I do:  1) You can find a list of apps using the most battery resources in the battery usage section of the device's main Settings menu. ...  2) Manage Background App Refresh. ...  3) Turn down the brightness. ...  4) Turn off Fetch  5) Turn off Bluetooth if not in use with a deviceNow with the backup 2600-MAH battery, even when I am careless with battery hog applications ... I can continue to work with my phone without worrying so much about battery life.  The form factor obviously is not as sleek as the regular FRE case but in my mind, it's better than carrying around external power and LifeProof has done a great job of making the form factor look attractive and less bulky than other options I have seen.To me, this case is winning.  I like the look and feel and find that the exchange of a little extra heft allowable for the option of longer lasting battery power.  As a side note, I found that the case charged perfectly fine with my Amazon Kindle power cord.  I am not saying that every or any 3rd party USB micro cord will work for you ... but for me it did.  The form factor did not differ greatly from the regular FRE, the main difference is in thickness but is negligible.Thank you LifeProof for the chance to test and review another great product.

I am reviewing the Dechunxian Stylish Built-in Infuser Portable Real Borosilicate 100% Glass Water Bottle Travel, Tea Tumbler + Stainless Strainer.I like the feel of this bottle and like another reviewer said, it looks like a bank or mail tube.  The design looks futuristic and is very nice quality.  The bottle holds 11 ounces of fluid and for some, this might be a little small.  But for me - drinking different loose teas like Yerba Mate, this is a perfect size.  The opening of the bottle works ok for me but does hit my nose.  I would have opted for a wider bottle design.  Still a great bottle with a neat design.  Sure to catch attention.I received the bottle free in exchange for my honest review.

These silicone suction lids are a great alternative to using plastic Saran wrap to cover leftovers.  They are dishwasher and microwave safe and contain no BPA.  The set includes a 5.5", 8" and 9.5" version.  I was not really sure how they were going to work but the suction works great and they easily peel off too.These suction lids are for use up to 425F and this should help to cover some steaming temperatures.  I am unsure about general covers for long-standing items on a stove (making pasta sauces or soups).  Versatile covers.  For me they win because they save quote a bit of plastic wrap.Time for me to continue to think a little bit differently and use these instead of automatically reaching for the saran wrap or tin foil.

This is great "utility" shirt that can serve a lot of purposes.  The fabric is light and 100% cotton so is breathable but I would not recommend this shirt if you are looking for something in a technical cloth (Coolmax, etc).  If you need something for camping or fishing and need SPF protection or wicking, you'll have to find something else.  This looks like one of those other shirts from Columbia or North Face.  But it's different.  A comparable shirt from Columbia is Columbia Men's Bonehead Long-Sleeve Shirt which is 100% cotton as well but has a few more features and a vent in the back of the shirt.  The Wrangler version does not ... this is more an everyday work shirt with a few flaps of velcro, tabbed roll up sleeves and a little venting at the neck of the neck.The could have done so much more with this shirt.  But as-is, it is a nice value at the $20 pricetag.  Just understand what you are getting when you buy this shirt.  It looks more technical than it is.  It has a nice, clean put together look though and looks great with jeans.  I am unsure what one is supposed to do with the "rod loops" on the left top?Nice shirt.

For it's price point, this is a great shirt and is very well made.  The descriptors for this woven shirt on the Amazon page are wrong.  There are none of these things:- Mesh fabric in back neck for coolness  (no, instead there is chambray material lining the neckline)- Roll tab sleeve (NO - on the utility shirt)- Rod loop at front chest (NO - on the utility shirt)Instead, this is what you are getting with this Long Sleeve Classic Woven Shirt:  - 100% Cotton  - Imported  - Machine Wash  - Caviar mid-weight brushed twill  -  2 chest pockets with button thru flap closure  -  Button closure  - Relaxed fit  - Made in BangladeshThe shirt itself is great quality and will soften up over time.  The twill is considered mid-weight fabric, color and workmanship on this shirt make it a real value at it's under $20.Seems like the people at Amazon mixed up the descriptions for the Wrangler Men's Authentics Long Sleeve Utility Shirt  and this one.  The descriptions are mixed up between both of them.  Just understand what you are purchasing.Great shirt!

I have been using the Luseta Beauty Tea Tree and Argan Oil shampoo and conditioner over the past week and my hair is soft and supple.  I was asked to test the products in exchange for a fair review.The products arrived in two pump bottles and I was happy that the pumps worked smoothly to dispense small amounts of product with each pump.  The shampoo has a great smell (mainly tea tree) and a wonderful, luxurious feel when lathered.  The lather was perfect and the feel on my scalp was extremely refreshing without being overpowering.  The main difference comes from the addition of Argan oil which aids this formula in providing moisture and smoothness (I am using another Tea tree product which is very very drying).  I love the way my hair feels when using both products together or just one at a time.This is a great scalp calming formula that feels refreshing without overdoing it.  Definitely love it!

This is a beautiful silk pillowcase that has two sides to it of different materials.  One side is silk with a really soft hand ... the silk feels very luxurious and the other side is a 300 thread count cotton with a contrasting color.  Both sides have their purpose and for me, who likes to flip pillows around, this provides a different option.I was provided with a discounted sample of this beautiful pollowcase for testing and reviewing.  It truly is lovely and is sized to fit a standard pillow.  The zipper is hidden so you don't need to worry about sleeping on it at all.A nice and affordable luxury that feels delicious.

I have used so many different selfie-sticks and most of them are the same and only differ slightly in form factor.  I have found many of them contain very cheap components, are funky colors or designs (I don't necessarily want a selfie-stick with pink accents on it).  Many of them look and feel pretty lightweight and cheap.I was asked to review the Kamotech Selfie-stick and received it free in exchange for an honest review.  I get asked to review many selfie-sticks and refuse many of them because they are all the same.  When I saw this one, I knew it was a bit different than most of them I have tried given it's size and portability.  I was anxious to test it and compare it against so many of the others.  It is different in a few areas and really sets itself apart quality-wise because of this.If you are looking for a truly pocket-sized selfie-stick, this is one that fits that description.  When you receive it, you also get a small carrying bag so that it fits in a pocket or purse without getting hung up on keys or other items.  The bag is soft and contains a drawstring.  This is a nice plus.  But really, one of the main features that I love and think is versatile is the GoPro type of mount/hinge that allows me to hook a GoPro camera to it.  This adds another level of versatility that makes this Selfie-stick just a little bit better than the others.Sure, this SS is more expensive than some but If you are looking for a selfie-stick and value compactness and flexibility, this is the one.  I definitely recommend it based on it's size.  It truly is compact.

I have tried various supplements for this or that usually with results I cannot truly identify.  My Mom's doctor recommended Antronex for her (she deals with some minor allergies and post-nasal drip) and I decided to give it a try without any great expectations.  The bottle calls for one pill a day.  I actually take about 6-10 per day to support my severe allergies (I take Zyrtec too and am a bit too chicken to NOT take my OTC antihistamine).To preface, I have asthma and get sinus infections like it's no one's business.  I live in Florida and the allergies can be intense.  I have found a regimen though now that excludes the nasal sprays I was on and minimizes the use of Sudafed.  I took Sudafed like crazy and it was contributing to UTI's for me.  I have MS and Sudafed changes bladder tone ... who knew!?  I was taking quite a bit of Sudafed and I knew it wasn't the best for me but I needed it to avoid getting sick.  Well, since starting Antronex about a month ago ... I have managed allergies pretty well in the moment and as they arise.  I take my daily Zyrtec and my nightly Benadryl but inbetween instead of reaching for a Sudafed for sinuses or a Kid's Benadryl for breatkthrough allergies during the day ... I take two Antronex and voila, it does the trick.For me Antronex took a few days to really notice much of a difference.  Now about a month later it is working well and keeping my allergies at bay and under control.  The biggest change I see is the sinus support it provides me so that I do not have to take Sudafed every 4 hours and at night.  For me, this is a huge change and one that I am very happy about.  I am impressed with Antronex ... no doubt about it.  I certainly am not afraid to take them throughout the day as needed.  This equals 6-10 a day.  The stuff is smelly as heck but it really works.  My allergies are intense and severe and this is a great supportive therapy option for me.5 stars.

This is a nice quality sleeping mummy bag for the price.  I prefer a down bag for warmth and weight but for a modest price, this bag will do.  It has features on it like more expensive sleeping bags and is well made ... but the I agree with many of the others who reviewed stating that the warmth rating is probably an overstatement.  I cannot test in this temperature as I live in Southwest Florida.The bag is comfortable and with a camping mat, more warmth and comfort is achieved.  The bag comes with a stuff sack and the zipper is on the right.  This bad does not appear mateable and no left-handed option is available.Factors such as humidity, how you are camping (mat or no mat) and amount of clothing worn in the sleeping bag are all going to contribute to overall warmth.  I would treat this bag like a 30+ range and probably be happy.  I am accustomed to an Army sleeping bag and did well with mine back in the 1980's sleeping in the Appalachian mountains in Alabama.  It was wet and cold and the middle of Winter.  The trick ... sleeping with very little on and the use of a mat.I do not believe this bag could fare in temps of 20 degrees.  I would trust it in the over freezing temperatures and even in the 40's.  Of course there are multiple factors.  This is a nice sleeping bag for the hobbyist ... a more serious camper and outdoor enthusiast.  For about $30 more I would probably opt for a Kelty Kelty Tuck 30 Degree Sleeping Bag or Kelty Tuck 20.

I have 5 cats and the largest of them is 16 lbs ... he's the one I was thinking about when I got these steps because he is arthritic and a Senior boy.  While I am still in the process of training the kitties with treats and catnip, I cannot help but feel that the plastic (and I notice it on the lower step) is much thinner than expected.  There is a lot of "give" on that step and I am not sure kitties feel extremely secure when climbing.  I would have paid $25 for this quality but not twice that.  The rubber feet all came off within a day and did not seem to have very good tackiness.If you are looking for a set of pet stairs, keep searching ... I think you can probably do better.  These seem too cheap to me.

This is a solid and very rugged reversible Black/Brown grommet belt.  Like a throwback from the 70's, this belt reminds me of Wrangler jeans and even bell bottoms.  But it is a very functional and sturdy belt.  The leather is stiff and as listed on the belt itself is a "Genuine Leather" product (this means layers of leather versus one solid piece as in "Full Grain Leather").  For the price, it is a value and a little bit of break-in time is to be expected.  The hardware and buckle on the belt are good quality and the buckle roller help make the job of securing the belt on the waist a little easier.  Getting out of the belt when it is new is a bit more of a challenge.One of the coolest features that was not immediately clear to me at first was the fact that this belt was reversible.  The black or brown side can be worn with the simple twist of the buckle.  The brown side is very dark - think "Espresso".  No latches or screws to undo to take advantage of the belt color of choice, a simple pull and twist motion and you are in business. Without directions I ALMOST pulled out my tiniest of screwdrivers but had to believe there was an easier way.  There was.  Maybe the belt twist and turn is familiar to you, but I am depicting it anyway in attached photos.If you want a soft and supple belt, this is not the one for you.  If you want something rugged, Wolverine has your covered at a price point that won't break the bank.  Wolverine provided me with a free sample of this belt for testing purposes and review purposes.

This tuner, metronome and tone generator is really like the Swiss Army Knife of musical gadgets.  Great for pitch, tempo and tones.  It also comes with great directions and a nice soft carrying pouch.I appreciate the metronomes out there and even metronomes with tuners ... but this one also provides a tone generator along with an earphone-in jack and a 1/4" plug in and out jack.  It has a stand on the back that makes it flexible enough to position it multiple ways - whichever suits your particular set up.  The unit is small enough to fit in a pocket and isn't much bigger than a standard cassette tape (for those who actually remember them).  Every feature on this little device has a purpose.  From the sharp and flat lights to the volume button on the left side to the thumb wheel (JOG dial) which moves like a charm and helps to toggle between tones and tempos.  The Tap In feature is neat and allows you to tap in your desired tempo ranging from 30-250 beats per minute - just the way you want it.To top things off, turn over the Metropitch and you will find a tempo range table that corresponds from "Largo" to a jumpy "Prestissimo" (200-208 bpm) and everything in between.  This provides a nice reference.I received this Metropitch tuner and metronome for free in exchange for a review and this is the second product I have reviewed from KLIQ. This is definitely a versatile gadget for hobbyists like me and professionals.  It's priced right so that if you need to have several, you can place them strategically in a music case, studio area, etc.Really a great and handy little device that even accommodates instrument specific tuning modes.  For me playing Ukulele (yes, that is a mode) this is great.  The modes are:  Guitar, Bass, Violin and Ukulele.  Another great feature!

This is a great mesh shower caddie for college or camp or any kind of situation where you have to bring your toiletries with you and take them away.  It's a great option to replace those plastic shower caddies like this one - InterDesign Orbz Divided Bath Shower Tote, Small, Black.This caddie is versatile and holds bottles, brushes and towels.  You don't want to overload it but it is durable.  It also dries easily and can be rolled up with a rubber band and thrown into luggage.  It takes up a lot less space.  It has polyester edging and a neoprene handle.  I am curious if the polyester edging will attract mold over time.  This is really the only issue I see with this Mesh Caddie and the reason I knocked off a star.  Maybe a completely PVC or touches of silicone product would make it more mold or mildew resistant.Otherwise, a great and versatile item for the dorm, camp or even the beach.

I have owned 4 Evriholder FURemover Broom over the past 6 years or so.  Some people have "borrowed" them and 1 actually got worn out.  With a house full of cats, a fur removing rubber broom is an absolute necessity.  These brooms work great on all kinds of surfaces: laminate, wood, tile and carpet (but expect more labor on carpet).  I am doing a little comparison on both of them.When I compared both brooms, the Perky (this one) and the FURemover and found that each has their strengths.  If you are mainly using bristles and less squeegee, I think the FURemover wins hands-down for it's smooth sweeping feel on hard surfaces.  The Perky was not nearly as smooth over my tile surfaces and the rubber was different ... creating a bit of a "pull".  The Perky did a fine job sweeping up debris, but the effort to use it seemed greater with more resistance on surfaces.  I also think that the larger bristles on the Perky worked better on my short pile area rugs.  But sweeping rugs with any of these rubber brooms is a chore.The Perky has a better squeegee and does a bit better on rugs.  The FURemover has a longer handle that telescopes and can give you some height where the Perky does not.  It is also a pleasure to sweep with because it's smooth motion.  Effortless on hard surfaces.Pros of the Perky:- the Squeegee is awesome! Works well- the larger bristles work better on carpetPros of the FURemover:- smooth as butter on hard surfaces.- telescoping handle allows for height adjustments.For my purposes, I prefer the FURemover.  I use mostly on tile and small area rugs.  I prefer the smooth motion versus the resistance I feel with the Perky.  Each has their place and perceived values.  Both are good and will do the job.  It just depends what you want this rubber broom for.  Regardless, if you have hard surfaces and pets ... you really should consider picking one or the other.

I liked the toy from it's description and our cats seemed to like the toy the first night I opened it when the ball actually lit up ... but there are real problem with QA and quality of this product.  I am basing my review on that.Our LED ball stopped working after the first night and no catnip was included in the package as promised.  The plastic is also quite brittle unlike the Bergan Turbo Scratcher Cat Toy, Colors May Vary and products which have a scratching surface and a ball and don't cost $40+ for poor quality and QA.In theory, this would be a nice toy for cats.  But my kitties love the Turbo scratcher equally as much and are happy with the <$15 toy over the $40+ toy.Go for the cheaper toys and use a laser pointer to simulate the lighted ball.

I think that conceptually this is a pretty cool tuner.  Please keep in mind that I am testing on a 4-string Ukulele  and this tuner is supposed to shine with a 6-string guitar.  Even when tuning with a Bass guitar, the PolyTune technology is disabled.I like it's relatively compact design and it's flexibility to toggle between needle and strobe viewing.  I like "needle", so I chose that view.  However, given that there are so many tuners out in the market today for so much less ... I am underwhelmed.  Especially given the cost of this tuner at just under $50.The Polyphonic tuning feature seems more gimmick than substance.  If you have a guitar and strum, it can attempt to tell you where the strings are individually as far as pitch +/- ... but to me, a well trained ear can do as well if not better.The clip is grippy but I personally like the Snark tuners better and find the rubber clips on the Snarks a little more amenable to expensive instruments.  I clipped the PolyTune to my KoAloha Concert Ukulele (this uke is the lightest and nicest I've ever owned - feels as light as balsa wood with a tone that is gorgeous).  Besides the lack of the PolyTune feature, I don't feel that this tuner is the right one for my preference.Snark SN-8 Super Tight All Instrument Tuner in a pack of 2 has been my choice for my multiple ukes.  Two for $25 and they cannot be beaten.  Totally not convinced that this PolyTune clip does anything that warrants the price tag.  If you have the extra money, and if you like a sleeker look and want to try something a little novel - grab the PolyTune Clip.  It works wonderfully as a standard tuner with a new little twist for those playing guitar.  I don't personally see the value of the features being worth the cost ... I could buy a pair of cheaper tuners for my Uke and a set of strings or two for the same price.

These are a beautiful pair of Pro Mark Hickory drumsticks created with a twist.  Not only are there articulations to enable grip at the end of the sticks but there is also a finish on them that gets more tacky as you perspire and warm up.  You need to evaluate if this tackiness is something that will be amenable to you?  Imagine playing your set after eating a bucket of caramel corn or Cracker Jacks.  That is what the tackiness feels like to me.  Like I have caramel corn-laden sticky hands and I just picked up my sticks to play.  If that kind of stickiness doesn't bother you ... then these sticks might be your favorite pair.  If, like me, you may feel a little bothered with sticky hands ... I would recommend something a little different like the Zildjian Trilock Gurtu that have a rubber grip/  I prefer the Zildjian sticks.These Glenn Kotche Active Wave 570's are about a 1/2 longer than most and have a nice, responsive feel.  They are weighted well and my pair showed no signs of warping or unevenness (except for some of the finish/coating which is flaking off right out of the package - thus the 4 stars).The acorn shaped tip is nice and responsive and DOES NOT have any of the tacky finish on it.  Free and clear so they shouldn't leave any strange marks or stickiness on your drum heads.They feel good with weight and length.  A nice balanced stick.  I am not sold on the tacky finish though ... or me, I will stick with my Trilok Gurtu sticks - Zildjian Trilok Gurtu Artist Series Drumsticks

I live in Sarasota, FL (South of Tampa) where the lightening storms can be intense and frequent.  I use surge protection on everything to save my electronics.  I trust APC as my brand of choice and definitely do not skimp on power protection (no dollar store surge protectors for me).  We used the brand where I used to volunteer as an EMT and also in my corporate workplace.  APC is the brand I recommend when looking at surge protection and I can say that I have used the brand for about 20 years.When offered a product geared toward more sensitive electronics like those used in home theater, I was glad to try it out.  While this is not the most compact of power strips (it's titled a "power filter" not a standard power strip) it offers some flexibility with a rotating outlet bank which is cool.  So you can stand it on end or lay it on the ground and use the orientation that works best for your set up.  I am using the APC C20B version (although the enclosed instructions also encompass info for the C25B version as well which is a little smarter and has a couple more options).  Still, the APC C20B seems like it will be a solid performer.I am using 7 of the 8 outlets in my living room where one of our plasma televisions and the cable box, FiOS/wi-fi, Amazon Fire TV, Blu-Ray players are and everything fit just fine.  There are outlets for a telephone, but I have not connected one to this device.  Installation was easy and straightforward and the APC directions are thorough and clear as usual.Another great product from this company.  I'm thankful to protect my sensitive electronic devices a little bit more with this Power Filter.  APC will continue to be my brand of choice.

I received these earbuds for a penny in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.I tried the earbuds in several Apple devices and the phones did not work for me.  The build quality looked better on the outside than it actually was.  The sheath by the plug came off and I suspect a problem with the wiring.  It appears that the sheath came unglued.  I am unsure if this is the cause of the phones not working??These did not work for me so I cannot comment on the sound.

The Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD replaced "Asperger's DIsorder" in the DSM 5 in 2013) encompasses all levels of Autism.  What was once called "Aspergers" (and Just Add Water still uses this diagnosis) has now been replaced with a spectrum diagnosis.  Asperger's sits high on the spectrum and depicts someone who is high functioning.Clay Marzo is a master surfer.  He surfs with finesse beyond his years and an ability that is hard to quantify and replicate.  He surfs without distraction and is purely focused in this pursuit.  This book is about his journey as a Prodigy of surfing and through school and life as a surfing celebrity.  It shares the story of Clay's struggles socially and in the limelight as a representative of the Quicksilver brand.  The reader gets a practical peek into the mind and thought processes of someone struggling on the Spectrum (Asperger's).For a teen struggling with Asperger's and for the parent trying to understand what it is like ... "Just Add Water" is a triumphant story of a child who moves into adulthood with a new awareness of coping and eventual outreach.  Clay is doing some great things for those with Autism these days.  His struggle becomes a story of greater awareness and giving.  The water was his joy and comfort zone ... being out of it was hellish.  This great book shows how he made the journey to greater awareness and living.Great book, inspiring and telling.  The surfing story makes it fun but I feel the greater value in this book is in the journey towards awareness by both Clay, his parents and his sponsors.

4 out of our 5 kitties really love these Kittles Treats.  To me, that is great odds and the sign of a good treat in our household.I know when I use the Wellness brand products, I may pay a little more but I also get a product that is more nutritious for my kitties and more packed with the good stuff instead of fillers.The treats are a good size and small enough so that they can be chewed or swallowed whole (one of my senior cats has a chronic upper respiratory condition that affects his gums too).Very happy cat Mama who enjoys seeing very happy cats!  I think that with a little time, perhaps all 5 of the cats might enjoy them ... but with this first pouch used for review, 4 out of 5.  To me, those are good odds.  :)

This is a fun and functional toy that takes a bit of patience to build.  I don not have children but I understand from a cognitive perspective how the mind of a child works.  I could recommend this set to a more advanced 8 Year Old or an average 10-11 year old.  This building project takes time and I was able to build them myself with the direction booklet which was clear.  The pieces were also arranged well and easy to identify.The finished product is neat ... but to me getting to the finished project is where the value lies in this product.This is a project that works best with a child who is patient and organized.  Be careful around very small children and dogs because there are many small parts.  I think the best way to approach the project is with a block of about 2.5-3 hrs where things can be organized and assembled in one shot.

This is a great flat bench that fits a general workout niche.  It works well on it's own as a place to leverage and stretch or as an adjunct to barbells.  Dumbbells are great on here too.It's low profile makes it easier to store than I expected .  The only caveat to that is the thick legs (which add to stability and are necessary) make it more bulky to store than it would be if the legs were foldable.  Of course, that creates another more expensive product.  This product out of the box had a little bit of assembly.  No big deal.Overall a great and sturdy flat workout bench.

I've noticed over the past 10+ years that I have had problems with various Apple cables.  Whether for an iPad or iPhone or Macbook Pro ... it seems that there was one end of the cable towards either the pin connector or USB connector where the vinyl covering bunched up.  I was able to watch YouTube and find ways to remedy this problem .. .but it seemed to be a problem inherent to all of Apple cables that contained the vinyl outer cover.  It seems like this cover would crinkle and lead to exposed and eventually frayed wires.This Belkin cable alleviates any of that problem by using a braided material that provides a bit more flexibility along with an aluminum shell at both of the connector ends.  This seems like a good combination.I use the cable in my car to plug my Apple devices in it.  It holds up to Florida heat without a problem (but so did the OEM cable).  This cable looks cool, is easily identifiable and has an extra layer of ruggedness.  It does well being wrapped up and shoved into a purse, bag or whatever.  No need to have to baby this cable.  Love it.

I love the shape of these glasses and they are crystal clear out of the box except for a couple of slightly visible seams.  The shape feels great in the hand, they are boxed well and for the price  They are much thinner walled than I would have ever imagined and can be easily manipulated (squeezed) out of shape.  Besides those stackable plastic cups you see at open bars or a red Solo cup ... I would not expect a pastic wine glass in this price range to feel so cheap.  At $22+ for the set of 4, I could not find any person I asked who thought the glasses were a good value.  What they and I did like was the shape of them.  The ergonomic shape is wonderful and wine looks great in them.  They serve a great purpose when glass or crystal is just not the best option.  But the thin walled nature of these glasses undermines them and makes them feel almost disposable.Let your guests know these are not throwaway glasses if you are serving others.  They are of a beautiful design, and it's the design and shape that gives them 3 stars in my eyes.  I took off two stars for the build and price.  They seem far too pricey for what a person is getting.  Priced at the $10 mark, I would definitely increase the rating by 1 star.I received these Govino glasses for FREE in exchange for an honest review.

This is such a neat piece of "functional art".  If you like modern, clean lines ... this is a nice little piece to hold a bottle of wine suspended.  It's a very cool concept and makes a nice piece for the dinner table before the wine is opened and poured.  Talk about a conversation piece.  I had never seen anything like this.What you see is what you get - minus the wine bottle.  Very easy to use and it balances a wine bottle so nicely.I was provided a free sample for testing purposes and I really like this piece.  It's like art that holds a wonderful elixir.  5 stars.

This little mini Bluetooth speaker is more than just really cute and compact, it actually sounds pretty good (albeit a little bit tinny with the highs).  But  for what it is, this is a great little speaker that is ultra compact.It excels for being a tiny little drum speaker but keep realistic expectations in knowing that it cannot possibly rival something larger.  But what it does, it does well for the size.
