I no longer have to worry about smacking myself in the face with it, like I used to notoriously do as a kid. That - and my kids can use it, too!Overall, this is a wonderful jump rope that is very well made, with attention to detail, and quality material. I am comfortable recommending it to anyone of all ages!

I love this coffee maker! It's compact and light, so it fits easily in my backpack, so I can take it with me on all my favorite adventures whether I'm climbing my favorite mountain ranges or hiking the Appalachian trail! And it comes with a convenient little carabiner, so I can just clip it on the outside of my pack making it very accessible and easier to start my day!To use, simply pop it open, insert paper filter, add desired amount of coffee, place coffee maker over cup, and pour hot water into the filter. Couldn't be easier.I received this item in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

This is a high-quality, durable, and nicely designed set of essential silicone tools! Each that I've used has been highly effective at serving it's intended purpose, but being easier to use than most.I got this to replace an worn out bamboo set that had silicone tips. This one I like much better, because it has silicone on the handles making it easier to work with. It's also much stronger than other ones I've used before. It looks a lot better, too. The design of the handles is especially nice, having a hole for hanging. This keeps them sanitary on my hanging rack, and out of the utensil drawer where my kids are always grabbing for silverware.Because of its durability and strong structure, I do expect this set to last for some time. By all means, I highly recommend it!Disclosure: I received this set at a discounted price, to evaluate and provide my honest and unbiased review. I hope my observations and experience can help you with making a better buying decision.

After recently reading an article about the bulb aspirator, seeing the photos, and realizing that they can actually do much more harm than any good- I was immediately concerned for my nephews newborn. This nasal aspirator is a serious upgrade that is a must-have for new parents. I only wish they had something like this when my two were young!It's simple to use and isn't painfully invasive like the bulb. Simply put the soft tip to the baby's nose and begin suction. The process is quick and effect my cleans. And immediately afterwards, it's very easy to clean by washing with soap and water.I also love that it has a storage box! This keeps it sanitary, and the extra tips in their place alongside the aspirator. Overall- I feel much more comfortable knowing my nephews new son will be congestion free in a safe and sanitary way. By all means, I highly recommend this aspirator!Disclosure: I received this at a discounted price, to evaluate and provide my honest and unbiased review. I hope my observations and experience can help you with making a better buying decision.

Thermos Food Jar with Microwaveable Container / B00EO0K1M4I really like this thermos as a microwaveable food container. I eat a "mini-can" of Spaghettios every day at work for lunch, and the contents fit perfectly in this thermos jar. And even though pasta sauce will stain most plastic food containers red, this jar is still crystal clear after multiple uses and daily runs through the dishwasher. I also appreciate that the thermos keeps my food warm while I eat it--I've used food containers before where the food would be cold by the time you finished.I personally find the rotate-to-lock/unlock snapping mechanism for the thermos and jar to be perfectly intuitive and easy to use. I've not had any problems with the jar falling out when it shouldn't; nor have I had trouble rotating the jar on my own without help (I have weak hands). It's been totally easy to use, and I appreciate that.I wouldn't use this Thermos for hot stuff that you hope will *stay* hot longer than 2-3 hours; the container holds heat pretty well at first, but not for the long haul. And obviously you want to check your food-size needs; 12 ounces isn't a lot for a packed lunch for some people or some situations. This jar is also very likely too wide for a briefcase, though it will sit well in most "sack" lunch bags (the one I use has a roll-down top that works great with short jars like this one).NOTE: This review is based on a free Advance Review Copy of this product provided through Amazon Vine.~ Ana Mardoll

Longbourne / 978-0345806970I've never been a huge fan of Pride & Prejudice, though I freely acknowledge Jane Austen's skill as a writer. But I've always been more interested in the lives of the serving girls than the lives of the women upstairs, with their balls and shoe-roses. (Seriously, Margaret Atwood's Alias Grace is one of my favorite novels specifically *because* of all the servanty bits.) So as soon as I heard of Longbourne on Sarah Wendell's review site (Smart B------, Trashy Books), I knew I would love it.I sped through this book over the course of three days and bitterly resented every moment that I had to put it down! As other reviewers have mentioned, this book is more "around" Price & Prejudice than "about" it, and the format of the one novel serves as a perfect backdrop for the material in this one. Jo Baker's writing is superb and evocative, and fits well with the language I expect in a Regency without being turgid to slog through. Baker has wholly embraced the servant framing, and we receive all the world-building of that sort which you could possibly hope for, and she perfectly interweaves characterization through the daily grind of chores.What I like most about this novel is how it focuses so well and so thoroughly on its entire cast of characters. Whereas this might be confusing or jarring in another novel, the multiple characters work well here and we care deeply about exploring the romantic relationship between Sarah and the men in her life, and the surrogate familial relationship between the servants in the household as they quarrel and love and comfort and scold and shelter each other. The result is realistic without being too harsh, touching without being saccharine.I struggle with recommending this book without giving too much of the plot away, but I will touch briefly on the issue of Mr. Bennet. I will say that I have never much cared for Mr. Bennet--yes, he is the comic relief and gets the best lines, but he is also harsh to his family members and careless of his daughter's futures. Longbourne explores this side of his character further, pointing out (for example) how callous it is for him to receive Mr. Collins for a stay without alerting the household staff. The staff not only have to prepare at short notice for a guest, they also need to impress Mr. Collins deeply so that he will not dismiss them when he inherits the house. I thought this handling of the character of Mr. Bennet was realistic towards what was displayed in the original P&P novel; here he is not overtly villainized, but his casual self-indulgence does provide some of the conflict for the servants to overcome.If I can find fault with this book, it is that at the 3/4 point there is an extended flash-back which is well-written but could not hold my interest as I was too anxious to find out what would happen in the future to take time out to hear about the past. This is important to the characterization in the novel, though, and I don't feel right complaining that the book hooked me so deeply that I couldn't wait to turn each page!A couple more things I want to mention that gave me great pleasure: One, this is the first Regency book I've read which has a black man as both a major character *and* as a viable party in a love triangle. I felt like this was handled fairly well, and he is treated in the story with respect from most parties and like it would be no big deal for Sarah (who is white) to marry him. Even the characters who react to him in (relatively mild) racist ways do acknowledge that he's the handsomest man in town and certain to turn the girls' heads. I loved that.Two, this is also the first Regency book I've read which has a gay man in it. And even better, the book strives to not treat him like a rare unicorn: one line which particularly pleased me was "The farmhands--at least, those of them that tended towards the liking of women--stopped and stared, mouths hanging open, as she went by in Mary's pretty cast-offs." Of course, I haven't read a ton of Regency books, but it seems (in my experience) that a lot of authors tend towards entirely white casts and heteronormativity; I appreciated that Jo Baker didn't do that for her novel.Probably the best compliment I can give Longbourne, though, is that it made me want to read Pride & Prejudice again (something I'd decided I'd had enough of for a lifetime) just so that I can relive the lives of Sarah and Mrs. Hill and James and Polly and Mr. Hill all over again in my imagination. I strongly recommend this book and consider it the best fiction I read in all of 2013. (And I most seriously hope that Jo Baker decides to tackle Sense & Sensibility next, if she sticks with Jane Austen as an inspiration.)~ Ana Mardoll

360 Mobile Solutions Smart Micro USB LED Cable Powerful 2.1A Output / B00FYIB7F0I bought this fast-charge cable for use with my chargers which claim fast-charge capabilities (including a car charger I recently received) so that I could be sure that any lag in charging wasn't the fault of my older cables. This cable from Mobile Solutions has worked really well for me so far, with a variety of chargers and devices, so I'm really pleased with it. The price is a little steep (though check across all the colors because some of them cost more than others), but if you're not seeing the performance you'd expect from your chargers, this may be worth the investment.I'm not sure why one reviewer said they were getting a slow charge on this, but one thing you do need to be aware of is that not all chargers charge fast. And not all devices (especially older devices) can charge fast. Basically in my experience, for a fast charge you need 4 things: (1) a device that can accept a fast charge, (2) a charger than can deliver a fast charge, (3) a cable that can carry a fast charge, and (4) a connection between device, charger, and cable which *doesn't* put the device into a data transfer mode which usually provides only a minimal trickle charge.The lighted tip on this cable is something you'll probably either love or hate. It's convenient for letting you know if the device is charging, and if the connection is good--the cord lights up blue when not connected and red when connected and charging. On the other hand, if you're using this in your bedroom when you're trying to sleep, it'll probably be way too bright. I've been using this in the car with a car charger where the light doesn't bother me.Note that this cable is about 3 feet long.~ Ana Mardoll

Black and Decker SL5470C Stainless Steel Slow Cooker / B002SB8K4WI've had an older-model Hamilton Beach 33967 Set 'n Forget 6-Quart Programmable Slow Cooker for years and we've gotten so much use out of it. I thought it might make sense to try out this Black & Decker model and maybe upgrade to it permanently if it turned out to be better.Controls: This Black & Decker model is manual control, which means that you just have a turn knob with three options: Low, High, and Warming. I don't really like manual control, and I prefer my digital programmable Hamilton Beach model (which also has Low/High/Warm functions in addition to fancier temperature settings). I will say, though, that I can see manual being useful if the power goes out (briefly) while you're cooking and if, when the power comes back on, the manual cooker continues cooking. (Though it seems like this could be dangerous, in the Food Safety sense, if the power was out for some time without your knowledge? I'm not an expert, though.)Lids: One thing I don't like about this Black & Decker model is that the lid just sits loosely on. My Hamilton Beach model actually has lid-clamps to hold the lid firmly in place.Sizes: This Black & Decker model has a 7-quart capacity whereas the Hamilton Beach one only has 6-quarts, however (a) I can't tell a difference by sight (and both units look the same size to me), and (b) we've never cooked anything which needed more than 6-quarts worth of space.All in all, this is a good slow cooker--don't take away from my rating that it's not. And if you really need a 7-quart capacity or if you prefer manual to digital then I do recommend this model. But I'll stick with my Hamilton Beach one for now, because I so much prefer the digital options.A note on cooking: When we were new to slow cooking, we thought that roasts had to be covered to the top in broth or water, and we never understood why the meat came out so tough. Someone finally told us to stop using so much liquid and that made all the difference in the world. I now never use more than 1 small can of broth with our roasts and they come out as tender as you can imagine. Also look up how to cut against the grain instead of with it, because that can make a huge difference as well. Good luck!NOTE: This review is based on a free Advance Review Copy of this product provided through Amazon Vine.~ Ana Mardoll

Tylt YCHGBL-T Ycharge 2.1A USB Car Charger Dual Port / B00BJR64CQI have an older model phone that needs to be charged throughout the day. I figured I could use this on the morning commute and save my battery backup for when I get out of the car. This car charger works well. The feel of the device is nice; a rubbery feel with a "give" that is still very sturdy and well-made. The Y-design fit well in my car, and (unlike previous car chargers I have tried) didn't try to work its way out of the car-charger port--this charger has stayed in place for a couple of weeks without needing to be pushed back in or readjusted.However, this charger isn't as speedy as some 2.1A battery backups I have at home. At first I thought it was the fault of the USB cord, so I bought a new cord specifically rated for 2.1A (360 Mobile Solutions Smart Micro USB LED Cable Powerful 2.1A) and that gave me a little more speed but still not as speedy as I'd like. With my Skyrocket playing an Audible book and using the stock Navigation app, I got approximately 1% of my battery every 2 minutes; without running energy-intensive apps, I was able to get 1% every 1 minute.Now, obviously those stats aren't going to mean a lot to you unless you have my phone (1% of my phone's battery isn't going to be 1% of *your* phone's battery), so the more generalized version is that this charger is faster than ones I've tried in the past, but still not as fast as some of my speedy battery backups. I don't know if that's the fault of the car, the cord, or the charger, but I can recommend this charger if you need a dual charger, want something that isn't molasses-slow, and/or want a charger that will stay put and won't fidget in the charging port.NOTE: This review is based on a free Advance Review Copy of this product provided through Amazon Vine.~ Ana Mardoll

EasyAcc® 5000mAh 2.5A Dual Port / B00EK3UHS8There's not a plug handy at work so I've been trying out a lot of battery chargers lately for my phone. This one hits the perfect sweet-spot of having an all-day charge in a slim unit with a fast charge rate, and I was really pleased to have the chance to try the version sent to me by the manufacturer for review.I love the size of this charger -- it's almost exactly the same height and width of my Samsung Skyrocket, and it fits perfectly in my purse or pocket. The built-in charging cable is convenient and sturdy, and means that you get the fast charge promised without having to worry if your cable is up to snuff. The LED lights that let you know how much charge is left is the usual 4-tier affair (25/50/75/100%) rather than a percentage display, but I don't really need precision estimates on a day-charger I expect to plug in every night. I'm not a big fan of built-in flashlights, but at least this one doesn't turn on by accident like my last one did, so that's a plus.I get one full day's charge on this unit, give or take a little on either side depending on daily phone usage. Do note that this is one of those chargers where you can't just plug it in -- you have to plug it in and then press the power button to start charging. I'm used to that now and hardly ever forget, but it does take a learning curve if you're used to the automatic plug-and-charge. The good news is that even if you do forget to turn it on when you plug it in, it'll catch up fast when you finally remember -- this is *easily* the fastest charger I own.I currently own 6 battery chargers, and this is the one I reach for every time I leave the house. It wouldn't keep well for a long vacation, or even necessarily for a 14-hour day trip somewhere, but for a 9-hour shift at work, it's perfect.NOTE: This review is based on a free review copy of this product.~ Ana Mardoll

Philips HF3500/60 Wake-Up Light / B00F0W1RIWWhen I received this from Amazon Vine, I'd already purchased (and been using for a full year) its older brother model, the Philips HF3520. This 3500 model is significantly cheaper, so I was interested in seeing how it held up without the bells and whistles.The Good: For a 'bare minimum' model, this 3500 model gets the job done. The unit is less bulky and -- since it uses push buttons instead of the touch-screen of the more expensive model -- is less prone to accidental touch-changes. The 'snooze' feature of tapping the top of the unit is intuitive once you know what you're supposed to do. Actually setting the unit is less intuitive; I had to use the manual not only for the initial setup but again a couple days later when Daylight Savings Time hit -- but this wasn't a big deal-breaker. This unit can get just as bright as its older brother, though it doesn't have the colors of the HF3520 model (i.e., it doesn't get orangey like a real sunrise).The Bad: You can't turn off the alarm sound with this, so if you just want to wake up with the light, you'll have to invest in the higher end models. Similarly, you only get one buzzer -- you don't get the radio or nature sound options. (Having said that, the nature sounds on the HF3520 are *very* disappointing, as they're all on an extremely short and therefore noticeable loop.) You don't get the dusk simulation, which can be nice for tuning your body to go to sleep at night.The big reason I've been holding off on reviewing the HF3520 is that, well, the light didn't wake me up! It gets pretty bright in the room, but not nearly so bright as a full-blown sunrise (at least, in my opinion and in my neck of the woods). And I'm a very heavy sleeper who routinely managed to sleep through the light, and didn't feel like I was waking up naturally. Interestingly, I've found that coupling the HF3520 with this new HF3500 has made the room more at the 'natural' level of brightness I'd expect, and I am able to wake up more easily in the mornings. But of course it's mostly luck that I ended up with two wake-up lamps instead of one, and not everyone will be able to afford two lamps.But I mention this so that if you're new to these, you will know that they don't wake up everyone. I recommend investing in this cheaper model first to see if it works for you, and then upgrading to the bells and whistles later if you really love it. You'll be missing out on the radio/nature sounds and the orange colors and the dusk setting, but you'll be able to judge whether this lamp actually wakes you up in the morning, which is the most important thing, I think.NOTE: This review is based on a free Advance Review Copy of this product provided through Amazon Vine.~ Ana Mardoll

3:39 MinsiClever Wireless Bluetooth Stereo Receiver / B00FLL2ZTWThis device is designed to hook into a stereo which takes an auxiliary input (AUX) to play through the speakers; the attached dongle is a bluetooth receiver which accepts music and audio sounds from your phone/tablet/other-device-capable-of-sending-via-bluetooth.This is *great* for stereos (especially built-in stereos in cars) which have aux capability but no bluetooth capability. As has been noted by other reviewers, people sitting in the backseat can access the stereo now, using their phone as a remote control, and if you just get tired of wearing an earpiece all day, this stereo accessory will let you listen to music without having to use your phone's tinny speakers. (Assuming your phone has tinny speakers. Maybe yours doesn't! But mine does, lol.)Huge bonus, not always true for all bluetooth devices: Pairing with this dongle is amazingly easy. I held down the power button until the light alternated blue and red, scanned on my phone, and *boom* there it was. No passwords, no combination button-presses, no fiddly connection issues.A couple things to note here:1. The device does have to be separately charged; it doesn't draw power through the auxiliary cable. The device comes with a USB cable (USB-to-plug) for charging, but I am unsure if the cable plug is an industry standard or a proprietary size. You'll need to be careful not to lose the cable.2. The charging cable is 48 inches long, which is long enough in my car to reach from the stereo to the cigarette-charger. So it is *possible* to keep the device entirely in your car, if you have the right distance between stereo and cigarette lighter.3. The device charges in 2-3 hours; I need to run some benchmarks on how long it can go between charge. I'll update this review once I know.4. The device will NOT play phone conversations -- this is for music/audiobooks/"media" sound only. My phone was able to simultaneously connect to both the iDevice for media AND my earpiece for phone conversations, such that I could listen to music on the stereo but when a call came in, the call audio came in on the earpiece. (My phone also pauses the media playback when a call comes in, so the stereo wasn't still playing.)5. I've played audio from my phone via an actual auxiliary cable strung from phone to car stereo and now from phone to iDevice via bluetooth. The iDevice sound is noticeably crisper and cleaner to listen to, with very little white noise or "hiss" in the background. I'll definitely keep using the iDevice, even though it's technically more work (because of the charging) than the auxiliary cord.The only downside I can see to this device is that I don't understand why they engineered the power button to have to be "held" 3-5 seconds to turn on and off -- I guess they were afraid of incidental bumps, but I would have preferred a physical switch. But that's just me being nitpicky for various quirky hand-related issues I have.NOTE: This review is based on a free review copy of this product.~ Ana Mardoll

3:55 MinsiClever Wireless Bluetooth Stereo Transmitter / B00FLKW0JIThis device is designed to hook into a music player (in the headphone jack) in order to transmit the music from the player to a headset/stereo/other-device-capable-of-receiving-via-bluetooth. This device is NOT to be confused with the iClever Wireless Bluetooth Stereo Receiver, which looks the same, but does the exact opposite (i.e., it receives signals rather than transmits).This is great for MP3 players or portable CD players which don't have bluetooth capability. People in the backseat of the car can send with their MP3 player to the sound system, or if you want to use a portable bluetooth speaker without having to tether to an MP3 player or CP player, then this is what you want to use.Pairing with this dongle is easy, but there's not a lot of input from the user -- you put the speaker into search mode and the dongle into send mode and they either find each other or they don't. I was able to pair this dongle with my HMDX JAM Plus Portable Speaker and with my Plantronics M165 Bluetooth Headset. I couldn't get the dongle to pair with my phone, which didn't surprise me (because the phone is a sender, and not a receiver).A couple things to note here:1. The device does have to be separately charged; it doesn't draw power through the auxiliary cable. The device comes with a USB cable (USB-to-plug) for charging, but I am unsure if the cable plug is an industry standard or a proprietary size. You'll need to be careful not to lose the cable.2. The charging cable is 48 inches long, in case you want to keep the device entirely in your car and need to know if you have the right distance between wherever you want to keep the MP3 player + dongle and the cigarette lighter.3. The device charges in 2-3 hours; I need to run some benchmarks on how long it can go between charge, but so far it seems to last for a good while.The only downside I can see to this device is that I don't understand why they engineered the power button to have to be "held" 3-5 seconds to turn on and off -- I guess they were afraid of incidental bumps, but I would have preferred a physical switch. Plus, you also hold down the power button to go into "search" mode, so it's sometimes fiddly and you get Power Off or Search when you were trying for the other. But it's not a deal-breaker, just something you have to be aware of.NOTE: This review is based on a free review copy of this product.~ Ana Mardoll

PS3 Bluetooth Headset / B0042R81XUI bought this to be able to hear game sounds while my husband sleeps; we have a "proper" full-sized PS3 headset that plays game sounds, but it weighs fully one hundred pounds and hurts my neck to wear. I noticed several reviews lauding this headset as great for "night play". However, it turns out that this headset is ONLY for online chat -- you can hear yourself and others speak through it, but no game sounds whatsoever will come through. I wish the current marketing blurb would actually make that clear; maybe they'll update it soon.So, to be very clear: This is *not* a PS3 headset in the sense that you can hear games. It only allows you to hear other players. If that's what you want it for, it works fine. (Though it is a little big to fit comfortably on smaller ears. And I didn't even know that my ears were particularly small! But this headset is a bit too big for me.) I am leaving this review not to "trash" this product, but to help other buyers since the product blurb is ambiguous about this limitation (at the time of writing). I would prefer to leave no stars, but Amazon doesn't provide that option.~ Ana MardollETA: I note that this review has already attracted negative attention. I wish to underscore that I am leaving this review entirely to help inform other customers, with no personal animus towards the manufacturer. Please note that just because the Amazon description says "voice chat only" on one day doesn't mean that description was the same when I left the review or will be the same next week; Amazon descriptions can change frequently.I would prefer to leave a "star-less" rating, but since I have to leave a star-rating and since the device was uncomfortable to wear AND not accurately described at date of purchase, I have left 2-stars in order to inform other potential buyers. As the product has 500+ 5-star ratings already, this will not hurt the overall average rating, but will make it easier for shoppers to locate and understand drawbacks/limitations when making their purchasing decision.Thank you.

Stay On Satin (Extra Large) / B007I5256CI bought this to wear at night, but the "extra large" size is way too tight; I can barely get it on, and even then it's insta-pinched-headache time. I don't feel like I have a large head; my dress maker's tape shows a head circumference of a little under 23 inches, for what it's worth. Also, the material is *very* thin and feels like a single cat scratch would tear it. So I'm very disappointed.~ Ana Mardoll

Stay On Satin (Extra Large) / B00A6VJUC2I bought this to wear at night, but the "extra large" size is way too tight; I can barely get it on, and even then it's insta-pinched-headache time. I don't feel like I have a large head; my dress maker's tape shows a head circumference of a little under 23 inches, for what it's worth. Also, the material is *very* thin and feels like a single cat scratch would tear it. So I'm very disappointed.~ Ana Mardoll

Satin Pillow Case / B00BEZ546KI bought this case because I read that sleeping on satin, rather than cotton, would be better for my hair and would dry it out less. Let me just say that this is a stellar pillow case: it has a recessed zipper so that the case doesn't slide off the pillow and the satin flap over the zipper means you're not going to scratch yourself on it. I got the beige color and it's a nice dark-cream color. And all the stitching is very nice on this case; if I were going to do over all the pillows in the house in satin, I would use these.Unfortunately, it seems satin isn't really for me at this time. I have kind of a thin pillowcase that I like to "bunch up" under my head, and the satin causes the pillow to slide into a fully flat position. And on the rare times when I get the bunching up to stick, my head starts sliding off! Whoops! I'm going to keep the pillowcase, though, and experiment with buying a few more pillows and see if any of those work.So, bottom line: If you know you like satin, these are great pillowcases. If you're not sure; keep the receipt.~ Ana Mardoll

Zanies Rattling Hypno Mice / B000M1B7I6I bought these for my two cats, and they look absolutely lovely on the living room floor. They're stripey and colorful and not likely to be mistaken for a real mouse in the dark. They're also fur- and feather-free so they've yet to leave any sheddings on the floor or choking hazards. I will point out, though, that these are *very* hard so you don't want to step on them because they *will* hurt your foot. Shuffle like a zombie and you'll be fine.Alas, I cannot speak to the durability of these mice as my cats are too lazy to play with anything, including these. They perked up for about 20 seconds when they heard the mice rattle, but then remembered they were toy-snobs and went back to diligently ignoring the colorful pile of toys. Ah well.~ Ana Mardoll

Toddy Gear 5x7 Microfiber Cloth / B008XGTYT6I received a free review copy of this cloth (the French flag model, to be specific) and I just love it.I have about a zillion microfiber cloths because they always come included when I buy my Skinomi screen protectors. The problem is that the cheap microfiber cloths on the market attract cat hair like nothing else, and my very fluffy calico just loves to roll all over the cloths. After she's spent about five minutes rubbing her face on them, they're forever-furry and not something I want carrying in my electronics bag.Not so with these Toddy Gears! I'm not sure what the microfiber is made from, but it's obviously a high quality material and seems to have been doused in fairy dust because it's VERY cat hair resistant. I rubbed this cloth all over my calico (which was very painful for me to do, as it is a VERY nice cloth and I hated to ruin it, but I figure it's my job to try to break free review copy items!) and the only hair that stayed on the cloth was a few strands that got caught in the side-stitching and which were easily removed.The size of these cloths are pretty perfect for my 8" Samsung Note. I just lay the cloth on the screen and close my screen cover and everything stays snug and tight for traveling. I do wish these were a tad cheaper; for $7, I'd buy several more colors, but the current ten dollar price tag still seems just a bit steep. I've included pictures of the item in the product image gallery above.NOTE: This review is based on a free review copy of this product.~ Ana Mardoll

Toddy Gear 5x7 Microfiber Cloth / B008XGTYT6I received a free review copy of this cloth (the French flag model, to be specific) and I just love it.I have about a zillion microfiber cloths because they always come included when I buy my Skinomi screen protectors. The problem is that the cheap microfiber cloths on the market attract cat hair like nothing else, and my very fluffy calico just loves to roll all over the cloths. After she's spent about five minutes rubbing her face on them, they're forever-furry and not something I want carrying in my electronics bag.Not so with these Toddy Gears! I'm not sure what the microfiber is made from, but it's obviously a high quality material and seems to have been doused in fairy dust because it's VERY cat hair resistant. I rubbed this cloth all over my calico (which was very painful for me to do, as it is a VERY nice cloth and I hated to ruin it, but I figure it's my job to try to break free review copy items!) and the only hair that stayed on the cloth was a few strands that got caught in the side-stitching and which were easily removed.The size of these cloths are pretty perfect for my 8" Samsung Note. I just lay the cloth on the screen and close my screen cover and everything stays snug and tight for traveling. I do wish these were a tad cheaper; for $7, I'd buy several more colors, but the current ten dollar price tag still seems just a bit steep. I've included pictures of the item in the product image gallery above.NOTE: This review is based on a free review copy of this product.~ Ana Mardoll

Rosa Faia by Anita Active Range Front Closure Sports Bra / B000JLI4JYThis bra is made from what seems to be a high quality material, but I ordered it because it was available in higher sizes than the other front-closing bras on Amazon only to find that it runs WAY too small.I ordered a 42 band size and even though that's what the tags say on the bra, it isn't even close to a size 42 -- I couldn't even get the hooks to meet. My dressmaker's tape has this bra at 33 inches along the band, and it does NOT stretch the remaining 9 inches. I don't know what happened here, but I'm sending this back.I will also point out that the seller I purchased from, HerRoom, is making me pay for shipping to return this, which means I have to go stand in line at the post office which is a problem for someone with a disability (like me!) that makes that difficult. This did not affect my star rating, but I do want to make other shoppers aware of that since "runs small" tends to mean a lot of returns.~ Ana Mardoll

Closet Candy Hangars / B00A2AI8PMThe Closet Candy manufacturer contacted me and asked if they could send me a set of hangars in exchange for a review. I figured it might be fun, as I've never reviewed hangars before, so I said to send them along. When they got here, mindful of the fact that a beta tester is meant to try to break the product, I enlisted my husband to break these "unbreakable" hangars. For SCIENCE!Now, I'll note that the "unbreakable" claim is followed by the words "under normal daily use" and I believe it now. It took my husband well over five minutes to break this hangar, and we were seriously considering pulling out the power tools except that seemed unfair. (HANGAR VS. POWER DRILL! FIGHT!) He *finally* got it to snap by folding it in half about three dozen times, and then lying on his back, hooking his foot into the hangar bottom where the newly-created weak spot was, and then pulling with all his strength on the handle. I wasn't able to work out the physics of the amount of force applied, because I was too busy laughing at the amount of trouble this hangar was causing and how determined he'd gotten, but I feel reasonably confident estimating it at A LOT.By contrast, I was able to snap one of our old hangars on the first twist. And I'm nowhere near as strong as he. To add injury to insult, the regular hangar snapped in such a way that a shard splintered off, flew across the closet, and hit the bathroom mirror with considerable force. That seemed kind of hazardous, so we stopped the experiment at that point. But the Closet Candy hangar did NOT shatter, so I'm chalking that up to SAFETY.Others have pointed out how thin these are, so I won't belabour that point; the hangars are thin, your clothes may not be, your mileage may vary, etc. But something I personally really like is how strong they are and how well they keep their shape when holding heavy clothes -- I have some thick jeans and sweaters that usually bend thin hangars, but these are still straight and strong after several days use. My biggest disappointment, though, is that the dimples in the hangar-shoulders are ridiculously shallow and won't hold my spaghetti-strap clothes with any real conviction; for those I'll have to stick with the hangars that actually have a little sunken "holding area" for straps.At more than a dollar per hangar, I don't know that these are worth the price -- but then I haven't priced hangars lately. What I *can* say is that these are thin-but-sturdy, and they won't break unless you're *really* trying to damage them. So that's pretty impressive.NOTE: This review is based on a free review copy of this product.~ Ana Mardoll

Skinomi TechSkin for Samsung Galaxy Note 8.0 / B00C9HYTVSNormally I like the Skinomi skins; they aren't good for eInk devices (as I belatedly learned with my Kindle), but they work well with tablets and phones. And I love that the wet application method reduces bubbles and fingerprints and all the other little hassles which accompany putting on tablet skins.However, I have sadly learned that the Skinomi skins simply do not agree with the S-Pen that comes with the Samsung Note. The Skinomi skin has a pleasant "give" to it that makes it spongy, and the pen presses down into the spongy skin and leaves a permanent impression. After the Skinomi skin was applied, I drew a dinosaur later that night with the Sketch 'Em app, and the dinosaur was permanently etched into the skin to be seen forevermore. I ended up having to peel the skin off and toss it; a complete waste.I have attached pictures to the Amazon product page which I hope illustrate the problem.~ Ana Mardoll

The Flex Belt Ab Belt / B00340H2TUBecause I have a history of reviewing medical equipment from the perspective of my disability, the Flex Belt company contacted me and asked if they could sent me a promotional copy of this belt in the hopes that I might be moved to write a review. I researched the existing reviews online and noticed that at least one other openly disabled person had found good results with the belt, so I told them I would try it.I have been through two major back surgeries (the most recent being a little over a year ago).  I have three metal rods screwed into my back, and several of my vertebrae have been fused into a solid mass. My range of motion is *very* limited, and as a result there are very few stomach muscle exercises I can perform -- crunches and sit-ups are actively dangerous for me. Prior to my most recent surgery I was able to exercise my core muscles by repeatedly clenching them, but my last surgery left me so weak for so long that I lost that capability from extended disuse and muscle atrophy.What this device does is stimulate the underlying muscles by using electrical charges. I was able to confirm online through several sources that the electrical charge would not be dangerous to my internal metal rods -- and then mentally slapped myself because my physical therapist used a similar device directly on my back for several sessions a few years back. So I felt comfortable that this would be safe for me to use. (And, as anticipated, I have experienced no harmful side-effects.)The setup and use of this device is easy and has been covered more adequately elsewhere in the other reviews, so I'll just jump straight to my experiences with it. I've used this belt almost every day for a month, for 40 minutes per session. I have had zero trouble with the pads -- they went on the belt fine, and have never once tried to peel off or stay stuck to my skin. (I do try to do my sessions in the morning before my shower since they sometimes leave a slightly sticky residue.) I *really* like that the belt lets you set different electrical charge strength for the left and right side; my back surgery left the right side of my body significantly more numb, so I was able to use a stronger charge on that side.I started with the charge set to 20/25; after a month of use I'm now using 40/50. I've been testing during the day, and I have finally gotten to where I can clench my muscles on my own -- something I couldn't do for months before I started using this device. I'm really very pleased with that. (For the record, I have not lost weight, nor do I have visible stomach muscles, but I wasn't expecting to, and would have been deeply concerned if I had because I knew my body wouldn't react that way.) I've gone ahead and ordered replacement pads since the ones that came with the belt are getting kind of ratty.I'm glad that I had a chance to receive and review this device, but I'm not sure I'd throw down for the 199 dollar price tag if something happened to this one -- as it is, I'm already a little anxious about the 15 dollar recurring monthly cost of the replacement pads. I intend to keep using this for now, with the hopes of getting up to the max charge and see if I'm still seeing improvement in my core strength at that point -- if I'm not, I'll retire the belt with my blessings; if I am, I guess I'll keep using it regardless of the maintenance cost since I'm not precisely spoiled-for-choice when it comes to disabled-friendly devices. (I will say, though, that if there were one of these for arm muscles, I would definitely buy it, as I'm concerned that I may need to start building up for an eventual wheelchair.)NOTE: This review is based on a free review copy of this product.~ Ana MardollUPDATE: And I've just been informed that there *is* a Flex Arm, so I know what I'll be asking for at Christmas, lol.

Feathered Serpent / 0-609-61029-5Falconer shows his genius again with this fantastic novel. The characters of Cortes, Malinali, and Motecuhzoma are brought to vivid life on the page. In careful steps, Falconer outlines how a handful of men can wreak havoc on a powerful empire - provided that they are aided by a powerful mythology, by united allies driven by a long-standing enmity, and by a detrimental caution on the part of the empire.While I am not a student on the period in question, Falconer appears to hit the topic of historical accuracy as closely as one can expect with a historical novel. Cortes is shown to be a very clever tactician, but burdened with an unbending conviction of his own rightness at all times. Malinali is proud of her birthright and impressive talents as interpreter, but she has learned that women and slaves have little power in her world, and she uses her power carefully and cautiously. Motecuhzoma walks a fascinating tightrope between a shrewd emperor and a superstitious man, plagued by the many doomsday prophecies that his unhappy subjects issue on his head."Feathered Serpent" really shines with careful use of secondary characters to highlight the many aspects of the conflict. One Spaniard prefers the lifestyle of the American Indians, and he provides a useful narrative counterpoint by explaining that the American Indian custom of sacrificing humans is not fundamentally different in his view from the Spanish custom of burning witches, heretics, and Jews. Another Spaniard grapples with his initial distaste for the American Indians as it is rapidly counterbalanced with his growing distaste for his fellow Spaniards. The native woman Rain Flower acts as a foil to the determined Malinali as she struggles to gauge between her duty to her Spanish "husband" against her desire for her Spanish lover.Powerful and tasteful, "Feathered Serpent" carefully treads the historical and the personal by giving private details of the lives and thoughts of these compelling people without sliding into vulgarity. This book is a fantastic introduction to this period in American history and is a compelling read - I couldn't put it down until I finished it entirely.~ Ana Mardoll

Sultan's Harem / 1-4000-8312-5"The Sultan's Harem" is a spectacular tale of hatred and revenge, as Falconer weaves the tale of a single woman - a slave of the most powerful man in the world - who tears down a powerful empire by careful manipulation of the man who loves her. This one woman, Hurrem, manages to take down an entire empire, all while only ever being seen by a handful of men - the sultan and his personal eunuchs.Falconer makes it difficult not to admire our cold-blooded heroine, who staunchly refuses to be a good little harem girl and concubine to the man who bought her from her parents. She despises the man who tore her from her home as just another bauble to add to his vast harem, and whom she must amuse endlessly lest she be tossed callously aside for another girl in the harem. If she must play the game of harem politics to survive, she will play it - but survival is too meager a goal for her. Carefully and coldly, she devises a plan to bear a child, remove the Sultan's favorite, entice him to fall in love with her, and then secure her freedom and unprecedented marriage to the emperor. Even as a wife, she is still a slave in everything but name, and she ruthlessly turns her mental hold on her husband to send him spiraling into madness while the kingdom collapses slowly around him.Falconer carefully treads the personal and the political here, as with all his novels, and we see sympathetic glimpses into both the main players (sultan and sultana) and into the lives of the hapless girls living silently in his lavish harem. Each girl has her own history, her own loss, and her own sadness, and - faced with the realities of the harem, and of the monogamous sultan - finds her own pastimes and petty jealousies. Are these women better off than the ones on the outside? They are safe and pampered baubles in a collection of sex slaves that are almost never "used" by their relatively monogamous master. But the silence and loneliness gnaws at their souls and the passage of time weighs heavily on all involved. Is our dark heroine really so unusual in her hate and cruelty, or are her sisters in the harem just as enraged but powerless to act out?Gripping and suspenseful, "The Sultan's Harem" is a compelling read - I could not put it down. I agree with another reviewer in that the story would make a wonderful movie, should anyone ever acquire the rights. Like other Falconer novels, the writing is frank and does not shy away from the facts of life, but the writing is never lurid or vulgar.~ Ana Mardoll

No/No Red Cardinal Bird Feeder C00322 / B000HHLHK8I'm really impressed with how big and solid this feeder is; I was expecting something smaller, and was pleasantly surprised at the size. (In fact, it's too big to hang on our fence-hook, so I got this free-standing Shepherd Hook which has worked great.)The feeder itself is a little unusual (at least, to me). The middle part is collapsible, which means that the empty feeder is basically the top and the bottom sandwiched together. This is great for storage but does mean that you'll need to have the feeder actually hanging down from something (and therefore expanded) before you can fill it.The top of the feeder is covered by a "cap" with two sliding flat bolts that hold it in place; you can slide the bolts to the side and then slide the cap off to fill the feeder. I wish the cap was entirely removable, but they were probably afraid that the cap might get lost if we could take it all the way off.What I like most about this feeder is the construction. It's big and solid and feels super well-made and nicely built. The color is pretty and bright without looking garish or like it will chip or fade over time. I expect this to last a long time. I do wish the lip around the bottom was a little bigger, but I haven't had any problems with birds being able to use this, and I don't mind squirrels, so I'm quite happy with this big, sturdy feeder.NOTE: This review is based on a free Advance Review Copy of this product provided through Amazon Vine.~ Ana MardollUPDATE (5/26/13): Ohmigosh, I have never seen a cardinal in our neighborhood and I just now this morning saw a no-kidding cardinal at our feeder. Clearly this feeder SUMMONS THEM WITH HARRY POTTER MAGIC. (Seriously, I'm pretty stoked -- I didn't think we got cardinals in Texas.)

Fellowes I-Spire Series Tablet Lift / B00BXF5GKKThis is a very simple what-you-see-is-what-you-get tablet stand. It doesn't fold or collapse or disassemble; it comes exactly as you see in the picture with no assembly required. But there's a line between "simple enough" and "too simple" and I think this stand crosses it for me.1. Limited use for smaller devices. The "stand slot" has a hole in it I presume was added to accommodate a charge cable but which effectively limits the portrait uses of this stand. My 7" tablet falls through the slot if I try to sit it in portrait mode. My phone can just barely sit on the stand in landscape mode. So basically, this stand will accommodate most tablets and phones in landscape, but only the larger 9" crowd for portrait-viewing. This seems like a missed opportunity crying out for a narrower slot or a closing capability.2. Not adjustable. The stand angle is hard plastic with no way (that I can find) to adjust it. If you don't like the angle of the inserted tablet, it's up to you to jury-rig a solution (by adding a thicker or thinner cover) or to just live with it.3. No extras. Not everything has to be a charger or speaker dock or keyboard jack or combination desk lamp or whatever, but considering that those do exist at comparable prices, I'm not sure what makes this stand shine out from the crowd unless you're buying the complete matching desk set.I'll probably keep using this until I find something a little more adjustable. If you like simple and you have a large tablet, you'll probably find that this meets your needs.Update: I'm adding another star because, several months after receiving this, I'm finding that it's my go-to stand for when I want to watch Netflix on my tablet. I still wish it had adjustable options, but it clearly works very well for me for at least one use-case (movie watching), so I'm bringing this up a star in response. Also: After several months of semi-regular use, it still looks brand-new, so that's a nice plus.NOTE: This review is based on a free Advance Review Copy of this product provided through Amazon Vine.~ Ana Mardoll

Whitelines Link A4+ Lined Notes / B00AZT304OWhitelines Link A5+ Lined Notes / B00AZT302GI really, really like the concept of these notes, but I had to send both my notebooks back because they cannot meet my needs.One, I wrongly assumed that the product statement which indicates that the Whitelines Link application is available in the App Store included the Google/Android app store in that statement. It does not; the application for these notebooks is only available on Apple devices. After looking into the matter, I see that they have an IndieGoGo fundraising campaign seeking to raise 40k to make an Android app by summer 2013, but I needed something available to me now.Two, the front and backing on these notebooks are super flimsy -- they're about as firm as just having a sheet of paper as the front and back of the notebook. I know that some people are okay with that, but I like notebooks that will hold up to a lot of travel and wear-and-tear in bookcases and portfolios, and I can already tell that this isn't going to cut it.Overall, I still really like the concept, and I might try buying again (a harder-backed version next time) when/if they ever get an Android version up. But for right now, I needed the scanning email/evernote/dropbox markers on the paper to actually work and I don't have access to an Apple device so back they go. I wish the company the best of luck and I'm only leaving this review here because (at time of writing) there is nothing on the information page or in the reviews that provides this information on app availability and notebook front/back flimsiness.~ Ana Mardoll

Whitelines Link A4+ Lined Notes / B00AZT304OWhitelines Link A5+ Lined Notes / B00AZT302GI really, really like the concept of these notes, but I had to send both my notebooks back because they cannot meet my needs.One, I wrongly assumed that the product statement which indicates that the Whitelines Link application is available in the App Store included the Google/Android app store in that statement.
