Brand Failures / 9780749444334Who doesn't love reading about epic failures in marketing and product branding? A good "brand autopsy" can be both fun and educational, and can really help educate amateurs (like me) and marketing savvy experts alike on what pitfalls to avoid and how to properly package and market a new brand."Brand Failures" attempts to ambitiously tackle 101 famous branding mistakes and errors, from the classic "New Coke" to the failure of "Betamax" to Kodak's recent efforts to remain relevant in a world where casual consumers are increasingly turning away from film and to digital cameras. If there is a problem with this approach, it is that at 235 pages, each brand failure story is spread distressingly thin - most of the vignettes have less than 2 pages devoted to them. This simply isn't enough time and space to discuss all the factors that went into the failure of Enron, or Crystal Pepsi, or most of the other brands on display here.The other problem with this approach is that some of the "autopsy analysis" statements seem a little questionable. It's easy, of course, to say when a brand has failed, but it's much harder to say WHY the brand has failed. Did "Earring Ken" really fail because his 'alternative' approach to masculinity alienated homophobic parents, or did he fail for the same reason that Ken sales have traditionally lagged behind Barbie - because little girls care more about the doll they can project upon? Did the leather substitute Corfam really fail because it didn't "feel" as good as real leather, or was it because the company failed to emphasize the animal-cruelty issue (which would still be a failure to correctly market a brand, but a different failure than what is given here)? Did the HotWheels PC and Barbie PC fail because parents didn't appreciate the overt gendered marketing or because parents in 1999 weren't quite ready to invest heavily in personal computers for their children?In some ways, "Brand Failures" is a failure because the quick overview approach leaves a lot of questions unanswered and aspects unexplored. I would have liked to see this book about twice the length and containing half the products - a solid 10 pages or so per product would have given the reader a much better grasp of each product and a better look at why the brand *might* have failed, with heavier discussion on potential alternatives and competitors and market factors that may have doomed the product. In other ways, however, "Brand Failures" is a success because as a good overview of failed products, there is a lot of information here that probably can't easily be found elsewhere in a similarly compiled form. I think this would be a useful text for an "intro" course as a supplemental material to a meatier book, or an interesting foray into the subject for casual readers who are intrigued by the subject but don't want to get bogged down in a lot of extra details.NOTE: This review is based on a free Advance Review Copy of this book provided through NetGalley.~ Ana Mardoll

Jam / B00A7H2E3WI loved Yahtzee Croshaw's first book, Mogworld, and I went into Jam expecting to love it and I *did*, so at least I'm both consistent and predictable, lol. (And I'm already on tenterhooks hoping that Jam will come out on audiobook soon so that I can listen to it for a second read-through.) But let me also just state upfront that Jam is not going to be for everyone (though nothing ever is), and then I'll get to why.Jam is essentially a zombie apocalypse story with the zombies replaced by man-eating jam. Our point-of-view character wakes up one morning to find that his city was covered with three feet of jam while he slept and now it's up to him and the remaining few survivors to paw through the wreckage while navigating the rooftops of a ruined city. And this whole setup reminds me of one of Yahtzee's Zero Punctuation reviews -- I think it was one for Left 4 Dead -- where he theorized that as long as an author can re-create the tension and horror of the zombie apocalypse, you can replace the zombies with koalas and you'd still have a zombie story on your hands. And that's what Jam essentially is: a proof of concept that is delightfully grim and utterly original.If you've read Mogworld, you'll already be familiar with Yahtzee's style of writing: Jam is semi-serious, but with a strong undercurrent of parody and sardonic wit. Most of the main characters are recklessly stupid and detrimentally self-involved with their personal preoccupations to the point where they routinely prioritize trivial impulses over their basic survival. And in some ways, the villains are differentiated from the protagonists ONLY by a matter of degree: when everything goes all Lord of the Flies a few days after the apocalypse, there's a strong implication that the villains just spiraled down a little faster than the majority of our protagonists.What keeps the novel from being a bleak indictment of humanity (unlike your usual Lord of the Zombie Apocalypse novel) is the humor that saturates every page. The protagonists bicker amusingly with each other as they work around each others' shortcomings, and with dialogue that had me cracking up on numerous occasions; the villains are cartoonishly evil even as they shrewdly point out the flaws of the protagonists; and the apocalypse surges on around the confused and deeply distressed point-of-view character as he tries to adapt to the total destruction of everything he's ever known. It may not sound like a laugh riot, but it has the same delightful gallows-humor of Mogworld and I loved it: it's like if Douglas Adams wrote a zombie apocalypse with Arthur Dent as the POV character. And also there was jam.Having said all that, Jam isn't going to be everyone's cup of tea. Many of the protagonists really are (or eventually become) flawed, sexist, racist, stupid, and/or evil to the point where some readers aren't going to appreciate being forced to stick with them to the end; to continue the above analogy, picture Zaphod Beeblebrox slowly devolving from a sexist misanthrope to, well, significantly worse. The characters are frequently called out on many of their flaws, both by each other and by the narrative, but always in a humorously sarcastic way that doesn't really make way for catharsis or improvement. For myself, I found the dysfunctional dynamics of the group incredibly compelling to the point where I finished the book in a day (and enjoyed every minute of it), but I also recognize that dark humor surrounding dark characters isn't going to be for everyone. (Relatedly: if you require your zombie apocalypse novels to be inhabited by sensible characters, this isn't going to satisfy.)[SEMI-SPOILERS] Speaking of, Jam continues the Mogworld tradition of bittersweet endings where things are nominally fixed but still deeply, terribly broken. Now, granted, this is a zombie apocalypse novel and those are pretty much *guaranteed* to have bittersweet endings unless it turns out to have been a dream all along, but even allowing for the genre and the "sweet" part of the "bittersweet", there's still a profoundly sad note underlying the ending. As a reader, I didn't find the end dissatisfying, but ... it's not something that will sit well with everyone. Again, you'll probably be the best judge for yourself as to whether or not gallows-humor and tempered cynicism will be your thing or not. I offer no judgment on readers, either way. [/END SPOILERS]I genuinely enjoyed this book and (as mentioned) tore through it in a day simply because I couldn't set it down. The premise is delightfully original, the POV character is deeply sympathetic, and the main characters are flawed in that very special way where they would be utterly insufferable in real life and yet are amusing to follow in a novel just so you can see how badly they will screw things up and so they can all call each other out every five minutes (in a manner which suddenly reminds me of Brian Clevinger's 8-Bit Theater comics, which I also immensely enjoy). If you won't be put off by a little unrealism (in the world) and a lot of unreason (in the characters) in order to carry a lot of delightful gallows-humor, I absolutely recommend this book if only for the sheer uniqueness.~ Ana Mardoll

TEKwriterUSA Gelwriter Gel Pen Set with Pop-up Case / B00B80SOUEI ordered these through Amazon Vine along with their cousins: the pens in the "rotating" stand (TEKwriterUSA Gelwriter Gel Pen Set with Rotating Stand). I vastly prefer this pop-up case.For one, the pens come "pre-inserted" and not in a big bag like with the rotating stand. (Though they're not organized as prettily as in the picture, I think. But I'm unusually particular about these things, so.) For two, the rotating stand is wobbly, while this one is comparatively elegant and tight. The case works fairly simply: you twist the lid off, set the lid on the table, and then place the case onto the lid. A skinny little obelisk attached to the lid pushes up through the bottom of the case and the tiers stand up.It's reasonably elegant for the price, and I've had no issues occur while popping up or retracting; it all goes fairly smoothly. I was going to say that one thing I do wish is that the case came with a carrying handle, but then I ran my hands along the top and lo-and-behold there are TWO carrying handles. They just blended in with the design so well that I hadn't realized it. So that's awesome and I'm really pleased with that.The pens themselves are pretty great. Most of them start a little "dry", but if you press the tip against the paper a couple of times like the instructions say, the ink starts flowing smoothly. These aren't as fine a tip as I usually like, but the writing is still remarkably precise and controlled, and with no "bleed" that I've seen so far. I'm quite impressed, and I think I'll be using these a lot. I wish there were a few more black pens (I only got 6) and fewer brown pens (I have at least 10+ of those), but I guess I can't complain. And, as I've noted in my previous review, I still regret that the pens colors aren't labelled with writing as well as with colored grips: some printed colors like on my Crayola crayons would be a nice upgrade for the company to implement in the future.Bottom-line: Great pens; would be nice if they had printed color labels on the pen barrel; this pop-up case is WAY cooler than the rotating one, and it has carrying handles too.NOTE: This review is based on a free Advance Review Copy of this product provided through Amazon Vine.~ Ana Mardoll

TEKwriterUSA Gelwriter Gel Pen Set with Rotating Stand / B00B80SOVILook at that product picture! Isn't it pretty? YES. Do these pens arrive like that? NO. (*sadface*) The pens come in a big bag, all mixed together, along with the empty stand and it's up to you to try to recreate the display. I wish they could have at least packaged them by color, but I suppose one bag for everything saves plastic.Once I got the pens into the stand, I was a little underwhelmed. The stand is a touch wobbly and feels cheap, and the pens aren't inserted very deeply or securely -- I can pretty much guarantee that one of my cats will eventually brush too hard against it and there will then be a Big Mess to clean up. So I wouldn't count on using the stand in a high-traffic area frequented by grabby children or pesky cats.The pens themselves are pretty great. Most of them start a little "dry", but if you press the tip against the paper a couple of times like the instructions say, the ink starts flowing smoothly. These aren't as fine a tip as I usually like, but the writing is still remarkably precise and controlled, and with no "bleed" that I've seen so far. I'm quite impressed, and I think I'll be using these a lot. I wish there were a few more black pens (I only got 6) and fewer brown pens (I have at least 10+ of those), but I guess I can't complain.The approximate numbers above does lead me into one semi-major complaint: I'm a little irked that the pen color isn't written on the pen anywhere. The cap, the grip, and the bottom are all colored, so if you can see all colors equally well then you're fine, but if you have any kind of color-blindness, there are no words to help you differentiate as to what pen color you're using. (And before someone asks why a color-blind person would want to use a colored pen, I've worked in a lot of disciplines where colors were imbued with meaning for others, such as red ink for reviewing.) For myself, I'm not color-blind but I still struggled when assembling this display because I wanted to separate the orange from the brown and there were several pens where I just wasn't sure which was which from the external color. So some printed colors like on my Crayola crayons would be a nice upgrade for the company to implement in the future.Bottom-line: Great pens; would be nice if they had printed color labels on the pen barrel; some assembly required to recreate the pretty display; the stand isn't made to endure harsh treatment from clumsy hands.NOTE: This review is based on a free Advance Review Copy of this product provided through Amazon Vine.~ Ana Mardoll

CaseLogic 14" Neoprene Netbook Case / B001F7HI02I bought the 14" netbook case based on the measurements given in another review saying that this would fit 13-14" slim laptops. I have an ASUS Zenbook which has a 13.3" screen and is (when shut) 13" wide and 9" tall. This case fits my laptop with room to spare on either side, and I've been very happy with it.The front zippered pocket has a sewn-in case for USB sticks, and the interior for both pockets is a soft gray (I've attached pictures to the product listing above). Other than that, this case is no frills but in a good way -- it doesn't add a lot of bulk, and there are no handles to take up space in your larger bag (assuming that you carry this case in a messenger bag or backpack like I do). And the zipper is a nice strong rubber, which means it's not always trying to scratch up the other stuff in your bag.Overall, I'm very happy with this case for my laptop carrying needs, and I think the product is of high quality. I've already purchased the 7-10" version to carry my smaller Asus Transformer tablet and docking keyboard. (Which I think is why this review is labeled by Amazon as being a Verified Purchase for the 7-10" case instead of the 14". But they're both the same, except for the difference in size.)~ Ana Mardoll

CaseLogic 7" Neoprene Case / B004LSUR3MI bought this as an eReader carrying case. I own four eReaders, but I didn't expect them all to fit this 7" case. The results were (not entirely unexpected):1. Kindle Paperwhite with Amazon Leather Cover (fits)2. Sony PRS-350 with Silicone Cover (fits)3. Sony PRS-950 with Silicone Cover (doesn't fit; reader too tall)4. Nook Glowlight with Silicone Cover (doesn't fit; reader too wide)Note that even though this case does fit the Kindle Paperwhite w/ Cover, the resulting fit is a bit snug. But I like it that way, since I didn't want my reader rattling around in a big, mostly-empty case.Other than that, this case is no frills but in a good way. The interior is a clean, smooth black (I've attached pictures to the product listing above), and the case doesn't add a lot of bulk (unlike those 'bubble' cases, which tend to be larger and weightier). There are no external pockets, which is a bit of a shame, but I never really used them on my last case anyway. And the zipper is a nice strong rubber, which means it's not always trying to scratch up the other stuff in your bag.Overall, I'm very happy with this case for my eReader carrying needs, and I think the product is of high quality.~ Ana Mardoll

HP 11.6" Mini Sleeve / B002SU2DICI bought this carrying case for use with my Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 (7") student model. The student edition of the Tab comes with an 11" keyboard that features a hard drop-dock which sticks out at an angle. I searched high and low for a case that would accommodate both the keyboard and the tablet, and finally settled on this one.This case is 12" wide from side-to-side and 9" tall from top-to-bottom. The zippered opening is on the left side and is 9" wide -- perfect for sliding in my Tab keyboard. The front zippered pocket is 6.5" tall with a 12" zippered opening, and perfectly accommodates my tablet when I slide it in sideways (landscape). In this way, I'm able to protect both my tablet and keyboard without worrying that they will scratch each other or that the tablet will fall out. It's very difficult to find neoprene cases with zippered pockets that come up as high as this one does (nearly 7"), so I consider this case to be quite a find.Additionally, I was pleasantly surprised to note that this case has a little carrying handle at the top that slides flush with the case when not in use. So many cases have either bulky, floppy handles that are always in the way or no handle at all -- it's nice to see a case that has an invisible handle for use only when needed.~ Ana Mardoll

Fosmon GYRE Series Revolving Leather Case for Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 (7") / B009UV3PJII bought this case for my Galaxy Tab 2 on the grounds that it was white and I wanted a white case to match my white "student edition" of the Tab. I've been entirely happy with the case, given the idiosyncrasies that Samsung forces on users and case-makers.I love my Galaxy Tab 2, as well as the keyboard I received with my student edition, but I wish Samsung would adopt the Asus model for keyboards -- the Asus keyboards turn the tablet into a mini laptop that can be "shut" as needed, and the case-makers are able to create cases that enclose both the tablet and keyboard seamlessly as one. The Samsung keyboards, in contrast, have a solid dock-drop where the tablet is connected, and there's no moving from that position.I searched high and low, and couldn't find a single case that would accommodate the tablet while docked -- every case I found on Amazon has to be removed before the tablet can fit in the dock-drop. So if I must have a case that has to be taken on and off all the time, the next best thing is a case that comes on and off easily without (a) being a big hassle each time or (b) becoming loose over time such that the tablet is in danger of falling out. This case satisfies both requirements.This case is composed of a hard/firm snap case, where you press the Tab into place, and a leather cover that closes like a book cover and can be secured by means of an elastic strap sewn into the cover. The snap case works beautifully; the Tab snaps in without fuss, and then snaps back out again with moderate pressure -- not so little that you have to worry about it coming free in your bag, and not so much that taking the Tab out becomes a chore. The leather book cover is attached to the snap case via the circular swivel component, which lets you swivel the cover a full 360 degrees. This means that you can close the cover from either the left or the right side (depending on handedness and preference).You can additionally use the swivel combined with the grooves cut into the cover to loosely "stand" the tablet in place while using this cover. There are two cut grooves; the stand function works in landscape with both grooves, but in portrait with only the first groove -- if you use the second groove with portrait, the tablet will fall over. I feel that this is a product of the Tab's size and the cover limitations rather than a defect in the cover design, and the angle for the first groove is better suited for portrait viewing at any rate.Overall, I like this cover just fine. It does increase the size and thickness of the tablet, of course, but not so much that I find it bulky or difficult to carry. I think it offers good protection for the Tab when on the go, and I appreciate that it can be removed easily when I want to dock with the keyboard. I would have preferred something that can accommodate the keyboard dock without removal, but Samsung doesn't seem to consider that functionality enough of a priority to put out their own case. C'est la vie.~ Ana Mardoll

Brutally Honest Fast Food Reviews / B008PEZV20I usually enjoy blog-to-book collections, but this one didn't really hold my attention like I thought it would.To start with, I was disappointed with the technical aspects of this ebook. The pictures are displayed well, but the font-size seems stubbornly hard-coded to a very tiny font; using the Nook display options to increase the font-size didn't change the text size at all. This means that in order to read the book, you have to squint at the page until your eyes ache, and that didn't really enhance my reading experience. (This was as of February 2013, on the Nook version. I hope the publisher can fix this aspect after this review goes up.)Beyond technical issues, the content of this book was a little disappointing. I love a good snarky entertainment review, and for awhile this book delivered. But a lot of the jokes are repetitive and one-note, like the "joke" that fast food isn't considered terribly healthy fare. That's not exactly a new and original joke, and to see it repeated here in every other joke in the book ... well, it gets old fast. Maybe this would have been funnier on a website where the jokes were interspaced by time or by other reviews, but in a book collection, it starts to feel like every 'chapter' is the same.Adding to this feeling of repetition, the reviews are grouped by restaurant (McDonalds, Burger King, Taco Bell, etc.) instead of appearing in the order they were published on the blog. This is probably useful if you were wanting to drill directly down to a specific product, but if you're just a reader looking for something entertaining, the result is somewhat detrimental. Reviews across a specific restaurant -- like, say, Taco Bell -- contain the same jokes each time, with similar lead-ins each time about how the reviewer has historically felt about that restaurant. Again, on a blog this would make sense because it may have been three weeks since the last Taco Bell review and new readers might need to be brought up to speed, but in a book format the result is repetitive and bogs down the reading.Unless you're already a fan of this blogger (and therefore just want a book collection to save off your favorite posts), I would recommend giving this book a pass. It seems like a nice blog, but I didn't find it to be an entertaining book.~ Ana Mardoll

Baggallini Zipper Bagg / B002ZG92BKI've been using an eBags Piazza Day Bag for the last couple of years and while I really like the purse, I wanted something a bit smaller. I thought I'd try this purse, but I ended up having to send it back as it was too small for my needs.The product description claims that the purse is 9" x 9" x 2.5", but I genuinely think that the depth is much smaller than that. Here is what I hold in my Piazza purse: long thin credit card wallet (upright), glasses case (upright), very small leather bag with toiletries (lengthwise), Kindle Paperwhite (upright), keys and eyedrops (side pocket). I don't feel that's a whole lot to stuff in a purse, but I wasn't able to fit it all in this bag -- the wallet, glasses case, and leather bag were all arguing with each other, the bag was bulgy in the center, and it kept falling over in defeat.Most disappointing of all, the outer pockets don't have any expansion room, so you can really only fit something very flat in there -- flatter even than my already-pretty-flat Kindle Paperwhite. So I ended up sending this bag back and I will keep searching for something that holds my stuff while being fairly compact.Incidentally, this was my first Baggallini bag, and I was pleased with the material. The mushroom color is a nice medium brown, and the internal blue liner was very attractive. The nylon was light-weight, which is important for me in a purse, and the strap was easy to adjust, though a little more thin than I would have liked. The zipper pulls were pretty, but a little heavy. I'll probably try Baggallini again sometime, but will "size up" accordingly.~ Ana Mardoll

Skinomi TechSkin for Kindle Paperwhite / B009CG0LOII love the Skinomi TechSkins. They apply so much more easily than 'regular' skins, and whoever thought of the liquid application is a genius. What's more, the bubbles and streaks always dry out for me within a few hours, and I'm almost always happy with the final product. I currently have Skinomi protectors on at least 4 electronics in my house, and any time I get a new device I always go straight to Amazon to order a Skinomi for it.I can also vouch for their no-hassle lifetime warranty on these skins: after I applied this skin to my Paperwhite, I noticed that there was a small tear in the plastic that I am 99.9% sure I didn't cause. I wrote them what had happened, and they sent a new skin out that very day, no further questions asked and no extra cost for shipping. Now that is what I call great customer service.But. As much as it pains me to say it, I wasn't able to stick with this protector on my Paperwhite. I usually don't notice any added glare with the Skinomi skins, but I guess it's different on an e-ink screen rather than on an LCD one (like my tablet and phone). When I tried to read my Paperwhite with this skin on under the florescent lights at the local Y, the screen was pretty much unreadable from the glare. After a lot of experimentation with holding my reader at different angles, I gave up and removed the skin.If you're going to use your Paperwhite only at night in dark rooms, I think this skin will work just fine for you, but if you're going to be reading under bright lights -- particularly florescents -- then the glare will probably be very distracting. I've uploaded some customer photos that I took with my phone which show the glare effect and you can decide for yourself whether it's worth the added screen protection.~ Ana Mardoll

The Princess Curse / 978-0062008138Here is what you need to know about "The Princess Curse": I started the book a little after dinner one evening, and ended staying up till after midnight to finish this addictive and satisfying story."The Princess Curse" manages to seamlessly blend the fairy tale of the twelve dancing princesses with the Persephone myth, and does so in a way that is truly intriguing. I am enormously impressed with Haskell's elaborate world-building as well as with her ability to deal out gripping (and often delightfully creepy) details about the curse as the novel progresses.I am also deeply pleased with the characterization in this novel; even the "bad" characters are complex and if not sympathetic then at least understandable. And the heroine and her interactions with others is delightful: it's very nice to see Haskell's dialogue unfold organically, and to have a main character who understands how to maunevre herself thoughtfully through socially fraught conversations. For every reader who has hated Big Misunderstanding plot-twists and has wanted characters to just talk and think things out a little more, here is a novel that does that very thing.Another nice detail is that the protagonist Reveka is an herbalist's apprentice, and this shines through every time she's on the page. She has a real passion for her craft, she thinks in terms of herbs and remedies, and she approaches problems like a professional solving a puzzle. It's wonderful to have a protagonist who is truly unique from all the blank 'reader insert' characters out there -- you may not be much like Reveka, but I can almost guarantee you will find her interesting and likable.I also absolutely love that there are more female characters than male ones in this novel, and despite this being a novel with a 'historical setting', there isn't really a huge heap of sexism on display every five minutes. Instead, there are powerful women in the novel -- an Abbess, a herb-wife, a witch, an herbalist's apprentice, a Princess Consort, etc. -- who are powerful because they are clever and intelligent and because the men around them are willing and able to recognize their talents and give them space to use them. It's really wonderful to read a 'historical' setting which acknowledges that, okay, yeah, sexism exists while still giving its female characters room to be awesome and letting its male characters be sensible about the situation rather than being enormous jerks every five minutes for no good reason. More of this, please.If there is a place where this novel falls down a little, it is perhaps the ending. (Minor spoilers ahead.) I like that the ending is happy, but in places it feels a little too cozy and a little too unfinished. There's actually a line that sounds a lot like the old "and that's how I spent my summer vacation" stereotypical ending for old books and films which weren't sure quite how to wrap things up. And there are a number of dangling minor plot holes, which I'm not sure were avoidable given the specific myths involved, but which kind of niggle at your brain an hour after putting the book down. But I feel kind of picky enjoying an exquisite 5-course dinner only to harp that the dessert course was a bit short and a little too sweet.If you enjoy fairy tale re-imaginings, and particularly if you enjoyed the fairy tale of the twelve dancing princesses (a particular favorite of mine), I believe you will think "The Princess Curse" was worth the read. In spite of the occasional little plot hole or hiccup in the narrative, the overall writing style is fresh and evocative, and the final product is a tale that manages to be dark in the telling but bright in the resolution.[Content Notes (Spoilery!): Some ableist terminology which may be intended as deconstructive; blood and bleeding feet; some mention of torture in the context of iron shoes; kidnapping, Stockholm Syndrome romances, and underage marriages (but no sexual content, and an explicit-and-tactful denial that underage sex is taking place); comatose patients; religious themes involving witchcraft, paganism, and immortal souls and their possible salvation/damnation; minor discussion of siege warfare; some discussion of abusive orphanage upbringing.]NOTE: This review is based on a free Advance Review Copy of this book provided through Amazon Vine.~ Ana Mardoll

Hamilton Beach Big Mouth Juicer / B000FHQJ6CI bought this juicer back in 2009 and have used it less than I'd hoped (more on that in a minute) but often enough to feel that the purchase was worth it. When a Kuvings NJ-9500U Centrifugal Juice Extractor came up on Vine, I figured I was well-placed to review an expensive juicer and contrast it with the cheaper stuff on the market, and post the same essential review in both places. But I'll just cut to the chase right here: as a hobbyist juicer who just wants to whirl the juice out of a handful of fruits, I cannot honestly tell that much of a difference between the expensive Kuvings and the half-price Hamilton -- the Kuvings is better in some ways, but it's not twice as good in proportion to being twice as expensive.* Parts: Both the juicers have mostly the same basic parts: base (with cord and buttons), whirl-er (where the mesh screen sits and the juice comes out), pulp-bucket (where the waste goes), top (where the fruit is fed), and piston (to help jam the fruits through the top and to the whirl-er. But I was surprised to see that the juice pitcher that came standard with the Hamilton is NOT included with the Kuvings; you have to supply your own bowl for the juice to pour into, and since our bowl was wide and uncovered, the new juice pouring in caused the existing juice to splash lightly all over the nearby counter, which I found quite annoying.Advantage: Hamilton.* Weight: The juicers take up about the same footprint on the counter, in terms of width and height. The immediate obvious difference is that the Kuvings is plastic and lighter, whereas the Hamilton is heavier and uses stainless steel clamps. The lighter Kuvings is easier to carry, but I don't know how sturdy the clamps will be over time. Personally, I care more about weight than about sturdiness (we tend to 'baby' our appliances in general).Advantage: Kuvings* Assembly: The Kuvings is more fussy at assembly time; the pulp-bucket has to be sort of tilted up and in and snapped into the top before then being tilted down and sideways to snap into the bottom. The Hamilton, in contrast, just has the pulp-bucket sit flush to the side and the top secures it in place.Advantage: Hamilton.* Speeds: The Kuvings has two speeds, regular and turbo; the Hamilton only has one. Since I only use fruits with my juicers (and therefore only use the regular speed on the Kuvings), I can't say whether the turbo speed is worth the extra cost. That's something to look into if you're planning to use really tough veggies in your juices.Advantage: Neither / Depends.* Noise: The Kuvings boasts a 350-watt motor while the Hamilton uses an 800-watt motor. I do think the Kuvings is less noisy, but not proportionately so and not so much that it doesn't still mightily startle the cats. What I am saying is, when you are using the Kuvings, the rest of the house is aware that you are using the Kuvings. And when you are using the Hamilton, the rest of the house is aware that you are using a slightly louder version of the Kuvings. Neither of them are so loud that the neighbors will hear, nor so soft that you won't disturb your napping husband.Advantage: Kuvings.* Cleaning: Cleaning is the major reason I don't juice more often, and it's an area where I think improvement is possible. The only thing that doesn't need to be cleaned after juicing is the base (unless it got dripped on, which does happen); the whirl-er, piston, pulp-bucket, and juice pitcher will all need cleaning. (I did see recommended in another review that the pulp-bucket be lined with a plastic bag, which is a good idea I will try next time.)This means that if you want a quick juice on your way in to work, you have to assemble the juicer, run the juicer, unassemble the juicer, and either wash everything or at least put all four parts in the sink to soak. If you skip the unassemble-and-wash steps, you will come home to a sticky caked-on mess that will be a nightmare to clean. And since none of this is particularly fast, it means that your 'quick juice' is going to be a 20-minute proposition. No, that doesn't mean that the juicers are "hard" to clean, but it does take time -- or at least it does for us. (Maybe the rest of you have super-speed powers. If so, please come wash my dishes?)Both the Kuvings and the Hamilton use the mesh-screen whirl-er and that little guy is a fright to get clean. Husband -- who does the dishes in our family -- has declared after a great deal of consideration that the Kuvings mesh is slightly faster to scrub clean than the Hamiltons mesh, so I will award the advantage on his say-so but with the caveat that the Kuvings mesh still took several minutes of scrubbing to clean. (Husband also registers a concern that the Kuvings cleaning brush doesn't seem very sturdy. But we'll cross that bridge when we get there.)Advantage: Kuvings.* Juiciness: Both the Hamilton and the Kuvings juiced the heck out of a collection of apples and clementines, and in both cases the pulp was very dry afterward. And in both cases there was a lot of flecky foam that can either be strained with a cheesecloth or can be stirred in and drunk. We saw no difference in actual juicing performance between the two juicers.Advantage: Neither / Identical Performance.---I'm pretty sure that if you add everything up mathematically, the Kuvings comes out as better than the Hamilton. But the advantage overall is pretty slight -- the Kuvings is lighter, but seems more in danger of breakage; the Kuvings is less noisy, but not super-noticeably so; the Kuvings takes a minute less to clean but a minute more to assemble; and so forth -- and for twice the price I'm more than a little irked that there's no juice pitcher included because it means that if you don't have a bowl or glass that can fit under the juice nozzle, then you'll have to make another trip to the store.If you're a first time juicer and aren't sure how much you will use your new appliance, I would recommend starting with the Hamilton and seeing how you like it and whether the excessive clean-up process is a turn-off for you. But I would recommend buying the Kuvings over the Hamilton if:* You have strict weight-lifting limits. (I have a bad back.)* You intend to pulp a large volume and/or tough veggies. (Turbo speed!)* You need a less-noisy motor for medical reasons.Otherwise, I think both juicers are very good and do the job they're meant to do.~ Ana Mardoll

(Turbo speed!)* You need a less-noisy motor for medical reasons.Otherwise, I think both juicers are very good and do the job they're meant to do.NOTE: This review is based on a free review copy of this product provided through Amazon Vine.~ Ana Mardoll

To extend the life of Birkenstock sandals, it is important to keep the cork bed sealed and protected from weathering and wear and tear.  Kelly's Cork Renew was recommended by a local shoe repair shoe for this purpose and it works great: goes on easily, dries to a tough clear finish, and protects the cork foot bed. Apply it ONLY to the cork foot bed and not to the other parts of the sandal. Highly recommended!

Tripp Lite is well known for the quality of their products and their great customer service. Unlike others, they stand behind their warranty (Lifetime Warranty and $50,000 Ultimate Lifetime Insurance). This rotatable six-outlet surge protector is heavy duty  with 1080 joule surge suppression rating with EMI/RFI line noise filtering, is extremely well designed, has a heavy-duty cable, and the plugs have a smooth rotating movement. It also includes a built-in dual port USB Charger (3.4 amps total). Already, it is my favorite surge protector of all the ones I own. You can't go wrong with it. Highly recommended!

I have used Meltonian shoe cream for many years. It is an excellent product, made with consistently high standards, goes on easily, polishes nicely, protects and restores the look of the leather, and doesn't dry out in the jar. It comes in a wide range of colors. For best results, if you can't find a match to your shoe color, choose a lighter (rather than darker) shade. It is sold in shoe repair shops everywhere and they must know something. Highly recommended!

I bought this autobiography upon the death of Dean Jones on September 1, 2015. He was a fixture in many 1960s Walt Disney family films (such as The Love Bug and Blackbeard's Ghost) as well and on stage and television. This book tells the story of how he overcame personal demons through Christ and found happiness. He discusses career achievements through the lens of his search for personal fulfillment. Overall, it was a nice read, but I was hoping for more on his friendship with Steve McQueen and other stars and on his work for Disney. Highly recommended!

Excellent storage case. It is inexpensive (especially when compared to the Sony CKSX5 Carrying Case for SRSX5 Portable Speaker (Gray)), holds both the Sony SRSX5 Portable NFC Bluetooth Wireless Speaker System (Black) with Speakerphone and the Sony SRSX55/BLK Powerful Portable Bluetooth Speaker (Black) snugly, is well made, can carry accessories (like the AC adapter), and can be rolled up into a small package when not in use. I also appreciate the nicely integrated carrying handle. Highly recommended!

I am extremely impressed with the quality of both the video and audio of the new 4K restoration of "My Fair Lady" for the 50th anniversary of the film! Audrey Hepburn has never looked better! As of this review, be careful when ordering since only the "multi-format" version is the newly restored version. The Blu-ray and DVDs look to be the older (non-4K) version. Look for the "50th Anniversary" bubble on the package when ordering. Highly recommended!

I bought this book after reading an excellent review of it on the Daily Mail website (dated November 3, 2015). I recommend that you read the article before your purchase. It is a large coffee table book filled with pictures and the stories of the 628 Victoria Cross heroes for World War One. It is well laid out, beautifully done, and all the pages are in color. If you are interested in British history and the First World War, you will enjoy this book. Highly recommended!

"Downfall" is an amazing German-language film (with English subtitles) that tells the story of Hitler's final days. The story is a factual account based on well documented sources and is told for the perspective of one of his secretaries. The performance by Bruno Ganz as Hitler was truly amazing. The production was first-rate and included the construction of a replica of Hitler's bunker so the film would be as accurate as possible. Highly recommended!

I was inspired by this well written account on Sophie Scholl and the other members of the White Rose resistance group. In modern German, the White Rose is an important symbol for the half million German citizen persecuted and 100,000 citizens murdered by the Nazis and their story should be better known. This book is an excellent companion to the well done movie, Sophie Scholl - The Final Days. I highly recommend both.

This movie can be summed up as how one man beat the hide-bound British establishment and his own incompetent coworkers at Bletchley Park to develop the machine (almost single-handedly) that opened the door to the intelligence that won World War Two. Exciting stuff if it were actually true! If you read the book upon which this movie was based, Alan Turing: The Enigma: The Book That Inspired the Film "The Imitation Game", you will find that much of the story and most of the dramatic moments in the film were made up out of whole cloth. A few examples (!!! SPOILER ALERT !!!):- Turing thinking up a scheme to identify potential cryptology candidates through a puzzle contest -- he never did that and never personally administered those tests. In fact, Joan Clarke (played by Keira Knightley) was not recruited in that way in any case.- Turing sending a personal letter to Churchill to complain about the lack of resources due to clueless leadership at Bletchley Park -- he did write a letter that was given directly to Churchill requesting additional personnel and resources, but it was also signed by most of his peers at Bletchley Park and also defended the leadership there.- The British bombe decryption machine was never called "Christopher" as it was portrayed in the movie. In fact, many machines were eventually made and were located offsite from Bletchley Park.- Turing realizing he could use a daily weather message to give the bombe enough information to determine the German Enigma machines settings, then used those settings to decode German naval messages and plot all the positions of U-boats and German navy ships on a map in one night -- never happened. Upon cracking the Enigma, British Intelligence had to develop a large organization to interpreted and exploit the information. For instance, U-boat positions were reported using a grid system. The British did not have access to the map used by the Germans with those grid designations and had to develop one through painstaking analysis. That had to be done before U-boat positions could be plotted.- Turing locking himself in the room with the bombe while armed guards came to arrest him -- never happened.Bottom line, this movie diminishes (rather than celebrates) the scale of the intelligence challenge and achievements made by Alan Turing and the army of hardworking personnel at Bletchley Park in order to make a politically correct statement. Turing deserves to be celebrated, but not through a fairytale such as this.

I bought this twin-pack of shoelaces to replace the poor quality laces that came with my Pikolinos Mens Glasgow 05M-6543 Casual Shoes and could not be happier! These laces are strong, well made, and are offered in a wide variety of sizes. Highly recommended!

I bought these from Costco and love them! They are comfortable, well designed, fit nicely into the low-profile case (included), are noise-cancelling, sound great, and support hands-free phone calls. The controls are well designed and I had no trouble at all connecting them to my Samsung Galaxy Note 4, Frosted White 32GB (Sprint) via Bluetooth (version 3.0). The headphone controls are easy to use and allow you to chose from four separate listening modes: wireless Bluetooth with noise cancelling (up to 13 hour of usage/charge), wireless Bluetooth (up to 19 hours of usage/charge), digital noise cancelling (up to 24 hours of usage/charge), and passive mode with optional cable (included). The entire kit includes: the padded carrying case, accessories pouch, audio cable, USB cable, and USB charger. As with most Bluetooth products Sony sells, the headphones have one-touch Near Field Communications (NFC) support. Highly recommended!

I bought a pair of these shoes about a year ago from Zappos (a company owned by Amazon) and love them. They are very light, well made, comfortable, and good looking. They come with removeable inserts and the soles have held up very well. I find these shoes run a full size large. I wear size 11 1/2 and bought a pair in a size 45, as per the size chart, and they are too large, although wearable. I have since purchased other Pikolinos shoes in a size 44 and am much happier with their fit. The shoebox includes a small Pikolinos shoe cleaning kit: foam brush and sample polishing cream. Unfortunately, as with all the other Pikolinos shoes I have owned with laces, the shoelaces have not held up and I have had to replace them early. For such a expensive shoe, they should have lasted longer. As a replacement, I purchased Round Dress Very Thin Brown 33 inch Shoelaces 2 Pair Pack. Highly recommended (except for the shoelaces)!

I bought a pair of these shoes about a year ago from Zappos (a company owned by Amazon) and love them. They are very light, well made, comfortable, and good looking. They come with removeable inserts and the soles have held up very well. I find these shoes run a full size large. I wear size 11 1/2 and bought a pair in a size 45, as per the size chart, and they are too large, although wearable. I have since purchased other Pikolinos shoes in a size 44 and am much happier with their fit. The shoebox includes a small Pikolinos shoe cleaning kit: foam brush and sample polishing cream. Unfortunately, as with all the other Pikolinos shoes I have owned with laces, the shoelaces have not held up and I have had to replace them early. For such a expensive shoe, they should have lasted longer. As a replacement, I purchased Round Dress Very Thin Brown 33 inch Shoelaces 2 Pair Pack. Highly recommended (except for the shoelaces)!

Since the Kindle version of this book is free, I highly recommend it for anyone who owns a Kindle Fire. I purchased it to help me better understand the capabilities of the Fire HD 10, 10.1" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 16 GB - Includes Special Offers, Black and it has been helpful. It is a good complement to the manual produced by Amazon.com. Whether you have just purchased your first Fire or have had many, this book will add value to your Fire experience. Highly recommended!

I bought this speaker as a gift for my mother so she could get more out of her Fire, 7" Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB - Includes Special Offers, Black. I have been extremely impressed with the powerful and crisp sound this stereo speaker produces from such a small footprint! The speaker is not much larger than a paperback book. That said, the sound is best when not at full volume. It is best suited for a small to mid-sized room or in a local area of a large room. My mother (who is not tech-savvy) loves the great sound, small size, and intuitive controls. I liked it so much I bought one for myself! Highly recommended!The good:- Small footprint.- Clean, sharp, crisp sound with up to 30 watts of power.- Dedicated subwoofer with dual passive radiators for deep bass sound.- Easy to setup.- Excellent Bluetooth performance and NFC technology.- Built-in USB charging port (on the back).- Aux-in 3.5mm audio jack for direct connection to the speakers.- Speakerphone functionality.- Ten-hour battery life.The bad:- Only one physical control button (on/off), the rest of the controls are touch sensor points which are almost impossible to use in a dark room. I would have preferred that all the controls have real buttons as my other Sony Bluetooth speakers have had in the past. Apparently, Sony has gone this route for all their current Bluetooth speakers, not just this one.- The top surface of the speakers is glossy black which is a fingerprint magnet.

I love this 7.0" tablet. I bought six as part of a six-pack deal and could not be happier! It is truly an excellent value for the money!The good:- Excellent Wi-Fi performance with dual-band capability.- Excellent Bluetooth performance. I use this tablet with both a Bluetooth mouse and keyboard (links below).- Has a MicroSD card port that can accept up to a 128GD card.- Two adequate built-in cameras: VGA front-facing camera and a 2 MP rear-facing HD camera.- Fantastic new user interface replacing the tedious "carousel" found in earlier models.- Decent battery life.- Attractive display, but not the sharpest I have seen.- Extremely easy out-of-the-box setup.- The Amazon Silk browser is SO MUCH more stable than earlier versions I have owned!The bad:- This tablet does not have a "sleep" feature which would allow it to be put to sleep by means of the magnetic closure of a case in which it is placed.- No "Mayday" customer support button -- this feature was advertised before product release!- The sound out of the mono speaker is too soft. To hear anything adequately, I have to max out the volume.- As of this review, Amazon has not yet posted a user's manual for this tablet. The customer service representative I talked to said it should be posted in a week.Instructions from Amazon Customer Service on how to insert the MicroSD card into this tablet:- To insert a MicroSD card, hold your Fire tablet vertically (like for portrait viewing), with the front-facing camera top center in the tablet. The Micro SD card slot will be on the upper right-hand side of your device.- Open the MicroSD card port cover and rotate it slightly to reveal the MicroSD card slot. With the notch in the MicroSD card facing up, carefully insert the card into the slot -- the copper contacts on the MicroSD card should be facing toward the back of the tablet and the printing on the card facing toward the screen.- Push gently on the MicroSD card until it locks into place.Accessories I recommend for this tablet (and own): Amazon Fire Case (5th Generation - 2015 release), Black, Microsoft Sculpt Comfort Bluetooth Mouse, Logitech Keys-To-Go Ultra-Portable Bluetooth Keyboard for Android and Windows, and SanDisk Ultra 128GB Ultra Micro SDXC UHS-I/Class 10 Card with Adapter (SDSQUNC-128G-GN6MA).

I have been a fan of Coach wallets for many years since I bought my first one at their flagship store in San Francisco (at 190 Post Street) in the early 80s. I have worn this style wallet ever since and my current one has lasted over five years and should last for at least several more. I love the quality leather, workmanship, and classic design. The price has remained very consistent despite inflation over the past thirty years. One reason for this may be that Coach has clearly cut a few corners in the past 15 years or so to keep the cost down: the wallet is lined with nylon fabric instead of the gorgeous leather lining they used to use; and most (if not all) of the wallets are now made overseas and not in the United States. Highly recommended!Products I use for the care of this wallet (and own): Coach Leather Brown Logo Leather Cleaner Bottle 6oz, Coach Leather Moisturizer-6 Oz, Lexol 1112 pH-Balanced Leather Cleaner, 1-Liter, and Lexol 1013 Leather Conditioner, 1-Liter

This is a beautiful coffee table-size book that has the complete comics action of Mad Magazine's Spy vs Spy as drawn by artist Antonio Prohias. The book is well made with quality paper and inks and will last many years. All of the drawings are in black and white as is fitting for these two black-and-white-dressed intelligence service warriors. Highly recommended!

These are amazing headphones! They are high-end, well made, have a quality build, and a smooth, rich, well-balanced sound in an over-the-ear headphone design that shuts out quite a bit of external noise. The earpads are removable (held in place by magnets) and there is an extra cable with a built-in microphone and volume control that turns the P7 into an Apple-friendly headset. The kit also includes a gorgeous black carrying case and a P7 standard audio cable. Additionally, I love the premium black leather and chrome metal detailing used on these headphones. Highly recommended!A note on fulfillment: I am sorry that I have to weigh-in on Amazon Warehouse and Third Party fulfillment in the product review, but it is important to warn others. It took me FOUR separate orders (and three returns) to get a pair of used headphones that were "as described" on the Amazon.com website and had all the accessories. That has never happened to me before. The refurbished ones do not include the case and the P7 standard audio cable. The others (except for the most recently received one -- the "keeper"!) were either trashed or missing cables. I bought a used set to keep the price down, because these headphones are pricey, but I was put "through the wringer" for it.Note: The headphones I ultimately received that are "keepers" were described as in "Used - Very Good" condition and are, in fact, in better condition than that. All the "Used - Like New" headphones I ordered were either trashed or missing cables.

I bought two of these fobs to replace 18-year-old original Viper fobs that are no longer working properly: work intermittently and no longer have the range they once had -- you have to be very close to the car door for them to work. I only bought these replacement fobs because they were described as "reconditioned". Unfortunately, what I actually received looked ancient (grimy, badly worn, and very old) and are in worse condition than my 18-year-old original fobs! With these electronic devices it isn't good enough that the green light works, they need to produce a strong signal, as well, to use them at distance from the car. Opening the cases, I found the circuit boards were filthy and the components were oxidized. I have no faith they would function any better than the ones I already have. Additionally, the price ($15) is way too high for something in this condition. At best they should be priced at no more than five dollars. You could do better than this at your local automobile junk yard. The following is the text of the email I received from the seller confirming these fobs are marginal: "I am sorry to hear that. That is what they are. Understand please these remotes are no spring chicken and are very old models."

I am really impressed with the restoration given to this 1959 film. It is amazing war drama with standout performances by Jeff Chandler and Jack Palance as German bomb demolition specialists working in the ruble of post-war Berlin. The film has a strong documentary feel and was shot in bomb blast sites in Berlin. In fact, on one occasion production had to be delayed until an actual bomb was defused! I have always found it suprising that director Robert Aldrich considered this film "awful" and it was plagued by production, distribution, screenplay and personnel problems. In fact, 40 minutes of footage was cut from the film before its release. It would have been nice if some of that missing footage was included in this Blu-ray release as a "Special Feature". Highly recommended!

Like other reviewers, I bought this CD mainly for the fantastic "Le Mans" tracks. I would have preferred it if all of the tracks from the  Steve McQueen's "Le Mans" Soundtrack were included in this album, but the producer made hard choices to keep it to one CD. The quality of the music is excellent and appear to be remastered. Highly recommended!

I bought this for a Magnum Damascus Black Bone Knife. This is my second Boker leather sheath (my other one is a Boker Leather Sheath I). They are both well made from beautiful full grain leather and are an excellent value. I prefer this one (the Sheath III) over the Sheath I because the color is a little darker and the Boker Tree logo is a bit more pronounced. It fits my four-inch long knife perfectly. There is is still a little more room, so it could fit a slightly longer knife as well. My only complaint is the belt loop consists of two slots cut in the back of the case. I would have preferred a stitched-on leather loop. Highly recommended!

I bought a used ("new" condition) pair of these earbuds from the Amazon Warehouse and am extremely happy with their quality and the excellent deal I received. I really notice the brilliant sound these earbuds produce; although, they are not very comfortable to wear (but not painful) and the sound from my high-end headphones is superior. They come with a gorgeous lined black suede leather carrying case. I have not has any of the issues reported by other reviewers (static, etc.) in negative reviews  and recommend you consider the Amazon Warehouse as an option to keep the price down. Highly recommended!

I bought these headphones as a gift and appreciate their deep rich sound, light weight, good looks, comfort, and portability. Compared to other similar headphones (like the Sony MDRZX110 ZX Series Stereo Headphones (Black)), I find that I have to turn up the volume on the devices I use these headphones with in order to get the sound I want. Highly recommended!

A very nice traditional Japanese folding knife. I don't recommend carrying this in your pocket, because the simple thumb-lever for opening the blade sticks out and could poke a hole in your pocket. The handle is made of folded sheet metal. Recommended if you are interested in owning a very Japanese blade.

I received this book yesterday and have to agree with other reviewers, this is a riveting account and I can't put it down! I learned about this book from an excellent review on the Daily Mail website on November 5, 2015. In addition to giving Mr. Nicolai's personal account, it reveals many of the complex ethic, cultural, religious and political issues that are in play in the region. That said, the book has some editing problem (typos, grammar, etc.) and the pictures are poor quality. The book states that "a significant part of the book revenue will be donated to the children in the UNHCR and UNICEF refugee camps in Kurdistan as well as a vets home". Highly recommended!

Absolutely gorgeous gentleman's pocket knife and an excellent value for the money. I bought two (one for a Christmas gift) and could not be happier. The Damascus steel blade and bolsters and black bone handle make a beautiful combination. Both knives are well made and I could find no flaw with their workmanship, finish, and operation. This knife comes in a gun metal-colored metal presentation tin -- the color of the one reviewer-posted photo showing this (the one with the pack of playing cards) is not quite right (too brown). It is made in China by Boker. Highly recommended!

I bought two of these finders because they are well made, the batteries are rechargeable, and they interface well with my Samsung Galaxy Note 4, Frosted White 32GB (Sprint). After using them for several days, I am getting a bit tired of the alarms on my phone and the devices going off every time the Bluetooth connection drops. The app is nice, but the settings allow for very little customization of the system (app and finders): only for the first finder's name, working range, and ringtone. I wish I could mute the proximity alarm (or at least set it to vibrate), but that is not an option. Currently, I have my finders set to "sleep". The hole on the finders is too small to fit on any of my key chains. I solved the problem by attaching Nickel Plated Split Rings (12mm). Overall, I am having some seconds thoughts about this purchase, but will give it more time.

Split rings in this size are quite hard to find at local store fronts (Walmart, Hobby Lobby, etc.) and I am very happy to get them at Amazon. They are well made, durable, and perfect for a variety of tasks. I needed them to attach keys and electronic devices to my key chain and they are perfect for that purpose. Highly recommended!

This is the third one of these cases I have bought over the last 20 years and the quality has remained consistently high. I bought this for use with the Swiss Army Steel Blue Limited Edition Cadet, but it is big enough to use with a wide range of Victorinox Swiss Army knives. The case has a leather belt loop in the back. Highly recommended!

I bought this pouch for use with the Swiss Army Steel Blue Limited Edition Cadet. It fits the knife just fine, can be used with larger knives, but will definitely not fit Victorinox's larger Swiss Army knives. From the very large sticker that came on the pouch, it is "Made in Mexico", is well made, a very good value, and is constructed from quality materials. The pouch has a belt loop on the back. The logo is black and white. The pouch overall is not quite as nice as a similar model I bought 20 years ago that had a red and white logo. Highly recommended!

I bought this for the Fire HD 10, 10.1" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 16 GB - Includes Special Offers, Black. It fits perfectly and is an excellent value. The protector includes dry and wet screen cleaning packets, a screen cleaning cloth, and an adhesive dust removal tool. I especially appreciate the careful packaging to protect the glass during shipment. The instructions were easy to follow. I did have a few problems with my installation and still have a dime-sized air bubble near the middle of the screen that will not go away, but don't think it is due to a problem with the protector. I tried peeling off the protector and lifting off any lint in the area of the bubble (with scotch tape), but the problem remains. I had no problems otherwise. This protector is made and ships directly from China. Highly recommended!

Great compilation for any fan of the Carpenters. I bought the Amazon digital version of this album (for streaming) after buying a used copy of the CD version. The boxset contains the three remastered Carpenters albums: "Close To You" (1970), "Carpenters" (1971), and "A Song For You" (1972). This is the only compilation that I could find with the beautiful, but lesser known tracks such as "Rode Ode", "Sometimes" and "Crescent Noon". Highly recommended!

I bought this as a replacement for an original Samsung charger which malfunctioned after two years of use. This replacement charger charges the Tab 3 very quickly and is well made. I appreciate that it includes two charging cables which provide additional flexibility to charge a number of different devices. Highly recommended!

I bought a three-pack of these key trackers because the batteries can be changed, the smartphone app is well designed, and I like the idea of supporting a small startup company (founded by a team of former Boeing engineers) that want to "build a better mouse trap". Unfortunately, the one device I actually put on my key chain only lasted two days before malfunctioning (button stopped working, quit interfacing with the app, and the light on the device stayed on permanently) and the company's technical support is only an email address with a 36-hour response window. Also, I couldn't get the battery cover off the device with the three supplied tools: small rectangular pieces of plastic with two bumps that fit the battery cover. Although not perfect, I subsequently purchased the Veho VBA-008-S8 SAEM S8 Reperio Bluetooth Proximity Alarm/Finder with Smartphone Photo Remote and recommend you consider that instead.For the manufacturer: consider designing a battery compartment cover with a coin slot-style opener and ditch the tool.The following are the tech support email replies I received. Unfortunately, it took so long to get them that I had already returned my order for refund:"I'm sorry to see you're experiencing a problem with one of your Honey's! Re-inserting the battery should turn off the light. Here are more detailed tips for removing the battery cover:Put the plastic tool provided in the package into the two little holes on the battery cover and turn about 1/8 a turn, until it stops. It's a short turn, just enough to unlock the cover.  The seal on the lid may make it stick a little, in that case it is easiest to either push the battery out from the other side, or use tape to stick to the cover and pull straight out. If you have misplaced the tool, two dull pen tips can be used as well.Once open, there are two things you can do to reset the device's light:1. Reinsert the battery2. If that does not work, remove the battery. Please short the two metal leads in the Honey by using a metal object such as a spoon or knife.  That will release any power buildup and restart the system.  Then insert the battery again."Second email response:"Thank you for the feedback! As a small-but-growing startup, we do our best to respond to all customers in a timely manner and work hard to keep our response times to under 36 hours.I'm sorry to see the issue was not resolved better. We do hope that if you do not find a tracker that works great for you that you consider giving us another try down the road, as we are working constantly to deliver the best experience possible."

I bought one set of these key finders and was so impressed with their quality build, durability, LOUD sound, and easy of use that I bought five additional sets for Christmas gifts. Unlike many other similar products, this one has excellent technical support and a great warranty. Individual KeyRingers can be contacted and customized from the manufacturer's website using a computer or smartphone (using a web browser). Hopefully, the manufacturer will develop a cellphone app in future.Features (from the KeyRinger website):- Responds over distances up to 300 hundred feet- Bright flashing light that makes it incredibly easy to find in the dark- Loudest lost key finder available anywhere -- guaranteed!- Volume is user programmable from very soft to very loud- Extremely long battery life -- typically 18 months- Compact, durable, and weighs only 5/8 of an ounce- Operates just like the find button on your cordless phone- Low battery sensor -- beeps just like your smoke alarm when battery is low- Durable enough to withstand being run over by a standard size car- When buying multiple sets, all KeyRingers are identical and respond to each other- Multiple KeyRingers can be called simultaneously or individually -- over 2000 available channels- Full risk-free 90-day money-back guarantee and 2-year limited warranty

Fantastic key ring: holds keys securely, is easy to open/close, and is very durable. Since the ring opens easily, it is easy to put on larger keys, knives, etc., and keys don't get scratched up the way they would going on to a metal key ring. Don't get the blue one (comes open too easily), get this one. To open: hold the ring in both hands (with a hand on each side of the fastener) and twist it into a figure eight. To close: hold both ends of the fastener together and twist it into a figure eight.

Fantastic key ring: holds keys securely, is easy to open/close, and is very durable. Since the ring opens easily, it is easy to put on larger keys, knives, etc., and keys don't get scratched up the way they would going on to a metal key ring. Don't get the blue one (comes open too easily), get this one. To open: hold the ring in both hands (with a hand on each side of the fastener) and twist it into a figure eight. To close: hold both ends of the fastener together and twist it into a figure eight.

I love Caran d'Ache pens because of their uncompromising quality, beautiful design, craftsmanship, and the fantastic Goliath cartridge that writes beautifully and seems to last forever. This Swiss-made pen comes with a Medium Blue Caran D'ache Goliath Cartridge which provides up to 600 pages of smooth, skip-free writing. To disassemble the pen, twist the end cap counterclockwise. Highly recommended!

This Swiss-made pen comes with a Medium Blue Caran D'ache Goliath Cartridge which provides up to 600 pages of smooth, skip-free writing. To disassemble the pen, twist the end cap counterclockwise. Highly recommended!

This espresso brown colored Sterilite plastic chest of drawers is a great bedroom choice to blend in with your other wood or wicker furniture, at a much lower price.  This brand is known for its sturdy plastic storage items, and this one is very creatively designed and attractive as well as functional.  The three drawers are roomy & deep, and the basic height of 29" was tall enough in my bedroom that I had no need to add the four 3" beige plastic feet provided as an option.  I'm so pleased I just ordered a second one.

I love this style of paper hot cups, usually sold in supermarkets in the 9 oz. size, as these disposable cups are much healthier to drink from than the cheap foam variety which could or does have carcinogens.  These 16 oz. cups are pretty, particularly for the coffee lover, as the designs over a burgundy background have different coffee bar style drawings of steaming coffee cups, and wordings all around including café, latte, espresso & cappuccino.  Since my 9 oz. size supermarket hot cups are increasingly hard to find, I ordered 2 packages of these, and on looking at them they seem HUGE (about the size of a Starbucks Grande), so unless you want to quickly go through your morning 12 cup pot o' joe, only fill these a little over halfway for a regular size cup.  I wish they would sell the 12 oz. size in smaller packages than only the case of 300 offered, otherwise filling this size cup a bit less is a minor adjustment.

I recently bought a 2 ft. tall white tabletop tree for the holidays, and decided on these mini colored lights with white wire to complement it.  The little lights are in beautiful colors, the blue is actually a bright teal rather than royal, and you can count on Vickerman for reliability - if one goes out, the others stay lit.  The white wire is almost invisible on the white tree, and the effect will look dreamy in my front window for the holiday season.

I think most people are complaining of a skimpy tree because they are not unpacking it properly.  The tree arrives in a slim vertical box, and each branch must be pulled downward to create the full image pictured.  Some branches are packed very close together, appearing as one piece, so observe carefully as you are doing the "onion peeling" (or, have the patience to arrange the tree as you would a bouquet of flowers, moving the branches around at different angles).  My tree came out as full as the photo, though the height is slightly smaller than 2 ft. - 22" from the three sided white base to the top.  We have a small apartment without a lot of extra room, so my tree is going on top of an end table beside a sofa, right at the picture window of the living room.  I have already begun decorating it pre-Christmas with a small silver beaded garland, and have ordered multi colored mini lights w/ white wiring from Amazon to complement it.  Super price for a pretty little table-top tree.

This latest entry from one of my favorite suspense authors Rick Mofina moves at lightning speed.  Bombs are strapped to the bodies of a husband, wife and young son, with orders for the husband to cooperate from four desperadoes holding the others hostage.  Reporter Kate Page is hot on the case, a repeat character from other novels (Mofina, a reporter himself, almost always inserts a key reporter into his stories, often as the protagonist).  The ultimate revenge motive has a contemporary theme, and as always, Mofina writes a real page turner that will have you racing to the finish line.

I chose this Monarch (by Coaster) pedestal table because most round tables sold online have problematic drop leaves, and I don't want any accidents at dinner while entertaining.  We have a small dinette area, so this 48" round table is the perfect size.  Oak grain finish is called amber on the box, and is actually a warm medium golden oak shade that blends well with most furniture shades (we have some dark warm oak and medium cherry pieces and all look compatible).  I chose a highly rated oak company that created a courier label same day of order, but in fact the delivery was not completed until the full two and a half week window, so if you choose the oak version I would advise you to have patience to wait, because you will LOVE the finished product it's a beautiful functional table that looks higher quality than the price.

Having been to Hawaii several times, and to Maui itself one time, I can attest to the lush natural beauty the artist has magnified in this Iao Valley painting to highlight its rare qualities - the giant Ti leaves, broad banana leaves, volcanic grassy mountains & fanciful tropical parrots flying about near a rocky stream, all of them illustrate the Eden-like qualities of the Hawaiian landscape.  A calm and joyful rainforest scene that would look lovely in any room of your home if you love the tropics.

On one of our four treasured trips to the Hawaiian islands, my husband & I purchased a smaller version of this beautiful Hawaiian picture Held In the Arms of Heaven by Steve Sundram.  This is perhaps Sundram's most beloved work, and if yours is a romantic heart you will love placing this print in a special place in your home (ours is right over our bedroom headboard).  Perfectly captures intimate memories or dreams about the paradise that is Hawaii;  the flower-bedecked heads of an embracing island couple next to a double rainbow in the sky, a spectacular volcanic mountain vista, below which dolphins swim joyously in the sea.  Colorful yet subtle, you will never tire of looking at this lovely inspiring scene.

This is a gorgeous aqua vinyl tablecloth with an assortment of large sized beige seashells (nautilus, scallop, etc.) that makes a very soothing appearance on your kitchen table.  The aqua background has subtle seaweed and wave patterns making it very lifelike for an ocean theme, and looks really good if your room colors are any shade of blue, brown, beige or ivory.  Love the wipe clean vinyl fabric for easy entertaining, and its flannel backing makes it good for ironing out wrinkles with a dry iron over a towel on the tablecloth (either side).  Lovely product.

I purchased this pretty autumn leaves vinyl tablecloth in the 70" round size, as we have a round pedestal kitchen table.  Love the subtle turning leaf pattern on ivory & beige background, looks very festive for fall holidays such as Thanksgiving, and I love the easy clean vinyl to have stress free holiday entertaining.  Has a flannel backing, and wrinkles are easy ironed out using a towel over the surface then pressing hard to smooth out the fabric.

This royal blue thyroid lead protector is a very nice product, it arrived quickly and is well made with very adhesive Velcro strapping around the sides, and it came in a recloseable plastic casing.  However, the photo is a bit deceptive, it seems the large protective piece wraps halfway around the neck, when the measurement is just 6x8" at the fullest center, tapering to 6x7" before the 2.5" Velcro strapping takes over (the latter, a generous 24"). Amazon carries a couple other styles that appear to offer more full throat coverage, in a wider variety of colors, similarly priced.

A beautiful young teenage girl goes on holiday with her family from England to Greece, where she meets a seductive, handsome young Greek boy about her age, who pries her for personal information & learns she has an unhappy home life and is a vulnerable candidate for the sordid life of forcible prostitution that awaits her.  For ten long years she is transported violently from country to country, shackled and abused along with other girls, offered drugs to keep her complacent, and going on a hellish journey from private houses to brothels to the red light district of Amsterdam, Holland where her body is obscenely displayed in a window for prospective customers.  She finally ends up in a brothel in England that is raided, and admits the truth about her ordeal to the authorities;  however, she is extremely fearful of being returned to her parents and the miserable home life which is the classic lifestyle that produces many sex workers.  Told from 2 points of view, the girl Scarlett's, and the group of female DCI's who care for her and offer her a degree of protection, this is written by an author who worked inside Britain's Behavior Analysis crime unit and speaks from experience.  This subject of human trafficking/white slavery has always interested me, from the time when I was an impressionable young woman and could always imagine "there but for the grace of God, go I" if one were just unlucky enough to trust the wrong person.  You have to feel a deep sympathy for these poor, tortured, brainwashed girls, most of whom accept this life until they get too old to be of use, when they are killed or otherwise thrown aside as no longer needed.  A riveting, almost true to life account (the author does reference one of these girls' journals) that is well told but definitely unsettling.

Robert Crais' antihero Elvis Cole PI is a witty, wisecracking gumshoe character in the style of Chandler's Philip Marlowe and Spillane's Mike Hammer.  There is usually a pretty girl or two for flirtation or romance in each story, and each short novel in this collection of Elvis Cole mysteries is guaranteed to be a fast, enjoyable ride that keeps you smiling throughout.  This is the second three-books-in-one volume of Crais' early stories published in the UK in 2002, so check the sellers' origins as most are in Great Britain (takes a little longer to arrive, approx. 2-3 weeks) but you can often find a few in the U.S. for quicker delivery.  Elvis' sidekick Joe Pike is in these stories as well.  Fun reading, but all Crais' books are good, I loved the recent Suspect about a wounded K9 dog, and Hostage, both of which are non Elvis & Joe stories.

MJ Arlidge is a new British crime fiction author who writes a riveting story.  His first book Eeny Meeny was a Target book selection here in the USA, and I picked it up there about a month ago and became hooked on his main character, Detective Inspector (DI) Helen Grace.  She is a tough, plain spoken and somewhat unpopular  lead detective (a younger version of Helen Mirren's Jane Tennison), with a bit of a dark side due to her tormented childhood.  This book The Doll's House is the third in Arlidge's DI Grace series, and it is more focused on the serial killer, his victims, their families as well as introducing other detective personnel rather than strictly on DI Grace.  Very compelling killer, the doll's house of the story is not only a toy from the killer's youth, but is a metaphor for the underground dungeon where he keeps his female victims prisoner.  This book and Pop Goes The Weasel are UK publications so I had to wait a couple weeks for the books to arrive via Royal Mail, but these large paperbacks are well worth the wait and are enjoyable fast reads from start to finish.
