This beautiful black floral purse is in the currently hard to find 3x5" size, which has always been my favorite size to stuff credit cards, cash and coins, and still have room to add lists and receipts.  My favorite purses used to be made of leather by Rolf's or Buxton, who are now making them smaller and less roomy.  This Apt 9 beauty is made of a strong grainy imitation cowhide that should be durable, and it has many features of a finer brand including taffeta lining, a keyring in the inside corner, a see thru ID window on one side, as well as a great removable insert panel with three credit card slots on one side, and another see thru ID window on the reverse side.  There are strong zipper pulls on top and front pocket, the latter easily fits all credit cards or medical info cards.  At this price, get one for yourself and delight your female friends or family with one of these as a useful and attractive gift.

As an avid reader of crime fiction, I thought it wise to foray into the noir genre books of the great writer Raymond Chandler.  This 4-story collection is a marvelous journey into the life of Detective Philip Marlowe, wisecracking and jaded, and in my mind I could only picture Robert Mitchum as the weary Marlowe (though others have played the part also on film).  From the first to last novel, though many characters come and go through Marlowe's life (his romances are sexy for the day, with an amusing sarcasm), you are focused on this mesmerizing PI and his smart, snappy dialogue.  This hardcover book is in the classic mode and includes a wonderful descriptive introduction about each novel and well as Chandler's life, and has an attached top gold ribbon insert to conveniently use as a bookmark.  Most of these stories have been made into films and I look forward to finding them on DVD.

In this Season 3 Volume 2 4DVD set of 15 episodes from the original Fugitive starring David Janssen, any TV or movie fan who remembers top stars of the day (i.e. William Shatner, Mickey Rooney, Telly Savalas) will find this collection a welcome trip down Hollywood memory lane. Below is an episode guide to this set, with most prominent guest stars listed beside each show.Disc OneNot With a Whimper - Lee Meriwether, Laurence NaismithWife Killer - Janice Rule, Kevin McCarthyThis'll Kill You - Mickey Rooney, Nita TalbotEcho of a Nightmare - Shirley Knight, Arch JohnsonDisc TwoStroke of Genius Telly Savalas, Ellen CorbyShadow of the Swan - Joanna Pettet, Andre DugganRunning Scared - Joanne Linville, James DalyThe Chinese Sunset - Wayne Rogers, Laura DevonDisc ThreeIll Wind - John McIntire, Jeanette NolanWith Strings Attached - Donald Pleasence, Carol RossenThe White Knight - Jessica Walter, Ted KnightDisc FourA Taste of Tomorrow - Brenda Scott, Fritz WeaverIn a Plain Paper Wrapper - Kurt Russell, Lois NettletonCoralee - Antoinette Bower, Murray Hamilton

The great 60s B&W TV series The Fugitive stars brooding David Jansen as Dr. Richard Kimble, who as narrator William Conrad reminds you every week is wrongly convicted of his wife's murder and now on the lam.  The Conrad narration and musical intro/exit are all preserved here, if people are complaining about introduced music it might be subtly in the dialogue part of the show, or else the producers fixed it.  The guest stars in this Season 3, Volume 1 4DVD set are as follows:Disc OneWings of an Angel - Greg Morris, Lane BradburyMiddle of a Heat Wave - Sarah Marshall, JD CannonCrack in a Crystal Ball - Joanna Moore, Larry BlydenTrial By Fire - Frank Aletter, Marion RossDisc TwoConspiracy of Silence - Malachi Throne, Donald HarronThree Cheers For Little Boy Blue - Ed Asner, Fay SpainAll the Scared Rabbits - Suzanne Pleshette, Liam SullivanAn Apple a Day - Sheree North, Arthur O'ConnellDisc ThreeLandscape with Running Figures Part I - Barbara Rush, Herschel BernardiLandscape with Running Figures Part II - Jud Taylor, Barbara RushSet Fire to a Straw Man - Diana Hyland, Edward BinnsStranger in the Mirror - William Shatner, Julie SommarsDisc FourThe Good Guys and the Bad Guys - Earl Holliman, Bruce DernEnd of the Line -When the Wind Blows -

These bikini panties by Fruit of the Loom are THE most comfortable undies I have ever owned.  If you have a tummy and get pinched by the underbelly waistlines of bikini underwear, these panties are a marvel in that you cannot even feel the line around your gut, the elastic is so stretchy and overlaid with very soft cotton rich (60% cotton) fabric.  They are not skimpy about the size, I wear a 7 but these have a roomy fit even after washing.  I have also purchased the boy shorts in this Beyond Soft line, and its the same feeling, as if you have no panties at all on, yet you are comfortably protected by a really attractive pair of underpants.  Though they are a 60/40 cotton poly combo, there is a reinforced bottom panel that is probably 100% cotton for ventilation.  The different panty colors are also really pretty, and I have to say that while I shop panties for value and often go with the Hanes brand, I am now 100% devoted to Fruit of the Loom and hope they keep this Beyond Soft line around for a long time.

The 60s B&W series The Fugitive starred that handsome, intense actor David Janssen playing the mysterious Dr. Richard Kimble, eyes downcast, always ready to skip town.  Amazing that each episode could be so fresh, with his different assumed names & characters, and the great guest stars he acted with (see list below).  Note to those worried about the soundtrack, the original beginning & ending "on the run" music has been preserved intact. and any change to the middle dramatic music is not noticeable or distracting.Disc OneThe Garden House - Pippa Scott, Robert WebberCome Watch Me Die - Bruce Dern, Diane LaddWhere The Action Is - Telly Savalas, Joanna FrankSearch in a Windy City - Pat Hingle, Nan MartinDisc TwoBloodline - Nancy Malone, John ConsidineRat in a Corner - Warren Oates, Malachi ThroneAngels Travel On Lonely Roads Pt. I  -  Eileen Heckart, Albert SalmiAngels Travel On Lonely Roads Pt. II - Ruta Lee, Eileen HeckartDisc ThreeFlight From the Final Demon - Ed Nelson, Carroll O'ConnorTaps For a Dead War - Tim O'Connor, Lee GrantSomebody to Remember - Madlyn Rhue, Gilbert RolandNever Stop Running - Joanna Moore, Claude AkinsDisc FourThe Homecoming - Shirley Knight, Gloria GrahameStorm Center - Bethel Leslie, Dennis PatrickThe End Game - Christopher Connelly, Joe Campanella

Many years ago I saw the movie Single White Female starring Bridget Fonda and Jennifer Jason Leigh, and really enjoyed the suspense and tension of the story.  If you liked the movie, reading the book is a bigger thrill, as there are more and expanded characterizations, as well as deeper psychological analysis of the disturbed girl Hedra (called Hedy in the movie).  John Lutz is a favorite suspense author of mine, and this is one of his early works (reissued here), originally released as "SWF Seeks Same," referring to the ad placed by the nice girl Allie for a roommate.  Lutz paints a vivid portrait of living single in NYC and its dangers, and he adds a postscript to this book of how he greatly enjoyed the filming of the movie based on his book, which he didn't expect to as most authors dislike the filmed version.  Even if you are familiar with the story from the movie, you will not be bored reading this, as the book holds many surprises and is a great ride.

Though the book title is a line from the Billie Holiday song Strange Fruit about lynching in the American South, this tale of racial hatred is set in DCI Banks' West Yorkshire territory, and is between a group of law breaking Skinheads and their Pakistani neighbors.  Very well written and nuanced regarding the seeds of racial intolerance (the murdered boy's grandfather let a comment slip about his Jewish landlord, and feels a deep shame and responsibility upon learning of his grandson's involvement in a Nazi loving hate group, when he himself had helped liberate the camps after World War II), it is always an enjoyable and educational experience reading a DCI Banks story.  I'm looking forward to seeing this one filmed for the TV series of which I am a huge fan.

This jar of cream concealer by NYX is one of my favorite makeup products to use in summer.  Having redness in my t-zone area, I like to apply concealer liberally as others use foundation, and this product just glides on giving great large pore coverage without clogging them.  It works particularly well in hot humid weather throughout the day without much fading.  This low priced item works as well as more famous brands I have tried, and they offer many shades (mine, light, blends great without that pasty look).  Highly recommend.

My husband & I had first tried Brazilian coffee years ago when a Sao Paulo colleague gifted him with a bag of Café do Ponto.  We immediately fell in love, and have since discovered this delicious Café Pilao, which comes from Sao Paulo and is said to be Brazil's favorite coffee (though their actual favorite I'm told is the stronger demitasse style called cafezinho).  Pilao has the wonderful unique nutty smoothness of real Brazilian coffee, it is medium dark but never bitter, and whether you are a coffee aficionado or a new sampler, you can't go wrong with this flavor rich coffee.

These delicate St. Michael frosted blue glass chaplet beads are very beautiful & finely crafted.  The base medallion has the primary picture of St. Michael with sword raised that is repeated in smaller versions throughout the chaplet, behind which is written each of the nine choirs of angels (seraphim, cherubim etc.).  Though no prayer card is included, the beads arrived in a protective plastic packet in a cushioned mailer, shipped very quickly.

Firstly, Gregg Olsen is a very good writer but this book about serial killer(s) is a sick departure for him.  The methodology of the killings has been featured a few times on the show Criminal Minds, and there is a hint during one of the early murders as to who is behind the killing.  I read a lot of murder/serial killer/suspense novels, and I have to say that though any perversion is believable of a murderer, the rape violations in this one are pretty revolting and paint an unforgettable picture in your head.  Beyond this, its very well written and the law enforcement characters (one partner has an autistic son and is very compassionate) are interesting.

I purchased these lights in the amber, which after inserting 3 AAA batteries in the box, makes them a beautiful bright fire orange that is perfect for Halloween.  What's nice is, you can choose from three settings, regular continuous light, blinking type (like batting an eyelid, not twinkling), or the Off position.  However, the minus is that the batteries wear down quickly and make the lights pin dots after several hours on, even with long life batteries you need to change them frequently, so I now use the dollar store brand as those work just as well.

This 3-book set of early works by Robert Crais feature one of his most popular characters, Elvis Cole PI, as well as another favorite PI, the elusive Joe Pike, in a minor role.  My first Robert Crais book was the excellent recent release Suspect about a wounded K9 dog pairing up with a wounded policeman, and I became intrigued by this marvelous writer.  I then purchased a used copy of his early book The Monkey's Raincoat (featured in this set), but because of its late '80s release date, the book was rather yellowed & musty.  Since the dates on the other two novels in this collection are also late '80s-early '90s, and this 3-book set is dated 2001, it was a much better choice to purchase this more recent set.  I got the large paperback which is a bit bulky at @ 600 pages. but it works out that each of the novels is around 200 pages apiece (his works got longer later).  Note that this is a British publication, so unless you can find a U.S. seller or buy Amazon direct, you may wait a short while for delivery.

As a young schoolgirl, I used to buy these Pine Bros drops (called cough drops back then, though the ingredients are the same, and throat drops is a better description since they contain no medicine) at the local deli while waiting for my school bus, and they came in three of the four flavors now offered, which were honey, cherry & black licorice.  They were soft and chewy as now, and the only discernible difference is that the cherry was sweeter and less tangy then it is now, otherwise still the same great product.  It's rather expensive for a small bag of 32 drops that goes pretty fast, but its well worth the price if you have any issues with a dry throat - mine is that we share a duplex with heavy smokers, leading me to cough and have a raspy throat, and of everything I have tried, these Pine Bros drops do the best job of moistening my throat all the way down and preventing coughing.  I think the best flavor is the honey, which is like taking a spoonful of liquid honey and will certainly help a dry throat.  Highly recommend these.

This is a special, prosaic book that is a wonderful read.  The story of Lilith, a beautiful schizophrenic young woman confined to a mental asylum, and her manipulation of the young male attendant Vincent's emotions to the point where his own sanity is threatened, is very insidious and believable.  As Vincent slowly falls under Lilith's entrancing spell, you are swept into their rarified world, as you become all too aware of Lilith's destructive power over the young man and his youthful gullibility.  Though the book ends on a hopeful note, the 1964 movie has a more realistic ending, and I would encourage readers to get this DVD.  Jean Seberg played the part of Lilith perfectly, mysterious and seductive, and though Warren Beatty's wooden acting was widely criticized, it was actually a well done take on Vincent's naïvete.

Having been a reader of crime fiction (i.e. Michael Connelly, John Lutz) as well as non-fiction (Anne Rule) for many years, I am always on the lookout for a suspense author who is new to me.  I have recently begun Rick Mofina's books, starting with Full Tilt and now this one No Way Back.  While this story is gripping and revolves around the tense kidnapping of a reporter's wife, and it moves as a good fast pace, I am not wild about Mr. Mofina's choices as regards victim abuse.  In the former novel, a serial rapist/killer transports his young female victims across state lines in steel coffins, and in this book, poor abducted Ann Reed gets jostled around from place to place covered up at the bottom of the car, and her final punishment is hanging suspended in a deep subterranean well.  Being somewhat claustrophobic, I personally am not thrilled with these torture methods, though they are written about believably and engrossingly.  Hoping I did not spoil some of the story for any readers, but I had to remove a star for the discomfort factor.  As a tribute to Mr. Mofina's writing talent, though, I will be seeking out other books by him.

I use Febreze air freshener sprays in my bathroom as deodorizers.  Although I am not particularly fond of all-floral scents, this Summer Fruit Bouquet variety combines the smell of peaches, oranges, and Hawaiian plumeria flowers (pictured on the can) for a light, not too sweet aroma that is good at masking odors.  Its both fruity and floral, a very nice combo.

Back in the late '70s I had seen the film Bobby Deerfield starring Al Pacino and Marthe Keller, based on this book, and the intriguing story led me to read this haunting romance.  Lillian is dying of tuberculosis and resides in a sanatorium in the Alps, where wealthy people often hoped to find a cure.  Clerfayt (renamed Bobby Deerfield in the movie, and based on the real life race car driver Alfonso de Portago) is a formula one driver whose car breaks down in Lillian's Swiss town and needs repairs, and they meet by chance in a restaurant.  They become a couple, and set off driving around Europe on an odyssey of romantic discovery, living life to the fullest (staying at nice hotels, shopping, eating out) all the while aware of Lillian's unfortunate future.  When you read that Clerfayt will be driving in Italy's Mille Miglia race (where de Portago met his untimely end), you realize that the tables may be turned regarding their destinies.  Told from Lillian's point of view, E.M. Remarque's writing is absolutely prosaic, its the kind of book to savor and re-read, the book's title is so accurate, as in the old adage, "man makes plans while God laughs."  Also try to see the movie which is now on DVD, as the actors are 100% true to the written characters.

I had originally purchased the larger 12-packs of these bright mirrored disco balls to give as party favors, and was only short a few so ordered this set of 6.  Later on reading reviews that these were Christmas ornament sized, I expected a smaller version of the 12-pack w/ 30" chain.  In fact, this is EXACTLY the same product as the 12-pack, from tennis ball size to long silver chain, and comes packaged the same way in a clear plastic pkge w/ the disco balls individually wrapped in plastic like popcorn balls inside.  Very cheery and reflective, these are lovely to give as gifts and delight everyone from adult to small child (well not the smallest if they can eat the pasted-on mirrors, it comes with a warning).  Reminder of one of the happier products of the '80s.

These Frosty snow boots have a tag that says "Mountain Warehouse Ltd, London, UK" attached to the boot, and a tag inside them that says Made In China, with both sizing for UK & US.  When you order from Amazon, choose your regular American size, not the British, as I ordered an 8 and it was true to size.  I have a wide foot & with shoes usually order a 7.5C (or 7 1/2W), but as most boots are only even-sized I end up getting an 8.  These boots are a good fit, slightly roomy but not so your foot moves around inside, and the good news for wider feet is I had no need to use a shoe stretcher or split (cut) the boot, and they don't pinch my feet.  Also for comfort, the Velcro closure is a very wide panel placed at the outside of your foot so there is no rubbing when you walk, and it opens in a deep V like an accordion, so you have many choices of adjusting from looser to tighter.  For the money these are comfortable, really nicely made snow boots that are also attractive with their pretty honeycomb pattern and fur cuffs, plus the snow & ice traction is great.

This small but compact circular pagoda-shaped lantern takes 4 AA batteries, and I would say it can remain lit continuously on those batteries for more than 3 full days.  Its central core of light is very bright & clear, much more so than many LED lanterns twice its size, and the unit gives off light in any direction so it has been a Godsend in emergencies (i.e. blackouts).  Don't be deceived by the small size, it is a very well made product that can stand up to Coleman or any similar lantern brand.  Hard to find now in stores because of newer (and different) models, I just purchased three of these here online.

I purchased two of these rugs in the 5 x 7' (actually 5 x 6'6' on pkge) size to cover the hardwood flooring in our living room.  This type of flat, low pile, rubber backed rug is perfect for a high traffic area, they are sewn flat so you can walk over them easily without catching your foot.  The floral pattern is very subtle with muted colors over a tan (not ivory) background, and looks good in our mostly blue living room.  Baseboard heating can make bare wood floors hot in winter, so besides protecting the floor from marks & scratches, the rugs make the room more comfortable.  Though the rubber backing keeps them pretty secure, I like to roll pieces of duct tape to place at the bottom corners and down the middle so the rugs stay in place.  Nicely rolled at full length & packaged in plastic, arrived quickly from mfr.

I have recently purchased a different four pack of square shaped steel chairs here on Amazon at a slightly higher price, which are advertised as able to hold up to a 400 lb. person's weight.  Though this gray set is in the traditional curved shape, it is made of an even thicker steel than the square type, plus the frame has the same strong triple bars.  My husband is a bit heavyset, and he actually prefers the comfort and strength of these gray open-seated curved chairs to the thinner steel square variety.  Unless you require more back support (then choose the square type), this curved type is more comfortable, and if ordering through Amazon the boxed, individually plastic wrapped set arrives quickly and is a great value with the free shipping.

These thermal energy saving curtain panels by Sun & Moon are a satiny shadow stripe (alternating shiny & matte stripes, same color).  They are very elegant looking, a medium weight thermal curtain with white poly thermal backing.  I purchased four panels of the 40 x 84" size in mocha, which is called taupe on the package and is a beautiful medium brown color.  The package says "energy saving, noise reducing, saves on home heating & cooling costs," and this is a true statement, I have been using thermal curtains for years and they both prevent winter heat from escaping, as well as repel summer sun to keep you cool.

This is a great Verve album (now CD) from 1966 by Brazilian bossa nova organist Walter Wanderley and his trio.  He had a smooth, sophisticated sound with mostly breezy melodies that makes me think of Xavier Cugat, though my husband calls it "ice skating music."  There are some classics he does beautifully, such as Jobim's Agua De Beber, Voce E Eu (misprinted as Boce E Eu here, this disc comes from Japan) by Carlos Lyra, and a lovely rendition of the movie theme A Man & A Woman.  There are 12 tracks here, the others are Cheganca, Amanha, Take Care My Heart, Here's That Rainy Day, O Ganso, Mar Amar, O Menino Desce O Morro, Da-Me (Stay My Love) & Amor De Nada.  Pretty dinnertime music.

My husband and I make a lot of frozen meals (entrees, pizzas etc.) during the work week to save time.  We use steel cookie sheets to protect our oven from runoff drips & spillovers, and the problem is finding one that is thin enough that the food cooks evenly, and large enough to protect most of the oven's interior.  This Fox Run pan is perfect both in size & lightness, and there is no need for a curved edge (they are totally flat, with indented corners for easy grabbing).  At this low price I purchased a couple, as frozen foods can leave dark stains from their runoff that don't totally remove with steel wool, so I eventually replace the pans.  Buying more than one qualifies for free shipping from Amazon, making these pans a great value.

This product is very strongly sewn and lined, offering good security if you are choosing the lead variety.  I purchased the lightweight lead drape in navy, this is a front & lower neck covering that reaches to the mid-thigh, made of strong nylon in front, and a beige ribbed velveteen material in back.  Very comfortable and a good alternative to the heavier lead drapes/aprons which won't stress the lower back.

This smooth white shelf has very large suction cups that have to be popped in and swiveled around at the base.  They do not pop in tightly, but needed white duct tape around the connect part to stay in place.  My purpose for buying this was to put a decorative holiday figurine at the bottom of my window, so after assembling the shelf I cleaned off the window with alcohol, dried it well & pressed the suction cups against the glass.  No adherence at all.  Perhaps they work better on bathroom tile or tempered glass, otherwise its a very nice roomy small shelf for various uses (drain holes in the center make it a good soap dish, and side holes for toothbrushes).  I finally did use the shelf in the window by leaning it against the bottom window frame & duct taping around the base for security, and it works fine.

This sterling silver medal pendant of St. Michael the archangel is slightly smaller than a nickel, with shiny edges where it says "St. Michael, pray for us," and a filigreed inner image that is made just like a finer gold pendant; it is made in Italy, which is probably why.  It is about the thickness of a dime, very lightweight, with a very thin silver chain that is comfortable to wear.  It does not come gift boxed but in a small sealed plastic baggie, however, it would make a thoughtful gift for anyone in need of St. Michael's protection.  Very good quality.

This beautiful blue beaded rosary features a central medal with the image of St. Michael slaying the dragon, and on its reverse side, the famous guardian angel with children image.  This is a protective, comforting rosary for anyone who is devoted to St. Michael the archangel.  Comes in a white plastic ridged rosary box with the famous Guido Reni painting (top half) on the lid, and a full printing of the daily prayer (St. Michael the archangel, defend us in battle, etc.) on the bottom.

Howard Keel's wonderful voice remained great & strong even into his later years when he continued to record.  This CD collection, however, is from his Hollywood heyday as a romantic leading man, and on the duets in particular (who doesn't swoon at his Show Boat songs paired with Kathryn Grayson, his rich baritone the perfect complement to her sweet soprano), he is perfectly dreamy.  Original recordings from three of his movies:  Annie Get Your Gun, 1950 (five songs), Pagan Love Song, 1950 (five songs) and Show Boat, 1951 (three songs).

New Balance makes a dependably good walking shoe/sneaker, especially for hard to fit sizes like wide widths (me, 7.5 C/D).  I had two pair of the beige suede 643 trail shoes and they held up for years until finally the heels wore down.  While scanning through Amazon's choices for a replacement, I noticed these 659 walkers are almost the same style shoe as my favorite, right down to the sturdy beige soles with Abzorb feature (SO-O comfortable) and arch support.  They also come in beige, but I decided on the brown as more of a Fall/winter color.  The shoes are really gorgeous, and the worries I had about what appeared online to be a partial mesh design (too cool for winter) were unfounded, as the fabric part is thick enough that there are no air holes, yet that part of the shoe has enough "give" to make it super comfortable.  Highly recommended.

The beautiful singer Caterina Valente was a frequent guest on the Ed Sullivan & Dean Martin shows, and would always surprise you by singing a popular song in one of the several different languages she knew (Italian, Spanish, German, French, English etc.).  This 4CD collection features eight of her albums recorded between 1956 and 1962, 24 tracks on each disc, as follows:Disc OneThe Hi-Fi Nightingale from 1956 (songs include The Breeze and I, Malaguena)Ole Caterina from 1957 (includes Aquarelo do Brasil, Quereme Mucho)Disc TwoPlenty Valente from 1957 (includes Poinciana, Moonlight in Vermont)A Toast To The Girls from 1958 (includes C'Est Si Bon, Tenderly)Disc ThreeArriba from 1959 (includes Quizas Quizas Quizas, Copacabana)Classics with a Chaser from 1960 (includes Full Moon & Empty Arms, Stranger in Paradise)Disc FourSuper-fonics from 1961 (includes Serenata, You Stepped Out of a Dream)Great Continental Hits from 1962 (includes Melodie d'Amour, Scandinavian Song)

My husband & I have taken several Hawaiian trips, visiting the three islands Oahu, Maui & Kauai, and we have always been awestruck by the unique natural beauty of these islands.  This 2015 Hawaii calendar by National Geographic has especially beautiful photos of our beloved vacation paradise, from the reverence of the volcanically formed mountain ranges (including a rare shot of Diamond Head's less crowded side) to the gentle waterfalls of Kauai & the Big Island, classic beach scenes of Waikiki & Maui, & more.  This calendar is for anyone with a love for Hawaii, whether fondly remembering, hoping to visit, or hoping to return as we always & forever will.

This pretty strand of multi-colored glass beads has nine sections for the St. Michael chaplet, plus a small booklet describing the chaplet prayers.  If you are familiar with Mother Angelica of EWTN and her televised Chaplet of St. Michael (it is on every morning in my area, I love to say the prayers along with Mother), these beads are very similar to hers at less than a third the price the EWTN catalog charges for them.  I like that there are nine separate colors for each salutation, so you can remember your place if you let go of them.  The colors in the necklace part right to left are:  red, clear, amber, clear iridescent, blue, pink, green, amethyst & blue violet.

This is an absolutely stunning, completely realistic portrait of a lifesize pineapple surrounded by golden pears, berries & a bed of greenery (hard to tell from the online photo, the same green stalks on the crown of the pineapple are splayed out beneath it, as if it is naturally growing).  So many garden flags I've purchased are paler in person than online, but not this beauty, the colors are intense & gorgeous - the pineapple itself golden brown, its crown stalks shades of grass & emerald green, the pears Bartlett yellow, the background palest yellow, and framed in emerald green.  This is a terrific welcoming flag (without the annoying Welcome word) for any time of year; I will put it out in early autumn when fruit displays seem most appropriate.

My mother could hem pants & skirts perfectly freestyle without a sewing machine, an art that I could never master and which sent me to the tailor's to hem pants for years.  That is, until I discovered this product a few years ago.  This adhesive cream comes out like Elmer's glue but isn't sticky to work with, it goes on in a thin line (or two if you're hemming more than 1"), just lay the pants out on a table or the floor, apply per instructions, press each side & edges, then put something heavy over each leg to set the hem (don't laugh, I use pyrex pans).  I wait 30 minutes, take the weight off & I have a pair of evenly shortened pants.  Just be sure you apply the cream middle to bottom of the hem line, not near the top so there isn't overflow & the pants don't stick together.  This is a quick & simple solution to sewing, even if you use a machine.

I know these little stork shaped scissors are meant for sewing, and they are great for that purpose.  However in my household, this sharp & cute little fellow has many other uses.  For myself, it replaces cuticle scissors for trimming fingernails & toenails as it cuts carefully & never gets dull.  For my husband it's a great mustache clipper, which is a job that usually falls to me (better eyesight, but only slightly).  At these prices it pays to have a couple on hand, as I'm always digging to find one in my cosmetics box.  The gold plated one is really pretty, it also comes in pewter, and both have that pretty detailing over the bird shape.  An essential tool to have in the house.

This collection of bossa nova songs is from the late '50s when the musical style was just beginning.  Its most famous composer at the time was Antonio Carlos Jobim, and according to the CD's liner notes his breakout bossa nova hit in Brazil was "Chega de Saudade" which is featured here sung by both Joao Gilberto & Elizete Cardoso.  The primary singer in this collection is Cardoso, with 13 tracks from her 1958 album "Cancao do Amor Demais" mostly composed by Jobim, only a couple well known but all very melodic with gentle rhythms.  There are a few lovely guitar selections from Luiz Bonfa & Laurindo Almeida, a couple early songs by Sylvia Telles & Garoto, one gorgeous romantic ballad by baritone Agostinho dos Santos "Sucedeu assim", and several early songs from the Os Cariocas group who harmonized like The Lettermen.  An easy listening bossa nova CD that is also a history lesson of the genre.

This Time Out Sao Paulo travel book is a larger but not overly thick paperback that is good for packing & taking along on your trip - which is exactly what my husband has just done, along with the smaller Sao Paulo Focus Guide paperback.  The Time Out book is packed with pertinent information along with many photos on such topics as restaurants, maps & neighborhoods; for instance, my husband is staying at a business hotel on Avenida Paulista in the Jardins area, and the book has corresponding info particular to that area.  However, this book was published in 2009 and the little Focus Guide in mid-2014, so in case some of this info is outdated, I advise to get the smaller one too for its current recommendations.

This cobalt blue recycled bottle glass suncatcher has a beautiful raised (about 1/2") sculptured scallop shell in the center that is very lifelike, just like a beach shell.  If you want it to lay flat against your window, just reverse the side, as the shell image easily shows through and is very reflective on sunny days.  Because of the fine detailing of the sculptured side however, I like mine to face frontward, and I purchased a pair to go in the side panels of my 3-sided bay window along with the Amia large seashell design painted suncatcher in the center.  Beach theme summer beauty for the window.

This lovely summer garden flag has realistically painted seashells in & out of colorful pails, starfish, sand dollars and a sandpiper (not a seagull) on a beautiful pastel background of aqua & beige, with an ivory border.  This is a perfect outdoor flag for late summer once the patriotic holidays have passed, particularly if you are a beach or seashell lover like myself.  This flag complements the seashell window suncatchers in my 3-sided front bay window.  Made in USA, another pretty design from Custom Décor.

I bought these for my husband because he asked if my ladies version of the New Balance 801 slide came in a men's style, as he is comfortable with a clog shoe.  The ladies side sole is the same ridged rubber in white, and from the online photo the men's shoe appeared to have the same white side sole & New Balance "N" logo - but on receiving the shoe, both are in a nice dove grey, which complements the black suede beautifully.  I had purchased black heel & sole polish with plans to color the stark white rubber side sole for him, but with the grey color there is really no need - this is a case where the shoe is better looking in person than online.  From my own experience with the ladies version, they're very, very comfortable and I'm glad they come in wide widths as we both need them.  The satin placket at the lip of the shoe is soft & stretchy, and there is an upward dip in the arch for those of us who don't like the flat-to-ground type walking shoe.  Another winner from New Balance.

This 17" tall dark brown ottoman is the least expensive of its type online, but if all you're looking for is a footstool cube without storage, this is an excellent purchase at around $50 including shipping.  My husband has developed varicose veins as a result of his technician job which is mostly performed standing up, and we have a small living room so I just wanted a high & wide enough stool for him to put his feet up after work.  He loves this, doesn't need a pillow because the material is soft faux leather/vinyl with a nice cushioned top, very well crafted & stitched.  Slight new odor in box, but not on item once removed.  Shipped out via Fed Ex, arrived less than a week after ordering.  Very impressed.

I love recycled bottle glass suncatchers as they're so colorful & reflective on sunny days.  I have a front bay window with side panels, and usually purchase a pair of the same design.  This aqua glass sand dollar suncatcher is lovely, but just as it appears online, resembles a flower (such as Hawaii's plumeria) more than a sand dollar unless you really scrutinize the design, which does have slight sand dollar edging.  The image protrudes a bit in the middle, and the pair of them look very pretty alongside my seashell-themed large front window suncatcher for summertime.

Woe is us, but another holiday season is upon the world.  Before you know it, the kids’ll all be nestled snug in their beds with while visions of sugarplums are danced in their heads … so why not let the adults have their particular visions, too, eh?  Merry Christmas and God bless us all, but isn’t it time Christmas Eve unveiled a new hero in red, perhaps even a ritual slayer of the undead?  Such is the case with this darkly assembled caper, a clever and smartly tuned anthology sure to serve up a yuletide affair you’ll not soon forget.(NOTE: The following review will contain minor spoilers necessary solely for the discussion of plot and/or characters.  If you’re the type of reader who prefers a review entirely spoiler-free, then I’d encourage you to skip down to the last three paragraphs for my final assessment.  If, however, you’re accepting of a few modest hints at ‘things to come,’ then read on …)From the product packaging: “Last Christmas Eve, two teens came to a grisly end in a school basement.  Now, one year later, a new set of horrors has come to town …”There’s plenty more, but like any good giver I’m going to leave you with that as A CHRISTMAS HORROR STORY remains a gift best left unspoiled.  It isn’t perfect, nor methinks was it truly meant to be, but it does effectively skewer every treatise of the greater holiday season.  Santa.  The nativity.  The elves.  Even the blessed virgin makes an uncharacteristic appearance in this warped enterprise from the minds of writers James Kee, Sarah Larsen, Doug Taylor, and Pascal Trottier.  It’s as delightfully executed by directors Grant Harvey, Steven Hoban, and Brett Sullivan as it is magically conceived, so – if you’re as patient as can be – you’ll likely enjoy the full thrust that this deliriously fractured fairy tale delivers.Essentially, HORROR is an anthology flick but that simple term dismisses the genius of it all.  Instead of serving up three or maybe four stand-alone installments this red-nosed reindeer is gleefully interwoven – both with characters and timing – playing out more like PULP FICTION than it does THE TWILIGHT ZONE.  To its credit, each segment dishes up cookies and milk by way of great performances (there are honestly too many good ones to mention), and it’s all held together by the glue of a singular William Shatner’s performance.  His turn as the demented disc jockey for the rarely heard of Bailey Downs radio station gives the picture a special place in the warm hearts of horror aficionados everywhere … and stay tuned for the stocking stuffers of even more lunacy as the final credits start to roll.Now, HORROR as I said ain’t perfect.  The Nativity segment – though worthy – kinda/sorta drags in spots, and the mythology behind Krampus never quite makes the kind of sense SAW’s erstwhile scribes tried to imbue their potboilers with.  But the sum total of this holiday affair is that if you like your days off celebrated more than just a bit off-center, then pour yourself some eggnog (duly spiked) and pop this wicked little disc in the DVD player.  You’ll be glad you did.And having the North Pole look like Mordor during the Ice Age?  Brilliant.A CHRISTMAS HORROR STORY (2015) is produced by Copperheart Entertainment.  DVD distribution is being handled by the reliable RLJ Entertainment and Image Entertainment.  As for the technical specifications?  This is one smartly assembled production with the best quality sights and sounds available.  (The packaging insists its Closed Captioned for the Hearing-Impaired, but there was no subtitle track available – I almost always check that.)  Lastly, if you’re looking for special features, then there is a behind-the-scenes short that is actually quite good.HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.  Bah humbug!  The season’s merry enough as it is, so it’ll take time to see whether or not the shining star that is A CHRISTMAS HORROR STORY rises high enough to become the subversive holiday favorite for the rest of us (mainly horror fans, that is), but – as bad Santas go – I found it delightful in just the proper measure of naughty and nice.  Mind you: it’s definitely not for the young (in fact, a luscious Zoé De Grand Maison turns in some of the hottest teen sex while clothed in a motion picture ever, proving that age old expression “gingers rule” once more) – nor the young-at-heart (buckets and buckets of Elvish blood) – but for those of us properly disillusioned?  It’s exactly the gift that keeps on giving.In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at RLJ Entertainment and Image Entertainment provided me with a DVD of A CHRISTMAS HORROR STORY (2015) by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

As I’ve mentioned before, I don’t believe you’ll find anyone penning reviews these days who truly appreciates a quality listening experience more than I do.  I’ve been listening to music since the days of the early 1970’s, and I enjoyed a good decade or so gaining experience in amateur radio.  Those my time these days doesn’t allow for near as much listening as I used to do, I think I still possess ‘the ear’ to distinguish between low-quality and high-quality sessions, and it’s in the spirit that I try to approach each and every review I pen about headphones, Bluetooth speakers, and the like.For my tastes, this ThorX set from Sentey is phenomenal.  (Testing this morning was done via my desktop and my iPhone 4.)  They are very well made, built with track adjustments allow the top which allow for you to fit them to your particular preference over your ears.  The foam cushion is light enough so as not to cup your ears too firmly but solid enough to block out any ambient noise from distracting you from whatever it is your listening to.  The cable comes with AUX-style posts, one that plugs into the base of your ‘Left’ earpiece and another that jacks into your device.  Also, the cable has a microphone attachment that dangles a few inches away from your left side; it’s perfectly positioned to pick up your voice if you’re using the set to make and/or receive telephone calls, and there’s even a pushbutton in the housing which allows you to pause the music, make/take the call, and then return to the track right where you paused it.Kudos to Sentey for also including a soft plastic case for carrying and storing your headset while it’s waiting for your attention.  That’s definitely a nice addition from a caring manufacturer.Highest recommendation possible.  Nothing – and I mean NOTHING – replaces the euphoria of a quality listening experience, and these headphones from Sentey are truly exceptional.  Although they’re advertised as being something one can use while working out, I prefer vastly lighter and more compact sets when getting in my cardio.  But for good old-fashioned listening?  These are brilliant.In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Sentey provided me with sample testing product of their ThorX Headphones with Microphone by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

As I’ve mentioned in my reviews before, I spent a fair number of years broadcasting “back in the days” of fairly amateur AM radio.  That’s something to still be celebrated, especially in this age of the YouTube generation wherein everyone has their own show and web-based networks in development.  As such, I like to think I know a thing or two about how something sounds, and while I probably couldn’t spend any time debating decibel issues with some of the more technically accomplished I still maintain what I prefer to call “an ear for quality.”That said, I think this Desktop Condenser Microphone from Fifine is pretty spiffy for what it is.  The mike itself is either USB-port enabled OR AUX-style post depending upon your particular system requirements.  The microphone base is a bit thicker than other desktop models I’ve tried in the past, and the only downside to that is it may not work well with established microphone stands or extending arms you may already have in your possession.  There’s also a built-in echo feature that sounds OK but I didn’t hear it as anything all that special; there’s still no replacing high-end computer software that allows you to better augment voices for whatever projects you may be working on.  Still, the sound quality is good; I’d argue that it’s at least the caliber regular folks or gamers need in order to have a satisfactory experience.  Given the fact that it’s definitely modestly priced it might be worth the purchase if you’re looking for an addition.Kudos to Fifine as they’ve actually included a pretty nice (small) tripod-style stand and an accompanying windsock.Highly recommended.  It’s safe to say that this Desktop Microphone from Fifine not only looks good but performs as expected in the variety of basic consumer tests I walked it through this weekend.  Granted, it’s probably not going to produce the highest quality recordings imaginable – nothing would when you consider this price point – but it’s a far better mike than the cheapie low-end knock-offs which tend to come with desktop computer purchases these days.In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Fifine provided me with sample testing product of their Desktop Condenser Microphone by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

In my lifetime, I’ve used a variety of headlamps.  One of the most reliable ones I had the good fortune to operate was a variety that attached to the bill of a baseball cap; the only problem with it over time was that it tended to wear down the bill.  I’ve also used ones that serve as attachment to glasses as well as a few versions that clipped over the ear.  Still, the best I’ve owned have been the type that take the place of a cap over the head, very similar to the latest from Wolverine.Essentially, their soft straps slide over the skull much like a hat, and the wearer can adjust the tension so that it fits to whatever level of comfort is preferred.  (I tend to like mine relatively loose as anything too tight over time tends to give me a nagging headache.)  The straps do have enough give as well so that you can adjust it to whatever position you like on your head.  The light itself rests in a frame on the front (forehead) with the on-off switch located on top.  To their credit, Wolverine has built this one with three settings: there’s a bright, a soft, and a blinking light, though I’m not sure what use a blinking light would be on the head.  (My guess is that this is a safety feature wherein the user could have it serve as a warning light for others in the area.)  Wolverine’s also has a sliding case which allows the wearer to adjust the light cone for broader or narrower focus when dealing with whatever circumstances may require.The headlamp operates on 3 AAA batteries (not included), and you may be surprised at how much light you get out of so little charge.  This is a great item to have on hand for emergencies or the like, and I’m presently keeping mine in my hiking pack where it’s within arm’s reach should I require it.In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Wolverine provided me with sample testing product of their LED Headlamp (Red) by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

Ah, I do so love my cabled earphones!  As I’ve mentioned before, I’m a huge fan of this old school technology (meaning ‘cabled’ instead of Bluetooth).  I’ve always believed that sound is richer with this tried-and-true tech, and that’s certainly no different with this pair from Dialon.  The set comes with the usual silicone sound-cancelling buds, allowing the user to focus in on just the music (or whatever else you’re hearing).  Also, the designers have included a switch that allows the user to make and/or receive telephone calls while making use of them; in fact, when you press it, it automatically stops the music.What really matters (so far as this user is concerned) in making a good decision with respect to earphones is how well the quality is, and Dialon’s is pretty solid.  I’ve tried listening to a variety of tracks at different levels just to see if I notice anything unusual or any dip in quality; I didn’t detect anything significant; occasionally, there was a bit of a crackle when I tested the phone feature (iPhone 4 tested), but as I don’t make use of this feature all that often I didn’t find it any real deal-breaker.In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Dialon provided me with sample testing product of their In-Ear Wired Sports Earbuds by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

The health club I go to is a bit behind on updating their cardio equipment, so the stationery bikes and the treadmills are good though a little outdated.  The problem this poses for me as a consistent user is I don’t have any place wherein I can store my iPhone.  I’ve had to either keep it in my pocket or pouch – making it challenging to retrieve while I’m burning calories – OR position it “just so” on a handy little plastic magazine or book ledge provided by the machine.  I’ve noticed other folks have purchased these plastic grippers of their own that they use, but I’ve been slow to spend the extra money.Shineda has come out with a Multifunctional Mount that has been a bit of an answer to my prayers.  Their mount is two flexible clamps, one of which easily fastens to the handrail and one that grips the phone.  There’s a rotary dial between them which allows the user to turn the phone so that it’s in the desired position (if you’re watching video), and that’s a nice extra.  (I listen to music, and that makes it less important.)  For my take, the only downside to it is that the rail gripper could have greater tension: it works fine for keeping the phone in place on the bike but the constant thump-thump-thumping on the treadmill has proven greater than the clamp can withstand.  Basically, it slips around the bar slightly; though not a big deal to me, I’m wondering if – over time – the grip may become so loose that it slips off.  Time will tell.To my surprise, the grip on my iPhone is quite good.  At first glance, I honestly didn’t think it was going to hold; it seemed a bit big and, consequently, felt a bit loose to the touch.  But so long as you position the phone’s edge within the recessed area on the inside of the ring, the rubber surface does well to keep the phone clamped firmly into place.In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Shineda provided me with sample testing product of their Multifunctional SmartPhone Mount by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

As I’ve mentioned in the past (long story), I’ve had to resort to using external batteries in order to have enough juice to get through the busy workday on my cellphone.  Over the past two years, I’ve had the good fortune to try several different models, and Aukey’s has proven themselves over and over again to produce some of the most reliable support products in the market; this 20000mAh External Battery is no exception.The more powerful the battery, the larger it tends to be, and this 20000mAh one is fairly big.  (For the record, though, it still isn’t much bigger than the average SmartPhone these days!)  The case is built with two separate USB ports (output) as well as an industry-standard Micro port (for charging) or the increasingly popular Apple Lightning (also for input).  Aukey has done like many of makers are doing and has included a handy little LED flashlight built into the housing, but for all of the bells and whistles available it really isn’t all that grand: it’s just a special extra for those who like that sort of thing.Also, Aukey utilizes LED technology in a series of indicator lights with the on-switch.  It glows white when the battery is at anywhere between 20%-100% charge capacity, but it’ll flash red when the device has dropped to less than 20%.  That’s a great warning for those who are paying attention so kudos for including it.Also, kudos to the people at Aukey for providing an actual User’s Manual along with their battery.  So many manufacturers these days have either dispensed with this little nicety OR they’ve shrunk the type so small as to be nearly illegible.  Granted, Aukey’s type is small but at least I can read it without having to reach for the magnifying glass, and it’s all put together handsomely and is easy-to-follow.In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Aukey provided me with sample testing product of their 20000mAh External Battery Charger by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

In all seriousness, I have nothing but respect for technology that can interface with something which appears slightly outdated by today’s standards in order to prolong the life and usefulness of that earlier purchase.  Several manufacturers use to seek this comfortable middle ground but nowadays when cost containment becomes critical they’ve forgone serving consumer needs in favor of achieving cheaper production costs.  However, Etekcity and companies like them long ago realized that there was no reason to see this particular focus of their product lines drop off, and they’ve continued to impress with affordable yet practical solutions for those of us hoping to keep part of what we’ve already purchased while still bringing it into the modern technological era.For example, this Mini RoverBeats Bluetooth Receiver can be used with existing sound systems lacking any Bluetooth capable interface so long as there’s an old school style RCA jack with which to plug in.  I’ve had such a set-up in my kitchen for quite a few years now, and I was dreading having to pull the mounts and wires out of the walls so that I could update to something wireless; now I’m able to put that off a few more years by simply plugging this receiver into the system, jacking it into the speakers, and I’m ready for some tunes.I tested it out this morning for the past few hours.  (FYI: I used my iPhone 4 – also a bit older, as many will point out.)  The RoverBeats kit comes with everything one would need – the receiver and a variety of associated cables and cords for electricity and stereo hook-up – so I hooked everything in in only a few minutes, paired it up with my SmartPhone, and played music through a speaker system I thought was going on the scrap pile as obsolete.  Everything sounded brilliant, and I even (just for giggles) made a telephone call (with phone on speaker) just to see how well that audio came out, and it was terrific (though I’ll never do that again, most likely).As I said, the single greatest advantage to using this is that it prolongs what you already have (assuming it’s a generation or two behind-the-times like mine is) by giving you a contemporary access with Bluetooth tech.  That alone makes this worth the investment, giving you one more option as opposed to buying all new if you can’t afford it for now.  Kudos to Etekcity for keeping the dream alive!In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Etekcity provided me with sample testing product of their Mini RoverBeats Wireless Bluetooth Receiver by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

Yes, I’m a man.  And, yes, I can sew.  That doesn’t mean I do it all of the time, mind you.  But it does mean that I’m more than comfortable with a needle and thread for when the situation arises.  I have a small box that I’ve loaded up with my special scissors, needles, threads, and just about everything … and now I see I’ve been doing it wrong.  Evergreen Supply has done me one better.This kit is nothing short of incredible.  I haven’t had the need to use it as of yet, but I’m still amazed at what’s in here.  I’m practically chomping at the bit, almost willing to tear something, so that I can make use of it.  Anything you could need is right here, and it’s all kept nice and neat in a handsome zippered hardback pouch.  Impressive!Highly recommended.  Seriously, I’m gobsmacked.  I’ve seen sewing kits before.  I’ve purchased sewing kits before.  I’ve even tested and reviewed competitors’ models … but this?  Wow.  Evergreen Supply has once again upped the ante and produced ‘the Sewing Kit To End All Sewing Kits.’  ‘The Mother Of Sewing Kits.’  It’s amazing.  Anything you could possibly need to handle a sewing emergency is in here!  Kudos for once again showing how to get something done right!In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Evergreen Supply provided me with sample testing product of their Sewing Kit by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

Our household is not filled with big drinkers of – ahem – adult beverages, but what we do love to enjoy from time to time is the more-than-occasional cocktail.  We’ve always been a bit old school about it, simply pulling out a tall glass and pouring in a little bit of this along with a little bit of that, but now we’ll able to actually do it up in style with this Cocktail Shaker Set.  It includes four pieces – the shaker, the top, the cap, and the jigger – all of which are fashioned out of a very nice stainless steel.  It’s all very well-made, and the TropiCooland logo appears on both the shaker and the jigger, helping to set the mood for “drinks on the beach” when you’re so inclined.Side note: actually, this item came in at a very good time, too.  At my wife’s work, they are planning on doing a small(ish) motivational event for a specific team, and they’re looking into providing a bunch on non-alcoholic “mocktails” for the workers.  She’ll be taking this down to the office, and it certainly will help make a splash amongst her team.  Kudos!In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at TropiCooland provided me with sample testing product of their Cocktail Shaker Set by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

It’s pretty rare that I’m gobsmacked by a product.  To be fair, it usually isn’t the product alone that gobsmacks me; it’s the presentation.  It’s the bells and whistles that come with.  It’s the obvious interest in making the consumer experience not a good one but a great one.  This one gobsmacked me.My wife and I are avid hikers.  No, we’re not out climbing and sweating our lives away on the side of some treacherous mountain; but we love simply being out-and-about on a great walking trail – medium difficulty, at best – so that we can soak up the outdoors.  And the older we get the more we’ve had to rely on walking sticks to help alleviate the stress and eventually swelling of our knees (curse you, Father Time!).  We’ve tried out a handful of competing ones, but this one from H-Walking Poles gets our high marks for being the complete package.See, we don’t need to use the poles all of the time, but it’s nice to have them along with us in the event that a knee or ankle starts to tense up; and H-Walking Poles’ version comes with a carrying case.  It’s a canvas sling that contains the retracted stick that you can easily throw over your shoulder or as a cross-body bag, and you can leave it there until needed or even if it’s not.  As an added plus, the small bag also has a few Velcro pouches which allow you to carry a few items you might need while you’re out on the trail; and there’s even a webbed-style pouch for a water bottle.Now … THAT’s thinking.  Clearly, somebody at H-Walking Poles put some serious thought into what hikers need, and they went out and built THAT.  Instead of just giving you a pole that can go in your already full pack, these people built a pole that can go in a pack of its own AND gave you a little something extra for your money’s worth.  THAT’s innovation.  THAT’s useful.  THAT’s impressive.  Kudos to a company for being on top of their game.As for the pole?  It works like a charm.  It’s one of those telescoping varieties, so it extends to your exact height’s need, or it retracts for the next user.  Easy to use … and now easy to carry!In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Seven Elegance Brand provided me with sample testing product of their Trekking Pole by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

Now, this is going to be a little different reviews, folks: as I’ve nothing more than a bald head, I agreed that my lovely and gracious wife would use the Dry Shampoo and Conditioner and that I would do a touch’n’feel response for Luseta.  Basically, what we did was use it over a weekend (Saturday and Sunday) with the sole purpose of seeing how this ‘felt’ to both the user AND me.Application of the dry shampoo is a bit of a challenge (she thought) as it’s very much like applying hair spray; you have to be patient to get it evenly over a full head of hair (which she has), so be patient.  Once that’s done, you have to massage it in (I got my hands in there on this part, too, just to see how it all felt).  It’s a very light sheen feeling to it, but it’s pretty easy to see when you’ve got an equal distribution.  Then, you simply brush it out, though both of us thought this took a bit longer to do than either of us had expected.  (Only mentioning that because we figured it was relevant for those thinking they might be able to use this fast and on-the-go: might take a lot of practice for that to be the case.)As for the conditioner, that was really more of my wife’s ‘thing’ than it was mine as the user sprays it in and then basically styles the hair.  She thought that it seemed more like hairspray in this respect as if you get a bit too much conditioner on a patch of hair it works similarly, though with what she called a dull shine instead of bright.  Still, it was an easy process, and I didn’t notice (as the ‘feeler’) that the hair felt brittle the way that it can with some forms of hairspray; it had more of a subtle quality to it, though I’d agree with her that one area (where perhaps she oversprayed a bit) was a bit stiff and hard to manage.In the long run, I’m not convinced either of us were totally sold on the benefits of dry shampooing.  Don’t get me wrong: I think it’s definitely a convenience for some who are more concerned about keeping up appearances maybe on-the-weekend … but I’m not certain this is a Monday-thru-Friday workplace solution for some folks.  Nothing replaces a good shampoo!In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Komar Beauty provided me with sample testing product of their Luseta Volume Reviving Dry Shampoo & Conditioner Bundle – Lavender by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

I’ve mentioned before that due to circumstances well beyond my control my cellular life practically depends these days on keeping a portable battery charger on hand for when I’m out and about in my neighborhood; sadly, my cell provider doesn’t have as strong a signal presence as it should near my home, and my iPhone tends to run through the battery charge quicker than it should thanks to what seems to be afternoons of endless roaming.  In any event, I keep one of these puppies with me when I’m on-the-go, and this one from Lumsing gets my thumbs up.  (For the record, I have a handful of other related Lumsing products around the house that I’ve been using for well over a year, so I’m definitely a fan of their quality and craftsmanship.)As for the charger, their latest – the 10050 mAh portable charger – is about the size of a late 2000’s Smart Phone (still a plus as it can fit in one’s pocket), and it feels of excellent construction (very solid).  All of the ports are located on one end – the power input and two USB slot outputs – and there’s an on/off button easily built into the housing along its side.  The only other identifying characteristic I’d mention is that it’s a bit heavier than competing models I’ve had the chance to own or test, but that’s a small price to pay when you’re dealing in ounces and not pounds.Charging was a breeze: when I noticed my iPhone had dipped down to under 20%, I simply plugged it in (had my own cable in tow, as you’ll need to do for making use of this battery) and I was back to a full charge in about thirty minutes.As an extra added plus, Lumsing has cleverly put a flash-style bulb into the interface end; you can turn it on by holding down that power button (on the side), and now your battery becomes a flashlight.  It’s a ‘nice’ selling extra, but – to be perfectly honest – the flashlight isn’t all that illuminating: as I said, think of it as an ‘extra’ – nothing more, nothing less – but if Lumsing can get the next generation of this to have a more powerful beam then that might become a legitimate selling point.Still, it’s a great battery, and theirs is a great, reliable company.In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Lumsing provided me with sample testing product of their 10050 mAh Portable Charger by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

If you’ve failed to notice, effective horror movies do several things very well.  They introduce characters the audience can either identify with, care about, or wish dead.  They develop an interesting universe in which a monster, ghost, killer, slayer, or something else exists with a requisite hunger to sate.  And they focus all of this in such a way as to keep an audience focused on what’s coming next, building the suspense for a big finish.Now, I’m not saying that SOME KIND OF HATE is such a film.  It’s more than a bit uneven at times – some of which are problems due to its low budget – but it also fleshed out a mildly interesting Moira as its chief villainess and bloody antagonist.(NOTE: The following review will contain minor spoilers necessary solely for the discussion of plot and/or characters.  If you’re the type of reader who prefers a review entirely spoiler-free, then I’d encourage you to skip down to the last three paragraphs for my final assessment.  If, however, you’re accepting of a few modest hints at ‘things to come,’ then read on …)From the product packaging: “Relentless bullying has turned Lincoln’s life into a nightmare.  But soon he learns the true meaning of terror when he is sent to a remote school for trouble teens and the harassment starts all over again.  Only this time, someone is watching …”I’ve edited down the promotional blurbs because, mostly, I think it gives away more than it need to (certainly more than I would’ve), and I’ve left you with the nitty gritty.  Essentially what you have with a film like SOME KIND OF HATE is maybe one part originality with three parts derivatives: we’ve had horror films set at ‘remote schools’ before, and there’s even a major horror franchise that’s already marketed the whole ‘summer camp’ scene (of which HATE at times looks more than similar to) … so I’m not at all convinced writer/director Adam Egypt Mortimer has enough material here to stand entirely on its own.  As is often the case with first films in a potentially developing franchise, “only time will tell.”What he does have is Moira, a vengeful spirit from beyond the grave who only comes out to play (or is that ‘slay’?) when called from the other side.  Once summoned, she’ll use all of her ghostly feminine wiles to deliver her own brand of justice, one based entirely on the fact that even she took her life as a result of bullying by her supposedly good and pure school counselors.  Like any good horror flick worth its weight in blood, HATE works best when everyone involved plays second fiddle to Moira’s gruesome pursuits, but I’m not sure the script (from Mortimer and Brian DeLeeuw) really spent enough time developing the other warm bodies to the point where any of us in the audience would truly miss ‘em when they’re gone.Lacking that connection, HATE ends up being more ‘slash’ than ‘splash,’ and better production qualities – along with another draft – would probably have been required to elevate this to the level of wanting more.  As it stands, there’s nothing wrong with it … but I suspect you’ll forget most of the particulars with the exception of cunning little Moira after all is said and done.SOME KIND OF HATE (2015) is produced by Caliber Media, Destroy All Entertainment, and Revek Entertainment.  DVD distribution is being handled by the reliable RLJ Entertainment and Image Entertainment.  As for the technical specifications?  Meh.  It’s reasonably well shot, but I had some issues with the sound work (as I had to crank it up quite a ways to clearly hear all dialogue).  For those needing it, the packaging indicates that close captioning is available.  Lastly, if you’re looking for special features, then get set for some deleted scenes and not one but two commentary tracks for your enjoyment.(MILDLY) RECOMMENDED at best.  Here’s the thing: unlike many, many other horror releases I’ve watched, SOME KIND OF HATE isn’t without its merits.  Granted, they are few and far between, but it’s also pretty obvious someone put a modest measure of thought into the idea behind what makes for a successful franchise and then tried to start one.  While this may not be the last we’ve seen of Moira, I’m not exactly clamoring for a follow-up either.In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at RLJ Entertainment and Image Entertainment provided me with a DVD copy of SOME KIND OF HATE by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

For what it’s worth, I’m certainly experienced probably a bit more than the average person in confronting wrist and thumb pain issues.  Both of my thumbs have a curious ‘double-jointing’ issue that have caused some trouble.  My family (mom’s side) has a history of arthritis.  Also, a few years back, the place I worked decided to ‘right size’ my cubicle, and that sad sorry attempt brought me an unwelcome bought of carpal tunnel syndrome for an extended period of time.  Mostly, my condition is much better today, but it occasionally flares up, and that’s why I’ll use a wrap while I sleep overnight to help alleviate some pain from unneeded movement.Aegend’s Breathable Wrist Wrap is a bit of a step down in terms of what I’m used to, but – in some regards – that’s not a bad thing.  The one I own and have used for years is much more heavy duty in terms of materials and construction, the downside of which is that occasionally it feels heavier on my wrist than what I’d prefer.  Also, it gets to feeling warm and muggy during the warmer months of the year, and that’s probably when I’ll be reaching for Aegend’s version as an alternative.  As it’s advertised, it’s much more “breathable” – lighter fabric, etc. – and that’s really its biggest advantage.I know and have worked with plenty of folks who use a wrap of this sort while they’re on the computer, but (thankfully) I’ve never had to.  I have tried Aegend’s at my home PC station, and I can say that it definitely helps in maintaining one’s wrist in the proper position to help minimize some of a busy day’s works’ associated aches and pains; however, I’ve always found wearing one while working a bit too restrictive.  Still, because it’s lighter than my other, I’d be inclined to give this one a go should my symptoms point me in that direction.The only real drawback is (hate to admit it) I’m never all that good with Velcro.  I’ve had to reposition it a few times with the first few uses, mostly because of my own personal inefficiencies, but it is what it is.  It certainly complies with all of its advertised traits; as to how well it is long-term, I’ll have to continue testing and update here as needed.Also (thought it worth a mention), this is probably a great lightweight to use IF you’re a business person who travels.  It rolls up like a pair of socks, so it’s easy to stow it a backpack, briefcase, or toiletry pouch.  Kudos on that.RECOMMENDED.  It’s a good wrap though a bit difficult to get positioned perfectly the first few times, though I suspect repeated use will iron those issues out quite nicely.In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Aegend provided me with sample testing product of their Breathable Wrist Brace by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

Truth be told: I fell in love with Lucy Griffiths back in the days of her appearances aboard the BBC’s occasionally campy Robin Hood (2006-2009).  A few years later, she turned up aboard HBO’s True Blood, though her character – Nora Gainsborough – was sadly relegated to second-tier status, essentially a supporting player to Alexander Skarsgård’s Eric Northman.  Today, I was delighted to discover her as one of the leads aboard 2015’s UNCANNY, a clever and thought-provoking SciFi potboiler that deserves to find an audience as big as its ideas.(NOTE: The following review will contain minor spoilers necessary solely for the discussion of plot and/or characters.  If you’re the type of reader who prefers a review entirely spoiler-free, then I’d encourage you to skip down to the last three paragraphs for my final assessment.  If, however, you’re accepting of a few modest hints at ‘things to come,’ then read on …)From the product packaging: “For ten years, inventor David Kressen has lived in seclusion with his inventions, including Adam, a robot with incredible lifelike human qualities.  When reporter Joy Andrews is given access to their unconventional facility, she is alternately repelled and attracted to the scientist and his creation.  But as Adam exhibits emergent behavior of anger and jealousy towards her, she finds herself increasingly entangled in a web of deception where no one’s motives are easily decipherable.”Amazon review readers are quick to lambast me for taking more than a few words to tell you what I thought of a new release, so I’ll try to keep it as simple and sweet as possible, trying that in with my affection for the simple and sweet Lucy Griffiths.  She’s at times subtle, at times luminescent in this star-crossed triangle where woman meets man and machine.  In ways, it’s a mildly predictable tale – anytime testosterone edges out the estrogen there’s bound to be a conflict – but it’s still nonetheless ably delivered and smartly performed by Griffiths and her co-stars, Mark Webber and David Clayton Rogers.Granted, this is the kind of film that nerds, geeks, and general SciFi enthusiasts will have a blast with (with, as a said, some reservations for its more ‘soapy’ elements); but it’s also the type of feature which might win the genre some crossover appeal: Griffiths and her suitors are all lookers, and UNCANNY might just turn out to be one of those unheard-of releases that finds itself the recipient of solid word-of-mouth.UNCANNY (2015) is produced by Accelerated Matter, Shoreline Entertainment, Emergent Behavior, Ambush Entertainment, and Uncanny.  DVD distribution is being handled by the reliable RLJ Entertainment and Image Entertainment.  As for the technical specifications?  Director Matthew Leutwyler does an impressive job sighting and sounding the picture, though some of the close-ups seemed a wee bit too high (or too low) and the flick is adorned with those God awful JJ Abrams’ lens flares far too often.  Packaging states that there is closed captioned for the Hearing-Impaired (though there was no specific subtitling track that I could find).  Lastly, if you’re looking for special features, then you have about 10 minutes of deleted scenes (nothing all that grand, so far as I found).HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.  I’m a SciFi junkie, and that means there are parts of UNCANNY that I just couldn’t get enough of – the classic misdirect, the nuanced discussions of artificial intelligence, etc.  Granted, I could’ve done without the JJ Abrams’ lens flare effects constantly peppering the screen and some of the more obvious potboiler elements could’ve been dialed back just a bit … but – in the end – I’m still left with a smart, excellently conceived, and well performed cautionary tale about what’s likely going on psychologically behind-the-scenes in the whole man-versus-machine smackdown.In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Image Entertainment and RLJ Entertainment provided me with a DVD of UNCANNY by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.

Coffee, my friends, is a big business. Big business. BIG business. Make no bones about it, folks who love their coffee usually have several different means with which to keep it fresh and hot (no, I’m not talking about a Starbucks cup).  Me, I don’t drink coffee myself, but I have been known to partake of some hot (or cold) tea from time to time, so I was definitely willing to give this particular item a try. It’s an extremely smart-looking and well-made mug; the top screws off easily, revealing an excellently designed ‘pour’ piece that’s crafted to minimize the chances for spilling. Simply pop that off (it has its own seal embedded in the ring, so be careful when putting it back on to get it completely down as I noticed that mine ‘hangs’ a bit, requiring a firm pressing) and fill with your favorite flavor. This model comes with a certificate of authenticity, the company’s guarantee, and a spiffy little owner’s manual with directions and suggestions for extending the life and effectiveness of your exceptional travel mug.As to its ability to keep hot things hot and cold things cold? Well, I tried it with some iced tea while working around the house, and I’m pleased to say that it kept mine reasonably chilled for a few hours, though it’s pretty easy to notice a bit of a fade off after that. Still, that’s a minor price-to-pay for being able to keep it cold WITHOUT ice (I actually don’t like ice IN my tea, so there’s that), and I’m perfectly happy with it.In the interests of fairness, I’m pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Urbane O2 provided me with sample testing product of their 17 ounce vacuum mug by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review; and their contribution to me in no way, shape, or form influenced my opinion of it.
