"One of the problems with the word orthodoxy is that it is usually brought up when someone is being reprimanded. So it has gotten a bad reputation, like an older sibling who is always peeking around the corner, trying to catch you doing something wrong. ... I don't know any other way to say this: it seems like a lot of the people who care about orthdoxy are jerks." And here he begins to suggest the solution: a humble orthodoxy, caring deeply about truth, but defending and sharing this truth with compassion and humility. "Whether our theological knowledge is great or small, we all need to ask a vital question: What will we do with the knowledge of God that we have?" The Bible does not allow us to choose between orthodoxy and humility, but insists that we need both in equal measure, and assures us that through the Holy Spirit we can be humbly orthodox. I have always loved this quote from John Stott which speaks to this very thing:Thank God there are those in the contemporary church who are determined at all costs to defend and uphold God's revealed truth. But sometimes they are conspicuously lacking in love. When they think they smell heresy, their nose begins to twitch, their muscles ripple, and the light of battle enters their eye. They seem to enjoy nothing more than a fight. Others make the opposite mistake. They are determined at all costs to maintain and exhibit brotherly love, but in order to do so are prepared even to sacrifice the central truths of revelation. Both these tendencies are unbalanced and unbiblical. Truth becomes hard if it is not softened by love; love becomes soft if it is not strengthened by truth. The apostle calls us to hold the two together, which should not be difficult for Spirit-filled believers, since the Holy Spirit is himself `the spirit of truth,' and his first fruit is `love." There is no other route than this to a fully mature Christian unity.Harris lays out two alternatives to humble orthodoxy. The first is arrogant orthodoxy, where our doctrine is correct but we are unkind and unloving, where we are self-righteous and spiteful in our words, attitudes and behaviors. "If anyone thinks arrogant orthodoxy doesn't exist, he's never read the comments section of a Christian blog." Touche. The other alternative is humble heterodoxy where a person abandons orthodox Christianity but does it very nicely. The temptation for Harris, for myself, and for most of those who will read this review is toward the first of these alternatives, to pursue orthodoxy at the expense of love. "You and I need to contend for the truth. But there's a fine line between contending for truth and being contentious."The driving passion behind our pursuit of biblical orthdoxy is "not to prove ourselves more right or better than someone else but to better worship the holy God, the one who forgives and accepts us for Christ's sake alone." He looks to Tim Keller and says "if we make a good thing like correct theology the ultimate end--if being right becomes more important to us than worshiping God--then our theology is not really about God anymore. It's about us. It becomes the source of our sense of worth and identity. And if theology becomes about us, then we'll despise and demonize those who oppose us."Thus the solution to arrogant orthodoxy is not less orthodoxy, but more. The more we know of God, the more we love and trust him, the more humble we will be before him.This is a book that I would love to put in the hands of a lot of people I have encountered over the years. First and foremost, though, it is a book I needed to read. It is a book I need to read again. It is a book I plan to read regularly. It rebuked, encouraged and challenged me in very helpful ways. If you have a blog or you regularly peruse blogs (especially if you comment on them), if you just plain love theology and desire to believe what is right and true, then do yourself a favor and read it as well.

Christianity is a bloody faith. It is a bloody faith because it is the faith of sinful people and the Bible tells us that sin requires blood. For sin to be forgiven, for sinful people to be made right with God, there must be a payment of blood. That payment was made by Jesus Christ on a blood-soaked cross and through the centuries Christians have been praising God for providing the one thing they need most that they cannot do themselves. So Christians speak of the blood of Jesus Christ, they thank God for accepting the bloody sacrifice of Jesus Christ, they sing of that blood, they praise God for it. This is an unashamedly bloody faith.We can see the significance of blood in the pages of the Old Testament, where from the earliest verses there are bloody footprints leading away from the perfection of the Garden of Eden. The blood of millions of animals brings temporary peace between sinful people and a sinned-against God. We see the significance of blood in how frequently the New Testament mentions it--nearly three times as often as "the cross" of Christ and five times as often as the "death" of Christ. Says Richard Phillips, "At the very heart of our Christian faith is a precious red substance; the blood of our Lord Jesus Christ."In his new book Blood Work, Anthony Carter, pastor of East Point Church in East Point, Georgia, describes how the blood of Christ accomplishes the Christian's salvation. Through 140 pages that are equally descriptive and meditative, he traces the New Testament's blood motif and finds that blood is necessary for purchasing, propitiating, justifying, redeeming, cleansing, sanctifying, electing, freeing and so much else. Almost every benefit that is ours in Christ Jesus is explicitly connected to us through this trail of blood.The reason for all this talk of blood becomes clear in the pages of Scripture. "In Genesis 9:4 we are told that life is in the blood. If life is in the blood and the blood represents life, then the loss or shedding of blood represents death." Thus the blood of Jesus is a metaphor for the life and death of Jesus. "His precious blood signified His precious life and His precious death. Consequently, the redeemed do not receive a blood transfusion from God. We receive a life transfusion--His death for our death, His life for our life. It is all according to His precious blood, which satisfies God's righteous requirements for life and justice."If blood is so central to our great problem and God's great solution, "It should not be surprising that as recipients of God's gracious salvation through the person and work of Christ we preach, pray, and even sing of the wonderful power of the blood, as the popular hymn by William Cowper ("There Is a Foundation Filled with Blood") demonstrates." In fact, every chapter of Blood Work is marked by Christian hymns that, in both sorrow and joy, speak of Christ's blood. "And can it be that I should gain / An interest in the Savior's blood?" "I'll wash my garments white / In the blood of Calv'ry's Lamb." "Sealed my pardon with his blood / Hallelujah! What a Savior!" "Dear dying Lamb, Thy precious blood / Shall never lose its power."All this talk of blood and all these bloody songs called me to ponder why the Old Testament and all its blood-soaked history had to come before the cross. All the blood of all those animals was preparing us to understand the blood of the perfect and final sacrifice. The bloody doorposts in Egypt made death pass over the homes of God's people; the bloody cross of Calvary makes death pass over the souls of God's people.Blood Work is a powerful book that calls the reader to better understand why blood is such a integral, vile, beautiful necessity to the Christian faith. It is a book that calls the reader not only to understand, but also to marvel and to worship.

Most people who read this review will be like me in that they live in a culture of radical individualism. Where our identities were once inexorably wrapped up in a local community, today we are what one sociologist has referred to as networked individuals, people who are loosely bound together by interests, but each convinced that we are answerable ultimately, or perhaps only, to ourselves. Individualism reigns, solidarity is passe.Contra this individualism comes Chris Brauns' Bound Together: How We Are Tied to Others in Good and Bad Choices. Brauns wants Christians to understand that in God's economy we are tied together through what he calls the "principle of the rope." He holds that corporate solidarity is a key aspect of life as taught in the Bible. We are not meant to exist apart from fellowship and community.Brauns looks to man's fall into sin as the ultimate negative example of this principle and then looks to Christ's work on the cross as the ultimate positive example. In the first case one man sinned and saw the effects of his action extend to all who would come after him. In the second case one Man died and now offers the benefits of his death and resurrection to all who will take hold of the grace he offers and, in so doing, be united to him. In this way Brauns provides a uniquely interesting take on two foundational but often misunderstood Christian doctrines: original sin and union with Christ. And as he does this he shows the beautiful gospel truth that this second rope is infinitely stronger than the first.The principle of the rope finds application in all areas of life, but Brauns focuses on just a few:Christian Community. The truest and highest joys are found not in selfishness, but in selfless investment in Christ-centered community. If you want to pursue joy--and God's desire for you is that you would pursue joy--you will need to pursue it by investing in others.Marriage. The principle of the rope illustrates both the beauty of marriage and the devastation of divorce which represents the destruction of a tie meant to last to death.Family. Families experience the "bound together" nature of relationships in a unique way in both joys and trials. Brauns focuses specifically and pastorally on families that have been grieved by a family member who has turned his back on the people who love him.Death. Christians can face death without fear because of their solidarity with the One who has already conquered death's power.The Local Church. Brauns insists that the local church is uniquely qualified to counter the radical individualism that is unraveling the very fabric of Western culture. The church offers both the theology and the structure that reinforces the values that are necessary to hold a society together. It is, after all, God's plan a (and plan b) to reach a lost and dying world.Jerry Bridges, who has often spoken and written about how few Christians understand the doctrine of union with Christ (and what a difference it would make if they did understand it), says this about Bound Together: "Chris Brauns has done a masterful job of explaining the truth and its implications of the principle of solidarity ... His treatment of all humanity's solidarity with Adam in his sin and the solidarity of all believers with Christ is especially helpful, but the entire book is a masterpiece that will help us understand some of the interpersonal relationships we deal with every day."It is, indeed, a book that is both enjoyable and insightful in understanding not only that we are bound together in both Adam's and Christ's redemption, but that we are bound to one another in all areas of life. My actions affect those around me and their actions affect me. We are not isolated individuals, but people connected together in so many different ways.

That’s not what these liners cost. That’s what your refrigerator cost (or more, or maybe a little less) if you’ve bought a decent fridge in the last few years, as we have.  If you spend that much on a fridge, you want it to smell nice, keep your food clean and fresh, and not cause you a cleaning headache. That’s where these liners come in.These are fashionable, relatively thin, washable woven fabric sheets that you cut to size to line your drawers and shelves inside your refrigerator. They look wonderful, are super absorbent, and when they get dirty or dingy, you just pull them out, wash them, and put them back (or put in a new one). The precut size is one by two feet, which worked out great, to give me three sheets from one for each of our 12”x 8” drawers. I also used one cut to shape to put under my soda boxes so that if they get damp, they don’t leave pieces of carton behind on the shelf. They are such a simple thing, yet truly wonderful. I especially like the decorative dimension they give to our largely clear drawers (see before and after photos), which makes it easier to see what is inside and easier to notice when they are dirty.It’s just a clever, useful thing, and I would probably have given them five stars in the first place, but for protecting my investment in my refrigerator and the food I put in it, it’s easy to give them such a high rating.

Truth be told, I drink alcohol. It’s enjoyable, relaxing, and I’ve experienced much of the culture of the world both with and without drinks in hand. So when Tropicooland offered me the opportunity to try their cocktail shaker set in exchange for a review, I cleared some space at the bar and said yes. And I’m glad I did.This set stacks up well with my current set. (See photo of the two sitting on my piano bar.) It is about the same size, maybe a little taller and thinner, and it has the same sleek, stainless steel finish. The included jigger doesn’t have a handle like my existing set, which is fine, but what I do like is the Tropicooland jigger is in a one ounce and half ounce size. Compared to my 1/1.5 ounce jigger, it is much easier to precisely mix drinks with. The shaker itself is big enough to easily mix about four drinks at a time, great for larger cocktail parties. The strainer top stays on and doesn’t leak while mixing, but it comes right off for cleaning and mixing the next batch. The same is true for the top above the strainer. The walls of the mixer and strainer are a little thinner than my current set, but it doesn’t noticeably detract from the performance. (I still have to use a towel to hold either mixer, as they send shivers up to the tendonitis in my elbow if I don’t.)Whether mixing some Sidecars for me and the wife on a quiet weekend, or a batch of Negronis when a group comes over for cards or whatever, if it makes me a decent drink without making a mess, I have no complaints, so of course I rate it at five stars.

This past summer I started smelling strange odors where nobody else could. Strange, strange odors, mostly like smoke, sometimes in my car, sometimes at work, sometimes at home. I’d asked people around me if they could smell it, but no. I was alone. A cursory web search indicated something called phantosmia, and during my regular checkup at my doctor’s, I asked about it. He said my nose probably needed a good, regular cleaning and he suggested a saline nasal spray. About that time, I picked up this product.The best thing about this is how easy it is to use. You just fill it up, dump in a solution packet, shake, and then spray up your nose. Your body will try to keep the fluid out, so you basically end up shooting solution up one nostril that streams out the other. Give a good blow, spray the other side, and repeat until you’re out of solution. Then you can breathe easy. I was amazed at how easy this is to use, but I wouldn’t call it comfortable. (It made me recall a number of uncomfortable dunks in the neighbors swimming pool while growing up.). I can’t argue with the results: fresh feeling sinuses, probably healthier mucus membranes, and since I’ve been using it, no more phantosmia.This is a simple thing that does what it says. It’s easy to use, easy to maintain, reusable, refillable, and it solves a small problem. I want to give it a less than perfect rating because it is such a simple device, but I can’t find a thing to complain about it, so I did give it five stars.

I spent two days in Brooklyn once, looking for an apartment. We ended up living in Queens, so I’m certainly no expert on Brooklyn, but this book can make anyone an authority in short order, The design for this Brooklyn guidebook is totally different from the traditional complete guidebook that Fodor is famous for. (Fodor’s publishes a 544 page full color travel guide for New York City, which also includes Brooklyn.) Although this is a small, lightweight book, it thoroughly covers 18 neighborhoods in its 264 pages. Each neighborhood starts with a sort of whimsical map (first photo) to visually highlight the reasons to visit. Fort Greene and Clinton Hill (for example) is for “tree-lined streets, historic homes and sophisticated dining” while Carroll Gardens features “top restaurants, Italian-American culture, hip shopping". I found this especially useful to understand the allure of each neighborhood to casual visitors.The section for each neighborhood contains detailed illustrated maps (second photo), a brief description, and information on sights, shopping, dining, nightlife and hotels. It’s a format that makes it easy to find specific information. Another unique feature is “Local Q&A”, where Fodor asked Brooklynites questions like “Describe Brooklyn in three words”. Replies vary from the expected, such as “Diverse, vibrant, creative”, to the definitive “Just One: Amazing”. They all make me curious to go there again.The bottom line is this guidebook is informative, very stylish and fun to read. It is more like reading a weekend magazine and gives a truly representative overview of this vibrant area of New York City. I did deduct one star, however, as there isn’t a single photograph in the entire book, but it’s still a valuable four star guide.

This stuff is not very good. I followed the instructions for mixing: two capfuls (which is confusing to start, because the cap has a spout) per gallon of water. It mixed up really well, formed a great lather and smelled wonderful. I washed as normal, rinsed and waited. What I was left with was surfaces that were not clean at all. They were very streaky and not all the dirt was removed. A sort of filmy, streaky glare settled and curiously highlighted every scratch and ding. I had to go back and buff with a dry cotton towel while spot cleaning where the dirt was left behind. It was a lot of extra work.While I liked the smell and the promise of “wash-n-wax” in one was appealing, the results were far from desirable. Maybe if you have a really dirty project, you can wash once with something else and finish with this. That might leave your boat or car nice and shiny, but for me, that’s asking too much. If Meguiar's puts out a men’s cologne, I might buy it, but I will never use this two star stuff again.

I am an amateur chef who many years ago made a heavy investment in a set of serious German knives from Zwilling Henckels. They’ve never let me down and they’re the set I keep going back to. But this hasn’t stopped me from trying other knives over the years, from off brand Chinese fruit knives to Japanese sushi knives, and everything in between. This is the first time I’ve tried Sabatier.Although the brand is French, these one piece knives are made in China. They are individually wrapped and protected by cardboard sleeves and silicone tip guards, a number of which were missing or fallen completely off. The look is very sleek, as the handles and blades are all one piece, and the space age round block looks like a satellite orbiting our cook top, completely different from a traditional wooden knife block (see photo). A cursory inspection of the cutting edges revealed some noticeable areas of uneven edges and slight discoloration. It’s easy to tell these are machine sharpened in mass quantities. That said, they are decidedly sharp, and I’ve cut vegetables, fish, and meat and haven’t had anything give any of these knives any difficulty. They feel firm in the hand and have a decent heft, but aren’t what I would call “heavy”. For an all metal handle, they are remarkably comfortable once seated in the palm.But to return to their sharpness, here’s where I have a problem. The handle proceeds into the blade without much delineation. Sure, the pattern on the handle is different from the blade, but the shift is subtle and because the material is the same, it is impossible to have any feel for where the handle stops and the blade begins. This is completely different from my Zwilling knives which have a wood or composite handle on a metal blade. It is easy and natural to know when one needs to adjust one’s grip to not cut your hand, but this is not possible with the Sabatier. Sure enough, the first time I washed these, I got careless and did, in fact, cut a finger. I didn’t even feel it until I was done washing. I think the modern design is good looking, but I think it causes the functionality to suffer a bit. (I will note also that the cut was a lot rougher than the cut of the Zwilling, which cuts so straight and cleanly, an overnight bandage can seal up the wound. Two days on with the Sabatier cut, which is not deep at all, and I’m still struggling just to keep it closed. Ouch!)I’m not sure how these knives will stand up to steady use, nor am I even sure I’m going to steadily use them. I’m definitely going to have to learn to handle these knives differently from what I am used to. For someone looking for a good starter knife set at a decent price, who doesn’t have a bias from any previous knives, this is a perfectly useful and versatile set. For someone who’s been using quality knives for as long as thirty years, these probably won’t measure up. At least, I didn’t think they did, which is why I’m putting them at only four stars.

As a musician, I am, by default an audiophile. I have multiple Bose systems, two Yamaha receiver amps, Bluetooth speaker systems from Bang and Olufson and Devialet, and recently, a system similar to this Logitech from HP. I’ve even had a larger Logitech system that we used with our iPad until some of the more advanced equipment came along. So to be honest, I did not have high expectations for this system, especially as the HP AV system for computer audio was, at best, unimpressive. But as it turns out, Logitech has a winner here.One of the best things about this system is how easy it is to set up: plug it in, connect the speakers (standard RCA style), turn it on and connect a sound source, and you’re ready to jam. I tried mine out with some Freddie Hubbard jazz quintet stuff and was amazed at the clarity of the bass and drums. The bass adjusts individually as well and you can control the volume (and on/off) from a little rotating pod that is connected to the sub-woofer. The sound is very good, but not scintillating. The high end tends to get lost a little, and though you can turn up the bass, it doesn’t EQ the other sounds, so you really end up with either too much low end or a smidgen of distortion in the mid-range. But don’t get me wrong, the 80 watts puts out a lot of robust sound, and for video games, casual listening while working on the computer, or watching music videos and listening to downloads, this system has enough depth and power to satisfy even demanding music lovers. It held up well with electronica and classical music, and any of my favorite 80's hits sounded crisp enough to transport me back to high school.The worst I can do for a complaint is the power cord is really short, and I hate using these things with extension cords, as it often introduces some buzz that defeats the purpose of a unit with separate speakers. But if you make a few considerations for the device’s location and the speaker location, it isn’t hard to get good, three dimensional sound with exceptional depth and vibrancy. Of course, larger systems from companies that are audio experts put out more and better sound, but at this price point, size, and power level, you will have to look long and hard to improve on this Logitech. It’s a five star piece of equipment, well worth adding to your computer sound system.

When the manufacturer of this device – what I’ll call a “mood light” – offered me a sample in exchange for an honest review, I went to Amazon to check out what I was getting myself into. As soon as I realized what it was I would be getting, I eagerly accepted the manufacturer’s offer. The item arrived very quickly in secure packaging, and it was simple to set up (just plug it in and turn it on). Then the fun began.The device couldn’t be simpler. It just a bunch of LED lights set into a frame that has a multi-faceted lens that spins above the LED’s. As it catches the individual LED’s, it creates patterns of colored light on the ceiling above. There are different color modes that you can mix and match to a party theme or your own mood, or you can cycle through all the color schemes in a preset order. If you don’t want the colors plying their way all over the ceiling, you can mute the whole effect with a diffuser dome, which puts much softer patterns on the ceiling. I got our mood light set up in the living room where we have 16 foot tall vaulted ceilings, and although the light dissipated some and the ceiling fan was in the way, the effect was still broad, large, and very dynamic. Both the wife and I absolutely loved it. I noticed that in a few of the modes that use the red LED’s, the crystals are cut in such a way that the red beam seems to snake around the ceiling in a continuous motion, which is an even more dramatic effect. When we put it in a room with nine foot ceilings, the light was very bright and dense and much more colorful.The device also can play music, and although I haven’t tried it, I’m pretty sure that’s not going to be its forte. Here, it is all about the light show. If this could be dimmed enough to still fall asleep in a bedroom, that would be a great soothing feature, but honestly, I don’t have any real complaints about this device. The lighting effects are stunning, the thing is priced well, and it is small and built well, so it should last for a while. I’m only too happy to give this fun, flexible, fabulous product five full stars. It’s just fantastic.

This is one of those things that is nice to have but which is completely possible to live without. If I still lived in Japan and made regular onsen trips, I’d get a lot more use out of it. Just around the house, I might use it occasionally when getting ready in the morning, or I might not, depending on how I feel. I probably will never go out in public with this.The fabric is nice, as is the look. It isn’t terribly absorbent, but I wouldn’t use it like a towel, anyway. It’s just a nice wrap for getting from one bathing destination to another. The Velcro closure is not comfortable and difficult to align to avoid irritation. The size is adjustable, but my 36” waist is pretty much at the limit for this thing, at least, if you want to avoid “overexposure”. I do like the pocket and the overall feel, but again, I don’t really need to be carrying things to the shower, so I’m vague on the whole concept of utility here.I just don’t know what to make of this. It isn’t perfect, but it isn’t bad. It isn’t useful, but it isn’t without some functionality. It’s comfortable, but lacks a clear fashion purpose. I’ll probably keep it around for a little while, use it on occasion (especially if I go to visit the in-laws in Japan), and when I get tired of it, I’ll wash the car with it. Until then, I give it three stars for being an average piece of bath gear.

The manufacturer of these gloves offered me a pair for free in exchange for an honest review. As a jazz pianist, I have a number of different gloves that I use on a regular basis, from cut proof, puncture proof garden gloves, to chemical resistant latex gloves, running gloves, and even driving gloves. I wasn’t sure what I was going to do with “tactical gloves”, but I figured I’d find a use for them.I ordered the large based on the size chart on Amazon, and they fit perfectly. (I like them snug.) The protective knuckle pads were right over the knuckles and the dimensions of the palm and locations of the creases matched my hand exactly. The wrist band adjusts with a hook and loop strap for an even tighter fit, and there’s also a hook and loop adjuster on the back of the glove above the back of the hand. The fabric has a lot of give, but it feels thick and protective. The palm fabric is subtly textured and provides very solid grip. There are a couple of plastic inserts on the backs of the fingers for added support and protection. I still don’t really have a clear idea where I’m going to use them, but for starters, I’m going to keep them with my tool box and use them for projects anytime I’m using tools and don’t require cut protection. I’m thinking I’ll also use one of them for unloading the washer, as I often bump my hand on the agitator when pulling the clothes out, right where I suffered a broken bone four years ago.I’m not a firearms fanatic, but I did show these to one at work and he said he could see where the plastic supports would come in handy. I just think they are good, well-constructed, comfortable gloves that I’m sure to get some good use out of, and that’s why I give them five stars.

If you’re like me and work in factory, probably a number of your coworkers with iPhones already have Otterboxes and you’ve been jonesing after one of your own. At least, I was. But I have to say in all honesty after I received this one, I was quite happy at first, but I became a little disillusioned after a while. Make no mistake: If your phone is prone to be bumped, dropped, or otherwise handled around concrete surfaces, heavy machinery, or dirty environments, a Defender like this is one of the best cases you can put your phone in to prevent damage. The trade off, however, is, it turns your sleek, slim, light, easy to handle phone into a huge brick of acrylic, plastic and metal. You will never slip your phone into another pocket again, and it’s a good thing you’ve given it plenty of drop protection, because you’re going to be dropping it all over the place as you get used to your clumsy brute of a phone case.Once I figured out how to open the case (that took me a while), it was simple to get the phone in and to close up the case. I even was able to leave on the screen protector in case I go back to my other case (read on). There are access ports all around the case for charging, taking pictures and whatnot, so the phone stays eminently usable and functional. I can’t hear the button clicks like I could before, but that is easily fixed by just turning up the volume on the phone. I like the two tone look of the plastic inside the silicone, but the phone really feels heavy to me. I hate the belt clip. Loaded with the phone, it’s like attaching a small dumbbell to your waist, and I never get the phone to sit quite right without fumbling with the whole thing for a few extra seconds. At least twice on the first day of use, I dropped the phone while trying to put it in the clip. (I guess that was as good a way to test the drop protection as any – the phone survived.)The bottom line for me is I handle the phone more easily without all the protection, and that becomes a sort of protection in and of itself. Same thing for using a Defender: Your phone will be out and about, and dropped and bumped, a lot more inside a Defender, so thank God it’s in a Defender. I prefer slim and light and protected by careful use to bulky and heavy and protected by bulk and weight, so I’m going back to my original, slim Spigen case. Still, I see the value of this iPhone protector, so I’m comfortable giving it four stars, even though it’s just not for me.

This is my second Burei watch, and like my first, I received this as a sample in exchange for an honest review. There are two big differences between this watch and the first one I received. Number one is the black dial, which gives a sleeker, sharper impression than my first watch with a white dial face. And number two is, this comes with a stainless steel metal bracelet instead of my preferred comfortable, adjustable leather band. When I opened the box and first saw this watch though, I was immediately struck by how sophisticated it looked. I wanted to wear it to work the next day, but the band was too big and would need adjusting. As it happened, I had two new Invicta watches with metal bands that needed adjusting as well, so I took the whole bunch to a local store to have them serviced. What follows is a true story.I started with the most expensive Invicta. The technician looked at it, said we’ll take out five links, took them out, and I was fitted with a nice Invicta men’s chronograph with a black textured face and stainless steel band. Next came a two-toned metal Invicta that I think actually looks sharper than the first Invicta, being less bulky and more snappy looking because of the two tone coloring. It was adjusted and placed back in the box. Then I pulled out this Burei. The technician took one look at it and said, “Wow. What a nice looking watch!” Here’s a guy who looks at fine watches and jewelry all day long, just finished servicing two Invicta watches that cost ten times more than this one, but this one was the one that made him ooh and aah. Phenomenal.Both my Burei watches have been standouts, whether at the watch shop, at work, or out on the town. This is a classy looking, inexpensive, perfectly functioning watch, more than worth a five star rating.

When the manufacturer of this portable rechargeable light offered me a sample in exchange for a review, I was excited because I have been looking for a music stand lamp for a while and still haven’t found one that works the way I want. This one, too, works to a degree for that purpose, but it’s a really outstanding light.First off, it is well built and feels really solid. I can see this being used as a task light in a workshop, or as a hobby light, reading light, or any number of applications. Once it is charged (with a USB cable) it can go anywhere. The handle swivels out to form a base, and then the light portion can be set to any angle, all the way up to a straight 180 degrees. The head itself also swivels around for a more focused beam, and can itself go 180 degrees, giving a full range of lighting coverage. It didn’t quite work on my music stand because the stand is tilted, but I used a pen to compensate for the height difference and got it to work (see photos). Probably, I will use this in the living room to serve as a reading lamp on those cloudy weekend afternoons where I might doze off, as long as I can keep the overhead lights off. This lamp has three brightness levels, so it can also be used as a sort of “mood” lamp. The matte silver finish blends with any décor.This is a really outstanding light (did I say that already?). It didn’t quite work out as my music stand lamp, but that just means I’ll get plenty of use out of it in other locations around the house, which is why I rate it at five stars.

The manufacturer of this light string offered me this product as a free sample in exchange for an honest review. This is actually the third string of this type I have tried, but this is the first multi-colored light string, and the first from this manufacturer.Because these lights are solar powered, you can put them anywhere you get sunshine without worrying about finding an electrical outlet. The solar collector panel comes with a detachable stake so you can shove it in the ground at the best angle to collect the most amount of light possible. I’m using these on the northern (front) side of my house, so I used the provided stake to set the solar collector above my gutters. Hopefully it will get enough power to keep the lights on through the dark, long winter nights. (The string is very long, providing more than enough length to do that and still decorate the bushes thoroughly.) The LEDs come in four colors, and the controller has eight different patterns for providing sparkle and movement. Of course, if you just want everything “on”, it does that too. The lights go off automatically when there is enough light from the sky and then come on again when it gets dark, so you can “set and forget” them.The makers of these lights really thought of everything, making them easy to use, fun, and very pretty. It’s hard to get excited about something so simple, but I did nonetheless, so I rate them at five stars.

This is one of the biggest and best Fodor books I have ever seen, and having been to 52 different countries, usually with a guidebook in hand, I’ve seen my share. This book is almost 1200 pages and covers all the countries and territories listed below. Oddly, several major Caribbean destinations, like Cuba, Haiti and the Bahamas are not included, presumably because there are dedicated guidebooks from Fodor for those locales. Instead, this book includes some hidden gems, like Montserrat, Saba, and St. Eustatius (the latter having been featured on a House Hunters episode on HGTV). Including these in this guidebook is just a nice touch.Although this book is in full color, there aren’t that many photos. The introduction pages give a lot of good information that is helpful in determining where to go in the Caribbean, and each destination chapter includes a photo, map, and a few “top reasons to visit”. All of that is helpful in deciding if a destination is for you, but some information on population, currency, language, and more “down to earth” facts would have been welcome. Still it’s a great start to learn about the area, especially the geography, since it probably is not too realistic to think one will visit all of those countries and territories.As a general overview of the entire Caribbean, this is a great book, but at almost two and a half pounds, it isn’t a very portable guidebook. But, for being so comprehensive, interesting, and useful for vacation planning, it’s hard to imagine a better resource,  which is why I still rate it at five stars.Countries:Antigua and Barbuda, 34 pagesBarbados, 51 pagesDominica, 30 pagesDominican Republic, 64 pagesGrenada, 38 pagesJamaica, 62 pagesSt. Kitts and Nevis, 42 pagesSt. Lucia, 44 pagesSt. Vincent and the Grenadines, 44 pagesTrinidad and Tobago, 46 pagesTerritories:Anguilla (UK), 28 pagesAruba (Netherlands), 36 pagesBonaire (Netherlands), 26 pagesBritish Virgin Islands (UK), 58 pagesCayman Islands (UK), 60 pagesCuraçao (Netherlands), 34 pagesGuadeloupe (France), 50 pagesMartinique (France), 44 pagesMontserrat (UK), 18 pagesPuerto Rico (US), 50 pagesSaba (Netherlands), 16 pagesSt. Barthélemy (France), 32 pagesSt Martin (France) / St. Maarten (Netherlands), 44 pagesSt. Eustatius (Netherlands), 15 pagesTurks and Caicos Islands (UK), 45 pagesUnited States Virgin Islands (US), 96 pages

My wife is always in need of small hand and face towels, so I got these from the manufacturer as a sample in exchange for an unbiased review primarily with her in mind. She helped with this review.When these arrived, I was a little dismayed. Of course, I was expecting a small package, but these arrived in a regular envelope that was impossibly flat. But no, it contained six towels, sure enough. We both like the pretty pastel colors, which were slightly different from the one displayed on the Amazon site (see first photo). They are incredibly soft, which makes them comfortable to use. These are, however, very small, much smaller than normal wash towels (second and third photos). We thought they would be highly absorbent, but they were just average, and after washing, they not only frayed quite a bit, but shrunk even more (last photo). (Note that the shrinkage actually made them their advertised size of just under ten inches.)Still, they are small enough to carry with you in a pocket or purse, and they still have decent utility as either a handkerchief or cleaning computer screens, glasses, or handheld devices and the like. In the end, we considered them just above average, so we ended up at four stars.

Who can’t use a solidly built, well-conceived and designed, chic modern thermos? The answer is everyone can. But if you’re going to get one, wouldn’t you want one with useful features, pretty packaging, and highly functional design? Then this “city background” vacuum bottle with infuser may be the one you want.Let me start with the infuser. If you are a tea drinker, an infuser equipped thermos bottle is the way to go. You get better more consistent flavor while keeping your tea hot. Of course, if you’re a coffee or soup person, you can just remove the infuser and you’ve got a sleek, slim, futuristic thermos bottle. Either way, the Urbane gets the job done. I love the matte black finish, the metal trim and the solid feel of this bottle. It also gets the job done of keeping your hot drinks hot, and on my workout days, my cold protein drink cold. It just works.What really puts this over the top are the quaint little quotes on the outer packaging and on the bottle itself. The oddball English is food for thought as you sip your oolong or rooibois. The thermos comes in a cardboard tube that is equally elaborate and has another quaint quote. It’s neat. I received this as a sample in exchange for an honest review, and honestly, this is a five star product.

Winter is coming and with it comes my annual battle against dry air, cracked skin, dried respiratory tracts, and the whole nine yards of torment that is winter. One of my frequent weapons in this battle is a platoon of humidifiers, so when the manufacturer offered me a sample of this nifty little decorative humidifier, I jumped at the chance to try it out.I was a little worried when the whole thing showed up in just a nylon mesh drawstring bag, but the unbreakable plastic parts were none the worse for wear. I took everything out and followed the simple instructions to fill and assemble and plug in the device. (The instructions are clear and pretty well written, too, rare for these types of devices.) Once I turned it on, I was immediately treated to a solid stream of cool mist and a repeating colored light show. The device cycles through seven colors or you can stop it and leave it on your favorite, perfect if you’re using this during a themed party or are striving for a certain mood effect. On high, the smallish tank only allows for a few hours operation before it needs to be refilled. The LED indicators are easy to decipher and with just two buttons, this humidifier is a breeze to operate. Because it is so small, it doesn’t put out a lot of mist, but the stream is consistent and steady enough to make a noticeable difference in an average sized room. The device isn’t loud, but it isn’t silent either. I think I could sleep with it on, but it probably is best used outside of bedrooms.This is one of those things where I had really low expectations that were quickly exceeded. It works well, is very attractive and quick to set up and get results. Although I got mine for free, I wouldn’t hesitate to buy another (or two, or three) if the need arose for even more beauty and humidity. So of course, I rate this at five stars.

I have a few patches of thin grass where the dirt has been exposed and started to look quite peaked. Watering didn’t help because there wasn’t enough plant life to hold it in, and grass didn’t take because it couldn’t get a grip – a vicious Catch 22. Although this is supposed to be used in the spring, I tried a few sample plots in a few of those exposed areas.I honestly want to say I notice a difference where I used EveryDrop, but to be frank, I can’t tell. Grass still hasn’t come in and the ground looks pretty much the same. Based on the generous and clear instructions, I don’t think this was quite the intended use, so I can’t say for sure this is good or not. All I can say is, Scotts makes lots of good grass and plant products, and I’m optimistic that next spring, I’ll use this to help me effectively restore my grass. In the meantime, I rate it at three stars for not doing noticeable harm, even while not doing noticeable good.

Despite living in the (relatively) sunny south, the wife and I still take a regular vitamin D supplement for good health. Lately, we had the opportunity to try a number of other Viva Labs products, all with good success and no side effects, so this D3 seemed a perfect fit to our regimen.At 5,000 i.u, this is a bit of overkill. It is more than double the dose of our current D3 supplement (shown at left in the photo, this product on the right). Still, the price is competitive and while our bodies may not need all the extra D3, this way we know we are getting more than enough. As can be seen in the photo, the pills are small, which means they are easy to take. They don’t leave any after taste and we had no noticeable side effects taking these.This is high quality vitamin that lived up to the Viva Labs reputation, making it another five star product.

My wife and I listen to music on an iHome every morning as we get ready for work. In the shower, I can’t really hear the music coming from the bedroom, so when Seedforce offered me a free sample of this waterproof Bluetooth speaker, I was excited to get wet with it.The speaker is compact and well-constructed. It comes in a drab olive with deep gray trim, looking militarily rugged. I charged it (it comes with a cord, but no plug), leafed through the manual and proceeded to pair it up with my Kindle to test out some tunes. The sound was loud enough, and clear as well, but because of its small size, I thought the music sounded quite flat and had lost much of its vibrancy. (I’m a hobbyist musician who owns a lot of high quality audio gear, so I’m pretty demanding when it comes to sound.) That is to say, this speaker doesn’t sound “bad”, per se, it just doesn’t have any bass or treble to speak of, and for me, it just isn’t to the level of performance I demand, not even in a shower.I’ll probably keep this around for using outside and in the garage when I would like a little background music while doing chores or whatnot, or in the shower when one of my good songs comes on the iHome. Because it is highly portable, waterproof, and easy to use, this is definitely an above average speaker, but the sound is just not there, which is why I end up giving it an average three star rating.

And you can get it, if you try. And if you do walk, you might want to consider doing so with this Smartfly watch and pedometer. I was offered a sample in exchange for an honest review, but I walk at least three times a week (between runs on the other days), and for walking, a GPS always seems like overkill to me. For years, I’ve used a small Omron clip on pedometer, and I’ve found it to be very accurate, so I had something to gauge this Smartfly pedometer against.Like most pedometers, this one is very simple to operate. You set your stride length (in metric or English), make a few simple adjustments to the clock, charge it up and you are ready to go. The wrist band is a flexible overlapping thing which is nice because it does away with buckles and other fasteners, but to be honest, I felt it was little clumsy. That’s okay, though, because this also comes with a lanyard so you can wear it around your neck if the wristband is too funky for you. I found that accuracy was not affected either way. Of course, because this does not use a GPS or other location finding function, it’s distance accuracy is entirely up to how accurately you can gauge your stride length. If you have been walking for years (like me), this is easy enough, but if not, you may have to do a little tinkering. Once set, however, the Smartfly is highly accurate in judging steps and distance.In this day and age, where even two year olds have smart phones and most smart phones have a plethora of available health apps at hand, the need for a pedometer like this is certainly diminishing. But, if you just want to take a stroll and not get bogged down in satellite signals, reams of data, apps and analysis, something simple like the Smartfly is a good way to go. Again, I’m not a big fan of the wristband, but everything else about this device is great, so I gave it a solid four star rating.

It’s hard for me to get too excited about something as simple as ground turmeric, but in reality, this is a very high quality food product with amazing texture, color, and of course, taste. About the time I received this free sample, I came across a recipe for Yemenite soup that requires a boatload of turmeric, along with cumin and black pepper mixed. (The resulting spice is called “hawaji”.) After pouring all three into a jar for mixing, I took a picture. The deep yellow layers are the Kazu turmeric. You can tell how rich it is, just by looking.I’ve now tried two teas and two spices from Kazu, and I’ve been impressed with every item they sent. If I had to complain about something, I don’t really like storing spice in these plastic zip pouches, but I’ve been okay by transferring small amounts to the shaker jars in my spice rack. These food products have been very impressive, so of course I continue to rate them at five stars.

The manufacturer of this product offered me a free sample in exchange for a review, and although I have a double-USB port plug already, it is big and bulky and doesn’t travel well, so I was ready to give this Blitzwolf product a try.This solid black plastic plug even looks good in a white outlet. Just plug it in and you are ready to charge two USB devices. The plug folds into the body of the device for great portability. (We used this on a recent road trip, with great success.) I did not notice any effect on charge time and I like the little blue LED which helps you find the plug in the dark (see photo). Plus, it just looks good.In this day and age, it’s hard to imagine how anyone doesn’t have at least one of these two port plugs, but if you don’t, you might as well get a five star product like this one.

The manufacturer of this product offered me a free sample in exchange for a review, and as I was just about to take a three-day road trip with the wife, the timing couldn’t have been better. Between her and me, we have two phones, three computers, and iPad, and some mobile speakers that all charge via USB. This creates a lot of headaches, but not anymore.This Blitzwolf 4-port USB car charger really came to the rescue. Let me say that again: there are four ports. That’s enough for two people, no matter how many devices you have. It was nice having everything getting charged as we rambled along, and I like the shiny look of the solid black plastic. To be honest, if the whole thing were a little shorter, it would be better for our compact car, (see photo – notice the limited space due to the hand brake) but we didn’t have any problems plugging up and unplugging things, even in the relatively tight space. Charge time seemed about the same as with other USB charging devices / connectors, and oh, this has 4 ports!This is just a nifty, neat little car charger that I’m sure I will get a lot of use out of, so I rate it at five stars.

Although it was neither the best timing nor soil conditions, I had just reworked a flowerbed in my back yard and was left with a few dirt patches that needed attention. I tried a sampling of this product and Scotts Turf Builder Grass Seed - Heat Tolerant Blue Mix, 7-Pound, and got similar results from each test patch, so I’m here to tell you in this review that both products will work well.I just followed the instructions for preparing the ground by breaking up the clods and raking everything even, then sprinkled some grass seed over the areas. I did my best to keep it watered, but a cold snap kept the seeds from germinating as quickly as the four days Scotts says. Still, after it warmed back up and rained a little, in about a week, I had two decent patches of grass. Again, since the timing isn’t great, I can’t say much about the hardiness of the rye grass or the heat tolerance of the other one, due to the seasons changing, but I’m satisfied so far.In limited testing, these both worked quite well, and I’m looking forward to a full planting next year. If my results are anything less than satisfactory, I will revisit this review and re-rate these products, but for now, they are performing like five star seeds.

Although you can connect USB 3.0 devices to this hub, because it is a USB 2.0 version, you won’t get the faster data throughput that 3.0 provides. (You can tell which is which by the connector color: blue for 3.0 and white or gray for 2.0.) Most of our devices, cords and connectors are 2.0, so that wasn’t a big concern for the wife and I. We both, however, like devices that are easy to set up, and this was just plug and play, so it excelled in that department. It is small enough to carry around, and with 7 ports, even our overloaded home office with a hard disk, scanner, printer, camera, smart phone, tablet and music speakers could be connected all at once. You think we would be happy about that, but there was one drawback.The ports are not on one side of the device (see photo) but instead, are spread evenly around it. This means you really need a little extra space around the hub and even with the space, the look is kind of messy. Compared to a hub with the ports all on one side, like the AmazonBasics 7 Port USB 2.0 Hub with 5V/4A power adapter, you can see that this hub is really not the best solution if you are only using it on top of a desk or cabinet or something.For keeping devices connected and charged while traveling, especially for two techie wannabes like my wife and I, this is a convenient hub and a good connection solution. It is still eminently usable in our home office, it just isn’t quite laid out the way we need for maximum efficiency, which is why we rate it at a high four stars.

I am a music student, jazz enthusiast, and sometimes performer and composer, as well as a well-traveled concert goer, so I have and use more than my share of high quality audio systems. Right now, my house has three Bose systems, a JBL system, a Bang and Olufson Beolit Bluetooth device, Yamaha receiver, some Sony and Logitech speakers, and enough off-brand Chinese shower speakers to fill a bathtub. I’d never heard of Devialet, but I am always on the lookout for a better sound and music experience, so I was excited to give this high-priced, designed and manufactured in France, product a try.The Phantom comes packaged very securely in a box that is in itself a work of art. You cut the seals and slide everything out, open up the inner shell, and the speaker is sitting on the floor, ready to be plugged in and put to use. (You know when a company pays attention to the packaging that the thing inside the package is going to be great.) When you plug it in, the Phantom emits an ethereal music that Devialet calls “breathing”, which means it is ready to connect to with any standard Bluetooth device. For test purposes, and because I have a lot of different music on it, I tried out the Phantom with my Kindle.I went to the settings and connected with no issue on the first try. The Phantom’s music stops and is ready to play yours. I started it with something deep and thumping, Exit Planet Dust, and holy cow! Even the cats were looking around trying to figure out where all the sound was coming from. I daresay, right out of the box, this is the most unbelievably great sounding wireless speaker I have ever laid ears on. Next, I went to jazz with some The Complete Village Vanguard Recordings, 1961 [3 CD]. The sound is deep, and so realistic, you can even hear the clinking of the glasses and the whispers of the crowd while the solos are going on. From there, I went to the Go West, which has a lush men’s choir that positively makes you stand up and shake your head. The guitars on Just Like a Pill rattled my teeth. The violins on Symphony 5 gave me goosebumps, and then, Gordon Goodwin’s Big Phat Band playing with Chick Corea on Senor Mouse (Act Your Age) just made me sit down and laugh. Nothing has ever sounded as realistic, deep, and true to the recordings as the Phantom. Sure, Bose and Beolit don’t sound bad, but Devialet seems to be able to carry more genres at a higher level, which is a big plus for someone who listens to as much, and as different types of music as I do.The device itself is very attractive, but it does look a little like a vacuum cleaner canister and it is heavy. (See photo, with the Phantom still sporting the speaker warning sticker, next to our Roomba.) You have to be careful handling it, not only because of the weight, but because the speakers on the side can be damaged if mishandled (per the aforementioned sticker). Also, my wife didn’t like the lemon yellow cord, which I suppose is a design consideration and didn’t really bother me, but she found it just ugly. I haven’t really found a good spot for the Phantom yet, and am experimenting with different tables and corners of various rooms. The app for iPhone installed in just a few seconds and gives you another degree of control over this fantastic device, with a volume control, mute, and a “nighttime” button. (The neighbors will not like the nighttime button, which bumps the sound up louder for a rock out party.) The app is just another really nice touch and customer consideration from the manufacturers.I don’t know what more I can say. This device is cool looking, as easy to set up as anything I have ever owned, and it gives a new dimension to music and entertainment in our home. The fact that it is so simple to get so much out of it, just makes it a modern marvel. Devialet is, as far as I can tell, a new company to the audio market, but the Phantom promises they will make fast and thorough inroads. If they continue to develop winning products like this one, they will be a household name like Bose and Sony faster that you can say “Magnifique!” I love my Phantom and will be using it steadily for the foreseeable future. This is the single most obvious five star product I’ve ever owned.

I received three different Ammex products at the same time, so I think the best way to review them is to do a comparison, as each glove is just different enough to be used for slightly different tasks and purposes.This product, the Ammex ILHDD Gloveworks Heavy Duty Latex, is by far the strongest of the three gloves reviewed here, as suggested by the metal grate pattern on the box. The glove has a very firm feeling and would be a good choice for DIY projects where safety is more important than fingertip sensitivity. This is latex, so latex allergy sufferers are advised to go for one of the nitrile choices.The Ammex GPNB GlovePlus Black Nitrile Glove, Latex Free, Disposable, Powder Free, Medium (Box of 100), has a much stronger feel and is nice and thick in both the palm and fingertips compared to the other two gloves. It seems like it would stand up to quite a lot of stress and stretching before it might break. The large fit perfectly on my hands and was easy to adjust when it bunched up on a few slightly wet fingers. Some sensitivity was reduced, but the sleek black look is probably going to show up in a garage or a tattoo studio before it does in any medical application.The Ammex APFN Blue Nitrile Glove, Medical Exam, Latex Free, Disposable, Powder Free, Medium (Box of 100) is designed for medical use, so it is thinner, with good touch sensitivity through the thin rubber membrane. There is no powder (all three products mentioned here are powderless) and no latex, so persons who have or may be treating those with latex allergies will appreciate this glove. The medium was a little small for my largish hands, but it was still possible to wear them without ripping them when I put them on. I wouldn’t use these for DIY projects, like painting or stripping wood, but they might work for coloring hair or even just washing dishes or whatnot. They are quite strong and durable, but they are highly disposable and once they come off, they are basically impossible to put on again.Any of these products is a solidly performing glove. If you keep some of the above comments about application and use in mind when making your purchase, you will end up with a five star glove for whatever project you have in mind.

Although this bag has a number of advantages over my workaday Takata computer bag (see photo: this bag on the left, Takata on the right), the single biggest advantage is the generous pockets on the outside. My other bag just has one pocket that is very small, and it can’t really hold all the cords, chargers, USB flash drives, phone chargers, and other accoutrements of a modern day, tech savvy businessman. This case logic bag has two pockets on the outside and two dividers on the inside, so everything fits. It also is well padded and with the extra organization and dividers inside, you could even carry a tablet without worrying about scratching the screen or otherwise damaging it.Of course, the bag also looks great, in a subtle, profession elephant gray with tan accents and handles. It is lightweight and just the right size for my laptop (an Asus Chi with Bluetooth keyboard). The charger fits easily in the aforementioned pockets, and with the divider, I can now throw in my Dell Venue 10” tablet, and even the Belkin keyboard I got for it, and I still have room for a notebook, some pens, and a few cords and USB to micro-USB converters.With this bag, I really feel like I’ve moved up in the world. I didn’t think I’d ever find another bag that fit my computer without being over-large, yet that could also hold all the things that go with the computer. But Case Logic has delivered, so I’m satisfied to deliver five stars in return.

Right on the heels of the missus and I trying out the luscious Vichy foaming face cleanser, we got to try out this dark spot evener.  For purposes of this review, I just tried a smidgeon, while my wife has used it regularly for the past few days. Here’s what we thought.It took a while to figure out how to open this, as there are no instructions on the box telling you that you have to use the cap to also pierce the tube. As a result, the tube is easily crushed and deformed (see photo). The “cream” is also very thin, possibly from too much of the famous Vichy volcanic water being added. So even with the small spout, a little squeeze and this stuff come gushing out.The cream, however, is very light and smooth and it absorbs into the skin quite quickly. The fragrance is nice but very subtle. My skin is titanium, so I didn’t have any irritation issues, but my wife, with the tissue-paper-on-needles skin (hey!) also had no irritation. This cream just makes skin soft and supple. As far as the dark spot evening feature, that can take up to eight weeks to notice, so we may have to report back, but based on the results of other Vichy products we have tried, this should be quite effective and do what it say.Although this is a little pricey, it really is another great product. Names for a city that has some world famous spas, this makes one feel pampered and relaxed, so we rate it at five stars.

Although the wife and I prefer Tiffany’s holiday series china, because they are so expensive and so formal looking, we long ago switched to Lenox’s Winter Greetings series as our holiday dinner ware. We have always loved the red ribbon pattern and as avid bird watchers, you can put a cardinal on just about anything and that will convince us to buy it.This plate is very hefty, weighing just a little over two pounds, which means it should stand up to frequent use and probably will be harder to break, whether hand washed or tossed in a dishwasher. The design is a little sparse compared to the dinnerware issued in the past (with more leaves and other birds), and the overall color is lighter. (See photos: this cardinal has red wings and a red beak, our other dinnerware has brownish wings. Everything is still a match, though.) A little scary is how this cardinal is facing forward, staring straight at you with his beady eye. He’s still a looker though. The gold trim and accented corner really add a lot to the beauty of this plate, and it comes in a sturdy, well cushioned gift box.Even if this wasn’t a perfect match for the dinnerware we already have, it good looks, stylishness, and overall beauty would still earn this plate a full five stars.

It’s been about three years since we ditched our 32” Sony CRT TV for an LG 55” HD 3D jobbie, and when we made that upgrade, I for one sincerely thought that it would be a lifetime before a better, sharper TV would come along. But now I’m back in the Sony fold and not too proud to admit, I was completely wrong.This Sony 55” Bravia ultra-thin, Ultra HD 4K TV is simply amazing, and it decidedly outclasses and outperforms our LG in many, many ways. And make no mistake, that is not a statement to take lightly, because our LG TV is, for our money, one of the best TV’s you could have bought three years ago. But the Bravia really has it all.For starters, right out of the box, the Bravia is a breeze to set up. Even the box comes with plastic locks that allow you to set the box down and raise the box up to expose the TV. Every piece of literature that Sony sent with the TV shows set up to be a two person operation, but because it is so thin and not that heavy, I succeeded in setting it up by myself twice (keep reading). Once you have the TV out of the box, you can attach the legs to put the TV on a stand, or you can do the included wall mount (which probably really is a two person operation). After attaching the legs, I realized the TV was actually wider than the stand we had prepared and just as I resolved to have to buy a new stand, I came across the page in the manual that shows how to attach the legs towards the middle to fit it on our smaller stand. So I took everything down, reassembled with the new configuration, then had the TV up and ready to go.The first time you turn it on, you have to update the software and firmware, and if you are going on a home network (we did wireless), you’ll have to configure that. The firmware download said it would take 30 minutes but took only about 15 over our cable connection, and once that was in, I was connected to Netflix, Amazon Prime, and everything else through wireless, and regular TV through the onboard tuner. Remaining set up was less than two minutes: just ran an HDMI cable from a Sony Blu-ray player to the TV and an HDMI ARC cable to the Bose sound system. Total set up and configuration time was under an hour and there were no hiccups.Turning on the disc player and TV turns on the sound system, and boom! We were shaking the house! The picture is stunningly bright, with remarkable depth. Watching the Sony ads on the disc we put in (Avatar, Die Hard, etc.) and sitting only ten feet away, I honestly started to get dizzy during some of the shots. Even something like black-line animation (Archer) showed up crazily sharp and distinct. Already the wife is suggesting we move the Sony out of her study (where we put it to watch her art films) and into the living room, where we watch the majority of our movies together. (We’ll probably do that.)In short, this TV is just amazing. The sharpness, deep blacks, color range, motion, just everything is gorgeous. The ease of set up is a huge selling point for me, and I think it will make a lot of tech-fearing home owners feel more confident and happy. Other than the brief letdown of fiddling with the legs, there isn’t a single drawback to this TV. It’s just unbelievably good, and way better than two other TVs that I rated at five stars, so of course, that’s what this one gets.

Shortly before I stopped lessons with my piano instructor, he threw out the name Lee Evans as an approachable jazz pianist whose style was eminently learnable. So I put a bunch of Lee Evans music books on my wishlist, and for whatever reason (there’s little logic in my approach to learning the piano, unfortunately), I bought this one. The cover says it is “Late beginner” level, so I thought that would be hard enough to teach me some new things, but easy enough I could learn without an instructor. My assessment turned out to be exactly correct.Two of my biggest weaknesses before starting work on this book were, first, rhythm, especially keeping time, syncopation, and observing note lengths and rest locations and length. (As a former organist, I tend to not take advantage of the percussive capabilities of the piano.) My second weakness was a lack of movement and depth in my left hand. Although the songs in this book are very basic, using nothing shorter than a quarter note, the pieces are cleverly built to work all aspects of a jazz performance. So, immediately, I was challenged to sustain notes across bars, sustain notes in one hand while the other moved, and presented with assorted rhythms and passages that (of course) I was not familiar with and was challenged to construct without a teacher to show me the way. It took a lot of practice with the metronome, taking everything at a slow pace to get the timing and notes down, but once I had done that, the songs were sounding very musical and, magically, jazzy.Speaking of the metronome, because all the notes in the pieces are a quarter note or longer, the pieces are meant to be played at fairly brisk clips. Again, this is a huge advantage of this book, because the student can always set the metronome to four beats a measure, slow it down to an approachable level, then play the pieces through, without having to worry if they’re keeping good time or not. (Either the quarter note is on the correct beat, or it isn’t.) For me, this is huge, because once I have the notes down, it’s just a question of kicking up the metronome until the piece is being played at the specified meter. And once you reach the specified meter, the flavors of the pieces, flamenco, boogie-woogie, blues, whatever, start to come through. They bring the whole world of jazz to your piano. Turn the metronome off and start to swing them, and your ears will be amazed.Really, I couldn’t be happier with this book. Some will probably find it a little too simple, but I still think working through the pieces will help 90% (or more) of pianists understand and play jazz tunes better, especially if they are making the transition from other piano styles. I love this five star book, and I can’t wait to work through the last few pieces and pick up the second book in the series. Lee Evans has made me a happier, and better, jazz piano player.

For the longest time, I wondered what, if anything, these sort of clip-on lenses could do for the average, dinky, low-res smart phone camera. But as in-phone cameras rapidly improved and become more and more useful – indispensable really – and as their quality approached higher and higher levels, I started to think an enhanced lens set might not be a bad idea. So when the manufacturers of this lens set offered me a sample in exchange for a review, I was ready to give them a try.And right out of the box, the Go Go Robot lens impressed, as it uses the previously mentioned clip-on feature to great effectiveness, allowing you to use the phone camera and lens without removing your phone from its case. Of course, it becomes a little trickier locating the lens, especially with bulkier cases, but it’s still much easier than removing the phone from the case. The two lenses included with this set are a fish eye and a macro lens. To be perfectly honest, while I can see that they alter the image or the photo the camera takes, they really are small lenses, so the alteration is quite subtle and the image is severely reduced. With certain subjects and lighting conditions, it can even be hard to notice any difference at all. But for specific objects under certain lighting conditions, the effect can be more dramatic. (Some samples appear below. L-R, no lens, fisheye, macro, all taken standing in the exact same spot.) The lenses are well constructed of what looks and feels like aluminum, and they screw onto the clip quite easily and firmly. A small cloth carrying pouch is included, and each lens has its own protective cap, so you can just toss them in the pouch, put the thing in your pocket or purse, and away you go. To use, you just pull out the clip, screw on the lens of choice, and clip to the camera, ready to shoot in just a few seconds.As an amateur photographer, I have to admit that I’m still quite reluctant to replace my high quality cameras and lenses with a smart phone and a couple of clip-on lenses. But I don’t drive around with and carry my camera everywhere I go, and I certainly don’t carry my advanced lenses unless I know I’m going to have something to shoot. (They’re heavy and expensive, you know.) Recognizing, however, that the phone is usually handy and that these lenses vastly increase the phone camera’s utility and “artsiness”, I’m probably going to find it not too hard to get in the habit of keeping these around and getting a fair amount of use out of them. For that reason alone, even if they didn’t have all the fun and function I mention in this review, I’d rate them as a five star product.

I am a regular tea drinker, but as I’ve gotten older, I’ve found caffeine affects me a little more than it used to, so I’ve been swinging my way over to herbal tea of late. Kazu offered me a free sample of this ginger tea in exchange for a review, so I decided to give it a try.Although I usually drink chamomile when I don’t drink black tea, I use ginger (raw root and dried powder) in a lot of Asian dishes that I cook, so I felt like the flavor of ginger tea wouldn’t be too “alien” for me. And while I found it soothing enough, I will probably only drink it occasionally. My wife, however, absolutely loves this tea and has been enjoying a cup four or five times a week. She’ll drink it in the morning, afternoon, or evening, just whenever, as it is a great anytime tea. We both felt it was pretty soothing tea, and of course, no caffeine jitters.We both really like this tea. I was leaning toward a four star rating, but my wife said she wouldn’t appreciate it if I gave her new favorite tea less than five stars, so, there you go.

The makers of this product offered me a sample in exchange for a review. I do a lot of baking and Asian cooking, so naturally, I use my share of cinnamon, so I agreed to give this product a try.In the bag, this is as fine a powdered cinnamon as I have ever seen. Compared to some of my Vietnam and India cinnamon, as well as the most common Sri Lankan (like this one and the McCormick I have on hand) this is a slightly lighter brown, almost tan, than I am used to. After opening the bag, the room smelled like a shopping mall food court with the sweet, tangy cinnamon smell. Taste wise, I want to say this is slightly more intense in flavor than my usual cinnamon, but that may be my olfactory senses telling my brain and tongue more than they really know on their own. Overall consistency is what I expect from a fine quality cinnamon, and in all the taste tests so far (lamb kebabs and cinnamon toast), flavor has been excellent.I would have preferred if this came in some kind of bottle or container, as it is a little hard to handle in a bag and transferring the contents to a spice jar is a meticulous, time-consuming, and still messy task. But that mess is a small price to pay for a lot of delicious cinnamon, so I still rate this product at five stars.

This is my fourth or fifth food thermometer, and I received this one as a sample from the manufacturer, but it is by far the best one I have owned. I say that not because I got it for free, but because it truly has some features that set it above the others.For starters, the probe swivels on the handle so you can set it at an angle to insert it into just about any cooking vessel, or poke it into meat or another dish to get maximum exposure to wherever you want to check the temperature. It also turns on automatically when you swivel the probe out, and shuts off when you close it. You can set the device to read either Fahrenheit or Celsius, which is convenient for me because I have a number of Japanese recipes that specify degrees in Celsius instead of the more common Fahrenheit. It also features a button that holds the temperature before you extract it, so you can take the temperature of a dish while it is still in the oven or on the range and pull it out to read the temperature, thereby not singing your eyebrows. Of course, the display on this one is actually quite large, so I haven’t really had to take advantage of the hold button all that much. For storage, the probe folds against the handle with the point protected, so it is safe to store in drawer with other implements. And, it takes a regular AA battery, which is a godsend compared to smaller food thermometers that use combinations of tiny watch “coin” batteries.Seriously, this is a great food thermometer and as I said, is the best of four I have owned so far (including two that broke). That makes it a five star performer in my kitchen.

Although I received this watch for free from the manufacturer, I have to say that this is the kind of watch I would buy for myself anyway. I like that it is a simple, easy to see design, and I also like the leather band, which is sturdy but comfortable. The elements of the watch, such as the silver-finished hour markers sit on a raised ring on the watch face, with the minute markers set outside the ring but also slightly raised. It gives the watch face a three dimensional quality resulting in a very distinctive look. The day can be set to either English or French, but it clicks through two settings so that it always stays in the language of choice. After two weeks of use, time appears to still be very accurate.The watch came with a fashionable box which includes a pouch for gift giving or toting around. The instructions are clear and the watch is as easy to set as any other, with a two level pin for choosing to adjust the day and date (clockwise and counterclockwise) and time. There’s really nothing that I don’t like about this watch. It looks good, goes with my wardrobe, is simple and functional enough to wear to the factory where I work, but elegant enough for a night on the town. And, as I said, even though I didn’t pay for this, it is priced reasonably for what you get. This is a genuine five star watch.

As a musician soon to be starting on earning a music degree, I spend a lot of time, money and energy looking for good sound reproduction for both commercial and personal recordings. Depending on what I’m listening to, and where I’m listening to it, I can need anything from a heavy duty Bose system, to just something that gives me an idea of what I might hear when I play something a certain way. With that in mind, I decided to give this HP system a try.The system is quite small and sets up in just a few minutes. The connectors are of average quality, and the speaker cords are basic, vinyl shielded, nothing special black cord. The right speaker is the power unit and confusingly, the cord from the right speaker to the subwoofer is about five feet long, but the cord to the left speaker is right around four feet. That means you can set up the subwoofer a little farther front or back of the speakers, but if you want to put the three speakers equidistant from each other, your set up can only be about four feet wide.Sound wise, I’m not particularly impressed. The subwoofer helps the system achieve a fairly deep bass, but heavy electronica bass sounds fade pretty quickly, even with everything turned up. On full blast, the system is not loud at all, so this is probably good for basic computer and tablet sound in an apartment or condominium.
