The high ends are not very crisp, but they aren’t tinny and crackly either. I listened to classical, jazz, electronica, and 80’s pop, and nothing stood out. All sounded decent and a little flat, but there was enough richness to hear everything that was going on.For compactness, portability, ease of set up, and price, this system is very good, but serious audiophiles will likely be disappointed. It’s just run of the mill audio gear for improvement over a “back of the device” speaker, which is why I rate it at three stars.

I started taking this just a few weeks after I got new eyeglasses. As I’ve aged, I’ve noticed that when my prescription changes, it takes a good while for my eyes to get used to the new lenses. Also, because I work in a factory, I have not only distance glasses and reading glasses, but also safety lens bifocals. I’d been having headaches and severe enough eye fatigue that I basically had to give up computer work after three in the afternoon (don’t tell my boss). Then, I started taking this astaxanthin. And to be perfectly honest, I took this thinking it would help with run recovery due to its anti-inflammatory properties, and I knew nothing at all about its effect on eye health.You know what? My eyes started doing noticeably better. I’ve been able to keep up with work throughout the day, still use a computer for personal things in the evening, and even play the piano for an hour or so, learning – and reading – new music. I hardly even noticed how well my eyes were doing. Then, we had to do an audit of third shift production and I put in a thirteen hour day starting at 4 in the morning (instead of my usual 7:30). Again, no eye problems through the entire day. Is it because of the astaxanthin? I honestly couldn’t say, but I don’t think I’ve all of a sudden gotten used to all my new glasses, and I haven’t been doing anything else differently or changed any of my other supplements. I’m compelled to conclude that astaxanthin is really having a noticeable positive effect on my body, particularly my eyesight.I’ve tried a number of Jarrow products in the past, and this is not the first time I’ve had such dramatic results. And when I have had good results with no negative side effects or digestive issues or whatever, I’ve always given their products five stars. This is definitely another one in that category.

I’ve been a fan of Black and Decker corded yard tools since the day I bought my first house sixteen years ago. They are always highly functional, easy to use, and they get the job done. Although I was already quite happy with my Poulan electric chainsaw, it is getting a little old, so I was happy to try this B&D model.I have to say that out of the box, I wasn’t too happy that this thing had to be put together. That said, it is a tool-free operation and it only took a few minutes to get the bar and chain inserted, sprocketed, and ready to go. The chainsaw itself is what I would consider average power, but electric chainsaws never quite have the power that a gasoline model would, anyway. For my purposes of removing tree limbs, trimming crepe myrtles, and dispensing with a neighbor’s willow tree that fell in my yard, this chainsaw was more than powerful enough. I suppose that with the tools free feature, one might also not complain about being able to remove the bar and chain for easy storage, although this makes for a little messy operation, due to the auto oiling feature that keeps the tool lubricated. (This is a positive, by the way.) And anyone who has ever used a chainsaw for an hour or two will tell you that eventually the chain will need adjusting, and being able to do this without looking for a little wrench or special saw tool is probably this chainsaw’s greatest advantage.All in all, I’m pretty pleased with the chainsaw. It is simple, user friendly, and as I’ve said, gets the job done. It didn’t revolutionize my life in anyway, but it still makes me quite happy, which is why I’m also quite happy to give it five stars.

I’ve been a regular jerky eater for as long as I can remember. My homemade jerky is by far the best (pinot noir and black pepper marinated flank steak jerky, anyone?), but I don’t always have the time and energy to make it. Walmart beef jerky was my favorite for a long time, but they recently changed the recipe (or something) and it didn’t excite me anymore. I’d had Jack Link's before and it didn’t leave a strong impression, but I was ready to give it another shot.This is a fairly straightforward, tasty jerky. Not too hot, not too sweet, it has the right amount of salt and bitterness with just a hint of heat and umami, with a slightly honey-like finish. The texture is good, though some of the thinner pieces are a little chewier than others, but those are sometimes the ones I crave the most. For a quick snack that satisfies and is healthy for an older runner like me, it’s hard to beat any kind of jerky, but Jack Link's is one of the tastier ones and definitely worth going for. That is to say, this is a delicious, protein rich, five star snack for anytime a hunger pang hits.

Our normal brand for cutting products is usually Fiskars, even for things like plant pruning. But the wife has been a fan of Martha Stewart for years, especially for craft products, so we decided to try out this paper cutter.At first glance, it seems kind of light and cheap, as the plastic does not seem especially robust, but once we began using it, that image was quickly dispelled. This is a very sturdy cutter that had no problem dispensing with thin paper, thick paper, thin cardboard, and large envelopes (as a test). The handle is very firm feeling and has a locking mechanism for safety that works very simply and sturdily. The handle part of the cutter can be removed for easy storage, and the cutter also comes with another mechanism that presses down on the hold bar to secure the paper as it is being cut. The light blue lines on the traditional square grid make it easy to cut precise triangles and other shapes (see  photo). With a large deck, the grid, the triangle lines, and the secure handle, it is really easy to use. It’s just a first class cutter, top to bottom.I know my wife is going to get a lot of use out of this cutter, and although I’m not a particularly “crafty” type of guy, this thing is good enough to make me want to be creative. That alone makes it a five star product.

Of course, as pretty as this ring is, it doesn’t really go with my wardrobe, so after making some initial observations, I handed it over to my wife for testing. (Okay, “wearing”.) Here are our joint comments and assessment:Unlike some other jewelry from Amazon, this ring is a decent enough size that it really has some presence when worn. The cubic zirconia is cut quite intricately, and it is brilliant enough that it almost looks like it is being lit from within by an LED light or something. If you look at it closely, or catch the angle that makes it look like a light, you can tell this isn’t an exquisite or expensive rock, but from most distances and angles, the overall presentation is gorgeous. This is probably thanks to the elegant and classy design of the setting and ring itself. The size turned out to be right on (see photo on the ring sizing cone), and it comes with a nice gift box. For the price range, this is a high quality, five star piece of jewelry.Finally, my wife is glad my fingers are as big as they are, because I would borrow it if I could.

I’ve been a Fruit of the Loom guy for as long as I can remember, so I thought my wife would like to have and appreciate this women’s underwear. Turns out I was right. Here’s what she thought about this five star product:You can select the size but not the color, and the colors we received were completely different from the picture on Amazon. (See photo.) I did like the vibrant color with accent trim. The sizing, however, is a little confusing. I normally wear an 8 or 10 for most brands, but these came in 6 and were just a touch bigger than necessary. Determine your optimum size by the numbers of “bottoms” and you’ll want to go one size down. Note also the sizing is important because these do not shrink in the wash.These panties were very comfortable, possibly due to the “breathable” feature. They are stylish enough and the tag free feature is a nice touch, with the logo and size printed on the back. I really like just about everything about this underwear.

We only recently for the first time tried Solid Gold Indigo Moon Chicken Holistic Dry Cat Food, Chicken & Egg, Grain & Gluten Free, Cats & Kittens of All Life Stages, All Sizes, 12lb Bag, and although it wasn’t an unqualified winner, our two adult Persians, after some deliberation, took to eating it pretty regularly. And although neither of our cats has a weight problem, neither do they have any other health issues, so even though this has reduced protein content, we decided to give it a try. The cats’ reaction to this was almost exactly the same as with the first product: they showed some hesitation, then began picking at it, and after leaving it out all night, it was gone.Like its sister product, this is a pretty healthful cat food, so we are comfortable feeding this to our two cats. Our cats are also quite finicky, so adding variety to their regular diet really helps. As I said, Solid Gold was not on our radar before, despite the psychedelic holograph-laden packaging which probably shows up on the local airport’s radar, but now that we’ve had success with two very different products from the same maker, we’ll definitely keep an eye out for Solid Gold, as we now consider this five star product to be an important part of our cats normal feeding regimen.

Sure, you can buy colored napkins, check out a YouTube video or online instructions and make your own party decorations just like these, probably for less money, but why would you? These solid but soft napkins come twelve in a package, pre-folded into an elegant origami half-moon shape. Just pull them out of the box, give them a twirl, set them down, and you’re ready to party. The look is fantastic, and I’m all about ease when it comes to this type of decoration. Available in multiple colors for all sorts of occasions and themes, these orange ones arrived just in time for Halloween, making great accents for an otherwise black and purple table.Some people might feel these are a little pricey, and I would too if the napkins weren’t such high quality, but these are thick, soft and absorbent, and they definitely have a sophisticated look. I’d be inclined to deduct a star from the rating for the lower cost performance, but I really do feel these are worth the price, so I’m sticking to a five star rating.

As a regular gardener and a sometimes DIY’er, I always have use for something as handy as these stakes. They’re ideal for supporting plants, with their generous 3’ length allowing you to secure them in the ground and still leave a good portion for tying off branches, chicken wire and whatnot. I also used mine to lay out the edging of a flowerbed. I plan to cut them down and use them for supports and spacers for a wooden pathway that I’m running through the middle of the flower bed, too.They come in a box that keeps them organized and clean until you are ready to use them, and it makes a great space saver, too, as these can be unwieldy when you have a handful of them out and loose. Besides all the practical uses, you can paint and decorate them for sundry art projects and outdoor décor, and with Halloween around the corner, I’m thinking a skeleton with one of these through the rib cage might be just the right level of scary and artsy to get the neighborhood kids talking.It’s a simple product, but it is manufactured to a high standard of very sturdy wood. I’m sure my projects and imagination have only scratched the surface of their functionality and utility, making them a five star product by any measure.

The manufacturer of this dog whistle offered me a free sample, and I had an idea that this would be useful on my morning walks to keep the neighborhood dogs at bay. So when it arrived and I learned it was mainly intended as a dog training aid, I was a little unsure it would suit my purposes. Nonetheless, I took it with me on a few morning walks and runs, and tried it out.The problem I have in my neighborhood is that we have a number of covenants and restrictions on barriers and home decoration. This means that more than a few of my neighbors utilize the so called “invisible fence” to keep their dogs reined in. This is fine for them and their dogs, as they both know where the animal is going to stop his mad charge toward the sidewalk. I, however, am unsure if I’m about to have my ankle choked by a terrier, or if I need to go ahead and start running (or running faster) to save life and limb. So, I decided to try this whistle as a general deterrent or “confusion inducer”.As near as I can tell, it works pretty good. It doesn’t really make the dogs stop, but I did get at least two animals to stop barking and one that kept barking but looked like he wanted to play rather than attack. I think this is better applied in the training of a dog as described in the sketchy instructions (no doubt translated from Chinese). The lanyard/strap is soft, strong, and has a generous width, and the whistle itself seems cast from stainless steel or some other corrosion resistant metal. That is to say, everything looks and feels very high quality. Everything comes in a resealable plastic pouch, which is handy and hygienic. All in all, it seems effective and is decidedly well made, so I felt comfortable giving it a full five star rating.

Our two pure bred, adult, Persian cats are never easy to please. They also tend to get in a finicky food rut pretty frequently, from which they are not easily removed. This was a brand that not only had we never tried before, we’d never heard of, so we opted to start them out by mixing this with their favorite (usual) snack one evening. They showed some typical hesitation, but picked at it for a minute or two. We left it out all night and were pleased to see it had all been eaten by the next morning, warranting a try without mixing. Long story short: They ate it without issue after the initial test.Although we’d love to credit the high (42%) protein and grain and gluten free ingredients chock full of vitamins and omega-3 and -6 fatty acids, probably more than anything else, the small piece size and good texture attracted them and convinced them to stick around and eat it. We like that it comes in a convenient package and is priced competitively, and it also has a number of other flavors, which we plan to try out. For just being good enough to get consumed, but not particularly aggressively “liked”, we’d normally call it a five star cat food, but with the psychedelic, holograph laden package and multiple flavor options, we decided this is actually worthy of a full five stars.

I’m a pretty regular drinker and I indulge in a cocktail or two most every weekend. I’ve tried varied and assorted mixers in the past, but I often just stick with homemade. Still this product promised a good cocktail with not much fuss, so I gave it a try.The size is just right to make one drink. For this bloody Mary mix, you just add one ounce of vodka and you’ve got a tasty, smooth drink. This mix is spicy enough that you won’t need to add any hot sauce, unless you really want to burn it up with your drink. The consistency was perfect and that taste was really good. Like the copy and the label says, you can leave the alcohol out for a virgin drink, and the taste really is good enough to enjoy as is. Honestly, I was really surprised at how good this is.These single serving cans are easy to use and full of great taste, and if you have them on hand, you’re always just a shot of booze away from a tasty drink. I can’t think of a single bad thing to say about this product, so of course I rate it at five stars.

Before taking this product, I did review the “vegetarian” product ingredients beforehand, and suspected that what I was looking at was a bloated belly of fiber that would make me less hungry. What I was not expecting was a high (and low) colonic of such intensity that I thought about calling my doctor and seeing if he wanted to go ahead and schedule a colonoscopy to coincide with me taking this product. Here’s the poop:After taking the first dose of morning pills, I drove to work. Shortly after sitting at my desk, I felt a rumbling. I spent the next thirty minutes not working (in the rest room). When I finally felt well enough to return to my desk, I was dizzy and vaguely nauseous. That was when I decided to check out some of the other reviews of this product on  Amazon. (Yes, boss, sorry. Still not working.)As a rule, I do not read other product reviews before at least composing, if not posting my own, but I wanted to know if my distress was a case of bad luck and happenstance, or if I had jumped into something I shouldn’t have. By now, you know the answer. In fact, I’ve never seen a product on Amazon with so many terrible reviews. I almost didn’t want to pile on.Then (speaking of piling on) I had to run to the rest room again. This is a horrible product that I wish I’d never put in my body. I stopped the “regimen” after one dose, thankfully living to tell the tale.If you have an iron stomach and need to drop a few pounds to fit in a tuxedo at a friend’s wedding or want to impress your former classmates at a reunion or something, this will definitely help you drop a few pounds in a few days. Just make sure you charge your phone and laptop before your self-imposed exile to the toilet. Otherwise, I suggest reasonable diet and exercise over a few weeks as opposed to this three day, diarrhea inducing, one star digestive torture.

If you have an air conditioner that uses a remote control for normal operation, this Tado unit can take it over for you. Then, using the phone app, you have enhanced control of your air conditioner, including programmability and operation from outside the home. The app installs quite easily and the operation of the unit is straightforward. You will have to experiment a little bit to figure out all the operations, because the included manual is sketchy and not very thorough. Also, the icons on the unit itself are quite wonky and unintuitive, so you’ll have to keep the manual handy until you figure out what everything means.To be honest, though, as good as this product is, I’m just not sure how useful it is. I think a programmable thermostat is more than adequate for HVAC operation, and it provides other advantages like a clean, unobtrusive install and sleeker look. If you have a standalone AC unit and no thermostat, then this is probably a great thing to have and certainly would rate five stars. Nonetheless, as good a product as it is, I have to question its utility, which is why I rate it at four stars.

The makers of this package of silicon freezing devices offered me a sample in exchange for an honest review, and while it has been years since I ate, much less made, a popsicle, I agreed to try out their products, mainly for the round ice cube making tray. I enjoy a cocktail or two now and again, and I’m always looking for ways to make my concoctions a little more interesting. So I gave it a whirl.These ice molds are very well constructed. I like the swirl pattern of the popsicle molds, but I’m glad they made the round ice cube tray look a little more subdued and “adult”. Using these products is about as straightforward as it gets: fill them up, freeze them, pop out your ice cube or frozen snack. The cone shaped popsicles were fine, but the round ice cubes are what I really want to focus on. As you can imagine, this tray is just a little tricky to use. I requires patience to fill and the final shape is highly unlikely to be completely round, due to the fill hole and seepage at the seams. But, when you pour your libation over the cubes in the glass, the protrusions melt off quite quickly, leaving you with nice, partially clear, round cubes. (I’m told distilled or filtered water would result in clearer cubes, but that makes filling the tray a little harder, due to the small fill holes.) Because the cubes  are larger than average, they also keep your drink cold for a while without diluting it too much. I have to confess to have experienced beginner’s luck, as my first batch of round cubes was the best, but since then, I’ve had difficulty duplicating the feat. Still, just getting pretty close still makes for an attractive way to keep your drink cold. The mold set also comes with a collapsible funnel, an interesting little contrivance that isn’t completely useless, but not something I have a lot of use for anyway.All in all these are very nice molds. I’m not sure if they could be designed better to be a little easier to use, but they are attractive, fun, and I will get a lot of use out of the round ice cube mold, so I think these are definitely worth five stars.

I guess marketers have figured out that by putting a small ‘i’ in front of the name of an electronic device, they can make everybody think it is something special and sell a bunch more of them. Although we have a scale that is somewhat sporadic and were looking to replace it, this thing turned out to be not much better, despite a huge price gap. The iPhone app is a complete non-starter, and “sorta, kinda” worked, but not really.What I’m sure its manufacturer considers its biggest advantage is absolutely this scale’s biggest disadvantage, and that is the setup through the craplet. You have to scan QR codes, connect to wi-fi, get everything talking to each other, then you have to download another, updated app (which the manufacturer apologizes for the inconvenience). So I followed the instructions and set up myself, weighed myself, stored my data, voila. Great. Now let’s try the missus. Well, you have to set up a completely different user account, which will cause you to lose the first setup, which means rescanning QR codes, and doing everything from scratch. Try to add yourself back in: oops! That doesn’t work. Try to delete an account to eliminate the confusion: oops! That’s not possible. Check the manual for how it might be possible: oops! That’s not in the manual.In fact, there are no instructions for using the app with the scale ANYWHERE. As in NOWHERE! Download data, connect other devices, add users, delete users, calibrate the scale (which it needs), none of the information is available anywhere, even if you read eight languages fluently. Pitiful.Almost forgot: There is a way to get the scale to tell you the temperature and humidity of the room, and that is carefully explained. (Hooray!) How that will help you lose weight or track your health is anybody’s guess.My wife hates our other scale because it sometimes gets off by a pound or two after moving it or getting a few drops of water on it, but it was only about $40 and it eventually rights itself. This one, I can’t even get it to tell me if it is sure who it is weighing. I congratulate iHealth on designing a superlative scale. When they actually implement it with usable hardware and intelligent software, I hope they will give me another one to try. This one star piece of modern detritus is going into the back of the closet until further notice.

The missus and I both tried this hair product, me when I was getting out of control between relatively short-hair haircuts, and she as a normal everyday hair care product for her shoulder length hair. The label indicates two uses. One is for adding “youth” and shine to damp hair, which you style as usual after applying to wet, washed hair. The other is as a touch up to dry hair that is losing its vitality as the day wears on.For the damp hair application, it seemed to work pretty well. The product smells nice and hair was easy to style and (I’ll say) fresh looking. I think one would definitely want to use some active drying and styling with this, as I believe there is some danger of hair looking greasy and flat if you don’t. I say that because as a touch up to dry hair, that’s really what it does. Sure, it brings the frizz of the stray curl under control, but it does it by making hair wet-looking and heavy. Users will have to experiment with which level of each application they are comfortable with.This is an above average post-shampoo styling aid, and a more-or-less average touch up cream, but it smells good and is priced very economically. For all that, we think four stars is a fair rating for this Tresemme hair lotion.

L’Oreal Paris is one of my wife’s favorite brand for inexpensive but effective skin and hair care products. She’s been quite satisfied with their Youth Code product line, but even with summer ending and the UV index is getting lower, she said she wanted to try this product because protecting her skin from harmful UV rays is one of her biggest concerns for her aging and sensitive skin. Here’s what she thought:When I saw this RevitaLift Triple Power™ Day Lotion Moisturizer SPF 20, although an SPF 20 factor seems to be a little low, I saw some information on WebMD that said an SPF 15 product blocks about 94% of UVB rays, while an SPF 30 product blocks 97% of UVB rays. After that, the numbers take on less and less meaning and it just gets silly, but I felt SPF 20 was a sufficiently high protection factor. This moisturizer has nice fragrance, and is very light in texture. It was not greasy at all and it didn’t cause me any distress, discomfort, or any breakouts on my skin. Best of all, I can tell the result that the manufacture promises, which is vital and younger looking, healthy skin. After using this for more than three weeks, my skin looks brighter and smoother.I had no doubt this product would work well, and I was proven right. For being an easy to use, effective product that delivers on its promises, I rate it at five stars.

This product is mainly for curly hair, but my wife and I both tried it on our relatively straight hair. My hair is too short for me to adequately evaluate, other than to say, this works fine for holding short hair in place, as long as you don’t mind the sticky, sort of wet feel. My wife, however, does curl and add wave to her hair, but she too said that this felt very sticky and made her hair heavier. It held in place, but the natural look was lost. Having recently tried Dove Intense Restoration Mask, Quench Absolute 6.7 oz, she thought this wasn’t as good as the Dove product, which even though it isn't a styling gel, still left her hair easier to control.We both did like the fragrance of this product, which was fresh and not too strong. The professional appearance of the sleek black can was also appealing, but in the end, we could only rate this at three and a half stars, as it was just too gooey to make a better grade.

Every time I write cat food reviews, I explain how our two Persian cats are really finicky eaters. To be more specific, golden chinchilla will eat human food at the tables (everything from roast chicken, turkey, sashimi tuna and salmon, to roast beef and even goat cheese) is not nearly as finicky as the Himalayan, who never eats human food and sticks only to high quality cat food. One thing the two cats have in common is they hate to be served the same food (flavor) every day. We try to accommodate their demands, and since we have had some success with other Nutro products in the past, we had pretty high hopes for the multi-pack sliced version of this high protein, grain free, real meat product, three important factors we look for in high quality cat food.The verdict on this is above average. The first flavor (Sliced Chicken & Tuna Entree) was a hit with both cats. The golden chinchilla even ate the food on the floor, which was scattered while eating. We were quite surprised to see him doing this, because he never does this with other wet food. The next day, when they were served the second flavor (Sliced Turkey Entree), the chinchilla ate some without passion, but the Himalayan was immediately turned off. He strode away and defiantly sat twenty feet away from the food bowls until after dinner snacks were brought out. On the third day, the third flavor (Sliced Salmon Entree) was much the same story as the second day, with the Himalayan begging (demanding) to be served something else, walking around and meowing loudly. On the fourth day, we went back to the first flavor both cats ate and both of them ate in the same fashion as if they were programed that way.Besides one cat’s positive acceptance of this food, another advantage is that with three different flavors, it makes it easy for us to rotate these in with some of their other favorites, such as Fancy Feast Appetizers (now called Purely Fancy Feast) and Simply Nourish.The smaller 3-oz size of the can is good, as neither of our cats are big eaters. This allows us to keep too much from going to waste. Because each can has the similar design and color and the text on the side is quite small, however, it’s rather hard to tell the difference between each flavor and actually, all three flavors look the same. (See the photos.) If they were packed in plastic containers like Purely Fancy Feast, with a design on the top instead of side, that would make our life much easier. It would be nice if Nutro sold this sliced version of product in the “perfect portions” package like they do with the soft loaf version of their product. Still, all said and done, this is more of a pleaser than a failure, so we rate it at four stars.

Oddly enough, at about the time I received this wireless TRENDnet adapter, I also received a TRENDnet wireless PTZ camera. Unfortunately, the camera was so hard to install that the installation ended after two frustrated hours with not even being able to get the camera working. As hard as the camera setup was, that’s how easy this upgrader/adapter setup was.To install this upgrader, all you do is, plug it into a power outlet, then plug it into a port on your existing router. Instantaneously, you have a wireless AC network where before you only had whatever your other router had. I used ours on a Mac Airport router and I had no issues. It just worked easily and intuitively. I can’t tell what kind of throughput and bandwidth it provides, but I imagine it is only limited by the specifications of the host router. It’s nice, too, that the device is very small and unobtrusive. It can easily be hid somewhere, or just stacked on top of the router being upgraded.Whatever, this provides a great solution for a better, stronger network with AC level capabilities for people who already have a working wireless network that they don’t want to dismantle just to upgrade. Get this simple to install, highly effective five star upgrader, and take the rest of the afternoon to relax and rest.

So, it will soon be 2016 and you own a smart phone, a tablet, and a netbook, all with calendars, all synched, and all with more notifications and features than you even know how to use. You couldn’t possibly need a spiral bound daily planner made of paper, could you? Well, maybe. Maybe you are of a certain age, like me, that the paper format is just more familiar and “comfortable”. Or maybe you want something you can keep open and out on your desk for quick easy reference, without running down the battery of a device or having to find it and boot up an app to get to. Or maybe you’re like me and you have an alternative use for this planner. Whatever the case, if you are going to get a bound daily planner of paper, you’re going to want one that is nice looking, functional, easy to use, with generous space for notes, appointments and everything that threatens to clutter your busy life. That is why you need to consider something like this At-A-Glance weekly planner.Right off the bat, probably the single best feature is the tabbed pages for each individual month. This allows quick and ready access, even though the planner has a generous number of pages. I like that it includes a monthly spread for a general overview, but when you get to the individual week pages, you have a full quarter page for each day to write down a either a chock full schedule, or plenty of notes and reminders. That also leaves another quarter of a page for general notes not specific to any day. I happen to be planning (sorry) to use hits as a piano practice notebook, as I am now working on my music without an instructor, so I need to be able to guide myself and my musical work. This allows me to plan specific things on specific days, and then I can make adjustments as I go, or just note what I did or did not work on. Then I compare day to day and week to week results and make even further adjustments. It’s intuitive and easy. I’ve already begun filling in my regimen for next year, as I loosely test various programs this year. It may not singlehandedly make me a virtuoso pianist, but at least it gives my practice routine some direction and structure.Going back to the more traditional use of a scheduler-slash-planner, this has a holiday calendar through 2019, which is handy, plus a time zone chart and a few extra pages for notes. The light gray cover has the look of heavy paper, but seems to be some kind of plasticized material, which means it should be quite durable and travel well. (This will come in handy if I decide to go back to a music instructor for lessons.) The spiral binding means the whole thing will lay flat, or you can even fold it over and carry in one hand with the pages open.This is just a really nice looking, easy to use, well-thought out planner. You may want to rely on some electronic device instead of an old school notebook style planner, but if you are old school or just plain imaginative in the use of a typical daily planner, then this five star planner is definitely the one you want.

TRENDnet makes some great electronic products, and I’ve been very happy with some of their other products, most recently a wireless router adapter. Also, although I may not be the savviest person when it comes to setting up electronic gear, I’m pretty close to advanced, as I have set up everything wireless from printers and scanners, to cameras (D-link), light bulbs, thermostats, and of course routers and adapters. I say all this because I am about to tell a story of completely failing to install this camera.I thought that installing this camera would be quite straightforward and quick, and so I timed my set up effort, expecting to be able to say something like, “I had it up and running in about 20 minutes”, but that was simply not the case. In fact, after two hours of installing, uninstalling, re-installing, wireless set up, wired set up, and everything I could think to do, and although I confirmed the camera was working (see below), I couldn’t get a picture on my computer or my phone. Of course, without working software, I also had no way to control the camera, making it essentially useless.I followed the not-always-completely-clear-or-helpful instructions for wireless set up using WPS. My expensive new D-link AC router knew what to do after I pushed the WPS button, but the camera failed to find the network on the first try. It succeeded on the second try. As soon as the camera came on, the audio function conflicted with my computer’s Bose sound system, creating a huge bass hum that shook the floor. I had to turn off the sound system. Inside the set up app, I could see what the camera saw, so things were looking good, but every attempt to set up the browser software failed at the plug-in stage. I tried three different browsers and all failed. No worries, because I have an iPhone. I installed the TrendNet app on the phone, filled in the fields and away we went … to an error screen. Authentication failed. This was probably because it asked for an ID, but the software didn’t provide a way to input a new ID during the setup process. So, redo. Same thing. Authentication failed. I plugged up everything with wires and tried again. Same result with all browsers failing to install the plug-in. I searched for some solutions online, but best I could determine, this camera is just tough to set up and it is unclear if it is compatible with Windows 10. I read through some of the troubleshooting docs on the CDI don’t know if Windows 10 is the culprit or something else. It could also be some browser incompatibility, but that doesn’t explain the problem with the phone app. The inability to get the phone app working is just a mystery. In the end, I unplugged everything, uninstalled all the software and apps, and put everything back in the box. We may at some point try to install this on our older Mac, but for now, this camera just failed, on every level except the in app set up on the computer. I think giving it two stars is more than generous for a device that was impossible to set up, completely and correctly, through no fault of my own.

Last fall, Tony Bennett released a fantastic vocal jazz record together with Lady Gaga, Cheek to Cheek (Deluxe). In an interview with the Wall Street Journal, Lady Gaga said that she loved working with Tony Bennett, loved jazz, and that she planned to record “one jazz record a year, forever”. One year to the day later, Lady Gaga’s next jazz album is nowhere in sight. Instead, we have Tony Bennett, the octogenarian king of jazz, who basically reinvented the concept of the duet with his two duets albums, stretched that work with a pop diva, and now, much in the mold of his inimitable work with Bill Evans many years ago, we find him paired with one of today’s premier jazz pianists, Bill Charlap. And, as Tony has become one of the defining masters of the American songbook, he stays close to home by taking on a number of standards by Jerome Kern. The result is an eminently listenable, fascinating jazz record.One big difference between this Bennett-Charlap recording and the Bennett-Evans recordings is that this time, they went ahead and used a full rhythm section on a number of the songs. With Peter Washington on bass and Kenny Washington on drums, the sound has more of a club atmosphere and less of the intimacy of the pure duets with Evans. Another difference is Bill calls in his life partner and fellow jazz pianist Renee Rosnes to do some fabulous piano duet work on four of the tunes. (As a jazz pianist, those tunes really stood out for me.) Throughout, the solos of Charlap tend to be more evenly constructed and hone closer to the original songs, especially so as each song is kept (for the most part) close to or under the classic three minutes twenty seconds time frame. The selection of songs is solid and includes all the “standard” standards: Yesterdays, All the Things You Are, The Song is You, and even I Won’t Dance, which Tony may have done simply because it was still fresh in his repertoire from last year’s Lady Gaga recording.Tony sounds great, and the recording is very clean. (It was produced by Tony’s son, Dae Bennett and Bill Charlap, with another son, Danny Bennett, as executive producer.) Charlap is absolutely on top of his game here, carrying each tune along until it’s time to solo, cleverly breaking and shifting the solo while keeping the feel, then throwing it underhand back to Tony so Bennett can knock it out to the finish. It’s a formula that Tony has stuck with for five decades, and I personally am glad that he decided to not try and change it up. The CD booklet includes full liner notes and a nice background essay/exposition by WSJ columnist and jazz writer Will Friedwald. There are plenty of calm photos and a portrait of Jerome Kern to fill out the booklet.I don’t know how much longer Tony is going to be with us, but I hope it’s a long time and I hope he keeps singing, because treasures like this five star vocal jazz album are few and far between. Maybe he will do like Ella did with Norman Granz and work through some of the songbooks of some of the other great American composers. And if he keeps Charlap, his trio and Rosnes along for the ride, there will be lots more great music to come.I’ll also keep my eyes open for that next Lady Gaga record, while I’m monitoring the airwaves.

These are some very nice plastic cups. They are sturdy clear plastic, but classy looking, perfect for tailgating, birthday parties and events of that nature, but also highbrow enough for a typical buffet type party. They’d also be great for more formal occasions where beverages are being served and you just don’t want to do dishes afterwards.Really, there isn’t much more to say: they are plastic, they are cups, they hold drinks without leaking, and you throw them out when you are done. Since they do all that, I decided to give them five stars.

If you’ve been thinking of picking up a sporting pair of comfortable, sharp trousers for casual wear around town, but you haven’t enough quid to sashay down to Saville Row for a bespoke number, you’re going to want to look seriously at ringing up a pair of these British khaki twill trousers from Wrangler. Until recently, I hadn’t even owned a pair of Wranglers, but after falling in love with Wrangler Men's Authentics Classic Carpenter Jean, Retro Stone, 36W x 30L, and then also a pair of Wrangler Men's Authentics Premium Relaxed Boot Cut Jean, Blue/Black Stretch, 36W x 32L. I’ve become a big fan of Wrangler’s pants.Ah, beg your pardon. Trousers.Although these may not be fancy enough for tea and scones at The Ritz, their fine weave twill looks refined and classic. The fit is very comfortable, and the cut is natural and falls neatly over my 179 centimeter, 14-stone-eight body. You probably will want something sturdier and more casual if you’re going to work under the bonnet of your lorry, but for a night of pub crawling or some fish and chips with your lass in the park, these strike a perfect balance of sophistication, fun, and fashion. Because they are carpenter pants, they also give you some options for hauling stuff around town, like the generous front or side closure pockets big enough for an oversize cellular. Peoples' eyes will open like the doors of a lift as you stroll in your twill with confidence and panache.My wardrobe has stepped up several levels with the addition of these Wrangler trousers. My wife even suggested taking her out a few nights, just to be seen in my new finery. (That usually only happens when she buys them for me.) So British or American or something else, get yourself a pair of these khaki pants/slacks/trousers. You’re sure to look like a proper gentleman wherever you go.

There are a couple of features that make this a handy little item. First are the, not one, but two USB slots for charging. I can’t begin to count the number of road trips I’ve taken with the missus where we had to switch out phones and charging devices based on whose battery was lowest and what the phone was being used for (music, communication, GPS). Now, either or both of us can plug in anytime we want.Second is the hands free earbud phone headset. It comes with four sizes of silicone (?) plugs and uses a magnet to hold it in the housing of the charger. I’m not busy enough that I need to take advantage of this Bluetooth phone extender, but I can see where it would be useful for some power-user-slash-road-warrior. The whole thing just plugs into your cigarette lighter on the dash and you are ready to phone or charge for as long as your car is running. I like the polished sophisticated look, especially of the modernistic headset. It won’t look out of place in a rundown Pontiac or a sleek new BMW.I would like to add as the third feature the oxygen bar. I say “I would like to…” because I can’t really add it, as I haven’t a clue what it is. The manual hints at it being some kind of ionizer, but in my small cabin car (yes, a Pontiac, a Vibe no less), I couldn’t tell any difference in air quality, oxygen level, or anything. It’s a mystery function.One more plus is the intuitive use of the device, which like most Bluetooth devices, involves turning on devices, searching for devices, and pairing them up. I read through the manual, and while I knew what they were trying to say, the Chinese translators sure seem to have had a bit of a struggle. Fortunately, I read through to the end where they talk about avoiding heat, oil depots, and magnets due to the threat of explosion. That section cracked me up.Wait! Is this thing going to explode? Glad I’m not putting it in MY ear!In the end, this device definitely has some utility for me, just because of the double USB charger ports. The oxygen bar is a non-starter, and the threat of explosion is unsettling, but I don’t mind living dangerously if there is some convenience involved. For solving a first world problem and giving me some laughs, but because of the trepidation, I give it an average rating of three stars.Note: I received this as a free sample in exchange for an honest review.

My first experience with zinc supplements was when I was much younger and used it to help with my inflamed teenage acne. I continued to use it into my college years when I took up (don’t laugh) body building. So, it had been over thirty years since I had taken zinc as a supplement when Pacific Coast contacted me to offer a sample in exchange for a review. I’ve had a lot of success with some of Pacific Coast’s other supplements and I had nothing to lose, so I decided to try zinc again.A quick look on the web will tell you that while zinc has a lot purported benefits, most of these are not well supported by scientific facts. There is, however, plenty of evidence of the ill effects of zinc deficiency, which leads me to believe that as long as there is no harm in taking zinc as a supplement, it might not be a bad idea. I say all this because, while taking the zinc, I did not notice any tangible benefits or effects. I am physically active, in pretty good health, and I take a few different supplements and vitamins that are generally recommended for a male in my demographic, so I would probably notice it if there was some effect. Nonetheless, I didn’t feel any different taking the zinc.Pacific Coast is a high quality, reliable manufacturer of a number of different supplements, so despite my lackluster results with this supplement, I still feel like it is a quality product. I especially like that PC provides a brief e-book so users can learn about the supplement and use it correctly. As with any supplement, it is recommended that you talk with a health professional before taking this product if you are being treated for a chronic illness or condition. Everybody, and every body, is different, so results may vary, but for being a good product that did no harm and possibly has some benefits, I give this four stars.

After getting a pair of Wrangler Men's Authentics Classic Carpenter Jean, Retro Stone, 36W x 30L, I more or less fell in love with Wrangler pants. When I saw these, I immediately wanted them, both for their good looks (I love that semi-faded look), but also for their stretchability. These also look sharp enough to wear for a night out on the town if you have a quality T-shirt and a nice sport coat.When they arrived, I found they were everything I thought they would be, and more. The color is fantastic, with the base being more or less a hyper-dark blue that fades to black, but lightens to a light tan at the wear points. If anything, they look much better in person than they do in the picture. The fit is more or less perfect, as is the length. Having recently learned the proper way to wash jeans (like delicates, and inside out, line dry), these really maintain their fit and look well. My only problem is I work in a factory where spills and splashes are pretty much inevitable, and sometimes, you can even rub up against equipment the wrong way and tear your clothes. So not wanting to take a chance on losing them, I can’t wear them nearly as much as I would like.Honestly, prior to getting the carpenter pants, it had been something like 35 years since I had worn Wrangler, but now, I’m a major Wrangler fan. Their pants are just terrific and if I could quit my job so I could wear them more often, I would. That is reason enough to give them five stars.

I was pleasantly surprised with this piece of jewelry, because sometimes when I see pictures of accessories on Amazon, they look a little lame, but I have a tendency to think they will look better in person than the photograph. Then when it shows up on my doorstep and looks just like the picture (or smaller, or duller), I’m disappointed. This one actually looks pretty good in its photo, but really does look much nicer in person.One big plus is its size. It isn’t huge, but it does have some heft to it, with the winding band portion being thick but not overbearing. The accent diamonds are set on a portion of the symbol that is sort of frosted to contrast with the polished look of the rest of the piece. The chain is a basic 18” silver that conveys the beauty of the piece without distracting attention away from it. It provides a nice accent. The piece comes in a solid black box that suggests elegance and sophistication. Inside and out, and out and about, my wife enjoyed this piece.It’s a great piece of jewelry and I like the theme, as it suggests a number of possibilities and uses (infinite love, infinity and beyond, etc. etc.). This earned a five star rating without even trying.

Like most adults who had acne growing up, I’m prone to the occasional stray pimple or two. Stress, breaks from a healthy diet, general ill health, and even environmental factors such as heat and sun can cause a temporary breakout. So I keep a few tried and true remedies on hand, and was glad to have the opportunity to see how Benzac works.Because this is a mask, it takes a little time to use. You put this on your face like a normal mask and in a couple of minutes, it dries, This one is kind of aggressive going on, but I like the feel of it doing something as opposed to just being soapy or greasy. It rinsed clean and while my skin didn’t look noticeably different, the one pimple I had on my jawline appeared to be reduced in size and was definitely less red after my face had dried. On another occasion, I applied this before bed and when I woke up, a pimple had vanished completely. That was quite impressive.I wouldn’t use this on a regular basis, but as a spot treatment of a breakout or as a weekly rejuvenation for the face and pores, I think it will work fine. I found it to be better than Nexcare Acne Absorbing Cover, Two Sizes, 36 Countwhich I have used in the past and rated at four stars, so that’s why I make this a five star product.

I’ve had great success with Epson products in the past, especially their WorkForce series of scanners and printers. When our main meeting room project started acting up, this seemed well-timed to fill the gap, so I decided to try it out.Out of the box, this projector really is light. It isn’t compact by any means, but it is still easy to carry around. Despite offering a wide range of hook ups, from HDMI to USB, it comes only with an outmoded VGA cable. Since my computer only has one VGA connector and I didn’t want to fool around with it, I opted to try the USB connection. I did so with some trepidation, as the quick set up guide indicated some software would have to be installed. So, I started timing and what do you know? The software was downloaded, the connection made and my projector was on and displaying my desktop in just under four minutes. That made me happy.Looking at the screen, I have to say that the picture is super clear and the colors are bright and vibrant. (See photo. Apologies for the reflections - it's a makeshift screen.) Once I had everything focused and aligned, I could tell the picture was at least as good. If not better than my 1080p HD monitor. I played around with a few different screens, and they all looked good to me. I like the one switch for orienting the grade of the picture from left to right, as we often have to do makeshift meetings and displays on the factory floor or break room. It’s nice that the projector compensates for that so you don’t have to mess with the big screen. It also has a standard one point height adjustment and amazingly, does not require a cool down period before you can move it or pack it up. (It still gets pretty warm, though.)If this projector came with all the cables necessary to make whatever connection you wanted (or needed) at any given moment, I’d have absolutely nothing to complain about. The device is well-made, solidly built, and has great optics that are easy to adjust. It’s very portable and the remote can be made to do things on both your computer (move the cursor, etc.) and the projector to make it even easier to use to give masterful presentations. The picture is projects is crystal clear at any size and can be adjusted on the fly. Set up is fast and easy. The more I think about, the more I think I’ll just give this five stars and say, if you need to make a connection other than VGA, buy that cable when you buy this projector. You won’t go wrong.

My notion about Ahava is, they make great skin care products. My wife and I recently tried out the AHAVA Dead Sea Mud Dermud Intensive Foot Cream, 3.4 fl. oz. and were amazed to find out how effective it was at rescuing dry cracked foot skin. This German manufacturer of skin care products is all about the ingredients, and this particular moisturizer contains Osmoter (a perfectly balanced concentrate of Dead Sea minerals that effective replenishes, rehydrates and recharges the skin) and witch hazel (powerful antioxidant ingredient to smooth skin, help minimize pores and rebalance skin). For those who want to be in the know, the full list of ingredients is at the bottom of this review.Since I don’t really use facial moisturizers, but my wife does multiple times a day, I deferred to her experience. She has sensitive combination skin and is always changing up her skin care products. She started to use this at night even though it says “Day” moisturizer, because she wasn’t sure if it would irritate or cause day long oily skin by wearing it in the morning. Ahava passed her evening test without irritating her skin and with the right amount of hydrating without oiliness So, she started applying it in the morning. It is not a regular product in her skin care regimen.The best thing about this product is there are options to try a mini size (0.51 fl oz / 15 ml) to see if this works for you or a full size (1.7 fl oz / 50 ml) if you know it’s what you want. At the time of this review, however, buying 4 of the mini (total of 2.04 fl oz / 60 ml) is less expensive than the full size. Unless the price of the full size becomes less expensive, we’ll continue to purchase the mini so that not only can my wife always have fresh tube, but this makes a perfect travel size solution. We both plan to continue to try out Ahava products, because so far, they’ve all been five star performers.Full ingredientsAqua (Mineral Spring Water), Ceteareth-30 & Cetearyl Alcohol, Ethylhexyl Palmitate, Cetyl Alcohol, Glycerin, Sodium Cetearyl Sulfate, Ethylhexyl Methoxycinnamate, Propanediol(Corn derived Glycol), Caprylyl Glycol & Chlorphenesin & Phenoxyethanol, Maris Sal (Dead Sea Water), Dimethicone, Parfum (Fragrance), Aloe Barbadensis Leaf Juice, Hamamelis Virginiana (Witch Hazel) Flower Water, Alpha- Isomethyl Ionone, Benzyl Alcohol, Benzyl Benzoate, Benzyl Salicylate, Butylphenyl Methylpropional, Citronellol, Coumarin, Geraniol, Hexyl Cinnamal, Hydroxyisohexyl 3-Cyclohexene Carboxaldehyde, Isoeugenol, Linalool.

Recently, after stopping music lessons in favor or working by myself to learn music for a little while, I discovered a book called Practiceopedia: The Music Student's Illustrated Guide to Practicing. It’s an almost four hundred page book of music practice ideas and strategies, and although it is written more with school age students in mind, it was very helpful in giving me plenty of new ideas and practice “tricks” to get back at the piano. Unfortunately, it wasn’t really helping my musicality. Just as I was finishing that book, the author of Sound Origins contacted me to offer me a free copy of his book in exchange for a review. The timing couldn’t have been better, so of course, I agreed.Mr. Robitaille is a noted musical scholar and accomplished musician. In addition to performing with a plethora of jazz musicians, he’s also a teacher and composer. This book, however, is not about improving your chops or giving you a pep talk. Instead, he covers, in a very personal way, what it means to make music. He explores music making by delving into the thought process of music itself: what we mean when we say “music”, how we can expand our musical thinking, and how our life experience and the world around us can influence (and I presume, improve) our music. Not to oversimplify what the author says, but I took it to mean that it’s about harnessing the forces and energy in the universe that make music, rather than about beating a song out of a Steinway or Les Paul.Some ways a musician might do this is by exploring other art forms: poetry, painting, conversation, even science fiction and random noise. All these can become driving influences in the creation and composition of music. There’s also a rundown of the elements of music, from touch and timbre, to articulation and expression, where a full understanding of the individual element makes its execution that much more meaningful and impactful on one’s music and the process of making music. Those sections certainly bring a tangible feel and recognizable force to the music making process.If there is any weakness in this book, it is that it is too short. Often the author makes an intriguing suggestion or points out another aspect of a musical concept, only to leave it to the reader to determine its ultimate use and impact. Although I’m glad to have had the thought-inducing starting points given to me, I would have welcomed the author to more purposefully discuss and expound on those ideas. I had the feeling that the author has more ideas to share, and I think those would have made the book more interesting.The electronic version of the book that I received had several examples of songs with the sheet music in the book. (The book assumes readers possess a certain level of musical ability.) This did a lot to emphasize and illustrate some of the points the author made. This is an easy read, and although it is a short book, I believe any serious musician will take away something of value from this book. Especially if you find yourself where I did, wanting to make music but having “forgotten” how to even be musical, Sound Origins is a great place to start over from. Because of its short length and narrow subject matter, I can’t rate it at a full five stars, but this is worth every bit of four stars, simply for providing the musical mind jog that it does. I commend Mr. Robitaille on his insight and effort to put such difficult subject matter into words.

For the longest time, I needed, but did not have a vise. Then I ransacked my father’s tools (don’t worry; he can’t use them anymore) and found a small Craftsman vise that I used growing up, and have been getting by with that. Then Yost came along and well, I wondered how I got along without it.This vise is huge. (See photos for how it dwarfs my Craftsman vise.) It weighs almost 50 pounds and comes with a base plate that allows it to swivel. It looks great right out of the box and after mounting, it works great, too. It can hold anything you can imagine needing holding, including pipes up to three inches in diameter. If you have a proper work bench and properly mount it (more on that in a moment), it’s hard to think of what it couldn’t hold. I like the powder blue finish, which is easy on the eyes and looks “professional”. Operation was smooth and straightforward: Turn the handle counterclockwise to loosen, clockwise to tighten. I worked on a few pieces of wood that needed cutting for a pathway in a flowerbed. It held securely without slippage, making fast work of my project.Disappointingly, they did not include screws or bolts for mounting. Presumably, they figured too many handymen would have too many workbench configurations for a “one size fits all” approach with the mounting screws. Yost also recommends under-mounting a 18” square, 2” thick piece of wood, or a quarter inch steel plate. It all sounds like overkill to me, as I used oversized wood screws from an antique piano project gone bad to mount to a fiberboard table and experienced no problems. Note, however, that I’m just a DIY’er and I wouldn’t expect that sort of mount to last for a heavy duty user, or even for a long time.The vise itself, with the surface anvils, cast construction, powder coat, swivel mount plate, and everything else is quite amazing. For someone like me, it’s really over the top, which makes me believe just about any serious handyman, mechanic, carpenter, weekend warrior would love this thing. I thought about deducting a star for the lack of mounting screws, but I decided that wasn’t actually a disadvantage for the majority of users (I mean, people who are going to buy this surely have a few screws lying around – even I did), so I stuck with a five star rating. As the title says, you get the most with Yost!

After overexerting myself running one morning, sort of testing my limits, my bum knee was bummer than usual and I had sore muscles twinging in both my lower and upper back from compensating for the knee. Normally, three ibuprofen tablets would be my remedy, and normally, I would notice some relief after 30 minutes to an hour. I figured this was a perfectly controlled opportunity to test Goody’s Back and Body Shot.So I took a gulp. If it hadn’t been for the twinge in my back keeping me from straightening up too fast, I would have spewed this halfway across the room. Seriously, this is some horrible, vile stuff. In the interest of science (okay, this review), I slugged back the rest in two more agonizing, battery acid flavored Kool-Aid, gulps. The Japanese have a saying that “The bitterest medicine is the best remedy.” If that is the case, then Goody’s should probably be able to cure cancer, tuberculosis, measles, and malaria. At least I had hope as I washed out my mouth with soda to revive my chemically burned taste buds.Alas, it was not to be. After 30 minutes, my back and knee were the same. After another thirty minutes, still no discernible improvement. Two hours? Still nothing. It seemed that I had tortured my tongue to absolutely no purpose. The back and body shot was, just plain, shot.Very rare is it for me to come across a product that I can’t find something positive to at least give it a two star review without giving my conscience a fit. But this Goody’s product is awful tasting, slow (or no) acting, and essentially ineffective against pain – back, body, knee, or otherwise. I imagine it is also pretty expensive (unavailable at this writing, so no price available), especially compared to a huge bottle of ibuprofen at Costco or Amazon that is a couple of bucks for 500 or more. Even at a competitive price point, there is nothing that would make me take this again, and so Goody’s goes to the realm of one star products.

To start, let me say, these are two very fine products. With Perky Pet bird feeders, you never know if you’re going to get a “beta” design that doesn’t work quite proper and the birds don’t like it, or if you’re going to get the National Geographic approved, “flocks will migrate to the thing” bird feeder. This is definitely the latter. It’s big, easy to use, holds a ton (well, over two pounds) of black sunflower seed, sets up in less than a minute – just hang it up and fill it – and it looks great. The birds have already integrated this into their feeding routine. (We have a number of different feeders already set up, and this one is pretty much already getting equal time. Check the photo and notice the little bird, left on the cardinal feeder, taken about five minutes after filling it up.)The spinner is just cool. It ships flat and you simply fold out the metal spines and you have a really eye-catching, optical illusion like decoration. It, too, takes just a minute or two to set up, and you’re spinning in no time. I’m not sure if this isn’t a distraction for the birds, however, I doubt it acts as any kind of attractant. I don’t think the birds see it, and go “Hey! Look at those two dimensional half-sized cardinals over there! Let’s go eat!” I put ours up well away from the feeders, just because I prefer natural birds over fake ones, but still, we love the look of the spinner. I just don’t think a sparkling, moving mobile thing, even in a bird motif, is an obvious pairing with a bird feeder.One other confusing thing: both these items ship completely flat, but they were shipped together in an absolutely oversized box that probably could have held a dozen of each of them, with that space taken up by wads of butcher paper. (Which reminds me: if anybody needs 125 square yards of wrinkled butcher paper, let me know.) Surely, with all the stuff Amazon ships, there had to be a more economical box somewhere.The products themselves are close to or exceeding my expectations overall, I just remain unsure of the pairing concept, and I totally don’t get the packaging, but what you end up with is two five star products and three star everything else, so I’m setting it down at four stars.

It took me three or four tries to get into this book, but once I got going, I found it fascinating.Omm Sety was born Dorothy Eady. She was an Englishwoman born in 1904 to relatively normal, middle class parents. When she was a child, she had an accident, and the doctor who was summoned declared her dead...which made everyone all the more surprised an hour later when she opened her eyes.The author of the book, Hanny el Zeini – an Egyptian chemist (of all things) who was a good friend of Omm Sety's and had an interest in ancient Egyptian history – even points out the obvious conclusion: that the doctor was wrong. Maybe his examination was too cursory, or maybe his stethoscope didn't work properly, or whatever. That's likely what Omm Sety's family believed, except for the fact that after her “miraculous” recovery, she turned a bit...odd. (Which I suppose is like saying the sun is a bit warm.) This very young girl was completely convinced that she could remember a temple that not only had no one she knew ever visited, but that no longer even existed except as a ruin.Anyway, thus began Omm Sety's lifelong fascination with ancient Egypt, so after spending her childhood learning from an Egyptologist friend, she married an Egyptian man, moved to Egypt, took an Egyptian name, and spent the rest of her life quite literally living the dream she had as a concussed toddler. Her unusual experiences didn't end with her childhood, either. She spent a lifetime receiving otherworldly visitors...including her long-dead Egyptian lover.I am not a mystical person. I believe in science and logic. I believe that numbers always add up the same way, and I believe in following the rules. I am agnostic, and I lean more toward  atheism than theism. I am a great lover of fantasy fiction and video games, so it's not that I don't *want* to believe in magic or ghosts or past lives, it's that I'm simply not equipped to. I'll be the first to admit that I don't know everything about this sometimes-mysterious world we inhabit, and neither do I think humanity as a whole has even scratched the surface of all there is to know...but I have to say, I'm very skeptical about all of this.And so I spent much of this book entertained but still convinced Omm Sety was off her nut. But, assuming the book doesn't contain flat-out lies, there were enough inexplicable goings on that my doubt came to the fore, and I almost convinced myself more than once that this lady really did have a window into the past. I can say this much: should future investigations prove some of her theories correct, I'll be thrilled. Which isn't to say that I'd necessarily believe she'd had a past life as a priestess, but it would go along way toward convincing me that, wherever her knowledge came from, there was more to her than met the eye.Well, regardless of whether you think she was a total crank or the reincarnated spirit of 19th Dynasty priestess Bentreshyt, she WAS incredibly knowledgeable on the subject of ancient Egypt and one cannot say she didn't put her money where her mouth was, given that she chose to live in abject poverty so as to be closer to her temple and her work. If Egypt is a subject that interests you, well...biographies on the topic really don't get more unusual or interesting than this, you know? No matter what the truth is, I'm very glad to have read it.

The Dagger in the Desk is a short story set in the Lockwood & Co. universe.The plot is pretty thin, even for a short story; The Dagger in the Desk is essentially a single mission without much in the way of build-up. The Lockwood team is retained to investigate a school that, after some renovations, is experiencing a sudden uptick in ghostly activity. (And as children are most sensitive to spirits, a school is about as bad a place for a haunting as can be!) Dagger doesn't really contain any world-building or insight into the characters, and the mystery (of what the source might be) that the other Lockwood books are built on isn't really given the room it'd need to create any tension; this is pretty much just a single action sequence.The story is listed as 46 pages, but only about 2/3 of that is the actual story; the rest of the page count is taken up by the illustrated ghost guide (which, incidentally, contains awfully little illustrations, and the guide portion doesn't have much more than the glossaries included in the full books) and preview. This was a seriously quick read. So if you're hoping for something meaty, you might be a bit disappointed. What Dagger does provide, though, is another taste of Stroud's excellent world. It's short, but it's well-written and exciting...so, four stars. While I don't think it'd be worth paying for, this story is, at the moment, free, and I'll never turn down a chance to hang out with Lucy and Lockwood and, yes, even George, even if it's just for a few minutes.

I remarked on my review for the Magician's Tower, book two in this series, that I didn't care for it nearly as well as the first book. Oona aggravated me a bit, the antagonists aggravated me a bit...I loved the plot and the setting, but the irritations sucked some of the fun out of it all. And if I'm going to read a middle-grade book, being, you know, not a middle-grade person, I want it to be fun.Happily, I can say that with The Magician's Dream, we're back to a solid four stars and a thoroughly enjoyable read. The mysteries were well written, some of the overarching plot lines were resolved, and this book's specific plot – a combination of battle training for Oona, women's rights, and the investigations of the aforementioned mysteries – was probably my favorite of the three books. I was a bit nervous about possible romantic elements given the high angst quotient in book two, but what was in this one was not at all overbearing.If you haven't met Oona Crate and Deacon and Samuligan and the wizard yet, start with The Wizard of Dark Street. If you have met them, but you felt as I did about the middle book and you're wondering whether continuing is worth it, well...my opinion is that it definitely is. I have no doubt that this book, and this whole series, would delight just about any kid who happened to pick it up, but one doesn't need to be a child to enjoy it...which is, sadly, often not the case. I said it earlier, but it bears repeating: there may have been a few kinks that needed working out in earlier volumes, but overall? This series is *fun*.

Much to my surprise, I was able to give the first book in the Oona Crate series four stars. (I say “much to my surprise” because, for one thing, I'm a tough critic most of the time, and for another, I'm not in the intended age bracket.) While I can't say it blew my mind, I found it highly enjoyable. Unfortunately, this one, while still pretty good, didn't make me smile quite as much.Partly, I'd guess, it's just that the bloom is off the rose, so to speak. But it's also Oona herself. I really enjoyed her character in book one, but in this one, she started to get on my nerves.Oona was introduced to us as a young girl who, though she retains enough girlishness that we don't forget that she's not an adult (the way so many authors seem to when it comes to their own YA characters!), is sensible, and logical, and practical, and highly intelligent. The combination of little girl and capable protagonist was very well done. In this one, though, she...I dunno, regresses? Her bad traits start to come out a bit more — she's headstrong, she makes foolish decisions, she allows herself to get needled by her rivals... She doesn't seem quite as mature, which makes her harder to relate to. I'd have expected Oona to apply her impressive mind to her problems. And...well, she does, but not without indulging in a bit of scowling and foot-stomping first.Another (fairly minor) irritation was the inclusion of a couple of devices that quickly grew tiresome. Isadora, Oona's main rival, has a boyfriend, and as soon as he's introduced, Isadora refers to him in conversation as “my BOYFRIEND.” All caps, just like that. I assume that it was written that way to imply bragging. Well...it does. To the point of obnoxiousness. Another bit I didn't care for was the recurring theme of “chivalry,” which didn't have as much of an impact on the plot as I'd have expected, given how often it came up. I suppose I just didn't care for these characters, and not because they're antagonists, but because they're annoying.The whole not-having-an-impact thing brings up another thing: there are couple of situations that Oona finds herself in that don't really go anywhere. I'll assume they were included to set up a plot line for book three, but it felt a bit untidy.But, I'm doing a lot of nitpicking for a book that got a respectable three stars, so I ought to make it clear that I did like it. Not as much as I liked the first book, but it wasn't bad by any means. I enjoyed the light, cheerful plot, I enjoyed most of the side characters — I love the wizard, I love Samuligan, and I really really love Deacon! — and I enjoyed the little flashes of humor. Despite my three-star rating, I've already purchased and started book three; The Magician's Tower may not have been perfect, but there's...well, a *magic* to this series that suggests I'll find myself back on Dark Street sometime down the road.

Getting middle grade books makes me nervous. Every now and then, you come across a Harry Potter...but for the most part, you end up with books that, while delightful for children, don't really hold up to a worldly and discerning adult's suspicious, near-sighted eyeballs. I wasn't reassured when I saw all of the critical (or at least tepid) reviews for this first Oona Crate mystery, either — usually, I'm in the position of being harder on books than other reviewers, so when a lot of people dislike something, I generally take that as a sign and keep walking.I'm not sure why I didn't this time, to be honest. Maybe it was my mood; don't you, every now and then, just crave something simple and uncomplicated, something that's not going to make you *feel* too much? Maybe a desire along those lines subconsciously pulled me in. Or, I suppose it could've been most excellent cover, too. Or, maybe I was just riding high on my discovery of Jonathan Stroud's Lockwood & Co. series and wanted to keep the winning streak going. Don't know.And you know, the complaints others have about it? They're not wrong. The story is a bit thin. The bad guy is as stereotypical as Snidely Whiplash. The writing gets a little bit much at times. This book had more than one element that I'd normally find exasperating.Except...I didn't. Get exasperated, I mean. I don't know whether it really was a mood swing or what, but when I went in NOT expecting fine literature, I freed myself to simply enjoy riding along on Oona's adventures. Sometimes, when you read a book or watch a movie that you liked as a kid, you find the story just doesn't hold up anymore. But other times, and I've never been very clear how much of this was the story itself and how much was just frame of mind, but those other times you get taken over by the magic of a child's imagination and expectation and you remember how to delight in a story even when it isn't perfectly structured.I guess what I'm trying to say is that if you can suspend your adultiness for a bit and go into this without expecting a masterpiece, if you can enjoy it for its own sake, you'll probably have a pretty good time reading.And now? Now I'm off to read book two before this childishness wears off!

The Novelty Maker is a short story set in a steampunky world featuring Cole, a younger son in the upper class, and Harlowe, the scarred mechanical genius that fascinates Cole so.I can't say it really rocked my world, but it's a fairly sweet and fairly well-written story. I found the plot to be a bit thin, even if I'm making allowances for the length. Surprisingly, there's no overt sex...but not only that, there's precious little romance. (To be clear, that's not a complaint. I like a slow burn, I prefer implication to demonstration, and I think stories like this are almost sweeter when they aren't packed with juicy bits. If you're looking for something that gets you hot and bothered, though, this probably isn't going to be it.)This is one of those stories that was perfectly entertaining in the moment, but that doesn't have enough substance or complexity to stick with me. I'll happily recommend it while it remains free, however; it's a very quick read, so you really have nothing to lose.

This first book Jordan L. Hawk's new series surprised me. I'm a huge fan of hers, and as always, she does some things very, very well. She writes historical fiction that feels truly historical, without the anachronisms that pepper so much of it, and you can tell she really does her homework. She writes romances that I don't hate. (I know that sounds like faint praise, but I've really grown to dislike all the insta-love and cliched endearments and formulaic sex scenes that we see all. the. time.)And I've said before in reviews for other books of hers, perhaps her greatest strength is in her ability to create characters. They're complex. They have their own unique voices. They feel real, and you can't help but fall in love with them all.That's what surprised me. Throughout much of the book, I hadn't fallen in love with them. Don't get me wrong, they were excellently-drawn. They were definitely complex. They felt like real people. It's just...this time around, I didn't really like them. (I guess it was bound to happen. I meet people that I don't really like all the time.)In Restless Spirits, we have Vincent, a medium – a man who can interact with and channel ghosts – who has some severe doubts about his path in life, and we have Henry, an inventor and scientist, who has a strong prejudice against mediums thanks to an unfortunate past and who wants to make them obsolete with his latest invention.
