Now, again, I don't want to give you the impression that the recipes are unusually complex. It's just...the focus of the book seems to be skewed toward creativity, toward stuff I wouldn't have necessarily thought to try on my own, and that's a wonderful thing. But when you get right down to it, we all know I'm going to get home from work, look at the beautiful photos accompanying the inspired recipe of my choice, sigh wistfully because it looks so wonderful, and make a cheese sandwich.I'm disappointed by the number of beverage recipes, although I'm happy to be disagreed with. I don't want a recipe for tea, no matter how unusual the flavor combinations. I also wish the cookbook had provided nutritional information on its recipes, although there are notations for vegan, gluten free, etc. recipes, which could be helpful for some.However, I have learned that one of my talents is gauging how well I'll like a recipe just from reading it, and some of these sound excellent. I have wild rice soaking as I type for the wild rice and pistachio salad.I do feel like I ought to praise the look and feel of the book. It's printed on a beautiful heavy, matte paper, and contains some amazing photos.Anyway, the TL;DR version of all this is that if a cookbook is going to get five stars from me, it needs to call primarily for ingredients that I have ready access to, and it needs to wow me with the easy ways of preparing and combining those ingredients for a consistently tasty result. And I'll tell you the truth: that's hard to find. I know I'm not an easy customer to please. But, that's why I probably wouldn't have bought this book for myself. If, on the other hand, you're looking for some daring new vegetarian food combinations, or if you've got access to some unusual foods and just never knew what to do with them, then this book might be right up your alley.

I wasn't sure what I was getting myself into, buying this, with all the tepid reviews over on Goodreads. Happily, I enjoyed it.ABSIY is comic fantasy, along the lines of Diana Wynne Jones or Robert Asprin. In it, a recent graduate of the wizard school applies for a job as the royal wizard of a tiny kingdom named Yurt...and he gets it. Unfortunately, he wasn't a terribly good student, so when he arrives at the royal castle to find sinister goings-on - the "bad spell" of the title - he doesn't really have the expertise to deal with them.[Note: What follows may include some (mild) spoilers. I'm certainly not giving away the ending, but I am complaining a bit, and it's hard to do that without getting specific.]I want to be clear that I really did enjoy this, quite a lot, but I'm not going to pretend it's perfect. The character development was lacking, for one thing. Daimbert (and BTW, I don't think I really registered the MC's name until the very end - the book is told in first person, and pretty much no one ever calls him by name...seems to me that not drilling the protagonist's name into your readers counts as a negative of its own) is sometimes pretty hard to relate to. He alternates between terrified determination and awkward ridiculousness - which works well for him - but some of his thoughts and actions are a bit incomprehensible. When a book is written in first person, one would hope that you'd come away understanding every nuance of the main character's motivations. In this book, though, I found myself wondering more than once why he was behaving the way he was.One example might be the chaplain. When Daimbert - it still feels weird typing that name, like I ought to be calling him "Wizard" or "Whippersnapper" - arrives at the castle, he makes up his mind that the chaplain, a young man near his own age, shall become his friend. The author then proceeds to make the chaplain fairly unlikeable, obnoxiously pious with zero sense of humor, who goes on and on at great length about evil influences. Yet, Daimbert never wavers in his decision that the chaplain - funny, now I can't seem to recall his name, either - is now his closest friend. It was odd.Not all the characters were like that. I rather liked the king and queen, I liked the duchess, I enjoyed the old wizard, and Lady Maria was entertaining. But if you're after characters with depth and nuance, you won't find them in this book. Even the characters I grew fond of were pretty flat.I also wondered about the idea that Daimbert was left to deal with the Bad Spell by himself. Now sure, I could understand him being reluctant to ask for help - he was quite determined to not let on how over his head he was. But...are we really to believe the more experienced characters were willing to risk the kingdom since it wasn't their problem? That seemed unlikely to me.Possibly the oddest aspect of this book was the religion. Now, I read lots of fantasy. LOTS. I feel quite at home in worlds where religion plays a large role. Thing is, in most of those worlds, the religion is...made up. I mean, sure, it probably resembles the religions we're familiar with, but it's still imaginary. In ABSIY, Brittain imports Christianity. Like, actual, unadulterated, regular Christianity. It was very startling; to hear a chaplain from a magical kingdom in another world talk about Christ dying for all their sins invoked a dissonance that jarred me right out of the story.Yet, you'll see I still rated the book four stars. If ABSIY's imperfections were to turn another reader off - which it evidently has, if Goodreads is any indication - I would fully understand. However, I still liked it. Kind of a lot. Do you ever have days where you don't want to read/watch/play/think about anything intense, or scary, or deep? Where all you want is something light and a bit mindless into which you can escape for a few hours? Because I do. (Regularly.) And this book turned out to be exactly what the doctor ordered. It was cute. It was funny - in a gentle-smile sort of way rather than a laugh-out-loud way. It was entertaining. And Yurt, the setting, was delightful.So, a masterpiece this is not. But if you're in the mood for a light comic fantasy along the lines of Howl's Moving Castle or Myth Adventures, you might enjoy this as much as I did. (And if you're wondering, at the 50% mark I still wasn't sure whether I wanted to continue the series. By the time it was done, though, I had book 2 bought and waiting for me.)EDIT: I came back to edit this because I wanted you all to know - I did buy and read book two. And three, four, and five, and I'm in the middle of book six right now. This review is like most of my reviews; even when I like something, I still tend to call out the various ways it could've been better. So while I'm not apologizing for that, and while I still think the book is a solid four stars, I feel like I ought to let you all know that man, does this series get better! The author keeps her same cheerful tone, but the setting fills in, the characters deepen...this series has turned out to be one I'll be re-reading time and time again. This book is good. Later, they get great.

This mix is truly outstanding. It's got the perfect balance between sweet and salty with a little tang from the fruit thrown in for complexity. It's almost got a buttery taste to it, like a really good fresh pastry. I'm a bit astonished that I had the willpower to only eat half the bag in one sitting.I may have moaned.Only reason I'm giving it four stars is the price. I almost wish I hadn't tried these because there's no way I can afford to blow four bucks on a bag of nuts that would take me all of 20 seconds to inhale if I were to give in to my base urges...which, let's face it, I probably would; the leaving-half-for-tomorrow thing was a fluke.If you can afford buying these in quantity, go for it. If not, maybe it's better to not find out what you're missing.

In my review for Super Powereds: Year 1, I wrote about how astonished I was to discover a book that was just. that. good. This series might not have sounded like my thing at first, but I decided to give it a shot based on the strength of Hayes's writing in one of his other books (NPCs, which, incidentally, I recommend). I'm so glad I did; SP1 was long and involved and meaty and totally riveting.I've read lots of decent books lately, and several darn good ones, but seriously: it was stay-up-till-1-a.m.-even-though-you-have-to-get-up-in-four-hours riveting.I'm pleased to report that SP2 is just as wonderful. All of the things I loved about the first one continued seamlessly. Love the characters, love the story, love the complexity and the intricacies and the length, and I have to say, I'm super-impressed by how well the author does intrigue.I feel the need to comment on the reviews that refer to the poor editing. For real, I hate badly-edited books. They don't just distract me, they actually have started to make me angry - angry at the author for thinking he or she has any right to collect my money for a slipshod product. Here? I just don't see it. Yes, there were some mistakes. (Not the all-too-common "this author has absolutely no idea how to wield an apostrophe" mistakes, but more like typos. Missing words, the occasional "too" instead of "to," that kind of thing.) I didn't find them particularly numerous or distracting, though. I can't decide if it's because there really aren't that many errors or if it's just that I was so enraptured by the story that they slipped past my vigilance, but...bad editing aggravates me. This book didn't aggravate me at all. Just the opposite, in fact.If you've started the Super Powereds series with book one, I doubt you need any recommendation to finish it. If you liked it, you'll like this one just as much. If it wasn't your cup of tea (which I have a hard time imagining), whatever bugged you about it is probably going to be in this one too. If you haven't read SP1, I really really recommend it; I thought both it and this book were outstanding.

I was prepared to be disappointed by this, considering it was a blind buy - I had no idea whether it would work or if it was actually stinky.I'm actually a bit impressed.First: the scent. I don't really get any hint of either thyme or fig from this, which is one reason it's not getting five stars. I was really expecting something green and herbal smelling, and it's not even close. Nevertheless, it does NOT stink. The predominant fragrance seems to be apple. Not a fake-smelling perfumey apple, but like what an actual Granny Smith smells like when you slice it. And while it's primarily a fruit scent, there's enough complexity - floral, other fruits, maybe the barest hint of some sort of pastry - that I can definitely call it both pleasant and interesting.It's got moderate-to-poor staying power. When I tested it on fabric, the smell had dissipated considerably ten minutes later...but the notes left behind were almost more pleasant than the original blast. There was some smell left, and it was just enough to smell nice without giving the impression that I had whipped out the fabric freshener.As to its claims of odor neutralization, it's not terrible. To test that aspect, I pulled some jeans out of the hamper. Not filthy, but not freshly laundered, either, and when I sniffed them up close - BTW, I'm so glad no one was around to see me doing this stuff - well, let's just say you could tell they'd been worn. I got the fabric damp on the outside without using so much it could soak through. The spray didn't completely neutralize the old jeans smell, but they did smell much fresher 15 minutes later - fresher in a way that makes me think the spray actually did something with those weird all-natural ingredients besides cloak the odor with fragrance.(Grain of salt: I've been told I don't have the keenest nose around. I won't argue with anyone who says they can perceive the fragrance more keenly or for longer than I did. So if you're particularly sensitive to smells, you may want a second opinion.)All in all, this was not the disappointment I thought it'd be. Frankly, I think it smells better than Febreze and as far as efficacy, it might not be quite as powerful but it can hold its own. I'd get this again.

If we're being extra precise - which, as an accountant, I tend to be - I'd give this book 4.5 stars. To translate that, let's just say that while I can see where others might find fault, the book's general excellence carried the story at a pace that allowed me to overlook the sorts of things that might otherwise bug me.I bought this book after reading another of this author's: NPCs. NPCs is one of those books you buy because it sounds lightly amusing and, since you're feeling a little frisky with that $0.99 rattling around in your pocket, well, why not? And it turned out to be the sort of book that made my obnoxious smugness evaporate about a chapter in because, holy cow, this author knows how to write! I point this out because, while I don't know if I would have been drawn to Super Powereds had I not already had a sampling of what this guy can do, I was delighted enough to take a chance on what might not normally have been my thing.I'm very glad I did.My reviews are generally on the critical side; while I have a hard time, sometimes, articulating what was so great about a story, I have no such hard time pointing out where one falls short. And even for an outstanding book, there's always something, right? This review won't be an exception to that trend, but understand that what follows are quibbles that, while about stuff that might bug others, were not enough to get me to round down to four stars. That says something right there.One of those quibbles might be about the pacing. This is a meaty book. This is not one of those stories that just hits the important parts and lets you fill in the rest. No, this is a story with everyday conversations, everyday activities (well, as everyday as they can be, considering they're superheroes)...and for five main characters, not just one. I can easily imagine people making suggestions as to how the writing might have been tightened up so that we're not left reading this sprawling gargantuan story that's only book one out of what I assume will be four. "Pfft," I say to that. This wasn't a story that boiled over and went wild (i.e. this wasn't one of those stories where the author throws everything but the kitchen sink in because he or she can't discern which bits are important). No, I get the impression that the author purposely wrote with density in mind, and I'm glad he did. It's long, it's detailed, it's wordy...but the length and the details and the words are all good. Then again, maybe I'm just the sort of person who likes a long, involved story.Another one might have to do with the characters. Now, I liked the characters in general. All of them, really, and with a book this vast, that's impressive. Nevertheless, there were occasions when, for example, a more minor character hasn't had a POV in so long that I'd almost forgotten about him or her. There were a few that approached the stereotypical category; one was unfailingly good-hearted, another was the very epitome of jerkishness. Or, there's the fact that we have so, so many unique characters with their own talents and personalities but who all have regular college kid names, and a "wait, who now?" would pop up while they're being juggled. Again, though, these are quibbles. I think the author did a pretty terrific job with them overall.The plot is a good one. Even though the general idea isn't new - I've read books with a lot of similarities - it felt pretty fresh. It wasn't a non-stop, edge-of-your-chair ride (which is good; a book can't be too constantly thrilling when it's this long or it just ends up feeling too busy and stressful), but the author a achieved a very nice balance between action, dialogue, and exposition.I was very impressed with the ending. Obviously, one expects a climax in this sort of story. We got one, but...it really wasn't what I expected. Or rather, the part that I expected happened, but it was immediately overshadowed by a much more climactic surprise. It's been a long time since I've had a real "Holy [crap], it can't be bedtime yet!" moment. That was fun.I've read other reviews that mention the editing, or lack thereof, and wanted to address those. I read one of those reviews before buying this one (I tend to skip the good reviews and jump straight to the bad ones so as to see whether the others' deal-breakers are the same as my deal-breakers), and admit, I was a little nervous. Poor editing actually gets me angry these days; if I'm going to buy an author's book, I expect him or her to have enough respect for me to make it worth buying. That worry was groundless. I did catch a couple mistakes - of the typo persuasion, which is a little easier to forgive, since we all make them - but I'm talking about maybe two or three over the whole ninety-two million page book. (Could there have been more I didn't catch? Certainly...and if that's the case, it says something that the book was so engrossing that I didn't catch them. I *always* catch them.) Perhaps there was an earlier edition that had more errors in it?Since this is getting ridiculously long, I'll just finish up by saying that I found Super Powereds a delightful, engrossing read from an author who clearly is really, really good at what he does. Do yourself a favor and check his stuff out.

You know, I thought the premise sounded amusing, but I was truly not prepared for how delightful this book was!I've never played a pen-and-paper role playing game; I thought they sounded like fun as a kid, but didn't know anyone else who was into that kind of thing. A little older and I was too ashamed to admit to liking something so nerdy...and then I discovered video games. Even though I'm not the stereotypical gamer, I like a game with a good strong storyline for the same reason I like reading well-written fantasy: it's a chance to immerse myself in a magical world, and the best games do it like a Choose Your Own Adventure. (Remember those?)Sadly, many of the books I've tried that are based on a D&D-style storyline just don't cut it. The "rules" that make a lot of sense in a game get cumbersome in a book, and things like characters and the depth of the plot are sometimes less developed than they should be. Too often they just sound like something that would be better if you could play it, like a you-had-to-have-been-there moment.Not sadly, this was not one of those.The author was completely transparent about basing this on an RPG; the whole story is built on a real-world frame of five obnoxious kids playing a pen-and-paper game, and the author frequently pokes lighthearted fun at the game structure that any of us who've played them for any real length of time probably don't even notice anymore. It really was a very funny book. One of those jabs was at the traditional party structure - a standard RPG party of adventurers contains a fighter, a rogue, a magic-user, and a healer because those four classes cover the bases. It's both an interesting look at stereotypes and a mockery of the way character races gravitate toward certain classes.I was a little nervous about the writing going in. I hadn't heard of this author before, and there are SO many e-books written by people who never really grasped the mechanics of telling a story well. I needn't have been; I thought the book was very well-written and I enjoyed the author's style enormously. It wouldn't have surprised me if the author's voice and sense of humor had started to grow old - again, it happens a little too often, and what starts out charming starts to grate before too long - but it never did. And I KNOW I don't need to mention the epidemic of editing fails going around lately. This book was definitely edited. I think I caught two mistakes.This was a very quick read. (Too quick? Only 'cause it was so good.) The plot itself was impressively well-paced, with a perfect scope for the length, and a terrific balance of action, discussion, and exposition. The main storyline is tied up neatly - I do so hate cliffhangers - but instead of a happily ever after, the author leaves plenty of room for the continuing adventures of the NPCs. I really, really hope we get to continue their adventures!I've been trying to decide whether people who aren't into role playing games would enjoy this, or even get it, and I'm inclined to think they would. While the universe is along the lines of Drizzt's or Elminster's (though to be clear, this is not set in the Forgotten Realms) or the Dragonlance books, it probably reminded me most of the comedic fantasy of Jig the goblin in Goblin Quest, with flavors of Robert Asprin and Xanth without the puns.I'm either off to see what else this author has written - he's seriously got some chops - or maybe I'll dust off Baldur's Gate or Neverwinter Nights; NPCs really reminded me why I liked those games so much. As for you, I say you should try it...and if you're not a "gamer" but find you like it, then maybe that's a suggestion that you ought to give an RPG a try and find out for yourself what it's like to be an adventurer.

You know, when I write a review, I tend to be critical. Possibly overly critical. Just because I enjoy a book doesn't mean I'm going to ignore the ways it may have fallen short.This series came out of nowhere and muscled my way onto my favorites list. For the first time in a loooooong time, I seriously had nothing bad to say about Night Calls. I was able to point out a few things I thought might bother other readers, but that was all the criticism I could muster up. Alfreda Sorensson isn't the only one with magic; Kimbriel has the touch.Then I read Kindred Rites (Night Calls Book 2), and if it's possible, I may have liked that one even better. It was a bit more suspenseful, but still maintained the slow, detailed, rich tone that so drew me in to Night Calls. Alfreda is a bit older, a bit wiser, and knows quite a bit more about working her craft, but she's still the same young, practical, precocious child who gets in over her head, gets on with things anyway, and with whom you have no choice but to fall in love.Except now I'm a little torn.Like books one and two, Spiral Path covers a very short period of time that nevertheless feels...bottomless. All of them are so well-crafted that even though we may only spend a few months at a time with Alfreda and Marta and the others, there's so much detail that it's like you're living right along with them. There are those who don't care for detail when it comes at the expense of action, but in this case you don't read the story, you drop into the pages and live it.So why am I torn? Because there's no resolution. Or, to be more clear, even though there's a conclusion to the specific adventures that make up the Spiral Path storyline - this does not end with some manipulative cliffhanger - we cannot be done with Alfreda yet. She's barely just gotten to school. She's barely explored her feelings for Shaw. We haven't helped Margaret, or gotten to know Esme's professors, or learned the implications of the unicorn.In other words: there's so much of everything left to do!It's been over 15 years between the releases of books two and three! Don't get me wrong. Spiral Path was a sheer delight to read. I certainly recommend reading the series - as if you needed the recommendation if you've already read NC1 & 2 - but good grief, make it last for your own sake, or you'll end up feeling as bereft as I am right now.Huh. I guess I'll just have to start over from the beginning, won't I?

I probably would've rated it higher had the plot not seemed so, well, thin. And holey. And a bit ridiculous. More than once, when a question was answered or something was revealed, my face got that scrunched-up, skeptical look that means "well that's an...interesting...direction to take things." (That's what it means when I'm being extra-diplomatic, anyway.)In other words, without getting into spoiler territory, Miller made some odd choices - ones that I think hurt the story. The writing technique, though - the language itself - was well done.If you're after a torrid romance, you won't find it here. Any romantic themes are essentially an afterthought. (I don't consider that a bad thing, BTW. A light touch with the heat is often an improvement.)It wasn't terrible, and it's free, so I guess just see for yourself.

If you're here, you've hopefully read Night Calls (if you haven't yet, start there), and probably need very little prompting from me to continue learning and growing along with Alfreda.I don't know that there's much to say other than Kindred Rights continues along in the same style as NC1, with the same masterful writing and the continuance of the delightful plot. I'd judge this volume to be more suspenseful than the first; Kindred Rights has a bit more of the typical how's-she-going-to-get-herself-out-of-this-one plot, although there's still plenty of the serenity that made NC1 so wonderful. If you liked the first book, there's no doubt in my mind you'll enjoy this one too.If I had to choose between which volume I liked better, I think this one has a slight edge. Very slight, really, because I have nothing bad to say about Night Calls. There's more suspense here, like I mentioned, and Alfreda has matured quite a bit, both emotionally and in the craft, which allowed the author even more latitude to spin a yarn. (Book three was just released today, and even though I'm not very far in, I have a hunch that one might surpass both its predecessors in sheer entertainment value.)It's been a long time since I've stumbled across a series that has me as excited as this one. Start with book one if you haven't met Alfreda yet...but if you have, for goodness's sake, stop reading reviews and start reading the book!

It is very relaxing and this is a high quality product.  It works wonders on my shoulders and back.  I use it on my neck when I get my tension headaches and in no time they are gone, seriously this is really good!  I would much rather use something natural than more medicine. I am coming to feel, after listening to Paul Desmond for over forty years, that he might just be the most melodic improviser in the history of jazz. Even Bird at his finest doesn't make PD sound anything less than what he was: a phenomenally gifted musician who almost never wanked at all. Just pure melody, all the time, which as any player will tell you is the hardest thing for an improvising musician to achieve. And this collection of Paul Simon tunes---one of the most melodic of all pop composers---is exactly as wonderful as one would expect. I love it more than any other Desmond album.I first got this on vinyl in the mid-1980s, finding it for 99 cents one fine summer day in the bargain bin of some used record and antique emporium in our little town. I brought it home, opened the windows and put it on loud so as to hear it with some very music-loving friends in the yard, where we were relaxing with a few cocktails. It should be mentioned here that Desmond was a prolific drinker, almost legendary according to his contemporaries, yet even though I have over twenty of his solo records and dozens with longtime cohort Brubeck, plus a whole bunch of bootleg tapes of Desmond in various live situations, I can't find one place where he sounds hammered. Happily floating, yes, all the time! But never really ripped. Which, coming from a guy who said he wanted to sound "like a dry martini", is pretty impressive. He knew how to lay back like few others ever have, and I can't even imagine him overplaying: how many jazz guys can you say that about?So there we are, lying in the sun on a perfect July day with icy margaritas perched on our stomachs, and this almost ridiculously sublime music wafts out the window. I wasn't yet a CTI nut, but when I saw Herbie and Ron listed on the colorful cover, I knew it would at least be solid. Yet HH's gorgeous Rhodes piano, enveloped in pizzicato strings, seemed somehow sweeter than usual when the first track started, and when Desmond's incomparably evanescent alto tone came floating in on top, man, we were mesmerized. I always loved Simon, but this version of El Condor Pasa was another beast entirely. It ended so quickly that it seemed unfair. We wanted that one track alone to last an hour.To our delight, every cut was just as good, and some, like America and Mrs. Robinson, seemed to lift the beautifully matched melodies and lyrics, a Simon hallmark, to the place where dreams are made. The lyrics didn't need words; Desmond brought them to life with his incredibly tasteful lines and unmatched tone, and the songs took on new meaning. Even if you've never heard Old Friends before, you can practically hear the wistful lyrics in Desmond's carefully gentle reading of this lovely song. I've never heard Paul Simon the same way since, in fact, and I have little doubt that his shift towards jazz harmony and more complex writing in the early and mid-1970s was spurred in part from hearing on this 1969 record what truly gifted jazz musicians could do with his work; o how I wish Desmond had given this same treatment to Simon's flawless Still Crazy album.The sweetest music takes your brain and body to a place of true peace, and I challenge anyone to find a smoother jazz record than Desmond's BOTW...that isn't cheezy. Smooth jazz is now a category with its own radio stations and stars, but so much of it is just pap. Thus the term Smooth Jazz is often pejorative, yet check out this album and hear what smooooth can be at its very best. Simon's excellent melodies and relatively sophisticated harmonies, even at this early point in his career, were well above the pack, and the CTI arrangements here do them complete and utter justice, and then some. This may be mood music, but when the mood it puts you in is unfailingly happy and relaxed, and the musical quality is this high, I say bring on the mood music!Carter's supple bass, the delicate cymbal work of Airto et al, Herbie's very tasty Rhodes work, and the sweet but never saccharine strings make this one of the best CTI albums I know, GB etc included. Desmond gives them all lots of room to play, unlike some solo leaders, and they are clearly in his thrall, as they are all at their early best here. But when Paul comes floating in, you realize, dang, this guy plays more music by himself than most any full band. His touch with a melody can not be overstated. He embellishes every head with subtle flourishes and grace notes that bring the melody alive but never overwhelm it; you never forget what tune you're hearing, but he's still playing freely, if almost always well inside.Which might bother some for whom not going harmonically or melodically outside means it ain't jazz, but to my ears jazz is a feeling separate from those categories. It's a free, loose, happy, intelligent feeling, and that feeling is all over this fabulous album. Mrs. Robinson is a perfect example. That was a HUGE hit for S&G, and most cover versions are schmaltz and take the tune nowhere new. But man o man, this version is absolute heaven. It swings like crazy yet always feels tight and right, and PD tosses off melodic phrases like leaves in the autumn wind.Laying in the backyard that July day, my fellow music lovers and I looked at each other and smiled that special smile I used to see on the happy heads at the best '80s Dead shows, when Garcia was having one of those extra special nights. That look that says, we'll never be able to replicate this exact moment, so let's just luxuriate in it like dolphins in the ocean. This is what it's all about; this is why music is the best thing we know.And now, thirty years later, hearing the fine cd remaster of what has become my favorite Paul Desmond recording of nearly 100, I still get little shivers every time I put it on. I still prefer my old vinyl, pops and all, as it has a warmth that suits this music to a T, but the digital version is also very fine, gently remastered and not compressed, as so many now are; the Loudness War is anathema to this quality of gentle music, so thanks to the engineers for taking it easy on the digital levels. It's a short album, barely a half hour, but it bears being put on repeat for hours, as I often do while lying on the back porch sofa under the trees with my wonderful lady and our magnificent mutt, where it makes any day that much sweeter. I often think back to that July afternoon when I first heard this record, and hearing it takes me there in an instant. Very few records still hold that kind of sway over my mind, but Desmond's Bridge Over Troubled Water is so melodic, so tasteful, so smooth, so masterful, that I have never once tired of it in over three decades.If you have ANY interest in jazz, saxophone playing, inside improvisation, or just perfectly musical music, please do your ears a favor and get this album. It's still around in used record shops, as most jazz fans apparently see the cover and concept and pass it by; their loss, your gain! The gloriously colorful and hazy fold out cover is so apt for the music. I often spread it out and display it with other favorite vinyl covers on my Wall Of Joy, and when I see it I think of hundreds of perfect days and nights that have been made even finer with the addition of this music.I have no doubt that Paul Desmond is sitting beside God's favorite harp player in Heaven this very moment, and the endless Cocktail Party In The Sky goes on forever as everyone toasts Sir Desmond, one of the most musical musicians to ever grace our world. Thank you to PD for all of your shared musical gifts, and especially for this album, which despite being relatively unknown remains one of the most melodic slabs of joy my ears will ever know.

I love solar anything, when it works, and this one does. It also charges via USB, and is of course much faster that way, because solar cells, while improving, are still along way from even 50% efficient conversion. Still, this will easily charge via sunlight if you leave it out all afternoon in bright sun.The other pluses here are that it's very light, amazingly so, in fact; it comes with a carabiner for carrying, and a nice loop; the USB cord can be tied up around that loop so you never forget it; and the rubber case is quite solid. And the battery works just fine.The 5500 mah should charge most phones at least twice, and because this thing is so light and thin, it's easy to carry in your purse, etc. I keep the sample they sent us in the little console between our front car seats. The glove compartment gets way too hot to store any battery in, as heat discharges (and might even explode) any battery. Our console doesn't get hot at all, stays cooler than the car in fact, so it's a great place to keep this for emergency purposes. You can just leave it on your dash for charging as well.I'd have guessed this to cost 25 without solar and 35 with, so seeing it sell for 25 makes this an easy five stars. It feels solid and made to last, better than most portable batteries, and the rubber case and good construction make me think this might last quite a few years if kept fully charged all the time, as all batteries should be.At 25 bucks, this is a very good deal.

Diffusers seem to be growing in popularity lately, and here's another in the long list. Unfortunately, this one has some drawbacks.The sample they sent had only a USB cord, so it can only be used near a computer. The cord is about 3 feet long, which is a decent length, but not being able to place this out of the way in a corner is a hassle. As is opening this to put in water; there is no easy method, you have to hold the whole thing in your hands and kind of pry the top off. It takes very little water, and the aroma tends to last a short time, as the oil usually sinks and gets diffused quickly. Then you get hours and hours of the tiniest little stream of mist, which is nice if you are using it for the rainbow lights but doesn't add much to the smell of your room. Adding more oil is a drag due to the opening issue, as mentioned; it's too easy to spill the water.It also makes a little noise, not much but enough to be heard in an otherwise silent room, which the best diffusers avoid by being totally silent.That, along with the tricky opening, the USB cord, and the quite cheap plastic feel of the unit makes this three stars at its price of 25. I'd give it four for 15 bucks, but could never give it five stars even at five dollars. You can get much much better diffusers with none of those issues for 30-40 dollars.If you need a little unit for your cubicle or office, this is a decent option. Otherwise, shop around for diffusers of higher quality. There are plenty out there now.

This is a hefty, well made battery. It takes about 6 hours to charge from a computer USB outlet, but then recharges most any phone etc at least four times. It holds its charge well, and is a good solid hunk of metal. It's not as light as some other batts I own, but that's because it's made with more care, from what I've experienced using it so far. Its various over-charging protections work well, and make this a good battery for those who tend to forget it's plugged in for a day or two.When I get sent a review sample of any product, I avoid looking at its cost and use it for a while, then assign what I think is the price I would pay for the item to be worth five stars, assuming it's made with attention to lasting more than a year or two, as most things these days are. I guessed that this would be 35 bucks. I am surprised and impressed that it sells here for 24.That price with this quality makes this solid, well-made battery an easy five stars.

This is a serviceable headlamp, if not exactly heavy-duty. I have a bunch of these kinds of lamps, and the best still remain Zipkas. I've been using one of those for over 15 years without fail. By that standard, this is a merely fair light for roughly the same cost as the cheaper Zipkas.The sample they sent me does not have a red LED, as advertised. It does have a very flimsy battery cover that seems destined for breaking in the not distant future, however. The spot and floods are somewhat bright, but nowhere near as bright as other high-intensity headlamps now selling for the same price---28 bucks---or less. The strap is cumbersome compared to the best headlamp straps, and not stretchy elastic fabric like those. The buttons are kind of odd here, and also feel rather made-in-china cheap, as does the whole lamp, to be honest.It has worked well enough for the hours I've used it, but the cheap plastic feel of it doesn't bode well, from my experience with other knockoff headlamp brands. I will stick with Zipka due to their proven reliability and fair price; when I find something that works for many years I remain a loyal customer. Their models with the single string strap that zips back into the lamp makes this type of huge strap seem truly archaic. I am always open to a better mousetrap in all walks of life, but this is not one of them.If this cost 15 bucks, I'd give it five stars. 20 bucks, four stars. At 28, it's three stars.

I've been hoping Attell would release something as good as his immortal Skanks cd for a while, and here it is. His last few specials have been solid, but this is truly a legendarily great collection of live highlights from a short US tour in 2014, filmed by one onstage guy and two folks in each audience. Low budget and it works perfectly. Attell is easily the most underrated live comic working today---except by his peers and fans, who know how very very sharp and creative he is, and how much new material he's always writing, inculding a number of improv bits on stage here, many of which are excellent. Most comics have neither the balls nor the brains to be this loose and easy with a crowd, and still get 6 to 10 laughs a minute, for an hour-plus. That is legend territory, in with Carlin, Rock, Hicks and the other handful of standup greats.Attell's material here is as always nice and raunchy, pushing the boundaries in most every direction and making you wonder if there are any subjects that can't be turned into comedy gold. Why should there be? Comedy's job is exposing our foibles and moral inconsistencies, and no one does that better than this guy. The simple filming concept fits Dave's act to a T, and when he jokes about his career being dead, it's real irony: he might not have a TV show any more, and is still working clubs while other less talented and simply less funny guys are filling theaters, but Dave Atell is consistently delivering the funny like few comedians today, or ever.Strong words, but then this is one of the best standup shows I've seen in about a decade, almost all hit and no miss. Watching a true pro work the various rooms here, incorporating the decor of each club as well as slinging custom jokes tailored to each city, makes you realize how great most comics are not. It also makes this special worth watching over and over; it's a lot of fun watching a comic crack both the audience and himself up! There's very little ego in Attell, and plenty of talent. And man is his timing beyond perfect. He knows exactly when to let a laugh sink in and grow, and when to cut it off and take it to the next level, until the crowd is howling. That's mastery.Dave Attell might not be the biggest name going, maybe not even in the top 20 these days, but he is easily as funny as anyone else out there now. Gaffigan, CK, Barry, Rock, Chappelle and many others haven't put out anything this good in years. Dave has honed his wit to a fine edge, and is only getting better as he ages. If he keeps pumping out shows this good he should finally get the respect he deserves, and be filling theaters across the country. If he comes to your town...GO!!Even at 41 minutes, this is a great deal for five bucks, but really deserves a dvd of its own, with cutting room extras, of which there must be hours.All told, this is to me one of the best comedy specials by anyone in many years. In fact, the more I watch it the more I think it might be in the all-time pantheon. Get it if you like to laugh and aren't uptight or easily offended, as this is not "clean". This is not even blue. It's black humor at its best.Thanks for all the laughs, Dave! Your career ain't dead, buddy. It's just getting started. Rock on.

These dissolve very quickly under the tongue, in about a minute, and sublingual is the best way to abosrb many vitamins, especially B12. I like that the dosage per gummy is very small. Good for kids and also for adults; I like to stick one under my tongue before going running, gives a nice little boost and keeps the mouth moist.The quality of the ingredients is unusually good, if not perfect. Still, much better than most. The sweeteners are much, much better than most, if over-applied. The mix of oil and multi is a wise concept, and D3 is vital for dental health and remineralization, so it helps make up for all the sugars in here. These gummies really are very sweet.The price---20 bucks for 120 is about 16 cents a piece---is good, if not great. But, all told, these are a solid value and as long as your kids know that these are NOT candy, and too many are a real health hazard, these are worth checking out.

This is MASSIVELY overpriced.And it's soggy mush to boot.Apart from that, our dog eats it only if there is no other option offered. Adding warm water and then waiting for a while while it becomes firm mush is also rather pointless. In fact the only point I can see to dehydrated food like this is maybe travelling with it...but then you still need to heat up water. Standard good dry dog food still makes far more sense, and freshly homemade food for our furry loved ones makes far, far more sense. The one plus I see here is that they used realtively decent ingredients. It's nice to have human-standard food, but then again  I personally won't eat any of the GMO etc crap that passes as food these days, so it's not as if the FDA stamp of apporval means anything of use any more.Back to the price. This stuff adds up to about two hundred bucks a month for a fair-sized dog at this price! Are they kidding us? We can get the finest all-organic no-prep-needed dog food available for about half that. This price is insane.This is "boutique" dog food, for rich folks who need "love" written on their package to tell them that they are great people who really care about their dog. Hardcore dog lovers will be making food for their dog with fresh ingedients with their own hands...and still be paying half what this stuff costs, with the same prep time and far better ingredients. Andf they know their dog will love it.Did I mention our dog doesn't much like this stuff...and she's really not picky about food?She just doesn't enjoy exceptionally expensive mush, I guess.

I love top notch single malt scotch. I own a number of double-walled glasses. Here's what I think of these two sample glasses plus "Artisanal Hand-Cut" whiskey stones.First, as is obvious from the artisanal marketing slogan, there's no shortage of Hipster Factor involved in these products. But as a serious Scotch drinker, let me add a vital thing that it seems most new Scotch drinkers haven't learned...or aren't being told because it doesn't sell artisanal pebbles.The best Scotch is almost always drunk WITH a splash of spring or other good water...by the folks who make it. Yes, the whole "don't get ANY melted ice in your Scotch" is hoohaw. A little water helps bring out a Scotch's character and tames the alcohol edge that can overwhelm the more delicate aspects of a fine single malt's taste. Do some research and read interviews with top Scotch distillers. Few will tell you to drink it neat. A splash of water, or one or two ice cubes (though the cold lessens the taste) are preferred, and have been for centuries in Scotland. But what do Scots know about Scotch?Now back to these glasses. They're too thin.They are thinner than my other double-walleds, and I wondered about the safety of dropping the stones in to test them out. I gently placed them in and drank some Macallan 12 with stones in one glass, then with a bit of water in the other glass. The water one was far tastier. Artisanal or not, you might as well just freeze the glasses as put in cold stones. These stones go for 12 bucks alone, by the way(!) Good thing there are no free stones in your local creek, ain't it.So I think the stones here are unneeded, and hilariously over-priced to boot.The box the glasses come in is nice, however, thickly padded with heavy foam which has become a nice safe place to store my extra guitar amp tubes. So Teikis has got that going for them.The glasses do what dw glasses should, which is not sweat, and look kind of stylish. But two things to consider as a buyer: there are thicker versions available for less money, and the three one-star reviews here reveal some self-exploding glasses (from the thin glass plus a bad vacuum inside, perhaps). So, for 25 bucks, I can only give these three stars. Free or not, I'm giving these an honest review.And why not discuss that for a minute? As people who actually paid for these are complaining about, on this item's page and on many more items' pages on Amazon lately, those of us who get free stuff to review give them five stars very very very very often (ok, sorry, that's not fair, more like maybe only very very very often). This is becoming endemic here, and makes me as a customer begin to wonder what I really can trust on Amazon now.Funny little side note: I first mentioned this a few weeks ago in another review, and my rating dropped one hundred points almost overnight. I was top 500 for many years, then the first time I criticize Amazon openly they dump my rating, like I've been a bad little boy and must be spanked! Hohoho, getting a little greedy now, are we Mr. Bezos and friends? Is mistreating your workers like slaves not enough (go online and search for "Amazon workers mistreated" to see some very disturbing interviews and videos from BBC and elsewhere)? Now you also actively discourage what you've always said we reviewers should do: be 100% honest? How very phony, greedy and hypocritical. How many more hundreds of billions of dollars do you need, anyhow? Is it worth treating tens of thousands of temp workers like dirt? When is enough greed and deceit enough?Anyhow, perhaps this overly honest review will get my rating dropped another couple hundred points. From many years of being ranked in the 200s to 400s for being honest and accurate, then from 400 to 800 in weeks! For the very same reason, oddly. Honesty and Amazon are becoming distant cousins, it would appear. Please do feel free to dump my ranking because of this overly honest review; it would certainly expose your growing greed as a company even more. Maybe better to do it slowly, over a month or too, though; that way it looks less obvious that you don't truly want honest reviews any more, just lots of money. Fine by me, whatever you do, as I will still write honest, accurate reviews even if my ranking becomes 25,000,000. I didn't start writing here eight years ago to help Amazon, and I ain't doing it now. I write for people like me who simply want total honesty before they spent their hard-earned money.It's time people woke up to how this whole ratings system has become a Pavlovian reward for selling stuff for Amazon, and not saving customers money, time and sometimes even their health. (Broken glass is bad for fingers, isn't it?)But really, Amazon Ranking Drones, no worries, as readers here know to trust the quality of writing and thinking in reviews more than ranking. Now more than ever, in fact, with the very top reviewers usually giving five stars to 9 out of 10 items, or more; one of the very Top Scamazon Reviewers TM has given over 95 of their last 100 items five stars, and almost every one was for a free item. The low-starred reviews of this item and so many more show that I am but one of a rapidly growing number of readers and potential buyers here who are questioning how honest Amazon really is as a company. This could swiftly bite you in the corporate butt: five star reviews might become a sign of deceit and not quality, at this rate.And as a longtime Amazon shareholder who has only recently seen the evidence of how badly Amazon treats so many of their employees---the online WalMart is what Amazon is becoming, it appears----I say to Jeff Bezos and friends: stop cheating and gaming your own review system, and start treating your employees better!!!Finally, seeing as I'm being as 100% honest as Amazon has always told us to be (an incomparable feeling, truly), let me add another very vital detail: these glasses and Artisanal Hand-Cut stones were sent to me for free via Amazon shipping, not the company. Not every company chooses to do this, but more and more do, for this sneaky reason: it allows them to count it as a sale, thus falsely inflating the sales ranking of the item. Just as all the easy-five-stars-for-free reviews for items given away like this falsely inflate the rating of the product. Yes indeed, it's a never-discussed but very effective scam that Amazon seems to have no problems with. But when you treat your workers like slaves, why would you treat your customers any better?So there you go: the most honest Amazon review you may ever read.It will probably not make me any friends at Scamazon, but gee whiz, it may wake up lots of you, the readers and customers who support Scamazon and their increasingly shady business methods.. And I am one of you first and foremost, not a shill for Amazon or any drop-shippers-of-made-in-china-crap firm that tosses a couple of free trinkets at me then writes an angry email asking why I didn't give them five stars.Thus, my fellow readers and writers, I say look elsewhere for thicker, cheaper double-walled glasses, as there are many of them out there. These glasses plus the stones are ok at 25 bucks, but you can do better. Shopping online is all about comparing reviews and prices, so look around at various sites---and even better, LOCAL stores that hire your neighbors and treat them fairly!---and make your informed purchase.I do hope this review has been quite informative for many of you.Cheers!

Yes, this thing has various limitations: short battery life, weak camera and no bluetooth chief amongst them. But it is very thin and light, so not a lot of battery room, I suppose. Cameras, meh, 15 mp cams are now cheap so I prefer a dedicated, real SLR camera with real lenses. And the two-plus hours while watching a movie is plenty, especially as it'll work for days if you keep it plugged in to a little remote 5 or 10 mah battery which are now ubiquitous and very cheap. But it's worth four stars for me simply because it does so many other things so well...for 50 bucks.The 1080p is almost unbelievably crisp for a screen this small. The wifi works quickly and well, even though it's becoming ever clearer that Google is now the devil. Speaking of, the home page is default on Android and thus this box, natch, and when it came up it said, "Say 'OK Google". Like a sucker I did and suddenly the next thing I said was entered into the search box as text (reminding one that every mic around us these days is always on, and likely always recorded by TPTB)...followed by my next sentence to my better half, written as this by Gaggle: "Holy ****, these *********** are listening to us!" (What, I'm going to be offended by seeing what I just said in actual words? The PC Police are everywhere now, no doubt. **** all of those weaselly *************, by the way.)So I then said, "Is Google evil?", referring to their old (very old now, it turns out) slogan, Do No Evil. The first link that came up was a great blog post wherein the fellow points out that Google now has major shares in many of the most socially invasive markets, and are out to basically catalog and control the world's collective lives. Seriously, search for it, read it, and be amazed, dismayed, and justifiably enraged.Which perhaps answers my question: how can a screen this good and device this versatile be only 50 bucks? Gosh, maybe Google just gives away Android so that they can remotely listen and watch what everyone does for their masters at the NSA! Yes, do a little Google + NSA search/research about how they are, as with the internet itself, essentially a military/government project posing as everybody's pal (except creative artists...read Zoe Keating's recent piece about how Google/YouTube brutally rips off musicians and other artists). Thanks, Larry and Sergey! If this is No Evil, what's Evil? Guess we'll soon see...So perhaps that's why we are inundated with gaggles of everything Google now, including super-cheap hi-quality devices like this free sample I was sent. All I know is that after I watch something on this, I put it in its case, then in its box, then in a cupboard...just like we do with every smartphone-type device.Why be Winston Smith voluntarily?Yet here we are, not only carrying devices with us everywhere that can remotely record everything we do and say...but WE PAY for the "privilege"!If that's not Eisenhower's Military-Industrial Complex wet dream/nightamre come to life, what is?In any case, with 8gb memory plus room for 32 more on sd card, a serviceable 512 ram, and a picture this good, this makes a decent leave-it-in-the-car emergency internet or movie-watching device, and for 55 bucks, you can even lose it without remorse, or perhaps even toss it in the ocean while intoning, "Google, thou art the Devil, begone with your greedhead owners to the depths of Hades from whence you slithered!"

This is a good neck pillow. I have a bunch of these things, and my favorite has beads in it, which somehow seem to massage my neck while I use it. This memory foam version is a little firmer, maybe a tad too firm for me but perhaps perfect for airplane travelers who need their head to stay very put while snoozing. I like the removable cover; the grey sample they sent washed up well with no fading, but make sure to not put it in the drier, as it will shrink a bit.My only niggle would be that I'd be more likely to pay 10-15 for this rather than 20; my bead pillow cost seven bucks and I like it more. But its cover doesn't come off, so that is its one minus. If you use your pillow a lot and need the washable cover, this is a decent choice.

This is basically generic Frontline under another name. It is cheaper than Frontline, but nowhere near as cheaper as a generic should be; you're still paying a hefty pricetag for a tiny bit of chemical. This could and should easily be ten bucks, not 19, and they'd still be making massive margins. Frontline Plus is still the best we've tried, but it has a much higher priceteg than most brands, though buying it at bulk stores gives a fine price break.In any case, vets recommend switching between brands of Fipronil-containing meds every month or two, as fleas are developing immunity to various formulations and that helps slow that process. So this is a decent choice for those off-months.But seriously, Big Pharma, or rather Medium Pharma (the knockoff firms who do generics): make this stuff for ten bucks and you will do business like you never imagined. There are a lot of us with dogs out here...what's ten bucks times ten or twenty million...every few months?That's a very nice QR for your shareholders...

I like this belt, it's a very useful idea for nighttime runners. It offers three modes: all blue, fast flash, and slow flash. It also has a double zipper around almost all of the belt, good for storing cash and keys but not much else, as the pouch is by design only a couple inches high and barely half an inch deep. But it's the lights that sell this thing, not the pockets. The clasp is solid enough and should stay on well, very similar to most heavy backpack clasps.So if I like this, why only three stars? Simple: it costs WAY too much. 30 bucks is at least ten bucks too much. These LEDs are cheap as heck to make now, maybe a penny a piece, and this while thing is just nylon webbing, a plastic clasp, and a couple zippers. It's made well but simply ain't worth 30 clams. If you need one of these now, go ahead, but I think many other firms will be knocking these off like crazy within a few months for 10-15 bucks, so I wouldn't pay 30 for one just yet. They sent me a sample for an honest review, and here it is: good runner's belt, but overpriced.

These don't replace a Furminator-type brush, but along with one of those these give you most everything your pooch needs to stay clean. I like the wide brush best, as it goes deeper than a furmy and gives a nice little skin massage along with pulling out lots of old hair. It doesn't clump onto the brush like a furmy though, so best to use it outside or on a towel to catch all the hair and dead skin, etc. The other brush is an all-in-one deal, not bad, and the dematter is good to have after messy park trip etc.The samples they sent are made well enough to last for a few years at least, and at 13 bucks total, the price is very good, considering what some specialty pet stores charge for similarly basic plastic made in china stuff. I'd pay about 8-10 for the wide brush alone, so this is a very decent for three useful doggy brushes.

I have now researched DVP more thoroughly. Turns out they were bought out by Del Monte, a super-sleazy multi-national who don't give a damn about my dog or yours. They source some of their ingredients in China and MANY people have reported their dogs becoming very sick with UTI's and other serious issues since they have started using China's sickeningly greedy and morally bankrupt suppliers.Let me just say this:NEVER BUY ANY NATURAL BALANCE AGAIN IF YOU LOVE YOUR DOG!!There are many brands for far less money that are sourced from people who care.Don't support these greedy corporate weasels.I apologize for not researching this company better for previous reviews. I hope to make up for it by costing them a lot of business. They don't care about my dog, why should I gave a damn about their bloated corporate profits?Dick Van Patten must be turning in his grave. SHAME on whomever in his family sold this good brand to the Del Monte scumbags.

I think the Pro-15 is the best probiotic I've ever used, though expensive, so I was looking forward to trying this formula for colds and sickness in general. I got this sample three months ago, but have been perfectly healthy until recently, when I caught the flu that's been going around from a friend who works with kids (I know to always wipe my eyes with my sleeve, not my hands, but after a few beers I forgot, and paid the price). I got it pretty good too, simultaneous chills and fever, and about 12 hours in I felt so bad I started laughing at how painful it was just to expose a bare arm to the air (embrace your pain to erase it!) . Then I remembered I had this stuff.I had already been hitting the echinacea-goldenseal tincture and Vitamin C every two hours, which always works for me. Then I remembered having this stuff, and took one. In about an hour I felt a definite lifting of the worst of it. Took another after 6 hours, and within 12 hours I felt like I had a mild cold. Three days later there was little trace of anything. Whereas other folks I knew who'd caught the same flu had it bad for at least three days, some of them a week. So I know this helped.Which only makes sense, as it combines four of the most vital compounds to battle sickness: C (the king and queen of illness prevention and cure), zinc (which is a great acute immune system boost), echinacea and a vast spectrum of probiotics. I've been taking probiotics off and on for about 15 years, as needed, and these are as good as the Pro-15. They work fast, and you'll be pooping within a few hours. I believe in fasting when sick, drinking only liquids and vegetable soup, as a clean gut is the easiest way to let your body focus on the infection. Digestion takes a lot of energy. A good probiotic will help empty your colon fast and let your body go to work on the virus.That's what happened here, and in this case the high cost is almost no issue at all. When you're really sick, relief is at a premium. Getting rid of that wicked flu in a day was wonderful, and I know this stuff helped. I think echinacea is more of a long-term preventative than a quick attack---goldenseal does that best---but everything else here is exactly what I usually take separately. Plus they use "EpiCor", a fruit-derived substance I know nothing about, but it seems to work and that's the main detail I care about.While I recommend splitting the Pro-15 pills in half to get more value and almost the same effect, I would say take a whole pill of this Pro-Immune formula when you get sick or feel like you're about to (sore throat, tiredness, aches). The buck a pill or so will end being a bargain as you won't need to buy much else. I took two of these while sick; two bucks is a small price compared to many "remedies" that barely work. Although I still advise at least a gram of Vit C every day of your life, and five to ten times that when sick. You can't OD on C, and as Linus Pauling proved, it cures cancer and just about everything else (please research C in real depth to learn about Nature's greatest gift to our bodies, aside from pure water).They gave me this stuff for free, but I will buy more when it's gone; I can't offer a better rec than that. The thing I really like about the Hyperbiotics pro's is that they are shelf-stable and don't need to be refrigerated, unlike almost all other pro's. For a sickness formula you'll only use a few times a year, that makes these a good deal at any price under a buck a pill. I still keep them in the fridge though; it can only make them last longer.Highly recommended to combat and ward off illness, along with a gallon of pure water a day, and always lots of Vitamin C.

3.7 starsThis is a decent machine, but it's more for the in-a-hurry morning folks than serious java aficionados.If you need convenience, here it is. But there are some negatives that come along with the ease of use.The good things:-You can just put beans in before you go to bed, set the timer, and wake to a freshly ground and brewed cup of coffee. That's pretty sweet for the morning commute, doubly so if you have a few folks in the house to share the coffee. If you're going to have a 12-cup large coffee maker like this, it's nice to justify that size.-Put the filter and the carafe into the dishwasher and you're good to go.-This would be good for an office; set it before you leave at night and when everyone gets there in the morning, fresh coffee and lots of it.-Easy to dump out the grounds into your compost. I always compost coffee grounds, they make great soil and our tomatoes love that coffee ground mix.-Makes very good coffee. Not the best, but I'd give it an 8 out of 10 for taste compared to the way I prefer to do it. (See below.)The not so good things:-The worst thing is all the plastic. Not only is most of the body plastic, but the filter parts are too, and boiling water plus plastic equals leaching and plastic taste, never good. That's a real knock here. The filter and all parts that touch boiling water should be stainless steel, like any good french press, which make the best coffee in my estimation.-It's made in that country where quality control seems the absolute last concern, but then so is most everything these days. Gotta keep those corporate profits high! Employing people in your company's home country? Not so vital, apparently.-I prefer real buttons to these plastic overlays. They often go bad within a year or two and are a hassle to fix.-This thing is LARGE. Wider than most coffee machines and not short either. Depending on your counter space, this might take up too much space for some folks.-If you don't have a dishwasher, the filter/blade combo is a pain. It's hard to clean the underside of the blade.-The grinder doesn't grind fine enough on the highest setting for my preference. It's nice to have varied settings but the top one should be finer.-They probably do that because when properly fine, the filter lets a tiny bit through and you get some grit in your cup. It settles, but still, not ideal. That's why I prefer a french press.-Which leads to this thought: do you really need a 12-cup machine? This one is rather huge.My preferred coffee ritual is to grind beans in my old Krups or Braun grinders to a very fine grind, then brew in a small four cup french press with all-metal parts. The taste is perfection, there are zero grounds in the coffee, and it's all very easy to rinse clean in a jiffy. We have a Keurig too, but it doesn't compare to a quality press either.French press plus grinder is my recommendation for single or a few cups, by far. A good grinder is only 20 bucks at most, and a good french press only 30. That's 30 less in total than this machine's price of 80 here now. Plus you can grind the beans precisely as you like them, from very coarse to pure powder, and no grounds in your cup with a good filter in your press, no matter how fine you like your cuppa joe.But, as mentioned, if you have lots of counter space, a dishwasher and a specific time you get up every morning, the convenience here certainly might be worth the money for you. If that's your situation, this is worth checking out.

Edit, 2/18/2015: I have now researched DVP more thoroughly. Turns out they were bought out by Del Monte, a super-sleazy multi-national who don't give a damn about my dog or yours. They source some of their ingredients in China and MANY people have reported their dogs becoming very sick with UTI's and other serious issues since they have started using China's sickeningly greedy and morally bankrupt suppliers.Let me just say this:NEVER BUY ANY NATURAL BALANCE AGAIN IF YOU LOVE YOUR DOG!!There are many brands for far less money that are sourced from people who care.Don't support these greedy corporate weasels.I apologize for not researching this company better for previous reviews. I hope to make up for it by costing them a lot of business. They don't care about my dog, why should I gave a damn about their bloated corporate profits?Please read about these issues on consumeraffiars dot com, and many other places.Dick Van Patten must be turning in his grave. SHAME on whomever in his family sold this good brand to the Del Monte scumbags.  *************************************************At less than three bucks a pound this is a pretty good deal, not up to the buck a pound for good doggy food that Kirkland offers, but still solid for bison-based kibble. Bison is very good meat; there are no factory bison farms that I know of, it's all free-range so your dog is getting less chemicals and antibiotics than any chicken-based foods. I also like the bigger pieces: makes dogs chew more, which keeps them fuller and is good for their teeth.Edit: I wonder if they are growing bisons in big cages in China? Wouldn't surprise me at all.It sickens me that Del Monte will endanger all of our furry loved ones for their own profit.I WILL NEVER BUY ANOTHER DEL MONTE PRODUCT AGAIN.

These multiple usb outlet chargers are pretty standard these days, and I've tried a bunch of them and own a few. This is a good one with plenty of power to charge your phone or computer etc quickly. The slow and fast outlets seem to charge at roughly the same rate, but it's quick in any case, a few hours for most devices I've put into the sample charger they sent me. It's very simply laid out, an on button and five outlets, plus a wall wart that's almost as big as the charger but at least it has a long cord on both sides to facilitate hiding it.I say hiding it because I assume anyone paying 40 bucks for this unit is doing so for the look of the real wood case, for this costs about twice what most comparable basic plastic case units do. That's my one knock on this item; you really do pay a premium for the wood. But if you want a nice-looking charger sitting on your office desk, this will do very nicely, as the wood grain is very pronounced and quite attractive.In any case, this is a very solid charger. In the case that you don't mind paying top dollar for the fine case, then this is a good buy.

In short, these are excellent for gaming, but not so much for just listening to music. They have punchy, solid bass for all of your boss-destroying pleasure, and the boom mic is good quality. But the upper mids and top end are less natural than one would like for musical listening, and these simply don't compare to their Sennheiser competitors for doing both jobs well, though they do have more bass.They are comfortable enough, but if you have a larger cranium, try out the various other wireless gaming headphone options and see if these feel too tight compared to their competitors. They get their bass from their large cups and seal, so it's part and parcel. For normal or smaller heads, say 7 1/4 and under, no issues at all.I would definitely recommend two sets of three AAA batteries to switch between while charging, as these will chew through normal batteries way too fast at normal gaming rates. I'm no hardcore online player, but I can see that you'd really need that extra set to play long sessions without breaks. The corded version of these is very bulky, so the wireless version is a whole lot easier to wear.All in all, I wouldn't recommend these for both music and gaming, but if you're dedicating them purely for gaming---which makes sense as few cans will do both perfectly---then these will give you all the oomph you'd ever want, and the wireless gives you plenty of freedom to move around unencumbered.

SHAME on whomever in his family sold this good brand to the Del Monte scumbags..  *********************************************************Our furry friend likes these sticks a lot, but we'd prefer that molasses not be such a main ingredient. Apart from that and the mildly high price, this is a good snack with plenty of quality protein. Here's hoping that the ducks are treated better than factory chickens. In fact, if anybody knows about this---we're calling you, DVP company reps who certainly must read these reviews---please let us know how the ducks are raised. Our pooch ate this right up first time out, but then there are few foods she doesn't like. She got a little rambunctious afterward, which I ascribe to both something new on her menu and the (truly minimal) bits of freeze-dried raw meat in here, but we're talking one bit in maybe fifty or so, so the whole "raw boost" aspect here is more marketing than substantive. They are in there though...you can tell because they're a different color! Oh those clever marketers.I do appreciate the ingredients in general here, there are a wide array of good things, including probiotics which those who are victim to older dogs' farts will certainly value highly. Salmon, turkey, a little bit of kelp and broccoli and many other varied foods provide a good nutritional spectrum. The main ingredient is chicken, and I really wish, especially at this high price, that it was free-range or organic. If you're going to charge five bucks a pound, at least use some non-factory-farm chicken, guys! This stuff is full of antibiotics and GMO feed, and where's the health benefit in that for our dogs, or our environment? (Please look up the billions of pounds of fecal matter, blood etc that factory farms dump into our rivers and lakes every year). So I'm less than impressed by that aspect here.They also make a big deal about this being grain-free, but frankly I've found that all of my dogs have loved some whole grains in their diets, especially brown rice and whole wheat. Animal protein is vital, yes, but dogs are omnivores just like us, and a wide diet is a wise thing and makes our dog happiest and healthiest. We feed her various dog foods and raw food and stuff we make for her, and a good mix of it all keeps her very jolly indeed. Her favorite is still Kirkland lamb-based kibble, which is good stuff, and at just over a dollar a pound it sure is hard to see replacing that with this, at five times the price.But she does enjoy this Instinct food, and we'll give it to her in rotation with the many other things we share with her to keep her diet fun. (Imagine eating the same food every meal for years! Crazy that so many of us think such a mono-diet will keep our dogs as happy as they could be.) There are lots of good foods in here and as a spice of life every few days this is welcome in her always happily-eyed food dish.

There are a number of things I like about this stuff. The vegetable base, the vegan proteins, the enzymes, the lack of any GMO ingredients, the mild sweetening; I even like the very mildly chocolate taste, unlike many reviewers here. Not great but not bad. I ALWAYS put any powder destined to become liquid into a blender, even when it says "shake or stir into water". A lot of the chalky consistency and even taste issues people complain about with protein powders go away when the stuff is properly and heavily blended for thirty seconds. I also use plain organic almond milk, which thickens the drink and makes it far more palatable. It helps powders to have something to bind with in the liquid as well; water never quite does the trick for me.There's plenty of protein here, so I only use half the recommended amount, as I only want about 10-15 grams of protein per meal or snack. My personal experience is that we are hyped by the media to take WAY more protein than we need every day. I find 50 grams or less is plenty for me, and more simply goes undigested or slows me down in various ways. I am in good shape and exercise a lot, and even then I find 10-15 grams of protein is plenty at a time, even easily assimilable veggie proteins.But, there are also a number of things I don't like about this Vega protein powder. The first is that the container is huge...for no reason. Opening it up, I found the container 2/3 full. "Settling during shipping" blah blah, whatever. NOW and other brands pack the stuff in and save me cupboard space, but Vega seems to think using 50% more plastic than they need to, and taking up 50% more of our cupboards than they need to, makes sense. I sure don't. I think it's a waste of energy and space, and is mindless. I think they do it to justify the price.The price is the main thing I don't dig here. 40 bucks, or 50 MSRP, is just too much for this, especially as it has no organic ingredients. I can get various protein powders that are mostly organic for less than this stuff...so why pay this much for non-organic? It doesn't make sense, nor does a company called Vega---thus trumpeting their vegan creds---who won't got the extra mile and source organic ingredients.I'd pay twenty bucks for this, maybe 25. 40 is way too much. Add the pointlessly massive container and lack of any organic ingredients and no way does this justify a 40-50 dollar price tag.I do applaud Vega's basic concept, but will wait until they package stuff more wisely and use better ingredients before shelling out what they're asking for this powder.

I was offered this as a review sample, and loved the concept, so I tried one out. In short, I love this idea, but wish the execution was better.The instructions are so tiny I had issues reading them and had to read reviews here to realize you have to wait 30 seconds after turning the mic on for the blue light to signal it's ready to record. To me that's a big minus, as a device like this is mainly useful for sudden ideas etc to me, and waiting 30 seconds is a drag. I was going to use it to record song and writing ideas when waking from dreams, which I often have, but waiting 30 seconds makes that kind of pointless, unless I plan on staying awake.The quality is fair, not great but not bad. It might be 384 kbps but it sounds like 64. At least it's 16 gb, so space is no issue.But for 26 bucks, I would expect this to work within a couple of seconds, not 30. And for the instructions to be clearer, and bigger. It is however nice to have something this small to carry around as an emergency notepad, so that's a plus, no doubt.All told, it's worth three stars for what it does, but loses those other stars for what it won't do.

For fifteen bucks, this is a good deal. The LED is very bright and can be focused to be even brighter. The included battery lasts for many hours and is LI so it will hold the charge for months. This makes it a great option for keeping in the car as an emergency light, and it also has a flashing strobe mode for alerting cops, etc.It's made of tough metal; I dropped it onto concrete from three feet with zero issues at all. The clip on it is also very useful, as is the plastic case with the little charger.For a solid rechargeable flashlight with these features, I'd pay 20 with no qualms, so 15 is a very fair price. They sent this as a review sample, and I'd gladly buy another at this price. I've used many crappy plastic flashlights that chewed up batteries in an hour, so this is a true upgrade to that sort of junk.

Gund has always made the plushest, softest kid's s toys. They also last pretty well. This one is likewise super soft and seems well made, with solid seams and nothing for a little kid to pull apart, except maybe the feather, which won't sit up straight like in the pictures. But that's about the only mini-complaint here. Mostly this is just a really fun little toy at a good price. It's a pretty cute little monkey as well.The best thing is that the ball lights up in rainbow colors and is quite entertaining to look at for kids of all ages.
