There are almost two dozen different answers, mostly variations on yes and no with a few maybes. The monkey's voice is maybe a little squeaky, but then a basso profundo hardly makes sense. The on-off switches hidden in the paws (nice touch) work well and seem unlikely to break, and it's easy to change the batteries, though I think there won't be much need for that, as the LED lights and the voice module use little juice. The moving mouth, which is quite amusing, probably uses the most energy, but even then we've used this as a kind of basic I Ching many times as we walk by its perch on the shelf and it's still showing no signs of monkey non-business. It's surprisingly accurate, too. Perhaps there's a job in Congress and/or Senate for it.All in all, for twenty bucks this would be a decent deal even without the light show and fortune teller aspect. With them, and the promise of Gund quality helping it stand up to lots of monkeyshines as time goes by, this is a good value that might last quite a few years, a rarity for a moving toy these days. This is a cuddly little pal and could easily become a kid's favorite furry toy.

Shane was obviously a one-off, a guy with less fear about risking his life skiing down near-vertical mountainsides and jumping off buildings and bridges than most of us have just walking down the street. There's some incredible footage of his many astounding feats here, no doubt. But somehow despite all that, I was left feeling that this film could have been better.No complaints about the endless spectacular stunts shown, and watching it just for that will leave anyone who appreciates true daring exhilarated and maybe exhausted. McConkey routinely went for tricks that even the average daredevil considered insane, and seeing some of them will put butterflies in your gut. There's a lot of mind-blowing footage here, footage that Shane risked his life for time and time again.Was it worth it? That's the very tough question that this film sort of attempts to answer, rather than simply showing the stunts. But by the sad end (no spoilers here, it's pretty clear from the start that Shane is no longer with us, and if you're watching this you probably know that already), I was left with a few questions about the way this film showed Shane's life.The best thing here is McConkey's sense of humor. He didn't take life too seriously and was a truly funny fellow. His naked ski runs show a guy who just wanted to have fun, and also to remind others that fun is what skiing, and life, are all about for him. That love of laughter, combined with Shane's maniacal quest for extreme thrills as a way of daily existence, made him a truly unique individual. He did what he loved, every day. How many of us can say that? However you measure success, it can't be far from that.One fascinating thing early in the film was after he left school and was floating around looking for what he wanted to do. A number of people say, "He was aimless, and he was living in a little shack, and he was even a busboy." OMG!! A busboy?! O the shame. So what? The shots of him during that time show a very happy young man doing what he loves. So what was the problem? Many people NEVER figure out why they want to do. Why would the son of a (successful) skibum want to start seeking security when he just got out of school? The guy just wanted to ski. So why do his some of his friends and family look back at it like he was somehow a failure for taking his time, eschewing greed and security for the freedom of chasing his dreams? That's a strange thing here, but Shane showed that following your bliss is how you get to be happy, that's for sure. Was he happy? He sure seemed to be. Maybe guys like him will never be happy unless they are risking their lives. Thanatos for happiness? Some people are just wired that way.I know some will say, this guy is selfish for risking his life after he was married with a kid. I don't fully subscribe to that notion. His wife married him knowing full well who he was and what he did. They both wanted to have kids, though he wanted them sooner. Upon hearing her say that, my first thought was he knew the odds were that he was going to buy the farm sooner than later at the rate he kept jacking up the risk level in his stunts. Thus he wanted a kid as soon as possible just in case that was true. Is that a selfish thought? Very tough question, and one I can't answer. It was his life to risk, after all is said and done.But one of the issues with that is that this film makes it clear how deeply affected he was by not having his father around as a kid, and how he ended up idolizing his father's uber-skibum ways, and carried on likewise. Was this in his DNA, or was it a product of his emulating the man his Mom clearly didn't like, seeing as she left him when Shane was 5 and moved thousands of miles away? Interestingly, she comes off as quite bitter here, while his father seems like he's at peace with his son's decisions and life. He never left Shane, it's worth noting; his Mom took him away from his father.But Shane knew what he wanted from life, and it was what his Dad wanted: thrills and fun! And he sure got them, as this film shows. But one of the things I found a little lacking here, as this film tries to be a doc and not just a typical highlights film, is that they barely mention the many brutal injuries McConkey suffered throughout his career. They're mentioned briefly in passing, and only near the end of the film. I felt they should have been integral to the course of the film; as it is, it all seems almost safe and doable to the average kid watching this, and you know there will be plenty. Shane rarely wore a helmet for some of his most nutty stunts, but hey, he was one in a billion, and most kids don't have his intense skillset. A little more emphasis on safety would have been nice.For instance, it's mentioned in passing a couple times that Shane was very careful about planning his stunts. But we almost never see him doing that, or hear about how he did it. That is a VITAL detail! This flick often makes it seem like the guy just saw a cliff and skied off it. We need, I mean the kids watching this need, a little more awareness of how much work and planning went into these stunts. At least, I think they do. Maybe I'm wrong, the filmmakers bear no responsibility of that sort, and it's all fun and games until someone pokes your eye out with a stick.But let's be honest. McConkey died doing an almost pointlessly dangerous stunt, one he obviously didn't prep well enough for. One he was maybe too old to reliably pull off. One maybe he shouldn't have ever attempted with a little daughter waiting for him. One that left her to be raised by her Mom, just like her Dad was. Except she won't get to reconcile with her father years hence.Does that make Shane selfish? Probably, but I really don't think it's our place to judge him for it. He made his living doing these things. He paid his family's way risking his life. His wife knew that and accepted that's who he was. She's a cool lady and she understood. But his daughter didn't. Will she one day? Probably, but it's still all very sad. Yet in the end, it was McConkey's choice to make, and make it he did.Which brings up the question this film neatly sidesteps, though it's truly at the heart of the project and of Shane's life: was it all worth it? Was all that crazy footage worth his life? He clearly thought so, and so do the filmmakers, judging by how they avoid the subject of his death until the very end, instead of leveraging his achievements with it as the film goes along. The guy never really grew up, and seeking thrills was his sole raison d'etre, even after having a family. Is that admirable?That's for each of us to decide, and I wish it was examined more carefully throughout the film. If you read the many books about the Everest catastrophes, for instance, you see over and over men deciding that their thrill of climbing paled in comparison with staying healthy for their loved ones' sakes. It took a near-death experience to wake them up to that. Shane had those basically every day! His decision was to never stop seeking them, because they made him feel good. Is that selfish? Well, look at how many of us are entertained by his risk-taking. We give him (and the cameramen who make their money from others risking their lives) our cash in return for seeing them take chances we never would, or could.And it's that "could" that I wish we saw more of here. McConkey was a freak, a super-talented guy who decided death was just an inevitable side effect of seeking the most extreme thrills. But most of us watching this, and especially the kids, might think they can try this stuff too...without the benefit of seeing how Shane carefully planned the stunts, or what training he put in, or even all of the brutal injuries he suffered, again and again. This film kind of seems like it takes advantage of the footage Shane risked his life for, while rarely showing what work led to that footage. It's all a lark! That feels somehow wrong.But maybe that's not the filmmakers' job, and it's all about the thrills and the fun. But if that's the case, why was I left feeling sad after watching this? Not just for Shane's wife and fatherless child, but for the 99.999% of kids watching this who will never have the innate talent that McConkey did, but think they do, and take chances far beyond their abilities. And also for Shane, in a way. What drives a man to risk the life he had worked for and achieved (admittedly by risking his life)? We get hints of an honest look at that question here, but somehow it feels not only sad but unsatisfying by the end.Maybe I'm crazy though, and this is all just radical fun, dude! One thing for sure: if you want to see a lot of death-defying stunts, and one that wasn't, here they are.Wheeeee.

This is quality stuff. A lot of thought was clearly put into these products, as they all accomplish what they're supposed to, which many brands do not, and entirely without any toxic chemicals. Most standard household products use a potpourri of carcinogens, simply to save their corporate masters some money. What they do to our health is of far less concern to corporations like Procter and Gamble than how much money they can make from us. It's nice to find a company that offers instead a better product that is also entirely safe to use, and at a fair price.I like this multi-pack, as it lets you get all the usual cleaning stuff at once to compare with what you usually use to see if it truly is better. When you figure the individual price of each item, it works out to being quite cheap per product, so it's not only a good sampler, it's a good way to save some cash.My favorite of the bunch is the hand soap, which I normally never use. Most types leave a film on my hands, and feel odd. This stuff is basically transparent after use, to the extent that I can use it for washing my face and have a completely clean feeling after, just like my favorite soap, Dr. Bronner's. There is very little scent, which I prefer, and it takes a dab to clean my hands or face. This stuff is as good as Bronner's, which is as good as it gets in my book.The laundry detergent works well, is very concentrated, easy to dispense from the pump, and gets clothes very clean with only a tiny fresh citrus scent left. I like that, as I don't want my clothes to smell like perfume.The stain remover actually works! We've used other types that didn't do much, or left a bleached spot. This stuff doesn't leave any mark, and after spraying on and leaving it for half an hour then washing it, we got rid of some stains on a white shirt that have stayed there for over a year. Plus it takes very little of this liquid to do the job, so it cost a couple of cents to get rid of what were previously rather incorrigible stains. My better half asked me to say how very effective it is on every type of stain we've tried it on; she was surprised and happy at how well it works.And we don't discuss laundry very much, so for her to mention it is a sign of how uniquely good this stuff is.The multi-surface cleaner is decent, though we haven't really found any stains for it to show its magic on that we couldn't get off with just plain water. Maybe we'll get some crayon marks on the walls to try it on...but we'd rather not!This dish soap, on the other hand, has had plenty of grease etc to tackle, and it works perfectly. It takes very little to foam up enough to do a load of dishes, and it cuts through even baked-on grease that I forgot to soak. It also leaves absolutely no film or smell on the plates or glasses, and the glasses rinse spotless.I think Puracy will be gaining more and more fans as families realize how much their health is affected by the normal crap we all usually buy. People are increasingly aware of the dangers of all those chemicals, and when a company takes the time and care to offer completely clean alternative products at a fair price, they're bound to do well. These guys deserve to, as they created excellent cleaning products I can feel good about my family using every day. They offered these as samples for us to try, and the highest praise I can give is that we'll be buying more of them when these are finished.

[Edit: Five stars to three stars. After two months, this thing does NOT hook up automatically every time we move it from one socket to another. We have to turn everything off, plug this in, then turn on the router and the computer and then we get five bars MOST of the time, but even then sometimes it won't hook up. Sad, as it hooked up quickly at first. TP-Link had this issue with the last version of this, so it's not impressive that MkII is having the same problem.]We can never get a full signal in the guest room or office, so I thought I 'd see if this would help.We have a TP-Link pocket router, so I figured they'd hook up easy. But I forgot to see if the router had a WPS button. Turns out it doesn't. So I had to do the other setup, where you:-plug this into the wall-go online to the TP site they list in the instructions-type "admin" in both boxes-disconnect from wifi on your computer-enter your router password-wait two minutes for this to hook up automatically to your router-turn the wifi back on on your computerTook me about four minutes total.And there you go. Without this we get two bars in the guest room, one in the office.Now it's five and four!Yay.They say to put this in between your router and the computer, in an open area like a side wall in the middle of a room, but I have it five feet from the router, and it still goes through the walls (or around the corners) like a champ. It might work even better in between as advised, but it works perfectly like this as well.It definitely also makes surfing the net faster and we haven't had one dropout all day, whereas we often have about one an hour. (I sure hope this unit is why, as that would be a major bonus, especially when dealing with the greedy corporate nightmare that is Time Burner, maybe the worst company in the world. Money-saving tip: we use their cheapest service, as we found the top tier to be not much faster for three times the price; with this thing we get better speed than TW's top tier gave us on both our laptops, at one-third the price.)You can also plug this little guy into any socket and after 30 seconds it resets itself and is good to go in that room. Which means you can get good wireless outside, in the attic, etc. And for 30 bucks, that's a good deal.By the way, we've had the TP router for over a year with zero issues, and when we needed to call their customer support to set it up they were some of the most efficient, friendly folks I've ever met in CS, so that's a big plus.Nothing to not like with this range extender for us so far. Easy to set up, and if you have a WPS button, even easier. I'd pay 30-50 for this, so at 30 it's a very fair deal, and an easy five stars.I see that the last version of this needed a firmware update out of the box (this version fixed that...I hope!), and folks had issues with it after a few months, so if I have issues I'll come back here and post them.Fingers crossed...but so far it's been a very simple and powerful little device.

To my mild amazement, this thing seems to be working.I don't know why I'm surprised; people across the world have been wearing copper bracelets etc for millenia, so there's probably a reason for that. (I even recall seeing Hercules and Conan wearing thick copper wrist rings, and gosh, they're pretty strong!) But if you look online, Western Medicine TM is very quick to say "copper bracelets don't work". Of course, experience has shown that old WM doesn't like anything that is natural, cheap and effective. How can you sell billions of dollars in pills every day when people might buy something once for a few bucks and have it work for them for years?But still, part of me is a skeptic, and I need to see and feel proof before I believe anything.So when I heard these bracelets can help arthritis and joint pain, etc, I decided to try this sample and see.I got it a few months ago, put it on for a few days, noticed nothing different, and thought, oh well. So I put it in a drawer and forgot about it.Then this week I was playing a lot of guitar one night; sometimes I'll practice 4, 6 or even 8 hours straight while watching movies or reading or just wailing away. And after a few hours my left wrist and fingers can get pretty sore, and I have to take frequent breaks. My inner voice said, "Hey bozo, where's that copper bracelet?"I dug it out and put it on.And to my great and happy surprise, my wrist and finger tendons slowly stopped feeling sore.I kept playing for over 7 hours total, and felt great afterwards. So I wore this thing to bed. Slept well, maybe a little better than normal but nothing spectacular. But then the next day I decided to really test this thing out, and I plugged in and started playing riffs like mad, every Zep, Jimi, Floyd, ZZ, Santana, Van Halen etc solo and song I could remember, for hours on end. Hundreds of riffs and solos, blasting away, playing as fast as I could to see what happened to my wrist.Incredibly, I played four hours with only a brief break, and NO wrist pain!The only thing I had changed was wearing this bracelet. So I know it does work, for me, for this issue. But what makes it work? Is it the copper, which is said to enter your bloodstream very gently while mixing with your sweat, and balance your brain chemistry a little better as well? Is it the six magnets? That could be it, as I believe we are being massively hurt by the wireless frequencies we are all now surrounded by every day, all day and night. We are very sensitive electromagnetic beings, and the cell phone grid is now all-pervasive; how can that be good for our bodies' magnetic fields?Well, whatever makes this work, it DOES work. For me, at least. It's more than just a little discernible; it stops my wrist pain. I also seem to feel a bit more balanced and grounded while wearing it, and my temper seems a little more stable while driving. Copper bracelets for road rage!This is pure copper, and very flexible, easy to get on and off and easy to shape to my wrist perfectly. I wear it with the opening on top, as that seems to work better for me and be more comfortable. I hate jewelry and wear no rings or watch etc, but this doesn't bug me at all, got used to it in hours. It also doesn't leave a green mark on my wrist as others say some copper bracelets do to them.If this thing was bunk, I'd say so in two seconds. But I've felt the difference and I know it works for me.Do all copper bracelets work? No idea, I've only tried this one. Some cost only six bucks, while this is almost 30.Is it worth it? If it works, it sure is. Try a few and see, and then please write a review and let us all know!Is it the magnets, the copper, or the synergy of the two together? Probably the latter, but who knows.All I know is that this does work. For me.So if you have sore joints, arthritis etc, they give you a month money-back guarantee on this. Try it, and if it does nothing, send it back. Don't trust me or anyone else, see for yourself. Because if it DOES work for you, wouldn't it be nice to stop taking all those pills with all their side effects? Wouldn't it be nice to not spend hundreds a year on pills when a 25 dollar bracelet could be helping even more...without side effects?It's worth a try, isn't it?I didn't believe in this thing, but it's working for me.That's all I can say, other than to encourage doubters to see if it works for you.Because, if it does...how great would that be?

3.7 starsThe big knock on this machine seems to be its weight, a little under twenty pounds. I agree that this vacuum is heavy compared to most of the new vacs, but I also have my fingers crossed that this weight means solid construction that will last for many years. Remember when things were built that way, rather than made of cheap plastic to make you buy a new one every couple years? Hello Kirby! Serious reliability rarely comes with cheap plastic.So for Samsung to make this so heavy, in a world of lightweight throwaway vac, gives me the thought that they made it to last, as they're not stupid, and they know folks are now used to lighter machines. Only time will tell. Meanwhile, it's really not that tough to move around; it's no Dyson, but of course it costs half as much. It also has a wider mouth, which equates to less laps around the room.The suction is quite strong, better than average to be sure. It does carpets well, though more level adjustment would be welcome on the rug brushes. It clogs a little too easily with pet hair, but it's easily pulled off. The hand-vac is a good idea but the design is weak; having it up top makes this already heavy machine more top heavy than it should be. The hand vac is ok but I still prefer a dedicated hand vac that's light; less suction but so much more easy to get into corners and sofa edges.It's easy to empty and does hold a lot of dust and dirt before needing to be emptied, a big plus.I would recommend this for folks who don't need to carry it up any stairs (although 20 lbs is really not super heavy), who have large flat areas without lots of corners to maneuver this in and out of, and who don't have more than one dog and one cat.The price has been coming down here over the last month, from 299 to 231, and I think it's just under four stars at that price. If its heaviness translates over the next few years to heavy duty reliability, then it would easily be worth 250, I think. But if it's just another fall apart in two years modern vac, it's worth half that. I have high hopes for this unit, because I've had good luck with Samsung in the past, and their products seem made to a higher level of durability than many of their competitors.

There's absolutely nothing I don't like about this detergent.It works well: cleans as thoroughly as any detergent I've ever used over the last four decades, including all the big name, chemical-laden brands. Except Puracy has no toxic chemicals, and you can both smell and feel that.Our clothes came out soft (we hang them dry) and smelling fresh, free of fake fragrance, with just a tiny hint of citrus smell.It has a simple pump top, so it never drips or leaves a mess.It's so concentrated that two quick pumps did a large wash easily and effectively.Amazingly, on top of all that: it's not only not expensive, it's cheap. Just about fifteen cents per load.And since clothes come out soft even when we hang them dry, they come out even softer from the drier, and thus need no fabric softener in either the washer or drier. That makes this detergent even more of a bargain.I love that it's Made In The USA, and that Puracy is a small local firm, not a multinational tax-dodging corporate behemoth. They clearly care about keeping their products as safe and yet also effective as possible. Which makes you wonder why the Big Label boys are dumping all those chemicals in our homes....and why we let them!This laundry detergent works perfectly, costs very little, and is completely safe for your family and the environment. Any product I can say that about that gets five stars and a thank you to the manufacturers for taking the time and care to offer real value on every front. They sent me this as a sample, and when it's gone we'll buy more. I can't offer a higher recommendation than that.

This is a very useful tool for your glove compartment. Normal flashlights have nicad batteries that leak easily in heat, whereas this lithium battery has less issues with that. It not only makes a good and VERY bright emergency flashlight, it also strobes to signal help. Plus it doubles as a cellphone charger for emergencies, very useful in the car. As small as it is, it puts out a lot of light and power; this is a very good, basic design and is made pretty well.It has a good solid metal housing with one simple recessed switch. The sample I was sent has already taken a couple of falls and bashes and seems built to last. I'd pay about 20 bucks for this, so at that price or less this is an easy five star item.

We have a collection of retractable dog leashes, so I compared this sample with various other models. The first thing of note is that this is almost exactly the same leash as the best selling RL on this site, for a dollar or two less. So that's a decent endorsement. But by the same token, there are a number of other companies selling this exact same leash, with their logo on it in the same place, for a few dollars under that. Clearly these are all made in the same factory in China and rebranded for each company. So, they might be pretty good leashes but they are not a unique design, which means you need to check out all the similar RL's on here and see which of these is the cheapest, as they all seem identical. And which has the longest warranty. No idea of the warranty on this one.The leash extends exactly 13 feet 4 inches (our dog measured it). The handle is a fair bit bigger than the spool, and easy to hold. The stop-leash button is spring-loaded, which is frankly not my favorite design, as those springs do go after a while. I have a very similar leash to this and our 50 lb shepherd ran hard at a squirrel and popped the leash off its inner sprocket. Because these are two halves glued shut, there are no screws to take it apart and fix it, which I've done with other higher quality RL's. That's a negative, as this is pretty solid, but nothing near the kind of heavy duty leash that a real running/playing medium/big dog will need to be able to rock hard while you brace yourself for the big pull at the end of the leash.13 feet is ok but my favorite RL is 20 feet, and those extra feet are well worth the mild extra weight and size, to me at least. I like to give our sweetie lots of room to roam when she has to be on leash.***By the way, we tie a little poop bag around the handle so we always have one ready if she goes.  Keep your city clean for your neighbors and they'll be more likely to love and support our doggies!***The leash is all band style, not cord plus band end, so that's a plus.The clip is decent, and well-attached to the band.If you have a light dog and don't want a long leash, this should do you well.But if you have a 50 lb or more dog that might be chasin' squirrels and cats suddenly and put pressure on the leash and mechanism inside, I would go for a heavier and longer retractable leash, preferably with the halves attached with screws so that you can do maintenance. This leash will be toast when that spring goes, and in my experience it will go in a year or two, especially as it's made in China. I have seen a MUCH higher failure rate on even simple mechanical items like this when they come from the corner-cutting Chinese factories.My best RL was "Made in West Germany", and it's been enduring much abuse and water etc for over six years with zero issues. It has a double switch for freezing the leash: one stops it and the other clicks it in. No spring, thus nothing to pop out or bend or break. That switch has taken serious abuse for six years and is as good as new (I've not seen any spring model be that good). It looks beat up but still works like a champ. It cost less than double this leash but it looks good to go for another six years. Sadly, I can't find it for sale anywhere any more. But look around at your options, there are a zillion in this category now.As with most things, I say go for maximum quality; in the long run it will save you money, and you'll have the best performance along the way. But if you just need a simple RL, this is the basic standard these days and is a decent deal at twenty bucks.

Get the blu-ray! It's 20 now and the dvds are 18, and the BD is of course crisper and with better sound , and you get everything on one disc. I've seen both the dvds and BD, and for only two bucks more the blu-ray is a no-brainer for a set of shows as splendid as this.I really like a number of the Kilburn songs, but it's the Coliseum show that makes this a must. They were at their absolute peak that night, and even the mediocre sound (but not terrible at all, especially if you're used to bootlegs and hearing the music first and sound second) doesn't detract at all. I also like the minimal camera movement and shots; I just want to see all the band at once to see how they interact. I hate today's constant cutting every half second. This is how I like to watch a group: working as a group.Kilburn might have annoyed Pete at the time, but it holds up well, especially Fooled and Baba, and I really like this version of My Wife. The jam into the unrecorded Who's Next is another highlight; Pete's got a major buzz on and is just having fun at that point. The footage looks very very crisp indeed in blu-ray, and the sound is good. Keith is starting to fade, we can see that, but he's still pumping out the rhythm and good humor, and his love-hate with Pete is on display for all to see. Clearly much more love than hate.Daltrey is as much an Ox as the Ox, I think, dependable and solid. But it's Townshend who is the real highlight in all of this. He is without doubt the most entertaining guitarist to watch of them all, including Jimi, I think. Maybe Eddie during the classic VH days was this much fun to see (check the VH live vids on yootoob from '78-82 or so), but Pete had that raging bull aspect that really lent his performances an air of danger and edge. He seemed to be falling over much of the time but was very in control while out of control, and his groove is unmistakeable as he careens around the stage, windmilling and doing knee-slides and jumping three feet in the air as he crushed those power chords (or "crash chords" as Roger calls them).And of course, to get the full experience, turn this up to 11. They were the loudest band ever, after all.Volume is a big part of their visceral impact. This is their power fully unleashed, and designed to overwhelm.The Coliseum show is just Who paradise, to me. I have many Oo bootlegs and this is as good as the best of them, with video added. So crisp, and Moon is in tip top shape here. He and Pete are so tight it's crazy, and you can see why John was called the Ox. A more reliably crushing bassist I have not yet heard. Plus the Tommy material was so fresh and clean at this point; they were riding a juggernaut in every way and they knew it. Pete's comments to the crowd also show why they were so special: no typical rock star buttkissery here, simply a serious rock fan whose goal was to be part of their celebration of music and exuberance, not a rock star.This is THE video for serious Who fans, I think, even more so than The Kids, simply because of the Coliseum show. That's one of rock's best bands on one of their best nights (Pete himself has said so many times, and he might know), and it's a joy to finally have it in decent quality.Can't say enough about how great this is. No Who fan, perhaps even no rock fan, should be without it.

An excellent overview of one rock's most rocking bands, Amazing Journey is full of truly intelligent interviews, and blissfully free of the excessive worship that plagues many rockumentaries. Pete isn't the only bright bulb in the band; Daltrey comes across as a very thoughtful and wise fellow, as do the filmmakers, who are smart enough to let the band speak for themselves.Six Quick Ones might be even better than the main feature, as we get more in-depth and personal stuff about each of the four, with Moonie of course being the most entertaining. There's some prime stuff in there, and plenty of laughs to boot. Curbishley's story about the Ox trashing Keith's hotel room in the extras is worth the price of admission alone. Hilarity followed Moon everywhere he went...as did astronomical bar bills. Drinking 18 margaritas and then walking upstairs to mess with your bassist's gourmet meal, and his wall? Priceless. Or, about 8k, all told.There's only clips of songs here, but plenty of them; if you want live footage, run don't walk to the Kilburn reissue dvd, or of course The Kids Are Alright. But this is the best overview of The Who's career I've seen, in terms of placing them into context of their times, socially and musically, and getting the band to talk about themselves and each other in depth. Anyone who sees them as a bunch of yobbos (which is how they see themselves!) will also find a very thoughtful group of frenemies who rocked as hard as they did because they never held anything back.And at the present price of less than six bucks for two dvds, this is a g-g-gift!So if you know any Who fans, gift them this and they'll love you for it.It's top notch all around.Highly recommended.

This is a very well-made thermos mug. All-steel body keeps things warm/hot minus 10 degrees or so for about two to three hours. The top is easy to open with one finger, and stays very closed when not. Also easy to flip and keep open for washing or finger-free sipping.The carry loop is a nice idea but I'd prefer it to be a bit more recessed, as it does make packing it etc a tad trickier than with an all-slim profile.My only real knock on this is the price, which they're not clear on yet here. It says 30-42, and that's just too high for this. I'd say 20 bucks is the perfect price for this item, and would give it five happy stars for that or less. Maybe even at 25. But over 30, this is a great mug but not a great value, unless you are a driver who loves hot hot liquids and must have a one-hand mug.One caveat: this does keep stuff very hot, so if you put in boiling coffee you will be sipping near-boiling coffee for at least one hour afterwards. That's a good thing, but my burned tongue reminded me to mention it, as it's easy to expect things to cool down faster than this. That they don't is the big plus of this mug.It's definitely built to last, so if price is no object, this should last you many years; the only thing that can break is the spring lid, and it seems to be a good steel spring. Time will tell!

Very brief:This is a good heater for small-medium rooms, but it does use a lot of juice. If you need quick heat, it's very good. But if you need long term, more affordable heat, I'd go with a good oil-filled radiator. Please read the whole review for the reasons why.Very not brief:I've been using portable electric heaters for 30 years now, and I've tried most every type there is: quartz space heater, baseboard, oil-filled radiator, and these infrared puppies. Each has their purpose and use, and in reviewing this infrared heater I'll compare and contrast all of those, and also, I hope, save you some money and aggravation. I'll also address some common issues people complain about with these heaters.First, how much power does this unit use? Electric bills are a main concern with these heaters, so always keep your power bill in mind when comparing them. This unit claims to pull 1500 watts and 12.5 amps. I have an appliance load tester and to be exact, while it's heating this draws 1430 watts and 11.9 amps. That is quite a lot of electricity at today's prices, and seeing as there is no low setting, that's what you'll be drawing from your wall ALL of the time with this. Keep that in mind when comparing.Bu the way, I must add here the most vital point with any of these heaters:NEVER USE AN EXTENSION CORD WITH ANY PORTABLE HEATER!!!Sorry for the all-caps, but it's a warning used not often enough in the literature for PHs. These usually draw anywhere from 500 to 2000 watts, and that gets their factory cords warm enough already. Add an extension cord and suddenly the resistance can easily result in hot cords and fires, and every year it does, in hundreds and maybe many thousands of cases resulting in torched houses and deaths around the world. Don't be one of these statistics.NEVER use anything but the factory cord, no matter how heavy, straight into your wall socket. And always keep all heaters at least two feet from all drapes. In fact, I set them on tiles, never a rug or wood, just in case. Tiles cost a buck a piece and might save your family's lives.That said, let's look at this heater. The best thing about this sort of infrared heater is that it heats very quickly, the most quickly of the four listed above. The element heats up within a minute and then the fan blows the heat out of this unit. (This fan makes a mild noise, not loud but very audible.) In this Duraflame's case, the fan is about 12 inches off the floor and blows slightly upwards into the room. You can feel the warm air blowing to about 30 inches away or so. This is very nice if you're in a very cold room and need direct heat on your body, or for putting your frozen toeses up in the air and letting the warm air thaw them. A tiny quartz space heater (let's call those QSH) will also do that, but a baseboard (BB) and oil-filled radiator (OFR) will not.The off-gassing smell took about 3 hours to disappear from this during first use. Put it outside or in your garage for at least three hours first time out, as whatever they claim, those chemicals coming off the filaments ain't healthy. That smell gives headaches for a reason: your brain is telling you to flee. But all heaters have this, so there you go.This unit lets you set the auto-off timer to 30 minutes, or 1 to 8 hours. That's a very useful feature. It also has a thermostat, going from 50 to 97 degrees. This is, like almost all of these PH thermostats, quite useless. It rarely matches your room's actual temp, and there is usually a 3-7 degree swing in using it as your on-off switch. For instance, you set this at 66 in a 60 degree room and it will try to heat the room to 68, then stop and not come back on until it's 62 or 63. That wide swing is often too wide for many folks' comfort, so I recommend using this as an on or off proposition, and letting the timer do the work. Otherwise, if you unwisely trust this thermostat, the heater might stay on 24/7 in serious winter weather, and 24 x 1430 watts equals a LOT of money at the end of the month.That brings up another vital thing I've learned about heaters. All of them work best if you have two simple tools: a thermometer on the wall, and a fan to move the heat around the room. I can't stress enough how vital the fan is. Heat rises and gets trapped by the ceiling, where it does you no good. A small (or large in a large room) fan pointed at the ceiling will keep that heat circulating, and end up saving you a TON of money. I've compared, and also paid the high bills without a fan.USE A FAN POINTED AT THE CEILING.You'll stay much warmer for much less money. Even this unit, with an enclosed fan, needs another fan to keep the heat moving properly in the room.When you're warm enough, check your thermometer. That's your baseline goal. Now try moving your heater in various places in the room and see how long it takes to get to that temp after it's dropped a few degrees. Pay attention and you will save a lot of cash, because one of the main goals with a PH is using as little electricity, and thus money, as you can.And now the most vital thing to make your PH work well: insulation. INSULATION! Look at reviews across this site for PHs and you'll see the same complaint: "This won't get my room above 60 degrees no matter how long it's on!" Well, in a word...duh! If your room isn't insulated properly, it's leaking heat! NO heater will get your room to stay warm unless you're using a wood stove or central heat, and you will still be wasting heat and money.Want to stay warm all winter? Insulate your main room and your whole house. Period. It's an investment that will pay major dividends over the years, and we know energy prices will continue to rise; in the long run they always do.This step will save you the most money in the long run, and keep you warmest, and you'll need a smaller heater. Even just some blankets over the windows can make a massive difference. Put some on the coldest walls too. Get plenty of blankets cheap at Goodwill and save hundreds of dollars in heat/power bills over the winter.By the way, you'll never get warm in zero degree weather without wearing some sweaters and thick wool socks. This might seem obvious, but how many folks have you met who complain about being cold while having thin shoes or no socks or sweater(s) on?Why heat a big room when it's only YOU that is cold?Wear a ton of clothes and save a ton of money! It's that simple.In fact, the easiest and cheapest way to stay warm is very simple: a wool watchman's cap. NOTHING will keep you warmer longer than a 100% wool cap. Socks are the other key, but a large amount of body heat radiates from your head. A simple all-wool cap will stop almost all of that loss, and you can keep your room cooler and save a lot of money. I've endured many winters in deep snow and sub-zero temps, and a wool cap is the absolute secret to comfort. Wearing one in your house saves you a load of cash and keeps you warm in every room. Don't feel silly wearing a cap in the house...feel silly for having to because your house isn't properly insulated! Seriously, try an all-wool cap, nothing works better. But get all wool, acrylic etc doesn't come close to insulating like wool.Hot tea is also extremely efficient. Nothing heats your body faster and cheaper. A wool cap and socks plus hot tea or soup every half hour has kept me toasty in minus 30 weather in a 40 degree cabin for days on end. Try it and see!And for arctic-cold area folks who complain that their little portable heater only gets the room to 50 degrees when it's minus 10 outside: NO portable heater will warm a poorly insulated room way above the outdoor temperature. You're dreaming! Dress warm, drink hot liquids and seriously consider a wood stove. For heavy-duty BTU's, nothing works better, and the new ones use very little wood and are very efficient. Small or large propane heaters are even faster, but cost more and I have never liked the very dry air they create, nor the way they suck oxygen from the air. I consider them and all gas heaters unhealthy, especially with the carbon monoxide issues. They give me headaches and make me feel lethargic, even with a cracked window. In order, I prefer central heating (if your house is well insulated), then a very good small wood stove, then PHs, and finally gas if there is no other choice.A quick summary of this heater's other features: it's a little over a foot high, made of solid, not too cheesy looking veneer, and is on casters for moving, a great feature that also keeps it up off the rug/floor. I still put it on tiles, but those casters are a good feature. It weighs a little over 20 lbs and is easy to move around. You could sit in a chair and put your feet up against the front to warm them with this, another good aspect. It has a remote control, useful for cold mornings in bed; hit the snooze button and turn this on, and in ten minutes your room is warm. Nice feature. On the front of the heater there's a power on/off button, temp up and down buttons, and the timer button. And as stated, only one power/heat setting is available: high!Which brings us to the disadvantages of this heater. You'll have issues getting it to keep your room temp right where you want it; the temp swing will make it a little cold then maybe a little hot. Or a lot too cold. But rarely too hot, unless you are a wise soul with good insulation on your body and in your room and house.And that is why, all told, I prefer a good oil-filled radiator heater. They are completely silent. They swing less in temperature, and best of all they usually have three settings: 500, 100, 1500 watts. I have found that with a fan blowing the warm air above an OFR around the room, I can leave it on 500 watts and keep a room as warm as a 1,500 watt heater like this. That is of course a major savings. Plus, a good OFR is often less than 100 bucks.BUT...the key with a heater is not initial cost, it's heating bills. You can end up paying fast and hard for buying a cheap portable heater.Speaking of, what about those quartz space heaters and baseboard heaters? I've found both to be very inefficient. BB are good because they are low and heat rises, but even with a fan I find their total power cost to be too high, and they sit against a wall, which is usually cold, and this makes them even less efficient. QSH are great for one use: warming up a cold bathroom or bedroom in minutes. On winter mornings before our central heat warms up the house in about 15 minutes, I put our little QSH on in the bathroom and it's warm in three minutes. They are basically a tiny version of this larger infrared heater, but this guy is way too big for a bathroom. I recommend having a nice little QSH on hand for folks in very cold areas, as it can be a life saver when coming to a cold cabin or house and needing to thaw frostbitten fingers or toes in minutes. And it can get your bedroom warm in minutes.Which is the main negative with OFR: they take a good 20 minutes or more to warm a room. But that also means they hold their heat well after that, which makes them far more efficient than the other types. That means money saved. I've compared power bills between all types of electric heat and the OFR wins by a mile. If your utility company is hosing you, get a small fan and an OFR, insulate your main room, and you will save big time.And please keep in mind: our electricity is coming from power plants that use mostly either coal or nuclear fuel, neither of which is doing our planet any favors. The less power you have to draw from your sockets, the better. You'll not only save money but also make the world a little healthier, and at this point in history we are fast running out of resources, so creating efficiency is doing not only your family but everyone's families a big favor.So here's my heating recommendations in a nutshell: wear a wool hat and socks and sweaters when really cold, no matter what heater you use. And stay under blankets, even on the sofa or at a table. Drink plenty of hot liquids (add some cayenne to really get your core sizzling). Make sure you've insulated your house, and especially main sitting room, as well as possible. No heater can warm a drafty room, period. For quick heat, use a QSH in small rooms or IH in large. BB heaters, don't bother, not worth it. But long term, an oil-filled radiator will cost the least and heat the most.Yet if you can afford it, I think one of these infrared heaters plus an OFR is the best all-around solution. The IH will heat your room fast, and then your OFR will keep it warm for less money. When it gets really cold, you can use the IH's blown heat right on your body.And this Duraflame is a good infrared heater at a fair price, and with its features like casters and auto shutoff, it's a safer unit than most. At its present price of 160, it's a good deal for a 1500 watt IH. I wish it had a half power setting, which costs it a star. But along with a quality OFR, this will keep you warm all winter and at a fair power bill price, if you pay attention to insulation of your house and your body, and use a fan or two to keep the warm air flowing.If you've read this far, you are likely trying to stay warm. Please try my tips and see what you think, and also please write a comment to say if they worked for you, or if you have other good ideas to share with the rest of us.Here's wishing you many cozy winter nights in your efficiently heated home!

This leather vest is extremely well made. The stitching is above average; I pulled on all of it, inside the pockets and out and along the seams, and there was no give at all. Bike gear needs to be extra solid, as it gets pulled and torn at more than most clothing, and Viking Cycle did a great job making this vest (in Pakistan, btw) solidly and with attention to detail.For instance, in addition to two outside zip pockets, it has two inside pockets, one zip and one snap. The snap one is big, the zip one smaller but perfect for a wallet and phone, etc. The linings on both pockets are solid and well-sewn, often an issue with inside pockets. The zippers are good quality, as are the snaps with buffalo nickel heads, a nice touch.The leather is a good thick hide, pebbled and sturdy. It's not butter-soft but I wouldn't want that nap on a biking vest. This is solid leather, thick enough to give you some protection in a mild wipe out but still pliable enough for daily use.I have only one minor issue with this vest: for an XL it's very tight around the waist. I am a 36 and this JUST snaps shut when I have on jeans and a shirt. The arm holes are huge and thus give good room for arm movement while riding, and you could wear this over sweaters, etc. But unless you have an unusually small waist, I would opt for the XXL if your waist is over 36, or maybe even 34 if you have a beer belly, as when this is buttoned up and I bend over, it's mighty tight. Still, if you want to look a little more svelte than you are while emphasizing your shoulders, perhaps this design is just the ticket. I do know that while I wear it, I keep getting ladies asking me for my autograph and saying, "We love you, Dwayne!" When I tell them I'm not really The Rock, they can hardly believe it. Until I take off the vest. Then they grab their pens back and look at me all huffy. Oh well.All told, I think this is a flat out bargain at its present price of 55 here. The leather is tough and will help keep you warm while giving your arms plenty of mobility, and the snaps, stitching and pockets are top quality. I was sent a sample for review, but I would gladly pay 75 for this and feel it was a good deal. Just keep the waist size in mind. Of course, if you like to leave your vest open, as many riders do, then the XL will be fine for you, unless you are the Hulk. But I'd recommend XXL if your waist is 36 or over.

This is certainly the lightest guitar stand I have ever used, and it folds up nice and small. If your gig bag has a big front pocket, it might even fit in there. Oddly enough, however, my main issue with this stand is that I wish part of it was bigger and another part smaller. The stand is not tall, so the back of the guitar touches it low on the instrument, making it less stable; this combines with flat legs that stretch so far out that some of my guitars, mainly electric, have to be quite far from vertical to grip the rubber properly, so the stand has to be far enough out from the wall that the neck of the git won't touch the wall, as it leans far from vertical on the stand. Not a big problem, and not for acoustics, but a mild issue for electrics in one very small practice room I use.The only other issue I had with this review sample is that it is so small and light that I'm a little edgy about having it out in the open and not a corner, as even a small nudge on a Les Paul I had in the stand made it almost fall out of the stand. So I'd recommend lighter guitars for this stand, and putting it far from where it might be touched. I would not recommend this as a gigging stand, unless you can find a corner of the stage that no one goes near.But it's still quite stable for its size, if used with lighter axes, and its portability is certainly a plus. The present price here of 25 is not bad, so if you need a very small, light stand, this is a good choice.

Carbons tend to be brighter but not quite as warm as old school nylon. This set is "hard tension"---ie thicker strings---and seems even brighter due to that tension, but the Dynacore bottom wounds are a little warmer than you might expect. These strings certainly do project well, with a fair bit of bite. If you use mainly fingernails, these might seem pretty stiff at 440. I use my pads and tips more, so the brightness is appreciated, but I also tune down to Eb, so the extra give is a big plus with these. I do that because I like the tone more, it's easier on my fingers, and I break WAY less strings. I don't know about you, but I'm not nuts about putting new strings on my classical guitars; it takes some doing to get it just right. These went on relatively easily enough, however, and I stretched them very gently to avoid breakage.These are on a good old '70s Yamaha, and at Eb they sound very full and rich, though with that carbon edge. I would recommend using normal tension for most players trying these strings, or tuning down as I do with these thicker strings, though some guitars might need an adjustment if they flop a bit too much for you at Eb. But with these hard t's it's a nice tradeoff, as the deeper tone compensates for the brightness nicely.I've used D'Addarios on my acoustics for over 25 years and love them, as they're very reliable and hold their tone well. I haven't used their classical strings much, but I do like these. I can't say much about the long term tone of these Pro-Arte carbons, but we shall see. They do feel good under my fingers, and the tone is sharp and strong out of the package. Another reviewer said he had breakage issues, so perhaps he and others with this problem might consider using normal tension strings, or tuning down a half step to compensate; the looser feel can be good, once you adjust. All I know is that these went on fine for me and play well at Eb, with no action or nut adjustment needed.They are a little pricey, but if they hold their good tone for a while I'd say they're worth it, as they do give the guitar a bit more edge and authority. I'm merely competent on the classical guitar, but I'm guessing serious professional players might really dig the projection and snap of these carbons.

I like everything about this unit, except the price. The mics work well, the speaker is clear, the build quality is solid. It's (USB) plug and play, pretty much, and relatively noiseless. But I've got a number of bluetooth mic/speakers that do just as good a job, or nearly, for 50 bucks or so. Perhaps if you are sitting around a conference table with many people, the multiple mics are useful, yet even then, one good mic will pick up everything in a room. But to charge 220 for basically a small speaker and a few small dynamic mics? Unless you're writing this off on your company's dime, I just can't see paying that much when I can get almost the same performance for 1/4 the price.For professional users, I would recommend this as a well-made, pro-quality unit. For the usual simple skype etc calls, though, I'd say shop around before committing to this price tag.

As a big lavender oil fan, I like this stuff. It's finer and stronger than most, and one drop goes a long way, and therein lies my only quibble with this product. I don't mind the 15 buck price tag, as fine oils do cost a lot. But the bottle most always drops out two or three drops at a time due to the crappy top, so that you end up with a very strong lavender scent where you might want it mild.Apart from that, it's excellent.I was sent this as a review sample. Free or not, however, oil this good deserves a better cap.

4.7 starsI've used this almost every day for the past few months, often for 10-14 hours, and can vouch for its durability. It leaves less mess under it than most diffusers, and the sleek design and quiet operation make it usable anywhere. It uses a little over 3 oz of water and will keep your room smelling of the oil you prefer for about 4-8 hours; the machine shuts off automatically after about 4 hours, usually with a little water left. If you add more water to that, you get a very light scent as the rest of the oil is diffused.We like lavender, peppermint, and lemon oils best, and this works well for all of them, and combinations thereof. Some oils are heavier than others, and this unit's sonic mister does use up the heavier oils faster, as they sink to the sonic ring faster. So you get more of those smells quicker, and then less as the hours roll by.Here's a VERY useful tip: after using many diffusers and seeing how they only diffused in a small area, I've started using a mini-fan behind this one, and what a difference! It blows the fine mist across the room, thus not only dispersing the scent far more, but also completely getting rid of any residue near the machine. Win/win! It also humidifies the room a tiny bit.By the way, the switch is really in the little rubber rear feet, so if you have issues with turning it on/off by pressing on the unit, simply lift it a tiny bit and use the little foot. The sample they sent me had a sticker where you're meant to push, and that left some goo after removal; a little rubbing alcohol on a tissue cleaned that right off.The changing lights are very nice in the dark, and being able to freeze the color you like is a very useful feature.That and the quality of this diffuser in general makes it five stars. I'd like it to cost 30 bucks, but even at 50 this is so well-made that it's worth five stars. It's as good as any diffuser I've used, and the good adapter, easy-fill, subtle rainbow color band and look of the unit makes it a truly fine diffuser.

I'll never really understand why electric guitar strings need to be "louder". Acoustic, sure, as the string and guitar top are what produce the tone together. But electric strings simply make a rather infinitesimal signal that is then picked up by the poles of the pups, passed on through the cable to the amp, and then amplified. Strings not loud enough? Turn up the amp. It's the tone of the string that concerns me, not how loud that tone is.So I'm always a little skeptical about "louder" e-strings. Really, what's the point? If you're trying to get your pups to create more signal, you can easily raise them closer to your strings, or use bigger strings (the legendary if mostly apocryphal SRV .15 set; his tone came more from how hard he attacked the string than anything else, though thicker strings will take more abuse). Or just crank the amp! So I put these "maraging steel" strings (weren't they a metal band from Putney?) on a Strat, with low expectations.And, for the most part, those expectations were met. Yes, these strings are somewhat louder than standard Slinkies, which for years were my usual choice, and a fair bit louder than the pure nickels which I now prefer. But the feel of these m-steels is not very pleasant. I slide and bend a lot, and these are just harsh on my fingertips. They might be great for metal players who chug along in drop-tunings and play basic riffs and power chords, but for blues, jazz and classic rock, these are overkill, and actually make the tone too harsh for my ears.I compared them to both regular Slinkies and pure nickel Slinkies, and I found the m-steels' ONLY "advantage" to be a brighter, edgier tone. But there weren't finer harmonic overtones, there weren't sweeter sounds, and above all they were just not as musical-sounding as the other two. I play mostly class A tube amps, and these m-steels just don't seem to vibe with them like the pure nickels, or even regular strings. They sound a little sterile and edgy, great for metal but that's about it.Plus, I just had a fret job on that Strat, and these m-steels are definitely harsher on the frets. I had played pure nickels on them for about 100 hours with no visible wear at all, but after only about three hours with the m-steels, I could see very clear flattening on the frets where I do a lot of bending. After only a few hours! Seeing as quality fretjobs cost at least 200-300 bucks, that's not very economical.Which brings me to the least appealing aspect of these strings: the price. They are now 11 clams here, three times the price of regular Slinkies and more than double the pure nickels. But why? Maybe the tiny bit of different steel is worth more, but three times? There's very little metal in a pack of strings, all told. The high price is a marketing scam, I think, and the tone and feel of these nowhere justifies that much more money. Add that 11 bucks times 10 or 20 to a new fretjob every year, which I would need playing these strings every day for hours, and these become very very expensive, unless you never bend notes. Which means these are, to my mind, useful only for metal rhythm players. Hetfield might love them.So in my opinion these are well-made strings that do seem to hold their tone (however sterile) longer than most, and give a louder, brighter signal to your pups. But I think only metal players will truly find that useful. Metal players who don't mind an annual fretjob, anyways. For classic rock, blues and any other music where sweet tone is at a premium, these are not only not worth three times the normal price, I wouldn't use them if they cost the same. The scratchy feel under my fingers, the grating bite of the tone as you go up the neck, the edgier harmonics: none of that is what I want from a string.But each to their own, and I know that Petrucci and Gilbert and other more-notes-is-better players use these, so that will appeal to some. Fair enough. But they can afford $300 fretjobs every year, and they get these strings for free. Plus, I'd rather sound like Gilmour or Page or Hendrix than those guys, and you'll have trouble getting their sweet tone out of these strings. Louder is not better, to my ears. Sweeter is better, and if I need louder riffs or more top end, I merely turn up the gain or the treble on my amp a bit. But I couldn't get the sweet, rich tone I love from m-steels while playing Time or Spanish Castle Magic or Out On The Tiles.Still, that's just one set of ears and fingers. Perhaps you'll love the edge and volume of these; compare them to your favorite strings and see what you think, especially if you use solid state amps. Only your ears know what they like, after all. But my ears and fingers say that no way are these worth three times the price of normal Slinkies.

Edit, 2/18/2015: I will never buy another DVP product. I just found out they were bought by Del Monte, who now sources some of the ingredients in DVP stuff from China. MANY dogs are getting sick from it, please read up about it. No wonder they never answered my question here: they don't give a damn about my dog, or yours.I WILL NEVER BUY ANOTHER DEL MONTE OR DVP PRODUCT AGAIN.Please read about these issues on consumeraffiars dot com, and many other places.  *****************************************************************These have decent ingredients, but a little too much sugar. The pooch loves them, but she also loves cat poop so I don't think that's a glowing endorsement.I do wish DVP would go the extra mile and use non-factory farm cruelty-free chicken, but other than that and the sugar these are made of good, non-chemical stuff, and are healthier than most dog treats. They are pretty big so you might want to tear them in half, depending on your dog's size.They are perhaps a tad expensive; I would have guess these cost about 7-9 bucks, so 12 and change is a bit much. It's rather nuts that we pay double or more for pet stuff  than we would for the same ingredients when meant for people. The pet market is clearly all about the premium price, but then we tend to love our little furballs and will ignore common sense when buying good things for them. But if you're going to charge this price, use some organic chicken, people! It would take little off the margin but would add much to the happiness of our animal friends, both pets and farm animals alike.As for supporting her immunity, who knows? She's never been sick since we found her a few years ago, so it's tough to say what effect extra vitamins and nutraceuticals have on her.I applaud DVP for using better-than-average ingredients, and if they start using free-range, happy chickens in their treats, it will be five stars all the way!Edit: Or not. Bye-bye, Del Monte and DVP.

This is a small solar led lamp that gives off a flickering effect from a little LED bulb under the dome. This reflects off the fake candle under it and gives the effect of a burning candle, or so.The first thing I'll say is you basically MUST have this below eye level, as seeing the LED bulb not only ruins the candle illusion, but it's just not very nice to look at directly and unreflected. Thus the hanging option makes little sense, unless you're hanging it from a low tree limb or bush (the famous Flickering Bush).The solar option is the best thing about this, as you can leave it outside on a table on the patio or by or even in the garden, and the sun will charge the little AA battery and keep the lamp flickering all night. Even indirect sun will suffice for a few hours each night. Not having to turn it on or off is nice, and there's a switch to turn it off if you want to.You can also replace the rechargeable battery after a year or whatever, a good option as that makes this usable for many years. The sample they sent came with a mediocre rechargeable battery; get a good one and you'll get a brighter light that will last longer.All in all, it's just a little plastic light, but the effect is pleasant, the price is about right at 15, and the automatic on/off solar aspect is the real selling point, making this useful for those who want to put it on a patio table or among the plants in their garden and let it do its flickering thing every night without your having to worry about turning it on and off.

These Russian tubes, like most Russkies, break up sooner than their Chinese counterparts. That really matters if you want more hair (harmonic distortion) on your tone. So why pay 30% more to get gold pins, which tend to smooth out the hair?Good question, unless you want the best of both worlds. I A-B-C-D'ed this and a normal EH 12ax7 and a JJ and a GT in the vital V1 position of my Blues Jr. The GT was crap, hard and cold. The JJ was nicer but still not as good as an old Mullard I had (a real old one, not a New Sensor-owned Mullard reissue). The normal EH was nice but a bit too tight in some ways, not smoothing out when the amp was dimed. But this gold pin EH was very golden with the amp wide open, not only creamier and warmer but also quieter than the other tubes. Darn close to the Mullard, which, when you can find them now, go for 100-200 bucks.For me, close to that level of tone is well worth 18 bucks.I wouldn't bother so much with gold tips in V2 or V3, but try one in that all-vital first position where your preamp tone is really defined, and see what you think. It took about 80 hours for this tube to really wear in and start fully singing, but when it did, it was quite nice indeed.

These are just rebranded Sovteks and weak Chinese whatevers.PERIOD.GT merely weeds out the occasional microphonics and ringers and then adds 20-30%. But then everybody does that lately...except JJ, who makes their own tubes in their own factory, and while their 84's aren't anywhere near the very best NOS stuff out there, they're way cheaper, and don't cost a penny more than these often sloppy Russian/Chinese tubes.It says something when these are the only tubes stocked in-store by the masters of monopoly, Guitar Center and Musician's Friend (by putting all the small locally-owned music stores out of business you're our friends?). Bain Capital owns both of those firms---now there's some guaranteed competition, not---and I think we all know that creamy, singing tone is what Mitt Romney is all about!These 84's vary wildly in consistency. They're stock in Fenders these days, and many other amps. Why? Not because they're the best, but because they're the cheapest with a "brand name". Aspen Pittman's days of being truly musician-friendly are long gone. Just another sell-out. He was for real in the '80s and GT put out some killer tubes back then, but now they're just logo'ed mediocrity.I pulled the stock GT 84's from my NOS Blues Junior and used JJ 84's and EH 12ax7's and the difference was night and day. For the same money as these GT's sell for here. Duh. You do the math.The top end was smoother. The mids were creamier. The lows were punchier AND more extended, with nice definition around 100-300k, where these GT's were flabby and bogus.There are worse tubes out there, but GT does not deserve their long-done reputation as boutique tubes. They're really just a scam: they're not Groove Tubes, they're Sovteks. So go buy Sovteks and save 40% if you want cheap. Some Sovteks are pretty good...maybe you'll get lucky! Just remember that, in general, Russian tubes break up earlier than Chinese, so if you want edge, go Russian. If you want smooth, go Chinese.Or why not getcha some JJ's, or better yet, look around on your local c-list and find some NOS tubes and play mix and match. THAT is how you will get the tone of your dreams. Trust your ears and change tubes at will and see what you like. Wise tip: always use contact cleaner when you change tubes, it helps your sockets stay clingy and avoid all those scratchy noises we hate; maybe even retension your sockets if they seem loose. Easy to do.You CAN do all this yourself, as well as biasing your own amps easily. No need to pay techs when you could be doing it all yourself and learning about what makes your dream tone as you go along. A little research goes a long way. But no need for a bias probe with a Blues Jr or other cathode-based, Class A fixed bias amps. Just mix and match various tubes and trust your ears. Stick 'em in and wail away! Just remember, some tubes take 100+ hours to burn in and really show their potential. Patience (and lots of practice time!) go a long way towards the tone you want.If you love that sweet British chime and snarl of good 84's (and 34's), AVOID Groove Tubes and look up JJ and local NOS stuff. It's out there if you search. Your Marshall, Vox, Blues Jr etc will thank you for doing your homework. Because if you've read this far, you know that when you finally find that tone you want, it will be worth all the effort.

These were certainly brighter than the factory bulbs they replaced. I wasn't nuts about the rather odd hue, but the throw was longer than before and they were quite bright. Though do you ever curse that guy driving at you with super bright bulbs, so you flick your lights to tell him he's got his brights on, and he replies by saying. "These are my normal bulbs!" by flashing his brights...which blind you? Well, I'm not really sure I want to BE that guy! Not very polite to blind other drivers, is it? The Golden Rule and all that...if our society still operates on anything remotely close to that outdated principle of putting kindness before self-interest.Exactly how bright IS too bright, before we're abusing other drivers? And maybe temporarily blinding them for even a second, enough to cause an accident? Look at the stats, it happens more and more. How bright is really fair to other drivers? Like people driving while talking on their omnipresent umbilical cell phones, we need to seriously look at how our driving behaviors hurt everyone else on the road.In any case, GE didn't give me the chance to find out, as the left bulb went out intermittently within two weeks of installation. (Installing headlight bulbs is usually very easy to do by yourself, by the way. Takes two minutes. If confused, look up a youtube video on it, there are many.) At first it happened only once in a while, then it started happening every ten minutes for a minute or two. Finally a cop pulled me over and said, "Your driver's side light is out." He said to turn it on, and suddenly it worked again. The cop looked confused and let us go (that was rather entertaining, I'll admit). Lucky break, but not exactly a fun way to almost get a hefty ticket.I thought it was a bad connection so I took it apart and used cleaner on the contacts. But no help, and finally it just stopped working half the time. Switched sides, same issue, so not the car's fault. Might be a bad element, who knows? The filament isn't broken, in any case. I bought another brand instead, bright but not too bright for other drivers' comfort. They are to date much more dependable than GE. And much cheaper. Ahem.And that's the thing: stuff does break sometimes...but when the company is charging WELL above the average price for that product, you have a right to expect top notch performance, and no bad batches. Isn't that why we pay top dollar in the first place?In any case, General Electric needs to get a little less general about quality control.If you're going to charge the most, you better deliver.I wouldn't pay anywhere close to this price for this performance. Caveat emptor.

Edit, 2/18/2015: I have now researched DVP more thoroughly. Turns out they were bought out by Del Monte, a super-sleazy multi-national who don't give a damn about my dog or yours. They source some of their ingredients in China and MANY people have reported their dogs becoming very sick with UTI's and other serious issues since NB/DVP have started using China's sickeningly greedy and morally bankrupt suppliers.Let me just say this:NEVER BUY ANY NATURAL BALANCE AGAIN IF YOU LOVE YOUR DOG!!There are many brands for far less money that are sourced from people who care.Don't support these greedy corporate weasels.I apologize for not researching this company better for previous reviews. I hope to make up for it by costing them a lot of business. They don't care about my dog, why should I gave a damn about their bloated corporate profits?Dick Van Patten must be turning in his grave. SHAME on whomever in his family sold this good brand to the Del Monte scumbags.  *************************************************Our pooch likes these, but that's like saying men liked Marilyn Monroe. It's just the nature of the beast. She'll eat most anything she can get her paws on (our dog, not Marilyn). But she seems to enjoy a soft treat like these as an alternative to the fine organic snacks we often give her, among other treats. I like the lack of crap in the ingredients, but if NB is going to really go healthy, why not spend the extra couple cents per pack and use free range, non-tortured chicken?Most chickens in this country are "raised" in tiny cages and stuffed full of hormones and antibiotics while barely moving inches from birth to death (it's the sad truth, look it up), so feeding the oft diseased parts of these maltreated, malnourished animals to my own animals somehow seems not only hypocritical but just plain wrong.If I love my pets, shouldn't I share that same level of love with animals I won't meet? I think so, which is why I try to participate in cruelty-free animal treatment by buying non-factory meat for my animal friends. Because they are indeed my friends.I bring this up because I think someone from DVP might read this and consider it. They are clearly trying to care more than most pet food companies, so why not take the quest for quality-sourced ingredients to the next level?It's for that desire that I give this product four stars, as it is mostly made of very decent ingredients. No GMOs, no bad grains, a small amount of nutraceuticals, much better than most dog snacks in general. But to fulfill Dick's desire to really help animals, why not whole-heartedly support cruelty-free animal treatment?Edit: Four stars to one. No wonder they don't use free-range anything. They don't care about animals, yours or mone, only their products. Join me in showing them the results of not caring; I am never buying any Del Monte product ever again.

As a long time (if presently former) New Yorker subscriber, I like the idea of this book: who dreams up those intelligent, wry and often hilarious cartoons? I have certain favorites among their veteran cartoonists, and a couple of them are here (Gahan and Gross). I was really hoping for BEK (Bruce Kaplan), the sharpest of the last few decades' bunch to my mind, but oh well. Insert dejected caption here.These are all world class single panel cartoonists/artists, yet the truth is that in every case the art is far more fascinating than the artist. I enjoyed learning about Chast and Koren and the others, and was most amused by the predictable yet welcome irascibility of Gross and Wilson, whose work has been the edgiest in the magazine for roughly a half century in both cases, a startlingly lengthy record (maybe laughter really does keep you young, or at least let you live longer). They are both grumpy old coots but still funny and committed to their weirdness in charmingly odd ways. If you don't know their work, I highly recommend their best-of collections, easily found on this site. They both have wonderfully warped senses of humor, and Gahan in particular has a macabre imagination unlike any other artist, which along with his weird whimsy has created thousands of classic panels.Likewise Sam Gross. The best part of this book for me was the inclusion of a few previously unpublished cartoons by most of the artists. The Gross ones are by far the best, if laughter is a fair barometer of a cartoon's worth. The box office sketch, which the NY would never publish, is so classically Gross I literally had to put the book down while I LMAO (no doubt Sam has a cartoon somewhere of a guy texting that while having a completely flat backside). The lack of a caption makes it doubly perfect.That's one of the details discussed here by many of the artists: what makes a great caption, and how not needing one is the pinnacle of the art. Another sad detail is how few cartoon outlets there are now. I grew up in the '70's reading many mags with great cartoons, not only Playboy but so many others. One odd omission here is no nod by anyone towards Hustler, who love them or hate them have published some of the funniest cartoons since the National Lampoon (king of all twisted cartoon mags). Flynt was all about freedom of expression, however sick, and many of these cartoonists had hundreds of panels in his mags, but won't mention him. Or the NY won't let them...Which brings up a real issue here: since there are so few outlets for these guys now, they're all rather fawning towards their last big cash cow, the New Yorker, and the author, part of that team. So this book often comes off as a rather dull magazine article advertising the NY's cartoonists, rather than a truly in-depth, no holds barred set of artist biographies. Which is kind of disappointing and perhaps overly ironic, considering how edgy and acutely accurate these artists' work often is about the shallow nature of our society and economy these days.But if you like these folks' work, you'll like this book.
