You'll learn about their methods and personal quirks, and you'll also get a last glimpse of what is, quite sadly for those of us who have loved their work for so many years, the last of a dying breed.Insert perfectly accurate single panel drawing here, with no caption necessary due to its perfectly pithy pictorial portrayal.Thanks are due in any case to all cartoonists for making our lives a lot more fun. From the New Yorker to the Far Side, Herman and Doonesbury, you've sure made me laugh for a long, long time. It's nice to see some of you get props via books like this. But how about some bio books as edgy as your cartoons?The great Rick Geary (and others) have done cartoon autobios that turned out very well, so here's hoping for more of the same from Wilson, Gross and company. Until then, this is a decent little tribute to some very fine and under-appreciated artists.

Although I am one of those odd folks who prefers using a computer for computer things and a phone for phone things, I know most people now want it all in one. Unless you're a constant all-day user, I would think this unlocked phone/camera/computer/toaster with dual sim and a very nice 8mp/1080p camera will do very nicely for 150 clams.First, the negatives. It's all plastic and a bit flimsy. But once again, this costs 150, and in two years you'll get twice this performance at half the price (and another 500 million phones will be rather needlessly thrown away, a very serious negative about new tech that no one seems to want to discuss, but some of us do notice and care; conserve when you can! Do you REALLY always need the newest phone?). The other main negative is the very short battery life, barely enough to get through the day if you use the computer aspects/games etc much. But it does come with a usb charger that goes straight into 120 AC, so that's a nice bonus that makes charging anywhere very easy. The last negative is the sound, pretty weak. But then again, there's not a whole lot of space for better speakers in a phone this thin. And I guess another negative is that this is pretty darn big for a phone; you'll need a purse for this, or a big cargo pocket. Phones were all about getting tinier and more portable for a long while, but that has clearly changed.The pluses are many, mainly that you get a ton of features with a crisp 5" screen for 150. The price of this thing is surely the selling point, and with a camera this good and so many other user-friendly features for online use, that price seems quite amazing. As for screen protectors, the one they include is good, but call me crazy, because I most always just leave on the peel away plastic that comes on most small screens. I have with this phone so far, and it doesn't show fingerprints and the screen looks just fine to me through it.The processor works very quickly for my needs, with over 1gb RAM, and 4 gb internal space, plus room for 64gb via SD card. I can't see needing much more space than that. Heck, those stats were tough to get on a small laptop not too many years ago, so to have them on a phone still blows me away. But we're all getting spoiled for performance more every year, so people want the moon. I for one am still astonished by all this stuff for this little money.And the very best thing to me is being able to drop most any firm's sim card into it and whammo, suddenly everything is ready to go. That is the joy of unlocked phones, and it's hard to justify buying a 600 buck flagship phone and paying 500 bucks a year for it and then having it be a useless brick (leaking chemicals in the town dump) if you want another carrier when phones like this are out there for 1/4 the price, plus unlimited consumer choice.All in all, despite the negatives, for $150 this is just a ton of phone. And computer. And camera. And hi-def video camera. And you're not tied to any company with it. Pretty nifty.

What a wonderfully sharp, stunningly quick flick this is. Nothing in it isn't top-notch. The script, every actor, the direction, the pacing, the twisty plot, the ending...it all works perfectly, and with wry wit.I don't even see the point of going into details. If you like a good mindbending thriller, and think Hitchcock was a true master, then you will love this film. It's 21st century Hitch. The violence is realistic but you're aware this is always a movie, so it's not overly disturbing. Not a film for kids, though.Nothing is over done, many things are wisely understated, and I can't recall the last film I saw where it kept getting more and more interesting as it went on. The laughs are mostly black but always great fun. Even its frequent, subtle social commentaries are crisp and unobtrusive. I liked everything about Headhunters, and only wish that Hollywood would make movies this well.Highly recommended to all cinephiles.

The only real faults I can find here are that the plastic casing could be tougher, and I wish the light swiveled, as it's tricky to get the right angle while reading in some chairs/positions. But in general this is a very handy tool for many reasons.-It's solar powered and also AC-powered, and takes half the time to charge by sun than it gives light-It is not only very very bright, but also dims by holding down the power switch so you can get even just a mild glow-You can use it to charge phones etc via the usb out port-I kind of like the cheesy plum blossom silhouettes on it!It's a rather weird little design, but somehow it's quite charming, and eminently practical for both emergency and everyday uses. I'd price this at 35-50 bucks, and it's now 40 here, so it's also a good value. If you are far from outlets but still need bright light, this thing will be the ticket. The dimmability is what really takes it over the top in my opinion, and along with the brightness of the long-lasting LED bulbs, that makes this little solar lamp a very cool thing indeed.

This is a near-identical copy of a unit Motorola sold about 4 years ago, the MBP36, and those had frequent battery-life issues (check out the 1,200 reviews of it here), so be aware of that when comparing this to other baby cams. Also be aware that while the daytime color picture on this is nice and crisp, the nighttime pic is black and white and not nearly so crisp. Seeing as most parents use this at night for peace of mind, that might be an issue for some.The good things here are that the camera is remotely movable and zoomable; the monitor works while plugged in, a plus due both to previous battery issues and the fact that this battery needs recharging pretty much every night; and the sound is quite clear and volume-controllable. The temperature feature seems somewhat redundant unless you keep your baby in distant cabin on the other end of your property, in which case both the temp and long wireless range of this unit will come in handy.All told, it's a good unit, but comparing this to other units, I would price it at 150, not its present 250 here. And if you're just copying your previous unit, why is the price the same and not a fair bit lower? There are a TON of baby monitors out there now, and you would do well to compare all of them on this site. There are about a dozen setups that do what this does, and some of them come very close while costing under 100 clams, so shop around.

This is a heavy duty water bottle for people who understand how serious an issue leaching from plastic can be (look up BPA leaching, etc). It weighs a fair bit but that's because it's good thick glass with a pretty solid rubber coating, triple thick on the bottom, a wise design feature. I dropped it from a few feet and it didn't break, whereas glass certainly would have.The lid is very wide, excellent for pouring stuff in and especially for inserting ice cubes, a big plus over most bottles. I generally prefer to reuse ice tea bottles etc, but for serious hiking, this is my new go-to container. I don't mind the weight as it means the glass is unlikely to break on me. The thick metal lid has a wide rubber grommet to prevent spillage, another plus over most bottles.It also has a strong carrying cord that is tightly attached but easily removable via spring-clip.Another reviewer said if you spill juice down the inside of the rubber it can't be cleaned, but in fact you can peel the rubber back and sponge the glass and rubber off and put it back on. You can also take the rubber all the way off with a little effort. Not easily, but I just did it one minute ago so it is doable. Yet this called a "water bottle", not "all liquid container", so H20 is clearly its intended use. One nice thing about is water is you don't have to worry about it getting sticky on you!For 15 bucks this is a very good deal, as it seems ready to last for years, and the wide mouth and thick metal parts all show a willingness from the company to make the best water bottle they could. I really do love this bottle; it's the best of its kind.

This is a good, warming tea for not only mothers but all people. The cardamom and shatavari and marshmallow leaves combine to make a pleasant tasting, mildly calming herbal brew that I enjoy in the evenings. Can't comment on the mother's milk aspect, but it is certainly a tasty concoction with a tonic effect, and it's wonderful that everything in it is organic. Worth trying if you need a soothing, very mildly bracing tea.

There are so many awesome things about this camera. One thing I have to say about this camera is it is so simple to use. Once you open the box and pop in a memory card you are ready to go! Mine came with enough charge to play around with the camera but you may want to charge it before using it first. I did not need any instructions to figure out the camera which is awesome. When you get a cool new toy you don’t want to waste time reading a book! Something that is very great about this camera vs the last one I tried is the case and the buttons. You are able to push every button so easily which is important in an action camera. The case is also very secure and water tight and helps to protect the camera. (My sister dropped it off her horse and it didn’t break!). As far as video quality goes it is very good for what the camera cost. You are able to see everything clear even on the small screen and the colors are nice and bright. The playback is a little shaky when you are filming in motion (and chances are that is what you will be doing) but besides that I don’t really have anything bad to say about this camera. We haven’t gone on any big adventures since getting this camera but I am excited to take it to the lake once the weather warms up! Action cam was provided for evaluation and feedback.

This is a great set of containers. I love the different colored lids. If I am prepacking several meals I can just place the lids on with the order I need to pull the meals out. Rainbow order! Eat the red first, then orange, followed by yellow etc! Very easy to remember. These are great for proportioned meals since they can be put in the freezer or dishwasher. They are also great for packing lunches when you have a house full. Everyone in my family likes different lunches so they now all have a designated color so they always know which lunch to grab. The containers fit perfect in everyone’s lunch and even my youngest is able to remove and replace the lid by herself. Containers were provided for evaluation and feedback.

This is a great box for any essential oil user. I have several different oils from several companies and I tried each one in this box and they all fit perfectly. It makes the most sense to store your oils that have lid labels in this box since you can not see the front of the bottle when they are stored in this. The wooden insert dividers are a little tricky to get apart at first but once you get the hang of it then it is very simple. I played around with several way to store my oils and finally decided it was best with all the inserts put in but I would love to get another box that I could store my roller bottles and homemade blends in. This is a great case and love the simple but effective design. Essential oil box was provided for evaluation and feedback.

I lo ooooo ooooooove this litter mat. It is twice the size of my old one and it works way better. I love that it is large enough I could set my whole litter box on it if I wanted. Right now, since we have a box with a door I just have the front half sitting on it. This mat is huge and my cat has to step on it to get out. It gets all the extra litter off his paws and traps it in the mat. About once a week I take the mat outside and shake it off pretty well and most of the litter comes out. It may need to be vacuumed from time to time but not very often if you shake it. This mat works so great and I am thrilled that I am no longer stepping on little litter rocks all the time. Litter mat was provided for evaluation and feedback.

I have a lot of pain in my wrist and thumb that gets a lot worse when I am on my computer a lot. I really weren't sure these compression sleeves would help my pain at all but they do!! When you first put them on they are a little annoying since they are so tight but that part is necessary for the compression aspect. I wore these the whole time I typed yesterday and then ending up wearing these for several more hours because I forgot they were even on and to my surprise I had no added wrist pain from the typing. This is a big deal for me because normally my hands will hurt very bad after typing and this time I had no more pain. I tried the sleeves again today just to make sure and I can say they really do help me. I will be keeping this pair in the top drawer of my desk so I am sure to always put them on. Copper wrist support was provided for evaluation and feedback.

This is super cool product. It is my first time playing with liquid latex. First thing I noticed is the smell. Not to nice but as long as you have a fan going you won’t even notice it and even without a fan the smell goes away very quickly. I dipped a paint brush into the liquid latex and sort of painted my finger and was a little surprised at how thin the liquid is. I really expected something different. If you are planning on making scars or wounds you will have to paint on several layers or apply it very thick. A big positive to it being thin though is that it dries extremely quick. This really comes in handy if you are using the liquid latex to work on your nail art. This stuff is great for painting the skin around your finger nail and then using the water marble technique. When you are done with your nails you can just peel off the latex and all the extra nail polish comes right off. I am excited to keep playing with this stuff to see what else I can do with it. Liquid latex was provided for evaluation and feedback.

Let me say that I have never had a real pair of Rayban wayfarer glassed to compare these to but I must say these are some nice glasses for a tiny fraction of the price of the real deal. Theses glasses come in a nice kit and have an included cleaning cloth. These glasses are very sturdy plastic and have been dropped by my daughter a few times and didn't break or scratch. I like the way they look on my and the fit is comfortable my ears and nose. They also do a great job of blocking the sun when I am at my kids soccer games. I am really enjoying these Rivacci wayfarer glasses. Oh they say they are mens glasses but I think they look good on me, and my husband can wear them too! sunglasses were provided for evaluation and feedback.

First off, I really like the way this fan looks. I know it isn’t seen much since my computer is sitting on it but it is still nice to have a sharp looking fan. I really love that this cooling fan has a usb cord that is plenty long enough to reach any usb port on my computer. I also like the placement of the fan. It is right in the middle and it is quite large so it puts out plenty of air to keep my laptop cool. I recently did a big update on my computer which took several hours and my computer never got even a tiny bit hot thanks to this product. Cooling fan was provided for evaluation and feedback.

I love that this is great for at home or on the go. I am quite bathroom shy and I really hate to take care of business when I am at someone’s house or when someone is at my house. But sometimes you just gotta go and it’s not good to hold it in. This spray is easy to use. Just a pump or two in the toilet before going and it will make a film on the water that will trap the scent. After going all you smell is the rose smell instead of the business you just flushed. I think every bathroom should have a bottle of this sitting where guest can see it and every bathroom shy person should carry some in their bag! Product was provided for evaluation and feedback.

This hair mask really works great for frizzy hair. I like that the instructions say to apply to damp hair instead of towel dried hair (because let’s be honest, how many people are going to towel dry their hair before doing this type of hair mask). The smell of this mask is great but it is very strong well the mask is sitting on your hair. It may be a little much for people sensitive to scents. The positive thing about having a strong scent is the yummy smell actually stays in your hair and you get little wiffs of it later in the day. This product was easy to use and spread around my hair. I don’t time it but I would say I leave it on for the full 5 minutes if not more then I rinse with cold water. It leaves my hair very soft and really helps to cut back on some of the frizz. Hair mask was provided for evaluation and feedback.

These are nice for people with smaller freezer or for people like me who have a ton of junk in the freezer which means you are forced to do a balancing act with the ice cube trays. (and yes I have had an ice cube try fall over and spill water all over stuff which obviously froze). I like that these have lids so if they happen to fall no damage is done. The lids also mean that the trays are easier to stack. I also like that they aren’t as long as other trays. The ices comes out of the trays very easy. I think the price is a little high but they do seem like good quality ice cube trays and they are the first I have seen with a locking, spill proof lid. *Ice cube trays were provided for evaluation and feedback.

This stuff leaves my hair super soft and smooth. I use it about once a week in the shower. I get in and shampoo right away and then do regular conditioner. After I rinse I will put a nice coat of this product and comb it through and let it sit on for the remaining of my shower. I really love the way it smells and I love that it didn’t make my hair oily. I did not put it right on my scalp like the directions say though. I also have put it on the ends of my dry hair at night before I go to bed and then wash it out the next mornings. Both methods work great. This hair mask was provided for my evaluation and feedback.

I have now tried the HSI shampoo and conditioner. My favorite thing about these hair products is just how great they smell. It is wonderful. I have only used the conditioner once so far. Sadly my pump came broken and it will not distribute and condition so I have to take the top of and screw it into my hair. Since the conditioner is so thick I find this task a little annoying. Besides that my hair was great when I used it and I will continue use when I remember to try and transfer the condition into a different container. It is unfortunate though because I feel like a lot of the product will be left behind in the bottle. Conditioner was provided for evaluation and review. (Would be 5 stars if pump worked)

This organizer looks nice. I do wish it did not have the pen holder as it a little cheap feeling and also none of the pens I have will fit in it. I wish it came with a pen or was slightly larger so I did not have to buy a special pen for it. I ended up just ripping mine of. I didn’t really pay much attention to the included calendar but I suppose it would be nice to have in a pinch. I do love the organizer thought and I actually keep it in the kitchen. I now always know where post it notes are when I need to leave a note and remind my husband to take the trash out or send a sweet note in my child’s lunch box. This organizer was provided for evaluation and feedback.

This is a soft mat and is going to be perfect for the cold winter that is quickly approaching. Right now it is still pretty warm where I live and my cat hasn’t seemed very interested in this mat. He has long hair though and doesn’t seem to get cold much. However, I have a shih Tzu who is shaved down and she is always looking for a warm spot to cuddle up. She loves this thermal mat. I have a feeling my cat will like it two once it gets colder and he needs a warm place to sleep. But for now as long as one of my fur babies like it then I am happy. Thermal mat was provided for evaluation and feedback.

These are great beach balls. There is a nice variety of colors in this pack. I like how durable they are. My kids are pretty rough with them and we have not had any pop or get holes. They also stay blown up for a long time without needing air added to them. They are more expensive than other beach balls on amazon but I have gotten cheaper ones that just did not last so they may really be worth the extra price. The best things we have done with these beach balls is write my sons sight words on them (and write ABCs on the other). We then use the balls to play catch and whatever my sons thumb land on they have to read. It is a really fun way to practice new words and letters. *These beach balls were provided for evaluation and feedback. They are a little high but they are positively great quality and deserve 5 stars.

I have De Quervain's tendonitis (aka mommy thumb) in both of my hands. Some days it is very painful. I am a big user of biofreeze and Icyhot but I have two issues with these creams. First it's very short relief; once the cooling goes away the pain comes back. Secondly I cannot have icyhot all over my hands when I have small children I will be picking up. This cream beats both of those issues. Since it doesn't warm or cool you can't really feel it working but a few minutes after rubbing this on my inner hands and wrist my pain is gone. The pain stays gone for quite some time too. Also I am able to put this on and rub It in than pick up my kids without worrying I will give them the icyhot sensation. I also really love that this doesn't have the mint smell. **I did receive a jar to test and review and I am very happy with it  but since I try and review as if I paid full price I must say this is a pretty small jar for the price and it isn't something I would be able to keep in stock in my house. It is more expensive than icyhot but it also works much better. ... I also have to point out the box it comes in is very cute!!

I love my captain America flash drive! It's different that any I have seen and would be perfect for a high school or college kid who needs to store things on a drive. The fun design makes it easy to find your flash drive in a crowd! I didn't have to do anything to be able to use it. Just slide the button and plug it in. I moved my files over which took a few minutes because I had so many. I then plugged the flash drive into my husband's computer just to make sure all my files had saved properly and they did. This flash drive is great. I would suggest making sure you are holding the flash drive straight when plugging it in. I wasn't paying attention the first time and it made the USB part feel a little flimsy. This wasn't a problem when I paid closer attention. Flash drive was provided for my evaluation and feedbackOh and it comes in a nice box that would be great for gift giving but I expected it to be in a captain America box instead of an iron man box

This is a great big bottle of shampoo and I am glad because I really like it. I am not going to say it made my hair 100% frizz free but it does help my frizz problem. I feel like I need a bit more of this shampoo to completely wash my hair vs the amount I used with my other shampoo. I could probably use less if I wanted to spend the extra time spreading it through my hair. The best part about this shampoo is the smell. Oh my goodness I love it. It positively smells like something they would use in my hair salon. I also really love the end results after I wash and condition and flat iron my hair. It is very soft and silky! This shampoo was provided for my evaluation and feedback. The amazing scent helps give it 5 stars! If it didn't smell this great I would probably give it 4

My Children absolutely love sands alive! We got some pink sand a few months ago and my kids both love it so much it was a constant battle to take turns so we knew we'd have to get more. Finally we got some blue sand for my son. This sand is amazing. It's by far the best sensory toy we have. We have tried store bought and home made moon, kinetic, and cloud sand and my kids love this the most and I love that it doesn't make a mess of the table. (You will want to put a spare tarp or shower curtain down if you are playing with it over carpet. It did come out of my carpet but I had to vacuum several times). When the sand comes you will want to empty it into a container and let it breathe over night. The sand will get even softer and fluffier! This size pack makes a nice amount of sand and is more than enough for my son to make some pretty cool tower. It's also a super nice bonus to get some molds in with the sand! We also used some small cups and cookie cutters with the sand. One of my children's favorite things to do is make large balls or blocks with the sand and squish it down. I am not exaggerating at all when I say my kids will sit down at the table and both play quietly with their sand for a full hour! My son even asked to take his new blue sand to show and tell. This sand alive building kit was provided for evaluation and feedback. I cannot say enough good about it! It is so much fun and keeps my kids very entertained

I’m thankful I was able to purchase this MasterPro ultrasonic pest repeller at a reduced price in exchange for an unbiased  product evaluation and review.We’ve been battling silverfish for years.  I bought this device in hopes of it helping and it seems to be.  It’s a bit hard to gage but I base this on the fact that each night when I turn on my bedroom light, I will see anywhere from one to three silverfish on the vinyl floor as I walk toward the bed.  It just makes me want to scream (or cry, or both!)We’ve tried commercial sticky traps (worthless), rolling up damp newspaper (also worthless), and placing masking tape on the outside of a glass with it going slightly over the top and into the inside (actually, this trick does work, but not well enough to make a difference in the silverfish population).  We have diatomaceous earth in our drawers, closet, around the bedframe, etc.  (no way to judge if this has helped or not).Since plugging this device into the outlet in our bedroom, I’m not seeing the silverfish at night when I turn on the light (only 1 since plugging it in last week).  I don’t know if the little buggers are leaving, hiding better, or of if it is simply coincidence.  I read testing reports that say these devices have not been scientifically proven work, but so far, it appears to helping.  I have a friend who was able to rid his home of rodents with an ultrasonic repeller.  He’s the one who suggested I try it.  I was not able to put this at the suggested height but that doesn’t seem to be a problem.My dog and cats do not act as though they are bothered by anything, soundwise, and I don’t notice anything, so that’s good.  Obviously, do not use this product if you have pet rats, hamsters, mice, etc. since these are among the critters this unit is meant to repel.This repeller came with a complimentary PDF (How To Keep Your Home Pest Free) email that was very informative in regard to how to deal with a wide variety of pests, so be sure to keep an eye out in your email for that after you buy this.

I’m happy I was able to purchase this Mr. Herb grinder at a reduced price in exchange for an unbiased product evaluation and review.  It works very well.My friend has been using a poorly-made plastic grinder for her cooking herbs / spices / small seeds, so I gifted this one to her.  She’s amazed at the difference.  Unlike her old grinder, the Mr. Herb grinder’s magnetic lid turns back and forth smoothly and stays on, and the threading allows the pieces to easily come apart and go back together.This unit cleans up well with soap and water (use a toothbrush to get between the sharp teeth). Use a little alcohol on the toothbrush first if the blades are sticky, followed by the soap and water.Overall, this is an excellent grinder and I’m glad I bought it for my friend.

1:06 MinsI’m excited to have been selected to purchase this NaskaShop diffuser at a reduced price in exchange for an unbiased product evaluation and review.  I’m loving it.PROS:* Super quiet operation* Easy to remove top, fill chamber (I use distilled water), and replace top* Can be used as only a lighting accent with choice of color* Good volume of mist when using as diffuser* Choice of continuous mist or intermittent (30 seconds on / 30 seconds off – I like this setting)* Can be used with or without essential oils* Simple to rinse cleanCONS:* Beeping sound each time a button is pressedMy video doesn’t do justice to how nice the colors look.  There’s 8 main colors to choose from, with two settings (basically a high / low) for each, so a total of 16 variations.Nothing to do with function, but I really like that the electrical connection is a two-prong slimline so it doesn’t hog up extra space when plugged in. No matter where I connect this, in my wall outlet or in my power strip, it doesn’t block the others.I’m really pleased with this purchase.

My father has BPH so I’m glad I was able to purchase this NutriSage saw palmetto for him at a reduced price in exchange for an unbiased product evaluation and review.My father has been taking this as directed on the bottle (1 capsule daily) and he just told me he is getting up less frequently at night to urinate (only once now instead of twice).  So, I’m glad it seems to be helping him.I did look up interactions to make sure it was safe for him and noted that saw palmetto shouldn’t be taken by those who are using any kind of anti-coagulant, so if you are on “blood thinners” do be cautious and speak with your doctor before adding this to your regimen.  Also note, there is a warning on the bottle for anyone with allergies like nuts, eggs, etc. as these are also in the facility where these capsules are manufactured.

I’m thrilled to have been one of those selected to receive this Manuka Lane face moisturizer at no cost in exchange for an unbiased product evaluation and review.I’ve long known of the many benefits of manuka honey but I’ve never tried any products with bee venom in it.  I have sensitive skin so I was sure to apply this to the back of my hand and waited several hours to see if I’d have any reaction to it (I do this with many products).After knowing it was safe for me, I began using this cream on my face.  It goes on lightly, absorbs well, and leaves my skin feeling refreshed.  I do notice a very mild, brief tingling from it, but this face life cream is completely agreeable to my skin.  It has just a hint of a pleasant, sweet scent to me.  I’m scent sensitive and this is very subtle (which is what I need).  I'm sure this next comment will apply to only a few people, but I've noticed this cream seems to make the strap mark left on my face by my VPAP machine headgear disappear more quickly.I notice that even my fingers are softer after applying this cream so I also use put a tad on the backs of my hands and rub them together.  I’m very pleased with this cream.

I was lucky to have been selected to purchase this Xestware rollup rack at a reduced price in exchange for an unbiased product evaluation and review. It is very useful.This rollup rack is very handy.  There’s many uses, as shown in the product listing, but here’s our favorite:When we come home from the grocery store, no produce goes in our fridge without being washed first.  This normally means we end up with our entire sink full of just-washed foods, as well as some of our countertop (which ends up getting wet and messy).  Now, we are able to still fill the sink with food, and the rack give us just enough additional overflow space that we no longer have to spread paper towels out on our countertop for the rest.  Anything that didn’t fit in the sink, now goes on the rack.The next best use, for us, is placing the cutting sheet on top it.  Brilliant!  I was always having to clean up the counter after cutting foods, especially if they were juicy. Now, the juices and tidbits fall into the sink. After, I can soap and wash the cutting surface, flip it, rinse, then give the roll-up rack a quick wash down at the same time.  Note: The only case in which this doesn’t work great for holding the cutting sheet is if I’m working with something that requires a lot of pressure (e.g.: cutting frozen kielbasa or carving larger (heavy) meats ... small ones are fine, especially the tender ones from the pressure cooker).  The rack is slightly flexible, so for those times when a lot of pressure is needed, I still use the solid countertop.I just let it air dry then give it one more wipe with a dry paper towel, roll it up, then stash it in the oven when not in use.  Very convenient.  Though it certainly looks nice enough that one could leave it out at all times if they wanted.I’m happy I bought this.  It’s definitely going with me to my mom’s house for Thanksgiving meal prep.  She is very short on counter space and being able to put this over her sink is going to make a huge difference for me while cooking.

I’m happy I was able to purchase these BoTy dog poop bags at a reduced price in exchange for an unbiased product evaluation and review.These bags are great for scooping up and disposing of my dog’s doody, however…..I also have two cats and two litter boxes in the house. I try to reuse as many plastic bags as I can (like those from cheese, bread, veggies, deli meat, etc.) but that can be a little messy or smelly, depending what was originally in them. I’m loving how compact and clean these poop bags are.  They are super convenient for storing near and using for collecting the litter (poop and urine clumps) from the boxes.  Easy to tie up and toss in the trash can, where these bags do a good job of keeping it from smelling. They are perfect for my needs.

My friend just got their first smart phone so I’m happy I was able to purchase this Galaxy S6 Edge case at a reduced price in exchange for an unbiased product evaluation and review.  I knew she’d be the perfect person to use it.My friend is really happy with this phone case.  Though she’s not yet dropped her phone, I’m glad this case includes extra protection on the corners because, as most of us know, at some point we pretty much all are going to drop our phones.She tells me she’s had no problems using the buttons on the phone and there’s no interference while using the screen, charger, headphone jack, or hearing from the built-in speaker.  I’m so glad I was able to give her such a useful gift.

I love trying a variety of skin care products so I’m glad I was able to purchase this Spin Trap serum at a reduced price in exchange for an unbiased product evaluation and review.The serum has a light, pleasant scent, though I’m unsure of how to describe it.  It isn’t what I would call sweet, citrus, spicy, or woodsy.  I guess it could be considered a floral? I’m sorry, I know this isn’t much help for those like myself who really want to know what something smells like prior to buying.  I can say that I’m scent sensitive and I don’t find this overpowering.The texture is similar to a gel, not a cream.  It feels to me just a tiny bit sticky immediately after applying it, like there is a coating on my face, but after a short while that feeling goes away.  I’m so used to creams that soak in fairly quickly, that it took a few applications of this serum for me to get used to that more firm sensation.  Now, it doesn’t bother me, and it does leave my skin soft without any irritation.

I’m excited that I was able to purchase Bubba’s enzymatic cleaner at a reduced price in exchange for an unbiased product evaluation and review.  This stuff is great!I have a dog and two cats so cleanup around the house is a daily occurrence.  Not so much for urine (though occasionally that too) but the little things like hairballs or regurgitated food.  That’s what originally got my attention about this product, and it does work well for the things, but after reading all it can be used for, I’m even more thrilled.My favorite new uses for this product are spritzing it:* In the litter box after washing it but before putting in the new litter (I wipe it dry after using the spray)* In the kitchen trash can before putting in a new bag (better than the spray I was using)* In the front loading washer to freshen it up* On and around the toilet in the bathroom (gentlemen …  Take note!)My dog likes to go wee in the same spot in the yard, on the outside of the trash can, which has gotten rather pungent recently.  This spray even works on that.This does have a rather strong scent while wet (not unpleasant, just strong to me, but I am scent sensitive).  However, once dry, it just leaves the area fresh.  I only use the sprayer on the “mist” option, but there is also a “stream” option if there is ever a time that I need to actually soak an area.  I’m really pleased with this purchase.

loving the comfort of this!Packaging:  It came folded up in a correctly sized box.  It unfolded easily without any crease or warping due to being folded. No chemical smell at all.It is heavy though (surprisingly so), and more than a little cumbersome, so I strongly advise you to carry the box up to the bedroom or pull out the folded product and carry it up still in its plastic. Then lay it out on the bed still folded and encased before cutting (carefully) the plastic--that way it will spring open on the bed and you'll only need minor adjusting.It was a perfect fit for our queen size bed--no hanging over and just a little (very, very little) smaller.  Less than an inch smaller.As for the comfort, we can't say enough about it.  We both lay on it even before we put the sheets on and just said aloud "wow" and "whose", and then neither of us wanted to get up. We've been sleeping on it for a few weeks now and still love it, possibly love it even more than at first. It is Auber-comfortable and you'll have to pry it out from under our cold dead bodies to get it off our bed at this point.  Highly, highly recommended!

So far so good with the sturdily built, relatively compact, good sounding speaker1)  Packaging:  packaging was minimal, no excessive space or paper or other such product and easy to open2) The Jam came charged and I got a bit over six hours on the "shipped charged"  battery.  When I fully charge it and run it again I'll update. I assume the fully charged will up the hours3)  build quality is excellent. It certainly lives up to its "heavy" name.  I wouldn't want to wander around the neighborhood with it, but who would do that?  So I prefer the heft for the sense it gives of superior durability.  This thing feels like it will stand up to lots of abuse, and it has a decent modernist look to it as well.4) Pairing:  it paired immediately with all my Apple devices, not a single issue with a MacBook Pro, an iPad2, and a 5th Generation iPod Touch.  All recognized it, paired, and were playing music in seconds5) Sound quality was quite good across the range.  Very sharp and precise, especially in the treble range. I'm not sure I'd call the bass booming, but certainly solid and deep enough for me. Not at all tinny or weak sounding.  And the volume cranks up pretty high without distorting.Will update with a full battery, but for build quality and sound quality, Jam seems to have  a winner with this one

Whether it be short stories or poetry, I always pick up a collection assuming I won’t like the whole thing.  With short stories, I’m generally pretty happy if I like more than half and thrilled if it’s over three-quarters.  With poetry anthologies, especially those by multiple authors, it’s a bit of a different story.  Give me a handful of poems that strike me on the spot, or that linger in the mind long after (sometimes they’re the same and sometimes not), or even some lines that wow me, and I’m good.  Because one good poem, or three powerful lines can make up for a whole lot of “meh.”  If you can’t find underlines or margin notes (or in the case of my Kindle, highlights and bookmarks) in my poetry book, I didn’t much care for it.  So how does Best American Poetry 2015 fare on this scale? Pretty good, even if to be honest there were a lot of poems that just didn’t do it for me.  But as poetry is so incredibly subjective, and as a reader isn’t investing in a 900-page novel, I’m going to focus less on what I didn’t care for and more on what I did (if I refer to great lines but don’t offer them up, it’s so as not to ruin the effect of their arrival in the poem for the reader).Jame’s Galvin’s “On the Sadness of Wedding Dresses” is a plainspoken piece that begins with a striking conception:On starless, windless nights like thisI imagineI can hear the wedding dressesWeeping in their closetsLuminescent with hopeless longing,Like hollow angels.and then moves on to some surprisingly evocative imagery as the dressesturn yellow over time,Yellow from prayingFor the moths to comeAnd carry them into the sky.The sky reappears at the close in a much more starkly concrete image, but one probably unexpected by the readers.Madelyn Garner imagines the inner thoughts of a next-door neighbor who comes outside,In her florid pink nightgown,Exposed  breasts like pendulumsAs she kneels in the gravelSpeaking to an empty planter.  As the two of usWait in the kitchenFor her children, it is clearHer thoughts floatFrom the back of the skull to the front . . .How resigned she seemsTo the eviction notices her body is receiving.Along with her neighbor’s thought, the speaker thinks as well of the neighbor’s family, their conversation about selling the houseBecause she is a system of bone and bloodBecause her hands are rusted hingesBecause wisps of spiderwebs float behind eyelidsThe brief stanzas, the sound quality, the use of repetition all build to a thoughtful, powerful impact, especially in the closing lines.“Goodness in Mississippi,” by Lawanda Walters, is another poem that ends with a killer close.  The piece opens with a great sense of voice:My friend said I wasn’t fat but she was, and we would go on that way, back and forth. She was my first realFriend, the kind who changes everything. Her mother was so cool,Didn’t shave down there for the country clubPool where weSat beside her. I saw a gleam of her secret, silverHairThe conversation tone, the sense of confidence lulls the reader into a kind of peacefulness, one shattered by a brutal ending that has stayed with me.An excerpt from Claudia Rankine’s Citizen, meanwhile, which may be as much essay as poem and makes highly effective use of second person should send all readers straight to her collection, if you haven’t already read it.Laura Kasischke’s “For the Young Woman I Saw Hit by a Car While Riding Her Bike” gives us a piece whose trauma lies not with the bike rider (“I’ll tell you upfront: She was fine”) but with the witness, who after imagining the young girl laughing over the witness’ reaction, thinks:But, ah, sweetThing, takePity. OneDay you too may beAn accumulationOf regrets, catastrophes.And then moves the reader into unforeseen territory, allowing us not just understanding, but that sense of pity she so gently asks of the young woman.There are other strong poems in the collection, and even more strong lines, even if the poems they are contained in didn’t succeed as a whole for me.  And yes, lots of the poems just didn’t work at all for me. Some felt more language game than poem, others were technically impressive but left me feeling cold, some I couldn’t recall for you a few minutes after reading them.  But as mentioned, I expect that in a poetry anthology. The joy is that there is so much here, and the editors have spread such a wide banquet in terms of style, length, and diversity of perspective that it’s hard to imagine someone not finding several poems and even more lines that they too would highlight or read to their significant other or a friend, even if they aren’t the same ones. I would have preferred to have enjoyed more of the poems as a whole, but I can live happily with what I loved.

Last year I gave Robin Hobb’s Fool’s Assassin five stars and put it on my list of Best Books of 2014.  Which puts me into a bit of a bind with her follow up, Fool’s Quest, since it’s even better. Clearly it will go on my Best of list for this year, but what about that ranking? I may have to petition our fearless leader Kat for a sixth star waiver, or a five-plus category.  Because in my mind, Fool’s Quest absolutely deserves that distinction.One of the reasons I found it a “better” book is that as much as I loved Fool’s Assassin (and I did love it), I could see how many readers might grow frustrated at its focus on personal relationships and um, “leisurely” pacing filled with small-bore domestic detail and frequent moments of introspection (though at this point, I’m not sure why you’re reading Hobb if introspection isn’t your thing).  Here though, those wishing for a little more plot in their plot shouldn’t have much to complain about. Yes, we still have long passages of Fitz musing on his life, detailed descriptions of clothes and food, and relationship, as always with Hobb, is the driver of nearly everything. But in Fool’s Quest we also get sword fights, chase scenes, escape attempts, wild gallops, dragons, torture, mutiny, vicious raids, and more.  In other words, it’s a more traditional balance of quietude and action, of inner and outer focus.Fans of this series will also I think get excited about how the different worlds of Hobb’s fantasy universe (Buckeep, Bingtown, Rain Wild) start to come together here, as the novel seems to point to a merging/capping off of these ‘till now mostly separate strands. We also get some scenes that call back to or shed a different light on earlier events in the series, adding to the feeling that Hobb is moving us slowly toward some closure.Even though I think most people will react more positively to Fool’s Quest thanks to its uptick in more traditional action scenes, what brings me back again and again to Hobb’;s work, and what makes this series one of my all-time favorites has always been, and remains, Hobb’s general strength in characterization. In particular, her greatest creation (and I’d argue one of fantasy’s greatest as well. Or heck, just literature’s)— FitzChivalry Farseer.  Hobb shows Fitz in the totality of his personality—good and bad, nobility and pettiness, selflessness and selfishness. It’s all here, the whole panoply of humanity, warts and all.Here, for example, is a scene between Fitz and the Fool, just after Fitz has refused to rush out and do something the Fool begs him to do:  He stared sightlessly at me as if I had said the cruelest thing in the world to him. Then is lower jaw trembled, and he dropped his face into his broken hands and began to sob.  I felt sharp annoyance and then deep guilt that I’d felt it. He was in agony. I knew it. How could I feel annoyed at him when I knew exactly what he was experiencing? Hadn’t I felt that way myself? Had I forgotten the times when my experiences in Regal’s dungeons washed over me like a wave, obliterating whatever was good and safe in my life and carrying me right back into that chaos and ruin?  No. I tried to forget that, and in the last decade of years, for the most part I had . . . “Please, don’t make me remember that.”  I realized I’d said the betraying words out loud.”How painfully real is it that Fitz, when his friend breaks down into tears, doesn’t feel sorrow or pity but annoyance? Annoyance!  What a crappy friend!  But that’s what makes Fitz and all the others feel so human. And then he feels guilt, and we as readers feel better about our protagonist. But then he goes back into his own world and has that selfish “don’t make me remember that” line—focused more on himself than on the Fool.There are so many such moments throughout this novel, this series, that Fitz has become such an accretion of tiny details over the years that it’s hard to remember he isn’t real. You know you’ve fallen wholly for a character, have completely bought into their human existence, when you tear up for a character not in a moment of tragedy (that kind of emotion can be easy to manipulate), but in a moment of happiness.  And that’s exactly what I did here.  Teared up, choked up, held the book loosely open in my hands for a minute or two without seeing the words, just reveling in this well-earned moment of joy for this character, this person I’ve spent so much time with over the years.  And then went back and reread it once I finished the book. And had the same reaction.  In fact, I choked up several times throughout the novel, which makes me worry just a tad about what might happen in the final book of this series.Of course, characters don’t become “great” on their own. Sure, Hobb creates three-dimensional characters who are compelling in their own right:  Fitz, the Fool, Bee, Chade, Riddle. Hell, she’s so good she creates compelling alias characters—some of Fitz’s disguises are more rounded characters than other authors’ protagonists.  Her animal characters are more “human” than some authors’ protagonists (Nighteyes, of course. But I defy you not to warm to “Crow” and “Horse” and even “Cat” in this book). The true genius of Hobb, however, lies not in the individual depiction of character, not in the parts, but in the whole—in the entirety of the complex web of human (and animal) interaction. And depicting this web, and having its individual strands resonate in the reader’s heart and mind, is something Hobb does perhaps better than anyone. It isn’t Fitz and the Fool and Chade and Nettle that get to me in this book; it’s Fitz with the Fool, Fitz with Chade, Fitz with Nettle.  Some of these interactions are touching, some are warm, some (not a lot) are funny, and some are just heartbreaking, heartbreaking in the present moment, but also heartbreaking in the anticipated future.The topics and/or themes of Fool’s Quest will be familiar to Hobb’s fans:  the impact of loss and the attempt to overcome it, the ways in which events of the past continue to ripple through time, the impact of violence on both the victims and the perpetrator, what makes for good parenting, free will. One aspect I do want to mention with regard to the violence is the depiction of rape in the novel.  I’ve pointed in recent reviews to major issues I’ve had with how rape is employed in many novels lately.  Its use here is, no surprise coming from Hobb, serious, moving, and realistic, with no hint of gratuitousness or of its use as a “motivating technique.”  Its lingering impact, as depicted in several passages, is crushing.  Lots of authors could do worse than study Hobb’s portrayal before they turn to it as a plot element in their own works.Beyond plot and character, the basic novel elements are just as one expects by now from a craftsman such as Hobb. The prose is vivid, sharply precise, evocative. Pacing and scene transition are expertly handled. Hobbs has always been a consummate writer, and that holds true here.I loved Fool’s Quest (so much so that I read its 750 pages in a single sitting), hated that it ended (and ended in a bit of a cliffhanger), and find myself in the position of eagerly awaiting the next book but also fearing it, nervous that I might have to say goodbye to Fitz and his world and knowing already that I’m “gonna need some lone time” if that turns out to be the case.  I might just stack up the earlier books next to me so I can start over from the beginning right away.

The Autumnlands, written by Kurt Busiek and visuals by Benjamin Dewey (art) and Jordie Bellaire (color), is an intriguing graphic series with lots of action, a complex character, and a visually and intellectually stimulating setting. The first six issues, which you can get separately or bundled into Volume One Tooth and Claw, resolve a particular arc, but are really mostly set up for further exploration of world and character.The story is set in a world peopled by animal races, themselves apparently separated into those who dwell in seventeen floating cities—masters of magic and technology—and land-dwellers (“the lesser ones”) who slave for them. The magic of their world, however, is failing, and so in a last desperate attempt to rejuvenate it, a group of wizards, against the wishes of the ruling council, try to bring back the, “The Great Champion,” the fabled warrior who ages ago, “facing the world’s destruction and certain death, opened the gates of magic and brought its power to us.”  Things, to say the least, do not go well.One of my favorite aspects of this story is summed up pithily in the back blurb:  “They needed a savior. They got a soldier.” What they are hoping for is a champion in the mode of great epic tales—one who wins against all odds but does so in noble, graceful fashion. What their spells get them (and it is a running question as to whether or not he is their true “great champion”) is a soldier who believes in surviving battles. And that means doing what is necessary, even if it is ugly and ignoble. This twist keeps a running tension throughout the storyline that adds not only some plot suspense but also a bit of depth as it forces not just the characters but the reader to question the ethics of particular choices/events. Busiek also does a nice job of playing off of this contrast between the old stories of heroism and the likely reality of heroism by having brief excerpts from typical epic tales open up each segment of the story.The champion himself, Learoyd, is a nicely drawn character. He maybe adjusts a bit too quickly to being thrust into such an alien world, but in a nice bit of dialogue, he explains to one character who wonders about his relatively sudden shift from trying to convince himself it was all a dream or hallucination:  “Maybe isn’t, maybe it is. But if so, it doesn’t have to be completely damn stupid, does it?”  Other characters aren’t quite such full creations. The wizard who has the idea for the spellwork to call up the Champion starts off pretty strong, but gets relegated to a pretty minor side story in the latter half (though I really liked the portrayal of the relationship between her and her significant other). The wizard opposed to her is a pretty stock type—stuffy greedy oblivious aristocrat type. A Coyote trader character who tries to play both sides between the city characters and the bison slaves (who wish to rebel), has some good potential, but is a pretty small role here. The narrator is a young terrier and as such is mostly a bit of a flat observer, though this changes toward the end and one assumes will continue to do so as the story continues. His flatness I’m guessing is more a portrayal of his youth in preparation for some maturing rather than a flaw of characterization.Visually, the artwork is quite strong, doing an impressive job of giving animal characters readable facial expressions and body language. Background scenes are vivid and colorful, and the art is equally convincing whether it is portraying characters or the natural world. And, as should always be the case in graphic stories, it both supports and extends the text and themes. For instance, that aforementioned tension between the image of the hero and the actuality of the hero is graphically portrayed at his early appearance, covered in blood. The art and text work great in tandem here, with our narrator stunned at the savage appearance:  “He was — He was — There as so much blood, but he didn’t even seem to notice it,” our character depicted baring his teeth and dripping in blood, and the text bubbles a series of nonsense syllables. It’s a great image because not only does it deal with the ideal/actual hero theme, but it also inverts the social structure of our world, with the civilized, dressed, speaking animals horrified by the savage, naked, bloody and growling human.I really had little to complain about with The Autumnlands. As mentioned, Learoyd does settle in kind of easily, but most of the other issues can be easily explained away as simply being a matter of the story only having just begun. But it’s hooked me enough to want to see where it goes. Recommended.originally appeared on fantasyliterature.com

Really, I’ve got to say it’s shocking to me that there hasn’t been a Star Trek/Planet of the Apes crossover until now, with The Primate Directive, a joint graphic venture between IDW Comics and Boom! Studios. The five-volume story is written by Scott and David Tipton, illustrated by Rachael Stott, and colored by Charlie Kirchoff. As a mashup concept, it’s brilliant. As far as this particular execution, though, well, it has its ups and downs, with most of the former coming in the first half.The story opens up with an arms deal with one side proffering automatic weapons to an unnamed General. It’s nicely drawn so as to add a sense of unfolding mystery, with a focus on hands alone on the first page, only revealing one of the two speakers to be a gorilla on page two. The seller, meanwhile, remains a shadowy figure (literally), though Trek fans will most likely pick up on clues via the dialogue as well as memory of a similar occurrence in the original series. The setting, and the color palette, then shift to Uhura and Sulu on an intel-gathering mission deep in Klingon territory, where after a few tense moments, banter, and a display of hand-to-hand combat skills, they return to the Enterprise with coordinates that lead them to an inter-dimensional portal, which they go through after a brief firefight.Yes, it does in fact lead them to the other half of the mash-up. On a strangely similar Earth, they enter the Planet of the Apes tale just after the famous ending of the movie. The Klingons, it turns out, have been selling arms to General Marius and encouraging him to overthrow his ape leaders (Dr. Zaius for one). Kirk, et. al. decide they have to stop the Klingons, but do so with minimal impact on the culture thanks to the Prime Directive. This becomes a more complicated decision once they meet Taylor, who tries to convince him to help the humans overcome the apes, who treat them like livestock or worse. When Kirk refuses, Taylor tries to take matters into his own hands, giving Kirk yet another problem to deal with. Eventually, the story moves through the rest of the Apes movie cycle, with a few changes.To being with the positives, the Tiptons do a great job with the characters, nailing each of them perfectly with regard to their original portrayals. McCoy, for instance, when Kirk is mulling over entering the portal, tells him in his inimitable fashion, “This is hardly the place for space tourism Jim.” Taylor is as angry and aggressively effective as he was in the movie, and the writers haven’t forgotten his views toward humanity, having him explain to Kirk that he joined his mission because he “was hoping to find something better. Something better than man.”  Spock is his usual rational self, Scotty is inventive, and Kirk, along with being his decisive self, even gets his shirt torn in a fight. You can’t get more classic Trek than that, as Galaxy Quest once reminded us. The apes fare just as well, coming off just like their characters in the movies, as when Zira calls Cornelius “primitive” when he says he “won’t allow” her to risk the transporter. The tense relationship between Kirk and Taylor is also perfectly handled; each of them is so used to being in command, to being active and taking the initiative that it should come as no surprise that they don’t fall immediately into an easy partnership. The fact that they have two opposing goals also makes perfect sense, besides offering up motivation for conflict.Another plus is the way the story takes its time in the first two issues, with the slow intro to both worlds via the arms deal and the espionage mission, then the firefight at the portal before entering it. Once on the planet, the writers take the space to create a sense of the Ape’s world and culture, with Zira explaining their stratification (chimpanzees for instance located primarily in academics and science), Zaius via an internal monologue giving us the context of possible famine (which makes General Marius’ actions a bit more understandable), and Cornelius detailing their ethics of “Ape shall never kill Ape.” Meanwhile, the Enterprise crew have sometimes-lengthy debates over what they should or should not do, wondering for example if the Prime Directive even holds in an alternate dimension such as this.Things heat up, and the pace picks up, once Marius makes his move, leading an army against Ape City. These scenes are mostly well done, but it’s shortly after the resolution of the big battle that things started to go off the rails for me. One issue is with Taylor deciding not to take up Kirk’s offer of a trip back to Earth (albeit a different one). The decision I’m fine with, but his reason —  “I left because I thought there had to be something better than human society. I think your world is the same old Earth I left behind . . . I’m never going to fit in there” — makes no sense in the context of this. He has seen nothing at all to indicate that humanity is still as savage or war-torn as his own was in his day, and in fact, given Kirk’s constant attempt to minimize violence and corruption of this world’s society, he’s seen just the opposite.Once they leave Taylor behind, the beam back aboard the Enterprise, only to take part in a weirdly detached cat and mouse game with the Klingons that goes on for a few days, ends in a wholly abrupt and anti-climactic fashion, and seemed to serve no purpose save to have the Enterprise around for when one of the movie events takes place (why I’m avoiding spoilers for 40-year-old movies I don’t know, but I am). And while up to this point one needn’t have known much at all about the movie franchise to make sense of events, at this point, if you don’t know the plot of Escape/Beneath the Planet of the Apes, the ending scenes will seem to come out of nowhere.The artwork is clean and pleasing to the eye, with well-drawn lines and generally makes good sue of color. Fight scenes I thought could have been more clear in terms of the action a few times, and sometimes the reader has to work a bit harder than perhaps they should to distinguish the ape characters from one another (stitching on the sleeves helps), but generally I’d regard the art as mostly a positive. It also offers up some iconic images playing off the films, such as the Statue of Liberty or the crying statue of the Lawgiver.The story definitely veers off its mostly positive path in the latter quarter or so, with abrupt shifts, scenes that appear utterly random and contrived, and odd character choices. Up to that point, however the mash-up was a clear success, with both worlds feeling wholly true to their origins and coming together in a near-perfect melding of character and plot and tone, with mostly good dialogue that occasionally becomes a bit talky or expository. Even with the weak ending, I’d say it’s worth picking up as the positives certainly make up the greater balance of the story. Recommended with caveats about the closing issue or two

Jade Mountain Dragon is about as classic a detective mystery as you can get.  In the main character Li Du, you’ve got your reluctant Everyman sort of character who is pulled into investigating a mysterious death.  You’ve got your “investigator gathers a roomful of suspects and works his/her way through why they could have been the killer and then why they are not” scene.  You have the investigator explaining to a befuddled partner exactly what happened and how he/she figured it out. Overheard conversations, hidden letters, possible femme fatales—they’re all here.  You even get some classic line deliveries:  “I know who killed [X], and I know why. There is not a second to waste.” While most of this is handled smoothly (exceptions to be discussed later), what really makes Jade Mountain Dragon such a pleasure to read is its characterization and its setting—an outlying province in early 18th Century China preparing itself for the arrival of the Emperor.Former librarian Li Du was banished from Beijing by this same Emperor several years earlier (for navely consorting with traitors) and has been a traveling, mostly solitary, scholar ever since. He arrives in Dayan unaware that the Emperor who had exiled him was arriving in six days for a grand festival, at which he will cement his divinity (and thus his power) by commanding an eclipse.  Li Du, of course, knows this is mere theater, that the Emperor’s Jesuit scholars have, as always, predicted the eclipse and the Emperor is merely making use of their science.  But when one of the Jesuits turns up dead, and then is revealed to have been murdered, Dayan’s magistrate, Li Du’s cousin, tasks him with finding the killer before the Emperor’s arrival.Included in the mix of suspects are:The magistrate himselfThe magistrate’s extremely efficient secretary, no fan of foreignersThe magistrate First Consort, a steely woman from the local village who may like her position a bit too muchAnother Jesuit in the cityAn ambassador from the East India Company trying to get the Emperor to open the countryA traveling foreign storyteller with a mysterious pastA pair of characters with ties to the former rulers of the area, ruthlessly conquered by the current EmperorAs mentioned, the strengths of this novel are the characters and the setting.  Li Du especially is sharply drawn and a wonderful character to spend time with.  Equally enjoyable is the foreign storyteller Hamza, whose intermittent tales add a nice bit of flavor to the story.  Other characters all feel fully three-dimensional and are nicely set up as potential killers in ways that feel wholly organic to their characters.The setting, meanwhile, is conveyed through vividly sharp details that create a fully present world that, as is not always the case in historical fiction, serve the story’s characters and atmosphere without calling attention to the author’s research.  Even better, the setting isn’t simply background visual tapestry but the political context drives much of the plot and motivations—the eager desire of the East India Company to get access to China, the tension between the current regime and the remnants of the old one, the Emperor’s need to emphasize his power in a region that has only recently come into the geographic fold, etc.As for the mystery itself, it’s well paced and clues are fairly revealed (some may find them too fairly revealed; it isn’t particularly difficult to suss out what is happening), and Hart does a nice job of tossing in a few “and then” moments, though some of them might have been more fully explored earlier.  It culminates in a strong ending, even if the big reveal in packed room of suspects is more than a bit familiar.In the end, as Li Du heads out, it’s easy to imagine most readers eagerly hoping Hart brings him back for further mysteries. I know, after zipping through Jade Mountain Dragon in a single night, I’d be happy to spend more time with Li Du in this world. Well recommended.

I wasn’t a huge fan of The Maze Runner by James Dashner, thinking its frenetic pace was as much weakness as strength and that its characterization was pretty thin (plus there was the whole let’s not have anyone talk to each other or explain things pet peeve of mine). I admit, however, that it probably would meet the needs of a particular reader—one who likes fast paced action that blows by any annoying plot holes and isn’t particularly looking for a lot of in-depth characterization. That same sort of reader will probably find the sequel, The Scorch Trials, just as satisfying, though again, for my own tastes, it falls mostly short of being a good book. It’s going to be impossible to discuss The Scorch Trials without some spoilers for the first book, so fair warning.The sequel picks up almost immediately after the end of The Maze Runner, with the Gladers having been rescued after their escape from the Maze and brought to a dormitory, with Theresa, as the only girl, placed in a separate room. Turns out their escape, however, was only the end of Phase One of these trials, allegedly meant to somehow save the world from the “Flare” plague (amongst other disasters) by forming mysterious yet apparently necessary “patterns,” in the test subjects. Phase Two begins with the unexplained disappearance of Theresa, the unexplained appearance of a bunch of dead bodies, and then a task to cross a barren wasteland filled with “Cranks” (those affected by the Flare to varying degrees) in order to arrive at “Safe Haven.” Along with the Cranks, who range from merely dangerously unpredictable to dangerously violent to dangerously-zombies-who-want-to-eat-you types, the Glades must also deal with a blistering sun, lethally violent storms, decapitating technology, and another group they apparently are in competition with in what may be a “Only One Group Survives” sort of contest.The strength of The Scorch Trials is again relatively frenetic action, though I think the sequel has more pacing issues in terms of lag time, especially early on, where bouts of excitement are separated by somewhat repetitive and overly-long segments with the Gladers discussing what to do about their current situation. As with its predecessor, the strength is also somewhat of a weakness, as once again we move so quickly from excitement to excitement that few of the scenes really have a chance to build. A worse issue for me is that these scenes all feel very random and arbitrary. The background, of course, is that there are a lot of mind games being played with the Gladers by WICKED (the corporation doing the trials), so it’s hard to tell at this point whether the randomness will eventually have some cohesive rationale as opposed to the mind games being used as a Get Out of Jail Free card, letting an author just toss up whatever to create some excitement. Plot holes are still an issue — at one point I kept wondering why Thomas wasn’t using his telepathic abilities, almost as if the author had forgotten he had them, and in another scene a character just “escapes” just because the author needed him to for a future event. One’s annoyance at these moments will vary, probably with age as well as reading experience. I found them incredibly frustrating and evidence of slack writing.Characterization remains slim. A lot of Glader Redshirters die, leaving the reader to care as little about their deaths as most of the surviving Gladers do. The main character, Thomas, is a bit too much of the PROTAGONIST, always stepping forward as needed or turning out to be special in some way. The two primary Gladers beyond Thomas leave little impact. A new female character is perhaps the most interesting of them all in the novel, though she plays pretty strictly to a type we’ve seen before.Worldbuilding is just as slim, with little sense of place or rationale behind settings. We’re give a barebones explanation of the world, though we’re not sure we can trust it, but nothing feels fully formed and “lived in;” it feels rather like the characters are moving through movie sets.To be honest, based on The Maze Runner, I wouldn’t have picked up The Scorch Trials had my son not finished book one recently for his summer reading list and wanted to move onto book two (I suppose that says something about its appeal to 13-yr-old boys: he found it “pretty good or OK” albeit with some issues). And it turned out to be pretty much as expected—a relatively mediocre YA that has a certain action appeal but that doesn’t stand up very well under a close eye and won’t satisfy those looking for more depth of character or worldbuilding.

Michael Swanwick’s Chasing the Phoenix is a slight but solidly enjoyably pleasant story of two clever con-artists that may remind readers of Fritz Lieber’s Fafhrd and Gray Mouser a bit, though the reflection/homage is perhaps a bit pale. The pleasures of the book arise from the humorously complex situations the two fall into (and have to escape out of), the sharp character banter, and the generally witty writing all around. How far those attributes carry you past an intriguing but thin worldbuilding, the not-too-substantive plot, and somewhat dull characters will go a long way to determining your level of enjoyment.The setting is a “Post-Utopia” far future that has only recently begun to clamber out of the cataclysmic battle between humanity and powerful AIs that took place generations ago. Wandering across this wonderfully rich mélange of futuristic (tailored viruses, frightening war machines, genetic engineered creatures) and more primitive technology are the grifters Darger and Surplus (himself a genetically engineered dog-human), looking for gullible marks wherever they can find them. The more specific “where,” in this case is China, which after the catastrophic war has devolved back into warring feudal nations. The two finagle their way into the advisory circle of a backwater ruler named The Hidden King and convince him they can lead him to his destiny of uniting all of China once more. Somewhat to their surprise, their plan actually begins to succeed, thanks to some luck, some old con man bravado, and with the help (and hindrance) of a cast of fantastically named characters:  Capable Servant of No Special Distinction, who attaches himself as their personal aide; Powerful Locomotive, the Hidden King’s top general; Vicious Brute, a Hillman bandit, and others. Two especially prominent female players are Fire Orchid, who somehow becomes Surplus’ fiancée, and White Squall, the Hidden King’s archaeologist and supplier of ancient weapons (which she’s dug up from Utopian sites).Darger and Surplus are recurring characters in a series of short stories (I have not read any of them), but while references are made to past adventures, reading them first isn’t at all necessary. It’s simply clear that we as readers have fallen into the middle of a tale (the story being their clearly long-running partnership) rather than the very beginning. The two have the warm fondness and shorthand communication/understanding one would expect for two who have been partners for so long. That said, the two were strangely disassociated throughout, either with wholly separate adventures or plotting together without us seeing them interact all that much. In other words, while you got that they know each other’s mind quite well, the duo lacked that true sense of camaraderie I’ve found in other pairings, such as the aforementioned Fafhrd and Gray Mouser or say, any of several in Steven Erikson’s Malazan world — Tehol and Bugg or Hedge and Fiddler.The two also have relatively removed personalities. Granted, Darger is playing the role of stoic mathematician/philosopher (his title is “Perfect Strategist”), but even so he comes across as more than a little vanilla. Surplus is a more vibrant personality, and his interactions with his “fiancée” Fire Orchid might have been my favorite parts of the novel (certainly the funniest), but unfortunately he disappears for surprisingly long stretches.As the challenges and obstacles pile one atop the other, growing ever more convoluted, the situations themselves become more humorous, and one does wonder how they’ll extricate themselves, but there’s rarely any true sense of danger or urgency. They mostly skate through pretty easily and even if a reader might worry they won’t this “last time,” it’s always made clear they’re ready to cut and run at the first real sign of personal risk. The still-dangerous AIs lurking in the background have a bit of a bite to them (and their dialogue is particularly well-done), and I wish a little more had been done in that area.In the end, I’d call Chasing the Phoenix a nice little tide-you-over snack between works of more substance or depth. It’s witty, will often make you laugh out loud, presents a sense of not a full picture of a richly intriguing world, offers up a number of quirkily engaging if not fully-rounded characters, has a wryly inviting voice, and wraps up at just about the right length (maybe just a tad long). I wouldn’t have wanted to read much more of this story with the two, but I’d pick up a second short novel with them at the center.originally appeared on fantasyliterature.com

Twelve Kings in Sharakhai is the first book in a new series by Bradley P. Beaulieu, set in the great desert city of Sharakhai, ruled for centuries by the same dozen Kings who long ago made a pact with the gods to fend off the desert tribes and establish their power. As a novel that comes to its own semi-resolution, it's nicely rewarding in its own self-contained way (if not without some issues), but Twelve Kings in Sharakhai I’d say works even better as an evocative opening to a world whose full complexity is only just hinted at by the end.The novel opens with a bang, presenting our main character Ceda (pronounced Chay-da) in a gladiatorial match in her persona as the White Wolf—a fan favorite in the city’s fighting pits. As character introduction, the scene is extremely effective. After Ceda defeats a much bigger and stronger opponent, one whom she purposely matched herself against, the reader immediately gets that this is a character who doesn’t back down, a resourceful, strong-willed young woman willing to put her sense of justice above her sense of self-preservation. All of which comes into play as the novel progresses.Ceda is a well-crafted, fully rounded character:  good, but not without flaws; a strong fighter, but not always the best in combat; clever, but not always the smartest in the room; likable but not always admirable. Orphaned at nine when her mother died (she has no clue as to her father), she was taken in for a while by the apothecary Dardzada, and then from there moved in with another street orphan named Emre, who became her best friend and more. Both Emre and Dardzada are equally sharply, fully drawn characters; in fact, just about everyone we meet is, though sometimes that depth is only slowly revealed through current plot events or via flashbacks (more on those later).One of the strongest aspects of the characterization comes not with the individual creations but in their interactions, which feel wholly real. Mostly thanks to the fact that the relationships are messy, ragged things, always changing shape, as is often the case in real life. When characters don’t talk to each other, as readers we don’t see it as a cheap means to send the plot in a certain direction (a pet peeve of mine), but as a natural occurrence due to the emotional interplay between two people. Trust is lost, won, lost again. Anger comes and goes.
