Of course genuine Baroque style has been heard by no one living, so what is now dubbed "authentic" should more accurately be called "scholarly."Scholars aren't known for leading musical revolutions, yet they certainly did in this case. Audiences now accept small instrumental groups, light voices, literal readings of the score, and, to my ears, a thoroughly antiseptic lack of expression in the performance of Bach, even though he was fervently religious and at times tragic in his writing. No one can assess if mini-Bach is the "correct" style, only that the musicologists have prevailed. As for authenticity, that clearly has not been achieved, since no two recordings of Bach's major choral works sounds consistent; each conductor simply invents the tempos, dynamics, phrasing, and level of expression he favors.In the case of Richard Egarr's choices, they are a mixed bag. No surprise, most of his tempos are quick, and as is the rule, nothing sounds reverent or passionate.  Yet the famous opening chorus, Herr Unser Herrscher, is taken ludicrously fast even by HIPpity standards.  The Evangelist, a boyish-sounding James Gilchrist, doesn't rival the best in this role, his primary fault, besides a thin tenor voice, is that he skips over the tragedy of the Passion story, goaded by Egarr's jack-rabbit speeds and refusal to vary the pace with rubato. The Jesus of Matthew Rose sounds rather lugubrious to me. The women soloists are better, and one is impressed that they can deliver the music at such breathless Allegros.Bach left a great deal of room for interpretative freedom, relying on the general understanding of Baroque style at the time. Modern musicians fill in the blanks using taste, musical instinct, and talent. I find that Egarr so totally misunderstands the St. John Passion, mistaking a heart-wrenching tragedy for a summer picnic, that the result, however skillful, is a travesty more often than not.James Gilchrist (Evangelist), Matthew Rose (Jesus), Ashley Riches (Pilatus), Elizabeth Watts (soprano), Sarah Connolly (alto), Andrew Kennedy (tenor), Christopher Purves (bass)Academy of Ancient Music, Richard Egarr

This is Part Two of "John Adams does the Bible," the first installment being his Nativity oratorio, El Nino. Here the angle is liberaiton theology from south America, which directed the Church's ministry toward social justice and poverty. After a period of suppression under two conservative Popes, liberation theology has gotten a boost form the highly popular new Pope, who of course comes from South America and personally embodies a connection with the mass of humble Catholics in the region. Adams, on the other hand, is an immensely clever Harvard-educated composer whose career is a model of elitist success.This doesn't disqualify him from writing a heartfelt feminist passion, any more than Bernstein's Jewishness disqualified him from writing Mass, a multimedia extravaganza that serves as the obvious predecessor of The Gospel According to the Other Mary. Mass was a disaster at its premiere, while Adams's Gospel - backed up by the popular success of Golijov's mass-makret, Spanish-language Passion According to St. Mark - fits more smoothly into the groove of fairly innocuous political correctness. The music is just as accessible as Golijov's and on the whole less powerful and passionate.In short, a whiff of opportunism hangs over this Gospel. In his opera Doctor Atomic contemporary poetry and a sonnet of John Donne's was inserted into the story of J. Robert Oppenheimer at the Manhattan Project, and the tactic is repeated her, with feminist poetry, largely Latino, interspersed with a New Testament narrative delivered by two countertenors.  It's an effective device, no doubt more so when the audience gets dancers and a light show to go along with the score. I imagine The Gospel According to the Other Mary will achieve its full stature only when a DVD of Peter Sellars' complete future staging is achieved. Bernstein's Mass is quite effective when staged, in part because clumsy, vulgar, or overwrought musical passages get softened.I found Golijov's Passion vulgar in the extreme, which puts me in a decided minority. It's been a huge hit with concert audiences, creating the air of a raucous salsa party to ameliorate the churchiness of the Biblical text, which in any case was so thoroughly turned into music by Bach that few composers in the succeeding four centuries returned to it. If The Da Vinci code hadn't canonized Mary Magdalene, turning her into a feminist icon, I doubt that Adams would have given a fig for the Passion of Christ, his output being notably devoid of religious music. Promoting the Magdalene on the basis of a tiny handful of New Testament verses, and conflating her with the woman taken in adultery, for which there is no valid reference, is pure pop culture putting on its serious face.I've offered a preface that some readers will find splenetic, and I admit to some jealousy that Adams has been so overpraised for works that seem to me derivative of Philip Glass ad on their own merits glib. But the irony is that The Gospel According to Mary is actually the most effective musical drama I've heard from him, possibly including Nixon in China. The vocal writing is varied and emotional. There is almost no motorized minimalism of the windup toy type. Not having a printed text - my copy is a download - I can't really make out the singers' enunciation of the poetry. Although she has a powerful voice, lead singer Kelley O'Connor turns English into a soft mush. For the first time Adams also shows a care for melody, far more so than in Doctor Atomic, which presented long stretches of the most boring vocal writing I've heard form him, relieved by one number, Oppenheimer's aria set to Donne's verse.He's still guilty of a reluctance to edit himself. Too much music, especially the Biblical recitatives, is spun out by rote, which of course comes habitually when your idiom is founded on the deliberate repetitiveness of minimalism. Is the boredom intentional or not? I doubt that the question has a credible answer, but thanks to Adams's unusually adept orchestration, even his repetitions sound colorful. Unlike either Nixon or Atomic, this score creates a real atmosphere of shifting moods, which is a major reason for it working so well on CD, without visuals. (It's also much less challenging harmonically than Atomic.)Dudamel conducts with complete dramatic conviction, and both orchestra and chorus are in great form. I can't say that I found the soloists as magnetic as the local reviewers did, but perhaps that's asking too much.  Making a splash is only the first step in the survival of a score, and only time will tell, but this one sounds like a keeper.  The only thing that is likely to work against it is extreme length and a certain sameness that for some will turn to monotony in the second hour.  The fact that it doesn't seem religious in any conventional sense probably won't matter to many listeners.

I was so impressed by countertenor Iestyn Davies' portrayal of Oberon in Britten's Midsummer Night's Dream that I would eagerly have attended this recital at Wigmore Hall in February 2013. I rarely listen to the repertoire that Davies' voice is meant for (you can't love everything), but he has excellent technique and affecting musicality. This particular program is almost entirely devoted to English songs, and the accompaniments are engaging, since they employ a full complement of instruments, not just a keyboard. Vocal numbers are mixed with dances for instruments alone. There's a festive air abut the proceedings. The main body of songs are by Purcell, who of course wrote dozens of great songs that combine text and melody with touching felicity.My only criticism comes in works I know well, such as Come Ye Songs of Art (I first heard the countertenor version by Alfred Deller and his son Mark) where Davies somewhat shorts the joy and emotional exuberance that make the music soar.  Yet in "If music be the food of love," he's sensitive and touching. For whatever technical reasons that are beyond me, countertenors can duplicate the range of a woman's voice but, for me at least, rarely evoke the same depth of feeling. Lovers of the countertenor voice are more abundant than ever, though, and this is a perfect album for them.Blow:Poor Celadon, he sighs in vainVenus and Adonis: SuiteClarke, Jeremiah:The Glory of the Arcadian GrovesCroft:Ye tuneful Numbers - A song with symphoniesGabrieli, G:Sonata No. 21Purcell:Arise, my Muse, Z320Strike the Viol (from Come Ye Sons of Art, Z323)Here the deities approve, Z339The pale and the purple roseTis Nature's voice (from Hail, Bright Cecilia, Z328)Crown the altar (from Celebrate this Festival - Birthday Ode for Queen Mary, Z321)If music be the food of love Z379A (first version)1st setting/1st versionFantasia: three parts on a ground, for three recorders & b.cO solitude, my sweetest choice, Z406Fairest Isle (from King Arthur)Iestyn Davies (countertenor), Richard Egarr (harpsichord), Pamela Thorby, Tabea Debus (recorder), Bojan Čičić (violin), Stephen Pedder (violin), Julia Kuhn (viola, violin), Mark Levy (viola da gamba), William Carter (theorbo, baroque guitar)

This, the third go-round with the Mahler Second by financier Gilbert Kaplan, is promoted as a public service. Kaplan and an assitant have reduced Mahler's orchestration so that it can be played, they say, by chamber, community, and regional orchestras.  Was there actually such a need? Perhaps so. Kaplan's career as an obsessive devotee of this one Mahler work began as a human interest story: a music lover with enough money to hire a world-class orchestra, got to fulfill his fantasy of waving a baton like a real conductor. Nothing succeeds like success, and although he isn't taken seriously by professional musicians (two years ago the NY Phil. complained to management about having to play under Kaplan), his first recording became the best-selling Mahler album of all time, according to the blurb for this one, amassing sales of 200,00 copies.To date he has "been invited" by more than 65 orchestras to conduct the Mahler Second, of which a certain proportion must not have asked him to pay his own way. Such arrangements aren't discussed.  As for this performance, it's reasonable enough on its own terms. The chamber orchestration doesn't sound preposterously thin most of the time; Kaplan is better than a stick waver who's just trying to get through the score; and the Viennese forces play quite well. The recorded sound is excellent. But even if you choose to buy his account over all the great ones on disc, from Bruno Walter and Bernstein to Tennstedt and Jurowski, it seems like carrying coals to Newcastle.  There's no advance over Kaplan's previous two outings.

For the past few decades the role of Isolde has been sung by any number sopranos without a true "Isolde voice," but the excellent Strauss soprano Anne Schwanewilms sings parts in the range of Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, which makes me wonder if her foray into Wagner owes a great deal to the microphone. Lyric sopranos can get away with singing Elisabeth in Tannhauser, and Schwanewilms gives a gleaming account of the Greetings aria, where her alluring, bright tone works very well. Next comes the Wessendonck Lieder, which hardly any sopranos sing - it fits naturally into the range of mezzos and altos - but I guess that's what transpositions are for.These are deeply romantic songs that dwell on inner rapture and melancholy, a span of emotions that is familiar to anyone who sings Strauss. But it's possible to be successful in Strauss's songs almost purely on the basis of a beautiful voice, which Schwanewilms leans on a little too much here. She skates over the surface here; to hear the difference, one only has to turn to Jonas Kaufmann's recent recording, a much more moving account (its unusual feature being that these are almost always a woman's songs). There's little inward quality from Schwanewilms, I'm afraid.As for the Liebestod from Tristan, it's out-of-body music that a light, floating voice might encompass, even if the whole role would prove totally unsingable. By this point it's no surprise that Schanewilms sings it like Strauss, soaring effectively but not, for me at least, conveying the character's transcendence. Needless to say, the orchestra is held back to accommodate her. Throughout the program conductor Cornelius Meister is workaday, as is the Vienna Radio SO. When they play on their own in the Tannhauser Over. and the Prelude to Act I of Tristan, the results are forgettable.I'm a fan of this singer and buy almost all her albums, but this is one to pass up.

Even conductors can think of a masterpiece as a warhorse, and under that influence, they don't go out of their way to rediscover why a score became a masterpiece in the first place. Here Mariss Jansons breaks a long tradition of indifference toward the Symphonie fantastique. Every measure of the work is refreshed, listened to for every implied gasp, lurch, and fever dream of its hallucinating hero. The music is invested with liberal doses of Romantic spontaneity, finding intensity where other conductors find blah. In a word, Jansons is channeling his inner Charles Munch.The conductor's intent is revealed early in the fist movement, where Berlioz's rhythmic irregularities crowd in. Jansons accentuates the agogic pace and underlines the eerie orchestration. These two tendencies are extended into all five movements - one notices that even the straightforward waltz in Un bal seems ghostly and strange. More striking still is the pastoral Scene aux champs, where no one before Jansons, not even Munch, has found a way to inject an air of strangeness - after all, the whole score is meant to be terrifying and surreal. It's eye-opening to hear the shepherds' serenade turn into shrieks. The cause is helped by the conductor's urgent pacing; too often this movement has been slowed to a trudge.The really disturbing music belongs to the last two movements, of course, which depict a ride to the scaffold and a witches' black Sabbath. Since even the most staid conductors put on their Halloween masks for this music, it's hard to out-Herod Herod. Jansons doesn't try. He relies on exact ensemble to bring out the music's color, abetted by remarkably good sonics, the kind we've become used to from BR Klassik's concert recordings, surely the best on the market. The Bavarian Radio SO makes such a golden noise that the usual Grand Guignol isn't missed. Much the same can be said of the finale, but it's here that Jansons seems a bit foursquare compared to Munch's wild rise. there's not much else to criticize about this vivid reading. (Purists may object at the lack of repeats in movements one and four.)It was a stroke of programming genius to fill the CD out with Varese's Ionisation, scored for a huge variety of percussion plus "high and low sirens," since like Berlioz he dreamt up his own fantastic sound world a century later. Purely as sound, the piece is eeriness piled on eeriness, and the result is deliciously unearthly, especially in this crystal-clear performance. In all, this CD is a total success, and after a similarly triumphant War Requiem from him, I'm beginning to reassess Jansons as a potentially great conductor.

New versions of Orff's enduring favorite appear at regular intervals, but as popular as Carmina Burana remains, few newcomers come close to venerable classic recordings under Eugen Jochum (DG) and Fruhbeck de Burgos (EMI), with a raft of other golden oldies (Stokowski, Ormandy, Previn) filling in the legacy. The score was never recorded (or taken seriously?) by the great lights of Solti, Karajan, and Bernstein, however. No matter, there's always another step to take in improved sound, since Carmina Burana has always served a double function as sonic blockbuster.This live account from Royal Festival Hall in April, 2013, doesn't aim for the gallery. In many ways it's a subtle, even strained performance, with especially clear singing from the excellent and apparently smallish chorus. They are among the best I can recall in this work, as is the demure children's chorus. As for the three soloists, they aren't starry by comparison with Fischer-Dieskau, Gerhard Stolze, and Gundula Janowitz for Jochum. No better trio has emerged in over fifty years. The solo singers here join in conductor Hans Graf's generally unexaggerated approach, but at a cost. Only a few of the characters really come to life with any vividness.There's not much galloping excitement, for example, in baritone Rodion Pogossov's rousing tavern song, Estuans interius, although I like his edgy Slavic timbre. The tenor is called upon to soar high in his range portraying the piteous swan as it's being roasted, and Andrew Kennedy does quite well, singing in tune with comic plaintiveness. He comes close to the grotesqueries of legendary Stolze in this song. The light lyric soprano of Sarah Tynan sounds pure and fresh in her four songs, and the high tessitura of Dulcissime doesn't remotely throw her off. But there's not much room made for characterization.I don't mean to damn with faint praise. The palm will always go to bold, garish recordings of a work painted in Technicolor. Still, it's appealing to hear an entry that focuses on the simple beauty of Orff's score, which this one does very nicely.

By 1993 when this live gala was held, Claudio Abbado was probably past his probation period - although for some Berliners this never happened. He was still "no Karajan" but had definitely loosened up the right discipline of the Philharmonic in a positive sense, giving the players more individual leeway for expression. New musicians were entering the ranks, younger, with more women and non-Germans. He moved the orchestra's native repertoire toward Mahler while remaining strong in Bruckner, one of Karajn's best composers.This brief sketch permits us to see that Abbado was still on shaky ground with one particular composer, Wagner, who stood at the summit of Furtwangler and Karajan's repertoire.  He hadn't conducted a Wagner opera when DG gave him Lohengrin (1995)  - a real success as it turned out - and here he has at hand three eminent Wagnerian singers in Studer, Meier, Terfel, and Jerusalem. The result repeats the "he's no Karajan" theme with some justification. The opening Tannhauser Over. is delicate and a bit underpowered, far from the show of force one expects from the Berliners. I don't find it very convincing.When the vocalists appear, Abbado is more in his element - he was, after all, the music director of La Scala - and even though the accompaniments are just a touch recessive,  his singers are well supported.  Studer, Meier, and Jerusalem starred in Abbado's Lohengrin and are fie here, although her brief period in best voice was in sight and the Tannhauser aria a bit tremulous. Meier repeats as a superlative Ortrud in the Act I scene with Elsa, really singing the part withno yowling of the kind that's become common in the part - only Christa Ludwig among modern Ortruds sings at this level.The men aren't able to duplicate the thrills of Meier's singing, although Terfel, as you'd expect, if warmly authoritative in Wolfram's  Ode to the Evening Star and Sach's Lindenduft monologue.  Jerusalem appears only in the concluding duet from Act I of Walkure, from Wintersturme onward.  In his prime I thought Jerusalem didn't have enough voice for Siegmund and just enough for Lohengrin, but today only Kaufmann really surpasses him. Meier sings Sieglinde in her dramatic soprano mode and is again spectcular; Abbado too is fired up by the end.Two other orchestral excerpts, the Act I Prelude to Meistersinger and the Ride of the Valkries. Both are skillfully done,but if one turns to the program of Wagner excerpts done by Tennstedt and the London Phil. on the orchestra's house label, a wide gap opens up between this and Tennstedt's total involvement.

After its devastating history in the last half of the twentieth century, I hope Dresden has become a happier place. It was an optimistic sign when Thielemann introduced New Year's celebrations in 2010, scoring a big success by deviating form the Strauss family template and substituting the music of Lehar instead. Here for the third installment he switches to the lesser known Hungarian-Viennese operetta composer Emmerich Kalman (1882-1953), who arrived late on the scene to catch the golden age of operetta and is now unknown to the general public except for occasional revivals of his best work, Countess Maritza. There's more than enough delightful music form him to fill a bubbly New Year's program.In the past tenor Piotr Becxala and diana Damrau had been starry attractions, but on this occasion Damrau cancelled at the last minute, replaced by the experienced bu uncharismatic Ingeborg Schopf, leaving Becxala to carry the day vocally. His limpid lyric tenor is naturally beautiful, and even though he lacks the extra dimension brought to operetta by Fritz Wunderlich, Beczala sts the gold standard for today, and the audience loves his five solo numbers. The Staatskapelle Dresden is no doubt the most luxurious-sounding orchestra to take up Kalman. They are a delight to hear, if only Thielemann could have added an extra spark and more smiles here and there. No matter. This CD is a lovely addition to the tradition to the usual fare of Strauss.Here's the complete program.Kalman:Gräfin Mariza: OvertureHöre ich Zigeunergeigen (from Gräfin Mariza)Einmal möcht' ich wieder tanze (from Gräfin Mariza)Die Bajadere: IntermezzoHeia, in den Bergen from Die CsárdásfürstinWeisst du es noch (from Die Csárdásfürstin)Zwei Märchenaugen (from Die Zirkusprinzessin)Kaiserin Josephine: Ballett & EnsembleMein Traum, mein Traum (from Kaiserin Josephine)Wenn es Abendd ... Grüß mir mein Wien (from Gräfin Mariza)Der Teufelsreiter: Grand Palotás de la ReineEin kleiner slowfox mit Mary (from Die Herzogin von Chicago)Heut' Nacht hab' ich geträumt von Dir (from Das Veilchen von Montmartre)Tanzen Möcht' ich (from Die Csárdásfürstin)Carambolina (from Das Veilchen von Montmartre)Ich tanz mit Dir ins Himmelreich (from Der Zigeunerprimas)Stolz, R:Ob blond, ob braun, Ich liebe die Frau'nStrauss, J, II:An der Elbe - Walzer, Op. 477

Teldec got more mileage from their high-profile Bruckner cycle with Barenboim and the Berlin Phil., but hose performances sound ponderous and corporate beside the cycle under Inbal with his Frankfurt Radio SO.  A case in point is this vigorous Sym. 1 form 1987, using the "Linz edition," which isn't significantly different from the "Vienna edition."  What's more important is that Inbal approaches the score as raw, exciting, and ready to be manhandled.  He may make the piece sound too rough for some, but far better that than to polish the surface, which exposes the various weaknesses and downturns in an inconsistent early work.The overall timing gives a fair idea of how energized this reading feels: 48 min. compared to 49 min. for Simone Young's excellent version from Hamburg and Karajan's 51 min. in his Berlin cycle on DG.  I especially like the variety of moods Inbal finds in the opening movement and his gravity in the adagio, which manages to remain lyrical and never somber - from the very beginning Bruckner's slow movements were a great strength, and his touch never left him.  Inbal attacks the opening of the Scherzo with a touch of ferocity and keeps the strong momentum going. The brass playing is somewhat rackety, and the bright, clear sound stings a little at loud climaxes, though. The finale is played for rough majesty, as you might say the whole symphony is.This is a dark horse in a race that has seen highly praised Bruckner Firsts from Jochum and Abbado, along with the more recent Young recording.  I consider it a find, along with an equally vibrant Bruckner Second.

When they headed the London Phil., both Solti and Haitink recorded the two Elgar symphonies, but Haitink explored a range of English music beyond that. As popular as Britten, Vaughan Williams, and Elgar are with audiences, I've always been mystified by their neglect at the hands of international conductors of the first rank. On this collection from the late 70s and early 80s the only international hit is the Enigma Var., and the Britten-Auden song cycle, Our Hunting Fathers, is basically unknown outside Britain - even there it's considered something of an oddity.Haitink is criticized for being too placid, but the program opens with a live Elgar  Introduction and Allegro that's lively and beautifully articulated. It could easily serve as a first choice, because the sound is better than on the sainted EMi recording under Barbirolli, and the reading itself is lighter and more lively. This is one of the masterpieces for string orchestra and deserves to be played everywhere.  The same light touch is used in the Enigma Var., which may catch some listeners off guard if they're used to Elgar as iconic Edwardian imperialist. The playing is accomplished (no doubt many LPO musicians were veterans of the Boult era), but I don't hear much emotional involvement on the conductor's part except in fits and starts. "Nimrod" brings no tears. The big moments are satisfying, to be fair. The great Decca recording under Monteux remains my favorite Enigma.Our Hunting Fathers is marked Op. 8, but Britten called it his true Opus 1. As a boy he'd gotten into trouble at school for writing an essay against hunting, and he returns to the theme here. To quote some online notes, he depicts "animals' interactions with humans as pests, pets, accomplices, and prey: An anonymous ancient exorcism against rats, a mocking lament for a rich spoiled woman crying over her sick monkey, and a "Dance of Death" wherein a huntsman calls to his pack of dogs and falcons to urge them to capture their prey." Auden helped the composer choose texts but himself only wrote some lines at the beginning and end.the five songs were written with a soprano in mind - later on, Britten's partner Peter Pears adopted it for tenor - and it's hard to imagine anyone giving a more sympathetic reading than the great Heather Harper, who  belonged to Britten's charmed inner circle of favored performers.  The vocal line isn't as high and demanding as in Les Illuminations, yet it is often quite emotional and dramatic, with moods varying form declamatory to satiric. Haitink throws himself into the orchestral effects, which are precocious from the young Britten. I almost want to say that you can ignore the words if they feel too preachy; there can't be many people who would reject the songs out of allegiance to their hunting fathers nowadays.In short, this CD contains two outstanding performances and one good one - it's well worth a listen.

The Philharmonic has led the way among American orchestras in offering their entire season in download format, with amazingly good sound considering how deficit Avery Fisher Hall is in that department.  Here from Nov. 2013 is one of the stronger programs I've come across, combining two popular Strauss tone poems, don Juan and Zarathustra, with Christopher Rouse's Oboe Cto. (2004), a showpiece for the orchestra's principal oboist, Liang Wang, just as Rouse's Pulitzer Prize-winning Trombone Cto. did for their first-chair trombonist.Rouse divides his ten concerti - a big number - into somber and genial, with the oboe one being the latter.  As the notes inform us, the piece begins with a five-note chord in the strings that supplies the root for later melodies and harmonies (not that the casual listener could possibly guess, or even gain much after being told). More helpful is to know that the concerto's moods shift from dreamy to sensuous to colorful, Rouse says, alternating lyrical material with virtuoso passages. Rouse has established himself as something along the lines of an established British composer who knows how to remain modernist while fitting nicely into audience expectations. That's true here - the music skips along agreeably (I almost said clucks along - the oboe has a hard time escaping its birdlike timbre) with glittering percussion in the background, only to shift to other textures, perhaps a snippet of a tune with the harp as partner. Rouse is nothing if not facile, and it's good to meet a work that has a chance to possibly enter the repertoire. there hasn't been a successful oboe concerto since Strauss's, seven decades ago.On to the red meat, the two Strauss scores.  Don Juan is given a polished reading with impressive playing - the NY Phil.could be the least acknowledged of the world's great orchestras, I think -  but as so often with Alan Gilbert, his ability to extract great execution isn't matched by any passion. Don Juan is the splashiest music imaginable, and its'a shame when it doesn't swagger. As for Zarathustra, it's the same story. As a sequence of beautiful sounds, it's unimpeachable, but not much happens beyond that.

Gergiev took young super flash pianist Daniil Trifonov under his wing for a stunning Tchaikovsky Cto. no. 1, and now hard on its heels comes another version with the conductor's favorite long-term keyboard partner, Denis Matsuev. He was the only pianist featured in the international broadcast of the opening of the new Mariinsky 2 concert hall. To say that a new recording of the Tchaikovsky First isn't needed doesn't suffice - there will always be an expanding shelf of new versions. Even if you own the Trifonov, it takes nothing away from this dazzling performance from an artist sixteen years more mature than Trifonov and gifted with exceptional powers of technical dazzlement and musicality - this is a commanding but never bombastic reading filled with lovely touches from both conductor and pianist. Nothing is routine; everything speaks with complete authority.It's true here, as with the Trifonov version, that the concerto is played as real music, not a warhorse to be banged through.  Critics have accused Matsuev of banging, but on the two occasions I heard him - and on this recording - he exhibits incredible power that brings the piano to its limit of loudness but doesn't cross over into banging.  There's a natural rise and fall throughout, adding variety and interest, all of it captured in excellent sonics for both orchestra and piano.  I'm especially happy that Matsuev doesn't fuss with the syncopation in the finale but turns it into an exciting rush. Horowitz in his prime was capable of tearing the roof off with the double octaves that cap the orchestra's slow, suspenseful buildup at the end of the finale, and Matsuev comes very close, in far better sound. It's altogether an astonishing performance that one could easily name as first choice in the modern era.As for the Second Piano Cto., I haven't heard a first-rate performance since the old Gilels with Maazel on EM (done with the cuts inserted by Siloti, not the complete score)I; there's an exciting Pletnev reading on Virgin that is unfortunately caught in tubby, blurry sound. So I had high hopes for Matsuev, who performs Tchaikovsky's revised version at full length (43 min.) - and he delivers beyond expectations. The piano part is filled with difficulties that Matsuev showcases in bravura fashion, while Gergiev keeps pace with an accompaniment that is far and away the best I've ever  heard. It's headlong and heroic in the fast outer movements, sensitive and engrossing in the slow movement, which has stretches that are almost a triple concerto thanks to  extended violin and cello solos.As much as purist have given the Siloti edition a bad name, the truth is that the old cuts were justified if you feel, as I do, that the material is stretched thin in spots. But that's a small matter when you hear a performance that sets a new standard on disc (besides being the first SACD recording of the Second Cto.).  I know that many listeners shrug off Gergiev's flood of recordings, but this one is a must-listen, for his contribution as much as Matsuev's.

The ABQ owed their pre-eminence to many qualities, but one of the most prominent was the power of their sound. They played with an intensity that astonished even the world-class soloists like cellist Heinrich Schiff when they joined in.  Not often was this power misplaced, but I think it is here. For decades the automatic recommendation for the frequently paired Debussy and Ravel quartets was the Quartetto Italiano on Philips, admired for the elegance of their delivery and sweetness of tone. To love that recording, or the fine French ones that have more recently appeared, is to be confronted here by the diametric opposite.These readings are about precision and detail, with almost no quarter given to charm. The finale of the Ravel sounds as if Bartok stepped in to make revisions.  The famed perfection of ensemble that was a trademark of the ABQ is everywhere in evidence, as is warmth of tone and individual virtuosity - no modern quartet, and perhaps none in the history of recordings, has been made up of four players who could easily have enjoyed solo careers. If you are a true devotee, the intensity and seriousness exhibited here won't seem misplaced, but I am almost a die-hard fan, and this recording, along with their Schubert C Major Quintet, are two ABQ readings I can hardly sit through.

this remarkably persuasive recording of the three Brahms sonatas was made in 2004, when the Hungarian pianist Tamas Vasary turned 71; it had been a long time since his time as a Chopin pianist for DG. Here he plays the prominent piano part as an equal partner of the violinist, and more. I'd say that his strong, imaginative pianism leads the interpretations, and since he is one of the best musicians I've heard in that role, the recital has a great deal going for it.The violinist Barnabas Kelemen, also Hungarian, was in his mid-twenties when the recording was made, after winning some gold medals at competitions.  His name was unknown to me, and in recent years he has been teaching at the Liszt Conservatory in Budapest, from which he graduated. He's extremely musical and fully capable of joining Vasary in finding more variety and color in these familiar three sonatas than one usually hears - so much so, in fact, that long stretches sound freshly imagined.  As a pairing, Vasary and Kelemen leave some famous recordings in the dust.  Nothing here is overly massaged or fussy - this is strong, direct playing that stands out because the two partners are so deeply involved.Since the recorded sound is very good and both instruments are captured in a natural perspective, there's reason to assert that this could be a first choice among modern recordings; I was engrossed from beginning to end.

The rise of the female cellist seems to owe a good deal to baby-doll poses on the cover, which is nothing new to the-violinist-as-babe syndrome. But of course  du Pre and Natalia Gutman represented a striking musical heritage to inspire younger cellists, and they competed on the world stage without come-hither looks. It was du Pre in particular who pioneered a free, even reckless style of playing that lifted the cello into the realms of the glamoursly exciting, something Rostropovich achieved through jaw-dropping technique and exceptional volume, the cello being rather mild on its own, especially in a large hall.I heard Weilerstein in a very large hall - Royal Albert - where her tone was too small to make a strong impression, but here the engineers amplify the instrument so that it's louder than the orchestra; her first entry in the concerto is guns ablazing. I found it distracting even by the amped-up standards we've grown used to.  There's also a drastic mismatch between her fiery, freely phrased interpretation and Jiri Bìlohlavek's accompaniment, which is bland an foursquare. I've rarely heard the long orchestral introduction to the first movement sound so d dull, no matter if he and his musicians are Czech.Happily, Weilerstein is so fiery that the conductor joins in the spirit of her playing for the remainder of the movement.  It's the Czech way to approach Dvorak without the overlay of German heaviness, and this proves a virtue in the slow movement, where the sweet, relaxed sound of the orchestra blends in beautiful ensemble with Weilerstein, whose sensitivity in phrasing slow music is quite engaging; so is the way her phrasing breathes and sings. Like du Pre, she knows how to draw a spectrum of tonal color from the cello, although du Pre was more willing to scrape and scratch if the music demanded it. Weilerstein tends toward the school that permits nothing but beautiful tons. She certainly has them at her command.As if we need more proof that the Cellist is in charge, she ignores Bìlohlavek's moderate tempo at the start of the finale and hurries up the proceedings, a lead he soon follows. This movement is a forward-moving Allegro, but she is eager to take rhythmic liberties, shaping each phrase personally, again like du Pre, and since I would be happy to confine all my cello concerto recordings to du Pre's,  this kind of passion and expressive freedom appeals to me - and to an adoring public, I'd say. there's no denying that Weilerstein brings this thrice-familiar concerto alive, and the performance deserves highest praise. She doesn't deliver a routine note, even if the conductor rarely departs from the routine when he's on his own.the filers for cello and piano find Weilerstein in the company of a sympathetic partner, Anna Polonsky, and the engineers have reduced the cellist's tone to the fairly small, lyric sound she produces. Within this limit she's very expressive; her tendency in a selection of arrangements that are basically songs without words - a genre that Mischa Maisky had great success in - is measured and melodic. that will satisfy anyone who likes soulful cello music. I am more impressed by how she can take Goin' Home (the famous theme from the Largo of Dvorak's "New World" Sym.) and phrase it so musically that it holds one's attention from start to finish.In short, a charismatic young talent demonstrates again why she is considered so special.

The campaign in favor of Schumann's late works seemed like an act of charity when it began, since the composer's widow and heirs suppressed much of it and even went to court to prevent the Violin Cto. from being premiered. That work has had its partisans over the past few decades, but it was extremely rare to hear Schumann's later chamber music, which was considered evidence of his failing abilities as his mental deterioration advanced - he died in an asylum in 1856 at the age of forty-six from mental afflictions whose cause is still debated (it used to be claimed that Clara Wieck's father so vehemently opposed the marriage to Schumann because of suspected syphilis).  Some critics are harsh about works written as early as 1850, but Tetzlaff belongs to a group of world-class musicians, among them Martha Argerich and the Capucon brothers, who promote very late scores.Tetzlaff won praise and awards for a recording of the three piano trios released in 2011, and my reaction to this new release of the three violin sonatas (composed between 1851 and 1853) is akin to the one I had then. There are beautiful moments, especially in the first two sonatas, but Schumann's estate was right to worry - structure is loose, developments rhapsodic to the point of feeling aimless at times, and the melodies far below Schumann's best.  For me, this music is too simple overall to add to the reputation of a great composer.  At 19 min. and 17 min. respectively, the first and third sonatas perhaps sustain their invention, but the four-movement second sonata is 32 min. long, a length justified mainly by its many peculiarities.The best I can say is that Romanticism saw madness as being next to inspiration - a somewhat cruel view when you consider mental disorders from a medical standpoint -  and the weird and wild opening of Sonata no. 2 could be justified that way.  Argerich and friends are wilder in a live reading from the Lugano Festival on EMI, compared to which Lars Vogt's pianism feels fairly restrained. But he and Tetzlaff are among the elite of current German musicians, and there's no criticism to offer of their performances - for the Gramophone to name this CD the Recording of the Month can't be argued against.The best way to approach late Schumann is to fully absorb yourself into each score, one at a time, and then either accept or reject the musical idiom he wound up with, wildness, looseness, oddness, and feebleness combined.

The Gramophone anointed this performance of the Bruckner Fourth in a long, pompous review (the sonority of the Vienna Phil. was referred to as "autochthonous"), but I'm not so sure. One cannot fault the orchestral playing, which is on a par with Karajan's two recordings of the work with the Berlin Phil. The smoothness of tone over a vast dynamic range, without the slightest harshness in the brass, is extraordinary. But Abbado tends to homogenize textures, and the effect is magnified by 1990 recorded sound that is congested at forte and above - on my system it's also dull unless the volume is turned up considerably. In concert the effect of Vienna's golden throat fully open is astonishing; here it's a little caramelized compared to the touches of grit and bite that bring Bruckner alive.Abbado applies suchcare to detail that it tends to put each bar under a microscope at the expense of momentum. This is especially evident in the studied slow movement, but my attention was already wandering halfway through the first movement. Abbado finally lets himself go in the Scherzo, just in time. Bruckner's major symphonies are so expansive that it takes a strong-minded conductor to pull them into shape by force. Klemperer was great at that; so were Karajan, Tennstedt, Furtwangler, and (sometimes) Celibidache. For me, Abbado doesn't belong in that select group, much as I admire his musicianship. My chief reason for keeping this fourth is because the other prominent modern recording with the VPO, under Karl bohm on Decca, doesn't appeal to me as much as to its many admirers.

Learn Game Programming with Ruby is a well-written, easy to read book for learning game programming.  It provides fully working code as well as starter files from the book's website.  The code is not always the best structured, but the beauty of software is that you can change it.  Mark Sobkowicz does a really good job explaining the concepts of the various types of games, and the examples do work as advertised.  I found that they were easy to experiment with for further learning.I would not recommend this as the first programming book that you pick up.  I have had experience with Ruby before, and I've been programming in various languages for almost 20 years.  I recommend Programming Ruby "The Pick Axe Book" as prerequisite material.  Ruby is not a difficult language to learn, and the Gosu library works as expected without any prior knowledge.I think this is a great place for people with fundamental Ruby knowledge to start their journey in game programming.  I had no prior experience with games, and I found the book very accessible.

As I’ve gotten more into headphones over the years, I have also come to appreciate what a good amplifier can do to enhance the performance of a good set of headphones.  I recently evaluated the M-Audio Bass Traveler, and I will give you both anecdotal and controlled experiment results to help you in making your purchase decision.I have a Sandisk Sansa Clip+ mp3 player, and it produces decent sound, but it isn’t capable of exercising a good set of headphones like my Klipsch Reference Series X7.  These headphones have a flat response, and I used the Bass Traveler on its flat setting.  Without question, I noticed more detail in my music than I did without them.  One my joys as a music listener is hearing something new in a song that I’ve heard hundreds of times before.For the controlled experiment, I used my MacBook Pro and my Sennheiser HD558 headphones.  These are rated at 50 ohms, and that is right in the middle of the target set of resistance that the Bass Traveler supports.  I used my standard headphone evaluation playlist below to get a feel for a broad range of styles.  I listened to them without the Bass Traveler and then with the Bass Traveler for comparison.When I used the flat setting, I noticed more detail in subtle places (e.g., “Chinese Democracy”) and busy songs (e.g., “Automatic Systematic Habit”).  However, I noticed the most improvement on “So What”.  This is an old, although remastered, recording, and with the volume at a lower level, the stand-up bass is hard to pick out without the Bass Traveler.  However, the Bass Traveler truly lived up to its name with the bass response on set to “H” on songs like “Chrysalis Heart”.  I generally prefer an unaltered sound, but I have to admit that it was impressive.  If you are a bass head who just isn’t getting enough out of your headphones, this is a fairly low-cost option (assuming that you made an investment in your headphones anyway) to squeeze more bass out of your cans.Overall, I’m looking for an amplifier to enhance my listening experience.  The M-Audio Bass Traveler does this admirably at a very reasonable price.  I recommend it without reservation.K'Naan - "ABCs" (bass)Delerium - "Chrysalis Heart" (bass)Guns `N Roses - "Chinese Democracy" (clarity)Evanescence - "End Of The Dream" (detail)Garbage - "Automatic Systematic Habit" (detail)Megadeth - “Sudden Death” (channel separation)Chris Cornell - "As Hope And Promise Fade" (clarity)Miles Davis - "So What" (jazz)Tchaikovsky - "Moderato (Swan Lake, Act II)" (classical)

Our house is predominately a Mac outfit, but I wanted to have a Windows machine around for those rare times with it’s the only option - like accessing my work VPN.  I don’t need an overly high-powered  or fully featured computer to serve this purpose, and the ASUS M32AD seemed like a more than adequate choice for the task.Out of the box, there’s nothing out of the ordinary about this computer.  I connected my monitor and speakers along with the keyboard and mouse that come with it.  The initial boot and setup were smooth if somewhat slow.This is my first taste of Windows 10, and I think that Microsoft did a decent job improving on Windows 8 (although that’s not a very high bar).  To me, it seems like a blend of Windows 7 and Windows 8.  It is much easier to navigate, and I had no problem at all finding what I was looking for.However, apps are still sparse with Windows.  Most of them feel like a stripped down web browser (Fox News, WeatherBug, and Twitter to name a few).  The new actual browser, Edge, seems like a minor improvement over Explorer, but I still find Chrome to be faster.  The thing I was curious about was Cortana; however, this also feels immature compared to Google Now or Amazon Alexa.  The most frustrating thing to me was that Cortana only responded to “Hey, Cortana” about one out of every five tries.  Not surprisingly, it also only works with Microsoft apps meaning that you can’t control Chrome or use Gmail or Google Calendar on the web.  While you can connect these to the Windows apps, the experience is not as good and, in the end, not worth it.The one other thing that I found frustrating was Wifi performance.  My router sits only five feet away, but the connection was intermittent.  In contrast, my laptops and tablets connect from across the house with no issue.In the end, the ASUS M32AD is adequate for my needs, but I would not recommend it as a primary machine.

The Taylors of Harrogate Yorshire Gold tea is exceptionally average.  I didn't hate it, but it really didn't have any substance or flavor that just jumped out at me and said, "Hey, this is some great black tea!"  I wouldn't be offended if a fried served it to me, but there's nothing about it that will make me seek it out.  I think that Numi has better tea offerings that this, and that's where I would turn for my next tea purchase instead.

Jack Link's has been a brand of snacks that I use when I'm on the road.  It's often hard to find anything sweet that doesn't have high-fructose corn syrup in it, and these are a reasonable alternative.  I've mostly had their beef jerky products, but chicken proved to be an interesting variation.  The package says, "Tender Bites", and that is not false advertising.  There was nothing stringy or tough about these.  The flavor is good, but I'm not sure "Flamin" is accurate.  There spice to be sure, but it's not the "set your mouth on fire" variety.  I like spicy things that stay on the right side of pain.  In other words, these are spicy but enjoyable.

I've been stocking up on gifts for my wife as the "gift season" approaches.  This one struck me as being great to stash away for Valentine's Day given the heart shape and stone color.  She has loved all of the recommended items that Amazon has presented me in the past, and I expect this one to be another hit.  Listen up, guys!  This is a great value to have on hand for when you need a gift.

I picked this up to give my wife as a "just because" gift, and she really liked them.  They are not too big, and they aren't flashy which she likes for everyday use.  This is an easy choice for a spontaneous "I'm thinking of you" gift.

Made to Kill is a fun romp of a Noir novel featuring Raymond Electromatic - a robot detective turned hitman who winds up mostly being a detective in this story.  While one might expect a novel about a robot detective/hitman to be set in present day, that turns out to not be the case.  Rewind the clock a mere 50 years, and you've got the timeframe for the novel set properly.A good part of the story takes place in Raymond's head as he drives, walks, or generally has a look around.  This is a risky proposition for an author, but the story is DOA if the narrating character has a boring personality.  Rest assured, however, that Adam Christopher deftly avoids this trap.  Here are some of my favorite lines from Raymonds's thoughts:* "The padlock on the gate was pretty big and strong but I was bigger and stronger."* "I assumed this was standard operating procedure for teenagers in an ice cream parlor when being given a free drink by a robot so I didn't argue."* "Fresco Peterman was smiling so much his cheeks pushed his big glasses up so high I wasn't even sure he could see out of them properly."You might argue that these aren't laugh-out-loud funny, but they struck me as the kinds of things Bogart would say in an old movie.  I guess that is what made this novel so enjoyable to me - nostalgia.  I can see where this style of writing might not appeal to everyone.  This is a quirky novel that I had a lot of fun reading.  It goes quickly too at fewer than 250 pages.  If you are looking for something that isn't too taxing for a quick, fun read, I would recommend Made to Kill.  However, if you are in the mood for something meaty and serious, this is probably not for you.

I eat protein bars as a regular part of my diet, and I'm always interested in new products with good ingredients.  I had never had any hemp-based products, but I was curious about these when I saw them.  I prefer Non-GMO at a minimum, and these passed my ingredient test.The taste and texture of these protein bars are good but not great.  That is to say that I like them; however, they are not my favorite.  I could see working them into my rotation on a periodic basis, but they aren't "go-to" status.  If you are looking for an apple-cinnamon flavored protein bar, these are worth a try.

The concept of this book made me curious, but I have to admit that I was skeptical about a book by Kareem Abdul-Jabbar.  Well, don't be like me.  This is a good entry into the periphery of the Sherlock Holmes Universe that countless people are fans of.  Mycroft Holmes is a character that I didn't know a lot about beyond his portrayal in the recent BBC series.  However, Abdul-Jabbar does a good job of bringing this Mycroft to life as his own character.  He is clever in his own right, and he carries this mystery on his own with his friend (and sometimes butler for travel purposes) Cyrus Douglas.  The story moves at a good clip, and soon you forget that you are reading a book coauthored by a former basketball player.  In some ways, that is the measure of success for this book.  It's a good story in its own right, and it fits well in the overall mythology.  You may buy it because you know who Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is, but you'll enjoy it because it's a good book.

My wife loves earrings like these, and I love the fact that they are so convenient to buy and for a good value to boot.  Guys, you have a lot of gift-giving to do each year with her birthday, Christmas, and Valentine's Day at a minimum.  An offering like this has to be useful for you somewhere along the way - even if it's 'just because'.  I recommend this with no hesitation.

I prefer to give my dogs grain free, natural food and treats, and I have used other products from this supplier with good results.  My dogs like these treats just as well as anything else, but I don't like them because they are small enough that my dogs try to swallow them whole.  This gives me concern for choking hazards.  I'm not sure what it is about these particular treats, but I will not get more of these.  The soft treats work better for my dogs.

The Wisk Deep Clean PowerBlasts pods are a good choice if you are already committed to the price of pod laundry detergent.  They do a good job of getting clothes clean, and I have noticed a difference with whites and towels the most.  These are the loads of clothes that have the most need of what these pods offer, and I have been pleased with the results.  I have no hesitation recommending this product as long as you are OK with the cost.

While the Star Wars Trapper Keeper is cool looking, it is not very functional.  Unless you have it filled with a moderate amount of paper/folders, the snap is very difficult to work.  The pockets on the inside, on the other hand, will not stand up to any volume.  These should only be used for current homework or things that not immediate attention.  Finally, it is not even a fully complete trapper.  You will need to buy trapper folders in order to use it for multiple subjects.  It is the epitome of form over function.

I have a pair of Bose SoundTrue over-the-ear headphones, and they are arguably the best headphones of that type that I have ever had.  I thought that the SoundSport could do the same for my in-ear/mobile experience, but I'm afraid that turns out to not be the case.  I tried all three different size ear tips multiple times, but I was never able to get a good seal.  I think that the medium size should have worked, but it is a problem with the design.  Unlike most in-ear headphones, the tips on these are not shaped like a round mushroom cap.  I am uncertain how anyone gets a proper seal with this design.  I have seen that Bose makes an alternate style of tips that I could buy separately, but I consider that unacceptable.  Perhaps some like the fit that these offer, but I can't see how that comes without a degraded sound as a result.  That defeats the purpose of buying Bose in my book.  I cannot recommend these unless Bose starts shipping them with both styles of ear tips so that those looking for quality sound can actually experience it.  I am rather disappointed.

A couple of months ago, I got a MacBook Pro 15”, and I was quickly looking for something to protect my investment.  I have been using a Brenthaven Bx2 sleeve for my MacBook Air 11” for over a year, and I was pleased with the quality.  I looked at what Brenthaven had to offer for my Pro, and I settled on ProStyle model.It is a quality product all the way around.  The inside is plush, and the outside is nice shiny black leather.  It also has a pocket for an iPhone, but it isn’t big enough for my Samsung Galaxy S5.  However, I am more than pleased with the basic function, and I recommend this sleeve and Brenthaven products in general without hesitation.

I normally use Paul Mitchell’s Tea Tree Oil shampoo, and I like it a lot.  However, it has a tendency to dry out my hair.  I thought that adding this shampoo and conditioner all-in-one as a rotation would have positive results.  My experiment has last a couple of weeks, and I have noticed some improvements.  I would switch to this, but the Paul Mitchell has an invigorating tingle that this shampoo from Jack Black doesn’t have.  If they added tea tree oil, I would switch to this as my full-time shampoo.

One of my dogs has a sensitive stomach, and I keep them on a limited ingredient diet.  My normal brand is Natural Balance, and I have given my dogs a number of their treats with great success.Enter new brand Wellness with their pure rewards natural grain free treats.  Unlike the jerky rewards treats, the smell of these is a bit much for me.  However, my dogs seem to have an attitude of "the stinkier the better!"  The ingredients read like people food, and I like giving my dogs quality food and treats.  I'm not sure if I'll get these again, but I know that my dogs want me to nonetheless.

One of my dogs has a sensitive stomach, and I keep them on a limited ingredient diet.  My normal brand is Natural Balance, and I have given my dogs a number of their treats with great success.Enter new brand Wellness with their pure rewards natural grain free treats.  These have a smoky smell to them, and both of my dogs love them.  They also have had no issues with them.  They are a great treat that I feel good about giving my dogs.

I am a coffee and tea lover, and I’m always up for trying new things.  The organic breakfast tea from Capital Teas is a basic tea without any flavor enhancers (such as vanilla) added.  I prepare my tea in a French press, and this tea works well with this method.  I would say that the malt flavors stand out more than the others, and I found this to be pleasant.  This is definitely a tea that I would consider having again.  Organic products are important to me, and I’m glad to have found a new organic tea that is a pleasure to drink.

The Friendship of Criminals is a crime fiction novel that is somewhat misplaced in the mystery/thriller genre.  I think the novel is also done a disservice when it is advertised in the product description as “explodes off the page with the crackling intensity of Scorsese's THE DEPARTED”.  To me the book started off too slow, and I thought there the amount of backstory was out of proportion for the length of the novel.  It gives a good sense of the Philadelphia mob scene, and the author does a decent job of conveying the scene.  I think that Glinski could write a compelling novel if he worked on pacing and balancing present day action with backstory.  You may well enjoy reading this, but you should not really expect explosive action or a taut thriller.  If you really dig mobsters and a slow burn, this might just be up your ally.

Signature Kill is the first of the Frank Behr series of novels that I’ve read, and it is also likely the last.  I read a fair amount of crime fiction, but nothing else that I’ve read compares to this in terms of gore, butchery, and depravity.  While I did finish the book, I considered stopping about halfway through.  The description of the killer (both his thoughts and his actions) was that disturbing.  In addition, I didn’t like Frank Behr as a protagonist.  He is a bit of a parasite himself given his tendency to use anyone he meets to further his case as a private detective.  There may be people who enjoy graphic murder and dysfunctional heroes, but I am not one of them.  I did not like this novel, and I can scarcely recommend it.

This whiteboard from Quartet would make a nice addition to your cubicle.  While the magnetic attachment might work on metal cabinets, I chose to use the hooks to hang it on the fabric wall instead.  Quartet also included one black marker and two round magnets for attaching notes or other papers to the board.  The marker writes somewhat faded compared to others that we have in our office.  The board erases cleanly, and that pretty well wraps it up.  I would recommend this to anyone looking to have a small whiteboard in their cubicle.

The Good:Nice AppearanceLong Battery LifeConfigurable NotificationsVariety of Watch Faces and AppsEasy SetupThe Bad:CostOverall:  The Pebble Steel is a bit of a luxury item, but it performs well and looks nice.Setup:  The Pebble Steel comes with the watch and charging cord; however, it is up to the user to supply the charger that accepts a USB connection.  If you are like me, you have plenty of these from other devices.  However, if you do not, just know that you will need an additional accessory just to get up and running.  The watch charged in a couple of hours, and then it was on to the pairing process.  I installed the Pebble app on my Samsung Galaxy S5, and it was easy to get connected.  Android is all about notifications, and the Pebble app lets you control which ones go to the watch on a per app basis.Watch Faces:  The Android Pebble app is where you go to get watch faces (and apps) for the Pebble.  I wanted my Pebble to look like a normal watch, and I went with the analog watch face that comes from the factory.  While that may seem boring, Pebble has a wealth of others to choose from including various bands and TV shows.  You can choose as subtle or outlandish as you desire, and the bottom line is that you have choices.  There are also composite watch faces that include weather, notification counts, and other items too.  However, be advised that everything that updates the display has a cost in battery life.Apps:  The Pebble Store has a number of apps to choose from too.  While there are many for weather, sports, email and text responders, I chose to keep things simple.  I have Dashboard (controls phone toggles), Here To There (gives estimated travel time to saved destinations), and Trello (list management such as shopping lists).  There are also apps for Evernote and Wunderlist, but I found the Trello watch app worked best for shopping lists.Usage:  I bought my Pebble for a pretty specific purpose.  I keep my phone on vibrate during working hours (at a minimum), and I often missed calls or text messages.  With the Pebble, I am able to see when I get a call or a text, and the information display provides useful information to me on the spot.  I can see who contacted me along with the contents of text messages.  I also like that I can dismiss/ignore phone calls from the watch.  The other notification that I have sent to my Pebble is calendar reminders.  It is handy to see where my next meeting is without having to pull my phone out.  Finally, I find it much easier to manage the shopping list without having to constantly unlock my phone.  As you may have gathered, the Pebble Steel is a pure convenience for me albeit one that does what I want it to quite well.Battery Life:  Battery life is heavily dependent on usage.  I have consistently gotten the 5-7 days as advertised.  However, user who have every email notification sent across along with sports scores and weather alerts should expect their mileage to be less.Looks:  You may be wondering why I went with the Pebble Steel over one of the Android (or even Samsung) options available.  This is purely a matter of personal taste, but I thought that the Pebble Steel provided the right feature profile in a watch that didn’t look like a toy.  The Android watches stand out too much in my opinion - especially with nicer clothes.  The Pebble Steel is a watch that you can wear just about anywhere without drawing undue attention.Conclusion:  I like the Pebble Steel, and I am glad that I bought it.  However, I’m not sure that it merits the full retail price.  I bought mine on a Black Friday Lightning Deal, and I had a $50 gift card too.  That made a discretionary purchase a little easier to justify.  I think smart watches will catch on when the consistently reach a price below $100 - at least for a usage profile like mine.  Please feel free to ask questions in the comments below.

Markus Gartner’s ATDD by Example is a good primer/introduction to acceptance test-driven development.  In keeping with the theme of the book, the first two parts of the book are example based.  Gartner gives a simulated dialog and development sprint in part one, and he “pairs” with you the reader in part two.  Finally, in part three he gives high level guiding principles for ATDD.  Gartner’s book is a quick read, and it is best suited for those new to the topic.  One group that will gain a lot from this is traditional testers who are moving into an agile development environment.  Developers who are looking to improve their testing knowledge can also find what they are looking for as well.  Those who are looking for an in depth treatment would be happier with BDD in Action by John Ferguson Smart.  I would also recommend BDD in Action as an excellent follow up to this book.  It covers a more holistic view and goes into greater depth on best practices and tools.  However, this is a great place to start, and I highly recommend it.Overall:  A

I feed my dogs Natural Balance food exclusively, and I have also tried a number of the treats that they have to offer.  The latest thing that makes my puppies go crazy is the Lamb Delectable Delights Burger Bites - try saying that fast five times!  They are not very big, and I have no reservations giving both dogs one if they finish their dinner in the evening.  They love them, and I like giving them something from a brand that I’ve come to trust for quality ingredients.  These are a great bite sized treat for training or just because.

Winter does a number on my hands, and I am always looking for a good lotion to relieve the dryness and aching that comes from the annual bought with dry skin.  I had high hopes for the Eucerin Professional Repair Body Lotion, but it just didn’t do a lot to relieve the dryness and cracking.  I have used Aveno products in the past, and these work the best.  I will be returning to them after less than desirable results from this lotion.  I wouldn’t recommend it if you have a tough case of dry skin from winter.

I’ve been treating my dogs to a sampling of the Natural Balance L.I.D. formula dog food, and this is one of the few others that they had not tried.  Now they can check this one off the list, and like the others (e.g. chicken and sweet potato, potato and duck, etc.), they love this one too.  One of my dogs has a sensitive stomach, but the limited ingredient formula dog foods work well for her.  It is a relief that both dogs eat this line of food eagerly.  I highly recommend the entire line and the Legume and Duck in particular.

The Patriot Threat is the latest installment in Steve Berry's Cotton Malone series.  I've read a few of the other books, but I've missed the last few.  Are you in the same boat or perhaps even a new reader?  No worries!  While Malone, Stephanie Nelle (his sometimes boss at the Magellan Billet), and (fictional) President Danny Daniels were familiar characters from prior novels, there is very little prior knowledge required.  Compared to prior novels, this one is about as close to standalone as I've read in this series.If you are a fan of the series, Berry has his usual mix of historical background and nasty villains.  Malone uses a balance of super spy combat and intellect to make his way through this latest adventure.  As with other novels in this genre, one does have to suspend a certain amount of reality for some of the action.  However, this is fiction, and I don't have a problem with that.  I found it also an eerie coincidence that the main foe is a lunatic from North Korea.  While this book doesn't use absurd comedy like The Interview, it doesn't paint North Korea in a very good light - not that it should be required to do so mind you.  I found the usual transcontinental plot with a dash of history satisfying.  It is a fitting entry into the series, and I look forward to more from Steve Berry and Cotton Malone.Overall:  B

The Zagg Folio Case for 10" Android and Windows tablets is a device that was full of potential that fails on build quality.  I have see others who have Zagg keyboards for their iPads, and I was quite surprised by the cheap feel of this keyboard case.  This is sad because it is otherwise a decent keyboard.  Unlike most universal tablet cases, this one has a design that doesn't put harsh plastic or metal on the corners to hold it in place.  The spring design in the bottom of the tablet compartment does a nice job of holding the tablet in place, but it has a rubber cushion where it touches the edge of the device.  The list of positives gets short from here.  The keys on the keyboard are small and the keyboard is very bouncy.  It is almost like a trampoline for your fingers!  (OK, I'm exaggerating a bit, but I couldn't resist a little hyperbole.)  The keys are also small with an unnatural border on the sides that is almost an inch.  It calls to mind all the negatives from the first generation netbooks, but we are five plus years removed from that time!  The biggest killer, however, on the build is that my tablet and top half of the case wobble when I use the touch screen.  There is no danger for the tablet, but I don't see this holding up to daily use.There are a couple of other positives.  The pairing and setup process is easy.  I was able to follow the instructions without issue the first time.  All of the special keys worked as expected with my Samsung Galaxy Tab S 10.5.  Also, this is a larger 10" tablet, but there is probably a half inch to spare on both sides.In the end, this keyboard case is maddening.  Some features are well designed and executed while others are maddeningly poor.  As an alternative, I would point users to either your tablet brand specific keyboard case (if there is one), or one from Logitech.  For fellow Tab S 10.5 users, the Logitech option is the way to go with.  If you have any questions, please feel free to ask below.

The Three Emperors is the latest installment in the Ethan Gage series, and it is the fourth that I have read.  I won’t bore you with plot summaries, so here’s what you need to know.  While you don’t need to read all six of the previous novels, I would strongly recommend that you at least read The Barbed Crown first.  The previous book ended with a great deal unresolved that lays the groundwork for this story.  This will sound vague, but it is difficult to describe without giving away too much.  The first half or so of The Three Emperors is a bit challenging due to some creative use of literary device on the author’s part.  Trust me, though.  You will have your “aha!” moment, and it will all fall into place.  I struggled to read more than a chapter at a time for the first half because I found it a bit ponderous.  However, it picks up the necessary steam once you reach the Battle of Austerlitz.  If you stick with it that far, you are golden.  The rest is a thrill ride that fans of the series have come to expect, and I felt sufficiently paid back for my investment up to that point.  The ending is quite satisfying, and that is all that I’m going to say at the risk of giving something away.  If you’ve read it, I’d love to hear your thoughts in the comments below.  Enjoy!Overall:  B+

I am having a hard time finding the right hat.  I pulled this one out of the box with high hopes.  It fits around my head, but it was too deep.  When I pull it down, it digs into the tops of my ears.  Now, I have a fairly large head, but this is even too big for me.  Unless you need a hat the size of a toilet, you should probably look elsewhere.

This would have been a sharp looking hat for me, but it was just snug enough that it was uncomfortable.  I ordered an XL, and I am bummed that they don't have a bigger size.  If you are a 'tweener on your size, but the next larger.  You will look sharp, and I will be jealous.  Hopefully I've helped you.  If you can help me with suggestions on where to find a similar hat that is larger, please leave me a comment below.

I had pretty high expectations for Fear the Darkness and the Brigid Quinn character, but this book fell flat for me.  It opens as much more of a literary drama than a mystery/thriller, and perhaps it is just in the wrong category.  I found the story moved excruciatingly slowly and had way too much setup for the second installment in a series.  I know that I am an outlier among the reviewers of this book, but I just found it slow, dull, and boring.  If you are looking for a fast paced mystery/thriller, this is not the book for you.  I would not recommend it unless you are having trouble sleeping.

I hadn’t realized how bad my skillets had gotten until this new set from KitchenAid showed up.  After I got them unpacked, I put them in the dishwasher prior to using them.  They came out exactly as expected with no ill effects, e.g. spotting, etc.  It got better from there when I started using them.  The non-stick coating worked to perfection.  I found omelets challenging in my old skillets, but turning in these was a breeze.  The cheese and other things left behind came loose with warm water.  I did have one concern about the handles, but they did not transfer any noticeable heat.  I’m very happy with these based on my first impressions, and I would definitely recommend them.

The Parrot MiniDrone is a fun little RC ground vehicle.  Parrot made an interesting choice that potential buyers should be aware of.  It does not ship with a remote control, but you must supply your own by way of an iOS or Android device.  I installed the FreeFlight 3 app on my Samsung Galaxy S5, and it provides a rich experience.  In addition to touchscreen controls, I was able to see the drone’s camera output on my phone.  The link between the drone and the phone is through a Wifi network that the drone broadcasts.  I found the range to be about four houses down from mine before I lost the signal and the drone stopped.  The controls worked well turning the drone left or right by 90 or 180 degrees depending on the input from the user.  It can also jump up or complete a long jump.  Battery life is as advertised, and it works indoors on carpet just as well as on concrete outside.  The yard was more than it could conquer, but that was really the only limitation I found.  My dogs had mixed reactions to it.  One chased it while the other one ran away from it.  If you try it with your pets, respect their reaction to it.  It is a cool little toy for kids of all ages.  I definitely recommend it.

American Spirit is a book that profiles a number of small/independent/craft distilleries across the country.  James Rodewald interviewed people from each of the ones included in the book, and he did a great job of providing a unified voice to the collection of stories.  I found it to be of particular interest because it begins with three distillers in my home state.  In addition I learned about new spirit makers from New York, Las Vegas, and Oregon among others.  The debate among distillers is “what counts as a craft spirit?”  Some start with “neutral grain spirit” made by other distillers and use it as the base for their spirit.  Others start from the very beginning with the raw ingredients.  There are no labeling requirements, and some are more transparent than others.  I will be trying some of the whiskies that I’ve discovered in American Spirits.It is also worth noting that this book is visually pleasing as well.  The paper is heavy, and the type and graphics look sophisticated.  It is informative, but it would also make a nice coffee table book.  I recommend it to anyone that is looking to learn more about the craft distilling boom.

Woman with a Gun is the second novel that I’ve read from Phillip Margolin.  It is a murder mystery in the classic sense, but it has an interesting twist.  The story centers on a novelist writing a murder mystery based on the portrait on the cover of the book.  Margolin also wrote is story based on the cover of the book.  This has the potential to be pretentious, but it is actually a great story.  The plot sequencing is a bit different as it starts in 2015 then travels back in time a couple of jumps to set up the actual murder.  The characters such as the would-be novelist Stacy Kim and attorney Jack Booth are very well done.  There were enough twists in the plot that Margolin kept me guessing until he revealed the true killer toward the end.  This phrase gets overused, but I don’t apply it lightly to Woman with a Gun.  It was hard to put down.  I usually take about a week for a novel around 300 pages.  I finished this one in 3 days.  This is a standalone novel, and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys murder mysteries.

Tom’s of Maine lotion is a good product.  It is very thick, but it absorbs quickly, and it worked wonders on my chronically dry hands.  I liked that it didn’t leave my hands greasy.  The only thing I would like different is the scent.  It is surprisingly strong for a lotion that is billed as lightly scented.  I would not want to use it when I would be going out because it is a fairly girly smell  My wife really likes it, but you wouldn’t want to use it before guy’s night.  Other than that, it is great.

The Golden Hour is Todd Moss’ debut novel.  It is an international political thriller that deals in which Dr. Judd Ryker works to reverse a coup d’etat in Mali according to his theory that it must be done within the first 100 hours - the “Golden Hour”.  I enjoyed the book, and it moves quickly for the most part.  The plot is a bit convoluted at times, and there were a couple of points where I had to reread a few pages to sort things out.  I thought that the resolution was well done, and I think that the best thing Moss can do is keep writing.  He has the potential to be a five star author, and I look forward to his future work.

I’ve been eating different bars from Kind for a number of years, and I was curious when I saw their new “Strong and Kind” line of products.  The premise is a higher protein version of what loyal Kind customers have been accustomed to.  The flavor of this particular bar is also a little different.  Whereas most of their prior products had more of a dessert flavor, these are more of a pure salty snack with a spicy kick.  Honey Smoked BBQ tells most of the story, but I’ve already hinted at the rest.  This is a spicy BBQ flavor that the ingredients (which include multiple types of peppers) confirm.  Here’s my shot at giving you a comparison of the flavor.  If you have ever been to Buffalo Wild Wings, the flavor of this bar is close to their Honey BBQ.  It is no sickeningly sweet BBQ.  It packs a little heat/spice.  While they won’t burn your mouth, it may be more than some expect from a product with “honey” in the name.  Overall, the flavor is balanced, and it is a fine higher protein product from a brand that I trust.  I highly recommend the Strong and Kind Honey Smoked BBQ snack bars.

The Dromida Ominus Quadcopter is my first RC copter; therefore, I will give you the novice perspective.  I liked that it comes fully assembled, and it is almost ready to fly.  You do have to charge the battery that goes in the Ominus, but that doesn’t take very long - maybe an hour or so.Once I had everything ready to go, I took the Ominus and the controller out to my driveway/sidewalk.
